DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Vice President Lien Chan formally announced his presidential bid.
The China Times:
Vice President Lien Chan declares candidacy for KMT nomination.
The United Daily News:
Vice President Lien Chan outlines new Taiwan vision while announcing his presidential bid in his hometown of Tainan.
The Liberty Times:
Vice President Lien formally enters presidential race.
The Commons Daily:
The United States announces US$150 million worth of arms sales to Taiwan.
The China Post:
Lien formally announces 2000 bid before Tainan supporters.
The Taiwan News:
China seizes Taiwan ship, accusing it of smuggling.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 1, or the 20th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: British chemist Sir Joseph Priestley announces that he has discovered oxygen.
1778: The first savings bank opens in Hamburg, Germany.
1833: In a momentous move, Britain finally ends its 400-year involvement in slavery.
1834: Robert Morrison, the first English missionary to go to China, and translator of the Bible into Chinese, dies.
1894: War between China and Japan over the question of Korea breaks out. The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed the next year, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea and cede the Liaotung Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1915: The Peking government mints its silver coin, known as "Yuantatou," bearing the likeness of Yuan Shih-kai.
1926: Kwangtung University changes its name to National Sun Yat-sen University with Tai Chuan-hsien as president.
1927: The Chinese communists stage the Nanchang Uprising against the National government.
1928: The Central Broadcasting System is set up in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1941: American volunteer aviators form the "Flying Tigers" with Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as commander. They help China to combat Japanese air superiority in the early stages of World War II.
1943: Lin Sen, chairman of the National government, dies at the age of 76.
1949: The Office of Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang is established in Taipei.
1958: An insurance program providing 180,000 government employees with maternity, illness, injury, disability, or death coverage is put into effect.
1966: The Chinese Communist Party opens a plenum meeting that declares the start of the 10-year Cultural Revolution.
1973: The Economic Planning Council (EPC) of the Executive Yuan is inaugurated. The EPC replaces the Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development.
1974: Prof. Hsia Yuan-yu, a noted zoologist, dies of heart failure in Taipei at the age of 86.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a slight raise in the premium rate of laborers' occupational injury insurance. The rates for thirty-two occupations are raised.
1986: The Ministry of Communications announces a freeze on the number of taxicabs owned by taxicab companies and forbids individual owners from transferring taxicabs to taxicab companies.
1987: The Council of Labor Affairs is formally established under the Executive Yuan.
1989: A foreign currency call loan market is established in Taipei, designed to make the metropolis an international financial center.
1992: The National Unification Council defines "one China" as "one country and two areas separately ruled by two-political entities."
1992: Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, the ROC's highest security institution, is disbanded; and the Coastal Patrol General Headquarters is established under the Ministry of National Defense.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By attending to the cleanliness and purity of his person and the propriety and dignity of his dress, and in every word and act permitting nothing which is contrary to good taste and decency: that is how the ruler puts in order his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF REAFFIRMS US COMMITMENT TO ABIDING BY TRA

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush reaffirmed on Saturday that the United States will continue abiding by the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and showing concern about Taiwan's security.
The US point man on Taiwan issues in the absence of official ties made the statement in his speech to an annual meeting of the World Formosans Association being held in Hawaii.

Bush's reaffirmation of the US commitment to Taiwan won the acclaim of all participants as relations across the Taiwan Strait are at a new low because of ROC President Lee Teng-hui's definition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Bush, who visited Taipei from July 22-26 in an effort to better understand Taiwan's basic stance on cross-strait relations, also stressed in his speech that the United States will adhere to its "one China" policy and maintain neutrality toward cross-strait issues.
Bush further renewed the consistent US call for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resolve their disputes strictly by peaceful means.
In his one-hour speech, titled "Taiwan Look Past, Look Forward," Bush said the most important task for Taiwan today is to work out a comprehensive blueprint for its future development and progress.
In addition to recounting Taiwan's past achievements, Bush made several suggestions for Taiwan's reference in setting the direction for its future development.
First of all, Bush said Taiwan should continue promoting democratic reforms to deepen its achievements in this regard.

Bush then recommended that Taiwan forge rapprochement with mainland China and strengthen engagements with other neighboring Asia-Pacific countries. Despite their conflicting views on some critical sovereign issues, Bush said Taiwan should never cease its efforts to maintain contacts and exchanges with Beijing to ensure peaceful co-existence.

Noting that the long-term US policy toward mainland China is to encourage Beijing to move in a positive, constructive direction, Bush said he believes that Taiwan can provide a good model for the mainland.
"Taiwan's continued march toward democracy and freedom has provided a good model for mainland China which has yet to be democratized," Bush explained.
More than 500 members of the World Formosans Association from Europe, the United States, Canada, Japan and Latin American countries attended the meeting.
Taiwan politicians present at the meeting included Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan and opposition Legislators Lee Ying-yuan and Lee Ching-hsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ASKS ARATS HELP TO FREE TAIWAN SHIP

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) sent a letter to its mainland Chinese counterpart on Saturday, asking it to help ensure the safety of a Taiwan ship and its crew that were forcibly directed to mainland China earlier the same day.

SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow said the information they received showed that the 975-ton Shin Hwa freighter was intercepted by a mainland Chinese military ship while carrying supply materials from the northern Keeling Port to the Republic of China-controlled outlying Matsu Island.

Ship owner Feng Neng-di contacted SEF for help, stressing that Shin Hwa is a civilian freighter, according to Shi, who asked the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to provide quick assistance to investigate the incident and ensure the safety of the ship and its crew members.

Mainland Chinese military guardsmen who boarded the ship accused the Shin Hwa of smuggling and entering mainland China's territorial waters, forcing the ship to go to Mawei Port in Fujian province. Ten crew members, including Captain Kuo Tai-sheng, were aboard.
SEF and the ARATS are semi-official organizations in charge of two-way exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China in the absence of formal contacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO SELL TWO AIRBORNE EARLY WARNING AIRCRAFT TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, July 31 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The US Defense Department on Saturday announced the sale of two E-2T Hawkeye 2000E airborne early warning aircraft and related equipment and services to Taiwan.
The Pentagon said the sale, worth about US$400 million, is consistent with US laws and policies, as expressed in Public Law 96-8.

It stated that this will augment Taiwan's present operational inventory and self-defense capability, adding that it will not affect the basic military balance in the region and will have no adverse impact on US defense readiness.
Just one day earlier, the United States announced the sale of US$150 million worth of spare parts and related equipment for F-16 jet fighters to Taiwan.

In addition to the two E-2T Hawkeye aircraft, the new package also includes two AN-APS-145 radar systems, two T56-A-427 engines, two OE-335/A antenna groups, two Mission Computer Upgrades/Advanced Control Indicator Sets, two Passive Detection System software laboratory upgrades, and spare and replacement parts.
The prime contractor is Northrop Grumman Corp., which will assign two representatives to Taiwan for two years for technical support following the delivery of the aircraft.

The Republic of China Air Force procured four E-2T aircraft from the United States in 1995. One is being repaired in the United States after suffering extensive damage from a forced belly-landing during a night training exercise in March 1997.
An ROC Air Force officer said in Taipei that the sale of the AN/APS-145 radar systems will extend the ROC's airborne early warning time by 10 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORT FOR LIEN SURGES FOLLOWING CANDIDACY: POLL

TEXT.P: Support for Vice President Lien Chan in Taiwan's next presidential election has markedly surged following his Saturday announcement that he would seek the Kuomintang's nomination, the latest survey has found.

According to the poll conducted in the wake of Lien's announcement, some 29.6 percent of respondents said they would vote for Lien in the March 2000 presidential race, ahead of 27.6 percent who said they would support former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong and 17.7 percent who backed Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian.
It was the first time that Lien scored greater public support than Soong among Taiwan residents.

As to the question of which candidate people most wish will be elected Taiwan's next president, around 31.5 percent of the people surveyed revealed that they expected Lien to be elected, while 27.2 percent said they wished Soong would win the election and some 17.8 percent said Chen, according to the results of the survey.
At the same time, 49.6 percent of the public believe that Lien has the best chance of winning the next presidential race, ahead of 20 percent who said Soong and 6.2 percent who said Chen.

It is worth noting that a 75 percent of the people said that the presidential hopefuls should focus their attention on providing the voters with the gist of their campaign and platform, rather than on other things, such as building a charismatic image or launching verbal attacks.

In addition, 46.1 percent agreed with the view that Lien's announcement had marked the beginning of a competition between the ruling Kuomintang and the major opposition DPP, while 39.9 percent disagreed, the survey found.
The telephone survey included 1,091 valid samples and had a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS WIDESPREAD SUPPORT FOR 'STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people support President Lee Teng-hui's definition of relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship," according to a public opinion poll released on Sunday.

The opinion survey was conducted by the Republic of China Public Administration Society from July 29-30 to explore local people's views on American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush's July 22-25 visit to Taipei and on their attitude toward top mainland Chinese envoy Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan this autumn. A total of 1,071 valid replies were collected.

Fifty-four percent of those interviewed said they believe that President Lee's "special state-to-state" theory is aimed at clarifying the status of cross-strait ties and that Lee's declaration is part of the ROC's preparations for the opening of cross-strait political negotiations.
Survey results also show that 80 percent of the respondents agreed to the government stance that the Republic of China has consistently been a sovereign state.

As for Bush's recent Taipei visit, 72 percent said they know that the AIT chief visited Taiwan earlier this month in an effort to prevent possible escalation of cross-strait tension in view of Beijing's furious reaction to Lee's "special state-to-state" definition.
According to the poll, 62 percent of those who knew of Bush's trip said they believe that Bush's visit was helpful to ease cross-strait tension.

Meanwhile, 51 percent of them said they were satisfied with senior ROC official's general performance during Bush's Taipei visit. However, 30 percent said they felt that ROC officials were not tough enough in defending the country's basic stance.
Turning to issues related to Wang's much-anticipated Taiwan visit, 78 percent said they still welcome Wang's visit in the wake of the recent cross-strait row over the "special state-to-state" theory.

Eighty-seven percent said they hope Wang will take advantage of his Taiwan trip to better understand Taiwan's democratization and the differences between the two sides in lifestyles and stances on certain sensitive political issues.
Moreover, 88 percent said if Wang can honor his promise to visit Taiwan as scheduled, they hope Wang will travel extensively around the island and will try to understand Taiwan people's aspirations.
Poll results also show that 55 percent said they feel Beijing leaders should let Wang visit Taiwan to signify their sincerity to promote cross-strait dialogue and exchanges.

In addition, 75 percent said they disagree with Beijing's claim that the "special state-to-state" theory has violated the so-called "one China" policy and eroded the very basis for cross-strait engagements.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER OFFICIAL HAPPY ABOUT INVESTMENT IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: An official of the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) said Saturday that Australia is the first country where his company has initially scored a successful mining joint venture.

In an exclusive interview with CNA, Edward Chen, director of Taipower's Fuel Department, said "The coal mining joint venture at the Hunter Valley in New South Wales is our first success story since we suffered our first failure in Canada in the early 1970s."
"We are thrilled by the initial production performance of the mine. It is a very good mine because it has high productivity," he said.

The new company, Bengalla Mining Company Pty. Ltd., is a joint venture among companies of the United States, Australia, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan. The US investor is Peabody Group. Australia is represented by Wesfarmers Limited. Both companies have a stake of 37 percent. Taipower has a 10-percent stake in the joint venture.

The venture was formed in 1990. The mine, which became operational recently, is expected to produce 2 million tons of coal in the first 12 months of operation. It is expected to reach the capacity of 6 million tons per year. The initial mining lease grant will expire in 2017. (by Edward Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN ATTENDS BUDDHIST GATHERING IN NANTOU
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan, who has announced his decision to run for president next spring, on Sunday stressed the importance of "spiritual reform."
Lien made the remark while attending a Buddhist gathering at the famous Chungtai Buddhist Temple in Puli, Nantou County.
About 10,000 Buddhist disciples from around the island attended the gathering, presided over by the venerable Master Weichueh. Lien was invited to address the gathering.
"Our society has become abundant, but the people's minds remain poor," and that was why President Lee Teng-hui initiated a campaign for "spiritual reform," he said.
Lien praised Master Weichueh for his outstanding contribution to the propagation of Buddhist teaching, as witnessed by the establishment of about 60 meditation houses throughout the island.
He urged the people to give up their greed and stinginess and to replace them with compassion and a willingness to make a contribution.

Although Lien avoided mentioning his decision to run for president, many attendants shouted "Wish you success" when he arrived at the temple, accompanied by Premier Vincent Siew and Chairman P.K. Chiang of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
Lien is expected to be formally nominated by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) as the party's candidate for next March's presidential election.

Three other candidates have also announced their decision to join the presidential race. They are former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and two independents: KMT member and former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong and former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW MAY VISIT KOSOVO DURING MACEDONIA TRIP

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Sunday that he may visit Kosovo during his upcoming visit to Skopje, capital of Macedonia, which set up formal diplomatic ties with Taipei in January.

Although the major purpose of his trip to Macedonia is to strengthen relations between the two countries, Siew said that he may also visit Kosovo to gain a firsthand understanding of the implementation of a US$300 million humanitarian package contributed by the Republic of China to the war-torn Yugoslav province.
The ROC government is determined to further boost ties with European countries as part of its efforts to promote its policy of pragmatic diplomacy, the premier noted.
Expressing his appreciation for the support the private sector has extended to the government, Siew said he hopes that Macedonia will become a springboard for Taiwan business in Europe.
Siew made the remarks at a rally of Vice President Lien Chan's supporters at a temple in central Nantou County prior to his departure for the southeast European state on Sunday night.
With Siew's attendance at the activity, speculation is mounting that the premier may serve as Lien's vice presidential running mate in the election slated for March 2000.
Reluctant to comment, the premier said only that he is not in the position to comment on the issue at present.
Lien officially announced his bid to seek the ruling Kuomintang's nomination for Taiwan's next presidential race on Saturday.

Meanwhile, officials with the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei, a member of Siew's delegation to Macedonia, will sign an agricultural cooperation agreement with his Macedonian counterpart while there.

The cross-the-board cooperative venture drafted by the COA, according to the officials, is designed to help Macedonia advance into the 21st century by sharing with it Taiwan's successful agricultural development.

Although the significance of the agricultural sector is fading in Taiwan, they pointed out that Taiwan's successful agricultural development will serve as the best model for countries like Macedonia, which is rich in natural resources.
Sugar, bananas and canned food were once the staple of Taiwan's exports in its early stages of economic progress, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FREIGHTER, CREWMEN STILL BEING DETAINED IN FUJIAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Shin Hwa freighter and the 15 crewmen aboard were still being detained in Fujian province as of Sunday night after being forced to sail to Fujian's Mawei Port after mainland authorities charged the ship was engaging in "tax evasion."
Legislator Tsao Erh-chung has been in Fujian in an effort to meet with the crewmen and to seek their early release. But as of Sunday evening, he had not received permission to meet them.

There have been unconfirmed reports that the Shin Hwa was detained in waters near the Republic of China-controlled island of Matsu after it was caught delivering half-completed electronic products to a mainland Chinese fishing boat.
That kind of act is said to constitute tax evasion in mainland China.
The 15 crewmen aboard the Taiwan freighter are still being detained by mainland Chinese customs authorities for continued investigation. The mainland Chinese fishing boat is still at large.

Meanwhile, Taipei's Justice Ministry reiterated on Sunday that mainland China's detention of the Shin Hwa freighter would have an unfavorable effect on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
It urged mainland China to release the freighter and crewmen as early as possible, saying Taiwan is responsible for handing this incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO ANNOUNCE EXPLANATORY NOTE ON SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE RELATIONS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Sunday afternoon was scheduled to issue a position paper on the Republic of China's stance on the "special state-to-state relations" announcement by President Lee Teng-hui last month.

The position paper is to make clear that Taiwan views relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as special state-to-state relations. This, however, is not an attempt by Taiwan to seek independence, and Taiwan feels the two sides should conduct negotiations on an equal basis to jointly pursue the eventual unification of a democratic and free China.

The paper will include transcripts of talks dated from July 9 by President Lee and his interview with Deutsche Welle radio. It will also contain an interpretation of the special state-to-state policy by MAC Chairman Su Chi and a statement made by Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu in response to mainland Chinese aggression resulting from the "special state-to-state relations" announcement.

The position paper will focus on the background that led to the "special relations" between the two sides and articulate the reason that President Lee specifically pointed out that cross-strait relations constitute "at least a special state-to-state relationship." The president's remarks were made in response to a German reporter's inquiry about the Beijing government viewing Taiwan as a renegade province.
The president's response is meant to lay a foundation of parity between the two sides for elevating the level of dialogue and to facilitate the mechanisms of democracy and peace.

The paper will point out that in the five decades since the People's Republic of China was established in 1949, China has been divided into two parts across the Taiwan Strait and ruled separately by two sovereign states. This has naturally resulted in a special relationship between the two sides across the strait.

The paper will explain that President Lee's "special state-to-state relationship" remarks have several meanings. First, the shared cultural and ethnic origins have resulted in a unique sense of affection between the two sides.

Second, the intensification of cross-strait civil and commercial exchanges is unparalleled when compared with other divided countries past or present. Third, and most importantly, both sides should have the common will to pursue a unified China in the future by engaging in negotiations on the basis of parity.

To tackle the highly political issues that are likely to be touched by Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits Chairman Wang Daohan during his autumn visit to Taiwan, it is essential for Taiwan to clearly explain the relations between the two sides. Hence, the "special state-to-state relationships" is a defensive and strategic way for Taiwan to state its position.

What we see as "one China" is something for the future since China at the present is divided and ruled separately by two equal sovereign states in existence at the same time, the paper will point out and it will add that the fact that each side presents a different interpretation of its position in consultations is simply part of the process of seeking common ground despite differences.

This paper will be issued in Chinese and translated into other languages by the Government Information Office for distribution to Taiwan's foreign representatives abroad as means of expounding on Taiwan's "special state-to-state relationship" stance.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL GROUP FORMED TO MARK 20TH ANNIVERSARY OF 'MAGAZINE' INCIDENT

TEXT.P: A supra-party group was formed on Sunday to organize commemorative activities to mark the 20th anniversary of the Formosa Magazine Incident.
The idea of forming such a group was broached by Legislator Shih Ming-teh, also a former chairman of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Shih, a political dissident-turned-politician who was once jailed for some 10 years for the Formosa Magazine Incident, said the incident provided a historical lesson 20 years ago.

"Now that Taiwan has developed into a full-fledged democracy, we should make the incident a 'tonic or nourishment' of the new era," Shih said, adding that he hopes Taiwan will move toward an era of "great reconciliation" and that local society will become even more tolerant of different political views.
Shih went on to say that he hopes the 1979 Formosa Magazine Incident will become a "positive memory" and an "important national asset" in Taiwan's history.

The incident refers to an event in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in December 1979 which was originally designed to mark the inauguration of the political magazine but later turned into an anti-government demonstration. At that time, Taiwan was still under martial law and political assembly or demonstration was taboo.
More than 10 key organizers of the event, including Shih and several other noted politicians in the DPP, were arrested and sentenced to jail terms.

The incident, however, inspired ever-mounting calls for Taiwan's democratic reforms and liberalization. In the late 1980s, the Republic of China government finally lifted martial law and launched sweeping political, economic and social reforms, laying a foundation for Taiwan's transformation from an authoritarian rule into a mature democracy over the past decade.

Nearly all of those who were jailed for the Formosa Magazine Incident and many lawyers who defended for those involved in the incident later emerged as influential figures in the opposition camp and have even played an important role in local politics.

Many political heavyweights from major local political parties, senior media executives, writers and scholars attended Sunday's meeting marking the formation of the organizing committee for commemorating the 20th anniversary of the inspiring incident.

Those present on the occasion included Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, China Times Press Group Chairman Yu Chi-chung, former New Party Legislator Yok Mu-ming and Po Yang, a noted writer who was also once jailed for political dissidence.

Shih said the commemorative activities will include an exhibition of photos and documents featuring the incident, a large-scale evening party, production of documentary films and publication of books detailing the incident and its implications.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE KOALAS ADAPT THEMSELVES WELL TO NEW TAIPEI HOME

TEXT.P: Two highly treasurable Australian koala bears have adapted themselves well to their new home at the Taipei City Zoo on their first night in Taiwan, zoo officials reported on Sunday.
The two male koala bears, donated by Australia to the Taipei City Zoo, arrived in Taipei Saturday evening after a long flight.
"The two koalas, named Hellai and Patrick, arrived in good shape, despite the long journey," said a zoo official.
The two-year-old koala bears were sent into a 100-ping exhibition room shortly after their arrival at the zoo at around 9 p.m. One ping equals 36 square feet.

The room is well-appointed. It has an advanced air conditioner and many other amenities to ensure a comfortable living environment for the two koalas, which rank among the endangered species needing special protection.

The Taipei City Zoo has planted 6,000 eucalyptus trees, the staple food for koalas. Zoo officials said the two koalas have eaten some Taiwan-grown eucalyptus leaves Saturday evening. "We believe that their eating amount will increase after they further adapt themselves to living conditions at their new home," an official said.

Many local schoolchildren rushed to the Taipei zoo Sunday in hopes of having a glimpse of the zoo's new guests. They were disappointed, however, as the two koalas won't be publicly displayed until mid-August.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUNGONG PRACTITIONERS PROTEST IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Some 200 practitioners of Falungong staged a peaceful demonstration before the Hong Kong branch of the Xinhua News Agency Sunday morning in protest against mainland Chinese crackdown on the spiritual sect and its founder Li Hongzhi.

The mainland Chinese government recently outlawed the sect, issued a warrant for the arrest of Li, detained members of the sect, and seized publications, audio and video tapes, and other materials produced by the Falungong organization in a nation-wide crackdown.
A spokesman for the protesters said that they did not understand why the mainland Chinese government wanted to crack down on the sect and arrest its founder Li. Falungong is non-political, he said.
The demonstrators dispersed peacefully at noon after a representative read a 30-page statement in front of the official news agency of mainland China.

The Falungong organization, which claims to have 100 million followers in mainland China, was outlawed on July 22. More than 10,000 members of the spiritual sect surrounded the Zhongnanhai leadership compound in central Beijing in late April in an enormous demonstration, which shocked Beijing leaders.
The Hong Kong government has said it would not crack down on the sect, if they do not violate the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Premier Vincent Siew left for Macedonia for official visit.
The China Times:
The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued new position paper on 'state-to-state' theory, urging Beijing to accept the principle that each side of the Taiwan Strait should have its own definition of 'one China'.
The United Daily News:
MAC issued position paper calling for 'parity, peace and win-win' in cross-Taiwan Strait ties.
The Liberty Times:
The domestic administrative districts will be re-demarcated.
The Commons Daily:
Cross-party group formed to remember 'Formosa Magazine Incident'.
The China Post:
MAC issues new position paper on 'state-to-state.'
The Taiwan News:
MAC tries again on 'state-to-state.'

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES TO PROBE INFILTRATION BY MAINLAND GANGSTERS

TEXT.P: In light of reported infiltration by mainland Chinese gangsters into Taiwan's criminal underground to affect Taiwan's next presidential election, Justice Minister Yeh Chin-fong vowed on Monday to probe all such rumors.

Responding to reporters' questions about local press reports that mainland China is planning to send gang members to Taiwan to disrupt the island's March 2000 presidential race, Yeh said she will ask investigative authorities to probe the reports.

Citing a recent report carried out by the Investigation Bureau under the Justice Ministry, local newspapers have reported that mainland Chinese intelligence agents might have gained a control in Taiwan's gang syndicates and sent mainland Chinese gangsters to the island. Meanwhile, gangsters from Hong Kong and Macau have also expanded into Taiwan at the same time.

In a bid to ensure public order and the personal safety of all candidates, the National Security Bureau has already set up a task force -- Chingtai -- to take charge of investigating all illegal activities in the lead-up to the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'STATE-TO-STATE' REMARKS PROMPTED BY US PRESSURE: REPORT

TEXT.P: The Washington Post said Sunday that the United States has played a role in pushing President Lee Teng-hui "to roil the waters in the Taiwan Straits," because since March US officials have pressured Taiwan to start concluding "interim agreements" with mainland China on issues leading toward reunification.

Post correspondent John Pamfret reported from Taipei that President Lee's motivations for the "special state-to-state" relationship announcement are complex. For one, it is increasingly clear that "the president has no interest in uniting with China -- even in the distant future."

C.V. Chen, who worked closely with Lee managing relations with mainland China from 1990 to 1992, told Pamfret that Beijing, by its diplomatic pressure, gave Lee the excuse he needed to sell the "special state-to-state" concept to Taiwan's people.
"China should have been more generous," Chen was quoted as saying. "They could have offered us a lot more diplomatic space without jeopardizing their position, but they didn't."

Another factor for Lee is the upcoming elections, according to the report. Next March, Taiwan will directly elect its president for only the second time. So far, the campaign has been going badly for Lee's man, Vice President Lien Chan.

The best way to hurt Lien's challengers, independent presidential candidate James Soong and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian, analysts said, is for Lee to create a crisis with mainland China, prompting people to opt for continuity with Lien. So far, however, it is not clear whether Lien is getting any boost from the current tensions.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRADLEY: US COMMITTED TO HELP DEFEND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: As things now stand, the United States is committed to help defend Taiwan against a mainland Chinese invasion, said Democratic presidential hopeful Bill Bradley on Sunday, although he prefaced his remark by saying he did not want to answer a hypothetical question.

But the former New Jersey senator also said in an interview with NBC's news program "Meet The Press" that if Beijing invaded Taiwan, Bill Bradley, as US president, "would have stepped back a few moves before that and been very clear that the United States should say to the Taiwanese government that if they take steps toward independence, that they cannot count on us for any help."

At the same time, Bradley added, "it should be clear to the People's Republic that if, in the absence of those steps toward independence, they take actions that would be of a military nature toward Taiwan, that we would be there (to help defend Taiwan)."

Bradley said he regretted what President Lee Teng-hui said a few weeks ago about the "special state-to-state relationship" across the Taiwan Strait. "The one nation, one China, is an important policy to be reaffirmed. It's a long -- you have to have a long view here, and I think if we did, that we wouldn't have this problem (of the war of words between Beijing and Taipei."

"I think we should have been clear in advance to make sure that he (President Lee) knows that this is a risk for him to take any step toward independence. At the same time, the People's Republic, the people there can't be surprised or outraged by talk of a democracy," said the former senator. "So there's got to be a meeting of the minds on both sides there in order to prevent this situation from becoming highly volatile and perhaps inflammatory."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING FACES A SCORE OF VEXING PROBLEMS: REPORT

TEXT.P: How the Chinese Communist Party confronts a score of vexing issues, ranging from its economy to its dispute with Taiwan, will determine whether social and political stability can continue in mainland China, according to the latest issue of US News and World Report.

Last week, the mainland Chinese Navy conducted exercises near Taiwanese waters, and Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui repeated his stance that mainland China and Taiwan should deal with each other as equal "states."
The reaction of Japan and the United States to North Korea's missile development program is also creating an environment that Beijing finds increasingly unfriendly, added the report.

Mainland China has blasted revisions to the US-Japan defense agreements that will allow close cooperation, and it is also upset that the United States and Japan are set to embark on joint research for theater missile defense, in part because it fears the technology may find its way to Taiwan.

Against this background of frustration and rising tension, there were at least a few signs that US-mainland Chinese relations were recovering from the depths after the NATO bombing of the mainland Chinese Embassy in Belgrade on May 7, according to the magazine.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN SEED MONEY BLOOMS IN TIBET: CBC

TEXT.P: In an age when international aid is spoken of in billions of dollars, it is remarkable to find an aid program that is a proven success that only costs Canadian taxpayers C$11,000 (US$7,400).
The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) reported Sunday that the success story is a women's weaving factory in an isolated part of Tibet.
In a dispatch from Shigatse, Tibet, the CBC said with just C$11,000 in start-up money given to them eight years ago, the women set up their factory and turned it into a thriving business.
"In fact they're so successful they've even branched out into making slippers and boots and the traditional Tibetan brew, barley wine," it added.
The factory has brought jobs to a depressed area. It has also unleashed an entrepreneurial spirit in the Tibetan women.
The CBC quoted the Tibetans as saying that with a little more Canadian monetary help they will be able to expand, improve product quality and train more staff.
The report did not estimate how big the Tibetan business is that is owned by the women who started with the Canadian seed money.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S SEIZURE OF TAIWAN FREIGHTER REPORTED IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Canada's national broadcaster reported that mainland China had seized a Taiwanese freighter carrying supplies to the military outpost of Matsu Island on Saturday.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) said the mainland Chinese towed the freighter and its crew of 10 to the nearby port of Mawei.
The seizure near the Taiwanese-held island came as tensions are high between mainland China and Taiwan because of remarks made this month by Taiwanese President Lee Teng-hui, the CBC noted.
It said Lee infuriated Beijing by saying Taiwan should have "special state-to-state" relations with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 2, or the 21st day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in the New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a 17-strong French fleet in the Mediterranean.
1849: Muhammad Ali Pasha, the Egyptian ruler, dies in Alexandria at the age of 80, a year after retiring from office.
1918: British, French and US troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1932: Peter O'Toole, Irish actor, most famous for his role in "Lawrence of Arabia," for which he won an Oscar nomination, is born.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese attack.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., US Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Postdam Conference, the final allied summit of World War II, ends.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington D.C., opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the navy ship Maddox in the Tonkin Gulf.
1980: A right-wing Italian terror group bombs the Bologna rail station in northern Italy, killing 84 people and injuring some 200 others.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of an illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to Aug. 4 ROC-US trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of its capital, Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and architect of the Fifth Republic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA STRIPPED OF PAN AM GAMES GOLD DUE TO DRUG USE

TEXT.P: The Pan Am Games Sports Organization (PAGSO) has withdrawn the gold medal given to the Canadian in-line hockey team after the team's goalkeeper Steve Vezina tested positive for a banned substance.

The head of the organization, Mario Vasquez Rana, announced Sunday that the gold now goes to the American team, the silver to Argentina and the bronze to Brazil. Canada won the medal last Tuesday in a 7-6 game against the United States.

Rana said Vezina's positive drug test had been confirmed in two separate tests. Games officials confirmed the drugs were performance- enhancing substances: pseudo-ephedrine, ephedrine and Nandrolone, an anabolic steroid.
Vezina, 23, a roller hockey player for the Buffalo Wings, was the only Canadian in-line hockey player to be tested after Tuesday's game. The testing is done by draw.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-FALUN GONG CAMPAIGN COMPARED TO CULTURAL REVOLUTION

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese leadership's campaign against the Falun Gong faith-healing movement has reached a manic pitch that is being compared to cultural revolution campaigns in 1967-76, according to The Australian Financial Review on Monday.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the report said the mainland Chinese media campaign against the Falun Gong organization has been relentless with TV stations constantly replaying a 90-minute documentary on the sect leader Li Hongzhi, who is now a US resident.
US authorities have received notice through Interpol of mainland China's request for Li's detention. But Washington and Beijing have no extradition treaty, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FM DENIES RIFT WITH US OVER UN PEACEKEEPING FORCE

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer denied that Australia had rejected overtures from the United States that Canberra play a leading role in the UN peacekeeping force in East Timor.

The Sydney Morning Herald and The Australian on Monday quoted Downer as saying that Australia would play a leading role in any UN peacekeeping force in East Timor, but only if a "yes" vote for independence was ratified by Indonesia's People's Consultative Assembly.
The Australian-led UN force is expected to include US Marines, to be ready for deployment in East Timor immediately after or even before the autonomy-or-independence ballot at the end of this month.
Downer said there had been discussions about contingencies between Australian and US officials, but denied there was any "stand-off" between his departmental secretary and a US deputy secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP VOICES CONCERN ABOUT ISLAND LANDING PLAN TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to Japan Chuang Ming-yao has expressed his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.

During a July 30 visit with Toshio Goto, the head of the Interchange Association, which handles Japan's unofficial ties with Taiwan, Chuang voiced his deep concern about the matter and said the Republic of China government will closely monitor subsequent developments.
Chuang, the ROC's de-factor ambassador to Japan, reiterated Taipei's four basic stances to Goto:
-- the Tiaoyutai Islands are ROC territory;
-- sovereignty disputes over the islands should be resolved peacefully through negotiations;
-- Japan should conduct separate negotiations with Taiwan; and
-- the fishing rights of Taiwan fishermen operating in that area should be fully protected before the issue is resolved.

Chuang's statement came after the media reported last week that a group of Japanese lawmakers had decided to travel to the disputed islands to raise the Japanese flag there in late August or early September, a move that ROC officials said would constitute an apparent violation of Taipei's territorial sovereignty.
The Tiaoyutai Islands, known in Japanese as the Senkakus, which lie to the northeast of Taiwan, are also claimed by Tokyo and Beijing.
The disputed islands have long been a traditional fishing ground for fisherman from northern Taiwan counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW WILL VISIT PANAMA AFTER RETURNING FROM MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew will visit Panama at the end of this month to attend president-elect Mireya Moscoso's inauguration on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui after returning from his current trip to Macedonia on Aug. 9, officials said Sunday.

High-level officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) revealed that Lee has appointed the premier to lead a delegation to visit the Central American nation to attend Moscoso's inauguration on Sept. 1.
Siew will be leaving for Panama after attending the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT) National Congress meeting, a MOFA spokesman said.
The premier will visit Panama via New York City, he said, adding that the purpose of his mission is very simple and that Siew will not be visiting any other countries during his trip.
He will then return immediately to Taipei to attend a summit conference between the Republic of China and the leaders of its Central American allies at the beginning of September, he said.

Siew left for Macedonia, the ROC's second ally in Europe, Sunday evening to strengthen relations between the two countries and to gain a firsthand understanding of the implementation of the US$300 million aid package to the warn-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
This is the first visit by a high-level ROC delegation to the Balkans since the president announced his plans for a humanitarian aid package for Kosovo in June.

Members of the group accompanying Siew include Foreign Minister Jason Hu; Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang; Lin Cheng-chih, chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs; Director-General of the Department of Health Chan Chi-shean; Council of Agriculture Chairman Peng Tso-kwei; Chairman Wea Chi-lin of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission; and Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPINION POLL SHOWS LIEN'S SUPPORT RATE OVER 30 PERCENT: CHANG

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan is the only person who can represent the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), and according to the party's own public surveys, Lien has already received a support rate of over 30 percent, KMT Secretary-General John Chang said Monday.
Opinion polls released over the weekend revealed that Lien's support rate has been on a marked rise since he formally announced his presidential candidacy on Saturday.

When answering reporters' questions Monday morning, Chang said that the surge in the vice president's public support rate has rallied the party's overall morale to a greater degree than expected. He added that this is a meaningful "index" for the party.

In addition, survey results revealed that Lien is "the only person who can symbolize the KMT," Chang said, adding that the party will continue its "steady and sure" campaign tactics, assuming a "humble but firm" low-profile in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Manila urged to clarify its unilateral decision to terminate aviation pact with Taiwan.
The China Times:
The ROC does not rule out the possibility of cutting direct air links with the Philippines ahead of schedule set by Manila.
The United Daily News:
The ROC plans to impose trade sanctions in protest of Manila's unilateral termination of aviation pact.
The Liberty Times:
Taiwan may retaliate against Manila's termination of air agreement.
The Commons Daily:
Taiwan may freeze import of Filipino workers.
The China Post:
500 feared dead in Indian train disaster.
The Taiwan News:
China tests a new missile.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD CLARIFY ITS TAIWAN POLICY: ARTICLE

TEXT.P: The United States must stop parroting Beijing's "one China" claim and make clear that whether Taiwan politically rejoins mainland China is a decision for the people of Taiwan to make, continue to sell Taiwan defensive weapons and under no circumstances the United States will become involved militarily in an armed conflict across the Taiwan Straits, according to an American expert.

Ted G. Carpenter, vice president for defense and foreign policy studies at the Washington-based Cato Institute, wrote Monday in an Op-Ed article titled "Washington's Incoherent Policy on Taiwan" that the new Taiwan crisis triggered by President Lee Teng-hui's apparent abandonment of the "one China" principle and his insistence that Taipei-Beijing relations are to be conducted on a "state-to-state" basis showed that "US policy toward China is in a dangerous state of disarray."

There is a dangerous contradiction at the heart of the Clinton administration's policy. Even as President Clinton parrots Beijing's view that Taiwan has no right to statehood (or even limited international recognition), the president implies that the United States would come to Taiwan's rescue if the island were attacked. "The sending of such mixed signals virtually invites trouble," said Carpenter.

The expert continued that the unsettling reality is that "neither the administration nor the hard-line opposition seems capable of articulating a China policy that is simultaneously clear, realistic and prudent."

The United States should seek to maintain decent relations with the People's Republic of China, Carpenter said, "but US officials must stop giving undue deference to Beijing's 'one China' claims. Instead, Washington needs to articulate a new policy that includes the following elements:
1) The United States takes no position on the issue of whether there is one China, two Chinas, or one China - one Taiwan;
3) The United States will continue to sell Taiwan defensive weapons as outlined in the Taiwan Relations Act; and
4) Under no circumstances will the United States become involved militarily if an armed conflict breaks out between the PRC and Taiwanese forces.

Carpenter concluded that "Such a policy would affirm the right of the Taiwanese people to determine their own political destiny. At the same time, it would put Taipei on notice that, if it rejects the 'one China' principle and proceeds down the path toward separatism and full independence, it must do so at its own risk."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENTISTS CALL FOR PROMPT RATIFICATION OF CTBT

TEXT.P: Nine renowned American scientists and former intelligence and military officials have sent a letter to all 100 US senators calling for prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.

The signers of the letter include Dr. Hans Bethe, Nobel laureate and head of the Manhattan Project's theoretical division; Dr. Herbert York, founding director of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory; Adm. Stansfield Turner, former director of the Central Intelligence Agency; and Adm. Elmo Zumwalt, former chief of Naval Operations, Joint Chiefs of Staff.

They wrote that "There is one essential step -- which only the Senate can take -- which would greatly help to protect the United States against the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets: ratification of the CTBT."

The Senate responded quickly last month to reports of Chinese espionage by voting to reorganize the Department of Energy to create a semi-autonomous Nuclear Administration Agency with improved security on nuclear weapons secrets. "But preventing future losses of sensitive information is not enough, Congress must also seek to prevent information that has already been lost from damaging US and global security," stressed the letter.

These nuclear weapons and national security experts noted that ratification of the CTBT is a key part of the solution to this problem. "With the CTBT in force and its verification system fully operational, China and other nations would be unable to conduct clandestine nuclear tests or even the triggers for smaller and lighter thermonuclear warheads for use on long-range ballistic missiles," they added. "This is the central security value of the CTBT, and one that the Senate cannot afford to ignore."

President Bill Clinton signed the international treaty banning nuclear weapons test explosions in 1996 and submitted it to the Senate for ratification in September 1997. But the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, chaired by Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC) who firmly opposed to the CTBT, has not yet held a hearing on the treaty.

So far, a total of 153 nations, including Russia and the People's Republic of China, have signed the CTBT, but it must be ratified by 44 specific nations, including the United States, in order for the treaty to enter into force.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN EXPERT WEIGHS IN FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The United States should start treating Taiwan as a state under a "real partners" doctrine to signal to Beijing and every other government what kind of nation Washington rewards with friendship, according to an American expert specializing in Asian affairs.

Mark P. Lagon, Council on Foreign Relations fellow at the Project for New American Century, wrote in the latest issue of "National Review" monthly magazine that Taiwan politics aside, President Lee Teng-hui's recent suggestion that cross-strait dialogue should be seen as "state-to-state" negotiation shows "Taipei may have wished to claim statehood before the military balance between Taiwan and China got any worse."
The PRC is intense about acquiring high-tech weapons, a larger missile arsenal and the means for air superiority -- all making the seizure of Taiwan feasible in about ten years, he said.

Lagon stated in the article titled "Taiwan Gets Bold" that to his credit, "Lee realizes that it will take boldness to lay the groundwork for the only permissible term of reunification: the democratization of the mainland."

What should the United States do? First, he wrote, "stop criticizing Taiwan for being provocative. Doing so only prolongs the current crisis by giving Beijing the sense that we do not back Taiwan, and it undermines efforts to deter China from taking military action against the island."

Second, find tangible ways to give Taiwan the help and respect it deserves. "Putting ceilings on levels of consultation with a democracy is simply wrong. Higher-level contacts, arms sales, and theater-missile-defense cooperation will likely deter a PRC attempt at reunification by force," he said.

Lagon noted that these steps would indicate that the United States will help Taiwan should the island be attacked. And these are precisely the steps prescribed by the Helms-Torricelli "Taiwan Security Enhancement Act" under consideration in Congress.

Third, give Taiwan "face" internationally. For instance, Taiwan has met the standards for joining the World Trade Organization as a customs territory. But Beijing insists that the PRC be admitted first, a position that Hong Kong, as a separate customs territory in the WTO, is assisting by holding up the last necessary accord with Taiwan.

Open and prosperous enough to import more than one and a half times as many US goods as the mainland does, "Taiwan is a model for the market reforms that China will need before it can legitimately enter the WTO," he pointed out.

Taiwan also offers the best model for mainland China's political evolution -- "neither a Singapore that squelches free speech in the name of 'Asian values' nor a Hong Kong that (as it has recently) behaves as a lackey," added the expert.

Last, in order to encourage the democratic evolution of mainland China and to bolster regional stability in the meantime, the United States should upgrade cooperation with real partners in the region -- namely, the democracies: Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, and perhaps India.

In lieu of President Bill Clinton's imprudent pursuit of a "strategic partnership" with the PRC, "a 'real partners' doctrine would signal to Beijing, and every other government, what kind of nation the United States rewards with friendship. And a very good place to start would be to treat Taiwan -- an admirably assertive democracy with 22 million citizens -- as a state," concluded Lagon.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MORE CUBANS DEFECT FROM PAN AM GAMES

TEXT.P: Three more Cuban athletes at the Pan Am Games are seeking asylum in Canada, bringing the total to seven, police said Monday.
The Games opened July 23 and will run 17 days.

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police won't identify the latest three defectors. One is reported to be a member of the men's relay track team, another a member of the men's soccer team, and the third a female gymnast.
Pan Am Games officials won't comment on the defections, because they say such cases don't affect the games directly.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN INTERESTED IN AUSTRALIA'S AGED CARE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Japan, faced by its rapid aging population, is interested in Australia's approach to aged care and the provision of aged care services by its companies and organizations, according to the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday.

In a dispatch from Tokyo, the daily quoted Australia's Minister for Aged Care Bronwyn Bishop as saying that her Japanese counterparts were particularly interested in private-sector provision of services in aged care.

By 2010, nearly a quarter of Japan's population is expected to be over 65 years old, mainly because its life expectancy is 76.4 years for men and 82.9 for women, the highest in the world, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA LOBBYING HARD TO JOIN G-X

TEXT.P: Australia is lobbying very hard in its bid to join a new international organization which would become the successor to the Willard Group or G22, the ad hoc forum that played a large role in drawing up reforms to the world financial system after the Asian crisis.

In a dispatch from Washington, the Australian Financial Review reported that the new body now only known as G-X will be selected by the Group of Seven industrialized countries and is expected to include emerging market countries and those that were affected by the financial crisis which later spread to Brazil and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR PARTY BACKS CHINESE MIGRANT VIE FOR SYDNEY MAYORALTY

TEXT.P: Mainstream Australian Labor Party has appointed Robert Ho compete for the mayoralty of Sydney, Australia's biggest city, in an election slated in early September.
Ho, husband of Helen Sham-Ho, an independent member of the New South Wales's Upper House, will vie against the incumbent Lord Mayor Frank Sartor and another independent competitor.

Ho, who migrated to Australia from Hong Kong over two decades ago, has not only received the support from the Labor Party, but also from architects, property owners and businesses for the mayoralty of Sydney.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANGTZE FLOODS MEAN MISERY FOR POOR FARMERS

TEXT.P: Flooding along the Yangtze River is an annual hazard, which claims thousands of lives and leaves millions homeless, results in misery for Chinese farmers and money for corrupt officials, the Australian reported on Tuesday.

In a dispatch from Wuhan, the daily reported that one year after central China's worst flooding in 40 years, Chinese living along the Yangtze basin remain vulnerable to breaches in river banks despite a long and expensive campaign. Last year, about 4,100 people died and million others were affected by the flooding, the daily reported.
This year, Hubei, Anhui and Hunan provinces have declared flood alerts after more than 400 people have been killed and 60 million others affected, the daily reported.

Premier Zhu Rongji has warned Communist Party officials against skimming money for flood fighting and flood relief. He was particularly scathing of shoddy projects he calls "tofu dregs" -- a term that seems to be on everyone's lips.

"Bridges and dikes have been built that should be reinforced with steel, but they're reinforced with bamboo because that's all that could be bought after the officials had their fill of food and drink," an unidentified man told the daily.
"They've taken the money and run off to America or Thailand or Singapore and nothing here gets any better," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, LIKE AUSTRALIA, CAN CLAIM INDEPENDENCE: ARTICLE

TEXT.P: Like Australia, the United States and Canada, Taiwan is a settler society that has a claim to independence, according to a veteran Australian writer.

In an article headlined: "Taiwan, Like Australia, Has a Claim to Independence," published by the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, Brian Toohey said the Australian republican movement should recognize a soul mate in Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui because both want essentially the same thing.

He said Taiwan is a prosperous, democratic country whose people show little sign of wanting to be ruled by a Communist Party government on the mainland. They clearly prefer that their island should continue to function as an independent state.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS ASK ECONOMICS MINISTER TO RESIGN OVER POWER OUTAGE

TEXT.P: Legislator Su Huan-ji of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday said that Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang should resign over the massive power outage on July 29 that resulted in over NT$10 billion in losses.

Su and another DPP legislator, Yeh Yi-chin, held a press conference Tuesday morning in which they demanded compensation from state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) and Wang's resignation for the islandwide blackout last Thursday.

Tsai pointed out that the electrical outage resulted in massive losses all over the island, but Taipower argued that there was no "human negligence," and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has not issued any explanations. Tsai said this is "far from satisfying."
He said he has already sought support from other legislators in his attempt to bring about the economic minister's resignation, he said.

Tsai stressed that the power failure greatly damaged Taiwan's international reputation and the people's livelihood, but no government officials are willing to step out and assume responsibility, much to the dissatisfaction of the public.

He demanded that Wang, who is currently abroad, step down from office, adding that the blackout was not only a "natural disaster but also a human error," for which Taipower must assume total compensatory responsibility.

The fact that one toppled electricity tower can lead to an islandwide power outage reveals a serious problem in Taiwan's electricity transmission system management, he said. The incident also showed Taipower's lack of ability in dealing with the crisis.
Taipower cannot avoid compensation by claiming no human error has occurred, and it should review its maintenance of power towers and transmission systems, he said.
Meanwhile, other legislators disputed the necessity of Wang's resignation when members of the Economics Committee went to the MOEA for a briefing on the blackout on Tuesday.
Wang was visiting Hungary when the blackout occurred. The economics minister is slated to return to Taipei Wednesday evening.

The legislators also disagreed over whether Wang should have returned to Taipei to take responsibility for the outage. Lee Chia-chin, a member of the ruling Kuomintang and a former MOEA official, said that Wang was abroad on an official trip. His deputy minister should be able to deal with the outage, he said.
But other legislators, including Ker Chien-ming of the DPP, said Wang, who did not return, seemed "indifferent" to the blackout.

Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-bang explained that the minister's European tour was pre-arranged by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs six months ago and concerns official bilateral economic and trade consultations with many countries.

Wang was not on a "simple research trip," and was thus unable to head back to Taipei immediately, Chang said. But Wang has phoned him every day for daily updates, and the minister is very "concerned and worried" about the blackout, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 3, or the 22nd day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born, in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers killed against British loses of 1,100 men.
1916: Sir Roger Casement, one of Britain's most distinguished civil servants, is hung in London for his involvement in the Easter Uprising in Dublin.
1926: The first traffic light in England is set up in London's Piccadily Circus.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the US atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K. T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park; it is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high minister of state."

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPENSION OF HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY HURTS 2000'S ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: If construction of the high-speed railway and the Taipei International Financial Center Building are suspended, Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) in 1999 and 2000 will suffer a reduction of NT$10 billion and NT$51 billion, respectively, said the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Tuesday.
Economic growth rates for the two years will drop 0.1 percent and 0.5 percent, respectively, DGBAS added.

The DGBAS predicted in May that Taiwan is expected to enjoy a 5.7-percent economic growth rate in 2000, but the suspension of those two major construction projects will bring the rate down to 5.2 percent, which is lower than this year's expected growth.

The DGBAS in May estimated an investment of NT$6 billion in 1999 and NT$45 billion in 2000 by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), and an investment of NT$4 billion in 1999 and NT$6 billion in 2000 by the consortium building the Taipei International Financial Center Building.

The THSRC won the contract to build the 340-kilometer railway in September 1997. It has threatened to stop construction because of the government's alleged failure to meet its contractual obligations, particularly its obligation to provide cheap loans to the THSRC for the US$16.06 billion project and to acquire the land needed for the railway.

The Taipei International Financial Center Building, which is to be located near Taipei's domestic airport, was to be the tallest in Asia when construction plans were made and approved by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA).

But once construction began, it was determined that the building's height could affect flight safety, and the Taipei City government and the CAA required the consortium responsible for the building's construction to reduce its height.
The consortium threatened to stop the project completely and petitioned for national compensation for huge resulting losses.
Negotiations on the project are continuing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND EXERCISES TO MENACE TAIWAN: KMT CADRE

TEXT.P: Mainland China's recent series of military drills, revealed by the press, are aimed at menacing Taiwan, a mainland affairs expert said on Tuesday.

Chang Jong-kung, director of the Mainland Affairs Research Department under the ruling Kuomintang, pointed out that Beijing will conduct a string of military exercises in the coming August-October period to mark the 50th anniversary of the Chinese Communist Party's holding of power in mainland China.

He called on the people of Taiwan to be aware of the situation and stay calm, saying that the mainland has no excuse to invade Taiwan as the ROC government does not have the intention to amend the constitution and insert into it President Lee Teng-hui's recent "special relationship" remarks.
Since mainland China's military exercises were seldom reported by the media in the past, Chang said the news of a missile test might be aimed at menacing Taiwan through the media.
Chang's remarks came one day after the media reported that mainland China successfully test-fired a ground-to-ground missile within its territory.
The news came amid escalating tensions between Taiwan and mainland China following Lee's July 9 announcement that Taiwan's ties with mainland China constitute a "special state-to-state relationship."

Beijing was infuriated by Lee's statement and accused him of seeking to separate Taiwan from the mainland. Beijing also claimed that the basis for two-way dialogue and exchanges no longer exists if Taiwan does not return to its "one China" principle.

Commenting on a position paper issued by the Mainland Affairs Council on Sunday night to clarify Lee's "special relationship" theory, Chang opined that Beijing should be able to accept Taipei's official stance.

As Taiwan and mainland China are not expected to break the impasse in their relations in the short term, Chang predicted that Beijing still needs time to digest Taipei's explanation, thereby casting a shadow on a planned autumn visit to Taiwan by Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan.
