DOC.HEADLINE: PARITY CRUCIAL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that continued ambiguity in the status of relations across the Taiwan Strait will be detrimental to the Republic of China's development in the long run.
Lee made the remarks while meeting with a group of Canadian lawmakers who expressed their concern about the recent state of cross-strait relations.
From historical and legal points of view, Lee said the co-existence of the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China in the international community is an undeniable fact.

"This was why I defined cross-strait ties as 'at least a special state-to-state relationship' when Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station asked me in an interview in early July about my opinion concerning Beijing's claim that Taiwan is a renegade province of the PRC," Lee explained.
The president said since he assumed the presidency, he has earnestly hoped that the two sides can engage in peaceful exchanges instead of military confrontation.

In a show of goodwill, Lee said, the ROC government has adopted a series of policy adjustments, including terminating the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, promoting dialogue and expanding exchanges.

"Mainland China, however, has responded to Taiwan's goodwill with hostility," Lee regretted, adding that mainland China is even unwilling to work with Taiwan to resolve certain pressing issues related to rights and interests of people on both sides of the strait, such as smuggling of humans and contraband goods.
While some people claim that the so-called "one China" policy provides "creative ambiguity" and has facilitated the development of cross-strait relations.
However, Lee said mainland China has asserted in the world arena that the "one China" refers to the PRC and that the ROC on Taiwan is a province of the PRC.

"Beijing's hegemonic 'one China' principle has seriously squeezed our international space and made our development in the world community increasingly difficult," Lee said, adding that communist China's hegemonic attitude has not only threatened the ROC's survival but also endangered peace and stability in the entire Asia-Pacific region.

Lee stressed that if the status of cross-strait ties remains ambiguous, Taiwan's development will be adversely affected as Beijing has consistently regarded itself as the central government and downgraded the ROC as a local-level government.
The president said he is afraid if the two sides cannot conduct dialogue on a basis of parity, cross-strait talks will lead to nowhere.

Lee further told his guests that since constitutional amendments in 1991, the ROC's jurisdiction is limited to Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu. Moreover, the ROC has since recognized the PRC's jurisdiction over the Chinese mainland. This is a pragmatic reflection of the reality.
The president also reiterated that the ROC's policy of pursuing China's eventual unification under freedom, democracy and prosperity has remained unchanged.
Canadian lawmakers present at the meeting included Paul Szado, Rose-Marie Ur, Raymond Bonin, Paul Froseth and Jocelyne Girard-Bujold.
Szado said the ROC's achievements in political and economic fields have won worldwide recognition. "We believe that Taiwan provides a good model for mainland China's future development," he added.
In addition to cross-strait ties, Lee and Canadian lawmakers also exchanged views on ways to further boost ROC-Canadian trade, economic and cultural exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES PARAGUAYAN SPEAKER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui Tuesday told visiting Paraguayan Chamber of Deputies President Pedro Efrain Alegre that the Republic of China is a free and democratic country whose economic and political developments can be a paragon to many other countries.
During the meeting, Alegre reaffirmed Paraguay's firm support of the ROC. He expressed his hope that Taiwan's dispute with mainland China can be resolved through peaceful and democratic means.
The president expressed total agreement with the Paraguayan speaker's views. He reiterated that the ROC's long-standing cross-strait policy is based on peace, stability, reason and pragmatism.

Alegre said that the government and people of Paraguay completely understand Taiwan's standpoint, adding that Paraguayan congress recently passed an act further supporting the ROC's cross-strait policy.

Taiwan's economic achievements and political development can be a great example to many countries, President Lee said, adding that it's unfair for the ROC to be excluded from the United Nations and other major international organizations.

Lee also told his visitor that as he has personally visited the Latin American country twice and that he takes a great interest in Paraguay's development. He added that Alegre's visit will further cement relations between the two countries.

Also present at Tuesday's meeting were Paraguayan legislator Oscar Denis and his wife; Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan; senior Presidential Adviser Ding Mou-shih; and Deputy Secretary-General to the president Lin Bi-jaw.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was quoted at 32.169 against the US greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, posting a drop of 0.26 cents, the first decline in eight days.
The local currency opened at 32.139 and was traded between 32.139 and 32.215. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$376 million.
Devaluation pressure affected the local currency amid continued tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and as foreign capital started flowing out of the country, dealers said.
But the New Taiwan dollar is expected to regain stability owing to the sound economic fundamentals of and intervention by the Central Bank of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC REITERATES RESOLUTION TO STABILIZE FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATE

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Deputy Governor Shea Jia-dong said on Tuesday that the CBC is determined to punish anyone speculating in the foreign exchange market and to stabilize the foreign exchange rate for the New Taiwan dollar.

Shea made the remarks in a provisional press conference, the fourth since the rise in tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait following President Lee Teng-hui's "state-to-state relationship" remarks on July 9. The conference marked the first time that the CBC specifically used the word "punish."
Shea also warned individual investors not to "jump onto the bandwagon" during this period, as they, too, might be seen as speculators.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$98.6 billion at the end of July, despite the jitters between the two sides once caused fluctuation, said Shea.
The CBC will not allow rumors to cause the devaluation of the New Taiwan dollar and will take measures to stop any market manipulation and speculation, Shea noted.

The foreign media, in particular Hong Kong tabloids, continue to publish unconfirmed reports that affect the local bourse and foreign exchange market. Shea said the CBC has no way of finding out whether the media is doing it on purpose, but he did not rule out the possibility.
What the CBC can do is to urge investors not to jump into traps set by rumormongers to prevent them from suffering huge losses, he said.
Shea pointed out that the New Taiwan dollar is expected to appreciate in response to an expanding export surplus, a continual inflow of foreign capital and a relatively weak US dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI BOURSE TO RALLY FROM NEAR BOTTOM IN NEXT FEW DAYS: RESEARCHER

TEXT.P: The effects of the "special state-to-state" theory on cross-Taiwan Strait relations have almost faded away, and the Taipei stock market will rally from near bottom in the next few days, a domestic economist said Tuesday.
Ma Kai, a researcher at the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER), made the remarks in an interview with CNA.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed clearly Monday in a position paper on Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" theory that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should abide by a consensus reached in 1992 that each side can have its own interpretation of "one China" principle.

The MAC said in the position paper that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should work hand-in-hand through consultations on an equal footing to create a new climate for cross-strait engagements and pave the way for a peaceful unification.
Ma said Taipei has sent a strong message to Beijing, and he said he believed that Beijing would soon issue a response to Taipei's position paper.
He said once Beijing responds, Taipei will further clarify its position, and tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will ease.

Commenting on Tuesday's dip of the benchmark weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange below the psychologically significant 7,000-point level, Ma said the market is near bottom and will rally soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, INDEX FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taipei share prices closed 0.3 percent lower Tuesday as powerful government support offset early losses resulting from a missile test by mainland China.
The benchmark Taiwan Exchange Weighted Price Index dropped 20.75 points to close to 7,175.19 with a turnover of NT$71.3 billion (US$2.18 billion).
Among the eight major stock categories, paper-making issues, textile shares, steel shares and department store issues closed slightly higher, while the other four categories fell.
The over-the-counter market was down 1.1 points, ending the day at 157.91 points, on a turnover of NT$3.21 billion.
Meanwhile, TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August dropped 15 points, closing at 7,195, with 4,199 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September fell 12 points to close at 7,208 points, with 277 contract transactions; those for December declined 1 point to finish at 7,249 points with 13 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March moved down 15 points to end at 7,155 points, with 2 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 ROC CARRIERS MAKE PROFITS FROM TAIWAN-PHILIPPINE FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will incure financial losses if airlinks with the Philippines are really cut, airline sources said on Tuesday.

The Philippines unilaterally announced on Monday that it will terminate its 1996 civil aviation agreement with the Republic of China at the end of September. Filipino authorities claimed that Taiwan carriers have abused their operational rights for windfall profits.

According to airline sources, all the five Taiwan carriers operating Taiwan-Philippine flights have made profits from such services. Termination of air services will mark financial losses for Taiwan, estimated at a total of NT$150 million per month.
At present, China Airlines (CAL) and EAV Airways operate scheduled flights to the Philippines, while Far East Air Transport Corp., UNI Airlines and U-Land Air Lines operate chartered flights.

All the five carriers said they will abide by the government regulations if the government finally decides to cut direct airlinks with the Pihlippines. Nevertheless, they also expressed their hope that the government will continue negotiations with Filipino authorities and work out a mutually acceptable solution to ensure continued fight services between the two countries.

CAL began to operate Taiwan-Philippine services back in 1967. It currently operates a total of 21 round-trip Taipei-Manila and Taipei-Hong Kong-Manila flights per week. Its monthly revenues from those flights are about NT$100 million, accounting for 3 percent of the carrier's total monthly income.

EVA launched its Taipei-Manila flight services when it was inaugurated in July 1991. It currently operates 11 round-trip flights a week, with passenger occupancy rate ranging from 75 percent to 80 percent. Its annual turnover from the route amounts to more than NT$30 million, or 1 percent of its total annual turnover.

Far East has operated chartered flights between Taiwan and the Philippines' Subic Bay since September 1995. It now operates a total of five regular chartered flights from Taipei and Kaohsiung to the Subic Bay per week, with an annual turnover of about NT$90 million.

UNI Airlines has operated chartered flights to the Philippines' Laoag since 1992. It currently has three flights between Taipei and Laoag per week, with monthly turnover estimated at NT$5 million. The carrier operates this route only during travel season.
U-Land also operates chartered flights between Taipei and the Philippines' Laoag and Cebu on an irregular basis, with its monthly turnover estimated at NT$10 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGLISH VERSION OF `SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY IS AVAILABLE

TEXT.P: An English version of an explanation of President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" statement regarding the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China is near completion, according to mainland affairs officials.

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taipei's chief policy-making body for the China issue, on Sunday issued a position paper in Mandarin Chinese on Lee's statement, but it is the English rendition, still being scrutinized by MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin, which will be used as a basis for explaining the concept to the international community.

The MAC position paper seeks to emphasize that Lee's remarks were aimed at laying a foundation of parity between the two sides in order to elevate the level of dialogue and facilitate the mechanisms of democracy and peace, so that a new cross-strait relationship can be ushered in for the new century.

The paper points out that Lee's comments were stated under the premise of maintaining the ROC's national interests and dignity, and to state the facts from the political, historical and legal points of view. It also points out that peaceful reunification of China remains the ultimate long-term goal of the government and people of Taiwan.

The MAC also indicated that Taipei rejects Beijing's "one China" principle, which belittles Taipei by shrinking its position to that of a local government, and which the Beijing authorities use as their basis for cross-strait dialogue.
The paper urges the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to return to the verbal consensus reached in 1992 for a "one China, with each side entitled to its respective interpretation."

According to that consensus, the paper notes, Taipei sees "one China" as something for the future, since China at present is divided and ruled separately by two equal sovereign states, hence the "special state-to-state relationship."

The paper further points out that the word "special" in "special state-to-state relationship" acknowledges the fact that both sides share a common cultural, historical and ethnic background. What is most important, says the paper, is the fact that both sides are willing to seek common ground through dialogue and communication for China's eventual unification.
Taipei's mainland policy has not changed, and the new description of the cross-strait situation is merely Taiwan's efforts to seek a win-win outcome, the paper says.

Since Taipei's mainland policy remains unchanged, therefore, problems with constitutional amendments, revisions to the Guidelines for National Unification, changing of the status quo, or Taiwan's "trouble making" do not arise, the paper observes.

It also reiterates the MAC's most sincere welcome to Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan in autumn. Wang, the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan, is the chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

The paper stresses that once the two sides resolve their dispute concerning political meaning following Lee's clear redefinition of the cross-strait relationship, any topics can be brought to the discussion table.

Continuous open discussions between Taipei and Beijing, and a clear and positive direction for the development of a healthy cross-strait relationship, will be beneficial to regional peace and stability, the paper concludes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES WILL CONTINUE: ARATS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) on Tuesday stressed the importance of "continuing the promotion of all kinds of cross-strait exchanges."

Tang Shubei, ARATS executive vice chairman, made the statement in a letter sent to a seminar on the promotion of Chinese modernization which opened on Tuesday in Taipei without the presence of Zhang Xiaobu, ARATS deputy secretary-general and Wang Xiaobing, the association's liaison director, who canceled their participation in the Taipei seminar at the last minute.

Fan Xiaojian, a department head from mainland China's Ministry of Agriculture who took over as leader of the mainland delegation, pointed out that the sudden cancellations were personal decisions of Zhang and Wang. Fan stressed that he is in Taipei as part of an academic exchange that is not influenced by cross-strait relations.

Deputy Secretary-General Chang Liang-jen of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) pointed out that Taiwan welcomes any visit by ARATS personnel, and added that he was surprised to learn that Zhang and Wang had canceled.
Chang stressed that the ROC has not altered its cross-strait exchange policy and expressed his wish to continue the expansion of all types of bilateral exchanges based on an equal footing.

The 32-member mainland delegation arrived in Taipei on Monday evening for an eight-day visit. After attending the two-day seminar, they will visit southern Taiwan to observe the island's agricultural and economic development.
The seminar, now in its seventh year, is organized by Taipei's Academic Foundation for the Promotion of Chinese Modernization and is sponsored by ARATS.

DOC.HEADLINE: DASSAULT WORKING TO SOLVE TAIWAN JET FIGHTERS' CONDENSATION PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Dassault Aviation Concern, the French maker of the Mirage jet fighter, is trying to solve the problem of vapor condensation on the canopy of Taiwan's Mirage 2000s, said a spokesman for the Air Force Headquarters on Tuesday.

Confirming a United Daily News' report that a Mirage 2000 prototype and a team of French crew members arrived at the Hsinchu air force base in mid-July, the spokesman said the French crew is testing ways to solve the condensation problem.

The problem, which stems from Taiwan's warm climate and heavy humidity, has plagued Taiwan's 60 Mirages ever since France delivered them in 1997. The condensation blocks the pilot's view during flight and creating a safety hazard. Although the standard misting procedure prescribed in the manufacturer's operating manual has helped, it has not solved the problem, said the spokesman.
Technicians at Dassault have worked out several ways to address the problem and are testing possible solutions on the prototype, said the spokesman.
By performing the tests on the prototype, Taiwan's 60 Mirage fighters can remain in service, said the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETIRED WORKERS PROTEST IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: More than 300 retired workers of a state-run textile factory in Xian, capital of central Shaanxi province, staged a sit-in protest Monday at a crossroads in the downtown area of the city, a human rights group said Tuesday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Right and Democratic Movement in China said they staged the demonstration because the factory has delayed the payment of their retirement pension for one year, causing them unbearable hardship.
The center said that the textile factory, which used to have 1,500 employees, is losing money due to corruption and mismanagement.

It quoted one of the workers as saying that, if the government does nothing to relieve their economic hardship, they will continue to protest in public. Their demonstration once paralyzed the traffic in downtown Xian Monday, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC MISSILE TEST-FIRING IS PURSUIT OF HEGEMONY: MND

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Tuesday that mainland China's development of a new intercontinental missile "is not worthy of praise" from the viewpoint of world peace because it is being used as a tool to pursue hegemony.
He made the remark while responding to reporters outside the Legislative Yuan.
Tang also noted that the missiles in question, capable of carrying nuclear weapons, have a range of 8,000 kilometers, and cost as much as US$100 million each.
Therefore, he pointed out, if mainland China were to use such weapons to attack Taiwan, it would be akin to "taking a hammer to crack a nut."
The successful test-firing of the missile by mainland China on Monday, and a Hong Kong report about mainland China's heightened war readiness, have caused new concern in Taiwan.

Tang asked the public to believe the Defense Ministry rather than reports and speculation in the Hong Kong media, while a Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman told the media that the test-firing of the new type of missile is primarily to deter big powers rather than Taiwan.
Regarding the Hong Kong report that the People's Liberation Army has heightened its state of military alert in Fujian Province, the spokesman said that no unusual movement has been detected so far.

He noted that the MND has been keeping a close watch on mainland China's military movements and exercises, and will inform the public of its findings "at an appropriate time," so long as such information does not affect national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S POSITION PAPER ON 'SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE RELATIONSHIP'

TEXT.P: The following is the English version of the full text of the Republic of China's position paper released by the Mainland Affairs Council on the "special state-to-state relationship" with regard to the relations between Taiwan and mainland China. (The Chinese version was released on Sunday.)
PARITY, PEACE, AND WIN-WIN:
The Republic of China's Position on the
"Special State-to-State Relationship"
Mainland Affairs Council, Executive Yuan
Republic of China
August 1, 1999 I. To Develop a New Era of Cross-strait Relations Based on Parity

In response to a question during an interview with Deutsche Welle radio station that "the Beijing government views Taiwan as a renegade province," President Lee remarked: "The cross-strait relationship is a 'special state-to-state relationship.'"

President Lee's remarks concerning the nature of the cross-strait relationship were based on the necessity of protecting national interests and dignity. From the political, historical, and legal perspectives, he merely clarified an existing fact. He by no means twisted or exaggerated the truth, nor did he exclude the goal toward future unification of a new, democratic China.

This practical and forward-looking view fully voiced the aspirations of the twenty-two million people in Taiwan. It is designated to lay a foundation of parity for the two sides, to elevate the level of dialogue, to build a mechanism for democratic and peaceful cross-strait interactions, and to usher in a new era of cross-strait relations. II. To Oppose Beijing's Hegemonistic "One-China Principle"

Since its establishment of 1912, the Republic of China has always been a sovereign state. Although its jurisdiction is currently limited to the territories of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, the ROC is the 19th largest economy and the 15th largest trading country worldwide. These are facts.

The People's Republic of China was founded in 1949. In the past fifty years following that, the two sides of the Strait have been ruled separately, with neither side subordinate to the other. To date, a special cross-strait relationship of a divided China has not changed. These are also facts.

In 1991, we took the initiative in demonstrating our goodwill by renouncing the use of force to reunify China, acknowledging Beijing's rule on the Chinese mainland, and replacing military confrontation with peaceful exchanges and dialogue. However, Beijing has not responded with goodwill, but rather has denigrated the ROC as a local government through its hegemonistic "one-China principle." It downgraded the ROC in cross-strait exchanges, and appropriated the "one-China principle" as the premise for all cross-strait negotiations, in order to force us to gradually acquiesce to the "one country, two systems" formula.

Moreover, Beijing has done its utmost to suppress our international living space. Consequently, the international community has become accustomed to Beijing's pronouncements, while disregarding the obvious fact of separate and equal rule on the two sides of the Strait.

Precisely because the facts have been distorted by Beijing and neglected by the international community for many years that President Lee's announcement drew a great deal of attention from all circles, when he clearly stated these simple facts. While, Beijing's hegemonistic "one-China principle," which is the actual root of the problem, has been ignored in the discussion. III. To Start Political Negotiations with Prudence

The experience of countries negotiating with the Chinese communists has shown, through the years that, during the initial phase of negotiation, the Chinese communists always insist on setting advantageous "principles" for themselves. Once such "principles" are in place, subsequent results are unlikely to exceed those boundaries. Since 1995, when the PRC unilaterally terminated institutionalized consultations, Beijing has left functional issues, vital to the rights and interests of the peoples of both sides, unattended and has obstinately demanded negotiations on highly sensitive political issues with the ROC government. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: PARITY, PEACE, AND WIN-WIN: (II)

TEXT.P: Furthermore, drawing upon its presumptive "one-China principle" in cross-strait political negotiations and its "one country, two systems" formula, Beijing has denied the existence of the Republic of China by treating us as a local government. The ROC government is not afraid of negotiations, but we will not engage in negotiations, if we are placed in an unequal status, or if we are under pressure from a hegemonistic regime that assumes preset conclusions.

Should the ROC government conduct negotiations with the PRC under such circumstances, while vaguely claiming that we are only a "political entity," we would be placing ourselves at a disadvantage. Thus, before commencing any negotiations, we must have a clear orientation of cross-strait relations. In order to engage in meaningful dialogue with the other side and to protect the dignity of our country and the interests of our people, the ROC government must transcend the unfair framework in which a "political entity" deals with a "sovereign state." Only when cross-strait consultations are on an equal basis, can they win support from the people. IV. Returning to the Agreement on "One China Respectively Interpreted by Each Side"

Taiwan and the Chinese mainland have always differed in their definition of "one China." Thus, in 1992, following the establishment of the SEF and the ARATS, bilateral talks focused mainly on the definition of "one China." It was only after several rounds of consultations that the two sides eventually reached an agreement on "one China to be interpreted respectively by each side." That is, both sides are free to state their own definition of "one China."

This is an ideal approach that would have enabled the two sides to continue promoting cross-strait relations, while resolving their differences. However, Beijing has unilaterally abandoned this agreement in recent yeas. It has often objected to the application of the agreement in international relations. At times, Beijing has stated that the agreement only applies to technical consultations and not political negotiations in cross-strait relations. On other occasions, Beijing has even denied that such an agreement was ever reached in 1992. Then, in recent years, it has gone as far as to object to the ROC's right to state its own definition.

In the framework of the 1992 agreement, whereby each side is entitled to its respective interpretation, we have always maintained that the "one China" concept refers to the future rather than the present. The two sides are not yet unified, but are equals, separately ruled. We both exist concurrently. Therefore, the two sides can be defined as sharing a "special state-to-state relationship," prior to unification. Cross-strait relations are "special," because we share the same culture, historical origins, and ethnic bonds. The people on the two sides engage in exchanges in social, economic, trade, and other areas, activities for which other divided countries cannot match.

What is most important is that the two sides are willing to work in concert and engage in consultations on an equal basis to pursue the future unification of China. If the two sides can recognize and appreciate this special relationship and return to the agreement that each side is entitled to its respective interpretation, then, through consultations on the basis of equality, we can transcend our political differences to jointly cooperate in opening a new chapter in cross-strait relations that will be conducive to the unification of the country under democracy. V. To Clarify, Not to Change the Status Quo; To Seek Peace, Not to Make Trouble

The purpose of clearly defining the cross-strait relationship according to reality is to ensure the equal status of both sides of the Taiwan Strait. We have also repeatedly stressed that various related policies will not be changed, especially those that promote constructive dialogue and positive exchanges between the two sides. Our resolve in seeking a win-win cross-strait relationship and our determined policy of pursuing the future unification of China, under democracy, freedom, and equitable prosperity, have not changed. Since there was no policy change, there is certainly no need to revise the Constitution, the laws, or the Guidelines for National Unification. Much less is there the issue of changing the status quo, or making trouble.

We hope that all concerned will examine the matter from a reasonable and objective viewpoint. Also, we would like to increase contacts with any party to fully communicate our ideas, so together we can maintain the peace and stability of the Taiwan Strait and the Asia-Pacific region. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BUSINESS SECTOR REPRESENTATIVES SUPPORT FREEZE ON PHILIPPINE LABOR

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan's business sector on Tuesday expressed support for the government's plan to freeze the entry of Philippine laborers in retaliation against Manila's unilateral termination of its aviation agreement with Taiwan.
Kao Chin-yuan, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, criticized the Manila government for "forgetting" Taiwan's contributions to the Philippine economy.
He told the media that Taiwan has so far extended a great deal of economic assistance to the Philippines, and that it is to Manila's shame that it has terminated the aviation pact with Taiwan.
Kao said he will call on the nation's industrial and commercial circles to join hands to back the government's retaliatory measures.
Wang You-theng, chairman of the ROC General Chamber of Commerce, was also critical of Manila's disregard of Taiwan's favors toward the Philippines.
He said local businessmen should support the government's policy and suspend plans to invest in the Philippines.

In another development, an official of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) informed Manila's representatives in Taipei that another freeze on the recruitment of Philippine laborers will go into effect on Aug. 16, if Manila fails to repeal a decree due to take effect on that date that infringes on Taiwan's jurisdiction over foreign labor brokerage.

Under the decree, Taiwan's manpower labor agencies will be blacklisted in the Philippines if they fail to fulfill the terms of their contracts with Philippine laborers and provide round-trip air tickets for contracted Philippine laborers.
According to the decree, Taiwan manpower agencies are also required to abide by Philippine law rather than Republic of China law regarding the interests of laborers.
Government statistics indicate that of some 270,000 foreign laborers in Taiwan, about 110,000 are from the Philippines.
Meanwhile, Yeh Ming-feng, chief secretary for the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that the government will no longer encourage Taiwan businessmen to invest in the Philippines.
Instead, he went on, they will be encouraged to invest in Vietnam and friendly Latin American countries. (Victor Lai)

DOC.HEADLINE: PARITY, PEACE, AND WIN-WIN: (III)

TEXT.P: The agreement for Mr. Wang Daohan's visit to Taiwan this year was reached during the "Koo-Wang" talks of October 1998, Later, we sent out the formal invitation to Mr. Wang. Over the last six months, Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) have conducted exchanges and made preparations for this historic activity. We would like to reiterate that we sincerely welcome Mr. Wang's visit to Taiwan in the fall.

We understand that the mainland authorities have been hoping to carry out talks on highly-sensitive political topics with us during Mr. Wang's visit to Taiwan. At this time, we have clearly defined the cross-strait relationship for the talks, so the two sides will be able to conduct thorough discussions of various issues, including the definition of the relationship between the two sides.

In the course of cross-strait consultations, if the two sides raise different positions and views, it should be seen as a necessary stage in the course of seeking common ground while resolving differences. If one side can express its position, it should also be able to accept the fact that the other side (can) express its position as well. In fact, exactly because differences now exist, all the more need is for consultations. Through consultation, there will be opportunities to comprehend or resolve differences. If either of the two sides refuses to hold consultations because of different views, then the cross-strait relationship is sure to recede.

We believe such is not the outcome that the two sides and the international community would like to see. We maintain that the Koo- Wang dialogue in Taipei can further enable the two sides to understand each other's overall views and eliminate misunderstandings. This will not only help reduce tension between the two sides while furthering the discussions for a clear direction of cross-strait relations, but will also contribute to regional peace and stability. VII. To Achieve Parity, Peace, and a Win-Win Cross-strait Relationship

Stability in the Taiwan Strait directly affects peace and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region. The maintenance of peace in the Taiwan Strait should be considered the common desire of both sides and the international community. The status of cross-strait relations is now clearly defined and reflects objective political and legal realities, offering a new opportunity for the resumption of positive interaction between the two sides.

After the normalization of cross-strait relations, a long-term pattern of peace and stability can develop through constructive dialogue, institutionalized consultations, and orderly exchanges. This should be the common goal of both sides, as they develop a unified and democratic new China in the future. A win-win situation would then be established for both sides of the Taiwan Strait. Nations in the region would also benefit. The situation is compatible with the long-term interests of the two sides and the entire Asia-Pacific region.

We call on the PRC to face reality and to acknowledge our earnestness in promoting cross-strait relations. We hope Beijing will be pragmatic and open-minded, so the joint efforts of both sides will create a new era of constructive interactions in the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER ARRIVES IN MACEDONIA FOR OFFICIAL VISIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew arrived on Tuesday in Skopje, capital of the Macedonian Republic at the head of a huge delegation.

At the airport, Siew and his entourage were given a red carpet welcome with full military honors as they were met by his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski, Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov, and other government officials.

Speaking after his arrival, Siew said his trip is aimed at consolidating Taipei's trade and economic ties with Skopje and fulfilling ROC President Lee Teng-hui's promise to aid the neighboring Yugoslavian province of Kosovo with US$300 billion.
Siew and his hundred-strong delegation left Taipei on Sunday aboard a chartered plane, and stopped over in Vienna for one day.

The delegation, consisting of lawmakers, government officials and business leaders, will inspect the Macedonian business environment and explore the possibility of setting up banks, hotels, and engaging in construction in the Balkan state.
They are expected to return to Taipei on Aug. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN RESERVES IN JULY REGISTER FOUR-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign reserves had surged to US$98.6 billion as of the end of July, the highest since August, 1995, and are anticipated to surpass US$100 billion soon, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Tuesday.
The figure makes the island the third-largest holder of foreign reserves in the world behind Japan and mainland China.
CBC statistics show that although by the end of June, foreign reserves were only US$900 million more than the previous month, they were US$15 billion more than one year ago, a remarkable growth pace.

CBC analysts attributed the surge to the increase in value of the new Taiwan dollar against the greenback, which would have pushed up the island's reserves even higher had the CBC not interfered to curb the NT dollar's appreciation by releasing greenbacks on the foreign exchange market.

Taiwan's reserves have been enjoying an upward trend since the second half of last year. They broke through the US$90 billion mark last December, and kept on climbing throughout the first half of this year.
The last time they rose above US$100 billion was in May, 1995, when they reached US$100.31 billion, and June, 1995, when they reached US$100.41.
As of the end of July, Japan led the world with the largest reserves of US$260.7 billion, followed by mainland China, with US$150.13 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO MINIMIZE MACAU GARRISON

TEXT.P: Mainland China has decided to keep its post-handover garrison in Macau small as a goodwill gesture towards Portugal, according to a report on Tuesday from the Portuguese News Agency.

Macau's future People's Liberation Army (PLA) garrison will comprise between just 700 and 800 troops, not 1,000 as had been previously believed, the report said, adding that the garrison will have merely a "symbolic" function.

Mainland China has decided to adopt a "long-term strategy" towards its relations with Portugal, stressing that a relatively small garrison will bring the matter more into line with Lisbon's opposition to the stationing of troops in the territory, the report said.
Portugal, which disbanded its garrison in Macau in 1975, has said there is no need for a military presence in the territory before or after the handover this December.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTRIES REACH CONSENSUS ON SANCTIONS AGAINST RP

TEXT.P: Various Republic of China ministries have reached consensus on sanctions against the Philippines in the wake of Manila's scrapping of the ROC-Philippine aviation agreement, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said on Tuesday.

Following a inter-ministerial meeting, Lee said: "Our carrots have been sown, and our sticks have been prepared." The meeting participants included Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Chang Chia-juch, Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Chan Hou-sheng, Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-pang, and Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lin Shiang-nung.

The ROC and the Philippines began negotiations on the air link accord last week, but the talks broke down almost immediately because of a dispute over the number of passengers allowed to be carried by Taiwan airlines.
The Philippines claimed that the ROC violated the air agreement by using larger planes than permitted under the terms of the accord.

Shortly after the talks broke down, Manila unilaterally announced the suspension of the air agreement. From Sept. 1, China Airlines and Eva Airways will be forced to suspend their Taipei-Manila flights.

Lee said the sanction measures will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval before they are implemented. He declined to reveal the contents of the sanction package, but stressed that the ROC hopes the dispute will be solved pragmatically to the benefit of both sides.

He said the ROC will continue to talk with the Philippines through normal channels prior to the Sept. 1 deadline, with the aim of restoring the content and spirit of the 1996 bilateral aviation agreement.

Commenting on Manila's description of the ROC Council of Labor Affairs as "Taiwan Province Executive Yuan's Council of Labor Affairs," Lee said the move is an insult to ROC dignity, and added that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has instructed its representative office in the Philippines to lodge the strongest protest.

At present, there are 115,000 Filipinos working in the ROC. Last year, 186,000 people from Taiwan visited the Philippines as tourists, and domestic flights to Manila and Subic Bay carry an average of 9,000 passengers per week, Lee said.
He further pointed out that the ROC's investment in the Philippines totals US$1 billion, US$300 million of which is at Subic Bay, with the electronics industry accounting for the biggest share.
These ROC manufacturers have said that if air links are suspended, their transport costs will increase and they will probably consider withdrawing from the Philippines.
Lee said that the issue will also determine whether or not an ROC-Philippine economic exchange conference scheduled for September will proceed as planned.

There has been no further news from the Philippines side toward the ROC's reaction, Lee said, adding that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will summon the Philippine representative in the ROC on Wednesday to set forth the ROC's position.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT DECLARES STATE OF EMERGENCY IN FLOOD-HIT AREAS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Tuesday declared a state of calamity in Metro Manila and the provinces of Pangasinan, Pampanga and Rizal due to flash floods induced by continuous heavy rains over the past week.

"All departments and other government agencies are hereby directed to implement and execute relief and rehabilitation work in accordance with existing operational plans, directives and orders issued in connection with calamities," Estrada said his declaration.

Meanwhile, chief forecaster Dr. Prisco Nilo of the Philippines Weather Bureau said there is a strong possibility Filipinos will continue to be pelted with heavy rain for seven more days in the wake of typhoon Ising which swept the country last week.
Meanwhile, a report said that as of Tuesday the death toll stood at 17 and still rising, with many more missing, and thousands of flash flood victims evacuated to higher ground.
Schools and offices have been closed for the past two days in the affected areas. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA LAUDS ECONOMICS MINISTER'S EUROPEAN TRIP AS SUCCESS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Tuesday lauded the just-concluded European trip by Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang as productive and successful.
In a statement, the MOFA said Wang and his 40-member delegation were warmly welcomed by the four host countries -- Britain, Sweden, Hungary and Norway during their July 20-Aug. 3 trip.

Describing the trip as part of the government's efforts to implement Premier Vincent Siew's policy of basing pragmatic diplomacy on economic and trade ties, the statement said that Wang won a positive response from officials in Britain to his suggestion of opening a regular channel of ministerial contacts with the Republic of China. They also expressed interest in Wang's invitations to visit Taiwan.
As a result of Wang's visit to Britain, the statement went on, London has listed Taiwan as one of the 15 countries it will target for trade promotion.
Calling Wang the highest-ranking ROC official ever to visit Sweden, the statement said Wang attended a bilateral economic conference in Stockholm, which has helped cement bilateral ties.
During his stay in Hungary, Wang received a warm reception from the host country and met with senior economic officials, despite strong protests from Beijing, according to the statement.

As the first ROC official to visit Norway, the very appearance of Wang and his entourage in that Scandinavian country was beneficial to bilateral exchanges, while their meetings with Norwegian political leaders and senior government officials, and their tour of industrial facilities during their stay were also very helpful, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER HOLDS TALKS WITH MACEDONIAN COUNTERPART IN SKOPJE
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Huang Chao-ping & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew held talks with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski on Tuesday to discuss concrete ways of promoting economic and trade relations between the two countries.
Siew arrived in Skopje on Tuesday at the head of a 100-member delegation for a five-day official visit.

Paving the way for Taiwan businessmen to advance into Europe, cementing Taipei-Skopje relations, and implementation of the US$300 million aid project for Kosovar refugees have been cited as the three main topics on Siew's Macedonia agenda.

After a brief rest at the guest house following his arrival, Siew visited a local church before donating US$1.3 million-worth of medical items, clothing, fertilizer, seeds and stationery to Macedonia.
On Tuesday evening, Siew held talks with Georgievski on economic issues.

Officials accompanying the premier said that a Taiwan investment and development company will establish a 180-hectare export processing zone in Macedonia as the base for Taiwan businessmen to expand their presence in Europe, while the Taipei-based International Commercial Bank of China is studying the feasibility of setting up a branch in Skopje.
Other businessmen are considering investing in hotel and public housing construction, the communication business, marble quarrying, and chicken raising in the Balkan country.
Siew plans to visit Kosovo Province in neighboring Yugoslavia on Wednesday on a fact-finding tour to get ideas on how Taipei can effectively implement the US$300 million aid project.

During the Skopje trip, the ROC and Macedonian governments will conclude economic cooperation agreements, information exchange agreements, agricultural development and cooperation agreements, as well as cultural exchange agreements.

Meanwhile, a delegation of Taiwan businessmen visited the Macedonian Chamber of Commerce and signed a cooperation agreement, witnessed by Chairman P.K. Chiang of Taipei's Council for Economic Planning and Development and Chairman Jeffrey Koo of the Chinatrust Commercial Bank.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices dropped 0.9 percent on Wednesday on strong selling in the electronics sector and continued tensions with mainland China.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 64.39 points to close at 7,110.80 points.
A total of 1.50 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$63.45 billion (US$1.97 billion), down from the pervious session's NT$71.30 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, plastic and chemical shares posted the only gain of the day, climbing 0.8 percent.
Electronics stocks suffered the largest loss of the day, falling 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues, which dropped 1 percent. Financial shares were down 0.9 percent.
Cement issues declined 0.6 percent, construction shares lost 0.5 percent, paper and pulp stocks slid 0.4 percent and the textile sector posted a slight 0.1 percent-fall.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market registered a 1.21-point rise, ending the day at 159.12 points, with a turnover of NT$3.13 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August suffered a 100-point setback to finish at 7,095 points, with 3,077 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September declined 118 points, closing at 7,090, while those for December lost 140 points to close at 7,100 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 214 and 9, respectively.
Futures for next March remained static at 7,155 points, with 2 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next June's futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,195 points for August, 7,208 points for September, 7,240 points for December, 7,155 points for next March and 7,285 points for next June.
The recently launched electronics futures (TE) and financial futures (TF) both reported losses.
August TE futures dipped 7.7 points to close at 306.0, with 932 contract transactions; September TE futures posted a 5.2-point drop, finishing the day at 308.8 points, with 28 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for next March and June's TE futures.
August TF futures fell 28 points, closing at 1,051 points, with 60 contract transactions. There were no transaction records for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC STILL STRIVING FOR JOINING WTO BY YEAR'S END

TEXT.P: Despite Beijing's continued boycott, the Republic of China is still striving for joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) by the end of this year, a senior official said on Wednesday.

Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), made the statement after returning from a visit to Geneva to attend an informal meeting of the WTO working party in charge of the ROC's membership application.

Chen said before the opening of the meeting, the ROC delegation already knew that mainland China would through its allies block the WTO working party from screening documents concerning Taiwan's entry terms.
Although four mainland China allies in the WTO -- Cuba, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka -- spoke against the discussion of Taiwan's entry protocol, the WTO working party still proceeded smoothly.
"Several influential WTO members, including the United States, the European Union (EU) and Canada, had voiced support for the screening of Taiwan's entry protocol and related documents," Chen said.

In an attempt to boycott discussion, mainland China's allies quoted a 1992 statement by the head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which was replaced by the WTO in 1995, as saying that mainland China's membership application should be approved ahead of Taiwan's.
In response, US, EU and Canadian representatives said the informal working party meeting was designed to discuss only technical issues, not any other issue.

As a result, Chen said the working party meeting proceeded smoothly last week. "At present, most WTO member economies are screening documents detailing Taiwan's tariff concessions and a timetable for the opening of its service markets," Chen said, adding that the ROC will push all WTO contracting parties to accelerate screening of all those documents to facilitate Taiwan's accession to the world trade regulatory body.
Noting that mainland China has never ceased its effort to block Taiwan's WTO entry since the ROC filed its application in January 1990, Chen said the ROC won't be daunted by Beijing's interference.
Mainland China filed its application in 1986. However, it lags far behind Taiwan in negotiations with WTO members for its entry terms as its trade regime is not as open and Taiwan's.
Taiwan has completed all bilateral trade consultations with its major trade partners in the WTO. "We hope we can be formally admitted to the organization by the end of the year," Chen stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 4, or the 23rd day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famed the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including: "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women," governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between fascists and socialists.
1938: The National government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the long-time War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding places in Amsterdam are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports to Britain within three months.
1981: A US court orders striking air traffic controllers back to work.
1986: ROC-US trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports, embargo arms and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve its soldiers as sex slaves during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1997: North Korea hands over the remains of four American soldiers killed during the 1950-1953 Korean War.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US VICE PRESIDENT SAYS UNITED STATES WILL FACE CHINA CHALLENGE

TEXT.P: Former US Vice President Dan Quayle said Tuesday that he does not support Taiwan independence, but the United States must make clear to mainland China that the issue of unification will be resolved peacefully and not by military force.

Although Beijing wants the "hegemonist" United States out of the Pacific, Quayle stressed that this is something the United States just cannot accept. "We need to reinforce the alliances that we have with South Korea ... reinforce our alliance and troop commitment to Japan, reinforce our commitment to our friends on Taiwan."

Addressing the National Press Club here, the contender for the Republican presidential nomination noted that the challenge the United States is going to face in the next generation, or the next decade, or maybe even before, is not in Europe, not in the Middle East, it is in the Pacific and it deals specifically with mainland China.

Many people believe that mainland China is the Germany of 100 years ago. If they are correct, Quayle said, "Let us hope and pray that we manage the situation with China better than we did with Germany at the beginning of this century, where it took us two world wars to get Germany into the family of democratic nations."

But the former vice president went on to say that he does not believe, as some Republicans do, that mainland China is the enemy. He views mainland China both as a huge challenge and as a huge opportunity. "I want to see China become prosperous. I also want to see China become democratic; not just to engage China, but to change China," he said.

And when the United States discusses this and the challenge of mainland China versus Taiwan, Quayle said, "It should not be China versus Taiwan. We ought to be talking about ideals. And as a nation, we cannot adopt the standard of excusing communism, but more importantly, we should adopt the standard of promoting freedom and liberty around the globe."

"I do not support the idea of independence for Taiwan, but it is a democratic entity, and I hope that they don't do it. But it must be made clear to the rulers in Beijing that this issue be resolved peacefully and not through military force," he said.

When asked about trade relations with mainland China and the World Trade Organization (WTO), Quayle said he is not for granting Beijing permanent most-favored-nation status (now called normal trade relations), because that would mean admission to the WTO, and mainland China just is not ready now.

"I want to see China eventually admitted to the WTO. I want to see China become democratic, I want to see them be prosperous. I want there to be peace between our countries and peace in the Pacific. But you have to realize that this relationship is more than just trade.

"There are a whole host of issues that we have between the United States and China. The Taiwan issue, the trade issue, human rights, religious persecution, technology transfer, the whole nuclear issue -- a whole host of matters that we have to discuss with China," he added.

Quayle continued that mainland China is a tremendous opportunity and challenge for the United States. "But we need to know what China wants. .... What China wants is essentially three things. They want recognition as a world power on the world stage, much like Russia. They want Taiwan. And they want the United States out of the Pacific."

On the first one, Quayle said, clearly they are a world power and they will be even more of one and better respected if they follow Russia in enacting political reform and political development and move toward democratic values.

As for Taiwan, the former vice president reiterated that the Taiwan issue will be worked out, "but peacefully and not militarily . ... Mr. Lee (Teng-hui) moved a little bit toward independence the other day and didn't quite say it, and they had trouble with the translation. But it was jarring to the PRC, it was jarring to the world."

But, he said, "Taiwan is a democratic entity. It's a democracy. They have elections there, and the people are allowed to vote and people are allowed to speak freely. They have the free press and that's a country that should have an impact."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.07 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at 32.099.
The local currency opened at 32.163 and was traded between 32.075 and 32.174.
Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$340.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY AND CAPITAL OF MARSHALL ISLANDS FORGE ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government and Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, Wednesday signed a joint statement announcing the establishment of ties between the two cities, making Majuro the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Tarmile Ishoda, mayor of Majuro, signed a pact of alliance at the Taipei City Government building Wednesday morning. This is the first sister-city alliance forged by Ma since he assumed office last December.
Ma pointed out in a speech that after the Marshall Islands established diplomatic relations with the Republic of China last November, Foreign Minister Jason Hu visited the new ally earlier this year.

During the visit, Taipei Deputy Mayor Bai Hsiu-hsiung, who was also a member of the ROC delegation, expressed the city's desire to forge a sister-city alliance with Majuro, he continued, adding that the plan was finally realized this day.

Ma said that the Marshall Islands is a beautiful country that possesses rich fishery and tourism resources, with many of the ROC's fishing boats fishing near the region. He hopes to step up more economic, trade and cultural exchanges between the two cities in the future, he said.

The Taipei mayor also expressed his wish to visit the Asia-Pacific island nation. But since there are currently no direct flights between the two countries, it would take 15 hours of flight and transfer time to get there.
Ishoda and his six-member entourage will visit major city constructions during his visit in Taipei. He is scheduled to head back home on Aug. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNFI MIGHT CANCEL SEPTEMBER VISIT TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The Chinese National Federation of Industries' (CNFI) much-anticipated September visit to mainland China might be canceled due to Beijing's hostile reaction to President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait relations, CNFI Chairman Kao Chin-yen said Wednesday.

In response to reporters' questions Wednesday morning, Kao, who is also president of President Enterprise Corp., said that due to mainland China's "unfriendly attitude," the CNFI will hold a meeting on Aug. 10 to discuss whether to continue with the scheduled research trip next month.

Since mainland China has displayed "considerable hostility" to Lee's "special state-to-state relations" theory, Kao said it would only "cause more trouble for ourselves" if the federation were to proceed with its original plans.
So even though members of the delegation have displayed much eagerness for the trip, Kao said he still tends to favor canceling the visit.
The CNFI's governing board in July had originally decided on a 10-day visit from Sept. 20 to 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST TIMORESE UNSHAKEN BY BALLOTING REGISTRATION THREATS

TEXT.P: The majority of East Timorese, including those living abroad and in the territory's rugged mountains, have registered for the UN-sponsored ballot on Aug. 30 to decide the territory's future.

In a dispatch from Dili, capital of the former Portuguese colony, The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday reported 383,000 Timorese had registered, compared with an original UN estimate of between 300,000 and 400,000 eligible voters. The turnout has met the United Nations' highest expectations, the daily reported.

Threats by the pro-Indonesia militia groups, the widespread burning of houses and the fact that tens of thousands of people have been driven into refugees camps by militia intimidation have not kept the East Timorese away from the polling stations, the daily reported.
Instead, the pro-independence activists are becoming increasingly confident with the number of people registering for the vote, it reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND URGES TAIWAN PEOPLE NOT TO PANIC

TEXT.P: Amid increasing media reports about mainland Chinese military movements, Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Wednesday that the ROC military can safeguard Taiwan and that the public should not worry.

Admitting that there has been increased sorties by mainland Chinese jet fighters on the western side of the Taiwan Strait, and approaching the mid-line of the strait, Tang pointed out that it is not the first time such increased movement has been reported, citing the events in 1996, when Beijing last used its military muscle to intimidate Taiwan.

The ROC Air Force, in compliance with normal procedure, will make appropriate moves to defend national security as long as such activity does not affect aviation safety on domestic and international commercial routes.
In other words, Tang said, the ROC military has the capability to defend Taiwan, but will not take the initiative to provoke mainland China.

Tang also urged the people of Taiwan to remain calm over speculation by the pro-Beijing Hong Kong media regarding Beijing's military intimidation, and warned local people against of falling for "Beijing's trickery."

"Past experience has demonstrated that the ROC armed forces are capable of handling any incident," he stressed, expressing the hope that the public will help the government build a positive climate across the strait, as Taiwan-mainland ties are vital to the continued development of all Chinese people.

The defense minister made the remarks while addressing the opening ceremony of a military head-hunting center which was witnessed by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Cabinet-level National Youth Commission Chairwoman Lee Jih-chu, and Kuomintang Legislator Wang Tein-ging.

As human resources are the key element to the fate of any enterprise, whether it is a government-run unit or a private firm, Tang said that the center will use professional marketing theory to recruit high-quality manpower for the military in order to inject new blood into the ROC regular armed forces.

Indeed, Tang went on, the military has already achieved initial success in recruiting high quality personnel since the beginning of this year, evident in the 20 percent increase in the number of students who have taken examinations to become career officers or to serve short terms in specialized military schools.

The head-hunting center will eventually expand its network from its present urban-based locations until it has offices throughout the island, as part of a bid to upgrade the quality of the military, he revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN PM MAKES MID-SUMMER CABINET RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien announced a partial Cabinet shuffle Tuesday, moving out five ministers, moving in five new ones and switching six other portfolios.

The ministers switching to other duties are David Anderson (fisheries to environment), Martin Cauchon (secretary's post to national revenue), Pierre Pettigrew (human resources to international trade), Lucienne Robillard (citizenship and immigration to national treasury board), Herb Dhaliwal (revenue to fisheries) and Jane Stewart (Indian affairs to human resources).

The most senior ministers -- Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy, Finance Minister Paul Martin, Health Minister Allan Rock, Defense Minister Art Eggleton and Heritage Minister Sheila Copps -- will maintain their portfolios.

New faces in the cabinet are Newfoundland's George Baker (veterans affairs); Northern Ontario's Robert Nault (Indian affairs); Marina Minna (international cooperation); Elinor Caplan (citizenship and immigration); and Martin Cauchon (Revenue). The new members were sworn in Tuesday afternoon.

Shuffled out of cabinet were Diane Marleau (international cooperation and francophonie), Sergio Marchi (international trade), Marcel Masse (treasury board), Fred Mifflin (veterans affairs) and Christine Stewart (environment).

Secretaries of state, who assist the ministers, are Ethel Blondin-Andrew, children and youth; Raymond Chan, Asia-Pacific; Hedy Fry, multiculturalism and status of women; David Kilgour, Latin America and Africa; Jim Peterson, international financial institutions; Ron Duhamel, western economic diversification and francophonie; Andrew Mitchell, rural development and federal initiative for Northern Ontario; Gilbert Normand, science, research and development; and Denis Coderre, amateur sport.
Prime Minister Chretien is expected to wait until next year before he announces whether he will contest the next federal election. His term expires in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PLANNING LIQUEFIED NATURAL GAS FACILITY

TEXT.P: Singapore is planning to build a US$500 million facility to store liquefied natural gas (LNG) to ensure that it is never short of energy supplies in the next millennium, Singapore's The Business Times reported on Wednesday.
However, a clear picture will only emerge in about a year, after proper studies have been done as to the best location for the plant, the report said.

The report followed news that the Indonesian government has threatened to revoke a contract with an international corporation to build part of a natural gas pipeline between Indonesia and Singapore because of alleged corrupt business practices in Singapore.
The US$8 billion deal was signed in January, under which Indonesia's state-owned Pertamina is to supply natural gas via pipeline to Singapore for 22 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS SEEN CRIPPLING PNG'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Left unchecked, HIV and AIDS could be more serious to Paupa New Guinea (PNG) than droughts and tidal waves, said former PNG Health Minister Peter Barter.
Barter's warning was published on Wednesday by The Post-Courier, a leading newspaper in PNG's capital, Port Moresby.
He said health professionals have provided information showing HIV-AIDS was particularly serious in the capital and said Port Moresby could become the HIV capital.
"The figures I have show that out of a reported total of 1,741, 1,249 of these were reported contracted in Port Moresby," he said.

"Assuming that a mere 10 percent of HIV cases were reported, one must assume that in Port Moresby there could be 17,000 infected with HIV. Worse still, increases reported each quarter indicate a dramatic increase. ... If you project this figure ahead to the year 2010, the least number of HIV cases in Port Moresby could be as high as 100,000." he said.

"In other words, by the year 2010, one in four persons could contract the HIV virus," he said. He warned that if the seriousness of the issue was not recognized, resources would not be used in the right ways to help minimize the outbreak's social, health and economic impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAHAMAS ATHLETE CHARGED WITH SEXUAL ASSAULT AT PAN AM GAMES

TEXT.P: Another scandal has rocked the Pan Am Games in Winnipeg after a 36-year-old Bahamas athlete was charged with one count of sexual assault. Police said Tuesday the suspect is a softball player from the Bahamas.
An investigation was conducted after police received a complaint on Monday. The incident is alleged to have occurred at the Athletes Village, involving a member of the cleaning staff.
The softball player has been released on bail and a court date has been set for Thursday.
The games, which opened on July 23, are set to wrap up Sunday. Besides a string of defections by Cuban athletes and delegation members, the Games have also seen two drug scandals.

Officials confirmed late Tuesday that Dominican high jumper Juana Rosario Arrendel tested positive for a banned substance. The decision means a Canadian who finished in fourth place, Nicole Forrester of Ontario, will now get a bronze medal.

The first drug case at the Games involved Canadian Steve Vezina, the goal tender on the country's roller-blade hockey team. On Sunday, members of the roller-blade team lost their gold medals after Vezina was caught using three banned substances. The United States, which lost the final game 7-6 last week, was awarded first place.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DECIDES TO ENGAGE BURMESE JUNTA

TEXT.P: The Australian government has decided to engage the Burmese junta, causing observers to ponder what will happen to Burma's opposition leader -- Nobel Peace Prize winner Aung San Suu Kyi, and her supporters.
The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday reported that Suu Kyi and her supporters would be sidelined if other countries opt to follow Australia and negotiate with the Burmese junta.

The daily reported that Australia decided to openly break ranks with most Western countries, which maintain strict sanctions against Burma, with its recent decision to negotiate the formation of a human rights commission in that country.

The daily reported Foreign Minister Alexander Downer this week sent the country's human rights commissioner, Chris Sidoti, to Burma where he is holding talks with the Burmese junta, even though Suu Kyi objects to the talks.
The Australian government ignored Suu Kyi's argument that any human rights commission in Burma would have no chance of being effective because of widespread abuses of power by the armed forces.
Canberra said international pressure, including political isolation and trade embargoes, has failed to pressure the Burmese generals into a more conciliatory approach.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE, NZ MINISTERS OKAY GENE FOOD LABELING

TEXT.P: Health ministers from Australia and New Zealand have reached a compromise to introduce mandatory labeling for genetically modified foods, but left open a way for items with low levels of ingredients to escape the net.

The partial agreement was reached at a ministerial meeting in Canberra between Australian and New Zealand health ministers after a series of debates over genetically modified foods, which were prompted by growing concern over whether they could pose health risks.
They agreed to require mandatory labeling of food produced using gene technology and foods containing genetically modified ingredients, a joint communique said.

Final details will be worked out by October with the new rules to go into effect 12 months afterward. The proposed labels will include information that foods might contain genetically modified ingredients approved by health authorities or authorized symbols to reflect genetically modified content, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISPUTE WITH PHILIPPINES SHOULD NOT AFFECT `GO SOUTH' POLICY: CEPD

TEXT.P: The suspension of flight links between Taiwan and the Philippines should not become entangled with Taiwan's "Go South" investment policy, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang said on Wednesday.

Chiang, who is currently visiting Macedonia with Premier Vincent Siew and other high-ranking officials, made the remarks in response to questions from reporters over whether Taiwan should reconsider the "Go South" investment policy in light of the Philippines' unilateral decision to suspend flights into the country by Taiwan-based carriers.

The policy refers to the government's urging of Taiwan businessmen to invest in Southeast Asian countries instead of in mainland China, to avoid excessive economic dependence on Taiwan's political rival across the Taiwan Strait.
Chiang called for both countries to calm down and sensibly reconsider the flight dispute, and stressed that the issue has nothing to do with the "Go South" policy.

Jeffrey Koo, Taiwan's ambassador at large, and also the Chairman of Chinatrust Commercial Bank, echoed Chiang's opinion, saying that exchanges of all kinds with the Philippines are preferable to both sides. Koo is also a member of Siew's mission to the Balkan nation which entered a diplomatic relationship with Taiwan on Jan. 27 this year.
However, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said Manila's decision is likely to discourage Taiwan businessmen, and will also have a negative impact on the country's tourism industry.
He added that if the argument ends up with punitive measures against the Philippines, other ministries will follow up and take measures of their own.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS GROUPS TO FIGHT RAISING OF STOCK TRANSACTION TAX

TEXT.P: In response to reports that the Ministry of Finance (MOF) is to raise the stock transaction tax, the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China (GCC) on Wednesday voiced opposition to the idea.

According to the reports, the stock transaction tax is be increased in September to 0.45 percent from the present 0.3 percent. The GCC is planning to cooperate with two other major business groups -- the Chinese Association of Industry and Commerce and the Chinese National Federation of Industries -- to dissuade the MOF from setting a fixed tax rate and instead, to set a flexible rate subject to the trading situation of the stock market.
During periods of inert trading, the GCC said, such a flexible tax rate could even be set to zero.
According to the CGG, the local stock market will be damaged if the transaction tax is increased, and added that an alternative to the flexible tax scheme would be to maintain the status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE JAMES SOONG TO CONVENE MASS MEETING

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who has declared his candidacy for the 2000 presidential election, is planning to convene a mass meeting on Aug. 14 to drum up support for his presidential bid.

Chin Ching-sheng, spokesman for Soong's campaign office, said that the mass meeting at a riverside park in Taipei County will be a gathering convened with an attitude of sincerity and honesty to bring hope and happiness for all the people of the country.

The gathering will be Soong's first outdoor public meeting since he announced last month that he will run as an independent in the March 2000 election. Soong's office staff estimate that tens of thousands will be attracted to hear Soong's speech.

Soong will explain to the public his policies and positions on domestic and foreign issues, with the aim of winning greater public support for his election bid, Chin noted, stressing that the mass meeting will be solely an exchange of ideas with the people.

Soong's staff declined to comment on the actual contents of his campaign platform, but informed sources said they will be closely related to Soong's ideas for running the government, which includes an efficient government free from money-oriented politics and vested interest, a trans-party government that is caring, systematic and just.

Although there have been reports that the ruling Kuomintang has launched a movement in Taipei County to curtail Soong's warm-up and sponsorship activities, Chin said Soong's camp is not greatly worried about KMT maneuvering, and that Soong's grassroots support will be unbeatable.
Meanwhile, Soong's staff have been busy seeking support from every sector of society, preparing for the formal sponsorship drive to ensure he has enough support to launch an election campaign.
According to presidential election regulations, independent candidates must be endorsed by at least 224,000 voters, a figure which Chin said will be easily surpassed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROGRESS SEEN IN ROC'S PARTICIPATION IN BALKAN RECONSTRUCTION
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By C. P. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's plan to assist in reconstruction of the war-torn Balkan peninsula has taken a step forward as Premier Vincent Siew will make a fact-finding visit to Kosovo on Thursday.

In addition, the ROC has decided to offer aid to the battered Yugoslav province of Kosovo, which lies very close to the ROC's diplomatic ally of Macedonia, via the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development (EBRD).
