Siew, heading a 160-member business and industry delegation, arrived in Skopje, Macedonia's capital, on Tuesday for a five-day official visit.

Besides cementing the newly forged diplomatic ties with Macedonia and helping Taiwan investors tap the vast European market, Siew is also expected to get ideas on how Taipei can effectively implement a US$300 million aid project for Kosovar refugees.

Loh Ping-chang, secretary-general of the ROC's International Cooperation and Development Fund, who is accompanying Siew on his current Macedonia visit, said he reached a four-point consensus with the European Bank during a meeting held in London last week.
According to the consensus, the ROC will join in three aid projects for Macedonia and one for Kosovo.
For one, Loh said the ROC will join forces with the European Bank in offering financing for Macedonian small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) for business expansion or new investment.

"By so doing, we hope Macedonian SMEs will create more job openings to help reduce the country's unemployment rate, which stands at 40 percent presently," Loh said, adding that the aid projects are also aimed at helping buoy the listless Macedonian economy and assisting Taiwan business people in edging into the Balkan and West European markets.
Loh said the Macedonian government will attract Taiwan companies to make turn-key exports to Macedonia by offering land, joint-venture partners and market information.
Loh said the ROC will study feasible ways to tie its aid projects to Kosovo with Taiwan's investment projects in Macedonia.

Meanwhile, ROC Premier Siew officiated at a ground-breaking ceremony for construction of an export processing zone (EPZ) in Macedonia on Wednesday. The EPZ project, designed to accommodate Taiwan-invested companies, is invested by a consortium led by China Development Corp. in which the ROC's ruling Kuomintang has a large stake.
Siew attended a seminar on the Balkan reconstruction plan Wednesday afternoon, during which Siew spoke on Taiwan's current economic situation and its aid project for Kosovo.

Shortly after his arrival in Skopje on Tuesday, Siew held a summit meeting with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski to discuss concrete measures for promoting bilateral trade and economic cooperation.
Siew said he hopes his visit will help open more mutually cooperative projects in economic, industrial, agricultural, educational, journalistic and cultural fields.
During Siew's visit, the ROC and Macedonian governments will sign accords on economic cooperation, information exchange, agricultural development and cooperation, as well as cultural exchange.
The ROC forged full diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE APOLOGIZES FOR AIR TRAFFIC CHAOS

TEXT.P: The Air Force General Headquarters (AFGHQ) apologized on Wednesday for air traffic chaos which resulted from a practice fly-past by the Air Force Academy, and urged the public not to speculate about the issue.

Stressing that the fly-past was part of a rehersal for the Air Force Academy's celebrations to mark the 70th anniversary of its founding, the AFGHQ expressed regret for the inconvenience caused by the activity.

It is understood that the Air Force Academy will stage a large-scale fly-past of scores of a new generation of combat jet fighters, including Indigenous Defense Fighters, US-made F-16s, and French-built Mirage 2000s on Sept. 1 as a show of strength following recent military intimidation of Taiwan by Beijing.

Although the Kaohsiung office of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said it had informed airlines on July 28 of the academy's five rounds of rehearsals, slated from Aug. 4 to Sept. 1, Wednesday's activity still disrupted normal operations at Kaohsiung's Hsiaokang Airport and Pingtung Airport.

Thousands of passengers who were unaware of the Air Force Academy's activity were left waiting for flights at the airports when a total of 17 domestic and international flights were forced to be canceled or delayed because of the rehearsal.

According to the CAA, the Air Force Academy's rehearsal will affect scheduled flights at the Kaohsiung and Pingtung airports for another 13 days between now and Sept. 1, the biggest disruption of civilian air traffic by a single event in Taiwan's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PROTESTS MANILA'S UNFRIENDLY REMARKS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Wednesday protested the Philippine government's unfriendly remarks concerning a bilateral aiviation agreement.

Shih Ting, director of the East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), voiced the proest to Raul Concepcion, acting Philippine representative to the ROC, at his office.

Shih told Concepcion that the Philippine treaty and legal affairs division chief's recent remarks concerning a Taipei-Manila aviation pact has violated the general international regulations and the very basis of the agreement as well as hurt the ROC's national dignity.

The division chief with the Philippine Foreign Ministry said that as the ROC and the Philippines do not have formal diplomatic ties, their 1996 aviation pact was signed on the basis of the Philippine domestic law. Since the pact is a private contract, the Filipino official said, the Philippines can unilaterally cancel it.
Shih said such remarks were inappropriate and unacceptable to the ROC. "We demand that the Philippine government make an official clarification," Shih told Concepcion.
Shih went on to say that Manila's unilateral announcement of its decision to cancel its 1996 aviation agreement with the ROC has rocked the basis of mutual trust between the two countries.
"We hope the Philippine government will abide by the spirit and content of the 1996 agreement and continue negotiations with Taipei in a rational manner for mutual benefits," Shih said.

Shih stressed that the ROC does not like to see the aviation pact issue affect bilateral friendship and future development. Nevertheless, Shih said if the Philippines ignores the seriousness of the incident and fails to take remedial measures, the ROC will certainly adopt necessary countermeasures in retaliation.
Concepcion said he will immediately convey the ROC's stance to the Philippine government.

Meanwhile, MOFA acting spokesman Henry Chen said if direct air links between Taiwan and the Philippines are cut off, the cost for Taiwan investments in the Philippines' Subic Bay will increase sharply. In that case, Taiwan investors will be forced to withdraw their investment there. Moreover, the number of Taiwan tourists to the Philippines, about 180,000 annually at present, will also decline significantly.
The expected decreases in Taiwan investments and tourist arrivals will certainly deal with a severe blow to the Philippines, Chen noted.
"We hope the Philippines will revert its decision to cancel its aviation pact with the ROC from the end of September and resume negotiations to work out a mutually acceptable solution," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPE EXPECTRED TO DRIVE WORLD ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: The economic growth rate of the 11 members of the euro group is expected to reach 3 to 4 percent next year, higher than the rest of the world, according to French official statistics released Wednesday.

French Economics Minister Dominique Strauss-Khan said Monday at the cabinet meeting that French new car license plates in July increased 25 percent compared with the same month last year and that the nation's construction industry also performed very well in July, up approximately 5.3 percent from the same month last year.

Strauss-Khan said the economies of each of the 11 euro groups will grow significantly this year, especially Germany with an estimated growth figure of 3 percent, although the German unemployment rate is still high. French economic growth rate is expected to stand at around 3 percent, he said.
Spain, the euro group nation with the highest unemployment rate, flashed a green light in its economic development in June after its unemployed population fell to 1.55 million, the lowest since 1981.
Experts indicated that because Europe maintains a stable interest rate level, American investors have begun to swarm into the European market.
They expect the Europe economy will recover from the bottom and take the place of the United States to become the main impetus for the growth of world economy.

Beginning Jan. 1, 2000, the European auto market will open up to the outside world. With more and more circulation of the euro currency, prices of European autos will unify and drop by 1.2 percent from the present price. A brisk European auto market is expected to bring about a bullish international auto market.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN STILL THIRD DESPITE GAINS IN POLLS

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan is moving up slightly in public opinion polls after his announcement last Saturday to vie for ruling Kuomintang's nomination for the presidency, but still lags behind James Soong and Chen Shui-bian, according to a newly-released survey.
The poll, conducted between Aug. 1-3 by a local cable TV, the Chinese Television Network, gives Lien an approval rate of 18.7 percent, or an increase of 4.5 percentage points since the end of July.
Meanwhile, former Taiwan Province Governor James Soong, has slid from 37.4 percent to 35.3 percent in the polls.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian stands at 22.5 percent, or an 1.3 percent rise from his July numbers.
The sample has a margin of error of three percentage points, making Soong's decline and Chen's increase less insignificant. Only Lien's increased support is remarkable said the author of the survey.

Additional good news for the vice president is that the share of people who disapprove of Lien has dipped from 22.4 percent to 21.7 percent, compared with the rise of Soong's disapproval rating from 12.7 percent to 16.1 percent. Chen's disapproval rating also increased, from 20.2 percent to 24 percent.

An analysis of the survey found that although 46.6 percent of those surveyed favor Taiwan independence, only 38.6 percent of them said they would vote for the pro-independence candidate Chen Shui-bian. Another 27.8 percent who favor independence support Soong, while 18.4 percent prefer Lien.

At the opposite end of political spectrum, 56.9 percent of those favoring a reunion with mainland China, which account for 24.9 percent of the surveyed, said they would vote for Soong. Lien found favor with 21.6 percent and 11.8 percent chose Chen.
Soong is also the favorite candidate among the 9.3 percent who prefer to keep the status quo. He received 62.5 percent of that segment, compared to 21.9 percent for Lien and 6.3 percent for Chen.
Huang Hui-chen, KMT director general of the Department for Cultural Affairs, predicted that the 2000 race will be a competition between political parties.

In an apparent reference to Soong who is running as an independent, Huang predicted that a candidate without the endorsement of any party will barely make an impact in the race. Huang forecast Lien will garner 40 to 50 percent of all votes on election night.
Claiming that the KMT is well on track to win the election, Huang said his party will press ahead with its campaign strategy and will not pay too much attention to poll findings.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MERITS BETTER SUPPORT FROM THE WEST: CANADIAN DAILY

TEXT.P: A Canadian newspaper on Tuesday called on the West to stop kowtowing to Beijing by humiliating Taiwan, whose democracy may be new and not perfect but whose dissidents do not have to worry about being thrown in jail or "re-education camps."

In an editorial titled "Taiwan merits better support from the West" the Star Phoenix published in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, said that in Asia, the West talks the talk about human rights and democratic ideals, but is unwilling to walk the walk.
"The West kowtows to the repressive People's Republic of China against all reason," the newspaper said.

It noted that the countries of Southeast Asia, following the lead of the United States, have reaffirmed their perfectly ridiculous notion that Taiwan -- the second-strongest Asian economy, home to a population two-thirds the size of Canada and one of the few democracies in the area -- does not really exist.

All this to appease a country that, despite its saber-rattling and displaying of new neutron bombs, is ill-prepared and unwilling to violently confront the rest of the world and risk sabotaging its fragile but growing economy.

For centuries the West has ignored all the evidence and considered China a potential vast, untapped market, the daily said. "It has led to our shame in the past. For instance when Britain, in order to extract hoarded silver, led a war that forced the government in China to accept the opium trade that was killing Chinese people," it added.
Now the greed for trade "is forcing us to ignore a friend and our principles," it continued.

The dispute arose from a statement Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui made to a German journalist that negotiations between Taiwan and Mainland China should be "state to state." That is, both entities deserve equal respect and weight when it comes to discussing issues that affect the two political systems, the Star said.

It quoted David Lee of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Toronto as pointing out that, this was not a declaration of independence but a statement of the obvious. "All we want is to stay alive," he was quoted as saying.

The article noted that Taiwan has been part of mainland China for a mere four years since 1895; since 1949 it has developed a political and economic system that is completely distinct from mainland China's.

In spite of that difference the Taiwanese maintain close familial and cultural ties and dream of one day rejoining the mainland -- but only after the government in Beijing becomes inclusive, responsible and multi-partied. It is not an unreasonable expectation, the daily opined.
Canadians, too, would surely refuse to accept being ruled by an intolerant, communist government that uses violence to crack down on dissent, it said.

Taiwan may be new to democracy and the transition may sometimes be awkward, with fisticuffs breaking out in the legislature. But at least overzealous dissenters are not hauled away to "re-education" or execution, with their body parts harvested for transplants, the daily said.

"We are more than willing to accept the fact Slovenia is no longer part of Yugoslavia, Bangladesh no longer part of Pakistan, Panama no longer part of Colombia, Belize no longer part of Guatemala -- all because it would be completely illogical to think they were.
"Yet, we have blinders on with our unwillingness to recognize the People's Republic of China and Taiwan as two distinct entities, each entitled to international recognition," it said.

"We have drummed Taiwan out of most international bodies and don't allow it the respect of setting up embassies. Whether Taiwan eventually rejoins China or not is a matter to be settled peacefully by the people of those two countries," it stressed.
It is not something the rest of the world should be involved in, either actively or passively, by pretending that Taiwan's independent political and economic systems do not exist, it stated.
"Our participation in the humiliation of our proven friends in Taiwan is a matter for Westerners to hang our heads in shame whenever we think of ourselves as Lone Rangers," it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANS OF EXECUTED SOLDIER TRANSPLANTED INTO 4 PATIENTS

TEXT.P: The organs of an Armed Forces Museum soldier who was shot Tuesday night after being sentenced to death for raping and killing a schoolgirl were transplanted to four patients on Wednesday.
Kuo Ching-ho's heart, liver, kidneys were rushed to a hospital for transplants soon after he was executed.
Doctors on Wednesday implanted the organs into four patients who have been on a waiting list for a long time.
The guard at the Armed Forces Museum raped and killed Chang Fu-chen, a Taipei city high school student, on June 19 when Chang visited the museum to collect data for a school report.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORWAY, TAIWAN TO STEP UP ECONOMIC COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang held talks with Norwegian officials during his visit to Oslo, with both sides agreeing to strengthen bilateral economic cooperation, according to a member of Wang's delegation on Wednesday.
During the trip, Wang conferred with John Lilletun, a rotating minister of the Norwegian government, and Chairman Heiberg of the Norwegian National Trade Commission.

The Norwegian side indicated their intention to cooperate with Taiwan in jointly developing trade in other countries, while the Taiwan side asked Norway to support its bid to join the World Trade Organization at an early date.

In Oslo, Wang also witnessed the signing of a letter of intent on research cooperation between the ROC Economics Ministry's Industrial Development and Investment Center and a Norwegian foundation on scientific and industrial research.
Norway, a major oil and salmon supplier for Taiwan, is attaching a lot of importance to Wang's official visit, the first by a Taiwan cabinet minister in 19 years.
Beijing reportedly tried but failed to force Oslo to alter Wang's agenda. The delegation returned to Taipei on Wednesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON URGED TO ABANDON AMBIGUOUS POLICY TOWARDS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Washington, Aug. 4 (CNA): The Washington Post urged Wednesday the Clinton administration to abandon its policy of "strategic ambiguity" toward Taiwan so as to enhance the chance of deterring war across the Taiwan Straits, securing peace and even fostering good relations with Beijing.

The influential American newspaper wrote in an editorial titled "Taiwan Tensions" that in the past few days Communist China has illegally seized a Taiwanese ship, sent jet fighters provocatively across the Taiwan Straits, repeatedly hurled threats at Taiwan and its elected president and test-fired a new ballistic missile built in part with stolen U.S. technology.

But the Clinton administration response to all these has been, for the most part, to chide Taiwan and make soothing noises toward Beijing. In part, this may reflect the administration's dismay that the Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui reformulated his country's policy toward mainland China without winning Washington's advanced approval, noted the newspaper.

The editorial said the administration's unhappiness is understandable -- but so, unfortunately, is Mr. Lee's behavior. "It was President Clinton, after all, who chose China as the venue for endorsing a new and, from Taiwan's perspective, disadvantageous U.S. policy toward Taiwan. That, along with Mr. Clinton's Beijing-centered policy overall, hasn't fostered trusting relations between the United States and Taiwan."

The Clinton administration isn't responding out of pique; it believes an accommodating attitude toward Beijing is the best way to maintain peace in a dangerous part of the world. Mr. Clinton wants to develop a "strategic constructive partnership" with mainland China's regime, and "to do so he treats friendly democracies in the region -- Taiwan, South Korea, even Japan -- as if they were of secondary importance," added the editorial.

The Washington Post pointed out that "That's why Mr. Clinton accepts China's fiction that Taiwan is not a separate state. That's why he accepts as legitimate China's parallel views of Taiwan and Hong Kong, even though Hong Kong -- now incorporated into China -- was a colony and never a free entity."

Mr. Clinton said recently that Beijing has made clear "a sensitivity to the different system that exists on Taiwan, and a willingness to find ways to accommodate it, as they did in working with Hong Kong, and perhaps, even going beyond that."

But the people of Hong Kong were given no say before being turned over by Britain to the mercies of Beijing's dictators. Mr. Clinton should say that such an outcome would be acceptable for Taiwan only with the explicit consent of the Taiwanese people, stressed the editorial.

Instead, the editorial said, the United States maintains a policy of "strategic ambiguity," warning Communist China against the use of force "without explicitly promising to defend Taiwan against Chinese attack."

The Washington Post concluded that "This murkiness is designed to discourage Taiwan from recklessly declaring independence. The danger, though, is that China, rather than Taiwan, will misjudge U.S. steadfastness. In the long run, there will be more chance of deterring war, securing peace and even fostering good relations with China if the United States opts for clarity, not ambiguity, in showing support for its true friends in the region." (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-FINANCED SKOPJE EXPORT PROCESSING ZONE STARTS CONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew and his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski on Wednesday jointly presided over a ceremony beginning the construction of the Skopje Export Processing Zone.

The project, supported by the Macedonian government, is financed by Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF), and will be used by Taiwan businessmen as a base for expanding trade to neighboring countries.
Speaking at the ceremony, Siew said that construction of the Skopje Export Processing Zone is a transfer of the "Taiwan experience."

Georgievski called the reconstruction of the Macedonian economy the priority of his government. He expressed his belief that the sharing of the Taiwan experience would revitalize his country's economy.
The projected export processing zone covers 183 hectares in southeastern Skopje. About 30 hectares of land will be developed in the initial phase.
According to ICDF Secretary-General Lo Ping-chang, eight Taiwan enterprises have indicated their willingness to set up factories in the zone.
Siew led a 100-member delegation to Macedonia on Tuesday for a five-day official visit. Macedonia established diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan in January of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-MANILA DISPUTE WILL NOT AFFECT ROC INVESTMENT POLICY

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 4,(CNA): Vice Foreign Minister David Lee told a group of legislators of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday that the government's "go-south" investment policy would not change because of the controversy involving Manila-Taipei air links.
Lee made the remarks while meeting with the lawmakers who came to express their grave concern that the Taipei-Manila air link was unilaterally scraped by the Philippine government last Monday.

The DPP legislators who called on Lee were Wang Hsieh-feng, Tsai Tung-jung and Lin Kuo-hwa. Shi Ting, director general of the Asia-Pacific Affairs Department of the Foreign Ministry and Henry Chen, acting director general of the Information and Cultural Affairs Department of the Foreign Ministry were also present at the meeting.

Female legislator Wang Hsueh-feng queried Lee whether it was possible that the Philippine government would reverse its decision after evaluating the situation. Lee said that the ROC government is optimistic about the resolution of the issue. In fact, he added, the air link is much in the interest of the Philippines, and once the link was cut, the result will be a loss-loss scenario.

A senior official at the Manila Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei was summoned on Wednesday to the ROC Foreign Ministry's Asia-Pacific Department to receive the ROC government formal protest against the remarks by the director general of the Legal and Treaty Department of the Philippine Foreign Ministry. The director general earlier this week described the Taipei-Manila air accord as a private agreement since the Philippines government abides by its "one China" policy.
At the same time, a group of civilians held a protest outside the Manila Economic & Cultural Office in Taipei.

Lee pointed out that politics was not involved in the current Taipei-Manila air link dispute. The problem resulted from Philippine Airlines being jealous of the profitable operations of Taiwan's China Airlines and Eva Air.

In case the link is interrupted, "We will not let Philippine Airlines fly into Taiwan," Lee warned. He hoped that Philippine authorities would calm down and consider the issue on the basis of the mutual benefits so as not to harm both parties.

He said that the case has not yet seen the lowering of the curtain. There is still a 55-day period before the accord expires so there is still a chance the issue will be resolved. "We don't need to show our trump card at the beginning. Before the talks begin, we should examine the chips in our hand. In addition, we can employ the 'carrot and stick' approach," said Lee.

Wang said that the Philippine government is not willing to peacefully settle the issue, and the ROC government should map out counter measures. She said the people will back the government's action, otherwise, there will be no air accord, no economic interest and no dignity of the nation, resulting in a domino effect.

Legislator Trong Tsai stressed that sanctions alone will not resolve the air issue. "We should resolve the problem through negotiations and consultations. Otherwise, it will demonstrate our incapability in dealing with the international disputes," he said.
Meanwhile in the Philippines, it was reported that the Philippine government intends to renegotiate with the ROC for a new air link accord.

However, an official with the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the ROC Ministry of Transportation and Communications said that renegotiations will be meaninglessness if the Philippine side does not restore the spirit of the original accord.

Also on Wednesday, the Taipei Manpower Brokerage Agencies Association, which strongly supports the ROC government's suspension of the import of new Filipino workers, strongly criticized the Foreign Ministry for being weak and ineffective in dealing with the current controversy. Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP TO OPEN IN KAOHSIUNG ON THURSDAY

TEXT.P: The 18th IBM Junior World Championship AAA level is to open on Thursday in Kaohsiung County in front of scores of scouts from Major League Baseball.
A total of 12 national teams will compete in the 10-day event organized by the International Baseball Association, said the organizer.

Touting the tournament as bringing together the best young players in the world, Lin Chong-chen, executive secretary of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association said at a press conference Wednesday that almost all the participating teams are considered world class.

Lin said the Cuba, Panama, United States and Venezuela finished one through four at the Pan American Junior Baseball Championship, while Japan, Chinese Taipei and South Korea were first, second and third at the Asian Junior Baseball Championship. The Cubans, who have been preparing for the tournament by scrimmaging against professional teams from Taiwan, are the favorites to walk away as champions.

The Netherlands and the Czech Republic are the champions and the third-place finisher respectively at the European Championship, while Australia is the champion of Ocenia, and South Africa the champion of Africa.
Italy, the runner-up of European Championship didn't come, and was replaced by Guam, said Lin.
Chinese Taipei will confront South Korea in the opening game on Thursday. The 12 teams will then be divided into two groups to slug it out in a round robin tournament.
Group A includes Cuba, South Korea, Chinese Taipei, Venezuela, the Netherlands and South Africa.
Group B includes the United States, Japan, Guam, Australia, Panama, and the Czech Republic.
The 10-tournament is expected to draw the largest total sports audience in the ROC's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIOT BREAKS OUT AT JONES CUP

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won by forfeit after the professional team representing the Philippines refused to return to the floor following a free-for-all fight between the Filipino players and the host Chinese Taipei men's national team Wednesday during the third day of the 22nd annual William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament.

The riot stemmed from a brawl between players of the two teams and resulted in fans throwing water bottles and chairs onto the court with Filipino players throwing chairs back at fans. As a result three fans were sent to hospital for treatment of slight injuries.

The two referees awarded the victory to Chinese Taipei, which was leading 66-42 when the game was disrupted. The Philippine team refused to resume the game within the one-minute time prescribed by the officiating crew.

The melee began when Chinese Taipei player Huang Chun-hsiung struck the back of the head of his Filipino rival Joey Mente in retaliation for the latter's elbowing him in the stomach. Mente's teammate Elpidio Villamin immediately struck Huang in retaliation. Soon all 12 players on both teams had thrown punches.
Before the referees could stop the fisticuffs, jeering fans began throwing objects onto the ground. Filipino players responded by throwing chairs back at the fan.
After the riot, the Philippine players were escorted to their locker room by police.

Wednesday's win placed Chinese Taipei at the top of Group A with three wins and no loss, while the Philippines dropped to third place. The two top teams from Groups A and B will meet in Friday's playoffs. Costa Rica is expected to join Chinese Taipei in making the playoffs from Group A.

In the previous two games of Wednesday, in Group B action South Korea beat New Zealand 62-53, and Kuang Hwa (Taipei) beat South Africa 81-37. South Korea and New Zealand are expected to advance from Group B.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Defense Minister Tang Fei said the military keeps proper alert for self-defense purposes.
The China Times:
US Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth sees uncertainty in relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The United Daily News:
Both the US Department of State and Pentagon oppose the Senate-proposed Taiwan Security Enhancement Bill.
The Liberty Times:
Communist China rejects Taiwan Mainland Affairs Council's explanation of the "state-to-state" theory.
The Commons Daily:
Defense Minister Tang said the ROC armed forces is capable of defending Taiwan.
The China Post:
Room for negotiation in ROC-RP aviation row.
The Taiwan News:
Ministry demanding sovereign treatment for air-link talks with Manila.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US OFFICIAL CALLS FOR RECOGNITION OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: It is time for the United States to adopt a two-China policy and the ultimate result of America's extending full diplomatic recognition to Taiwan would be enhanced peace and stability in East Asia, according to a former U.S. assistant secretary of state for international affairs.

John R. Bolton, senior vice president of the American Enterprise Institute, wrote in the latest issue of The Weekly Standard, a monthly magazine published in Washington, that "Once it were clear that the United States would not permit the PRC to bully Taiwan, the prospects for peaceful cross-strait ties would grow, not diminish. Beijing's temptation to adventurism throughout the region -- which the Clinton administration's deference feeds -- would shrink."
The legal expert said, "This may sound familiar: It is what a truly Reaganite foreign policy produces. It has worked before. Will Republican (presidential) candidates embrace it?"

Bolton noted that watching the Clinton administration criticize Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui for calling his country a "state," it is tempting to ask how Ronald Reagan would have reacted. This is far from an academic question, at a time when Republican presidential candidates and others are striving to formulate a post-Clinton foreign policy, he said.

Early in the 1980 campaign, candidate Reagan said he wanted to restore full diplomatic recognition to the Republic of China. And Bolton admitted it is true that in 1980 some of his top campaign advisers ultimately talked Reagan out of espousing full diplomatic recognition of Taiwan.

But today, almost 20 years later and in vastly different circumstances, what would a Reaganite policy on Taiwan look like? Both for compelling moral reasons and as a matter of US national interests, Bolton said, "the Reaganite answer is diplomatic recognition."

The former assistant secretary of state during the Bush administration claimed that full diplomatic recognition of Taiwan "would advance key American interests by ratifying the self-evident reality on the island, and by shattering the Clinton policy of deference toward Beijing."

The United States desperately needs to create a balance-of-power structure in East Asia, building on existing alliances with Japan and South Korea. This would not be a traditional alliance like NATO, at least in the foreseeable future, but it would encompass something more than the ad hoc relations that now exist. And Bolton said, "Upgrading the Washington-Taipei relationship would be a major step toward creating such a regional balance."

By contrast, the Clinton administration believes that deferring to Beijing will prompt the leaders there to moderate the scarcely veiled threats with which they responded to President Lee's remarks. "But Beijing has the Clinton administration's number, and each US act of deference simply expands the PRC's appetite," wrote Bolton.

Moreover, he continued, Japan and South Korea interpret US deference to Beijing as an implicit rejection of partnership with them. They conclude that "the United States simply cannot be counted on to protect our mutual interests in the region. If this continues, Japan will be tempted to proceed more often unilaterally, no gain for Asian stability, while Seoul may gravitate into Beijing's orbit, before, and even more after, reunification with North Korea."
Bolton stressed that none of this would be in America's interest, "but it would flow inevitably from Washington's deference to the PRC."

Indeed, he pointed out, the only objection to full diplomatic recognition of Taiwan is that Beijing would erupt in rhetorical outrage, perhaps including threats of military force, and would attempt economic reprisals against the United States such as the cancellation of commercial contracts.

"At least for a period, our recognition of Taipei would leave us isolated. Some of our European friends would welcome an opportunity to profit at our expense, and others would cringe before Beijing's fulminations," added Bolton.

But he is convinced that diplomatic recognition of Taiwan "would be just the kind of demonstration of US leadership that the region needs and that many of its people hope for. For too long, Beijing has indulged in angry and intemperate language reminiscent of Nikita Khrushchev's performance at the United Nations when he pounded his shoe on his desk.

DOC.HEADLINE: HELMS PROPOSES TO BOOST ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC) said Wednesday that the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act is aimed to ensure that Taiwan will have the essential self-defense capabilities, and to accomplish this he and Sen. Robert G. Torricelli (D-NJ) proposed to bolster the process for defense sales to Taiwan and help Taiwan achieve and maintain an adequate military readiness.

Both Stanley Roth, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, and Kurt Campbell, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense, however, voiced the Clinton administration's strong opposition to this legislation, claiming that the Taiwan Relations Act has worked very well to maintain peace and stability in the Western Pacific and the unintended consequences of the new bill are likely to be dangerous.
Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman Helms stressed in his opening statement that "the need to enhance our defense relationship is obvious" due to the following reasons:

The reunification of Taiwan has become an increasingly high agitation issue for Beijing; Beijing constantly demonstrates a willingness to use intimidation to achieve its goal; part of Beijing's strategy is to continue its pressure on the US to limit or cease arms sales to Taiwan; and "our friends in Taiwan have a military capability that has operated in virtual isolation for over twenty years."

Taiwan's military does not conduct joint exercises with the US military and is not even able to observe many of American exercises. No US officers above the rank of colonel or Navy captain can go to Taiwan and those who do are limited in the things they can say and do. "This has certainly had a corrosive effect on Taiwan's military preparedness, at exactly the time Taiwan faces a growing military threat from China," explained the senior Republican senator.

Helms added that "The United States' strategic interests, US law and US moral values dictate that we assist our long-time friends on Taiwan in meeting these challenges and that is why Sen. Torricelli and I introduced this bill" in March.

But Sen. Joseph R. Biden (D-DE) then pointed out that the Taiwan Relations Act, which he voted for 20 years ago, has helped peace and stability in the Western Pacific and "China should have no doubt that our commitment (to Taiwan's security) remains firm."

And he said he is concerned that passage of this new legislation "would be the equivalent of waving a red cape in front of Beijing and inviting China to charge" against Taiwan, because there is no security measure included in the new bill that is precluded by the Taiwan Relations Act and the bill's mistaken conclusion that Taiwan security is primarily a function of its military capabilities.

Taiwan's security, Biden believed, "flows from its democratic form of government, its growing economic, cultural and political contacts with the mainland, and ultimately, the United States' abiding commitment to a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan question."

Therefore, he said, "we should concentrate on strengthening those areas rather than spend time preauthorizing the sales of weapon systems, some of which don't even exist yet." He is also convinced that the timing of this bill is very ill-timed, since US relations with Communist China leave a lot to be desired at the moment.

Biden added that there is no single issue with greater potential to bring the US and the PRC into conflict than Taiwan, and "a surefire way to spark such a conflict is for the US to reinforce the growing perception in Beijing, however mistakenly it may be, that the US is hostile to China or pursuing the fragmentation of China."

Sen. Max Baucus (D-MT) also said what is needed now more than ever is "dialogue across the Taiwan Strait -- dialogue without Taiwan attempting to change the framework unilaterally, and dialogue without the PRC making belligerent threats, taking military action, or trying in other ways to squeeze Taiwan."

Helms and Torricelli introduced the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act in late March mainly because Beijing has consistently refused to renounce the use of force against Taiwan and has repeatedly threatened force against Taiwan.
The act authorizes the US president to sell Taiwan such defense equipment as theater missile defense equipment and related items, ground-based and naval-based missile defense systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: TORONTO TO HOST 2004 WORLD AIDS CONGRESS

TEXT.P: As many as 15,000 delegates will gather in Toronto in 2004 for one of the biggest medical conference on earth -- the World AIDS Congress.
Canada has previously hosted the AIDS congress in Montreal in 1989 and in Vancouver in 1996.
The conference has been held in the United States three times, but new travel restrictions on AIDS and HIV victims now prevent it from being scheduled in that country.
The medical meeting is expected to inject about C$15 million into Toronto's economy, which is already the locomotive of the Canadian economy.
But Ron Rosenes of AIDS Action Now said the congress is much more than a financial bonanza for the host city.
"This is our opportunity to give the epidemic a human face," Rosenes said Wednesday, after Toronto Mayor Mel Lastman announced the city had been chosen to host the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 5 or the 24th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: Henry I, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, is crowned in Westminster Abbey, three days after his brother, William Rufus, was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest.
1858: The laying of the world's first transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland is completed.
1729: Thomas Newcomen, the Englishman who invented the first automatic steam engine, dies.
1792: Friderick North, British politician known as "Lord North," dies at the age of 60. He served as prime minister (1770-1782) under George III and instituted policies that led to the rebellion of the American colonies.
1861: A national income tax is introduced in the United States, initially to fund the Civil War.
1895: Friedrich Engels, German socialist theorist and writer, dies at the age of 75. He met Karl Marx in Paris in 1844 and collaborated with him on "The Communist Manifesto" in 1848.
1914: The first electric traffic lights are installed, in Cleveland, Ohio.
1921: The world's first driver-less remote-control car is successfully tested in Dayton, a city of southwest Ohio.
1930: Neil Armstrong, American astronaut and the first man on the moon, is born.
1948: The ROC and the United States agree to organize the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction (JCRR) with Chiang Meng-lin, James Yen, and Shen Chung-han from the ROC and Dr. Raymond T. Moyer and Dr. John Earl Baker from the US as commissioners.
1949: The United States issues a "White Paper" on Sino-American relations, blaming the Nationalist government for the occupation of the Chinese mainland by the communists.
1950: A Kuomintang Central Reform Committee is set up in Taipei.
1950: The US 13th Air Force is stationed in Taiwan to help the ROC guard against possible Chinese communist air attacks.
1952: The first Japanese Embassy in the Republic of China officially opens in Taipei's Chungshan North Road, following the exchange of diplomatic notes ratifying the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty.
1953: UN forces begin exchange prisoners of war at Panmunjom with North Korean military authorities.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Liberia.
1958: The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus completes an historic 2,000 mile (3,200 km) underwater journey from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Greenland Sea, passing directly under the North Pole during its five-day voyage.
1958: Vice President Chen Cheng, who was appointed on July 1 to the concurrent post of president of the Executive Yuan, presides over a ceremony laying the foundation for the construction of the NT$3,200 million Shihmen Dam.
1984: Richard Burton, Welsh-born actor and twice husband of actress Elizabeth Taylor, dies of a stroke at his home in Switzerland.
1986: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team leaves for Moscow to compete in the 10th Women's Basketball World Championships.
1990: Iraq claims that its troops have begun withdrawing from Kuwait.
1990: President George Bush sends US Marines into the Liberian capital of Monrovia, to evacuate American nationals and protect the US embassy.
1991: President Lee Teng-hui receives Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By strictly limiting the time of their service and making all imposts as light as possible: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to the mass of the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WARNS US AGAINST KOSOVO FORMULA IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Mainland China has warned the United States that it should not try to repeat the "Kosovo formula" in Asia because it might not have the support of its allies, including Japan and Australia.

In an exclusive interview with the Australian Financial Review, Chinese ambassador to Canberra, Zhou Wenzhong said Australia and Japan would not necessarily join a NATO-style action in intervening in another country's affairs.

The daily on Thursday quoted Zhou as saying, "The US has a powerful military, but it is a big world and the US should not try to extend its power in Asia in this way. Asia is not Europe." His warning comes as China confronts Taiwan and Beijing is angry at signs that the US might favor Taiwan in the contest, the daily reported.
Zhou, who was China's second top diplomat in Chinese embassy in Washington before taking up his present job, said the US and its NATO allies had crossed "a watershed" in Kosovo.

"China, Russia, India and other countries are very concerned about such a policy of putting human rights above national sovereignty. This is not right. But would the US have the same support from its allies in Asia if it were doing the same thing here? I doubt it," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA NERVOUS ABOUT FRENCH BID ON DEFENSE COMP.

TEXT.P: Australia is getting nervous about the bid by a French company to buy its defense development company because of its political, diplomatic and security-policy struggle inside the federal government, the Australian Financial Review reported on Thursday.

The daily reported the struggle centers on rising concerns over the sale of ADI (Australian Defense Institute) Ltd. to a consortium controlled by the major French defense firm -- Transfield-Thomson CSF, and over the regional employment consequences of the break-up of ADI by a rival consortium.

The ADI sale now looms as a litmus test of Australia's new and improved relations with France, with French ambassador due to meet Prime Minister John Howard to discuss the sale soon, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA BUYING AUST. LNG IN RETURN FOR SUPPORT AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland China is working out a US$10 billion agreement to buy liquefied natural gas from Australia as a reward of Canberra's support in its confrontation with Taiwan, a leading business daily reported.

The Australian Financial Review on Thursday reported President Jiang Zemin is expected to announce the huge agreement between China and Australia, the biggest LNG supply contract for Australia since Japan signed up to buy the Australian LNG more than a decade ago.

Zhou Wenzhong, Chinese ambassador to Australia, told the daily's Asia-Pacific editor Peter Hartcher in an interview that such a deal was preceding on the basis of the extremely good state of relations between China and Australia.

In particular, China has been pleased at Australia's unequivocal support in its confrontation with Taiwan. By contrast, it is displeased with the US's handling of the dispute between China and Taiwan, which came after President Lee Teng-hui's statement that the relations between Taipei and Beijing should be on a "special state-to-state" basis. Jiang is due to visit Australia in early September and Zhou told the daily that "the two sides are working on a deal by the time of the President's visit." The daily reported China is going to buy 3 million tons of LNG a year from Australia in the next five years and the contract will be a 20-year term.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF REBUTS BEIJING'S DENIAL OF PREVIOUS CONSENSUS ON 'ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Thursday rebutted Beijing's denial of a previous consensus on the "one China" principle.

SEF said it reached an important consensus with its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- in November 1992 that each side is allowed its own definition of "one China."

The Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) under mainland China's State Council, however, claimed on Wednesday that the 1992 SEF-ARATS consensus was that both sides of the Taiwan Strait support the "one China" principle.

"Taiwan authorities have distorted the consensus as 'each side is allowed its own interpretation of one China,'" the TAO claimed, adding that the distortion was aimed at facilitating promotion of secessionist concepts.
The TAO further said the ARATS has and will never recognized the Taiwan-fabricated principle of "each side is allowed its own one-China definition."
The TAO's accusation was seen as a response to the release of a position paper by the Republic of China's Mainland Affair Council over the weekend on the "state-to-state" theory.
Commenting on the TAO's statement, SEF said it had negotiated with ARATS for more than two years before they managed to reach the consensus that each side can have its own "one China" definition.

"The TAO's statement was not true," SEF said, adding that documents detailing the 10-plus rounds of bilateral talks on the principle in the early 1990s have long been known to the international community.
"Mainland authorities should not deny such facts," SEF stressed.

It further said if Beijing has different opinions about the issue, the two sides should conduct dialogue or consultations to seek a common ground on their dispute. "Without dialogue, the two sides can never find a mutually acceptable solution," SEF said.
Meanwhile, SEF reiterated its welcome to ARATS President Wang Daohan's much-anticipated visit to Taiwan this autumn to continue constructive dialogue between the two sides.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which oversees SEF operations, said it has authorized SEF to further clarify the 1992 SEF-ARATS consensus on the "each side is allowed its 'one China' definition" principle at 4 p.m. Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET OK'S ROC-THAILAND ACCORD ON AVOIDANCE OF DOUBLE TAXATION

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Thursday at its weekly routine meeting an agreement on the avoidance of double taxation and the prevention of tax evasion between the Republic of China and Thailand.
The agreement was jointly signed on July 9 by representatives of the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Thailand and Thailand Economic and Trade Office in Taipei.
The Cabinet said the ROC and Thailand signed the accord in a bid to promote bilateral friendship, cooperation and investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEN URGES TAIWAN PEOPLE NOT TO BUCKLE UNDER MAINLAND PRESSURE

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bien, presidential candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, urged the people of Taiwan on Thursday not to compromise and yield to pressure from mainland Chinese military threats.

Recent US reports confirmed that mainland China has stepped up its air force exercises near the Taiwan Strait, and the United States has urged both sides of the strait to restrain from causing unnecessary conflicts.

Chen, who has always advocated the importance of national security, in response to reporters' questions on how to "deal with the crisis," said that quite often "outside threats are not as intimidating as inner fears."
He urged the Taiwan people not to buckle under pressure from mainland China, adding that in the face of crisis, Taiwan must keep its faith to "confront, overcome and surmount" all problems.
"People have human dignity, as countries have national integrity," the former Taipei mayor said, and he encouraged the public to have confidence in themselves and in Taiwan.

Chen said the main problem between mainland China and Taiwan is that both sides do not have enough trust in each other. It is "unquestionable" that Taiwan is an independent sovereign country, he said, and it is imperative that "we do not give in first."

In response to the US State Department's opposition to the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, proposed by Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), Chen expressed his appreciation for Helms' support of Taiwan, saying this represents the "voice of the US private sector."

While the US administration might "hold a different view," Chen said the fact is that Taiwan's security is an inseparable part of the whole Asian-Pacific system. The best protection for Taiwan is the internationalization of the Taiwan issue, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER CALLS FOR 'WIN-WIN' RESULT IN ROC-PHILIPPINE DISPUTE

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan Thursday instructed related Republic of China ministries to resolve the Taipei-Manila air link dispute under the goal of achieving a "win-win" result.

During Thursday morning's routine Executive Yuan session, Liu, who was chairman of the meeting, asked Vice Foreign Minister David Lee to report on the latest development of the Taiwan-Philippine air link issue.

The Philippines unilaterally announced on Monday that it will terminate its 1996 civil aviation agreement with the ROC at the end of September. Filipino authorities claimed that Taiwan carriers have abused their operational rights for windfall profits.

After the meeting, Frederic Chang, deputy director-general of the Government Information Office, recounted Liu's instructions that this dispute involves both air link rights and Filipino foreign officials' "improper use of words."
The vice premier hoped that Taiwan will work toward achieving a "win-win" result, consolidating all government and private efforts to bid for its rights and resume air link contracts, Chang said.

Lee told the morning's session that Manila's unilateral termination of bilateral air links was against the 1996 agreement, since it did not give the ROC a year's notice before making the announcement.
Moreover, he added, the Filipino foreign ministry's "inappropriate statement" was detrimental to the ROC's national dignity.

Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng pointed out that according to the ROC-Philippine aviation agreement, each side is allowed to carry 9,600 passengers to the other country per week.
Until now, however, the Philippines has met only 10 percent of its quota while Taiwan has reached its full passenger capacity, resulting in a great disparity, he said.
The Filipino government has demanded that the passenger capacity be lowered to 4,000 passengers each week. Otherwise it has threatened to terminate the aviation agreement at the end of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE WILL NOT PROVOKE, NOR SUCCUMB TO, MAINLAND AIR THREATS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force will not provoke, nor succumb to, mainland Chinese military threats over the Taiwan Strait, Major General Jen Yu-sheng, deputy chief of staff of the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGHQ) said Thursday.

The AFGHQ held a press conference at the air force recreational center Thursday morning to clarify recent media reports of increased sorties by mainland Chinese jet fighters over the Taiwan Strait amid the US government's warning of self-restraint to both sides of the strait.
Jen admitted that mainland China has increased the number of its jet fighter exercises, but said there were no "unusual movements or developments" by the mainland military.

The ROC Air Force will comply with normal procedure in defending national security as long as such activities do not affect aviation safety of domestic and international commercial routes, he said. Jen added that the ROC military has the capability to defend Taiwan.
He also pointed out that since the Taiwan Strait is limited in both its depth and width, any air force exercise by mainland China is a direct threat to Taiwan's air defense.
To uphold the island's national security, Jen said the ROC Air Force must have enough military strength to guard against military activities from the other side of the strait.

The Air Force's principle is that it will not "initiate any provocation against mainland China, nor will it succumb to mainland air threats," the major general said. He went to say that the Air Force will closely monitor all movements by the mainland and respond to any movements according to air defense procedure.

Jen also apologized for Wednesday's air traffic chaos, caused when Air Force Academy fighter jets practiced a fly-past over the academy as part of the rehearsal for the academy's 70th anniversary celebrations.

He stressed that the fly-past was a simple rehearsal, not a military exercise, and urged the public not to speculate about the issue. Jen expressed the AFGHQ's regret for any inconvenience caused by the rehearsal.

According to the Air Force Academy, areas in the future that will be affected by the rehearsals include Kaohsiung, Tainan and Pintung. Since these areas have airports that host flights to and from Taipei, almost all civilian air traffic would be affected for another 12 days between now and Sept. 1.

Jen said the Civil Aeronautics Administration has approved the academy's five rounds of rehearsal between Aug. 4-Sept. 1, and that domestic airlines were informed on July 28 of Wednesday's activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices fell 2.1 percent to below the psychologically important 7,000-point level on Thursday to their lowest point in more than two months amid tensions with mainland China.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index dived 151.07 points, finishing the day at 6,959.73, its lowest level since April 31 when it closed at 6,881.72 points.
A total of 1.39 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$58.45 billion (US$1.82 billion), down from the previous session's NT$63.45 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, all sectors reported losses for the day, with financial shares suffering the largest hit, dropping 4 percent.
Textile stocks fell 3.1 percent, followed by cement shares, which closed 2.7 percent lower. Plastic and chemical issues posted a 2.4-percent loss, and construction stocks declined 1.8 percent.
The foodstuff sector fell 1.4 percent, paper and pulp shares decreased 1.3 percent and electronics stocks moved down 1.1 percent.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market saw a 3.35-point dive, closing at 155.77 points, with a turnover of NT$2.87 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August dived 137 points to close at 6,958 points, with 3,977 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September dropped 115 points, ending the day at 6,975 points, while those for December fell 100 points to close at 7,000 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 280 and 11, respectively.

Futures for next March saw a slight decline of 10 points, closing at 7,100 points, with 6 contract transactions. Next June's futures suffered a 135-point setback to close at 7,050, with 3 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,095 points for August, 7,090 points for September, 7,100 points for December, 7,110 points for next March and 7,185 points for next June.
The recently launched electronics futures (TE) and financial futures (TF) both reported losses for the day.

August TE futures slid 1.25 points to close at 304.75, with 1,043 contract transactions; September TE futures decreased 3 points to finish at 305 points, with 21 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for the other months.

August TF futures fell 43.8 points, ending the day at 1,007.2, with 199 contract transactions; September TF futures lost 46.6 points to close at 1,009 points, with 4 contract transactions. There were no transaction records for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEEFING UP TAIWAN'S SECURITY HELPFUL TO REGIONAL STABILITY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A Foreign Ministry official said on Thursday that enhancing Taiwan's security will certainly contribute to security and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region.

The official, who demanded anonymity, was commenting on a hearing in the US Senate on a Taiwan Security Enhancement Bill, jointly introduced by Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC) and Sen. Robert G. Torricelli (D-NJ).

During the hearing, both Stanley Roth, assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs, and Kurt Campbell, deputy assistant secretary of defense, voiced the Clinton administration's strong opposition to the bill.
The Foreign Ministry official said he cannot make a comprehensive evaluation until he obtains a detailed report on the hearing and the US officials' remarks.

Nevertheless, the official said the US executive branch has a consistent commitment to Taiwan's security and has repeatedly stressed that it will abide by the provision of the Taiwan Relations Act, the US law that regulates relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
Noting that the US Congress has shown even greater concern about Taiwan's security, the official said the US executive and legislative branches are consistent in their stances on Taiwan's security.

Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Torricelli introduced the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act in late March mainly because Beijing has consistently refused to renounce the use of force against Taiwan and has repeatedly threatened force against Taiwan.
The act authorizes the US president to sell Taiwan such defense equipment as theater missile defense equipment and related items, ground-based and naval-based missile defense systems.
Helms said at Wednesday's hearing that the bill is aimed at ensuring that Taiwan will have the essential self-defense capabilities.
To accomplish this, Helms said he and Sen. Torricelli proposed to bolster the process for defense sales to Taiwan and help Taiwan achieve and maintain an adequate military readiness.

Echoing Helms view, the Foreign Ministry official said he believes that strengthening Taiwan's security will not only contribute to stability in the Taiwan Strait but also help maintain regional security in the Asia-Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SECOND QUARTER ECONOMIC GROWTH TO BE REVISED UPWARD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is expected to score 5.7-percent growth in the second quarter, significantly higher than a previous estimate of 4.97 percent, according to government officials Thursday.

Officials at the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) pointed out that the island's economic growth in the upper half of 1999 is expected to reach 5 percent, and annual growth of 5.5 percent is likely to be achieved, which is the goal set by the government for this year.

Koo Bin-cheng, deputy director of DGBAS's Third Bureau, noted that an overall review of Taiwan's economic situation in the first half of 1999 will be held on Aug. 20, and the DGBAS will make public the island's actual economic growth from January to June.
An annual growth prediction of 5.3 percent to 5.5 percent for this year is just a primary assessment that did not take non-economic factors into consideration, Koo stressed.

Koo said factors that may affect Taiwan's economic performance include the future performance of the US economy, a devaluation of the mainland Chinese renminbi, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the question of whether construction will proceed on schedule for Taiwan's high-speed railway and for its tallest financial building.
The island's economic growth would decrease by 0.5 percent next year if the high-speed railway were not built as planned, said Koo.
Meanwhile, July's consumers' price index dropped 0.81 percent, a slide for the second consecutive month, according to the monthly report released by the DGBAS.
The annual increase in the consumers' price index for 1999 is expected to drop to under 1 percent; thus overall domestic prices will be kept stable this year, said the deputy director.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR HITS 17-MONTH HIGH AGAINST GREENBACK

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar hit a 17-month high against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at 32.086.
Thursday's closing level was 1.3 cents higher than that of Wednesday.
The local currency opened at 32.075 and was traded between 32.059 and 32.146.
Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$401.5 million.
An overnight plunge on Wall Street, due mainly to investors' fear that US interest rates would rise amid worries over inflationary economic pressure, resulted in the greenback's bearishness.

Dealers said the Japanese yen's bullishness in international markets and confidence-building statements by the Central Bank of China have prompted the NT dollar to go strong. The local currency will probably continue to soar and break the 32: 1 level against the US dollar, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE 35TH WORLD JAMBOREE WILL BE HELD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The 35th World Rover Jamboree, to be held in Taiwan in 2004, is expected to attract more than 10,000 Rover Boy Scouts from 151 counties.

During the 35th World Scout Conference Thursday in Durban, South Africa, 116 member countries voted for Taiwan to host the 35th Rover Jamboree in 2004. Taiwan will be the first Asian country to host the Jamboree in seventy years. (Michelle Tseng)
