DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE JOLTS SOUTHEASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.1 on the Richter scale jolted southeastern Taiwan early on Thursday morning, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.
No casualties or damage were reported.
The tremor hit at 5:03 a.m., with its epicenter located at latitude 22.80 degrees north, longitude 121.12 degrees east, or 5.3 kilometers northwest of Taitung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE MEN'S BASKETBALL TEAM CUTS SHORT STAY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Philippine men's basketball team involved in a melee during a Jones Cup game against Chinese-Taipei in Taipei Wednesday night cut short its stay and left for home on Thursday.

Before their departure, the head coach of the Philippine team, Daniel Gavieres, issued a statement of apology, saying that his team has no bad feelings toward the Chinese-Taipei team or their Taiwan fans.
He expressed his hope that the Philippines will be invited to future Jones Cup matches.
The Chinese-Taipei Basketball Association (CTBA) called a press conference afterward to indicate its regret over the Philippine team's departure.
A CTBA official said that out of consideration for the Philippine players' safety, the CTBA agreed to let the Philippine team leave for home ahead of schedule.
Meanwhile, Republic of China Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan expressed his concern over the incident on Thursday. He asked the CTBA to handle this incident carefully by separating sports from politics.
Liu's concern was conveyed to the CTBA by Nancy Chao, chairwoman of the National Sports Council.
In Wednesday night's violent melee at the Taipei Physical Education College Gymnasium, several players and fans were slightly injured. Chinese-Taipei won the game by forfeit.
To prevent similar incidents in the future, the CTBA has decided to prohibit fans from bringing canned drinks and other objects that could be tossed at players into the gymnasium.
The organizers of the tournament will also mobilize more security personnel to maintain order and will ask the coaches of participating teams to discipline their players.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO BUY 13 BOEING 747-400 FULL CARGO JETLINERS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) of the Republic of China has confirmed it will purchase 13 Boeing 747-400 full cargo jetliners, an order worth US$2.5 billion, a well-informed source said on Thursday.
The anonymous source said that the purchase, the biggest single order for full cargo aircraft that Boeing has ever received, will be formally announced next week in Taipei.
CAL also has an option on another six of the same type of the aircraft, the source continued.
He added that the new aircraft will replace CAL's Boeing 747-200 jumbo jets as part of the carrier's scheme to tap the world's air cargo market.
CAL's air cargo fleet today is one of the 10 biggest in the world, and is expected to be even larger by 2003, when the fleet will consist of at least 15 of the Boeing 747-400s.
According to another source close to CAL, the ratio of passenger to cargo flights stands at three to one, and the company hopes that this ratio will be shortened to two to one by 2003.
The source said CAL has mapped out an outlook strategy to develop air cargo services to the point where cargo flights may eventually surpass passenger services.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER CANCELS TRIP TO KOSOVO
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By C. P. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew canceled his planned trip to the war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo on Thursday for security considerations.
Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who is accompanying Siew on his current five-day official visit to Macedonia, confirmed the cancellation of the Kosovo travel plan on Wednesday night.

Hu said he couldn't explained whether the cancellation was related to mainland China's boycott. He instead said he sees no adverse impact of the cancellation on the ROC government's US$300 million aid project to Kosovar refugees.

Siew was originally scheduled to visit Kosovo, which lies very close to the ROC ally of Macedonia, on Thursday morning to get some ideas on how to implement the ROC's aid programs to help Kosovar refugees.

Hu said the situation became increasingly complex along with the approaching of Siew's scheduled visit. Because of changes in some objective conditions, Hu said even Macedonian officials called for a second thought of the travel plan. "In considerations of security, we have decided to cancel the Kosovo trip," he added.

Hu said Taiwan's aid projects for Kosovo will not be affected by the cancellation because the ROC will offer the humanitarian aid through various channels, including the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development.
Meanwhile, Premier Siew reiterated the ROC's willingness to join international humanitarian relief programs or development aid projects.
Speaking at a seminar on the reconstruction of the Balkans, Siew said military conflicts in Kosovo have affected many neighboring Balkan countries.
Out of humanitarian considerations, Siew said ROC President Lee Teng-hui has announced Taiwan's decision to take part in reconstruction of the region.
"We'll start from assisting Macedonia and will then expand our operations to other war-devastated areas under the principle that they welcome our aid programs," Siew said.
He explained that the ways taken by Taiwan to help Macedonia revive its battered economy can also be implemented in other neighboring Balkan countries.
To cement bilateral ties, the ROC has offered US$12 million in loans to help Macedonian small- and medium-sized enterprises expand operations or launch new investment projects.

In addition, the ROC has signed a US$20 million loan agreement with Macedonia for construction of public housing units. The ROC is also constructing an export processing zone in Macedonia to facilitate Taiwan investment in that country.

Moreover, the ROC will join forces with the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development to set up a US$50 million Macedonian reconstruction fund to help boost the Balkan state's overall development.

Meanwhile, ROC government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said here that even though Siew canceled his Kosovo visit, aid programs launched by Taiwan's private charities to Kosovar people will not be affected.

Siew arrived in Skopje on Tuesday for a five-day official visit. He is accompanied by a 160-member delegation of senior government officials, business and industry executives and private charity group executives.
The ROC forged full diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PANAMA TIES REMAIN STABLE
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Bilateral relations between the Republic of China and Panama remain stable despite the installation of a new Panamanian cabinet, ROC Ambassador to Panama C.M. Lan said on Wednesday.

Lan said he has sent congratulations to new Panamanian Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman and has exchanged opinions on ways to strength bilateral relations. The ROC embassy has also contacted the new Panamanian government led by President-elect Mireya Moscoso, he added.

Quoting remarks made by Aleman when asked by the local Chinese-language press whether Mireya may change Panama's policy toward Taipei, Lan said that during the presidential race, Mireya and two other contenders had claimed that no matter who was elected president, he or she would continue maintaining formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.
Lan stressed that Aleman has also assured him that Panama will stand firm on its relations with Taipei, as the new Panamanian government also attaches great importance to the ties.

Lan said that for its part, the ROC government is determined to continue offering Panama economic and technological assistance by implementing all the cooperative ventures signed between the two countries, as part of Taipei's efforts to help underpin Mireya's policy of eliminating poverty.

Although Beijing has never eased its efforts to entice Panama by setting up a trade representative office and courting local influential political figures and Chinese communities, Lan pointed out that Mireya and most of the new cabinet members are very aware of the fact that maintaining full diplomatic links with Taipei is more beneficial for Panama.

Admitting that there are some pro-Beijing voices within the Panamanian government, Lan promised to do his best to boost understanding and communication with those people to allow them gain a better understanding of Taipei's goodwill and sincerity.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AGREES TO SELL EARLY WARNING RADAR TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States has tentatively agreed to furnish Taiwan with early warning radar to upgrade its self-defense capabilities, US officials said on Wednesday.

US Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs Stanley Roth and Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Kurt Campbell mentioned the possible arms deal with Taiwan for the first time at a Senate hearing on a Taiwan Security Enhancement Bill.

Both Roth and Campbell opposed the enhancement bill. But they confirmed that the Clinton administration thinks that Taiwan needs to acquire appropriate early warning radar to enhance its self-defense capabilities.
Campbell said relevant US agencies are conducting internal technical reviews and discussing with Taipei the most suitable early warning radar system for Taiwan.
Campbell said a final decision on the model or specifications will be made during next year's Taipei-Washington military meeting.
Campbell said the United States has so far never exported early warning radar to any other country.
Given its proximity to the Chinese mainland and Beijing's mounting military threat, Taiwan does badly need early warning radar to beef up its defense capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURTLE FORCES PILOT TO GO AROUND FOR SECOND LANDING

TEXT.P: Taipei's Sungshan Domestic Airport got a scare on Thursday when the pilot of a Far East Air Transport Corp. (FAT) jet was forced to abort a landing and implement a go-around maneuver for a second attempt -- because of a turtle.

A FAT spokesman said the Boeing 757-200 jetliner from Hualien, eastern Taiwan, was preparing to land at 8:35 a.m. when the pilot noticed workers on the runway scraping up the hapless reptile which had been crushed by a preceding plane.

It was the first time in Taiwan's aviation history that a turtle had been found on an airport runway. The spokesman said that generally speaking, birds and dogs are more common causes of air traffic disruption at airports.
The plane eventually landed safely without further mishap.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TAKES BACK 168 ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Amid the increased tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, mainland China's Red Cross Society took back 168 illegal immigrants from Taiwan on Thursday.

The 168 mainland Chinese illegals were released from a detention center on the Republic of China-controlled Matsu Island to be transported back to the mainland by a ship chartered by the mainland's Red Cross Society, according to the ROC Red Cross Society.

The mainland Chinese side initially agreed to take back just 121 of the illegals, but finally agreed to receive 47 more after being persuaded by the Taiwan side, security officers with the Matsu Chinglu detention center said.
Currently, a total of 163 illegal mainland Chinese immigrant still remain detained at two detention centers on Matsu, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CONFIRMS RESIGNATION BID OF MINISTER WITHOUT PORTFOLIO

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew, currently on an official visit to Macedonia, confirmed on Thursday that Minister Without Portfolio Wu Rong-ming rendered his resignation two weeks ago.
However, Siew added that he will try his best to retain Wu in office after he returns to Taipei.

An anonymous official close to the premier said that Wu did a lot of soul-searching before making the decision to resign, but felt he had no other option because sources in the camp of former Taiwan Governor James Soong had been putting great pressure on him.

Siew stressed that his entire Cabinet respects Wu and his capability in his job performance. Wu has said he intends to return to his university teaching job, and has denied ever mentioning that he will help Soong in his presidential bid, the premier was quoted as saying.
He added that he has not accepted Wu's resignation, and that he will try his best upon his return to Taipei to retain Wu in office since he is a good, experienced state official.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for Vice President Lien Chan categorically denied local newspaper reports that Lien made a late-night telephone call to Wu in a failed attempt to persuade Wu to remain in office, claiming instead that it was Wu who called the vice president. However, he declined to reveal the contents of the call.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE DENIES ITS JET FIGHTERS LOCKED BY SU-27S

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force denied on Thursday that two of its Mirage jet fighters were "lit up" or targeted by Beijing's warplanes during a patrol over the Taiwan Strait on Monday.

Maj. Gen. Jen Yu-sen, deputy chief of staff at Air Force General Headquarters (AFGHQ), dismissed as "groundless allegations" a report that two of Taiwan's French-built Mirage 2000 fighters were targeted by the radar systems of mainland Chinese Sukhoi 27s amid increasing tension between Taiwan and the mainland over President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
The United Daily News, which published the report, said the two Mirages were conducting a patrol on Aug. 2, the day Beijing tested its long range Dong Feng-31 missile.

The Su-27s, took off from southern China, and directed a narrow radar beam at the Mirages in an apparent act of provocation. The narrow radar beam, used to track targets and guide the fighter's firing system, was picked up by the Mirages own detection systems.

Although the Su-27s were not in a firing position, and there were other Taiwan fighters close by, the two Mirages were ordered to return to base to defuse what could have been a possible unintended accident, according to the newspaper.

Jen said that the air force has an established procedure to intercept enemy jet fighters which goes into effect automatically when an enemy plane intrudes into Taiwan airspace with apparent hostile intent which poses an obvious threat to Taiwan's warplanes.

Meanwhile, Minister of National Defense Tang Fei addressed Washington's concerns raised on Tuesday that increasing sorties flown by both Taiwan and mainland China could spark an "accident," telling a local radio station that Beijing should exercise restraint.
Tang said Beijing is the culprit behind the current strained situation because it increased its sorties over the Taiwan Strait first, forcing Taiwan to counter with sorties of its own.

DOC.HEADLINE: 41 M'LAND CHINESE BOAT PEOPLE MISSING IN PNG

TEXT.P: Police in Papua New Guinea are hunting 41 Chinese boat people after they disappeared from a temporary refuge at a Salvation Army compound, a PNG newspaper reported on Thursday.
Foreign affairs officials said they were part of a group of 60 illegal immigrants from mainland China awaiting deportation to the mainland, according to the daily.
The deportation has now been called off until the missing people have been found, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF LEADER ASKS BEIJING TO RESPECT REALITY OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The secretary-general of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Shi Hwei-yow, called on Thursday for the Beijing authorities to respect the reality of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Shi made the appeal while responding to Beijing's criticism of Taiwan's explanation of President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship."

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued a position paper on the "special state-to-state relationship" on Sunday, in which Taipei rejected Beijing's "one China" principle and asked Beijing to respect the 1992 agreement to allow each side to have their own respective interpretations of "one China."
The Beijing authorities blasted the paper on Wednesday, claiming that it was advocating "splittism."

They also denied that any such agreement was reached in 1992, and further stressed that Beijing has never recognized and will not recognize in the future the concept of "one China as respectively interpreted by each side."

Despite the fact that Beijing's criticism was puffed up with emotional rhetoric, Shi said that the SEF will respect Beijing's position in principle, but expressed the hope that Beijing will also respect the idea of "mutual respect."
He stated that Beijing should respect the reality that the Republic of China on Taiwan has been a sovereign state for the past 50 years, with neither side subordinate to the other.
Beijing should also respect the 1992 concept of "one China respectively interpreted by each side," said Shi.

The SEF leader reiterated Taipei's welcome to a scheduled autumn visit by Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), and added that the most important thing when the two sides are in dispute is to step up dialogue.
He also indicated that Taipei is still eager to resume institutionalized consultations between the SEF and ARATS.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT SHRUGS OFF THREATS FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Philippine President Estrada on Thursday shrugged off reports that Taiwan is threatening to impose economic sanctions against the Philippines for the abrogation of their bilateral air agreement.
However, he admitted that preparations are being made, including measures for the some 120,000 Filipino workers in Taiwan.
Aside from measures against the Filipino workers, Taiwan officials are said to be initiating a withdrawal of Taiwan investments in Subic and southern Luzon industrial parks.

Estrada insisted that the Sept. 30 cancellation of the country's air agreement with Taiwan is in order, alleging that two of its carriers -- China Airlines and Eva Air -- have been violating the 1996 agreement for several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CANNOT CONFIRM US CONTACTS TAIPEI SIX TIMES IN TWO DAYS

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Thursday that he could not confirm that the United States has contacted Taiwan and mainland China six times in the last two days over the mounting tension across the Taiwan Strait.
However, acting MOFA spokesman Chen Ming-chen said that various contact channels exist between Taipei and Washington, which are often used to exchange views by the two sides.

US Assistant Secretary of State for Asian Pacific Affairs Stanley Roth reportedly told a Senate hearing in Washington on Wednesday that Washington has contacted Beijing and Taipei, via civilian and military channels, six times in last two days over the increasing cross-strait tension.
Roth made the statement at a hearing on the proposed Taiwan Security Enhancement Act which is designed to give Taiwan access to more US arms.

Roth told the hearing that the legislation "could not be considered at a worse time." He, as well as Assistant Secretary of Defense Kurt Campbell, said it risks emboldening the "separatists" in Taiwan and enraging the nationalists in mainland China.
Describing the testimony by Roth and Campbell as "US international affairs," Chen would not comment further, but stressed that Taipei will continue its efforts to seek US support.

DOC.HEADLINE: IBA BIG LEAGUE BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The 18th International Baseball Association (IBA) World Big League Baseball Championship opened in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan on Thursday night.
Over the next 10 days, 12 teams will compete for the IBA trophy at the Kaohsiung Municipal Li-Teh Stadium and the Kaohsiung County Cheng Ching Lake Stadium.

Distinguished guests invited to the opening ceremony included IBA Chairman Aldo Notari, National Sports Council Chairwoman Nancy Chao, Chinese-Taipei Baseball Association President Peng Cheng-hao, and Kaohsiung Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien.
The major participating teams include Cuba, Japan, South Korea, Panama, the United States and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER TO ATTEND INAUGURATION OF PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT-ELECT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew will lead a large-scale delegation to attend the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Mireya Moscoso slated for Sept. 1, the ROC embassy in Panama reported on Thursday.

ROC Ambassador C.M. Lan confirmed that Siew's name was leaked when embassy personnel contacted the Panamanian Foreign Ministry to check the names of the ROC delegation. More than 80 Taiwan businessmen will accompany Siew on the tour to study the investment climate in this Central American country.
Siew, who is currently visiting Macedonia, will return to Taiwan on Monday.
Heads of state of five other Central American countries, as well as Spanish Crown Prince Felipe de Borbon, will also attend Moscoso's inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES MIGHT SUSPEND FLIGHTS OVER Y2K FEARS

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) might suspend flights on certain routes on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day, as part of its Y2K contingency plans, The Straits Times reported on Thursday.
Although the paper said a final decision will not be known until October, it noted that at least two other airlines have announced they will not be operating.
Poland's national airline LOT said last month it will ground its fleet on January 1 to avoid Y2K problems, while Vietnam Airlines has canceled all its flights just before the start of the New Year.
Responding to questions from the media, SIA's executive vice president (technical), Chew Leng Seng, said: "We shall not operate any service where safety is in doubt.

SIA said in its in-house newspaper, Outlook, last month that rigorous tests for Y2K compliance were completed successfully on all its internal systems in June, and that it is now focusing on contingency planning and stepping up scrutiny of the risks and exposure from external systems upon which it depends.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER HOLDS TALKS WITH KOSOVAR LEADER IN SKOPJE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew held talks with Deputy Prime Minister and concurrently Foreign Minister Mehmet Hajrizi of the Kosovar provisional government in the Macedonian capital of Skopje on Thursday.

Siew, who is currently heading a large-scale delegation on an official visit to the Balkan nation with which Taiwan forged diplomatic relations on Jan. 27 this year, was originally scheduled to visit neighboring Kosovo, but the schedule was canceled out of security considerations.
Instead, Hajrizi and several other ranking officials came to meet with Siew at the ROC embassy in Skopje.
During the 50-minute meeting, Siew reiterated Taipei's determination to implement its massive aid package for Kosovo.

He said the ROC government will provide US$5 million to establish a medium-sized commercial bank in Kosovo in a joint venture with a European bank, adding that Taiwan is also ready to help train Kosovar banking personnel.
Hajrizi briefed Siew on the current situation in Kosovo, pointing out that the Yugoslavian province currently controlled by NATO peacekeepers is urgently in need of foreign investment.

Before the talks, the ROC side donated a range of urgently-needed materials and equipment for Kosovo, shattered by months of civil war. The goods included 30 buses, 1,000 refrigerators, 5,000 blankets, 5,000 winter jackets, 5,000 school bags, 10,000 tool boxes and 500 tons of fertilizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Straits Exchange Foundation broaches 'three respects' theory for relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The China Times:
US Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Kurt Campbell said the Taiwan Strait situation is dangerously tense.
The United Daily News:
Premier Vincent Siew canceled trip to war-torn Kosovo.
The Liberty Times:
The United States has made six demarches in the past 48 hours to both sides of the Taiwan Strait asking them to exercise restraint.
The Commons Daily:
The United States expressed concern about escalating tension in the Taiwan Strait.
The China Post:
ROC Air Force denies Su-27 targeting 'lock-on' incident.
The Taiwan News:
No near clash across the Taiwan Strait, says Air Force.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 6, or the 25th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1806: The Holy Roman Empire ends when Francis II abdicates. He later becomes Francis I, emperor of Austria.
1825: Bolivia becomes an independent republic after being ruled by the Spanish for nearly 300 years.
1881: Alexander Flemming, Scottish scientist who discovered penicillin at St. Mary's Hospital, London, in 1928, is born. He won the 1945 Nobel Prize for medicine with Howard Florey and Ernest Chain.
1890: The electric chair is used for the first time, to execute convicted murderer William Kemmler at Auburn Prison in New York.
1911: Lucille Ball, American actress and comedienne who starred in the series "I Love Lucy," is born.
1914: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced China's congress to elect him president on Oct. 10, 1913, declares China's neutrality in World War I.
1917: Robert Mitchum, American actor who starred in "The Enemy Below," "Cape Fear," "The Longest Day," and many other films, is born.
1926: Gertrude Ederle, American sports star and 1924 Olympic gold medalist, completes the 35 miles (56 kilometers) that separate Cap Gris-Nez and Dover in 14 hours 31 minutes, becoming the first woman to swim the English Channel.
1932: The first international film festival is opened in Venice, with 29 films from the United States, Britain, France, Germany, the Soviet Union and Italy participating.
1933: Feng Yu-hsiang, an army general who revolted at Kalgan Pass (Changkiakow) in Chahar province on May 28, announces his revolt has failed.
1945: An atomic bomb, dubbed "Little Boy," is released by a US Air Force B-29, known as the "Enola Gay," above the central Japanese city of Hiroshima, killing more than 90,000 people, and injuring at least 9,000 others.
1949: At the invitation of Korean President Syngman Rhee, President Chiang Kai-shek flies to Chinhae, Korea, to discuss the formation of a Pacific alliance.
1952: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the designation of Sept. 28, instead of Aug. 27, as the birthday of Confucius, the great sage and teacher who has had a far-reaching influence on Chinese philosophy and culture.
1962: Jamaica becomes independent after 307 years of British rule.
1962: Film star Marilyn Monroe is found dead in the bedroom of her Hollywood home. She was 36.
1962: Ugandan dictator Idi Amin throws 50,000 Asians out of Uganda.
1971: British sailor Chay Blyth completes his solo non-stop 48,000-kilometer round-the-world voyage in 292 days on his 18-meter, all-steel ketch "British Steel."
1978: Pope Paul VI, who succeeded John XXIII in 1963, dies at the age of 80.
1990: The United Nations Security Council votes 13-0 to ban trade with Iraq except for medicine and some food for humanitarian relief after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
1991: A Republic of China-Fiji technological cooperation agreement is signed during Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara's visit to Taipei.
1997: A Korean Airlines Boeing 747-300 passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area on Guam, killing 254 people on board. There were only 20 survivors.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By welcoming them when they come and giving them protection when they go, commending what is good in them and making allowance for their ignorance: that is how the ruler shows tenderness to strangers from far countries."

DOC.HEADLINE: US PROFESSOR CALLS 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' A SHAM

TEXT.P: Recent events in Hong Kong are sending a clear message to Taiwan about how it would fare under Beijing's "one country, two systems" policy: It does not mean anything, according to an American professor.

R. Thomas Berner, professor of journalism and American studies at Pennsylvania State University, wrote Thursday in a commentary published Thursday on the Internet that when he returned from teaching in mainland China five years ago, someone in local groups listening to his experience would invariably ask how he thought Hong Kong would fare when it reverted to the mainland Chinese rule in 1997.

He said he would reply consistently that "Beijing is not going to let anybody under its control follow a different set of rules. In China, it's Beijing's way or no way." The only surprise was that it took two years before Beijing made it clear that "the late Deng Xiaoping's promise of 'one country, two systems' did not mean anything," noted Berner.

Berner is convinced that mainland China has a chance of becoming a great nation, but he does not expect to see that happen in his lifetime, saying, "Perhaps my 18-month-old granddaughter will visit a much-improved China -- when she is a senior citizen."

"Until then, Taiwan should take note of what happened in Hong Kong if it wants to see how the 'one country, two systems' policy really works. It does not. In Beijing's eyes, there is only one country, one system, and it has a red star for a symbol," concluded Berner.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSIONAL GROUPS TO VISIT TAIWAN TO SHOW SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Three to four US congressional groups will visit Taiwan in the next two weeks to show their concern about the Taiwan Strait security, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said on Friday.

Kao Shou-tai, deputy director of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, said the upcoming visits are also aimed at expressing US congressional support for ROC President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
Kao was speaking at a hearing on how Taiwan will promote pragmatic diplomacy in the wake of the release of the "state-to-state" theory which has sparked furious reaction from Beijing.

Kao said since President Lee defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station on July 9, the MOFA has 15 to 16 times asked the Republic of China representative office in the United States to collect the US public opinion about the "state-to-state" theory as well as initial reaction of the Clinton administration, major think tanks and news media toward the theory.

"Many of them throw support behind the theory and offer goodwill suggestions," Kao said, adding that the US mainstream society has gradually come to understand what President Lee said are just historical facts and political realities.

Kao went on to say that the US Congress has offered a great deal of moral support for the "special state-to-state" theory. Moreover, 26 US senators have sent a joint letter to President Bill Clinton expressing their support for the ROC's cause.

"Over the next two weeks, three or four US congressional delegations are scheduled to visit the island to show their concern about Taiwan's security and support for the 'special state-to-state' theory," Kao added.
The public hearing was called by opposition Legislator Parris Chang, who said the "special state-to-state theory" symbolizes that Taiwan has broken off Beijing's "one China" framework.

"I hope the government will take measures to substantiate President Lee's 'special state-to-state' theory so as to create a new opportunity for Taiwan to expand its diplomatic frontier," said the lawmaker from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Chang said Taiwan should not be daunted by Beijing's fury over the theory. "Budging from our basic stance would only restrict our own future development," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE BOAT PEOPLE BECOMING AN ISSUE IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Canada's largest opposition party was not happy about the release of 86 mainland Chinese refugee claimants in British Columbia.
They are part of a group of 123 people found on a decrepit boat off the coast of Vancouver Island two weeks ago.

Reform Party immigration critic Leon Benoit said Thursday history shows that almost half of the refugee claimants who are freed never show up for their hearings. Police noted most of them sneaked into the United States.

Benoit said new Immigration Minister Eleanor Caplan should overhaul the system. He added that Canada needs to be tougher on criminals who smuggle people. He also said those who come to Canada illegally should be sent back to their country of origin.

The 123 Chinese arrived in Canada's territorial waters aboard an unnamed ship, after a 39-day voyage across the Pacific. The government is treating them as refugees, though a number of them may be charged with illegal smuggling of humans.
Some major Canadian newspapers have written editorials urging their government to get tough with smugglers and shown little sympathy for the desperate "economic refugees."

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG SEEN ABLE TO EXTEND LIFE OF WOMEN WITH BREAST CANCER

TEXT.P: A new chemotherapy drug is holding out hope to sufferers of advanced breast cancer after an Australian study demonstrated that it could extend some women's lives after their disease has spread to other organs, according to The Sydney Morning Herald on Friday.

The study, conducted by Professor Jim Bishop of the Sydney Cancer Center, shows women who used the drug -- taxol -- survived on average 17 months after first being told their cancer had metastasized or spread, compared to 13 months for those who used the more standard combination chemotherapy regime, called CMFP, the daily reported.
In a study of 209 women across Australia and New Zealand, Bishop said their quality of life was slightly improved after taking the new drug.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN BACKS AUSTRALIAN PLAN TO DOUBLE FORCE IN EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: The United Nations will press Indonesia to accept an Australian plan to double the number of international police and military personnel in East Timor so that they can tighten security during the Aug. 30 ballot.

In a dispatch from New York, The Sydney Morning Herald reported Australia has gained support from the United States and other UN members following a series of talks for a confidential proposal to send in an extra 200 to 300 police officers.
It has also won full UN backing for a plan to boost the international military presence from the present 50 advisers to between 250 and 350, the daily reported.

The daily reported Australia would provide up to a third of the additional forces, which would arrive around the time of the Aug. 30 ballot. Indonesia has given its tacit approval for the Australian proposals when Foreign Minister Alexander Downer met his Indonesian counterpart and President B.J. Habibie in Jakarta recently, it reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA OPPOSES DEFENSE TRADE-OFF WITH US

TEXT.P: Australia will oppose any defense arrangements with the United States to be used as "negotiating coin" in trade disputes between the two countries, according to The Australian Financial Review.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer was quoted by the daily as saying that Australia's security would be undermined if that happens. He reiterated "Australia's deep disappointment and anger" over the United States' decision to restrict imports of Australian lamb, saying the restrictions were "founded in hypocrisy."

He stressed that Australia was "actively encouraging a continuing constructive US role" in exchanges on security issues in organizations like the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Regional Forum, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATOR DEFENDS `TAIWAN SECURITY ENHANCEMENT ACT'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: US Senator Robert Torricelli on Thursday defended his proposed "Taiwan Security Enhancement Act," stating that the bill will not alter or amend US commitments under the Taiwan Relation Act (TRA).
Rather, he stressed, the bill, which he co-sponsored with Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC), will ensure that Taiwan's security needs are adequately met.
Torricelli's absence from Wednesday's hearing on bill S.693, which was submitted in March, raised public attention.

The Democrat congressman from New Jersey is a long-time supporter of Taiwan, although on July 14 he criticized President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a move which ran the risk of further isolating the country.

He said Lee's July 9 statement calling cross-strait ties "a special state-to-state relationship" contradicted not only the policy of the People's Republic of China, but also that of the United States, and asserted that Taiwan has triggered a confrontation with the PRC "on the wrong basis and at the wrong time."
However, recent events make it necessary for the United States to continue its support for Taiwan, Torricelli indicated in his written statement released on Friday.

"President Lee's statements have led China to threaten the use of force against Taiwan. However, we all recognize that the peaceful resolution of Taiwan's status is important to the Taiwanese people, the United States and China," the congressman said.

He noted that the people of Taiwan have a right to determine their own future by peaceful means, but added that the United States must remain committed to two important principles -- dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China must continue in October, and the United States must demonstrate its commitment to Taiwan by adhering to its commitments under the TRA.

The "Taiwan Security Enhancement Act" bill is designed to ensure Taiwan's ability to meet its defensive security needs. It authorizes, but does not mandate, the sale of theater missile defense equipment, satellite early warning data, and specific air and naval defense systems, Torricelli said in the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 2 percent lower on Friday amid weak buying by bargain hunters and the fear of a possible confrontation between Taiwan and mainland China.
The local bourse rose 28.78 points in early trading following an overnight rebound on Wall Street, but fell 136.21 points throughout the day to close at 6,823.52.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index dropped 136.21 points to close at 6,823.25, with a total 1.55 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of NT$67.26 billion.
Among the eight major stocks categories, all sectors reported losses for the day, with cement issues suffering the most, diving 3.6 percent.
Paper and pulp shares fell 3.6 percent, followed by construction stocks, which closed 3.1 percent lower. Textile stocks posted 3 percent losses, and financial shares dropped 2.9 percent.
Plastics and chemical issues declined 2.6 percent, the foodstuff sector decreased 2 percent and electronics stocks moved down 1 percent.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market was down 2.3 points, closing at 153.47 points, with a turnover of NT$3.54 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August moved down 88 points to close at 6,870, with 3,809 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September declined 85 points to finish at 6,890, with 268 contract transactions; those for December fell 109 points, ending the day at 6,891, with 20 contract transactions.

Futures for next March saw a drop of 169 points, closing at 6,931, and those for next June fell 68 points to end the day at 6,980. Contract transactions for the two months totaled four and two, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 6,958 points for August, 6,975 points for September, 7,000 points for December, 7,100 points for next March and 7,048 for next June.
August electronics futures (TE) and financial futures (TF) also reported losses.

August TE futures slid 1.35 points to close at 303.4, with 1,159 contract transactions; September TE futures decreased 4.7 points to end at 302.5, with 45 contract transactions. There were no transactions recorded for TE futures for the other months.
August TF futures were down 35 points, ending the day at 972.2, with 143 contract transactions; September TF lost 32.2 points to finish at 970, with four contract transactions.
There were no transactions recorded for TF futures for other months. (by Michelle Tseng)

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.023 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at 32.109.
The local currency opened at 32.072, the highest level for the day, and was traded between 32.072 and 32.128.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$223 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT HAS OVERSEAS KMT SUPPORT FOR PRESIDENTIAL BID
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's overseas delegates to the 15th National Congress have voiced support for Vice President Lien Chan's presidential bid, a KMT official in charge of overseas affairs said on Thursday.

Wang Neng-chang, head of the KMT's Department of Overseas Affairs, made the remarks at the airport in San Francisco, where he was heading for Chicago for a reunion of overseas Taiwanese in the United States.
Among the 196 overseas delegates that are expected to attend the second conference of the 15th National Congress, more than 100 have stated their support for Lien, Wang said.

More than 90 "friends of Lien Chan" clubs have been set up abroad, and they plan to congregate on July 26 in Taipei to hold a pep rally kicking off a series of campaigns in support of the KMT's presidential candidate for the March 2000 election. The rally will be attended by KMT Chairman and Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, as well as by Lien himself, Wang noted.

He claimed that the upcoming presidential election will be a battle between the KMT and the opposition Democrative Progressive Party, because the independent candidates lack the party machinery to survive the race.
Wang predicted that Lien's popularity, which has been lagging far behind that of former Taiwan Governor James Soong, will surpass Soong's after October.
He also urged overseas Chinese to make sure they register for a correspondence vote, noting that very few bothered to do so during last presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESOLVE CROSS-STRAIT DIFFERENCES THROUGH DIALOGUE: MAC

TEXT.P: Any differences between Taiwan and mainland China should be resolved through dialogue, exchanges and consultations, rather than exchanges of virulent abuse and saber-rattling, a government official said on Friday.

Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks during a regular press briefing as he reiterated Taipei's position on the promotion of cross-Taiwan Strait relations under the framework of peace and stability.

The MAC issued a position paper on Aug. 1 which was intended to explain President Lee Teng-hui's controversial July 9 definition of cross-strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship". The paper stressed that Taipei's mainland policy remains unchanged, and that Taipei hopes to return to the framework of "`one China,' respectively interpreted by each side," under which to pursue a peaceful, democratic and unified "new China."

Sheu also stated the historical facts behind the concept of "`one China' respectively interpreted by each side," pointing out that consensus on the issue was reached in November 1992 after several rounds of consultations between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

That consensus made possible talks in Singapore in 1993 between the top negotiators of both sides, Koo Chen-fu and Wang Daohan of the SEF and ARATS, respectively, and was conducive to the subsequent ensuing dialogue, exchanges and consultations between the two semi-official bodies, Sheu added.

However, the Beijing authorities have been promoting its hegemonic "one China principle" in the international community sine 1996, trying to downgrade Taipei to the level of a local government, and even denying the existence of the Republic of China, Sheu continued.

In September 1996, Beijing brought up the premise that "there is only one China, the People's Republic of China is the sole legal government of China, and Taiwan is an inalienable part of it," which led to misunderstanding in the international community that Beijing's interpretation is the only possible interpretation of "one China," Sheu went on.

If the two sides can return to the agreement that each side is entitled to its "respective interpretation of one China," said Sheu, then through consultations on the basis of equality, both sides can jointly cooperate in opening a new chapter in cross-strait relations that will be conducive to the unification of the country under democracy.

Sheu concluded by reiterating that Taipei still welcomes Wang's autumn visit to Taiwan, and expressing Taipei's hope that both sides can resolve their differences and seek consensus through dialogue and exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER MEETS SENIOR KOSOVAR OFFICIALS IN SKOPJE
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By C. P. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will never cease its diplomatic efforts despite mainland China's constant attempt to isolate it in the international community, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu said here on Friday.

Hu was commenting on a meeting in the Macedonian capital of Skopje on Thursday between ROC Premier Vincent Siew and Deputy Prime Minister Mehmet Hajrizi of the provisional government of the Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

Siew, who is currently on a five-day official visit in Macedonia, canceled a long-planned fact-finding trip to war-torn Kosovo on Thursday after relevant authorities backed off a promise to provide adequate security services for Siew and his entourage under pressure from Beijing.
After many twists and turns, Hajrizi and several other high-ranking Kosovar officials came to meet with Siew at the ROC embassy in Skopje.
During their 50-minute meeting, Siew reaffirmed Taipei's determination to implement its US$300 million aid package for Kosovo.

He said the ROC government will provide US$5 million to establish a medium-sized commercial bank in Kosovo in a joint venture with a European bank, adding that Taiwan is also ready to help train Kosovar banking personnel.
Hajrizi briefed Siew on the current situation in Kosovo, pointing out that the Yugoslavian province currently controlled by NATO peacekeepers is urgently in need of foreign investment.

Before the talks, the ROC delegation donated a range of urgently-needed materials and equipment to Kosovo, shattered by months of civil war. The goods included 30 buses, 1,000 refrigerators, 5,000 blankets, 5,000 winter jackets, 5,000 school bags, 10,000 tool boxes and 500 tons of fertilizer.
For his part, Hajrizi said he would hold a news conference after returning to his hometown to let Kosovars understand Taiwan's friendship and concern for them.

ROC Minister-Counselor to Macedonia Cheng Po-jeou, who had made painstaking efforts to prepare for Siew's aborted Kosovo visit and later arrange for the Siew-Hajrizi meeting, said although military action in Kosovo has already ceased, the region is still far from peace.
Cheng said he will continue his efforts to forge contacts and dialogue channel with the provisional Kosovar government.
Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Hu said the drama in the Kosovo rendezvous has once again highlighted the international reality and challenges facing the ROC.
Nevertheless, Hu said the ROC won't be daunted by all the difficulties nor miss any possible chances to forge ties with other countries or areas.

Although some ROC lawmakers have urged the government to reconsider its massive aid projects for Kosovar refugees after Siew was forced to cancel his trip to the Yugoslav province, Hu said the government's stance on joining the international humanitarian relief efforts for Kosovars will remain unchanged.
To work out more concrete measures for implementing various bilateral cooperative programs, Siew will hold an additional meeting with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski on Friday.

In preparations for the additional meeting, Siew met with senior business and industry executives accompanying him on his current visit late Thursday meeting to inquire their findings about Macedonia's investment climate and business prospects.

During the meeting, Jeffrey Koo, president of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, said Macedonia's investment climate is better than some Central American and Southeast Asian countries.

"Taiwan investors can consider building small cement factories and banks in Macedonia," Koo said, adding that a business center should also be built in the Taiwan-invested export processing zone (EPZ) in the Balkan state, whose economy has been seriously affected by war in Kosovo.

Lee Yung-shan, chairman of the International Commercial Bank of China, said the bank will open a representative office in Macedonia and will decide whether to upgrade the office to a branch in accordance with progress in the EPZ construction project.

The ROC forged formal diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January 1999. Siew's visit is part of the ROC's efforts to cement the hard-won bilateral ties in the face of mainland China's constant diplomatic offensive against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG WASTE TO STAY IN KAOHSIUNG FOR ANOTHER 45 DAYS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Friday granted a 45-day grace period to the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), allowing it to continue storing toxic waste in the southern port of Kaohsiung.

The period is an extension of a previous grace period granted by the EPA allowing the waste to be temporarily stored at pier No. 63 in Kaohsiung Port which expired on Friday. FPG now has until Sept. 20 to dispose of the mercury-laced waste or risk losing a NT$50 million guarantee fee.

The EPA also signed a pledge with FPG to prolong another existing agreement that the EPA will continue to monitor the waste, and that FPG must maintain the safety of the tanks at the pier in which the waste is being stored.

The 4,000 tons of industrial waste have been stored at the port for the past four months, ever since FPG was forced to ship it back from Cambodia earlier this year. The group had planned to bury the waste in a southern village in Cambodia, but was thwarted when residents found out and a mass panic ensued, attracting international outrage.

FPG has been exploring different avenues to dispose of the waste in another country, but has had no success. It has been said that FPG may now dump the waste at a landfill in Mailiao, in central Taiwan's Yunlin County.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL TIGHT-LIPPED ON RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan remained tight-lipped on Friday regarding his running mate on the ruling Kuomintang ticket for the March 2000 presidential election.
Speaking to reporters at a national rally to honor model fathers, the KMT candidate would neither confirm nor deny a press report that Premier Vincent Siew will be his running mate.
Saying that the inner party consulting process is still ongoing, Lien jokingly referred reporters back to the media outlet which published the story.
Under KMT rules, hopeful candidates vying for party nomination should seek the sponsorship of a quorum of party members before being confirmed by party delegates.

After having gone through this process, the candidate chosen by the party delegates is expected to name his own running mate and present him to a party congress, scheduled for Aug. 29, for the final endorsement of the ticket.
Meanwhile, Siew, speaking to reporters in Macedonia where he is engaged on an official visit, would not comment on the report that he will serve as the party's candidate for vice president.
As a loyal KMT member, Siew said, he will answer the party's call irrespective of personal interest, a statement regarded as signifying his willingness to be Lien's running mate.
However, the premier said he has not been consulted on the issue.
He is slated to return to Taiwan on Aug. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO STUDY LATIN AMERICAN TRADE ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade delegation is scheduled to visit Central and South America as part of efforts to honor a promise by President Lee Teng-hui to help stimulate economic development in those areas, members of the delegation said on Friday.

The delegation, named the Central America Development Company (CADC), was initiated by Kao Chin-yen, Chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, who was appointed president of the company at a board of directors meeting in April. At the same meeting, the board also decided to provide US$1.2 million to finance a jeans factory in Nicaragua.

It will be divided into three groups, one of which will head for Haiti, Nicaragua and Panama on Aug. 24, while another will leave at the same time to study investment opportunities in El Salvador, Costa Rica and Panama.
The third group will leave on Aug. 29 for Panama, Paraguay and Brazil, to investigate the economic situations in those countries.
The CADC has capital assets totaling NT$1 billion, most of which has come in the form of donations of the board members.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL'S ALLEGED CHANGE OF BOEING ORDER RAISES GRAVE CONCERNS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu and Jay Chen)

TEXT.P: Reports that Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) may change a plan to buy Boeing passenger airplanes are worrying the Boeing Co., the US government as well as one of the US senators from Washington State, Slade Gorton.

Sources in Taipei said on Friday that Boeing will soon send several high-ranking executives to Taiwan to persuade CAL executives to maintain the original order for 14 Boeing passenger airplanes, including the modern Boeing-777's.
US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky on Thursday wrote to Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew, extending her concern over the CAL decision.
She expressed in the letter her wish that Siew will help ensure that "the final decision is based solely on technical and commercial merit."

Barshefsky described the purchase as "being of great importance" to the United States, and as the first purchase of the Boeing-777's by Taiwan, it symbolizes the island's commitment to the growing US-Taiwan economic relationship.

Meanwhile, a report from Washington on Thursday said that Sen. Gorton will leave for Taiwan on Saturday. Gorton will visit President Lee Teng-shui and other ranking ROC officials in his bid to confirm the contract.
A spokesman for Gorton on Thursday told CNA that the senator is hoping he can salvage the CAL order, valued at over US$2 billion, by using "his personal relations with Taipei."
The spokesman said if the deal is called off, it will impact Boeing, the American aviation industry and the state of Washington.
CAL signed a letter of intent with Boeing in June 1995 to purchase 12 Boeing-777 long-range, middle-capacity passenger planes, an order worth US$2 billion.

The former flag-carrier of the Republic of China has since also ordered 13 Boeing 747-400 full cargo jetliners at a cost of US$2.5 billion, the largest single order for freighter aircraft in Boeing's history.

CAL has confirmed it will implement the deal for the cargo planes. However, due to a strong sales promotion by France's Airbus Industrie, CAL appears to be heading toward replacing its procurement of Boeing-777s with Airbus A340 planes.

The CAL Taipei spokesman, Shih Ping-huang, on Friday declined to confirm whether the Boeing procurement plan will be altered or amended. He also denied that CAL buying policy is connected with the ROC's political policy.
Shih stressed both Boeing and Airbus aircraft are good aircraft. But he added CAL must also assess factors such as price, maintenance and repair service costs.

The France-based Airbus Industrie Co. is also one of the world's largest aircraft manufacturers. However its Taiwan market share is 25 percent of that of Boeing's, according to statistics from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
CAL currently owns the most Boeing aircraft among local air companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: LA TIMES CARRIES GIO CHIEF'S ARTICLE ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The mass-circulation Los Angeles Times carried an article by Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office (GIO), on Friday explaining Taiwan's position on the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Chen said Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's recent redefinition of the cross-strait relationship as a "special state-to-state relationship" simply reflects reality.
"It does not signal a change in Taiwan's mainland policy," stressed the spokesman for the ROC government.

He quoted ROC Premier Vincent Siew's remarks, "Our policy of promoting constructive dialogue and positive exchanges remains unchanged, our resolve to pursue a win-win situation in cross-strait relations remains unchanged, and our goal for a peaceful, democratic and united new China in the future remains unchanged."

Because Beijing has disregarded the existence of the ROC government on Taiwan, Chen said, there is a real need to clarify Taiwan's status before the visit to Taiwan by the mainland's emissary for cross-strait dialogue this fall.
"If cross-strait talks are to be meaningful and substantive, then the two parties have to regard each other as equals," he pointed out.

Lee's recent redefinition of cross-strait relations and the subsequent explanation by the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council drew harsh criticism from Beijing authorities who branded the redefinition an act of "splittism."

In his article, Chen said Lee's characterization of Taiwan-mainland relations is a clear reminder that progress in cross-strait relations can never be at the expense of freedom and democracy on Taiwan.

He noted that "mutual trust between Taipei and Beijing based on reality, rather than diplomatic sham, will be the basis of lasting peace, progress and stability for all Chinese as well as the Asia-Pacific region."

The GIO chief acknowledged that Beijing's vilification of Taiwan as a "renegade province," its refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, and its continuing military buildup are a growing source of instability in the Asia-Pacific area. (By Lu-sheng Shu & Victor Lai) EDITERM ZCZC CEP021 08-06-99 MORE DISSIDENTS IMPRISONED IN MAINLAND CHINA
Hong Kong, Aug. 6 (CNA) Two founders of the Sichuan provincial branch of the outlawed China Democracy Party (CDP) were sentenced to long prison terms Friday on charges of "subverting state power."

The sentencing has brought the number of CDP members convicted of "subverting state power" to nine since early May, the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Right and Democratic Movement in China said Friday.

The center said Liu Xianbin, 31, of Suining city in southwestern Sichuan province, was sentenced to 13 years in prison. He was found guilty of drafting several documents concerning the CDP and advocating a multi-party system for mainland China.

Liu, who was a student of the Beijing Chinese People's University, was imprisoned for two and a half years for participating in the 1989 pro-democracy movement, which ended in a bloody military crackdown. He was arrested on July 7 for organizing the provincial branch of the CDP, which was set up and outlawed soon afterwards in the summer of last year.
The center added that She Wanbao, 41, of Guangyuan city in the same province, was sentenced to 12 years on the same charges.

Two other leaders of the CDP were also sentenced to long prison terms this week. Zha Jianguo and Gao Hongming, vice chairmen of the Beijing-Tianjin branch of the CDP, were sentenced to nine and eight years respectively on Monday, also on charges of "subverting state power."
Since NATO bombing of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgrade on May 7, nine members of the would-be opposition party have been convicted for the same reason, the information center added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSITIVE RESPONSE BY RP TO TAIPEI-MANILA AIR ACCORD

TEXT.P: Manila, Aug. 6 (CNA): The Philippine government proposed on Friday that Taipei and Manila either renegotiate their aviation accord or air carriers from both countries enter into a commercial agreement so as to avoid the cessation of the Taipei-Manila air link.
Fernando Barican, the spokesman for the Estrada Administration, said in a written statement that "between now and Sep.30, the two sides could still hold negotiations and come up with an agreement.
"The other alternative is for the Taiwan air carriers to enter into a commercial agreement, which could mean no cessation of the flights after Sept. 30, 1999," the spokesman said.
It was the first positive proposal made by the Philippine Government since negotiations failed to extend the aviation on July 30.
Both sides since July 30 have engaged in an oral battle -- Taipei is threatening economic sanctions while Manila says it will retaliate.

Barican blamed Taipei for the lack of progress in the negotiations. He stressed that the Philippine government had been asking Taipei to start the negotiations and review the aviation accord since early this year.
He noted that the Philippine government hoped that both sides could eliminate their differences through frank and sincere exchanges. Taipei eventually agreed to hold talks on July 29, he said.

"Manila had proposed to 10 Boeing 747 flights or 16 Airbus-300 flights a week for each country, based on projected figures that the number of tourists from Taipei to Manila for 1999 would reach 200,000," he said.
He pointed out that any flights in excess of this proposal would then be "subjected to the commercial agreement".
"Taiwan turned down the Filipino proposal even after the Philippine side repeatedly explained that these measures were taken to ensure the survival of Philippine Airlines (PAL)," he said.

Barican accused Taipei of repeatedly charging that the Civil Aeronautic Committee of the Philippines had temporarily suspended China Airlines' Taipei-Hong Kong-Manila flights, violating the Taipei-Manila Aviation Accord. In order to express "our good faith", "we had lifted the sanction against CAL flights," he said.

"In the face of the intransigent attitude from Taipei, the Philippine side was left with no other option than to terminate the operations of ROC carriers effective September 30, 1999," he added. Timothy Sun & Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA OFFICIALS DENY INFLUENCING BOEING DECISION

TEXT.P: Officials at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) denied on Friday that the government is using the China Airlines' (CAL) deal with Boeing as a bargaining chip against Washington.

Being a public corporation, CAL is responsible for conducting its own business and is free to decide to buy what kind of aircraft on the basis of its own professional consideration. The government is not in a position to meddle with CAL business decisions, said the officials who asked not to be named.
The MOFA officials were unaware that US Secretary of Commerce William Daley and US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky had sent separate letters to Premier Vincent Siew lobbying for Boeing.
However, they confirmed that US Senator Slade Gorton, R-Washington, is scheduled to visit Taiwan in the near future.
As a lawmaker from the state that hosts Boeing's headquarters and its main plants, the officials said they would not be surprised if Gorton raises his concern about the deal with Taipei authorities.

The officials dismissed as "unacceptable joking" reports by a US newspaper, the Tacoma News Tribune in Washington State on Thursday that CAL is caught in a political struggle between Taipei and Washington.

The Tacoma News Tribune said that Taipei is asking CAL to switch its order for 12 Boeing 777s, with a price tag of US$2 billion, to Airbus Industries of France, after Washington sided with Beijing over President Lee Tung-hui's recent redefinition of Taiwan's statehood.
The officials said deals involving aircraft orders are usually concluded after years of studies and negotiations, and couldn't be changed overnight.
CAL signed a letter of intent for the aircraft with Boeing in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOC PRESIDENT KIM UN YONG TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 6 (CNA): Kim Un Yong, president of Korean Olympic Committee (KOC), will make a three-day visit to the Republic of China on Aug. 10-12 at the invitation of his ROC counterpart Hwang Tai-chow.

Kim, to be accompanied by Rocky Kangiro Yoon, deputy secretary general of the Korean Olympic Committee; Sung Ii-Baeck, chief secretary; and Jung Hoon Kim, an assistant, will sign a Sino-Korean bilateral sports interchange accord with his Chinese counterpart aimed at strengthening sports interchanges between the two countries.
Kim and his entourage will also call on the Chinese Taipei Taikwondo Association. Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC TO RESPECT CAL AIRCRAFT PROCUREMENT PLAN: LIN

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng said on Friday that his ministry will respect the China Airlines' aircraft procurement plan.
Lin made the remark amid speculation that CAL will transfer part of its airplane order from Boeing Co. to European Airbus Industries.

The United States has expressed grave concern about CAL possibly changing its aircraft procurement plan. Rumors have spread that the ROC government has asked CAL to make the change after the US sided with Beijing over President Lee Tung-hui's recent redefinition of cross-strait relations as "special state-to-state."
CAL said its aircraft procurement plan has not been finalized and that the company will fully explain the plan at a future date.
Lin said CAL has not reported to him on the specifics of the procurement plan and his ministry will respect CAL's final decision on the procurement plan.

CAL originally planned to procure new planes last year. However, that plan was shelved after a crash in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, killed all 196 passengers and crew on board and six others on the ground.
Lin said the CAL procurement plan is solely intended to renovate the company's aircraft fleet and has nothing to do with politics.

Lin indicated that in the past, CAL purchased planes entirely from the United States in tune with ROC governmental policy. However, with more and more private enterprises competing for CAL's stake in the market, the former national flag carrier is gradually freeing itself from government control and is deciding by itself from which airplane manufacturing companies worldwide to purchase its fleet, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD TO ATTEND APEC SUMMIT AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang will attend the 1999 summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) slated for Sept. in Auckland, New Zealand, a ranking official with the CEPD confirmed on Friday.

Brushing aside local media reports that Taiwan may not be able to take part in this year's APEC summit due to the escalating tension between Taiwan and mainland China following President Lee Teng-hui's July 9 redefinition of Taiwan-mainland ties as "special state-to-state relationship," CEPD Secretary-General Yeh Ming-feng revealed that an APEC envoy has visited Taipei recently and extended an invitation to Chiang personally.
According to Yeh, the APEC envoy also praised Chiang as an outstanding representative, who will take part in the organization's Sept. summit on behalf of President Lee.

Commenting on the latest news that China Airlines (CAL) has decided to shift a purchase order of 14 passenger airplanes, worth US2.9 billion, from the US-based Boeing Co. to the France-headquartered Airbus Industrie amid the current situation across the Taiwan Strait, Yeh called on the public not to speculate on the issue as CAL's airplane procurement plan is only a trade activity.
He called on both Taiwan and mainland China to calm down first, and said that it is necessary for the two sides to demonstrate respect toward each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TO MEET SOUTH KOREA FOR JONES CUP CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei national men's' team defeated the New Zealand national representative squad, 79-73, to remain undefeated during the 22nd R. William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament on Friday.
The win by the local side sets up an encounter with South Korea on Saturday for the tournament's championship.
Chinese Taipei was able to penetrate the defense of New Zealand's two 214 cm. post players, by using outside shooting. Lo Hsin-liang paced Chinese Taipei with 30 points.
Chinese Taipei led at the half 40-35 and the game remained close until the final three minute when the locals built a double-digit lead.
Friday's win means Chinese Taipei will meet the tournament's only other undefeated team -- the South Korean national men's team -- for this year's championship.
Earlier Friday, South Korea beat Costa Rica 90-84. Costa Rica will play New Zealand on Saturday for third place.
In Friday's other game, Bahrain defeated South Africa 50-49 to keep South Africa winless.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL SECTOR IN ROC NEEDS MORE Y2K EFFORT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's financial and related sectors were told in late April and again in early July they need to make more effort to cope with the Y2K computer crisis by the Global Y2K Coordinating Organization.
The financial sector was given a yellow code --- meaning that ROC's financial and related sectors need to do more to cope with the millennium computer bug.

Hsieh Chien-hsing, head of data office of the Central Bank of China, said the international organization's rating of the ROC's financial and related sectors' coping with the Y2K bug was not totally accurate. He said his office has given an explanation through a channel to the international organization in the hope that it conducts a re-evaluation.

Hsieh said in a routine news conference that the main reason for the yellow rating was that the information released by the financial and related sectors was mainly in Chinese, therefore hard for the international group to interpret.

He said after the Central Bank of China collected related data and re-evaluated the data according to the method used by the international coordinating organization, the ROC's rating was green, meaning satisfactory progress.

The Global Y2K Coordinating Organization is an unofficial international organization that has participation from 70 countries' financial, securities and insurance institutions. At present, the 70 countries have 630 institutions participating in the organization.
