The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.104, and reached a low of 32.129.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$40.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO FREE ROC SHIP AND CREW

TEXT.P: New Party Lawmaker Lee Ching-hua on Saturday urged mainland China to quickly free a Taiwan ship and its crew detained late last month by mainland authorities in the Taiwan Strait.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Lee called on the mainland authorities to quickly release the Shin Hwa freighter and its ten crew members, including captain Kuo Tai-sheng, or at least allow their families to visit them.

Lee also urged relevant domestic government agencies to work out a package of measures to effectively protect Taiwan residents' safety, as the Shin Hwa incident is not an isolated case, despite its sensitive timing. The governments on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should give precedence to the interests of the people when handling similar cases, he added.

Lee said he immediately contacted Wang Xiaobing, a vice director of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), which handles the mainland's unofficial ties with Taiwan, upon learning of the Shin Hwa incident. According to the New Party lawmaker, Wang promised to contact him as soon as the ARATS had gained a better understanding of the case.

The Shin Hwa freighter was intercepted by a mainland Chinese military vessel while carrying supplies from the northern Taiwan port of Keelung to the outlying Republic of China-controlled island of Matsu on July 31.
Mainland Chinese security officials accused the Shin Hwa of smuggling and intruding into mainland Chinese territorial waters, and forced the ship to go to Mawei Port in nearby Fujian Province.
Family members of the crew who also attended the news conference also appealed to the mainland authorities to release the crew as soon as possible.

Pointing out that they have been unable to contact their family members, even by telephone, they expressed the hope that both Taiwan and mainland China will deal with the case rationally in order to prevent it from turning into a political matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA IS THE MAIN CULPRIT IN TAIWAN STRAIT CRISIS: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By C.C. Huang and Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, and its belief that Taipei can be coerced into accepting Beijing's terms through naval blockades and missile exercises, are the main cause of the crisis in the Taiwan Strait, a US expert said on Wednesday.
Wang Wei-cheng, a political science professor at Richmond University, Virginia, made the remarks in a interview with PBS's "News Hour with Jim Lehrer."

For the last 20 years, Wang said, the security of the Taiwan region has depended on "effective deterrence," that is, through a show of force. But mainland China's increasing build-up of its military strength and its perception that the "one China" policy adopted by the United States is leaning more towards Beijing, has become the cause of instability in the Taiwan Strait.

Wang said the government and people of the Republic of China welcomed Sen. Jesse Helm's proposed Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, since it would show US commitment to upholding Taiwan's security, and would boost Taipei's confidence in bilateral negotiations with the mainland. He added that it is in the US interest that both sides of the strait proceed with dialogue.

He pointed out that Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait relations as "a special state-to-state relationship" is simply a reaffirmation of the fact that the ROC has been an independent sovereign country since 1912.

He further pointed out that recent public opinion polls in Taiwan reveal that the majority of the island's people wish to maintain the status quo, with less than 4 percent wishing for speedy independence or reunification.

Meanwhile, Pei Minxin, a mainland Chinese scholar residing in the United States, pointed out that Lee's announcement of his "special state-to-state relations" theory is seen by the authorities in Beijing as a public declaration of independence.
If Taiwan holds to such claims, Pei warned, it will lead to a military conflict. However, he added that this is a latent danger, and that fighting will not break out for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAUER PLEDGES TO STAND UP TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Republican presidential hopeful Gary Bauer said on Friday that if elected US president, he will stand up to mainland China and ensure that the United States lives up to its defense obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

Following a US Senate hearing on the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act on Wednesday, Bauer said that in the face of clear signals from the mainland intended to intimidate Taiwan in recent weeks, the Clinton administration continues to appease Beijing, and is even suggesting that it will cut arms sales to Taiwan.
"Such a move could violate our obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act in which the United States is committed to supplying Taiwan with the weapons it needs to defend itself," said Bauer.

Unfortunately, he pointed out, the Clinton administration's weakness is only part of the problem. For several years, "Republicans as well as Democrats have been pushing for a policy that accommodates China's dictators regardless of concerns over America's national security and our most deeply-held values."

The practice of routinely granting Beijing most-favored nation trade status, which members of both parties in Congress recently voted to renew, has been a major element of that policy. "Sadly, when presented with opportunities to draw distinctions, many GOP leaders, including presidential front-runner George W. Bush, advocate a China policy indistinguishable from Bill Clinton and Al Gore," said the conservative Republican.

Bauer stressed that "America needs a president who will craft a new China policy, one that places our national security ahead of the dubious prospect of short-term profits. As president, I will stand up to China's aggression. I will end China's most-favored nation status which strengthens the communist regime and helps it fund one of the world's largest arms build-ups. I will deploy a Theater Missile Defense system to protect American troops and our allies in the region, and I will ensure that the United States lives up to its defense obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act."

Another threat to America's national security emerged this week with Beijing's test of its newest DF-31 intercontinental ballistic missile and its announcement of the development of another medium-range missile, the DF-25.

Bauer said that the recently-tested DF-31 has the capability to strike the western United States with a nuclear warhead. Moreover, the DF-31 warhead is believed to have been developed using information that Beijing gained through its espionage activity. "Once again we see that a weak foreign policy directly endangers the safety of the American people," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOA SLAMS BEIJING ON HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Voice of America radio station on Friday criticized mainland China for violating the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights it signed last year.
It also called on Beijing to release all jailed pro-democracy activists and give the mainland Chinese people a greater voice in domestic political affairs.
The radio, which expresses the policies of the US government, noted that the Beijing government has recently sentenced several more pro-democracy activists to long prison terms.

The VOA pointed out that all these activists are supporters of the outlawed China Democracy Party. More than a year ago, an open debate began in mainland China on the issue of political reform. For the most part, mainland authorities did not interfere with the debate. But when activists tried to organize an opposition to the ruling Communist Party, the government began making arrests, it added.

Nearly a year ago, Beijing signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, but as the ongoing arrests indicate, the VOA said, "the Chinese government has not brought its practices into line with the standards set forth in that United Nations document.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN TO ABANDON EAST TIMOR IF CIVIL WAR ERUPTS: REPORT

TEXT.P: The United Nations is considering plans to abandon East Timor in the event of civil war after the Aug. 30 ballot in the former Portuguese colony, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday.

The daily reported that the UN has rejected a phase 1 plan that an international military force be sent into East Timor for a short-term period to counter widespread violence. Instead, if war does threaten to break out, all UN personnel -- including military advisers and police -- will be immediately pulled out for their own safety, it said.
In its phase 2 plan, however the UN is considering sending 10,000 international troops to East Timor early next year to maintain law and order, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA-AUSTRALIA TIES SEEN GETTING WARMER

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Australia in early September is regarded by some analysts as helpful to the relations between the two countries.

The Australian Financial Review on Saturday reported that Jiang is expected to reward Australia with a US$10 billion contract to buy liquefied natural gas when he visits Canberra, and meets with Prime Minister John Howard and other senior Australian officials.

Jiang will be the first highest-ranking official from mainland China to visit Australia. It will be his second tour to Australia following a trip he made to western Australia when he was the mayor of Shanghai, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: JULY FOREIGN TRADE SEES DOUBLE-DIGIT GROWTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted double-digit growth in both exports and imports in July, a sign that the island's foreign trade has now emerged completely from the Asian financial meltdown, an economics official said on Saturday.

Taiwan exported US$9.99 billion-worth of goods in July, representing 11.8 percent growth from the year-earlier level. Discounting seasonal or holiday fluctuations, the growth rate was the largest since August 1997, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
Taiwan imports in July amounted to US$9.5 billion, up 20.2 percent from the same month of last year, the best on record since October 1997.
As a result, the island gained US$490 billion in trade surpluses for the month, the third month in a row that the island has enjoyed a surplus, according to the statistics.

MOF Director of Statistics Hsu Kuo-chung pointed out that capital goods imports amounted to US$2.72 billion in July, up 50.7 percent from the previous year. The figure represents a seven-year high, he said, adding that Taiwan's economy is now in an optimistic period of recovery.

According to a MOF analysis, the double-digit harvest can be mainly attributed to Taiwan's increasing trade with Hong Kong, Japan, the United States, European countries, and members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

MOF statistics show that Taiwan imports from the US posted a 38.4 percent year-on-year increase in July, the largest growth since the beginning of 1997, while exports to Asian countries expanded 28.1 percent, the largest surge since September, 1995.
In terms of export to South Korea, a 115.4 percent growth was recorded in July, the largest single-month growth ever recorded in Taiwan's foreign trade.

July exports to Japan climbed 36.4 percent, while exports to the ASEAN countries surged 33.9 percent, and exports to Hong Kong grew 14 percent, all representing new highs since the outbreak of the Asian financial storm in mid-1997, the MOF figures show.

The statistics also show that Taiwan's exports in the first seven months of this year posted an increase of 6.3 percent, thanks to active trading in the electronic, computer, machinery, and optical manufacturing sectors.

During the seven-month period, Taiwan exports to the United States saw a 5.9 percent growth compared with the year-earlier level, while exports to Asia rose 12.3 percent, and exports to Hong Kong moved up 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES SURGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices jumped 3.3 percent on Saturday to reclaim the psychologically important 7,000-point level on strong government intervention amid continued tension with mainland China.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index soared 226.22 points to close at 7,049.74.
A total of 1.94 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$91.82 billion (US$2.86 billion), up from the previous session's NT$67.26 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, electronics shares reported the largest gains of the day, surging 4.6 percent, followed by financial stocks, which climbed 2.6 percent.
Cement issues gained 2.5 percent, textile shares rose 2.2 percent, and plastic and chemical shares advanced 1.6 percent.
The paper and pulp sector posted a 0.9 percent rise, and construction stocks increased 0.6 percent.
Foodstuff issues suffered the only drop of the day, falling a slight 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market jumped 4.10 points to close at 157.48, on a turnover of NT$4.43 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August increased 165 points to close at 7,035, with 4,337 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September posted a 147-point rise to close at 7,037, while those for December soared 199 points, ending the day at 7,090. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 387 and seven, respectively.
Futures for next March advanced 160 points, closing at 7,091, with five contract transactions. Next June's futures remained static, finishing at 6,962 points, with one contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 6,870 points for August, 6,890 points for September, 6,891 points for December, 6,931 points for next March, and 6,962 points for next June.
In related news, the recently launched electronics futures (TE) and financial futures (TF) both reported gains.
August TE futures were up 13.6 points, closing at 317, with 1,459 contract transactions; September TE futures climbed 13.2 to close at 315.25 points, with 56 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for the other months.
August TF futures rose 30 points to close at 1,003, with 173 contract transactions; September TF futures gained 19.8 points and closed at 989.8, with four contract transactions.
There were no transactions recorded for the other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S CREDIT RATING HARD TO IMPROVE: REPORT

TEXT.P: Australia will find it difficult to boost its international credit rating because of its high current account deficit, external debt and low national savings rate, according to Moody's Investors Service in New York.

In a dispatch from New York, the Australian Financial Review on Saturday reported that Moody's published a positive view of Australia's economy, saying that this reflects Australia's stable political structure, advanced economic status and sound economic policy framework.
But it also criticized Australia for its heavy reliance on foreign capital which stems from a structural imbalance between domestic savings and investment, and results in a surge in foreign debt.

Moody's estimates that Australia's foreign debt will rise to US$135.4 billion this year, up from US$127 billion in 1998 and US$85.1 billion five years ago. This year's debt accounts for 60 percent of its gross domestic product, up from 56.6 percent last year.
Moody's also estimates that Australia's current account deficit will rise to US$23.3 billion this year, up from US$20.9 billion last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO PURCHASE AIRBUS PASSENGER JETS
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By C. P. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading carrier China Airlines (CAL) will sign a contract with France-based Airbus Industrie in Taipei on Aug. 11 to purchase 15 A-340 and A-330 passenger jets, a senior company executive said here on Friday.

CAL Chairman Chiang Hung-yi, who is accompanying ROC Premier Vincent Siew on his current five-day official visit to Macedonia, said the purchase of A-340 and A-330 jets instead of Boeing's 777 jets was purely a commercial decision and had nothing to do with politics.

"Our decision to purchase Airbus passenger jets is mainly aimed at simplifying aircraft models in our fleet as well as for our corporate benefits," Chiang said, adding that the recent controversy over the "special state-to-state relationship" theory has no role in the deal.
In addition to the passenger jet deal with Airbus, Chiang said CAL will also sign a contract with Boeing Co. of the United States next week to purchase 17 Boeing 747-400 all-cargo freighters.
The two contracts, worth a total of US$4 billion, form CAL's largest aircraft purchase deal in the 20th century.
Some press reports said on Thursday that Boeing is still making a last-ditch effort to lobby CAL to purchase its Boeing 777 passenger jets instead of Airbus planes.

Boeing claimed that CAL's decision to switch its passenger jet order to Airbus was out of political consideration. Boeing sources said the switch was partly for protesting the Clinton administration's opposition to ROC President Lee Teng-hui's recent definition of relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship."
Chiang said all such reports are sheer speculation, adding that the Airbus deal is part of the carrier's effort to simplify its aircraft models.

In the future, Chiang said Boeing 747-400 and 737-800 as well as Airbus A340 will form the backbone of CAL's passenger fleet. "We'll gradually phase out MD-2, Boeing 747-200 and Airbus A-300," he added.
