DOC.HEADLINE: 15 LAWMAKERS EXPECTED TO SHOW SUPPORT FOR EX-TAIWAN GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Some 15 lawmakers will show their support for former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong's 2000 presidential bid when he explains his national policies at a mass rally on Aug. 14 in Yungho City, Taipei County, Kuomintang Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said on Saturday.

Liu, a long-time ally of Soong who presided over the opening of a campaign office in northern Keelung City for Soong on Friday, said the 15 legislators are just the vanguard, and claimed that more opinion leaders will publicly demonstrate their backing for Soong as the March presidential race approaches.
As for the question of who will serve as Soong's vice presidential running mate, Liu said it is premature to talk about the issue, but added that Soong's camp is exploring all feasible channels.

Soong, a KMT stalwart who lost his position as provincial governor in December 1998 as a result of the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government, announced his independent presidential bid last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIEN WILL ANNOUNCE VP BY YEAR END

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bien, the presidential candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday that he will announce his vice presidential running mate by year's end.
Chen made the remarks when answering reporters' questions as he made a tour of his new campaign office in Taipei City's Tunhua South Road.

The former Taipei City mayor said that his present priorities are to put on track the organization and human resource deployment of his campaign office and integrate "DPP party affairs with campaign affairs."

The campaign's structural framework will be finished shortly, according to Chen. He then will announce who his vice presidential candidate will be, adding that he is "still undecided at present" who to pick.

The "ability" of his vice presidential running mate is more important than his "suitability," he continued. Chen pointed out that he does not rule out the possibility of pairing with someone outside the DPP.

In response to recently released opinion polls indicating that Chen's public support rate has fallen behind James Soong and Lien Chan, the former mayor admitted that while he does pay attention to survey results, he does not let them affect his mood or campaign tactics.
Chen declined to comment on a possible KMT ticket of Lien Chan with Premier Vincent Siew. He called the matter a KMT "domestic affair."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENTREPRENEURS' PRIVATE PLANES MUST BE REGISTERED ABROAD

TEXT.P: Since planes are not allowed to be privately owned in Taiwan, aircraft owned by Taiwan entrepreneurs have to be registered abroad in order to fly in and out of the country.

Liu Tai-ying, director of the ruling Kuomintang's business management committee, departed for the Philippines on a private plane provided by the ACER conglomerate on Friday. He reportedly is trying to resolve the dispute over Taipei-Manila aviation rights. The ACER plane Liu used is registered abroad.
Taiwan entrepreneurs who have owned planes include Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinatrust Commercial Bank; and J. F. Chang, president of the Evergreen conglomerate.
However, Chang sold his private plane several years ago, as his EVA Airways Corporation has flights worldwide -- negating his need for a personal plane.

In light of the fact that aviation and airport space is limited in Taiwan, domestic civil aeronautic laws state that all aircraft registered on the island must be available for public use only. No aircraft are allowed to be privately owned, said officials of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

If a plane is registered abroad, it is seen as a foreign plane, hence it is entitled to freely fly in and out of Taiwan after receiving CAA permission to take off or land in Taiwan, the officials noted.

According to informed sources, Koo's private plane is a US-made Gulfstream, while the planes owned by the ACER and Chang were made in France. Due to a very inexpensive registration fee in the United States, US$25 per plane, the three privately-owned planes are all registered in the US. Koo's plane is stored and maintained in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOD REFUTES REPORT ON AIR BATTLE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Defense (MOD) on Saturday refuted an Internet article saying that a furious air battle between the military aircraft of Taiwan and mainland China over the Taiwan Strait occurred on Friday morning.

The Office of Military Spokesman released a statement, spelling out the MOD's determination to find out how, from whom, and from where the rumor started. The MOD has asked law-enforcement authorities to investigate whether or not the rumor was started to cause chaos across the nation, the statement said.

The report written in simplified Chinese characters and in anonymity appeared Friday on the "Wforum.com/news" website, which is based in mainland China. It claimed, in the name of the Taipei-based Central News Agency, that the morning air battle had inflicted damage on the both sides.
The MOD statement blamed the story as a malicious attempt to disturb social and financial order in Taiwan and called on the public to neglect rumors.

Military Spokesman Maj. Gen. Kung Fan-ding urged the general public to use the information issued by MOD spokesmen and other authorized press officers as their primary source of news on the military situation in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO ATTEND APEC MEETING AS USUAL: HU

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu said here on Saturday that the Republic of China will attend the annual meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in New Zealand in September.

Hu, who is accompanying Premier Vincent Siew on his five-day official visit to Macedonia, was responding to a press inquiry whether the ROC can attend the annual APEC event in the wake of the recent controversy over the "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
In response, Hu said he doesn't think that the controversy should hinder the ROC's participation in this year's APEC meeting since the ROC is a full member of the regional forum.

Both the ROC and mainland China are APEC members. Because of Beijing's opposition, ROC President Lee Teng-hui has been unable to attend the annual APEC informal leadership meeting. He has instead had to name a surrogate to attend such annual summit on his behalf. Lee has designated P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, to represent him at this year's APEC summit.

Commenting on reports that the United States is concerned about the increased fighter jet activities in the Taiwan Strait in recent days because of the "special state-to-state" theory and has asked Taipei and Beijing to exercise restraint to avoid escalation of tension in the region, Hu said ROC military authorities have ordered fighter pilots to exercise "high degree of restraint."
"We don't want to cause tension in the Taiwan Strait," Hu said, adding that the ROC has never taken any provocative action.
Hu left the Macedonian capital of Skopje for New York around Saturday noon for a transit stop on his way to Nicaragua to attend a meeting with foreign ministers of five ROC allies in Central America.
It remains unclear whether he will meet with any American official to exchange views on the current cross-strait tension or other matters of mutual concern during his transit stay in New York.
On Saturday morning, Premier Siew attended a ceremony marking the ROC's purchase of 30 buses from Macedonia for donation to war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
Siew also met with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski to put finishing touch on some bilateral cooperative projects.

Siew, heading a 100-member delegation of senior government officials, business executives, private charity executives and journalists, arrived in Skopje on Tuesday for his first visit to Macedonia since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year.

At the end of his visit here, Siew will give a news conference to explain the ROC's basic stances on some critical issues, including its relations with mainland China, its concrete measures to assist Macedonia in reviving its battered economy and its aid projects to Kosovar refugees.
Meanwhile, the World Vision of Taiwan, a Taipei-based charity, donated 5,000 stationery bags and 10,000 tool boxes to Kosovar refugees on Saturday.
The donation was presented by Shao Ching-ming, president of the World Vision of Taiwan.

Shao said despite geographic distance, the ROC government and people are more than willing to offer assistance to Macedonian and Kosovar people rebuild their homeland and economy affected by civil war in Kosovo, which lies very close to Macedonia.
Shao said the World Vision of Taiwan has donated more than US$400,000 worth of relief goods to Kosovar refugees since the outbreak of the Kosovo crisis in May.
The charity has sent a team of volunteers to Kosovo to probe situation there and study feasible ways to assist in the reconstruction of the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PNG TO PRESS CHINA OVER DEPORTING REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Canberra, Aug. 7 (CNA): The Papua New Guinea government will press mainland China for the quick deportation of 60 Chinese boat people, who illegally entered the former Portuguese colony, according to the Post-Courier on Saturday.

The daily reported that Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister Sir Michale Somare will hold talks with Chinese embassy officials in Port Moresby so that the 60 boat people could be repatriated soon to the mainland.
The 60 Chinese refugees, including three women, illegally entered PNG last month and were captured at Gasmata in West New Britain Province, the daily reported. PETER CHEN

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTINUING HEAVY RAINFALL SERIOUSLY DAMAGES SOUTH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) Saturday continued to issue tropical low pressure warnings in southern Taiwan, where prolonged heavy rainfalls have already disrupted the region's land, air and sea traffic.

Chin Hsin-lung, a CWB weather forecaster, said Saturday that Changhwa, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and the outlying Penghu Islands will be under the influence of this low pressure zone, receiving torrential rainfall and strong winds.
Airports in the southern part of Taiwan were closed Saturday morning, seriously hampering domestic and international flights.
Flooding has also occurred in low-lying areas in Kaohsiung and Pintung, obstructing land traffic. The Kaohsiung harbor, swept by strong winds and waves, halted all entering and out-going vessels.

Vegetable and fruit prices have risen due to short supply. According to Council of Agriculture (COA) statistics, Taipei consumer market's vegetable prices have increased from NT$20.99 to NT$22.80 per kilogram.
COA officials said that as the downpour shows no signs of easing up, the upward price trend will continue in the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CALLS MEETING ON TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) called a meeting of government officials, bankers and contractor on Saturday to discuss some key issues related to the island's high-speed railway project.

The meeting was chaired by CEPD Vice Chairman K. C. Lee, with the participation of officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), Ministry of Finance, senior executives of several local banks and representatives of Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. (THSRC).
The agenda focused on bank loans, fund-raising and tax rates for the multibillion-dollar high-speed railway project, which will link Taipei in the north to Kaohsiung in the south.

THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing said after the two-and-half-hour meeting that the atmosphere at the meeting was amicable and that each relevant party was free to frankly express its opinion about all related issues.
Ing said she hopes the CEPD will clearly document consensus or conclusions reached at the meeting.

CEPD Vice Chairman Lee said the government will take all necessary steps to help THSRC, a private business and industry consortium which has won the contract to build the high-speed railway under a BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula, complete the massive infrastructure project smoothly.

It was decided during the meeting that the bank consortium which will offer NT$280 billion in syndicated loan to the THSRC to help finance the project can demand a maximum 1.5 percent mark-up on the Central Bank of China-set prime rate in deciding the interest rate for the huge loan.
The THSRC originally hoped that the ceiling on the mark-up will fall below 1.5 percent.

Meanwhile, the government agreed that the THSRC can raise additional funds at home and abroad if the construction cost exceeds its original estimate. In that case, the THSRC's own capital, about NT$121.9 billion, should still account for more than one quarter of its total corporate assets.

If the THSRC issues corporate bonds to raise funds, the amount should be deducted from its NT$280 billion loan from the bank consortium. After the deduction, the company's paid-in capital should still not fall below one-fourth of its total assets.

Lee said the CEPD will revise the wording of previous meeting minutes to let the THSRC understand that the government has no intention of restricting THSRC operations and is willing to assist the company in obtaining loans from local banks to ensure smooth proceeding of the project.

Commenting on press reports that several large European conglomerates and Taiwan's state-owned enterprises plan to invest in the high-speed railway project, THSRC Chairwoman Ing said she welcomes the participation of new investors in the project. "This will help enhance our confidence in completing the project," Ing said, adding that the joining of new investors is still in the "contact stage."
The new railway is scheduled for completion in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTER TALKS ABOUT SITUATION IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The combat preparedness of Taiwan's armed forces is maintained at a regular level, although the activities of mainland Chinese military aircraft in the Taiwan Strait area have increased recently, Minister of National Defense Tang Fei said Saturday.
In an interview with the Chinese Broadcasting Corporation in Taipei, Tang said there is no indication that mainland China is going to wage a full-scale war against Taiwan.

The purpose of mainland China to increase military aircraft sorties in the Taiwan Strait area is to wage psychological warfare against Taiwan and to wreak havoc on the Taiwan stock market, he said, adding that appropriate actions will be taken in case the activities of mainland Chinese warplanes endanger the safety of civilian aircraft over the Taiwan Strait.

Tang urged the general public not to believe the rumors being spread by mainland China through Hong Kong news media. He refuted as "totally untrue" a report on the Internet, which said a fierce air battle between the warplanes of Taiwan and mainland China took place over the Taiwan Strait on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY TO ISSUE NEW PUBLIC LOTTERY THIS MONTH

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government will issue new public lotteries by the end of this month, Mayor Frank Hsieh said Saturday at a press conference.

Showing samples of "Ai Hsin Lo" lottery tickets in the form of scratch-cards at the press conference, the mayor said that the city government will put 1.2 million tickets in the market for sale in the first period, and that it plans to sell 6 million tickets in five periods. But the length of each period has not been decided yet. "Ai Hsin Lo" means love and happiness in Chinese.

Hsieh said that, after consulting experts and scholars in law, he came to believe that the city government's plan is consistent with the recently-revised statutes governing the issuance of public lotteries.
The Kaohsiung city government marketed 240,000 public lottery tickets on a trial basis earlier this year. The sale ended after the central government took a legal action against it.

Hsieh said the new public lottery offers higher cash prizes for the winners. The highest prize will increase to NT$2,500,000 from NT$500,000, while the lowest prize will increase to NT$500 from NT$200.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P: A Taipei-datelined and Central News Agency-attributed Internet news report saying that an air battle erupted in the skies over the Taiwan Strait at 8:50 a.m. Friday was purely fabricated in the name of CNA.
We hope our subscribers and readers at home and abroad will pay attention to this and will not be misled by this fictitious report.

The fabricated report, appearing at an Internet website -- Wforum.Com/news -- on Aug. 6, quoted the Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense as saying that the air forces of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait started an air battle over the strait at 8:50 a.m. today.
Wforum.Com/news is a US-registered website using simplified Chinese character. It is probably an affiliate of a mainland China-based website.
CNA would like to caution our readers at home and abroad not to lightly believe in such fabricated news published on Internet.
We also call for concerted efforts to curb spread of rumors and maintain the purity of Internet order.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC STRENGTH KEY TO RESOLVE CROSS-STRAIT TENSION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Saturday that solution to the current tension in the Taiwan Strait does not lie in military wrangling or saber-rattling but in economic strength.
Lee made the statement at an annual congress of the private Council for Commerce and Industry Research, which groups a new crop of young business and industry executives.

Airborne activities over the Taiwan Strait have increased since President Lee defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station on July 9. Beijing viewed the "state-to-state" definition as a move to promote Taiwan independence and has launched saber-rattling against Taiwan.

Reviewing the current Taiwan Strait situation, Lee said so long as the Republic of China can stabilize its economy and ensure sustained economic growth, it will be able to score a final victory in its competition with mainland China.
Lee said the ROC faced an export slowdown and a bearish stock market two years ago when a dramatic depreciation of the Thai currency triggered a regional and even worldwide financial crisis.
The ROC government has adopted a series of pump-priming measures since late 1997 to stabilize financial markets and stimulate domestic economic growth, Lee said.

In addition, the president said, the government has taken concrete measures to streamline the economic structure and update economic regulations to create a more favorable business and investment environment and upgrade Taiwan's overall competitiveness in the world market.

Through all these efforts, Lee said, Taiwan's economy has bottomed out of recession and gradually regained momentum. "We should continue our efforts to promote structural and managerial reforms to sustain our economic growth and create a brighter future for our country," the president urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS SEE NO IMMEDIATE OUTBREAK OF WAR IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Despite mainland China's saber-rattling over the recent controversy concerning the "special state-to-state" theory, the possibility of an immediate outbreak of war in the Taiwan Strait is slim, local strategists said on Saturday.

The strategists and mainland affairs scholars made the forecast at a seminar on recent escalation of tension in the Taiwan Strait and Beijing's strategy in engaging in psychological warfare against Taiwan.
The scholars said nearly all sensational or shocking reports about possible mainland China attack on Taiwan were disseminated by Beijing's mouthpieces in Hong Kong.
"None of those reports have been proved true," said Su Chin-chiang, director of the Strategic Study Center of Nan Hua University.

Su said mainland China has to mobilize at least 400,000 troops if it wants to invade Taiwan. "As mainland China now faces many domestic problems and challenges, it's not easy for mainland China to launch an attack on Taiwan at the moment."
Noting that the so-called Taiwan issue is not just a problem between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Su said the issue is related to the United States' deployment in the Asia-Pacific region.
At the moment, Su said Beijing just tries to take advantage of the uncertainty concerning top mainland envoy Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan this autumn to intimidate Taiwan people.

Speaking on the same occasion, Hsu Ju-heng, an official with the Ministry of National Defense, said several units in mainland China's Nanjing Military Region, which is traditionally responsible for deployment against Taiwan, are now busy with fighting floods in several mainland provinces.

Against this background, Hsu said he doesn't think the People's Liberation Army is really ready for military action against Taiwan. "Beijing is just using Hong Kong media to release false news to intimidate our people," he said, adding that local people should not be panicked by such unfounded speculation and rumors.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi on Saturday chaired a meeting of advisers to the Cabinet-level council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.
Seven of the 11 MAC advisers present at the meeting voiced support for President Lee Teng-hui's definition of cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship."
Only one adviser expressed explicit opposition to the "state-to-state" concept and three didn't express any opinion.
Jan Jyh-horng, a MAC department chief, quoted Su as saying at the meeting that the government's mainland policy has not changed following the release of the "state-to-state" theory.
"The 'state-to-state' definition just reflects facts and realities," Su was quoted as saying at the meeting.

Some MAC advisers said mainland China is not expected to take actions to create a Taiwan Strait crisis similar to that in 1996. One reason was that such actions, including live-fire war games at Taiwan's doorsteps and test-firing of missiles, were very costly. Mainland China spent an estimated 17 billion renminbi during the 1995-96 Taiwan Strait crisis.

Another reason was that mainland China has come to conclude that its 1996 military action had produced many negative effects, including pushing for closer military cooperation between the United States and Japan, the MAC advisers said.
Moreover, the advisers said the mainland economy is currently in far worse shape than in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: S. KOREANS CROWN WILLIAM JONES CUP BASKETBALL TOURNEY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 7 (CNA): The South Korean National Men's Basketball team edged Chinese Taipei 70-67 on Saturday to retain the championship of the 22nd R. William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament in Taipei.

The Chinese Taipei five were apparently eager to win the game at the beginning and committed a lot of errors in the first half time. The gap once even reached 13 points. The Korean five led 36-33 at the end of the first half.

The Chinese Taipei has better performance in the 10 minutes after the second half began by leading the Korean team by five points. But at the last minute, a Korean player scored two point plus one penalty point to capture the championship.
In other matches held earlier, the New Zealand five defeated the Costa Rican National Men's Basketball Team 62-60 to win the third place.
The Second Chinese Taipei team, Kuanghwa, trounced the Bahrain five 74-47 to put itself at the fifth place.

The South African team was placed at the seventh place while the Philippine team, which left Taiwan on Thursday morning after a violent fist-fighting incident in a Wednesday match with Chinese Taipei, trailed the tourney.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PM SIEW CONCLUDES VISIT TO MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew and his delegation on Saturday ended their five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting between Siew and his Macedonia counterpart, Ljubco Georgievski.
During the meeting, several agreements were reached to enhance bilateral cooperative relations.
Under the terms of the accords, the ROC promised to provide about US$61 million in low-interest loans and aid to Macedonia to help with the national development of the Balkan country.

Of the total, US$20 million will be in low-interest loans for building public housing units, and US10.5 million for improving Macedonia's infrastructural facilities, including transportation, tap water supply, and schools, as well as social welfare programs and news broadcast systems.

Meanwhile, the ROC will take part in the Balkan action program by providing an additional US$31 million loans to Macedonia, including US$20 million for its city construction and environmental protection, US$6 million as reconstruction and investment fund, US$3 million for technical assistance and US$2 million as Taiwan's investment in Macedonia's pharmaceutical industry.
Siew, when asked by reporters at a press conference earlier Saturday, denied media reports that Taiwan has promised a US$1 billion aid-package for Macedonia.

"There is no such a big figure, ... simply talk about it (money) would be impractical," Siew said, adding that the development of bilateral relations should be on a long-term mutually-beneficial basis.
The accords signed by officials of the two countries were aimed to enhance bilateral cooperation in the fields of agriculture, export processing zones, and cultural and journalistic exchanges.

Siew arrived in Skopje on Tuesday as head of a 100-stong ROC delegation. The trip was part of the ROC's efforts to further cement the hard-won relations with the Balkan state in the face of mainland China's diplomatic offensive against Taiwan.
Although barred from visiting Kosov due to technical problems, Siew held talks with Kosovo Deputy Prime Minister Mehmet Hajrizi and ranking officials at the ROC embassy in Macedonia.
At the meeting, the premier reaffirmed Taiwan's massive aid package to the war-torn Kosov.

Members of Siew' entourage included Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang, Council of Agriculture Chairman Peng Tso-kwei, Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Chang Hou-sheng, Council for Cultural Affairs Chairwoman Lin Cheng-chih and Government Information Office Director General Chen Chien-jen as well as some 50 business leaders.

The business leaders have decided to import US$2.5 million worth of Macedonia-produced red wine, marbles, cigarette and woods and open a five-star hotel and invest in Macedonia's textile and marble processing industries..
Besides, the International Commercial Bank of China has also decided to establish a representative office in Skopje.
Siew and his delegation are scheduled to leave Skopje late in the evening and return to Taipei Monday morning via a third country. (By Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 8, or the 27th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
117: Hadrian becomes emperor of Rome after the death of Trajan.
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is finally defeated by the British.
1786: Dr. Michel Gabriel Paccard of Chamonix, Switzerland, and his porter, Jacques Balmat, complete the first ascent of the 4,807 meter Mont Blanc, the tallest peak in Europe outside the Caucasus range.
1834: Britain introduces workhouses for the poor.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Ester Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler hangs four of his top men with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain, and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first US president to resign from office.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1994: The SEF and ARATS sign and make public a joint press release confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
@The Central Daily News:
President Lee: Stabilized economy to weather Taiwan through cross-strait crisis.
@The China Times:
Ministry of National Defense to be reorganized, joined with Military Equipment Bureau.
The United Daily News:
Southern Taiwan hit by torrential rain, thousands of households inundated.
The Liberty Times:
Gusts and heavy rain forecast for four or five days in central and southern Taiwan.
The Commons Daily:
President Lee: The economy is Taiwan's weapon in its dispute with mainland China.
The China Post:
CAL bails out of Boeing deal to buy from Airbus.
The Taiwan News:
China Airlines confirms it will forgo Boeing 777s.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITIES RELEASE LIST OF FRESHMEN RECRUITED THROUGH JUEE

TEXT.P: Taiwan universities released a list of freshmen recruited through this year's Joint University Entrance Examination (JUEE) on Sunday.

The list of 72,466 freshmen, accounting for 61.39 percent of the total actually taking part in the uniform entrance examination in early July, was posted at the main gate of National Taiwan University at 11 a.m.
The total number of the recruits is 91 short of the full capacity of the universities in the JUEE program.

The list has also been posted on the Internet website set up by a JUEE committee. But the website was overwhelmed as soon as it went online at 8 a.m. Traffic eased somewhat after some media publications posted the list on their websites as well.
Of the number of freshmen admitted, 39,409 -- or 54.38 percent -- were men, and 33,057, or 45.62 percent, were women.

Among the newly recruited freshmen is veteran test taker Lee Cheng-gang. A senior at the industry and business administration department of National Taiwan University, Lee aspires to become a doctor. He was admitted into National Yang Ming Medical School this year after taking the examination for the fifth time.

There were 33 physically handicapped and elderly test takers this year, and nine were admitted into various universities. Muscular dystrophy suffer Chuan Shih-hsin was admitted into the entomology department of National Taiwan University, while Chen Pei-hsien, who suffers from weak vision, as admitted into National Taiwan University's law school.
Eighty-four-year-old Chao Mu-he, who attracted attention during the exam in July for being the oldest test taker this year, failed to win admission into a university.

Although the complicated scoring system of the JUEE allows various universities to weight the results of certain portions of the exams differently -- making it impossible to compare test scores across departments and schools -- law, medicine and electrical engineering are among the most popular disciplines.

DOC.HEADLINE: HACKER ATTACKS CONTROL YUAN WEBSITE

TEXT.P: The Internet website of the Control Yuan was broken into by a hacker who wiped out all of the information on the website and replaced it with an article advocating "one China."
The self-proclaimed "Chinese hacker" posted a Chinese-English announcement claiming that "there is only one China in the world, and the world needs only one China."
The announcement was clearly aimed at President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of Taipei-Beijing ties as "state-to-state" ones.
Hsieh Shung-chih, director for information affairs at the Control Yuan, told CNA that he was asked by Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien to restore the website Sunday morning.
Suspecting that there are political motives behind the attack, Chien also asked Hsieh to report the incident to law enforcement authorities, said Hsieh.
The website was taken off-line after the attack and remained down until Sunday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN AIRLINES, FORMOSA AIRLINES MERGE ON SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Domestic carriers Mandarin Airlines and Formosa Airlines formally merged on Sunday, bringing from seven to six the number of domestic fixed-wing airlines.
This is the second airline merger since the merger of UNI Airlines, Great China Airlines and Taiwan Airlines last year.
The new airlines will use the Mandarin Airlines name.
The new Mandarin Airlines will hold a formal press conference on Monday to give a detailed explanation of the merger.

Yueh Da-hsin, general manager of Mandarin Airlines, said the merger would not affect passengers' rights. In the early stages, people can still make reservations and obtain tickets through current telephone numbers, he said.

From Sunday, the logo of Formosa Airlines' counter at Sungshan domestic airport was changed to that of Mandarin Airlines, while the logo on Formosa Airlines planes will be changed on a step-by-step basis.
Both Mandarin Airlines and Formosa Airlines are subsidiaries of China Airlines, which decided to merge the two subsidiaries.

After the merger, China Airlines will step away from domestic flight services and transfer its operation of short-range international flight routes to Mandarin Airlines. China Airlines will serve only middle- and long-range international flight routes.
After the merger, Mandarin Airlines will receive a boost in capital, and China Airlines will reduce its stake in the company from 100 percent to 70 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF: NO US PRESSURE ON TAIWAN OVER STATE-T0-STATE STATEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The United States has never put pressure on or punished Taiwan over President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship," said Chairman Richard Bush of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Saturday.
Bush made the remarks while replying to questions after a speech to a meeting of the Alumni Association of Tunghai University in the Washington Area.
He told the gathering that he went to Taipei on July 22 to gain a better understanding of the situation, not to apply pressure or mediate.

The AIT chief said that as he indicated in a July 25 statement, issued before leaving Taiwan, he gained a better understanding of the situation from his trip, which means his superiors would also have a better understanding, he added.
Bush said that Lee's redefinition of the present cross-strait relations involved the nucleus of mainland-Taiwan relations, and therefore it is not appropriate for the United States to comment.
As the United States' policy is to let mainland China and Taiwan resolve their disputes, he stressed, Washington would not interfere in the cross-strait dialogue.
The important thing, Bush pointed out, is how Taipei and Beijing treat the other side's statements and whether progress can be achieved in the cross-strait dialogue.
When asked about the possibility of a military clash between the mainland and Taiwan, he said that there is presently concern over the escalation in the two sides' air force activities.
To prevent a military incident, Bush said, the United States hopes the mainland and Taiwan will show self-restraint.

Bush was invited to deliver a speech at the meeting, organized to welcome the Washington visit of Tunghai University President Wang Kang-pei. Bush's father taught at the English department of Tunghai University between 1966 and 1971.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CHILDREN'S LITERATURE CONVENTION OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A conference on Asian children's literature opened in Taipei on Sunday.

The Fifth Asia Children-Literature Convention has brought together 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines and Malaysia, as well as the host country, the Republic of China.
In addition to 60-odd papers to be read during the three-day convention, a dozen related exhibitions are being staged at the conference site, the Taipei City Library.
A 40-strong delegation from mainland China has canceled their trip to Taiwan because of the ongoing political dispute between Taipei and Beijing over the Republic of China's statehood claim.
Delivering an opening speech at the convention, President Lee Teng-hui stressed that literature is to children's mental development what nourishment is to their physical development.

Noting the far-reaching impact excellent literature has on children's intellectual and mental development, as well as on their sense of humanity, Lee urged the attendants to beef up exchanges between different countries in this field.
After the meeting in Taipei, the attendants will tour the island until Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWARMS OF PEOPLE LINE UP TO VISIT PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: To celebrate Chinese Father's Day, the Presidential Office was opened to the public on Aug. 8, and scores of people lined up to see the building.

Before the 8 a.m. opening there were numerous people gathering in front of the office, though this is not the first time the office has been opened to the public. Most people came with their with families and carried cameras.

More than 100 precious pieces of clay tea pots, provided by Deputy Secretary-General to the President Huang Cheng-hsiung, were on exhibition in the Presidential Office. Medals of President Lee Teng-hui were also exhibited in the office.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTINUING HEAVY RAIN IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) on Sunday announced that heavy rains would continue to threaten the middle, southern and southeastern parts of Taiwan, which are being affected by the approach of Typhoon Rachel.

The CWB said Rachel is moving toward a region north of Okinoerabu Island and will not hit Taiwan directly. The island will, however, remain under the influence of this low pressure zone, and southern Taiwan in particular can expect torrential rainfall.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIU HUNGDAH SLAMS 'SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A famous Chinese scholar criticized on Saturday the assertion of a "special state-to-state relationship" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, saying the point of view severely violates the constitution of the Republic of China.
Chiu Hungdah, a professor at the University of Maryland's law school, made the remarks at a seminar.
He said President Lee Teng-hui should not try to control the government single-handedly and that Lee was misled to raise the "state-to-state" concept by his subordinates.
Chiu said no matter who designed the assertion, the ROC's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council cannot shirk its responsibility.

He said that since there is no change in Article Four of the ROC's Constitution, there is no basis for Taipei to raise the "state-to-state" concept. Article Four stipulates that the territory of the Republic of China and its existing national boundaries shall not be altered except by a resolution of the National Assembly.
Chiu described the designer of the "state-to-state" theory as "totally mixed-up."

Chiu do not think the dispute would lead to a cross-strait military conflict because the ruling Kuomintang has not amended the Constitution to bring it in line with the "state-to-state" theory, rather, he said, Beijing has learned a lesson from the 1996 crisis in the Taiwan Strait.
Beijing would choose to let the United States solve the dispute that has resulted from the theory, he said.

Pei Min-hsin, a researcher at the Washington-based Carnegie International Peace Foundation, said that compared with the 1996 crisis in the Taiwan Strait, not only has the US Congress given only lukewarm support to Taiwan after Taipei redefined relations with Beijing in July, the US media is no longer fully supportive of Taiwan.
He said 55 percent to 60 percent of US news media editorials criticized the "state-to-state" concept, and few editorials support the renunciation of the "one China" principle.
He said the Clinton administration, while maintaining its "one China" policy, cannot overtly pressure Taiwan, because this would result in a response from the US Congress.

Chiu indicated that in the future, the Clinton administration can only treat the symptom, not the disease. But, he said, if Taiwan were to amend its constitution to bring it in line with the "state-to-state" theory, war would break out.

Jin Gan, a former researcher at mainland Chinese National Defense University, said the "state-to-state" theory is one step closer to separation. Gin also noted that since Taipei announced the theory in early July, the thinking of mainland China's People's Liberation Army has become unified, and they believe peaceful reunification is no longer possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO DISCUSS DEVELOPMENT OF NANKANG ECONOMIC PARK THIS WEEK

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will hold an investment symposium on Aug. 11 to discuss the development of the proposed Nankang Economic and Trade Park near Taipei.
The park, to be developed on a 12-hectare land by the government and the private sector, has been under planning for two years.

Facilities in the park will include large-scale exhibition halls, a five-star international hotel and a multi-functional recreational center. Total investment is estimated at NT$50 billion (US$1.51 billion).

The MOEA's Board of Foreign Trade has spent NT$9.6 billion (US$291 million) to purchase six hectares of land from the Taipei City Government and Taiwan Fertilizer Co. for the construction of exhibition halls.
The symposium will be presided over by MOEA Vice Minister Lin Yi-fu, and prospective investors and relevant experts will be among the participants.
The MOEA plans to forward the project to the Executive Yuan (Cabinet) for review and approval by the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$500 BILLION TO BE CHARGED THIS YEAR BY TAIWAN CREDIT CARD HOLDERS

TEXT.P: There were 11 million valid credit cards in the Taiwan area as of the end of May this year, and it is estimated that credit card charges in Taiwan this year will reach NT$500 billion, sources from the credit card industry said Sunday.

The number of cards issued in Taiwan relative to its population is 64.4 percent. This is considerably lower than South Korea's 130 percent, Hong Kong's 110 percent, Malaysia's 105 percent and Singapore's 93 percent. The high rates in these countries indicate that many people there have more than one card.

The survey also showed that Taiwan's credit card consumption volume accounts for only 9.1 percent of the island's total consumption volume, far below levels in the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore. This shows that Taiwan's credit card market still has room to develop.

Sources said Taiwan could reach a level in which there would be one card in circulation for each person on the island, with credit card consumption accounting for about 20 percent of overall consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSIONAL MISSION ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman (R-N.Y.), chairman of the US House International Relations Committee, led a delegation of his committee to Taipei on Sunday afternoon for a three-day visit.

The congressmen will hold talks with President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Defense Minister Tang Fei, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee and Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung.
The visit is a routine one, mainly for members of the House International Relations Committee to understand the situation in Taiwan.

Members of the delegation include seven congressmen, their family members and assistants. Vice Foreign Minister Lee and other Foreign Ministry officials greeted the mission when they arrived at Sungshan Airport by a US Air Force plane.

As President Lee's recent redefinition of current cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" has caused repercussions abroad, this issue is likely to be raised during the talks between ROC leaders and the visitors.
Gilman's delegation will depart Taipei on the morning of Aug. 10, with a statement to be issued before their departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOR THE STOCK MARKET, 6,800 IS THE POINT OF NO RETURN

TEXT.P: If share prices manage to maintain the 6,800-point level, it will take time to consolidate before eventually moving upward, but if it fails to maintain that level, the index could plunge to as low as 6,300 points, dealer said Sunday.

According to Fubon Securities, selling pressure will prevail in the short term and keep the local bourse bearish despite attempts by government-linked funds to push the index up to the 7,000-point level.

Government-linked funds on Saturday aggressively bought heavily weighted technology shares to prevent the index from falling to below 6,800 points. The buying was also seen as an attempt to prevent a massive sell-off by investors who have to repay margin loans.

Investors who buy securities on margin take out loans to buy them, using the securities as collateral. If the prices of the purchased securities fall far enough, the lending institutions may force the purchased securities to be sold to repay the loan. In such cases, a massive sell-off often results, triggering a nose-dive in share prices that government intervention would not be able to counter. Market analysts said 6,800 points is the government's bottom line.

A rebound on Saturday, however, was mostly the result of bargain hunters and short-term speculators, not institutional or individual buyers, both of whom lack confidence in the market, analysts added.
Jih Sun Securities suggested that mid- and long-term investors begin buying shares once prices fall below the 7,000 mark.
As for individual investors, dealers suggested they remain on the sidelines until the situation becomes clear and the market resumes its upward climb.
The situation will not be clear until mid-September, dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ROC will develop Taiwan into a global resourcing and operations center.
The China Times:
Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman, chairman of the US House International Relations Committee, heading a bipartisan House delegation, arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a visit. He will meet President Lee Teng-hui on Monday.
The United Daily News:
The Central Deposit Insurance Co. suggests that existing farmers associations around the island be merged in to 17.
The Liberty Times:
An aviation accord between Taiwan and Russia may be signed early next year.
The Commons Daily:
A 500,000 people hand-in-hand 'protect Taiwan' campaign to be held amid mounting mainland military threat.
The China Post:
Philippines says no need for Taiwan to make threats.
The Taiwan News:
China hinting at new laws to shield Taiwan investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAINS CAUSE NT$100 MILLION IN DAMAGE TO AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: Heavy torrential rains have caused damage worth NT$96 million (US$3 million) to the local agricultural sector since the beginning of this month, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Monday.
According to the COA, heavy rainfalls have caused losses of NT$75 million and NT$21 million to crops and farmlands, respectively, while the livestock industry has suffered losses of about NT$230,000.

Central Nantou and Yunlin counties were hardest hit, the COA noted, adding that agricultural losses in that two areas have hit around NT$44.5 million and NT$27.6 million, followed by southern Kaohsiung County with estimated damage of NT$12.9 million.
Crops planted on a total of 2,480 hectares of farmlands have been affected, with green vegetables being the crops most heavily damaged, the COA said.

Meanwhile, the Central Weather Bureau continued issuing warnings of heavy rainfalls for central Taiwan, saying that the current low pressure that has caused strong precipitation recently on the island will linger until this weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 9, or the 28th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: Thomas Telford, Scottish bridge engineer, is born. He is best known for his construction of the suspension bridge over the Menai Strait in Wales, and the Calendonian Canal built 1823-33 in Scotland.
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicion of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the US government and the Creek Indian tribe, the Indians are to lose 9.3 million hectares of land; over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia, to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the US and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested as an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six-week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto is crowned as Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1918: Robert Aldrich, American film director, is born. His films include "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?" "The Choirboys," and "The Dirty Dozen."
1919: India reaches a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sank during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify at an International court against Japanese war crime committed during invasion of China.
1954: The ROC Navy sinks 12 Chinese communist ships at Tungshan seaport of Dongshan Island near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon, becoming the first American president ever to take office without being chosen by the American people in a nationwide election.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district. A sign stated "Clothes Need Not Be Worn Beyond This Notice."
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The US government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWLY ELECTED ONE NATION SENATOR EMBRACES MULTICULTURALISM

TEXT.P: Deviating sharply from the line of party leader Pauline Hanson, newly elected One Nation senator Len Harris is embracing multiculturalism, saying migrants should not be prevented from speaking their native languages as long as it does not contribute to the growth of ethnic ghettos.
Harris has replaced Heather Hill, a One Nation candidate elected to the Senate but forced to give up her seat because she held dual citizenship at the time of the Oct. 3, 1998, election.
He told The Australian Financial Review that there were many positive features about multiculturalism. "Multiculturalism has contributed enormously to what we now know as Australia," he said.
"It has had a most positive impact on it (Australia)," he said. He said migrants should be allowed to speak their native languages.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS CONFIDENCE IN AUSTRALIA HIGHEST IN OVER A DECADE

TEXT.P: Business confidence in Australia is at its highest level in more than a decade, reflecting an improved investment outlook and strong employment growth, according to a July survey by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

The survey shows signs of an emerging skills shortage, and business executives believe inflation and interest rates will rise during the next 12 months, and they expect the economy will grow strongly for the rest of this year, The Australian Financial Review reported on Monday.
"The results ... show that the economy has weathered the worst of the international turmoil and has returned to a high level of business confidence," said ACCI chief executive Mark Paterson.
"Across the board the survey has indicated a positive economy with good business conditions, strong sales, improved profits and higher employment," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINATOWN FLEXES ITS MUSCLE IN SYDNEY MAYORAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Chinatown is flexing its muscle for the first time in its 80-year history as ethnic Chinese voters gain more influence in electing Sydney's mayor.

Chinese voters now account for about 20 percent of the estimated 12,000 electorate, and it is possible that three Australian-Chinese councilors could soon be sitting on the seven-seat council, according to The Sydney Morning Herald on Monday.
The daily reported three candidates -- incumbent Mayor Frank Sartor, Labor Party candidate Robert Ho and independent councilor Kathryn Greiner -- are running in the Sept. 11 election.
One important issue in the campaign is the restoration of Chinatown, which has been on the decline in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA: NO COMMENT ON REPORTED JAPAN VISIT BY FIRST LADY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Monday that it would not comment news reports that Republic of China First Lady Tseng Wen-hui left Taiwan for Fukuoka on Aug. 8 for an unofficial visit to Japan.
"We have no comment on her visit to Japan," acting spokesman of the Foreign Affair Ministry Chen Ming-cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.01 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 32.112.
The local currency opened at 32.120 and was traded between 32.111 and 32.150.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$306 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.3 percent lower Monday resulting from the continuing tension between Taiwan and mainland China.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 61.08 points to its daily high of 7,110.82 points in early trading, but ended the day off 21.73 points at 7,028.1 points. A total 1.57 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$73.98 billion.

Among the eight major categories, paper making shares posted the largest gain, ending the day up 2.6 percent, while foodstuff issues rose 1.1 percent and construction issues were up 0.9 percent. Cement stocks and plastic and chemical issues both enjoyed advances of 0.6 percent.
Financial shares declined 1.3 percent, followed by textile stocks and electronics issues, which fell 0.6 percent and 0.1 percent, respectively.
The over-the-counter market was down 1.5 points to close at 155.98 points on a turnover of NT$3.18 billion.
Meanwhile, TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August declined 20 points, ending the day at 7,015 points, with 2,494 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September moved down 19 points to finish at 7,018 points, with 282 contract transactions; those for next March rose 102 points to close at 7,198 points, with 1 contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for TAIEX Index Futures for next June.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,035 points for August, 7,037 for September, 7,090 for December, 7,096 for next March and 7,127 points for next June.
August electronics futures (TE) and financial futures (TF) both reported losses.

August TE futures slid 1.6 points to end at 315.4 points, with 818 contract transactions; September TE futures fell 1.25 points to close at 314 points, with 36 contract transactions. There were no transactions recorded for TE futures for other months.
TF futures for August dropped 17 points, ending the day at 986 points, with 86 contract transactions. September TF futures advanced 3.6 points to finish at 998.8 points, with 2 contract transactions.
There were no transactions recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL NOT CEASE ACTIONS BEFORE 2000 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei Monday told visiting US Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY) that mainland China will not cease actions against the Republic of China before next year's presidential election.

Gilman, chairman of the US House International Relations Committee, visited the Ministry of National Defense (MND) Monday morning to exchange views with Tang on the situation in the Taiwan Strait and to gain a first-hand understanding of current US arms sales to the ROC.

The defense minister expressed his appreciation for the long-term support and friendship shown by Gilman and the United States to the ROC. Tang told his visitor that before next year's presidential election ends, Beijing will continue with its "actions" against Taiwan, to which the ROC military will respond with "intelligence."
The Military Spokesman's Office issued a press release at noon explaining the morning's meeting and the content of their talks.

Gilman arrived in Taipei Sunday afternoon with a delegation of his committee for a three-day visit. The congressman will meet with President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee and Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung.

The visit is a routine one for members of the House International Relations Committee to understand the situation in Taiwan. Members of the delegation include seven congressmen, their family members and aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO SEEK BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES IN THE BALKANS

TEXT.P: A China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) trade delegation will visit the Balkan peninsula next month to explore local business opportunities after the armistice in Yugoslavia, a CETRA spokesman said Monday.
The trade delegation will visit Slovenia, Greece, Poland and the Republic of Slovak between Sept. 28 and Oct. 15 to open up trade and investment opportunities.

CETRA pointed out that with the end of the Yugoslav war, all kinds of construction materials and daily necessities are in demand in the region, making this a good time for Taiwan companies to enter the local market.

The trade delegation, to be led by CETRA Deputy Secretary-General Tsai Wen-kai, will invite business representatives from Macedonia, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia to convene in Greece for a trade conference as part of its itinerary.
CETRA will also arrange for Taiwan businessmen to visit and explore each investment target countries' sales channels to boost bilateral trade opportunities with the Balkan nations.

Ljubljana, capital of Slovenia, eastern Europe's most prosperous country, will be the delegation's first stop, followed by the harbor city of Salonica in Greece; Warsaw, Poland's capital city; and the Slovak capital of Bratislova, a CETRA spokesman said.

Each destination is a major regional business capital, he said, adding that Salonica is the Hellenic islands' gateway to the Balkan peninsula, and the Mediterranean and the Balkan region's most important transport center.

CETRA is targeting industries whose products are in high demand in the region following the war in Yugoslavia. Such industries include construction materials, hardware, glass, cement, tiles, computer products, textiles, footwear, plastics, mechanical parts, electrical appliances, automobile parts, foodstuffs and medical equipment.
The council will also invite Taiwan enterprises that are interested in seeking investment, merger or business cooperation opportunities in the Balkans to join the delegation.
