DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING AGENTS SPREADING INVASION RUMORS: REPORT

TEXT.P: Agents from Beijing operating in Taiwan are spreading rumors that an invasion is imminent, intensifying China's psychological warfare against the island, a Canadian analyst said Sunday.
Eric Margolis, contributing foreign editor for the Sun newspapers, said rumors have swept Taiwan that China is preparing an invasion.
He noted that the growing crisis over independence-minded Taiwan is causing deepening concern across Asia and in Washington.
He noted that much as China would like to invade Taiwan, it clearly lacks the military capability to do so.

"So it's more likely Beijing will continue to bombard Taiwan with threats and perhaps a few missiles... Behind all the threats, China and Taiwan still need one another as evidenced by that fact that Taiwan has over US$30 billion invested in mainland China," he said. S.C. CHANG

DOC.HEADLINE: PNG SET TO PRIVATIZE AIR NIUGINI

TEXT.P: Canberra, Aug. 9 (CNA): Prime Minister Sir Mekere Morauta of Papua New Guinea is keen on an open skies policy and wants to privatize Air Niugini, the nation's flag carrier, according to Post-Courier on Monday.
The daily reported Sir Mekere confirmed that Air Niugini was a prime candidate for sale under the new PNG government's privatization policy.

"Air Niugini is one of the candidates for execution," he said in response to a question in the parliament. He said he hoped whoever took over the airline, would ensure that the traveling public was offered an "affordable and reliable" service. PETER CHEN

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BARS POPE FROM HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Hong Kong, Aug. 9(CNA): A proposed visit by the Pope to Hong Kong has been blocked by Beijing because of Vatican links with Taiwan, the South China Morning Post reported today.
Vatican chiefs lobbying for an SAR stopover during the Pope's November Asian tour were rebuffed by mainland officials because the Vatican has diplomatic ties with Taiwan, the report said.

Hong Kong Bishop Joseph Zen Ze-kiu reportedly made the remarks on his return from a top-level meeting in Rome that the visit had been ruled out and the Pope would probably go to New Delhi or Bombay instead.
"He is definitely not coming," he was quoted by the report as saying.

Pope John Paul said after last year's Synod of Asian Bishops that he would like to visit Hong Kong, a move that local Church heads said at the time would test the "one country, two systems" policy for the SAR. Stanely Cheung

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE REITERATES ROC'S STANCE ON 'STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui reiterated on Monday that he was only telling the truth when he defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state" relationship.
Lee made the statement while meeting with a bipartisan delegation from the US House of Representatives, headed by Benjamin A. Gilman (R-N.Y.), chairman of the House International Relations Committee.
President Lee stressed that the "special state-to-state" definition describes a fact undeniable either from legal, historical or any realistic point of view.
More important, Lee said his definition is just aimed at further clarifying the fact and ascertaining parity in cross-strait relations.

Lee said cross-strait negotiations will have positive meanings only when they are conducted on the basis of parity, adding that the Republic of China can never accept Beijing's claim that it represents the central government of China while downgrading the ROC to a local-level government.

"Beijing's claim is not true and unacceptable to us," the president stressed, adding the cold reality is that the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China has co-existed in the world since 1949.
Lee pointed out that the ROC has not only existed since its inception in 1912 but has also created many admirable economic and democratic achievements over the past 88 years.

Lee went on to tell his guests that the ROC is the United States' longtime ally and firm supporter. Over past years, Lee said the ROC has encountered many difficulties and setbacks in its pursuit of freedom, democracy and reforms. "Thanks to full US congressional support, we have managed to overcome all those challenges."

The president further said he has consistently attached great importance to the development of cross-strait relations. "We have spared no efforts to promote exchanges and dialogue with the mainland," Lee said, adding that he fully supports US President Bill Clinton's call on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resolve their disputes strictly by peaceful means and to strengthen bilateral dialogue.
Lee also emphasized the necessity of strengthening cross-strait exchanges, saying that the ROC sincerely welcomes top mainland envoy Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan this autumn.
"We hope Wang can smoothly visit Taiwan at any time of his convenience," Lee said.
During the meeting, Lee has repeatedly expressed his gratitude for US congressional support for Taiwan.

For his part, Gilman said the US Congress recognizes and supports the ROC's democratic reforms in recent years. "We admire your efforts to establish a fair, just, free and democratic system and society," he added.
The House bipartisan delegation arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a brief visit as part of its efforts to gain a fuller understanding of the current Taiwan Strait situation.
Other members of the delegation included Rep. John D. Dingell (D-Mich.), Rep. Alcee L. Hastings (D-Fla.), Rep. Robert Underwood (D-Guam-AL), Rep. Tom Campbell (R-Calif.) and Robert Ney (R-Ohio).

Also present at Lee's meeting with the US lawmakers were Vice Foreign Minister David Lee; Ding Mou-shih, a senior adviser to the President; Yin Chung-wen, secretary-general of the National Security Council; and Lin Pi-chao, deputy secretary-general to the President.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSTAL SERVICE PRIVATIZATION PLAN DISCUSSED

TEXT.P: The issue of whether postal affairs in Taiwan will remain state-owned or public operated was discussed during a seminar here on Monday.

A proposed governmental project calls for the privatization of the current state-owned and public-operated postal department. The proposal is causing much controversy due to the fact that postal savings is one of the three foundations financing the government's National Stabilization Fund.

Monday's seminar sponsored by the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CHIER) discussed the privatization project. Those invited included Huang Shui-cheng, deputy commissioner of the Directorate General of Posts under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications; Deng Tien-lai, director of the Post & Telecommunications Dept.; and Legislator Fong Fu-Hsiang.

Both the Ministry of Finance and the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development advocate the postal administration being divided into four companies operating independently: delivering service, counter service, banking service and insurance service.

If the postal savings and postal life-insurance sectors were to be governed by the "banking law" and the "insurance law" as planned, the incentives currently offered by the postal savings division would be greatly reduced, a fact deemed as negative for its growth.
As this is the case, during the seminar CHIER expressed concern that the function of postal savings as the protector of the Taiwan bourse will certainly be weakened.

Survey results released by CHIER Monday indicated that only 20 percent of those interviewed deemed the current goal of the postal service of offering "inexpensive, safe, convenient, and private correspondence" would remain intact if privatization were to occur.

Up to 93 percent of the interviewees favor the island's postal administration remaining state-owned. The survey found that the public deems that the quality of the postal service can only be guaranteed under a state-owned or public-operated framework.

In addition, up to 86 percent of consumers interviewed felt that the inexpensive and reliable postal service enjoyed by residents here is due to the fact that the domestic postal office can operate simultaneously the profit-making businesses of postal delivery, savings and life-insurance. The profit from these three businesses makes up for the losses resulting from inexpensive delivery charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUEL PRICES TO RISE 3 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corporation (CPC) is expected to announce a 3-percent price increase for oil on Tuesday due to price hikes in the internaional crude oil market and a pre-tax profit for July that is lower than the government projection.

CPC's business earnings for July totaled NT$33.83 billion with pre-tax profits totaling NT$2.62 billion, a NT$178 million decrease from the government's projected earnings. At the same time, the cost for imported crude oil reached US$15.68 per barrel in July, a 19-month record high.
In light of the increasing cost of oil, the CPC has adjusted upward the oil price three times since April. The revised rates were 2.69 percent in April, 2.8 percent in May and 2.99 percent in July.
A price rise on Tuesday seems inevitable since the international price of crude oil continues to rise, CPC noted. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN BOAT CRASH CLAIMS TAIWAN IMMIGRANTS LIVES

TEXT.P: The four people who died and the one person still missing from Saturday's collision between a yacht and a barge off West Vancouver were all overseas Chinese from Taiwan, officials of the Canadian liaison office in Taipei said on Monday.
The officials noted the victims had long resided in either Canada or the United States. No Taiwanese tourists were on board the yacht, they added.

A total of 14 people were on board the yacht which crashed into the 300-foot barge being towed by a tugboat. The yacht was trying to get into position to watch a fireworks show, according to foreign wire reports.
The Canadian officials pointed out that nine of the 14 people on the yacht, including the skipper, his wife and two sons, were injured and are now in a local hospital.

The four people killed by the boat collision have been identified as Susie Chen, 53; Marilyn Waye, 51; Manfai Ngo, 36; and Frank Ngo, 5. Louis Chen of West Vancouver, 50, was identified as missing, according to the Canadian Trade Office (CTO) in Taipei.
Chen's two 13 year-old twin daughters and his 17 year-old daughter, Waye's boyfriend, and Ngo's wife were among the victims sent to the hospital, the office reported.
The CTO said that it on Monday contacted the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to offer its help for the Chinese victims' relatives in Taiwan in obtaining Canadian visas.

Reports said that the yacht flipped over after striking a submerged cable between the towboat and the barge. Many passengers on the Seattle-based yacht were not wearing life jackets, a report cited witnesses as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS REACT TO SUNDAY'S HACKING OF CONTROL YUAN

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China's (CBC) information system is secure from computer hacker invasions, the bank's information office director Hsieh Chien-hsing said Monday.
A hacker broke into the Internet website of the Control Yuan and wiped out all the information on Sunday, rocking the whole island.
The CBC's information system, however, is protected by a integral management procedure, Hsieh said, adding that he is confident no hacker will be able to reach the bank's database.

Hsieh said that if the CBC's information system were to be broken into by hackers, the whole system might be paralyzed, leading to serious consequences. How to prevent computer hackers from breaking into bank information systems is thus every financial institutions' top priority, he said.

Meanwhile, National Police Administration Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Director Cheng Ching-sung said that in view of the fact that specific regulations preventing Internet crime are lacking, the most pressing task at hand is to establish international Internet laws and step up cooperation between government and the private sector.
Due to the lack of privacy, boundaries and territorial restrictions, many criminals are able to use the Internet to escape detection, adding to investigation difficulties, Cheng said.

While the CIB has set up a computer crime squad, Cheng said the unit still has a long way to go before it can prevent and detect most Internet crimes. He urged the private sector to participate in the CIB's crime-prevention Internet system by setting up a national public security network.
Cheng also urged the ISP (internet service providers) industry to exercise self-restraint and filter out illegal websites to create a "clean and healthy" Internet society.

In response to Sunday's break-in, Control Yuan Secretary-General Tu Shan-liang has instructed information office director Hsieh Sung-chih to report the incident to the Taipei City Police Headquarters' Chungcheng precinct.
Amid continuing tension with mainland China, Cheng urged all government agencies to raise their awareness to prevent future hacker invasions.

Control Yuan President Frederic Chien has personally expressed concern over Sunday's incident. He has instructed related agencies to step up information protection measures to guard against further break-ins.

Hsieh told members of the press that the hacker only managed to invade the Control Yuan's service and advertising website, and was unsuccessful in gaining entrance into the Control Yuan's' inner communication operation system. No Control Yuan internal data was lost, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES WITHDRAWING CHAPARRAL MISSILES FROM MATSU

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Monday denied a newspaper report that the military will withdraw chaparral missiles from the Republic of China-held frontline island of Matsu, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.

A press statement released by the Office of the Military Spokesman said chaparral missiles deployed on Matsu are still in a state of combat preparedness. "The military does not have any plan to relocate the chaparral missiles at the moment," the statement stressed.

The statement went on to say that the ROC armed forces has a consistent and well-designed military deployment and adjustment plan, and that strict procedures must be followed when the plan is implemented.

The MND also urged local news media to base its military-related reports on information released by the ministry, and to avoid speculating on military-related events, as such speculation has an adverse effect on national morale.

In related news, meanwhile, the ministry responded to press reports that the ROC Air Force has decided to cancel many warplane display flights during an upcoming Taipei aviation trade fair amid the current tension in the Taiwan Strait.

The ministry stressed that Air Force General Headquarters had never agreed in the first place to conduct dynamic airborne flight performances in connection with the aviation show to be held at the Taipei World Trade Center from Aug. 12-15.
"The reports are completely unfounded," the Office of the Military Spokesman said in another press release.

The MND press release explained that air force authorities did not agree to an airborne exhibition during this year's aviation trade fair for several reasons, one of which is that the air force base in Taoyuan, some 35 kilometers south of Taipei, is undergoing refurbishment, and another of which is that the exhibition overlaps with the celebration of the founding anniversary of the Chinese Air Force Academy.

Air force activities in the skies over the Taiwan Strait have increased since ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" on July 9. The definition has angered Beijing, prompting communist saber-rattling in recent weeks, and spawning wild local speculation on military activities of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The MND said it hopes local news media, and society in general, will stop such speculation, and also stop spreading unsubstantiated rumors, to avoid disrupting domestic stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. LEE EXPLAINS HIS REDEFINITION TO JAPANESE DIETMAN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said Monday the main reason he raised the "special state-to-state" theory on cross-Taiwan Strait ties last month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
President Lee made the remark while receiving Japanese Dietman Eisei Ito at the Presidential Office.
Lee reiterated that the ROC cordially welcomes the visit by Chairman Wang Daohan of the mainland Chinese Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.
Lee said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can discuss any issue concerning cross-strait relations. However, he added, the talks can occur only when the two sides are on an equal footing.
Ito said he agreed with Lee's "special state-to-state" theory and indicated that Beijing's hegemony has caused anxiety and instability in the Asia-Pacific region.
Lee admitted it is not easy for mainland China to democratize, however, he added, if the mainland Chinese economy can take a turn for the better, other Asian countries will benefit.
Lee stressed that the Republic of China has long been a sovereign state and that Beijing should not ignore the fact that there are 22 million people on the island.

He said seeking unification with mainland China has been and remains the ROC's consistent position and assertion. However, he clarified that unification with the mainland is a future task and will come into realization only when mainland China achieves democracy, freedom and equal wealth.

Ito was accompanied to the meeting with President Lee by Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan and Chairman Lin Chin-ching of the Association of East Asia Relations. Also present were Senior Adviser to the President Ding Mou-shih and Deputy Secretary General to the President Lin Pi-chao.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA, FRENCH TRADE AGENCY SIGN COOPERATIVE PACT

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 9 (CNA): The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) has signed a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for the International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France, a CETRA senior official said Monday.
Kao I-hsin, CETRA's secretary general, said both parties will benefit from cooperating in trade and investment in the fields of information technology, semi-conductors and biotechnology.

France is the Republic of China's fourth largest European trade partner, although bilateral investment accumulated only to US$30 million last year. Kao, who had accompanied Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on his recent trip to Europe, visited France with the aim of tapping and strengthening trade and investment opportunities.

At the initial stage, both sides will either hold seminars Kao said. As a result, a French semi-conductor and information industry mission will visit Taiwan in October and another trade group will come to Taiwan in November, he said.
"We hope that the Sino-French technology interchange cooperation will substantially help increase investment and trade between the two countries," Kao added. By Edward Chen enditem

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DISSIDENT CAI GUEIHUA GIVEN LONGER SENTENCE

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissident Cai Gueihua has recently been given longer sentence because he staged a hunger strike after being beaten by public security officers in his "reform through education camp," a human rights group said here Monday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Cai, a member of the Shanghai branch of the outlawed "China Democratic Party (CDP), was sentenced on Oct. 30, 1998 to nine months in reform camp, but he was not released when his sentence expired on July 30. Public security authorities have recently given his wife a notice, saying that his sentence has been extended because he staged a hunger strike in the camp. But the notice did not say when he will be released.
The information center said however that Cai is a victim of the on-going nationwide crackdown on the CDP, which was set up and outlawed soon afterwards in the summer of 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS PROBING WEBSITE INTRUSION BY MAINLAND CHINESE HACKERS

TEXT.P: Following a series of intrusions by mainland Chinese hackers into a dozen government-run Internet websites over the weekend, prosecution and police authorities on Monday launched an investigation into the incidents.

C.J. Chou, a chief public prosecutor with the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office (TDPO), said a task force led by Prosecutor Chang Shao-pin, an expert on computer crime, is probing the incidents involving the infiltration of websites maintained by the Control Yuan, the Taiwan Provincial Government, the Pintung County Government, and various other official bodies, by hackers suspected of being mainland China-based.

Chang's task force is also cooperating with the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the Ministry of the Interior, in an investigation into the hacking of the website of the American Institute in Taiwan, which handles the United States' unofficial ties with Taiwan, according to Chou.

Tien Ping-lin, head of a TDPO committee on computer crime, said the mainland Chinese hackers' actions may have violated Republic of China laws on copyright, document forgery, and defacing of documents.

If any concrete evidence showing such illegal activity is found, local police authorities might seek the cooperation of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait in asking the mainland's public security authorities to crack down on such Internet attacks, a CIB official said.

On Sunday, more than ten breaches by mainland hackers into local websites of government agencies were reported to a local organization set up to assist victims of computer crime known by the acronym CERT, which has offered technical assistance to help the victims recover data wiped out by the hackers.

The incidents came amid deteriorating relations between Taiwan and mainland China following President Lee Teng-hui's airing of his view that Taiwan-mainland ties are a "special state-to-state relationship" in a July 9 interview with the Germany-based Deutche Welle radio station.

Meanwhile, officers of the Investigation Bureau under the Justice Ministry said the hackers may have invaded the Taiwan websites through websites backed by mainland Chinese authorities, or through US-based websites run by mainlanders, as links between mainland and foreign websites are closely monitored by the authorities in Beijing.

Some of these intrusions might be no more than acts of mischief, the officials said, but they added that they are worried that Beijing might be attempting to test Taiwan's ability to protect its websites, and use the breaches "to steal secret information."
They called on government webmasters to pay special heed to the situation, and added that a comprehensive monitoring system has been implemented to ward off further disruptions by mainland hackers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARITY KEY TO POSITIVE DEVELOPMENT OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Monday that parity is crucial to constructive development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Lee made the remarks while meeting with US Senator Slade Gorton (R-Wash.), who is currently in Taipei for a brief visit.
The president said he was stating a fact when he defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state" relationship in an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station on July 9.
The "special state-to-state" definition is also aimed at further clarifying and asserting that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are equal, Lee said.
He stressed that the definition does not mark a shift of Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, adding that he has consistently supported cross-strait exchanges and dialogue.

The president also threw his full support behind US President Bill Clinton's call for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to enhance dialogue and exchanges and to resolve their disputes with peaceful means.

Lee went on to say that the Republic of China can never accept Beijing's claim that the ROC is a renegade province or a local-level government under its jurisdiction. "Cross-strait relations will develop in a positive, constructive direction only when their engagements are conducted on a basis of parity."
Lee extended a warm welcome to Gorton's visit and expressed his gratitude for longtime US congressional support for the ROC's national cause.

For his part, Gorton said the US Congress has consistently supported free and democratic Taiwan. The senator further said he does not find any impropriety in President Lee's "special state-to-state" theory. He also said the US government should maintain balance in its policies toward Taipei and Beijing.

As a senator elected from Washington State where Boeing Co. is headquartered, Gorton expressed his concern about China Airlines' (CAL's) plan to purchase European-made Airbus A-340 and A-330 passenger jets instead of Boeing 777s.
In response, Lee said that the ROC government is not in a position to interfere with CAL's aircraft purchase plan because it is purely a commercial deal.

Nevertheless, Lee said he fully understands Gorton and other American politicians' concern about the deal. Lee suggested that Boeing executives directly discuss the purchase deal with their CAL counterparts. "I believe that such a practice will be more conducive," he added.

Taiwan's leading carrier is scheduled to sign a contract with Boeing Co. at the Sherwood Taipei hotel on Aug. 11 for purchase of 14 B747-400 all-cargo freighters, worth a total of US$2.5 billion. CAL originally also planned to purchase 13 Boeing 777 passenger planes. However, the carrier may switch its US$1.5 billion passenger jet purchase order to France-based Airbus Industrie, causing concern of the US government.
Earlier in the day, Gorton also paid a visit to Lin Feng-cheng, minister of transportation and communications, as part of his effort to help salvage CAL's passenger jets order for Boeing Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: GILMAN VISITS DPP LEADERS

TEXT.P: Rep. Benjamin Gilman, chairman of the US House International Relations Committee, visited leaders of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Monday to exchange views on cross-strait relations and the situation in the Taiwan Strait.

He talked with Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, Representative to the US Chiu Yi-jen, Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu, Legislator Parris H. Chang, and other leaders of the party during the 45-minute visit at the DPP Central Committee in Taipei.

Contents of their conversation have not been made public, but participants in the meeting said the DPP leaders stressed that China and Taiwan should resolve their differences in peaceful ways and that all moves that may escalate the tensions between the two sides are not necessary.

They also said that Gilman was very concerned about the situations in the Taiwan Strait, and that he believed China and Taiwan should increase their contacts so as to improve their mutual understanding.

Gilman led a high-powered Congressional delegation to Taiwan Sunday on a two-week fact-finding mission to East Asia and the South Pacific. Taipei is their first stop. He had visited President Lee Teng-hui and Minister of National Defense Tang Fei before meeting with the DPP leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL URGES COMPUTER HACKERS NOT TO DISRUPT WEBSITES

TEXT.P: An official with the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Monday urged computer hackers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to observe "moral regulations" and refrain from disrupting Internet websites.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng made the appeal at a public hearing titled "Internet discussion of the two-state theory" sponsored by a legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
He pointed out that Internet data is public property, and that nobody has the authority to destroy it, adding that any sabotage of websites should be condemned.
Jan was referring to invasions of various government-owned websites by mainland Chinese and Taiwan computer hackers over the past few days.
He added that while handling of such incidents are not within the domain of the SEF, the foundation can still appeal to the public to observe "ethical rules."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAID CONSIDERING KMT CHAIRMANSHIP ISSUE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui has said he is likely to continue serving the rest of his term as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang if the party wins next year's presidential election, a ranking government official said on Monday.

Keh Wei-shin, vice minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said Lee made the remark while meeting a group of representatives from the Chinese community in Los Angeles about one week ago at the Presidential Office. Keh was present at the meeting.
Lee was asked whether or not he will finish his existing term as KMT chairman as scheduled in November, 2001 after he steps down as ROC president on May 20 next year.

"I am considering the issue. One of the options is to let the new national leader, the new president, implement his ideas in accordance with tradition if the KMT wins the presidential election next year," Lee said.
"The other option is for me to continue to serve as KMT chairmanship until my tenure expires," he added.
The president also told his visitors that he "might be too old to fulfill his dream of a being a Christian preacher after he retires."
But he stressed nevertheless his desire to "do something to help the less privileged in society," Keh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUSELAGE OF CRASHED MILITARY CHOPPER SALVAGED

TEXT.P: The fuselage of a military helicopter which crashed into Taichung County's Techi Reservoir on July 17 was raised to the surface on Monday, although the bodies of the two missing pilots were not recovered, according to a spokesman for the search and rescue center.

The spokesman said that the rescue team will continue its 24-day search for the bodies, while the fuselage of the AH-IW Cobra combat helicopter will be taken to a nearby base for further investigation.

The spokesman said the rescue team did not find the bodies of missing pilots Feng Chun-chieh and Shih Po-shou because the cabin cover was smashed and the seatbelts disengaged during the salvage procedure.
Taiwan has 42 of the American-designed AH-IW helicopters which are especially suited to all-terrain operation and which proved themselves during the Persian Gulf War.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT TRYING TO SALVAGE AIR AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: An official of ruling Kuomintang said on Monday that he has received a promise from Philippine President Joseph Estrada that his country will not sever its aviation links with Taiwan without due cause.

Liu Tai-ying, who is in charge of the KMT's business operations, revealed Estrada's promise at a press conference upon his return to Taipei after a three-day private visit to the Philippines during which he met the Philippine president, a personal friend.
The visit attracted much attention at a time when the Taipei-Manila aviation agreement is in dispute.
Liu said that in addition to Estrada, he also met with Jalinto Ortega, the official in charge of civil aviation affairs.

During the meeting, he went on, they discussed the recent dispute which broke out when Manila unilaterally announced the suspension of the air agreement between Taiwan and the Philippines, forcing China Airlines and EVA Airways, Taiwan's two major carriers, to suspend their Taipei-Manila flights from Sept. 1.
Liu said Estrada felt that the dispute was mainly caused by miscommunication between the two sides, and that he suggested more negotiations by aviation representatives from the two countries.
Estrada gave his word that his country will not cut air links before the conclusion of such talks, according to Liu.
Earlier negotiations aimed at renewing the Taipei-Manila aviation accord began in late July, but broke down almost immediately because of a dispute over passenger quotas for Taiwan carriers.

The Philippines claimed Taiwan violated the 1996 aviation agreement by using larger airplanes than permitted under the terms of the accord. This violation has hurt the Philippine Airlines, according to Manila authorities.

Liu said he has also learned during his meeting with Estrada that it is not just Taiwan airlines that are being targeted by Manila in its fight to keep the moribund national flag carrier in the air. Other airlines from countries such as Thailand, Singapore, South Korea, Malaysia, and Hong Kong are also facing the challenge, he stressed.
Philippine Airlines, which currently employs around 7,000 people, has been suffering operational deficits of around US$1.55 million per month, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAL FORMALLY INVITES CAL AND EVA TO AVIATION TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Philippine Airlines, the country's flag carrier, has formally asked China Airlines and Eva Air of Taiwan to negotiate over disputed bilateral aviation rights, according to aviation industry sources in Manila on Monday.
According to the sources, PAL has been instructed by the Philippine government to issue the invitation, with the timing and venue to be at the discretion of the Taiwan side.
Meanwhile, Philippine President Joseph Estrada said he hopes the dispute over the two countries' aviation agreement will be resolved by the air carriers of both sides.

"We hope that under the basis of the cooperative spirit established by the Manila Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (MECO) and the Taipei Economic & Cultural Office in Mania (TECO), CAL and Eva Air will renegotiate with us with the aim of setting reasonable passenger quotas acceptable to both sides," the letter said in part.
The letter, dated Aug. 5, was sent on Monday to CAL and Eva Air, with copies also sent to MECO and TECO.
In related news, a well-informed source said that CAL General Manager Liu Ke-ya visited Manila on Sunday and met with Lucio Tan, PAL board chairman, to exchange views on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAINS CAUSE NT$250 MILLION LOSSES IN CENTRAL, SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Heavy rains in central and southern Taiwan in recent days have caused NT$253.5 million-worth of losses in the agriculture, forestry, fishery and livestock sectors, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Monday.
Kaohsiung County has been the area hardest-hit, and the COA has adopted a series of measures to assist farmers in disaster-stricken areas to reconstruct their damaged homes.

The losses break down as NT$21 million-worth of losses to farming land, NT$147 million in lost crops, NT$20 million-worth of damage to fisheries, NT$190,000 for forestry, and NT$64.4 million-worth of soil erosion, the COA said.
Twenty-five hectares of farmland have been washed away or inundated in central Taiwan's Nantou County alone, with losses of as much as NT$21 million, according to COA calculations.

Crops have been severely damaged in Kaohsiung, Yunlin, Nantou, and Tainan counties, the COA went on, with a total of 861 hectares of crops in the four counties destroyed beyond salvage, mainly vegetables, papayas, water melons, bananas, and tomatoes.

One hundred meters of breakwaters along the coast of Chiayi County, and the protecting dyke around the base of the Chiayi lighthouse were also destroyed by the flooding, with an estimated loss of NT$20 million.
Several sections of industrial roads in Miaoli, Nantou, Tainan and Kaohsiung counties have been damaged by the floodwater, with the COA estimating that reconstruction costs will exceed NT$60 million.

Estimated agricultural losses thus far for Kaohsiung County have reached NT$68 million, followed by Nantou County, NT$65 million, Tainan County, NT$44 million, Yunlin County, NT$35 million, Chiayi County, NT$26 million, Pintung County, NT$8.2 million, Changhua County, NT$3.5 million and Miaoli County, NT$180,000.
The Central Weather Bureau has said the danger is not yet over, with more heavy rain forecast over the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF EXCHANGES VIEWS ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES WITH US CONGRESSMEN

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi held talks with a US congressional delegation in Taipei on Monday to exchange views on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Both sides expressed the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will continue their dialogue.
The six-member congressional delegation, headed by Benjamin Gilman (R-N.Y.), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a three-day visit.

Su told the visitors that President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" was intended to place future cross-strait political talks on an equal basis, and did not signal any policy change on behalf of the Republic of China government.
In addition, he went on, Taipei wants to provide more protection for the existing status quo, and hopes the voice of the Taiwan people can be heard more clearly by the international community.
The MAC chief stressed that Lee's statement merely reflected a simple fact -- "one China" is a concept for the future, and China today is divided.

He described Taipei's raising of the "special state-to-state relationship" as a "defensive political display," and reiterated Taipei's welcome of an autumn visit to Taiwan by mainland China's emissary to the island, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait Chairman Wang Daohan.
If Wang visits Taipei as scheduled, Su said, it will improve mainland-Taiwan relations, and bring the triangular relationship between Washington, Beijing and Taipei into better balance.
In the hour-long talks, Gilman's delegation reiterated the Clinton administration's desire for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to continue engaging in peaceful dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS COSTA RICA
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu arrived in San Jose on Sunday for a visit.

In addition to calling on Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez and Foreign Minister Roberto Rajas on Monday, Hu is scheduled to take part in a meeting on Tuesday of the foreign ministers of the ROC and its Central American allies, including Costa Rica, Guatemala, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Honduras.
Major topics to be discussed in the meeting will be ways and means of enhancing economic cooperation between Taiwan and its Central American and Caribbean allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER RETURNS FROM TRIP TO MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew returned to Taipei on Monday night from a weeklong official visit to Macedonia, and described the trip as "very fruitful."

Speaking to reporters at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon his arrival. he said that his 100-member mission was warmly welcomed by the Macedonian people and attracted considerable attention from the international media.
"The trip has elevated Taiwan's international image in Europe, especially on the Balkan peninsula," Siew claimed.
During his stay in the capital, Skopje, Siew held talks with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski. The two sides also signed several bilateral cooperative agreements.

In addition, Siew also announced the donation of US$10.5 million-worth of direct aid to Macedonia in 10 areas, including transportation, information technology, water supply, education and social welfare.
He also dismissed domestic press reports that he had presented Macedonia with "big gifts" during his stay.
Siew stressed that Macedonia's economy has been ravaged by the conflicts in surrounding areas, and that there is a need for Taiwan, as a friendly country, to provide assistance.
He added that these moves will also help pave the way for Taiwan businessmen to expand their operations in Europe.

The premier was originally scheduled to visit the war-torn province of Kosovo in neighboring Yugoslavia, but the plan was canceled due to security considerations. Instead, several ranking officials of the Kosovar provisional government went to Skopje to meet with Siew.
Siew told the media that President Lee Teng-hui's announcement of US$300 million in aid for Kosovar refugees and rehabilitation projects was a "very correct decision."

The aid program was made out of humanitarian consideration, not merely out of diplomatic consideration, he said, adding that it will be implemented in phases over the next several years, and the budget will be deliberated by the Legislative Yuan.
Siew's mission consisted of government officials, lawmakers, representatives of charity groups, businessmen and journalists.
It was the premier's first visit to Macedonia, with which Taiwan forged diplomatic relations in January of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:

The 'special state-to-state' theory is undeniable, says President Lee.
The Liberty Times:

The Commons Daily:

The China Post:
US senator fails to sway China airlines (CAL).
The Taiwan News:
CAL to sign Airbus deal, despite US senator's visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF BRIEFS FOREIGN ENVOYS ON 'STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi on Tuesday briefed 13 foreign envoys stationed in Taipei on key points of the English version of the Republic of China's position paper on the "special state-to-state relationship" theory.

Su's briefing was given at the request of resident ambassadors of 13 of the ROC's diplomatic allies. The presentation, held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, was presided over by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee.

Su said President Lee Teng-hui's definition of relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" is a political declaration aimed at clarifying the real nature of cross-strait ties and asserting the equality and parity of the two sides.

The ROC's top mainland policy planner stressed that the declaration does not mark a shift in Taiwan's policy toward the mainland nor does it has anything to do with the ROC's constitutional amendments.
Noting that the "special state-to-state" theory only describes a fact, Su said the ROC's policies on civilian exchanges, trade and investment across the Taiwan Strait have remained unchanged.
During the meeting, Guatemalan Ambassador Luis Alberto Noriega Morales asked Su whether the current tension in the Taiwan Strait over the "special state-to-state" theory will ease soon.

In response, Su said the so-called cross-strait military stand-off is mainly an exaggeration spread by Hong Kong news media. "In fact, our intelligence shows that the situation is not as tense as reported by Hong Kong newspapers," Su said, adding that ROC Defense Minister Tang Fei said last week that many Hong Kong-originated reports concerning recent mainland Chinese military deployment were false or fabricated.
Noriega further asked whether the current cross-strait tension and the "special state-to-state" theory will have any impact on the ROC's next presidential election scheduled for March 2000.

Su said it's still premature to predict whether present cross-strait ties and the "special state-to-state" theory will have any effects on the coming election. Nevertheless, Su said he is convinced that declaring the theory now is better than announcing it in October or after the autumn.

This was the first time that Su has directly explained the key spirit of the "special state-to-state" theory to foreign envoys since President Lee explicitly defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station on July 9, sparking furious reaction from Beijing which views Taiwan as a "renegade province."
Foreign Ministry officials said Su will hold a similar briefing on the "state-to-state" concept for resident representatives of countries with which the ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO STAND UP TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Washington, Aug. 9 (CNA): Both the Clinton administration and US Congress have continually acquiesced in the face of Communist Chinese defiance. If they do not make a stand against Beijing soon, they may never be able to change Communist Chinese behavior, warned an American national defense expert Monday.

Jason Morrow, research associate of the National Center for Public Policy Research's National Defense Center, wrote in an analysis titled "Clinton's Flawed China Policy: Is Clinton-style Engagement Really Constructive?" that the progress on many issues that the engagement was supposed to bring Washington has not materialized, but the world has seen the following:
-- The US trade deficit with mainland China has risen to $58 billion;
-- The PRC government has begun a severe crackdown on dissidents and religious movements; and
-- Communist China's threats toward Taiwan have reached new levels.

Morrow noted that after all these setbacks, the Clinton administration apparently still believes that "kowtowing to China is beneficial." And in an egregious display of bad timing, President Bill Clinton proposed the continued extension of normal trade relations with mainland China earlier this year, only hours before the tenth anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.
Not even Congress has been immune to engagement fever, said the national defense expert, adding that the House of Representatives recently approved continued normal trade relations with the PRC.

The next critical issue will be the upcoming negotiations to allow the PRC into the World Trade Organization, an idea that President Clinton supports. "To do so would complete the process of capitulation to China, as it would effectively prevent the US from using trade restrictions as a tool in future negotiations," pointed out Morrow.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVISER DOUBTS MEGAWATI WILL WIN PRESIDENCY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, Aug. 10 (CNA): The possibility of Megawati Sukarnoputri becoming the next president of Indonesia are doubtful due to vote-buying by the incumbent head of state, according to one of her advisers.
In a dispatch from Jakarta, the Australian on Tuesday quoted Kwik Kian Gie as revealing that the PDI-P was "not very confident that Megawati will be elected (president)."
Kwik, who is expected to have a Cabinet position if Megawati is elected to the presidency in November, said "money politics" could see incumbent B.J. Habibie returned as president.

Despite her recent victory in the general election by winning 34 percent of the votes, assuring her the front-runner spot in the November presidential election, Megawati will face the 700-member People's Consultative Assembly (MPR). Her PDI-P and its alliances have only 257 votes while the ruling Golkar party could grab 405 votes in the MPR, Kwik said.

Kwik warned that if Habibie won the presidential election, there would be "enormous chaos." Student organizations and other opposition groups have warned that they will take their protests to the streets if he remains president.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MAGAZINE CALLS FOR FIRM CHINA POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, Aug. 9 (CNA): The United States can engage in a scholastic debate about the misguided "one China" policy later, but Washington must now embark on a firm policy of deterrent to preserve peace across the Taiwan Straits, wrote an American political magazine in its latest issue.

The Weekly Standard said in its editorial titled "Peace Through Strength" that journalists and China watchers have written off the PRC's seizure of a Taiwanese freighter, its launching military aircraft on hundreds of sorties over the Taiwan Straits, test-firing a ground-to-ground ballistic missile with a range of 5,000 miles, and conducting military exercises in Fujian province as the usual Beijing bluster, provoked by Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui's declaration that mainland China and Taiwan must negotiate as one state to another.

And China experts are hoping that Communist China, in the interest of preserving US-PRC relations will not step up the military confrontation with Taiwan. The Clinton administration, or at least most of the Clinton administration, seems to be operating on the basis of this hope as well, added the editorial.

But the magazine pointed out that "This hopefulness is dangerously misguided. The current Chinese military activities may not be mere gestures designed to intimidate Taiwan (and us). They may well be the opening phase of a serious military confrontation, one that could culminate in the coming weeks or months in some form of attack -- probably not on Taiwan itself but against the tiny islands of Matsu or Kinmen."

The Clinton administration, probably unwittingly, has given a yellow light to the Communist Chinese to take some kind of action, because Clinton officials have declared that the United States is in fundamental agreement with Beijing's position that President Lee Teng-hui's statements are unacceptable and provocative, noted the editorial.

The Weekly Standard said Lee's most recent statements are far more significant than his trip to Cornell University. If the Beijing leadership wants to make a strong statement this time, one that will really frighten the Taiwanese electorate before it goes to the polls to elect a new president next March, then it will have to undertake a military action that goes beyond missile tests.

The PRC does not now have the capability to launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan, but it does have more than enough capability to invade and seize Matsu or Kinmen. It could launch missile strikes against them, or it might simply set up a naval blockade around the islands, opined the magazine.

The editorial went on to say that any of these options is plausible, but the last one strikes it as potentially most attractive to the Communist Chinese. And blockade of Matsu or Kinmen would present the Clinton administration with this choice: Either send the Seventh Fleet to break the blockade, or acquiesce in Chinese aggression against Taiwan and accept the consequences of allowing Beijing to set such a precedent, with all it would mean both for the future of Taiwan and for the US position in East Asia generally.

The right-wing magazine said it hopes that the Clinton administration will choose the first course, but it strongly suspect, as may the Communist Chinese, that the administration would back down and desperately seek a negotiated solution to the crisis.

The fact that the PRC and the United States would be continuing to talk about Beijing's entry into the WTO, that President Bill Clinton and President Jiang Zemin would be meeting, and that relations between Beijing and Washington would appear in all other respects to be on the mend would only make it more likely that the Clinton administration would refrain from decisive action that might disrupt this "progress."

And it would reinforce the point the Communist Chinese want to make: that the United States should care, and does care, more about preserving good ties with the PRC than about defending Taiwan, noted the editorial.

But The Weekly Standard said "We hope we are wrong. We hope the Chinese seizure of the Taiwanese freighter is not, in fact, the first step toward a total blockade. But the scenario we have outlined seems sufficiently plausible to require immediate action by the American government. To avoid the Hob son's choice a Chinese blockade or attack on Matsu or Kinmen might present, the United States must now embark on a firm policy of deterrent."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S ECONOMY SEEN SLOWING
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, Aug. 10 (CNA): Australia's economy is showing signs of mixed figures with housing starts falling while employment rises.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics on Monday released figures showing a 3.2 percent drop in housing finance approvals during June, including a fall in finance for the important new-construction category. Housing is one of major drivers of economic growth in Australia.

But the Job Advertisements series compiled by the Australian New Zealand Banking Group showed a rise of 2.6 percent in July to its highest level in almost a decade, suggesting strong employment growth and an unemployment rate below 7 percent by September.

Treasury believes recent weak economic figures could be the first signs of a slowdown in the country's economy, and it is doggedly sticking to its conservative 3 percent growth forecast for the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: US APPEASEMENT SEEN ONLY MAKING CHINA MORE AGGRESSIVE AND DANGEROUS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, Aug. 10 (CNA): US appeasement towards mainland China has only made Beijing more aggressive and dangerous, and unless Washington draws a clear line, the challenge will only grow more dangerous, an American columnist warns.

In his article headlined: "US in sweet and sour relationship with China" published on the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, Charles Krauthammer, a columnist with the Washington Post Writers Group, said: "The Clinton administration's China grovel has gone from merely embarrassing to potentially dangerous. The past two months of our relationship with China are a chronicle of appeasement that has, predictably, made things worse." ** The U.S. appeasement started from President Bill Clinton offering five public apologies and a compensation of US$3 million after the accidental bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, Yugoslavia; ** U.S. repeatedly berating Taiwan and demanding for a retraction of President Lee Teng-hui's statement of "a special state-to-state" relationship with China; Krauthammer said it would be one thing if this obsequious attempt to placate China worked. But look at how China responds: ** It organizes massive anti-US demonstrations over the embassy bombing, leading to the stoning of the US embassy in Beijing. (The US ambassador responds in perfect Clintonesque tone: "Clearly this is going to make the road a little rockier to stabilizing the relationship between China and the United States.) ** It seizes a Taiwanese ship near the island of Matsu (last heard from in the John F. Kennedy-Richard Nixon debates in 1960), accusing its crew of "smuggling." ** It flies more than 100 menacing military sorties over the Taiwan Strait. ** It denies the United States landing rights for military planes in Hong Kong. ** It launches an intercontinental ballistic missile with range designed to reach the United States.
** It sentences two human rights activists to long prison terms.
** It launches a massive crackdown on the Falun Gong sect, a peaceful semi-mystical movement in China that the regime has decided to eradicate.

"Most ominous is the manner in which the crackdown is carried out. The sect is being persecuted in classic high-Maoist fashion: State TV launches an incessant, vitriolic propaganda campaign. Sect members are arrested and sent en masse to 're-education' schools. Sect leaders are forced into giving public confessions," Krauthammer said.
He noted that globalization does not change China because its economic freedom has not led to its political freedom.

"But there is nothing inevitable in history. We had several mid-20th century cases of vicious fascist dictatorships running non-socialist, relatively free economies. Which is what we have in China today: a ruthless party dictatorship, communist in name only, savagely bent on maintaining power against all opposition," he said. "The Clinton administration seems totally wedded to the notion that as long as it keeps feeding the Chinese economy and propping up our much-touted 'strategic partnership', it will soften China's internal repression. That is no more true than that US appeasement is softening China's external aggressiveness," he said. "The Chinese know how pliant Clinton is and how far he will go to keep trade relations humming. That has emboldened them to openly challenge both the US 'hegemony' and its Taiwanese client," he said.
"Unless Clinton draws a clear line across the Taiwan Strait, the challenge will only grow more dangerous," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO HOLD HUMAN RIGHTS DIALOGUE WITH CHINA IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, Aug. 10 (CNA): Australia will hold a human rights discussion with China in Beijing from Aug. 16 to 20, the third round of such bilateral talks since Canberra publicly denounced human rights abuses in the mainland in 1996.
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is expected to send officials to Beijing to discuss the human rights situation in China.

Human rights analysts are critical of the Australian initiative because it may not improve China's human rights records of abuses and repression. Instead, such talks could encourage China to be more repressive and aggressive in its crackdown on dissidents and even the Falun Gong sect, they said.
They said Australia is losing its traditional courage to speak out on human rights abuses in China because it is now interested only in exploiting the mainland market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 10, or the 29th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
843: The Treaty of Verdun divides the Frankish empire.
1810: Count (Camillo Benso) Cavour, Italian statesman, is born. He played a large role in the unification of Italy and became prime minister in the new kingdom.
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institution is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1885: The first commercially operated electrical streetcar begins operation in Baltimore in the United States.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He is prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffer heavy loses when the Japanese fleet block them as they are trying to escape from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of US President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: US State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the US Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the EEC.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES SOAR

TEXT.P: Taipei share prices climbed 3.4 percent on Tuesday as listed companies reported positive corporate results.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index climbed 241.59 points to finish at 7,269.6 points.
A total of 2.24 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$113.78 billion (US$3.54 billion).

The rise was a technical rebound after many corporate results showed sharp growth, but the surge may be short-lived given continuing uncertainty in cross-strait relations, which have pushed the index down by more than 15 percent over the past month, dealers said.

About 80 percent of Tuesday's turnover was in the trading of technology companies and resulted in a 4.2-percent advance in the electronics sector, the largest gain seen among the eight major stock categories.
All eight major stock categories posted gains, as the financial sector listed a 4-percent advance, the second largest gain seen Tuesday.
The least traded issues -- construction shares and foodstuff shares -- achieved slight gains of 0.3 percent and 0.5 percent, respectively.
The over-the-counter market enjoyed a 5.38-percent gain, ending the day at 161.36 points on a turnover of NT$4.70 billion.
Meanwhile, encouraged by the bullish sentiment in the stock market, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted large gains.

TAIEX Index Futures for August soared 275 points to close at 7,290 points, with 4,111 contract transactions; those for September rose 272 points to close at 7,290 points, with 535 contract transactions, and those for December climbed 247 points to finish at 7,290 points, with 13 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for next March rose 151 points to close at 7,349 points, with 8 contract transactions, and those for next June moved up 213 points to end at 7,320 points, with 4 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,015 points for August, 7,018 points for September, 7,043 points for December, 7,198 points for next March and 7,107 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported gains.

August TE futures rose 16.6 points to end at 332 points, with 1,451 contract transactions; September TE futures climbed 15.65 points to finish at 330.75 points, with 143 contract transactions; December TE futures advanced 21 points to close at 330.3 points, with 2 contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for TE futures for next March or June.
August TF futures rose 53 points to close at 1,039 points, with 147 contract transactions; September TF futures moved up 41.6 points to close at 1,019.8 points, with 1 contract transaction.
There were no transaction records for TF futures for December, next March or next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, CENTRAL AMERICAN COUNTRIES TO HOLD FOREIGN MINISTERS' MEETING

TEXT.P: The Eighth Conference of the Mixed Commission of Cooperation between the Republic of China and Central American countries is slated to be held in San Jose on Tuesday morning.

ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu will report on the ROC's current political and economic situation at the meeting. He will also probably take this opportunity to further clarify President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" theory with regard to relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits.

Meanwhile, foreign affairs ministers from the Central American countries are expected to report on reconstruction efforts in the aftermath of damage caused by hurricanes, as well as ways and means to promote investment and tourism industry in their countries.

In addition, they are expected to discuss matters related to next month's Central American Summit, which is to be held in Taiwan. Hu will invite the heads of Central American countries to attend the event on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui.
A joint communique will be released before the one-day meeting closes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM VISITS COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affair Jason Hu met his Costa Rica counterpart Roberto Rojas Lopez on Monday, and exchanged views with him on economic cooperation.
Hu was accompanied by Mao Kao-wen, the ROC Ambassador to Costa Rica, and Central and South American Affairs Director under the ROC Foreign Ministry, Hu Cheng-yao.

Hu and Rojas Lopez discussed bilateral economic cooperation and Taiwan's imports of more Costa Rican goods for 75 minutes. Rojas Lopez expressed his concern over the continuing tension between Taiwan and mainland China. Hu also explained President Lee Tung-hui's recent "state-to-state" theory to his counterpart.

In addition, Costa Rica President Miguel Angel Rodriguez held a welcoming banquet for Hu. Costa Rican Vice President Astrid Fischel, Economics Minister Samuel Guscowski and Mao all attended the banquet.
Rodriguez apologized that he will be absent from the Central American Summit in September and that Vice President Astrid Fischel will attend the event on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT TO COSTA RICAN UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) government contributed electronic lab equipment worth US$530,000 to Colegio Universita Rio de Puntarenas of Costa Rica.

A ceremony, jointly presided over by Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriquex and ROC Ambassador to Costa Rica Mao Kao-wen, was held on the school's campus over the weekend to mark the inauguration of the equipment.
Ambassador Mao said at the ceremony the donation is based on a bilateral cooperative agreement that aims at enriching the students' knowledge in information, mechanics and electronics.
President Rodriquez thanked the ROC and noted that the equipment will provide the university's students with a good learning environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREIGN EXCHANGE MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.003 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, ending at 32.109.
The local currency opened at 32.109 and was traded between 32.103 and 32.125.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$308 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID TO SHIFT BATTLE FIELD TO DIPLOMATIC FRONT

TEXT.P: Beijing is expected to keep its pressure on Taiwan from the military front to the diplomatic field, said Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Tawei David Lee on Tuesday.

Beijing may not make strong military moves against Taiwan but is likely to further pressure Taiwan in the international community by seeking to block Taiwan's diplomatic relations with other countries, Lee told reporters.
As to the question of how Beijing would continue to intimidate Taiwan, Lee said that Taiwan must be well prepared for Beijing's possible moves.
Relations between Taiwan and mainland China have deteriorated recently after President Lee Teng-hui redefined Taiwan-mainland ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS LOCK HORNS OVER TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAIL PROJECT

TEXT.P: Legislators from the ruling and opposition parties locked horns on Tuesday over financing problems surrounding the high-speed rail project.
The members of the Legislative Transportation Committee heard a report delivered by officials at the office of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) has threatened to terminate its contract with the government on Aug. 16 if financing issues cannot be resolved by then.

Against this backdrop, Chen Gun-teh, legislator from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), demanded during the meeting that the MOTC not make any further concessions. Meanwhile, a lawmaker from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) supported the THSRC's stance.
THSRC CEO Nita Ing has made her company's position clear to the government.
Firstly, the company wants to have its business tax lowered from 5 percent, the figure mandated under law, to 2 percent.
Secondly, the THSRC wants 1.5 percentage points to be the maximum banks are allowed to charge, instead of the minimum as previously agreed, above their costs.

Thirdly, the THSRC is pushing for flexibility in regard to the total amount of financing the company must provide. Under the current contract, it is obligated to raise NT$280 billion. The company is now suggesting that capital raised in the form of corporate bonds should be allowed to count against their financing targets.

Chung Ching-chiang, a legislator from the DPP, said that the government should be well prepared to deal with the island's first and most ambitious infrastructure project. The railway is being built under the build-operate-transfer formula, whereby a private consortium builds and operates the system for a specified period of time, and after that period control is transferred to the government.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Fong-cheng said that he has done his best to assist the THSRC in resolving its critical financing problem.
As long as a compromise can be reached among the MOTC, the THSRC and the banking consortium that will provide the financing, noted Lin, the high-speed rail contract will not be scrapped.
Even if the THSRC wants to terminate the contract, the contract cannot be terminated unilaterally. The termination must follow a certain procedure, said Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD NOT BE PRESSURED TO NEGOTIATE UNTIL MAINLAND DEMOCRATIZES

TEXT.P: An influential US congressman said here on Tuesday that the Republic of China on Taiwan should not be pressured to negotiate a reunification until mainland China is a democracy.
Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman (R-N.Y.), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, made the remarks in a press release issued at the end of a two-day visit to Taipei.
Gilman said he and his bipartisan House delegation strongly support democratically-elected ROC President Lee Teng-hui's right to address Taipei's views of the cross-Taiwan Strait relationship.

"It is our view that the two sides should engage in a dialogue as equals," the press statement said, adding that: "President Lee should not feel pressured to negotiate until China is a democracy, to negotiate a reunification until such time."

During their stay in Taipei, Gilman and his colleagues had met with President Lee, Vice President Lien Chan, National Security Council Secretary-General Yin chung-wen, Defense Minister Tang Fei and several other senior officials for candid exchanges of views on important issues confronting Taiwan at the moment.

"Our extensive discussions we feel were highly productive and they also helped us and enhanced our understanding of President Lee's decision on cross-strait relations and Taiwan's hope for the future," the press statement said.
During those meetings, the delegation has expressed the United States' abiding interest in peace and stability in East Asia and for the peaceful resolution of Taiwan's future.

"We expressed our concern about Chinese 'saber-rattling' over President Lee's state-to-state remarks and its effect on the confidence and security-building in the region," the press release said, adding: "As we leave Taiwan, we are calling upon the PRC to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

The US lawmakers also expressed their belief that Taiwan should have better representation in international bodies and be recognized in those bodies. "The 22 million people of Taiwan deserve this fundamental right no less than any other global citizen."

The press statement further said the delegation hopes its visit has in some way strengthened long-standing bonds of friendship between the United States and Taiwan -- a relationship which is based on their shared commitment to democracy, to freedom, to respect for human rights and for a market economy.
Meanwhile, Gilman also said at a pre-departure news conference that he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will resume dialogue this year.

Gilman further said he fully understands that President Lee has faced up to the reality while defining cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station on July 9.
Taiwan was the first stop of the US House delegation's two-week fact-finding visit to East and Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES OIL PRICE INCREASES AVERAGING 2.97 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. announced on Tuesday an across-the-board oil price increase averaging 2.97 percent, effective Wednesday.

The price of natural gas for industrial and electrical use will be adjusted upward by an average of 2.93 percent, a spokesman for the state-run oil company said. The price of gas for home use, however, will remain unchanged, he said.

This is the fourth price adjustment since April this year, and there may be another adjustment in October if international oil prices continue to rise, since the CPC always sets its prices according to international oil prices, the spokesman said.
