DOC.HEADLINE: MCDONALD'S BREAKS NO LAWS BY SELLING TOY KITTY: MOEA

TEXT.P: The fast-food giant McDonald's has broken no laws by selling "Hello Kitty" toys, as its business license permits the company to sell both fast-food and promotional items, said officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Tuesday.

Liu Kun-liang, director-general of the MOEA's Commerce Department made the statement in response to an independent legislator's question over whether the fast-food company is entitled to sell products other than food.
Independent Legislator Chiu Chuang-liang, from Taoyuan County, held a press conference on Tuesday to question McDonald's selling of the toy.
Chiu accused the company of violating business regulations by selling the toy, which can be bought for NT$69 with a set meal or for NT$119 separately.

MOEA officials said that when McDonald's sought to enter the Taiwan market, it applied to the MOEA for a business license allowing it to give away free gifts and to sell promotional goods. Consequently, McDonald's decision to sell the toy with or without an accompanying meal does not violate the law, officials said.

Officials added, however, that McDonald's chains around the island should apply to their respective local governments for licenses to sell promotional goods. If they fail to do so, local governments are entitled to take proper measures against McDonald's, the officials said.
Any companies violating business registration regulations by selling unauthorized goods will be fined up to NT$15,000.
The MOEA will require all local governments to determine whether the company's branches have applied for licenses permitting the sale of promotional goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE KOALAS BECOME HONORARY CITIZENS OF TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou announced on Tuesday that the two highly treasured Australian koala bears donated by Australia to Taipei City Zoo have become the city's honorary citizens.
Ma also said the two male koala bears, named Hellai and Patrick, will make their first formal public appearance here on Saturday.

The two two-year-old koalas arrived in Taipei on July 31. They have smoothly passed quarantine and inspection and have adapted themselves well to living conditions at their new home at Taipei City Zoo.
"Barring unexpected development, the two koalas will be on public display starting this weekend," Ma said.
As koala bears, which rank among the endangered species needing special protection, spend 19 hours sleeping per day, they have not yet got fully familiar with their new living environment.
Therefore, Ma unveiled a set of regulations for local people to follow when they visit the city zoo this weekend.

According to the regulations, visitors should not tap the glass wall errected to protect the koalas, should not use flashlights, should not throw any article into the koala bears showground, should not feed them any foodstuffs and shoul not make any noise.

Noting that the introduction of koalas is mainly aimed at inspiring local people's support for wildlife conservation, Ma urged local people to exercise restraint and strictly abide by the regulations when they visit the zoo.

Zoo officials said the two koalas' appetite has remained normal over the past week. "By Aug. 7, Hellai's body weight remained at 6.7 kilograms, same as that recorded on its arrival day, while Patrick's was 0.25 kg higher than its original level," said a zoo official.

In connection with the upcoming public display of the two koalas, the city zoo has opened a website on the Internet to provide information and enlist public support for wildlife conservation and environmental protection. The website address is "http://www.koala.taipei.gov.tw".
A variety of souvenirs featuring koala themes will be sold at the city zoo from Saturday.
"We hope the two koala bears will inspire a craze comparable to the Hello Kitty mania which is now sweeping Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan," said a zoo official.
The city zoo has planted 6,000 eucalyptus trees, the staple food for koalas. Zoo officials said they are happy to see the two koalas show high interest in Taiwan-grown eucalyptus leaves.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE PILOT SENTENCED IN TAIWAN FOR HIJACKING

TEXT.P: The pilot of a mainland Chinese Air China passenger jet who hijacked his own plane last year and landed it at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport had his sentence reduced from one year to 10 months' imprisonment on Tuesday by the Taiwan High Court.

The one-year sentence had been imposed on Yuan Bin by Taiwan's Taoyuan District Court. Another defendant in the case, Yuan's wife Hsu Mei, had her original sentence of six-months' imprisonment suspended for two years upheld by the high court.
Yuan commandeered the Air China jetliner which was en route from Beijing to the Myanmar capital of Yangon on Oct. 28 last year.

He announced his intention to defect to Taiwan to the 80 passengers and crew on board, and then locked himself in the cockpit. Crew members and the co-pilot tried but failed to break into the cockpit and stop Yuan. The plane later landed safely at CKS.
All the passengers and crew, except for Yuan and his wife, returned to mainland China several hours later on the same plane.
Yuan and Hsu can still appeal their sentences at the Taiwan Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO REPRESENTATIVE IN PHILIPPINES SAYS NO RETALIATION EXPECTED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines assured the Philippine government Tuesday that it will not pull out its multi-billion-dollar investments here amid speculations of possible retaliation for the suspension of an air agreement between the two countries.
In a media interview, Chan Hsien-ching, an official representative from Taiwan, expressed confidence that the problem would soon be resolved.
Chan said there is no indication that Taiwan will do something to sever its bilateral relations with the Philippines as a result of the suspension of the air agreement.
The Taiwanese public, however, has called for a response to the Philippines' order for ROC airlines to stop sending aircraft into the Philippines.
Taiwan, he said, has worked to calm its public down as negotiations between the two countries have taken place.
Chan also discounted reports that Taiwan will send back a large number of Filipino workers there if Manila does not allow the resumption of flights by commercial airlines to Philippine destinations.

The imbroglio happened after the Philippine government recently suspended the air agreement, which allowed China Airlines and Eva Air, to pick up passengers from and deliver them to the Philippines. The suspension came after the Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) noticed that the airlines had violated some provisions in the air agreement to the detriment of the country's flag-carrier's business interests.
Chan said Taiwan would continue to negotiate until a compromise is reached.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND WARNS TAIWAN OF BEIJING'S INFORMATION WAR

TEXT.P: Amid the deteriorating relations between Taiwan and mainland China, the Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense (MND) has warned the people of Taiwan of Beijing's "information war."
The MND urged people to stay confident but remain on high alert in the face of the "Internet War" which has broken out across the Taiwan Strait.

The MND's remarks come as tension between the two sides of the strait remains high following President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of Taiwan-mainland ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in a July 9 interview with the Germany-based Deutche Welle radio station.

In addition to verbal attacks and military intimidation, ranking MND officials said mainland China is also waging a propaganda war by spreading groundless rumors through the media and the Internet to erode Taiwan's confidence, evident in the dozen government-run websites which have been infiltrated by mainland-based hackers who replaced the original data with pro-Beijing propaganda.

According to National Defense Minister Tang Fei, mainland China has kicked off a comprehensive campaign to develop its hi-tech military technology, as Beijing has realized that its conventional military strength will not be any match for that of the United States within the next 20 years.
At the same time, Beijing is also deeply worried about the progress of Taiwan's computer industry, prompting it to pay special heed to the "information war," Tang added.

Although the definition of "information warfare" remains in dispute, ranking MND officials said it is widely agreed that the term refers to any move which uses computer technology, either to protect one's own data or deface that of the enemy. Computer virus propagation is just one of the techniques which can be used, they noted.
However, the officials pointed out that mainland China's information war against Taiwan has not yet fully matured, and is limited to "psychological warfare" at present.

In light of the vehement campaign by the mainland against Taiwan, the officials said the MND has erected a string of "firewalls" to prevent domestic websites and networks from being damaged by malicious hackers.

In addition, the MND has already set up a task force to assess the technological aspects of information warfare and work out training programs to address new warfare patterns, the officials revealed, adding that the Republic of China military is also seeking to acquire long-range early warning radar systems and satellites, and will establish an information war unit by 2000.

Given the fact that the extent of the current information war already surpasses the jurisdiction of military affairs and requires the participation of different sectors, the MND officials urged the government to establish a supra-ministerial organization to take charge of its study and research.
They stressed that the setting up of such an organization is a serious task which the government will have to face sooner or later.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT STAFF DORMITORY BURGLED

TEXT.P: A burglar broke into the staff dormitory of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) in downtown Taipei, making off with jewelry and other items belonging to three AIT staffers, police reported on Tuesday.
A local police spokesman said the thief, believed to be a professional criminal, netted a haul worth at least NT$1.8 million according to initial estimates.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) immediately asked the police to reinforce patrols in the vicinity of the AIT staff dormitory.
The AIT Taipei Office and the houses of the AIT Taipei Office director and deputy director already have a 24-hour police guard. By Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL STUDENT SUSPECTED OF BEING `CHINESE HACKER'

TEXT.P: The self-dubbed "Chinese hacker" who attacked the website of the Control Yuan on Saturday might be a local person rather than a mainland Chinese, and investigators have already closed in on a suspect, a local evening daily said on Tuesday.

Investigators probing the case in which the homepage of the Control Yuan's website was replaced with a map of mainland China and an announcement that "there is only one China and only one China is needed," have suspected all along that it was an "inside job," and have narrowed their investigation to a university student in central Taiwan, according to the China Times Express.

A source from the computer crime center under the Criminal Investigation Bureau said that police have tracked the hacker by traces he left on network, and are set to launch a search, according to the paper.

Chang Hsiao-bin, the prosecutor at the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office who is heading the investigation, said that anyone who breaks into the websites of government agencies and alters their contents will be charged with destroying government documents, a crime punishable by up to seven years in prison.

If the attacker has stolen "classified" information from the websites and resold it for profit, other charges could be filed, said Chang, without elaborating on how "classified" information could come to be placed on a public document in the first place.

The website attack, which has unleashed a wave of counterattacks from Taiwan hackers on websites operated by mainland Chinese government agencies in retaliation, has drawn attention to the security, or lack thereof, of websites.
A non-profit information promotion organization, the Institute for Information Industry, on Tuesday set up a network security panel which will provide free security information to website owners.
Meanwhile an intelligence officer from the Ministry of National Defense cautioned on Tuesday that there might be military purposes behind the hackers' attacks.

Describing the attacks a form of unconventional warfare, Maj. Gen. Hu Yuan-chieh, director of the office of the vice defense minister for intelligence affairs, said that the ministry has a set of security measures to protect its computer network, which is not linked to the Internet and is almost impossible to break into.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, PARTY MEMBERS ENDORSE VICE PRESIDENT'S PRESIDENTIAL BID

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, senior Kuomintang officials and more than 1,000 delegates to the party congress have so far endorsed Vice President Lien Chan as the party's presidential candidate for the 2000 election.
The senior KMT officials who endorsed Lien include KMT vice chairman Chiu Chuan-huan and former Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
According to KMT officials in charge of the party primaries scheduled for Aug. 21, the number of endorsees for Lien will certainly surpass 90 percent of the 2,180 delegates.
According to KMT rules, a candidate should receive the endorsement of at least 10 percent, or 218 delegates, of the party congress, a figure which he has already achieved.
The KMT officials, however, declined to reveal how many of the delegates are supporting former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INAUGURATES ASIA'S FIRST FLIGHT RECORDER LABORATORY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Tuesday inaugurated Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.

Weng Cheng-yi, chairman of the Flight Security Committee of the Executive Yuan, said that in the past, the first step of an aircraft accident investigation was to send the black box to the United States or Australia for analysis.

However, because of language and cultural differences, the results then had to be sent to Taiwan for further analysis, which made the investigative process very inconvenient. The decision to set up a local flight recorder laboratory was made last year in the wake of a China Airlines crash at Taoyuan, the country's worst-ever air disaster.
The laboratory can read and analyze the cockpit voice recorder and the flight information recorder, which will shorten the investigative process and also help flight security education and study.
The facility, which was built at a cost of NT$100 billion, will provide results which are 96.6 percent accurate, according to Weng.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOEING, AIRBUS TO SIGN PLANE PROCUREMENT ACCORDS WITH CAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) will buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes from Boeing Co. of the United States and 13 passenger jets from France's Airbus Industrie, sources close to CAL said on Tuesday.
The sources said Fred Howard, head of Boeing's operation in Asia, will arrive in Taipei on Tuesday for the signing of a procurement agreement with CAL.
Public Relations personnel of Boeing's headquarters arrived in Taipei on Monday, and have spent their time with CAL officials preparing for the signing scheduled to take place on Wednesday.
The cost of the 13 cargo planes procured from Boeing is estimated at US$2.5 billion.
Meanwhile, John Leahy, senior deputy chief of Airbus Industrie, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Wednesday, and will sign a plane procurement agreement with CAL on Thursday.
CAL had originally planned to buy all 26 planes from Boeing, but changed its plan and decided to buy the passenger planes from Airbus Industrie instead.

The change of decision shocked Boeing and it was reported that the US government thought CAL made the change because Taiwan was not satisfied with the US attitude toward the "special state-to-state" theory on cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

US Sen. Slade Gorton from Washington State arrived in Taipei on Monday to meet President Lee Teng-hui and Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng to try to find out more about CAL's change of plans, whereupon it was pointed out the deal is purely commercial in nature and has no political implications.

Although the procurement plan has not yet been formally approved by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Lin has said his ministry will respect CAL's decision and will not oppose the signing. However, the deals will not become effective until the approval has been granted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC JET FIGHTERS TWICE CROSS TAIWAN STRAIT CENTER LINE

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese jet fighters twice crossed the center line of the Taiwan Strait in late July, but with no apparent hostile intent, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) revealed on Tuesday.

The MND spokesman's office said the first incident occurred on July 25 when two indigenous Jian-8 fighters crossed the dividing line and penetrated five kilometers into Republic of China airspace, while the second took place on July 30 when two Jian-7s penetrated about 10 kilometers into local territory.
Shortly after the planes crossed the line, the spokesman's office noted, they corrected their routes and returned to the west side of the center line.

Over the past few weeks, mainland China has been waging a war of nerves against Taiwan to protest President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship."

The MND also said that no unusual movements of People's Liberation Army (PLA) troops along the coastal provinces of mainland China have been noticed, and that there are no signs that a large-scale PLA military maneuver is to be held.
But a ranking MND officer confirmed that advanced Su-27 jet fighters stationed in Guangdong Province have begun training activities in areas close to the center line of the Taiwan Strait.
According to the MND, no significant increase in PLA power has been seen in the Fujian area, with the exception of the deployment of eight Jian-8s at Fuzhou airbase.
At present, the MND said, about 150 mainland Chinese aircraft are stationed in Fujian's coastal areas, with Jian-7s and Jian-8s increasing their patrol flights from Fuzhou and Longxi airbases.
The MND urged mainland China to exercise self-restraint in its jet fighter training, pointing out that about 340 international flights and 730 domestic flights fly over the Taiwan Strait every day.
In response to the increased mainland air activity, the MND said, the basic principles of the ROC armed forces are to avoid provocation and minimize the risk of hostility.
It expressed the hope that the Taiwan people and media will stop speculating on mainland military activities so as to prevent the island's stability and economic development from being harmed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY IN TOKYO FOR PRIVATE TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Tseng Wen-fui, wife of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, arrived in Tokyo from the ancient Japanese city of Kyoto on the Shinkansen bullet train on Tuesday for a private visit.
The first lady arrived in Japan last Sunday to attend the christening of a freighter built for a Taiwan company at a shipyard in Shikoku.
She came to Tokyo accompanied by Chuang Ming-yao, ROC representative to Japan, and is scheduled to return to Taipei on Aug. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: `THE MORE PUBLICITY THE BETTER' FOR ROC: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The more publicity caused by Taiwan's claim of "state-to-state ties" with Beijing the better, President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday.

In a pep talk to a group of middle-rank officials, the president, who made the "special state-to-state relationship" remark on July 9, said that the more international attention his statement receives, the more understanding of the Republic of China's plight the world will be able to obtain.

Lee said that with less than one year left in office, he wanted to clearly define the status of cross-strait relations before stepping down, in order to ensure a smooth course in dealing with Beijing for his successor.
"We do not advocate Taiwan independence, but the status of a sovereign state which is vital to the national survival and development cannot be compromised," said Lee.
What has gone, he went on, is the policy of "reclaiming mainland China by force" which was the war cry espoused by previous ROC presidents.
Instead, the government wants to transform the Beijing regime by spreading Taiwan's experience of democratization to mainland China and set the stage for national reunification, said Lee.

He stressed the importance of strengthening the island's defenses, citing as proof the reports of increased military movements which have been rife since Lee made his statement and have sparked a nose-dive in the local bourse.

However, Lee dismissed as "exaggeration" reports that Beijing's jet fighters, in saber-rattling gestures, have flown sorties across the central line of the Taiwan Strait which separates Taiwan and mainland China.

"Only two Beijing aircraft have been detected flying near the central line, one coming within ten kilometers of it and the other within five kilometers," he said, adding that he considered the near-intrusion into Taiwan airspace as an inadvertent accident due to the high speed of the aircraft and the fact that the center line is imaginary.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX US CONGRESSMEN ARRIVE IN TAIWAN FOR THREE-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: A group of six US congressmen, accompanied by the chief of a Washington think tank, arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a three-day visit.

The six Republican members of the US House of Representatives -- Sam Johnson from Texas, Charles T. Canady from Florida, Ernest Istook from Oklahoma, Van Hilleary from Tennessee, Joseph R. Pitts from Pennsylvania and Bill Barnett from Nebraska -- were greeted at the airport by officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as well as Edwin J. Feulner Jr., president of the Heritage Foundation.

Feulner, who arranged the visit, arrived on an earlier flight. He will accompany the congressmen to meet with President Lee Teng-hui and other government leaders to sound out their views on the island's "special state-to-state" ties with Beijing as defined by Lee on July 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui says clarifying the country's status is the most important.
The China Times:
The more publicity on the state-to-state theory the better for the ROC, says President Lee.
The United Daily News:
Controversy over the state-to-state theory will help more people understand Taiwan, says the president.
The Liberty Times:
President Lee says international uproar over 'state-to-state' imbroglio will help more people understand Taiwan's plight.
The Commons Daily:
Controversy over the 'state-to-state theory' highlights Taiwan's challenges, says President Lee.
The China Post:
PRC jets crossed Taiwan Strait boundary: MND.
The Taiwan News:
President Lee: Chinese planes crossed center line.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 11, or the first day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1519: Johann Tetzel, a German monk who was appointed to sell indulgences to raise funds for the Catholic Church, dies at the age of 54. His simplistic and unorthodox sermons, regarded by many as symptomatic of the abuses within the Church, provoked Martin Luther to write his 95 theses in 1517.
1673: Richard Meade, English physician to royalty and pioneer of preventive medicine, is born.
1786: Rajah of Kedah in Malaya cedes Penang to Britain.
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupied southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1893: The indicator plate of German engineer Rudolf Diesel's latest heat engine explodes in Augsburg, narrowly missing his head. Despite this setback, the 35-year-old engineer who devised and patented an internal-combustion engine in 1892, plans to have a revised engine ready in six months.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the ROC government.
1950: The UN Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1952: Crown Prince Hussein of Jordan is named successor to his schizophrenic father King Talal.
1955: Two US Air Force planes collide mid-air above West Germany, killing 66 soldiers.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which waiting to be scrapped in a shipbreaking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a north America free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to financial crisis-hit country.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO SIGN PURCHASE CONTRACTS WITH BOEING AND AIRBUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) is scheduled to sign contracts to buy 13 cargo jets from US-based Boeing Co. on Wednesday, and 14 passenger jets from European consortium Airbus Industrie on Thursday.

Boeing's Asian region president Fred Howard arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday to sign the US$2.5 billion contract for 13 B747-400 cargo planes, while Boeing archrival Airbus senior vice president John Leahy is slated to arrive at Taiwan on Wednesday to sign a contract with CAL on Thursday.
CAL has yet to announce the number of passenger jets it is buying from Airbus.
Sales have taken off in Asia in recent years for Airbus' new generation A330 and A340 jets, prompting the consortium to pay more attention to this market.

The company predicts that the civil aviation market in Asia will enjoy a 6.1 percent annual growth rate, while that of Taiwan will reach 6.2 percent with a potential demand of 250 aircraft, worth US$30 billion, in the next 20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: US NEWSPAPER SAYS SEVENTH FLEET PREPARING FOR DUTY IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The Pentagon and sailors of the United States' Seventh Fleet are watching the Taiwan Strait, but they must be hoping they will never have to choose between mainland China and Taiwan in the event of a military conflict.
Unfortunately, that scenario appears to be growing ever less likely, according to an American newspaper report.

The Pacific Star and Stripes reported Tuesday from Tokyo that as tensions escalate in the Taiwan Strait, members of the Seventh Fleet watch, knowing they could be sent in as they were three years ago to prevent a violent takeover of Taiwan by mainland China.

The newspaper noted that as much as the United States claims to be committed to the "one China" policy, it was the Seventh Fleet, sent by President Harry Truman, that prevented the communists from rolling over the island that the Nationalists retreated to a half century ago.

Ironically, the report said, it was also to mainland China's great benefit that the communists did not take Taiwan in 1950, as Taiwanese are now among the top investors in the mainland. "There is little reason to believe Taiwan wouldn't be a struggling backwater like most of China if it had not been separate for this half century," it added.
Mainland China's leaders, of course, see control of the island as their sovereign right. They are also suspicious of US motives and intentions, according to the paper.

The paper cited a passage from the book "China Wakes," by New York Times writers Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn, in which a classified mainland Chinese document in 1993 warned that "because of (the United States') political, economic and security interests, it is in America's best interest to preserve the situation in the Taiwan Straits as it is, with Taiwan remaining indefinitely as an independent entity."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ASKS ARATS TO ENSURE SAFETY OF DETAINED ROC NATIONAL

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has issued a letter to its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), asking it to guarantee the personal safety of a detained Republic of China national, a SEF official said Wednesday.

Tsai Chien-shih, president of a local security service company and a former intelligence officer of the ROC Coast Guard Command, was detained by mainland Chinese authorities while traveling in Fujian province with a tour group on July 28.

SEF Vice Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing said Wednesday that the foundation sent a letter on Aug. 5 to ARATS, asking it to ensure Tsai's personal safety and to assist mainland Chinese authorities in investigating Tsai's arrest.
He stressed that the ROC does not wish to see continued encroachments on Taiwan people's human rights by mainland Chinese authorities when ROC nationals are traveling in the mainland.
SEF has also enlisted the assistance of Hsu Chun-ta, chairman of a Taiwan enterprise association in Fuzhou, Fujian province, in securing Tsai's release.
Sources revealed that mainland Chinese authorities suspect Tsai of engaging in espionage activities under the guise of touring the mainland, and authorities have detained him for further questioning.
Tsai's family has denied the allegations and has hurried to Fuzhou to gain a firsthand understanding of the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANALYST SEES CHANGES TO MAINLAND'S 'THEORY OF NUCLEAR DETERRENCE'

TEXT.P: A Toronto-based military expert warned Tuesday that mainland China may have changed its "theory of nuclear deterrence" so significantly that a nuclear war between Taiwan and China can no longer be thought of as pure fiction.

Pinkov revealed his analysis in the Tuesday edition of the Kanwa News, saying that for mainland China, the function of nuclear deterrence is to safeguard territorial sovereignty, to contain the United States from becoming involved in the Taiwan issue through conventional warfare and to retaliate against a US nuclear attack.
Mainland China may have copied the new military theory that Russia proposed in 1993 and has, in fact, given up its promise of "taking no initiative in using nuclear weapons," Pinkov said.

He pointed out that Western military observers generally believe that mainland China's announcement of possessing the technology to make neutron bombs and small tactical nuclear weapons at an appropriate time implies a deterrent to Taiwan.

Shortly after the announcement, several mainland Chinese government-run military publications, including the Naval and Merchant Ship and National Defense Paper, confirmed the view both directly and indirectly, stressing that this announcement dealt a blow to Taiwan independence advocates. The Naval and Merchant Ship directly stated that the best way to destroy enemy planes on the ground and enemy ships at naval ports is to use tactical nuclear weapons.

"This new movement of China marks a possible conceptual breakthrough in the 'nuclear deterrence' theory of China and it has actually given up the policy of 'taking no initiative in using nuclear weapons under any circumstances,'" he wrote.

That is to say that the new theory of nuclear deterrence has gone beyond the traditional definition of "nuclear deterrence" to prevent nuclear war, he said. In fact, nuclear deterrence now plays the role of preventing conventional wars from breaking out, he said. (S.C. Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE'S WORDS SIMPLY REFLECT REALITY: TORONTO STAR ARTICLE

TEXT.P: Canada's largest-circulation newspaper, The Toronto Star, carried an article Tuesday by the spokesman for the government of the Republic of China stating that President Lee Teng-hui's controversial remarks about "special state-to-state relationship" with mainland China simply reflect reality.
"It does not signal a change in Taiwan's mainland policy," said Chen Chien-jen. The Star referred to Chen as "the director general of the government information office for the Republic of China."
He noted that Lee's reference to a "special state-to-state relationship" is just a straightforward summary of the current situation and demonstrates pragmatism, continuity of policy and innovation.

Chen quoted ROC Premier Vincent Siew as saying, "Our policy of promoting constructive dialogue and positive exchanges remains unchanged; our resolve to pursue a win-win situation in cross-strait relations remains unchanged; and our goal for a peaceful, democratic and a united new China in the future remains unchanged."

Pretending that the ROC has not existed for the past 50 years or that it has not exercised effective jurisdiction over the Taiwan area has only emboldened those in Beijing intent on intimidation and military adventurism, Chen pointed out.

He said Beijing has grown increasingly intolerant of any legitimate action in the international community on the part of the ROC government, no matter how minor, that does not accord with its own hard-line shift toward defining the term "one China" to mean the mainland itself.

There is a real need to clarify Taiwan's status with respect to mainland China before the visit to Taiwan by mainland China's emissary for cross-strait dialogue scheduled for this autumn, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US STATE DEPARTMENT AGAIN CALLS FOR CALM ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The United States on Tuesday again urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to exercise restraint and not take actions or make statements that make meaningful and substantive dialogue more difficult, and to resolve their differences in a peaceful manner.

When asked to comment on Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's televised statement about mainland Chinese Air Force jets crossing strait lines, US Department of State spokesman James Rubin told a regular briefing that for some time now, the United States has been monitoring the situation over the Taiwan Strait very closely.

"We are aware that recently a number of sorties have been flown by both China and Taiwan military aircraft in the Taiwan Straits. Any time you have military aircraft flying this close to each other, there is a need for and appropriate for there to be concern about accidents," said Rubin.

"We have repeatedly stated, both to Taiwan and China, that it is not beneficial for either side to take steps that increase tensions across the Taiwan Straits. We continue to urge both sides to exercise restraint and not take actions or make statements that make meaningful and substantive dialogue more difficult, and to resolve their differences in peaceful manner," he said.

As to New York Republican Congressman Benjamin Gilman's statement that he supports Taiwan's position on "special state-to-state relations" with mainland China, Rubin said a House delegation led by Rep. Gilman is in Taiwan and will meet with President Lee and others.

"They will speak for themselves, as members of Congress do, and it will be up to them to describe their own views. We certainly didn't ask the members to convey a message on our behalf," stressed Rubin.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.009 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 32.118.
The local currency opened at 32.105 and was traded between 32.102 and 32.125.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$216.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK DENIES ENTRY TO FORMER MAC CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) has officially rejected former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh's visa application amid continued tensions between both sides of the Taiwan Strait, sources revealed Wednesday.

Chang was invited to attend an academic conference at the University of Hong Kong, where he was scheduled to jointly chair the opening ceremony on Thursday with Ip Kwok-wah, special assistant to HKSAR Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa.
Fredrick Fung, general education coordinator for the university, confirmed to CNA that Hong Kong immigration officials notified him Monday that Chang's visa request had been denied.

Fung said the conference, slated to take place on Thursday and Friday evenings, originally invited specialists from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China to address the topic of China's reunification, with university students from Hong Kong, Beijing and the United States attending as well.

Because Chang is not able to take part, however, the first day's seminar had to be canceled at the last minute, Fung said. He added that this was regrettable, as this would have been a rare opportunity for experts from three sides to discuss the reunification issue.
Due to tense relations between both sides of the strait, Fung said that if the "central government" has instructed the HKSAR to bar the former MAC chairman's entry, he has "nothing to say."

But if it were the special administrative region's own decision, it is another matter, he said. He pointed out that Hong Kong is a "special region" that can play an intermediary role in private cross-strait exchanges.
Moreover, he added, Chang has already retired from his government post, which means his status should not be a matter of sensitivity.
Chang was allowed to visit Hong Kong while still in office last May on a "personal visit."
In response to outside speculation, a Hong Kong Immigration Department spokesman simply said that as a matter of policy, they do not comment on individual cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: 61 VIOLATIONS OF HEALTH FOOD REGULATIONS FOUND

TEXT.P: Local health offices under the Cabinet-level Department of Health has conducted overall islandwide inspections of the selling of drugs and foods, and it found 61 violations of health food regulations implemented last Tuesday.

It is known that 231 violations of various food and pharmaceutical regulations were recorded among the 2,492 stores inspected. Of that number 136 violations were of food hygiene regulations and 41 were of pharmaceutical regulations. The inspections have been conducted for one week, and most violations were found in Taipei City, where 77 violations were recorded.

The Bureau of Food Sanitation under the Department of Health pointed out that all health offices have mobilized related personnel to inspect pharmacies, weight-loss centers and exclusive shops selling products appearing on TV shopping channels.
In addition, the inspections also covered ads in newspapers as well as commercials on TV.

Deputy Director of the Bureau Chen Lu-hung said that during the inspection process, it was found that most store proprietors had unloaded unlawful products from their shelves in advance of the inspections and that some labels and ads had been changed or modified as well.
Some 90 percent of foods inspected were found to be within related regulations, and most violations were related to food labeled as "healthy" or whose healthful effects were exaggerated.
Chen also stressed that the inspections will be conducted continuously. In order to ensure the public's interest and health, store keepers must obey the laws and sell legal products.

According to the inspection results, no violations were found in several areas, including Taipei County, Chilung City, Nantou County and Yuanlin County. The bureau, however, will continue to examine those districts, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices fell 0.6 percent on Wednesday due to continuing uncertainty in the cross-Taiwan Strait situation and widespread profit-taking by investors following the surge in the previous day's trading session.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index lost 40.92 points to close at 7,228.68.
A total of 2.21 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$117.33 billion (US$3.65 billion), up from the previous session's NT$113.78 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, only electronic stocks and paper and pulp shares reported gains for the day, rising 0.5 percent and 0.1 percent, respectively.
Financial shares suffered the session's heaviest losses, sliding 2.3 percent. Plastic and chemical stocks and construction shares both dropped 1.4 percent, while textile issues declined 1.2 percent.
The foodstuff sector posted a 0.9-percent decrease, while cement issues closed 0.8 percent lower.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market saw a 1.28-point decline, ending the day at 160.08, on a turnover of NT$4.58 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August dropped 60 points to close at 7,230, with 3,604 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September slipped 65 points to close at 7,225, while those for December dropped 30 points, closing at 7,260. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 509 and nine, respectively.
Futures for next March were down 68 points, finishing at 7,233, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next June's futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,290 points for August, September and December, 7,301 points for next March, and 7,320 points for next June.
Electronics futures (TE) and financial futures (TF), both sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported gains and losses, respectively.

August TE futures closed 0.05 points higher on Wednesday 332.05, with 1,131 contract transactions; September TE futures rose 1.15 points to close at 331.9, with 147 contract transactions; December TE futures dropped 1.3 points, closing at 329.0, with two contract transactions.
There were no transactions recorded for TE futures for next March and June.
August TF futures suffered a 23.8-point setback to close at 1,015.2, with 116 contract transactions; September TF futures fell 17.6 points to finish at 1,002.2, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TF futures for December, next March or next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was quoted at NT$32.118 against the greenback on the Taipei market Wednesday, with a decline of 0.9 cent.
The local currency opened at 32.105 and was traded between 32.102 and 32.125. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$216.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI URGED TO FILE INTERNATIONAL LAWSUIT ON NAME ISSUE

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers urged the Republic of China government on Wednesday to file an international lawsuit against mainland China's use of the name "Taiwan" on its websites.

At a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan, Cheng Pao-chin and Yeh Yi-chin, lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, asked the government to take international court action within a week to bring global attention to the Taiwan situation.

Echoing remarks made a day earlier by President Lee Teng-hui that the more international publicity arising from his "special state-to-state relationship" theory on Taiwan's ties with mainland China the better, they asserted that the mainland's Xinhua News Agency's inclusion of a "Taiwan.com" Internet domain name on the home page of its "China.com" website forms part of Beijing's efforts to treat Taiwan as one of its provinces.

The state-run news agency's "China.com" has also set up a company in Taiwan to operate its "Taiwan.com," which they said is an apparent attempt by Beijing to achieve its "one country, two systems" unification goal with Taiwan by misleading the public, according to the lawmakers.

Therefore, they said, the government should file a lawsuit against Xinhua to fully protect what they called its "legal right" to the name of "Taiwan.com" and allow the international community to understand that Taiwan is not a part of mainland China.

Turning to the Taiwan-based Xinhua-run firm, the lawmakers also urged the government to carry out a thorough investigation to probe the role of mainland Chinese capital in the company. They added that this demand has been endorsed by 101 other lawmakers.

Y.C. Chen, a lawyer who also attended the news conference, claimed that under the US' Taiwan Relations Act, which is Washington's policy framework governing its dealings with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic links between the two sides, Taiwan is effectively a de facto independent country.

Against this backdrop, he went on, it should be feasible to peacefully settle the cross-Taiwan Strait "information war" by lodging a complaint with the US Federal Court and allowing it to handle the dispute.

C.C. Hsiu, a computer science professor at National Taiwan University (NTU), warned that relevant government authorities must take precautions against Beijing's spreading of propaganda through its "Taiwan.com" website, although the website at present provides only tourist and entertainment information.
Y.C. Yang, another NTU professor, criticized the government for moving "too slowly" in setting up a national website network of its own.

Blaming the government for lacking a forward-looking view in this field, he urged the authorities to seriously look into the issue to prevent Taiwan-based websites from being dominated by mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEGAWATI ASKS EAST TIMORESE TO STAY INDONESIAN

TEXT.P: Likening herself to a "mother" of the East Timorese, Indonesian presidential front-runner Megawati Sukarnoputri has urged all the people of the former Portuguese colony to stay Indonesian ahead of the Aug. 30 ballot on the future of the territory.

"East Timorese should have confidence and dignity to choose what is best for them and do not let anyone interfere to separate East Timor from Indonesia," she told a crowd of 500 mainly male supporters in a dilapidated sports stadium at the end of her two-day visit to Dili and other cities on Tuesday, The Sydney Morning Herald reported on Wednesday.

"When I was chosen leader of the PDI-P ... at one special party congress one of them members came up to me and said, 'We want to vote for you so please do not leave us.' So that is why I am not going to leave you. I love the people of East Timor," she said. Megawati made her emotional plea to the Timorese before heading home to Jakarta.

But East Timorese Nobel laureate, Bishop Carlos Belo, publicly appealed to Megawati to respect the outcome of the Aug. 30 referendum on self-determination. His appeal followed a short meeting with the PDI-P leader.
Asked what her response would be if East Timor voted for independence, Megawati replied: "We'll see at the MPR (People's Consultative Assembly) meeting in November."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SET TO LOWER BUSINESS TAX SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Australia is set to lower its business tax from the current 36 percent to 30 percent in its bid to lure foreign investment and help local businesses gain a more competitive edge in their exports.
Prime Minister John Howard has changed his earlier opposition to the sharp drop in the business tax and agreed with the proposal by Treasurer Peter Costello to slash the current tax to 30 percent.

Details of the deal between Howard and Costello, however, have yet to be hammered out -- a process that will take several weeks of high-level discussions in government circles -- but they are almost certain to see the company tax rate cut to 30 percent from the current 36 percent, sources close to the government said.

Australian businessmen are expected to welcome the sharp decline because they have repeatedly urged the government to agree to the reduction so that they can have a more competitive edge in selling their products in overseas markets.

At the same time, the lower tax rate will certainly attract more foreign investors to Australia. Australia's high company tax has deterred many prospective foreign investors from investing in this country in the past, economists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SCIENTIST IDENTIFIES VIRUS THAT CAUSES BREAST CANCER

TEXT.P: An American scientist has identified the virus that causes breast cancer, raising hopes that a vaccine can be developed against the disease.

The discovery -- the first to link an inherited virus with a major human cancer -- was announced by Professor Robert Garry, a microbiologist at Tulane University of New Orleans at the 11th International Congress of Virology in Sydney on Tuesday.
He said the finding may be used to identify people at risk of developing the cancer, so early diagnosis and treatment could be instigated.
The Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday quoted Garry as saying: "And if a vaccine could be developed ... we could even prevent (cancers) from occurring altogether."

He said the new human virus was almost identical to a virus that caused breast cancer in mice. He and other researchers found that more than 85 percent of women with breast cancer have the human virus, compared with only 20 percent of people without breast cancer.

Professor John Boyages of the New South Wales Breast Cancer Institute described the discovery as "exciting" but said the research had been conducted on only 30 women and large numbers needed to be tested to determine its significance.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT SEES WHY MAINLAND CHINA CONDUCTING INTENSE CAMPAIGNS

TEXT.P: A long-time China watcher has cited several factors as explaining why a frightened mainland China is conducting intense campaigns against the United States, Taiwan and the mystical Falun Gong sect by arresting its members and leaders en masse over the past few weeks.
Robert Elegant, author of "Last Year in Hong Kong," said there are several reasons for the campaigns.

First the ruling Communist Party in Beijing finds its autocratic power directly challenged by phenomena such as unemployment totaling about 200 million; the usurpation of its powers by provincial and municipal party and governmental organs, by secret societies such as Falun Gong, and by new commercial units; and the People's Liberation Army, which is quasi-independently rattling sabers over Taiwan's insistence on equality with Beijing.

Second, any large organized group outside the Communist Party-controlled structure is seen as a threat -- especially one claiming mystical, religious characteristics, such as Falun Gong, which claims 70 million members in mainland China, compared to 56 million members of the Communist Party.

Finally, the government, unable to deliver the constantly growing economic prosperity it has promised the Chinese people, must find another rallying call to win the people's loyalty to the communists.
Since so-called Maoist Thought, as well as socialism, are not merely passe, but reviled, the only remaining sentiment is nationalism, Elegant said.
"Nationalism is very hard to arouse or organize in a nation of 1.3 billion that has for millennia been characterized by strong local loyalties, rather than national allegiance," he said.
"It is, therefore, necessary to fan nationalistic feeling against a specific enemy, rather than for China itself. And what better enemy than the world's sole superpower, the US?" he said.
"The drive to reclaim Taiwan and revile the US are clearly also the endeavors of a shaky government," he said.

He also noted that universal corruption further alienates the mainland Chinese people from the Communist Party as does the total refusal to allow the people a voice in their government , despite the charade of local elections with one slate of party-approved candidates in some villages.
"But growing unemployment is the source of the greatest popular disillusion and the most intense hostility towards the government," he said.
