DOC.HEADLINE: ROC COMPLETES MISSILE DEPLOYMENT ON OUTLYING ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China armed forces have completed missile deployment on the country's outlying islands to beef up their defense capabilities in the face of the mounting threat from mainland China, a military expert said on Wednesday.

The expert, who spoke on condition of anonymity, was commenting on a Hong Kong newspaper report that the Beijing leadership has decided to use "an appropriate degree of force" against Taiwan, possibly including the occupation of an outlying island, should Taipei refuse to abandon President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" theory.

Noting that the ROC's military deployment on its outlying islands, many of which lie closer to mainland China than to Taiwan, is based on the principle of fortifying firepower while trimming manpower, the expert said military authorities have also taken into consideration the geographic situation of the various outlying islands, and the deployment of the enemy forces.

Under the military's troop reduction plan, the expert said, weaponry deployment on Taiwan's offshore frontline islands has been reinforced significantly to make up for the smaller number of personnel stationed on the islands.

According to the expert, the military began to deploy surface-to-air missiles on the island group of Penghu as far back as 1989, as the islands off Taiwan's southwestern coast sit at a strategic point close to the center of the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, naval authorities are planning to deploy locally built Hsiung Feng II anti-ship missiles in Penghu which will be able to reach the southeastern mainland port city of Xiamen. The navy has also deployed the missiles, with a range of more than 100 kilometers, on the ROC's second-generation warships.
The expert went on to say that although military deployment in Penghu focuses on anti-invasion operations, the military has also built up sizable air and naval defense forces there.

As for other outlying island groups as Kinmen and Matsu, he continued, military deployment there focuses on traditional forces because some of their islets lie within firing range of mainland China artillery. Nevertheless, the military has also deployed chaparral missiles on some of the islets for low-altitude air defense.

Most noteworthy is Tungyin, an islet belonging to the Matsu group, which is out of range of mainland guns. Moreover, Tungyin is formed from granite, which makes for excellent natural protection, and is the only outlying island to have deployed the highly advanced surface-to-air Sky Bow missiles.

According to the expert, the deployments on the various outlying islands are not only for passive defense but also have a deterrent purpose. "Local people should have confidence in the defenses on the outlying islands," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI, KOREA SIGN COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT ON SPORT

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) on Wednesday signed an agreement with the Korean Olympic committee in an effort to push bilateral sports cooperation and exchanges.

International Olympic Committee member Wu Ching-kuo, Vice Chairman of the Cabinet-level National Council for Physical Fitness and Sports Lin Cheng-hung, and other representatives from sports circles attended the signing ceremony.

CTOC chairman Huang Ta-chou expressed his hope at the ceremony that under the current framework, the two countries will also be able to promote bilateral relationships in culture, arts, trade, and economics, as well as in sports.
He also stressed the importance of the agreement, saying that from now on, the bilateral relationship will be closer and more active through sports cooperation and exchanges.
For his part, chairman of the Korean Olympic Committee Un Yung Kim said he hoped bilateral cooperation and exchanges of the two sides can be made in a more pleasant atmosphere.
The agreement covers increased visits and talks involving sports officials, and efforts to promote international sporting events.
The CTOC has already signed similar agreements with Iran, Bulgaria and Macedonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL ACQUIRES OVER 1,000 KMT SPONSORS FOR NOMINATION

TEXT.P: The sponsorship procedure for the recommendation of the ruling Kuomintang's candidate for the March 2000 presidential election had accumulated 1,204 names as of Wednesday morning, all of them in support of Lien Chan's nomination.
Lien, vice president of the Republic of China and also vice chairman of the KMT, obtained party chairman Lee Teng-hui's sponsorship on Aug. 7, the first day of the sponsorship period.

It was estimated by ranking KMT officials that Lien would have the support of more than 90 percent of the party representatives by the end of the sponsorship process on Wednesday at close of business.

According to KMT presidential nomination regulations, potential candidates must acquire sponsorship of at least one tenth of the party congress delegates to be eligible for nomination. As there are 2,180 delegates, Lien needed just 218 names.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang noted that Lien's 1,204 sponsors mean that he has far surpassed the threshold.

The KMT congress delegates are to proceed with a vote for the party's presidential candidate on Aug. 21, and the result will be reported to the KMT Central Standing Committee for reference on Aug. 25. The elected presidential candidate will also recommend his vice presidential running mate to the Central Standing Committee for reference by the same date.
The final stage of the candidate-nomination procedure is to obtain party approval, which will take place during the Second Conference of the 15th KMT National Congress scheduled to open on Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACEFUL SOLUTION TO CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTE IS ROC GOAL: MOFA

TEXT.P: Seeking a peaceful solution to disputes across the Taiwan Strait remains the Republic of China's ultimate goal, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday.

MOFA acting spokesman Henry Chen made the statement in response to a senior US naval officer's remarks that the USS Constellation aircraft carrier battle group may move from the Persian Gulf to the Taiwan Strait if a 1996-style crisis erupts in the strait.
Reiterating that seeking a peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes is the ROC's consistent policy and national goal, Chen said the ROC is endeavoring to seek a resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
"We also sincerely welcome top mainland netogiator Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan this autumn as scudeuled," Chen said.

Wang, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), a quasi-official intermediary body authorized by Beijing authorities to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties, is scheduled to visit Taiwan either in mid-September or mid-October.

However, Wang's visit has become uncertain after ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station in July, drawing a furious reaction from Beijing.

Amid reports of increased sorties in the skies over the Taiwan Strait in recent weeks, Rear Admiral Timothy LaFleur, commander of the USS Constellation battle group, said in Singapore on Tuesday that the battle group may be dispatched to the Taiwan Strait should a military crisis break out in the region.

Noting that mobility is one of the navy's major advantages, LaFleur said US warships can quickly move from one area to another. During the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, LaFleur said, a US aircraft carrier battle group sailed from the Persian Gulf to the Taiwan Strait in a very short period of time.
The USS Constellation is currently docked in Singapore for training exercises with the Singapore navy following similar training drills with Japanese and South Korean forces.
LaFleur said the Constellation battle group has so far not received any directive to sail to the Taiwan Strait. "We instead have received an order to perform duties in the Persian Gulf.

The senior US naval officer said although Southeast Asia is a potential flashpoint, the situation in the area remains stable at the moment. Therefore, he said, the Constellation battle group will not stay in the region for long time.

The USS Constellation is the center of a battle group which consists of 10 ships and the air wing that is embarked with 71 airplanes. Within the group are also two cruisers, two destroyers, two submarines, as well as a replenishment ship, a Canadian ship and a US coast guard ship.
The Canadian ship is part of Canada's engagement with the United States to help enforce United Nations sanctions in the Persian Gulf, LaFleur said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA AIRWAYS FLIES FIRST ROC CHARTER TO NORTHEASTERN THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By F.C. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A charter plane of the Taiwan-based TransAsia Airways will fly more than 160 Thai workers working in Taiwan back to their hometowns in northeastern Thailand on vacation on Thursday.

It will be the first charter plane from Taiwan to northeastern Thailand since the two countries signed an aviation agreement last month, according to ROC Representative in Thailand Huang Hsien-yung, who added that the flight can be seen as a sign that TransAsia might operate scheduled flights to Thailand in the future.

The signing of the aviation agreement allows the two countries to increase flights and destinations between them, Huang said, stressing that bilateral ties have always been cordial, not only in the field of labor affairs but also in the trade and investment areas.

Huang also expressed the hope that the two countries will ink a labor cooperation accord as soon as possible to help secure greater benefits for Thai workers wishing to work in Taiwan, as the Republic of China government has been actively seeking to reduce the burden of brokerage fees for Thai workers.

Meanwhile, a Thai representative said the TransAsia charter for the vacationing Thai workers, allowing them to travel direct to their homes in the northeast instead of having to transit via Bangkok, is an indication that they have been well taken care of in Taiwan. Aug. 12 is the birthday of Thai Queen Sirikit, and is also Thailand's Mothers' Day, the representative added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION URGES GOVERNMENT TO SET UP INFORMATION SECURITY CENTER

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday urged the Executive Yuan to set up an "information warfare center" in order to protect the island's electronic networks.

In light of recent attacks by computer hackers on websites maintained by various Republic of China bodies, including the Control Yuan, Li Wen-chung (Taipei County) said at a press conference that it is easy for hackers to break into government websites and that if potential enemies launch a formal information war, the outcome would be "unthinkable."
Lin said he regarded the recent intrusions as just a prelude to an information war rather than a full-on attack.

Li also said that mainland China has put strong emphasis on its ability to wage information warfare since 1985, and has been building up its resources and strategies. According to assessments, he went on, mainland China will be able to intimidate Taiwan in this regard by 2005.

He said possible targets will include finance, aviation management, electricity, telecommunications, and even government administration. The government should not undervalue the powerful impact which would be caused by such an information war, he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT EXPLAINS `SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' TO US GUESTS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday reiterated on Wednesday that his description of cross-strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship" is no more than a reflection of the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are equal.
The sooner this equality is acknowledged, the sooner the two sides can conduct dialogue and negotiations on issues including political disputes, Lee said.
He stressed that "we shall never accept" Beijing's claims that Taiwan is a local province of mainland China, or the "one country two systems" formula espoused by the mainland authorities.

Lee made the remarks during a meeting with a visiting group of US Congress representatives headed by Edwin Feulner, the president of the Washington-based think tank, the Heritage Foundation, at the Presidential Office.

Other members of the delegation include House Representatives Sam Johnson (R-Texas), Bill Barrett (R-Nebraska), Charles T. Canady (R-Florida), Ernest Istook (R-Oklahoma) and Van Hilleary (R-Tennessee).

During the meeting, Lee explained that he made the declaration on cross-strait relations during an interview on July 9 by the German Deutsche Welle radio station when the reporter asked about mainland China's view of Taiwan as a "renegade province."

As leader of the ROC, Lee said, with the duty of defending the sovereign rights and interests of the country and people, he had to give a clearly defined answer to the question. The "special state-to-state relationship" statement, he said, refers to a fact which is undeniable from either the historical or the legal point of view.

The president stressed that he is obliged to declare the fact of the ROC's existence in the international community, a fact which he said has been submerged by false propaganda from Beijing, which defines "one China" as the People's Republic of China.
The claim neglects the fact that the ROC exists as a sovereign state, and has pushed the ROC into a dead-end position in its struggle for survival in the international community, Lee said.
After the meeting, the 16-member delegation called on National Defense Minister Tang Fei to exchange views on cross-strait relations.
During the 50-minute meeting, Feulner said he acknowledged and understands the ROC's determination to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Tang said the ROC military monitors every movement of its mainland Chinese counterpart, and stressed that the ROC military is basing its actions on the principles of "no provocation, no sparking of conflicts, and minimizing hostility."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINSTREAM US MEDIA SUPPORT 'STATE-TO-STATE' CONCEPT

TEXT.P: Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said on Wednesday that foreign news media have given extensive coverage to Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" theory.

"Since President Lee defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a 'special state-to-state relationship' in an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station in July, foreign news publications have carried more than 1,200 articles on the topic," Chen said in a report delivered at a weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee.
Quoting an analysis by the Government Information Office (GIO), Chen said the contents of all those articles cover a broad range of issues.
Chen said several mainstream US newspapers, such as the Wall Street Journal and the Washington Post, have expressed explicit support for the ROC's stance on its relations with mainland China.

The GIO director-general said foreign news reports and commentaries on the issue focus on the contents of Lee's political declaration, the timing and motivation of the unveiling of the definition, and the possible impact on Taiwan of the declaration.

Chen said the GIO has also stepped up its publicity campaign based on Lee's interview, Premier Vincent Siew's "three no changes" statement issued following Lee's declaration, position papers released by the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the Mainland Affairs Council.

"The GIO has ordered its staff members stationed abroad to send letters to major newspapers in their resident countries, or write special articles and give interviews to make comprehensive, direct explanations of the ROC's stance on cross-strait relations," Chen said.
According to Chen, 50-plus articles and letters to editors contributed by overseas GIO officials have so far been published by foreign newspapers.
An article written by Chen himself, titled "Taiwan Merely Affirmed Current Reality," appeared in the Aug. 6 issue of the influential Los Angeles Times.
Chen stressed in the article that President Lee's reference to a "special state-to-state relationship" does not signal a change in the ROC's mainland policy.

President Lee's "state-to-state" definition has angered Beijing authorities which have launched saber-rattling against Taiwan and even increased sorties in the skies over the Taiwan Strait in recent weeks.

In the face of mainland China's furious reaction, Chen said the GIO will further intensify its international publicity campaign to help more people around the world understand Taiwan's diplomatic plight and win their support for the ROC's national cause.

The career diplomat-turned-GIO chief said the publicity campaign will focus on three themes: highlighting mainland China's irrational reaction to the "special state-to-state" theory, its constant squeeze of the ROC's international space by distorting facts, and the ROC's desire and capability to take part in international activities as well as its possible contributions to the world society through such programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, MOTC REFUTE ACCUSATION OF POLITICAL MEDDLING

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on Wednesday refuted that politics had been involved in CAL's aircraft purchase plan.

CAL stressed that its decision to buy passengers jets from Airbus had previously passed a series of flight security evaluations and had received the approval of the company's board of directors in June, in denying the accusation the purchase was in retaliation for the US' preferential attitude toward mainland China after President Lee Teng-hui redefined the Taiwan-mainland relationship as a "special state-to-state relationship".
CAL signed a purchase contract with Boeing to buy 13 cargo planes on Wednesday afternoon. On Thursday CAL will sign another contract with Airbus for a fleet of passenger jets.

In an attempt to further understand how CAL reached it decision, legislators from the opposition New Party (NP) on Wednesday morning invited Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Chang Chia-juch, Deputy Director General Chang Kuo-cheng of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) and CAL General Manager Liu Ko-yia to a breakfast meeting.
NP's deputy caucus whip Feng Hu-hsiang questioned the reason for the change, while legislator Lee Ching-hwa warned the switch could deteriorate the US-Taiwan relationship.

Chang Kuo-cheng categorically denied the meddling accusation, saying the CAA neither took part in the company's decision-making process nor required CAL to buy aircraft from specific countries. Chang added that CAL has to pass a CAA flight security inspections before it is granted a permit to import newly-purchased aircraft.

Chang explained that after last year's fatal crash in Taoyuan, the CAA ordered CAL to simplify its aircraft models and forbid any new aircraft to be purchased before CAL's flight security and business performance improved.
Chang noted that the CAA lifted the CAL purchase ban July 2, several days prior to President Lee's "special state-to-state relationship" redefinition on July 9.
CAL then briefed the purchase plane to the MOTC on mid July.
However, legislators questioned the briefing date, arguing that the briefing occurred after Lee stated his "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
Legislators also questioned CAL why the company sided with the European aviation company after Airbus aircraft were involved in two major CAL crashes.
MOTC officials confirmed the CAL purchase decision was approved on June 28 by CAL board members and had not been altered since.

CAL General Manager Liu Ko-yia pointed out that CAL, a private corporation, had not received political pressure and that Airbus aircraft are not blamed for the two fatal crashes since the cause of both tragedies is yet to be determined.
He further stressed that the CAL decision was based solely on the Airbus aircraft's reliability and security. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED PARK OPERATIONS UP 33.6% IN FIRST 6 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Business revenue from the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park reached NT$283.6 billion (US$8.83 billion) in the first six months of this year, an increase of 33.6 percent, a park official said on Wednesday.
Wang Kung, director of the park administration, said that if the upward trend continues at the same rate, the business revenue might break the NT$600 billion mark by the end of the year.
Wang noted that 284 companies are established in the park, employing more than 74,000 people, increases of 8 percent and 5 percent over the same period of last year, respectively.
During the same period, capital investment totaled NT$542.2 billion, up 28.8 percent.

In terms of industry, revenue from integrated circuit (IC) makers during the January-June period totaled NT$149.3 billion, accounting for 5 percent of the park's total production, an increase of 39 percent compared with the year-earlier level.
Computer and peripherals totaled NT$97 billion, accounting for 34 percent of the park's total business, up 29.5 percent.

Revenue from opto-electronics manufacturers totaled NT$19.1 billion, representing 6.7 percent of the total business, up 22.4 percent, while telecommunications income totaled NT$15.8 billion, accounting for 5.5 percent of the park's total business incomes, up 27.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAL CHAIRMAN REVEALS TAIPEI-MANILA AVIATION RIGHT TALKS BASIS

TEXT.P: The chairman of the board of directors of Philippine Airways (PAL) said on Wednesday that upcoming talks between PAL, China Airlines, and Eva Airways will be limited to clarifying the third and the fourth aviation rights and a 5,000 person per week quota while revoking the fifth and the sixth freedom rights.

The third and fourth aviation rights only permit air carriers to land and carry passengers between Taipei and Manila. the fifth and sixth freedom rights permit the air carriers to extend their service to third destinations.

Lucio Tan, however, said that the employment of the fifth and the sixth rights will not surpass the passenger load by 2 or 3 percent. If both sides reach a mutual understanding, up to 5 percent is acceptable, he said.
The current weekly quota is 9,600 passengers.
Tan accused CAL and Eva Air of employing the fifth and sixth freedom rights to take away passengers from Philippine Airlines. He labeled the practice of the two Taiwan air carriers as "unfair".
He stressed that the aviation right talks have nothing to do with politics. He hoped that the talks would begin soon as PAL could not afford a financial loss.
Tan said that PAL is losing 20 million pesos a day or approximately 700 million pesos per month. Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL AEROSPACE EXHIBIT TO OPEN THURSDAY

TEXT.P: The 1999 Taipei Aerospace Technology Exhibition (TATE) is scheduled to open on Thursday at Taipei's World Trade Center.

The exhibition is co-sponsored by Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council, the British Reed exhibition company, the Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the Association of Taiwan Aerospace Industry.
Fifty-five domestic manufacturers, units and 42 foreign manufacturers will display their products during the exhibition.
As part of the four-day exhibition, an exhibition of indigenous defensive fighters (IDF) and helicopters will be held on Saturday and Sunday at the Taoyuan Airbase in northern Taiwan.

The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has called off the demonstration of Mirage-2000, F-16 fighters and Thunder Tiger stunt flying groups that was originally on the exhibition agenda. Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming said the cancellation had nothing to do with the renewed tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The MND ordered exhibition organizers last week to cancel the three stunt shows. It is believed that the MND decided to call off the Mirage-2000, F-16 fighters and Thunder Tiger stunts because their exhibitions would conflict with the fly-past activities over the Air Force Academy during the academy's 70th anniversary on Saturday.

On Saturday there will be shuttle buses to the Taoyuan Airbase leaving from Taipei's Sungshan airport, the World Trade Center, the Taipei Railway Station, the Panchiao Railway Station, the Taoyuan Railway Station, the Hsinchu Railway Station and the Taichung Railway Station.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH COURT SENTENCES THREE MAINLANDERS TO DEATH FOR MURDER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court on Wednesday handed down a death sentence after the fourth retrial of three mainlanders convicted of homicide, intimidation and abandonment of body.
The mainlanders -- Cho Changjen, Shih Xiaoning and Jiang Hongchun -- were convicted of murdering Wang Chun-chieh in Tamsui in suburban Taipei in August 1991.

The financially-troubled defendants induced Wang to Cho's Tamsui home, by saying they wanted to make a land deal with him. When Wang arrived he was murdered and his body abandoned in Taoyuan. Afterwards, the trio were paid NT$50 million in ransom from Wang's family.

The three mainlanders had previously been sentenced to death, once by the Taoyuan District Court and four times by the Taiwan High Court. The death sentence had also been handed down after three previous retrials by the high court all under the charges of kidnapping for ransom and homicide.

At the advise of the Supreme Court, the Taiwan High Court conducted the fourth retrial, and changed the charges against the defendants to homicide, intimidation and attempt to ransom and abandonment of body.
The three mainlanders failed to appear in the court during the fourth retrial.

The father of the victim, Wang Yu-ming, told the media gathered at the court after the trial that he agreed with the high court's verdict. (By Victor Lai) EDITERM ZCZC CEP033 08-11-99 MND CAUTIONS PUBLIC NOT TO BELIEVE SENSATIONAL REPORTS

Taipei, Aug. 11 (CNA) The Ministry of National Defense (MND) cautioned the public on Wednesday against believing unverified reports from Hong Kong which, the ministry said, aim at escalating tension across the Taiwan Strait.

The ministry aired the caution in response to reports Wednesday in a Hong Kong newspaper that Beijing leaders huddled in Beidaihe, Hebei Province, have decided to punish Taiwan for its deviation from the "one China Policy" by forcibly seizing a Taiwan-controlled frontline island.
While downplaying the reports, the ministry refused to comment on them other than saying that it would keep a close watch on military activity across the Taiwan Strait.

However, the MND said the Hong Kong mass media often carries unconfirmed reports about PLA military activity with the purpose of aiding Beijing in scaring the Taiwan public and disrupting local stability.
Calling the techniques "psychological warfare", the MND urged the public not to be influenced by misleading information.
In addition to monitoring Beijing's military movements across the Taiwan Strait, the MND said it will investigate the Hong Kong reports and then inform the public.

Emphasizing that the armed forces have the capability to keep abreast of enemy activity, the MND said the troops stationed on the two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu remain on ordinary alert, and are being allowed to take leave as usual.
Besides increasing air and sea reconnaissance, the ministry said there has been no upgrade of military readiness on the two islands.
In an unrelated event, Gen. Chen Cheng-hsiang, Commander-in-Chief of Army, arrived in Kinmen on Tuesday to inspect military units there amid mounting tension between Taiwan and mainland China.

Gen. Chen, a former chief commander of troops on Kinmen, told reporters accompanying him that his trip was business as usual and there was no unusual activity whatsoever on the other side of the Taiwan strait. He said that "everything is all right".

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WINS CENTRAL AMERICAN SUPPORT
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China earned solid support from its six Central American allies in its bid to join international organizations during the Ministerial Conference of the Mixed ROC-Central American Commission of Cooperation on Tuesday.

The one-day conference concluded after foreign ministers from the ROC, El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, and Belize signed a joint communique promoting broader cooperation among themselves.

The communique also stated the need for enhancing trade and investment between Taiwan and its Latin American allies. The document also revealed that the seven countries will conduct a leadership summit in Taipei on September 7, 1999 to more thoroughly discuss issues of mutual concern.

During the San Jose conference the ROC announced it will provide US$21 million in aid to Central America for disaster relief and prevention, trade and investment promotion, as well as improved education and infrastructure development.
Taiwan also pledged its support for increased human rights in the Latin American area by promising funds for a proposed Court of Human Rights.

Since 1992, the ROC has offered a total of US$72 million in aid to Central America and some Caribbean countries, while investing US$150 million into the Bank of Central America, according to ROC Foreign Minister Jasan Hu.

Taiwan has sent 15 technical missions, comprised of 130 experts and 19 overseas volunteer workers, to its allies in the Latin America and the Caribbean area to help with local economic development, Hu said. He added that cooperation between ROC and Central America is mutually beneficial and permanent.

In addition, Hu explained to his Latin American counterparts ROC President Lee Teng-hui's recent redefinition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship." He said that Lee's statement clarifies for the international community the fact that the two sides across the Taiwan Strait are two equal and sovereign bodies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AVIATION COMPANIES TO SIGN STRATEGIC TECHNOLOGICAL ALLIANCES
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Elizabeth Hsu) (By Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 11 (CNA): The Industrial Development Bureau of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, French Thomson CSF and Snecma, one of the manufacturers of the Mirage fighter jets will sign a three-party industrial cooperation accord during the 1999 Taipei Aerospace Technology Exhibition on Thursday at Taipei's World Trade Center.

In addition, the aerospace and electronic section of the Institute for Information Industry (III) and several local aerospace industry makers will sign a strategic alliance pact with the German Becker Company.

At the same time, the American Aeronautical Instrument & Radio Corp. will enter into a cooperative agreement with the Industry Technology Research Institute's Electronic Section. Under the cooperative program, both sides will conduct research and develop maintenance and remodeling plans for navigation systems.
The signing of the three agreements will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center on Thursday with Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming acting as witness.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REAR ADMIRAL WARNS PRC NOT TO TAKE ACTION AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Rear Admiral Timothy J. Keating of the US Navy's 7th Fleet said on Wednesday that the People's Republic of China should refrain from taking any military action against Taiwan.
He made the remarks while answering a CNA question at a press conference held aboard the aircraft carrier "Kitty Hawk" in waters adjacent to Pattaya.

Keating said Beijing must consider "very carefully" before it takes actions violating the "Taiwan principle," because the US military power is larger than China's and Washington is ready to take prompt counter-actions.

The "Kitty Hawk," equipped with some 70 various types of jet fighters, will depart for Japan's Yokosuka Harbor via northern Taiwan and the public seas after concluding its visit to Thailand on Aug. 15.
The rear admiral pointed out that the United States thinks Beijing will understand that the appearance of an aircraft carrier in the region will effect stability.

He went on to say that China will come to know that if they take military action against Taiwan or other areas, they will encounter the US military, which is powerful in its number of personnel, training and war preparedness.
Tension has escalated across the Taiwan Strait since ROC President Lee Teng-hui redefined Taiwan's relations with the mainland as a "special state-to-state relationship" in early July.
Jet fighters from both sides of the strait have increased their patrol sorties, and on some occasions mainland Chinese fighters have crossed over the center line of the strait.

The US has asked mainland China and Taiwan to exercise self-restraint, and reiterated its desire for the two sides to resolve their differences through peaceful dialogue. (By Kuo Fang-chin & Victor Lai) EDITERM ZCZC CEP037 08-11-99 LIEN ENDORSED BY 97% KMT DELEGATES

Taipei, Aug. 11 (CNA) Vice President Lien Chan was endorsed on Wednesday by 2,119, or 97.2 percent of all Kuomintang delegates to be nominated the party's presidential candidate during this month's party congress.
At Wednesday's deadline for would-be party candidates to submit their lists of sponsors, Lien had collected signature from 2.119 party delegates, including President Lee Teng-hui.
Lien's total was higher than the 1,700 sponsors President Lee attracted when he vied for the party's nomination in the 1996 presidential election, said Huang.

Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who has vowed to enter the race as an independent candidate, received three sponsors, KMT Secretary General John Chang got two while another party delegate sponsored himself.

The result ensured that Lien will be the lone valid KMT nominee when the party holds its congress on August 29. The purpose of the party congress will be to officially nominate the KMT candidate for next spring's election.
Lien acknowledged the party delegates' support after being informed of the results.
In a statement released through the his office, Lien vowed to do his best to win the election.
Soong and former Kaohsiung City Mayor Wu Den-yih, who has never declared his support for Lien, was the only two KMT Standing Central Committee members who didn't sponsor Lien's candidacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL SIGNS PLANE PROCUREMENT AGREEMENT WITH BOEING CO.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) on Wednesday signed an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.

CAL also announced it has decided to purchase five B737-800 passenger aircraft with option for four more B747-400 cargo planes and two more B747-400 passenger jets at a cost estimated at US$1.3 billion.

Fred Howard, head of Boeing's operation in Asia, said he hopes CAL would continue to purchase planes from Boeing, adding that Boeing would not abandon its efforts to promote the sale of its B777 jetliners to CAL.
He said Boeing respects CAL's decision to switch to Airbus for the purchase of a number of passenger aircraft and declared that the Seattle-based company is satisfied with CAL's procurement plan.
The ceremony was held at the Sherwood Taipei in the afternoon with CAL's Deputy General Manager Chou Kuo-hsing and Fred Howard jointly signing the agreement.
CAL Board Chairman Chiang Hung-yi, General Manager Liu Ke-ya and several high ranking Boeing executives witnessed the ceremony.

Chiang said at a news conference following the signing that CAL had mapped out an aircraft fleet renovation plan last year. According to the plan, CAL will buy 19 new passenger jets and 17 B747-400 cargo planes over the next few years at an estimated cost of US$5.6 billion.
CAL will also sign an agreement with France's Airbus Industrie on Thursday confirming the purchase of passenger jets, mainly A330 and A340, for an estimated US$1.8 billion.
Despite Boeing's promotion of its B777 jetliners to CAL, the company decided to buy the French planes.

Liu denied speculation that CAL switched part of its order of passenger jets from Beoing to Airbus because Taiwan was not satisfied with Washington's attitude toward Taiwan's "special state-to-state" theory on cross-Taiwan Strait relations. Liu stressed that CAL made the purchase after reviewing its financial ability, market situation and plan to streamline its air fleet.

DOC.TEXT:

The Taiwan News:
'Don't worry,' Lee tells Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NOT BACKING ANY MACEDONIAN PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is not taking sides as Macedonia prepares for a presidential election and will continue to render assistance to the Balkan country as long as the election results are beneficial to the Macedonian people, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said on Thursday.
Macedonia is scheduled in late August to announce the official date of the election.

Chen said the ROC government believes that the result of the presidential election will be in the best interests of the Macedonian people and would be delighted to see even closer relations between the ROC and Macedonia in light of the election.
He said the ROC rules of diplomacy forbid the government from backing any foreign presidential candidate. Chen emphasized that the rules include Macedonia.
Macedonia established formal diplomatic relations with the ROC in January of this year, becoming Taiwan's second diplomatic ally in Europe in addition to the Vatican.
