DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON'S APPEASEMENT OF CHINA CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration's unwillingness, and thus failure, to abandon its predecessors' policy of cuddling Communist China and proceeding with a policy of appeasing Beijing will never succeed in deterring expansionist dictatorships as the West failed to deter Adolf Hitler's Germany, according to the editor of the American Journal of Strategic Studies.

Amos Perlmutter, a professor of political science and sociology at American University, wrote in The Washington Times Wednesday that "the only wise act on the part of the American administration has been to enhance Taiwan's strategic and security status by selling them the F-16," he said.

The tension between the United States, the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China on Taiwan is mounting. "We do not expect a repetition of the 1996 military confrontation over the Taiwan Strait, but the risk for escalation is still in place," said the professor in an article titled "Taiwan cliffhanger closer to the edge?"

Perlmutter accused the Clinton administration of kowtowing to the world's chief violator of human rights, the PRC, while the United States conducted a "humanitarian war" in Kosovo. The conflict between the PRC and the ROC "calls for a clear, courageous, and determined policy on the part of the United States, he said.

The professor added that President Bill Clinton can no longer oscillate between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, but he does not expect Clinton to call for a different policy toward China because, as James Mann's book "About Face" shows, the US policy has been to cuddle the PRC since the Nixon-Kissinger regime was in power.

But Perlmutter pointed out that the price of appeasing Communist China, despite the recently invigorated US-Japanese strategic alliance, is indeed high. Mainland China is surrounded by unfriendly countries, which recognize its importance but are unwilling to submit to its aspirations. This is true of Russia, Japan, and above all India, Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore.

"None of these has great love for the PRC. The United States has a unique role to lead these nations in a balance of power arrangement to help de-escalate the PRC's expansionist aspirations," said Perlmutter.

He stressed that the relationship with Taiwan is fundamental here, because "there is no reason in the world to appease and kowtow to China as if it is the single dominant hegemon in East Asia. Mr. Clinton's shameful retreat from his declared human rights policy in China is not a tactical, but a strategic, error. China should be treated as an economic and political competitor and rival, not a strategic partner."

Beijing's effort to absorb Taiwan the way it did Hong Kong must be halted. In view of the coming presidential election in Taiwan, President Lee Teng-hui and his governing KMT are obviously asserting themselves on the issue of their relationship with the PRC, wrote Perlmutter.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ACTIONS CONFIRM US CONGRESSIONAL FINDINGS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA): Communist China's recent test-firing of a long-range ballistic missile, its admission that it has the neutron bomb, and its announcement that it would test a new submarine-launched ballistic missile sometime this year have all validated the findings of a US congressional select committee report on the PRC espionage.

The House Select Committee on US National Security and Military/Commercial Concerns with the People's Republic of China said in a Cox report update published Tuesday that "Events since the release of the select committee report have confirmed some of its most disturbing conclusions about the PRC espionage threat facing the United States, the weakness of our efforts to counter it, and the threats to our national security that have resulted from it."

"With the stolen US technology, the PRC has leaped, in a handful years, from 1950s-era strategic nuclear capabilities to the more modern thermonuclear weapons designs," according to the Cox report. Events of the past months bear this out, stressed the select committee report update.

Since the bipartisan committee, led by Rep. Chris Cox (R-CA), published its report on May 25, the PRC has announced the successful test-launch of the Dong-feng 31, a ballistic missile capable of delivering nuclear warheads to Alaska, Hawaii and parts of western United States.
The PRC announced in June that sometime this year it would test a new submarine-launched ballistic missile with a 7,500-mile range, a development that was predicted in the Cox report.

In July, the Chinese Communists admitted for the first time that their army had developed a neutron bomb, confirming the predictions of the Cox Committee. The committee also reported the 1996 finding of the US intelligence community that the PRC stole neutron bomb technology from a US national nuclear weapons laboratory.

The Cox report, approved by all nine members of the committee's Republican and Democratic members, added that the PRC had "stolen classified information on every thermonuclear warhead in the US ballistic missile arsenal, including the W-88, our most modern warhead."

"Despite repeated PRC thefts of the most sophisticated nuclear weapons technology, security at our national nuclear weapons labs does not meet even minimal standards and will not be satisfactory until sometime in the year 2000," said the report.

But the Cox committee noted in the update that since its report was published in May, "Congress has moved decisively to implement some of the select committee report's most important recommendations, strengthening our counterespionage program and protecting our national security. In the coming months, Congress will finish the job."

DOC.HEADLINE: ANALYSTS AGREE CHINA ATTACK ON TAIWAN WOULD HARM ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung) (By Nelson Chung) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA): Business people on both sides of the Taiwan Straits are anxiously watching to see how events develop across the strait, and they agreed that if Taiwanese companies are forced to leave mainland China, the level and quality of economic growth on the mainland will take a turn for the worse, reported the Voice of America Wednesday.

The US government-funded radio reported from Hong Kong that the rising tensions between Beijing and Taipei are putting billions of dollars in cross-strait trade and investment at risk, because Taiwan's role as a financial lifeline for mainland China could result in economic fall-out from the political conflict.
In the two decades since Beijing began to reform its economy, Taiwanese businesses have invested more than US$30 billion in mainland China, according to the report.

A Hong Kong-based analyst with the investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Andy Xie, told the VOA that Beijing has created a friendly business atmosphere for Taiwanese companies, which are much more concerned about profits than politics. But while some China watchers say Beijing will go to great lengths to protect these lucrative ties, Mr. Xie said they could become a casualty of war.

He was quoted as saying, "China will encourage investment. China will go out of its way to assure the safety and protection of Taiwanese businesses in China just like last time during the military exercises (in 1996).....But in terms of this assumption that China will not go to war because of concern about the economy, that is absolutely wrong."

"China has gone to war many times before, despite catastrophic consequences for the economy," noted Mr. Xie, adding "The modern history of China is based on national unification, and there is no doubt that China will go all the way."

The VOA continued that the potential for mainland Chinese economic sanctions against Taiwan or other actions that would deter Taiwanese investment comes at a difficult time for mainland China's stalling economy, since the country is in the grip of a deflationary spiral due to a glut of goods and reluctant consumers.

Mr. Xie said the on going deterioration of the mainland Chinese economy is a concern for Taiwan-based financiers, and as a result they have cut their investments there by more than 30 percent in the first half of this year.

Frederick Poon, a China economist for the investment house ABN Amro, told the VOA that Beijing hopes to attract more funds from Taiwan in the second half of 1999. But he is also convinced that if necessary, Communist China will put the issue of unification ahead of its financial interests.

"Maintaining economic ties with Taiwan is an important factor in the Chinese authorities' consideration of the relationship with Taiwan, but I do not think we can preclude the possibility that if Taiwan declares independence, China would not hesitate to go into war, even at the expense of the economic relationship," said Poon.

The VOA reported that the potential losses for mainland China are undeniable, since Taiwanese investment in southern China has financed an unprecedented boom. Taiwan investors have built countless factories across the provinces of Guangdong and Fujian, providing thousands of jobs, job training and exposure to new technology. Taiwan is also currently mainland China's fifth biggest trading partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER HUMAN SMUGGLING ATTEMPT STOPPED IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Canadian authorities have seized another ship carrying a human cargo of would-be immigrants off the coast of British Columbia.

About 150 people were dumped off the ship and onto the beach at Gilbert Bay, in the Queen Charlotte Islands Wednesday afternoon. The captain and the crew of the ship then tried to race back to sea to avoid capture. The boat was hailed by a military plane and told to turn back. Canadian police then boarded the suspicious ship. Police said pre-teen children are among the illegal immigrants. Police had not confirmed their nationality but noted they "may be from China."
Canadian authorities believed the mystery ship was carrying another load of migrants hoping to bypass immigration rules.

Immigration Minister Elinor Caplan made the announcement of the seizure at a news conference in Ottawa. Caplan said she deplored the smuggling of humans and hinted she may introduce changes to Canada's immigration laws to prevent such activities in the future.

The newly-appointed minister said the government would take "appropriate action" against the ship's captain. "We have the authority to warn the captain of the consequences of bringing people illegally into Canada. If the warnings are not heeded, we will vigorously use all legal revenues," she said.
Three weeks ago, a similar vessel arrived in B.C. It was smuggling 123 Chinese nationals. After entering Canada illegally, they claimed refugee status.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA GOV'T SEEN RAISING ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, Aug. 12 (CNA): The Australian government is expected to raise its economic growth rate for fiscal 1999-2000, bringing it closer to the prediction made by private sector economists, the Australian Financial Review reported on Thursday.

The daily reported Federal Treasurer Peter Costello has signalled an upgrade in the current year when he told Parliament on Wednesday, saying Australia's growth rate would slow to "the threes rather than the fours" in late 1999, but pick up again during the first half of 2000. The government has set its gross domestic product growth for the current year at 3 percent. Private economists predicted the growth at 3.5 percent. Costello said: "During the course of 1999-2000, we would expect some slowdown on a 4.8 percent growth rate (recorded during the 12 months to the end of March 1999), more to levels we have seen in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 12, or the second day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, American film director, is born. He is legendary for large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol, ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four-cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War is pulling out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of an illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non-aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes on a mountain on it way from Hualien to Taipei, killing and injuring a total of 31 people.
1971: Syria severs diplomatic relations with Jordan after a conflict between the government and Palestinian guerrillas.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tienanmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, 750 injured and 3,000 detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear tests.
1996: Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS MOST PEOPLE SUPPORT 'SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY

TEXT.P: Most Taiwan people support President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relationship" theory, according to the results of a recent public opinion poll released on Thursday.

The telephone survey of randomly selected adult residents throughout the island was conducted by Focus Survey Research Co. at the request of Global Broadcasting Co. and the Journalist news weekly from Aug. 5-6. A total of 1,130 valid replies were collected.

Survey results show that 54.7 percent of the respondents agree to President Lee's definition of relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship," while 24.5 percent nix said they disagree with the concept.

President Lee's reference to the "special state-to-state" theory during an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station on July 9 has drawn furious reaction from Beijing, including saber-rattling.
According to the poll, 63 percent said they think mainland China's strong reaction is not reasonable, compared to 19.1 percent who said Beijing's protest is reasonable.
Asked whether they think President Lee is a trustworthy national leader, 61 percent said "Yes," while 27.1 percent said they don't trust the president.
As for Taiwan's current security situation, 54.7 percent said they feel Taiwan remains a safe place to live despite the current cross-strait row, but 36.3 percent said they feel Taiwan is unsafe.

Among the four hopefuls for the next presidency, 48.4 percent said they think that Vice President Lien Chan is most likely to follow President Lee's "special state-to-state" theory if he is elected president next year; 20.9 percent chose Chen Shui-bian, the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate; 3.5 percent selected James Soong, a former Taiwan governor who has announced his intention to run for the presidency even without the ruling Kuomintang's blessing; and only a marginal 0.2 percent chose independent presidential candidate Hsu Hsin-liang.

Turning to the issue related to Taiwan's future, 39.6 percent of those interviewed said they prefer to see Taiwan declare independence; 25.7 percent opt for unification with mainland China; and 19.9 percent want to maintain the status quo forever.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PUSHING FOR UN BID WITH EXPLANATORY MEMO

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is taking a new approach to regaining United Nations membership this year by using an explanatory memorandum to clarify Taiwan's redefinition of cross-strait relations.

In the explanatory memorandum, the ROC government emphasizes the fact that each side of the Taiwan Strait has been ruled by a distinct and separate government since 1949, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee said at a press conference on Thursday.

The government of the Republic of China, which was founded in 1912, moved to Taiwan in 1949. That same year, the people's Republic of China was established on the Chinese mainland, according to the memo.

Since then, the Republic of China on Taiwan and the People's Republic of China on the mainland have coexisted on their respective sides of the Taiwan Strait, with neither subject to the other's rule, the memo said.

"Over that past half century, each side has developed its own political system, social values and foreign relations. Therefore, each of these two governments can only speak for and represent the people actually under its jurisdiction on its side of the Taiwan Strait," it continued.

It was the first time that Taipei in a formal statement mentioned both the governments of the ROC and the PRC, in an effort to highlight the equity of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. The explanation fully reflects the spirit of President Lee Teng-hui's "state-to-state" concept on the current cross-strait relations, Lee added.

Quoting the memo, Lee said the ROC, a country with significant achievements, is a constructive and responsible member of the international community. Lee added that Taiwan has recently pledged an aid package equivalent to US$300 million for humanitarian assistance to Kosovar refugees and Balkan area reconstruction.
The memo stated that the Republic of China is a free and democratic country. The United Nations should consider with an open mind the appeal of its 22 million people for UN epresentation.

The participation of the Republic of China on Taiwan in the United Nations poses no barrier to the future peaceful and democratic unification of a divided China; indeed, it can be conducive to regional peace and security, it continued.
The United Nations General Assembly should act to ensure that the voice of the 22 million people on Taiwan is heard in the United Nations and its related organizations, it stated.

In changing from past methods to regain UN membership, this year Taipei has asked the UN General Assembly to establish a working group with the mandate of examining thoroughly the exceptional international situation pertaining to the ROC on Taiwan. The working group's examination will ensure that Taiwan's 22 million people participate, with a direct and representative voice in the UN, according to Lee.

Taipei has asked the UN General Assembly to establish the working group in consideration of the fact that the 22 million people of the ROC on Taiwan have no actual and legitimate representative in the United Nations and to recognize that since 1949 the ROC government has exercised effective control and jurisdiction over the Taiwan area while the PRC government has exercised effective control and jurisdiction over the Chinese mainland during the same time period, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, US COMPANY TO COOPERATE IN AERONAUTICAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS

TEXT.P: A strategic alliance cooperative agreement aimed at promoting bilateral cooperation in aeronautical telecommunications was signed on Thursday by US-based Aeronautical Instrument & Radio Corp. (AIRCO) and the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) of Taiwan.
The cooperation pact has been pushed for by the Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

AIRCO President Wilfrid H. Burke and a representative of ITRI's Electronics Research and Service Organization (ERSO), Hu Cheng-ta, jointly inked the agreement at a signing ceremony held at the Taipei World Trade Center and witnessed by MOEA Administrative Vice Minister Yin Chi-ming.
According to the accord, the pact covers:
-- maintenance of aeronautical telecommunications instruments;
-- research and develop in advanced liquid crystal display for aircraft; and
-- market expansion.

Founded in 1948 and headquartered in New Jersey, AIRCO has business branches in France, Germany and Portugal. Its main business range is aeronautical telecommunications products and wireless communications systems.

ERSO has in recent years actively assisted the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology under the Ministry of National Defense, as well as the armed forces in researching and developing techniques to produce important radar modules.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was quoted at 32.131 against the greenback on the Taipei market, dropping 1.3 cent.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.116, and had a low of 32.145. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$248.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI 1999 INT'L AEROSPACE SHOW OPENS

TEXT.P: A total of 96 local and foreign aerospace companies are attending the 1999 Taipei Aerospace Technology and National Defense Industry Exhibition, which opened Thursday, to demonstrate their innovative products and patented technologies.

There are 215 booths at the four-day show, which is taking place at the Taipei World Trade Center. France's Dassault Aviation and the United States' Bell are among the foreign companies attending, although the world's two leading aircraft makers -- Airbus Industrie and Boeing Co. -- are absent.

Products displayed at the exhibition include key aircraft parts and components, aircraft bodies, engines, modern testing and repair systems, defense equipment for military fighters and landing gear facilities for aircraft and spacecraft.

Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan attended the opening ceremony and delivered a speech, in which he called for local private businesses in the aviation and spacecraft manufacturing industries to link together to enhance international competitiveness.
Lien said the aerospace industry is among 10 key industries that the government is devoted to developing as part of its efforts to boost Taiwan's economy and improve its national competitiveness.

Since 1991, when the government formed the Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development to help develop the business, Taiwan's production output in the aerospace sector has increased each year.

At present, Lien said, there are 75 public and private companies involved in the aerospace business on the island, and those companies have a combined production capacity of US$2.17 billion this year.

The government has held an international air show every two years since 1991, inviting relevant manufacturers and research centers around the world to gather in Taiwan to discuss the future development of the high-tech industry and trade opportunities, Lien said.

As part of the last aerospace exhibition in Taiwan this century, a showing of indigenous defensive fighters and helicopters will take place Saturday and Sunday at the Taoyuan Airbase, northern Taiwan.

On Saturday, there will be shuttle buses to the airbase leaving from Taipei's Sungshan airport, the World Trade Center, the Taipei Railway Station, the Hsinchu Railway Station and the Taichung Railway Station.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ZOO PREPARES FOR KOALA COUPLE

TEXT.P: Patrick and Harley, two koalas that will meet the public at the Taipei Zoo starting Aug. 14, are expected to attract more than 70,000 people to the zoo this Saturday.

To prevent crowds of people from gathering in front of the koalas' area, zoo authorities have set up a tour route that will require visitors to see other animals first and keep traffic moving smoothly.
"We predict that there will be 70,000 or 80,000 people in the zoo on Saturday and more than 100,000 people on Sunday," said Yang Sheng-hsiung, the zoo's director.

"We have also prepared koala introduction pamphlets for our visitors and plan to build a 'koalas' shop,'" Yang said, adding, "People had better come to the zoo by subway or bus to avoid traffic jams or a lack of parking spaces."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, INDEX FUTURE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taipei share prices closed 1.4 percent higher Thursday due to strong buying by bargain hunters and an overnight advance on Wall Street.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 101.56 points to the close at 7,330.24 points, with a total of 2.59 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of 128.28 billion.

Among the eight categories, all sectors reported gains, with plastic and chemical shares posting the largest increase, 5.6 percent. The paper making sector rose 3.9 percent and textile shares were up 3.8 percent.

Construction issues gained 1.5 percent, followed by financial shares at 1.1 percent. Foodstuff shares closed 1 percent higher. Cement issues and electronics stocks enjoyed advances of 0.8 percent and 0.7 percent, respectively.
The over-the-counter market moved up 2.23 points to end at 162.31 points, on a turnover of 5.22 billion.
Meanwhile, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains, except for next June's futures, for which no contract transactions were registered.

TAIEX Index Futures for August moved up 86 points to close at 7,316 points, with 3,264 contract transactions; those for September advanced 105 points to finish at 7,330 points, with 610 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December rose 77 points to end at 7,330 points, with 19 contract transactions; those for Next March climbed 124 points to finish at 7,357 points, with 4 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures on Thursday were 7,230 points for August, 7,225 points for September, 7,253 points for December, 7,233 points for next March and 7,253 points for next June.

August electronics futures (TE) climbed 2.85 points to close at 334.9 points, with 13 contract transactions and financial futures (TF) rose 17.8 points to end at 1,033 points, with 146 contract transactions.
September TE futures were up 2.9 points, ending up the day at 334.8 points, with 1 contract transaction; September TF futures closed 35 points higher, with 146 contract transactions.
There were no transactions recorded for TE and TF futures for other months. (by Michelle Tseng)

DOC.HEADLINE: UN BID NEEDS 'CONSTANT HEAT AND DYNAMISM', SAYS VICE FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Seeking representation in the United Nations (UN) for the 22 million people of the Republic of China on Taiwan is one of the major parts of Taipei's long-term diplomatic strategy, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee said on Thursday.

Although efforts will not likely prove successful in the short term, the ROC's attempts to gain entry require constant "heat" and "dynamism" so that no chances to succeed are missed, Lee said at a press conference, during which the Ministry of Foreign Affairs made known the ROC's new approach to regaining UN membership.

According to Lee, 12 ROC diplomatic allies jointly presented a proposal to UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan early Thursday morning (Taipei time) to ask the UN General Assembly to establish a working group to examine the Republic of China's special situation in the international community so that the 22 million people in Taiwan can be represented in the United Nations and related organizations.

It is hoped that the Chinese mainland will treat Taiwan's UN bid based on a principle of equity, Lee said. "Some people may think the idea is too impractical, but Taiwan would not give up any opportunity to serve a goodwill ball to the opposite side's court," he added.

Lee said Taiwan's efforts to seek representation in the United Nations over the last six years have left the international community with a vivid impression. Nowadays, Taipei has revised its UN approach to more practical formulas in consideration of the fast-changing situation in the world, he added.

The proposal that a working committee be established to examine Taiwan's situation was submitted by Gambia, Swaziland, Liberia, Burkina Faso, Senegal, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Honduras.

For this the Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its most sincere gratitude to the allied governments and hopes that other nations around the world will join in the effort to signify the legitimacy of seeking representation in the United Nations for the government and the 22 million people in the Republic of China on Taiwan, he said.

The Republic of China was one of its founding members when the United Nations came into being in 1945. UN Resolution 2758, adopted by the 26th session of the UN General Assembly in 1971, forced the ROC to withdraw from the UN family to make way for the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF ASKS FEULNER TO CONVEY REGARDS TO TOP MAINLAND ENVOY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said on Thursday he has asked the head of a noted US think tank to convey regards to Wang Daohan, top mainland Chinese negotiator with Taiwan.

Su Chi, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said he has also asked Edwin Feulner, president of the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, to extend to Wang Taiwan's sincere welcome to his visit to the island this autumn.

Wang, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), a quasi-official intermediary body authorized by Beijing authorities to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence with official ties, was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan either in mid-September or mid-October. His visit, however, has become uncertain following ROC President Lee Teng-hui's reference to cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station on July 9.

Feulner, who and an 18-member US House of Representatives delegation left for Shanghai on Thursday after a brief visit to Taiwan, said he and many American congressmen hope to see Wang visit Taiwan as scheduled because Wang's visit is expected to help resume cross-strait dialogue and contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
Members of the House delegation included Sam Johnson (R-Texas), Bill Barrett (R-Neb.), Charles T. Canady (R-Fla.), Ernest Istook (R-Okla.) and Van Hilleary (R-Tenn.).

Some House members said when they meet Wang in Shanghai, they will ask mainland China's elder statesman if Beijing leaders cannot accept Lee's "special state-to-state" concept, "do they have a better solution?"
Su told Feulner and the House delegation that the Republic of China government has consistently welcomed Wang's visit to this island.

"We have been actively arranged for Wang's visit under the principles of safety, comfort, sincerity and constructiveness," Su said, adding he is convinced that the earlier the better for Wang's visit.
"Only through dialogue can the two sides find a common ground for their differences or disputes," Su stressed.

During their stay in Taipei, Feulner and US House members have met with President Lee, Premier Vincent Siew, National Security Council Secretary-General Yin Chung-wen, Defense Minister Tang Fei and other senior ROC officials to exchange views on matters of mutual concern, including the spirit of the "special state-to-state" theory and the ROC's policy toward mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PROMOTE EXCHANGES WITH GOODWILL: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China said Thursday that his government will continue promoting cross-strait consultations and seeking consensus with goodwill.

The government has always been practical in initiating, step by step, a new understanding concerning the interaction between Taiwan and mainland China, in hopes that the distance between the two sides' state of development would narrow for the benefit of all the people, Lee remarked.
He reiterated that the "special state-to-state" cross-strait relationship he brought up recently is based primarily on the necessity of protecting national interests and dignity.
Lee's remarks were made when he met with delegates of the regional 3490 Rotary Club.

Lee told the delegates that insuring the survival and development of the country has always been seen as his obligation since he became president 11 years ago, and to fulfill that responsibility his government must balance domestic issues, mainland issues and foreign affairs issues.
In regard to domestic issues, Lee said, the government has fared well in the pursuit of democracy while maintaining economic growth and social security, even during the Asian financial crisis.

As for the mainland issue, Lee pointed out that in 1991 the government took the initiative in demonstrating its goodwill by renouncing the use of force to reunify China, acknowledging Beijing's rule on the Chinese mainland, and replacing military confrontation with peaceful exchanges and dialogue. The establishment of the National Unification Council and the promulgation of the Guidelines for National Unification are concrete approaches to promote cross-strait exchanges, Lee added.

Lee stressed that the "special state-to-state relationship" statement was aimed at letting the international community understand the existence of the ROC. Only by highlighting the ROC's existence can the development of the ROC in the international community be possible, he continued.

As for the foreign affairs aspect of his responsibilities, Lee said that the government's endeavors to establish an international presence and national dignity represent the consensus of all the people in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WATCHING PANAMANIAN VICE PRESIDENT-ELECT'S MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Thursday it will keep a close watch on Panamanian Vice President-elect Arturo Vallarino's current visit to mainland China.
The ministry said Vallarino had informed the Republic of China government of his travel plan before his departure for the mainland.
According to the ministry, Vallarino is currently on a private visit to the mainland at the invitation of a private enterprise.

MOFA officials said Vallarino had received the invitation before he won the election earlier this year. "Vallarino had promised not to touch on any political topics during his mainland visit and to make a formal visit to Taiwan after his inauguration as Panamanian vice president," said a MOFA official.

Panama is one of the ROC's longtime diplomatic allies. Beijing has spared no effort to court Panama and other ROC allies to switch diplomatic allegiance in an attempt to isolate Taiwan in the international community.
Meanwhile, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said the United States should maintain an appropriate military force in the Asia-Pacific region.

Lee was responding to reports that Rear Admiral Timothy J. Keating, commander of the USS Kitty Hawk battle group, said in Pattaya on Wednesday that the berthing of two aircraft carriers of the US Seventh Fleet in Thailand and Singapore currently is not especially designed to cope with current tensions in the Taiwan Strait or the Korean peninsula.
Keating said USS Kitty Hawk will return to its base in Japan via the open sea off northern and eastern Taiwan coast after completing its training exercises with Thai navy.
Commenting on the reports, Lee said regional stability is very important.

"I think the United States should maintain a proper military force in East Asia to ensure regional stability and prosperity," Lee said, adding that the Taiwan Relations Act requires the United States to remain concerned about Taiwan's security.

The situation in the Taiwan Strait has strained since ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station in July. The definition has drawn a furious reaction from Beijing, which has consistently regarded Taiwan as a "renegade" province under its jurisdiction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR HOPING CITY'S ON-LINE POPULATION WILL SOON REACH 2M

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou expressed his hope on Thursday that his city's on-line population will reach 2 million by the end of 2002.
Ma made the remark in a webcast speech at the opening ceremony for a cross-century information application summit being held at a coastal resort near Taipei.
He said Taipei City is now striving for the establishment of a "new web city," with the hope of reaching the target on-line population by the time Ma's tenure expires in 2002.

Ma claimed that the city is well qualified to become "new web city." However, he added, the current on-line population of the metropolis is just 700,000, or one-quarter of the city's total population.

In addition to the small on-line population, he also admitted that the lack of software is another shortcoming for the city's information industry, and urged local manufacturers in the information industry to continue their efforts to improve the situation.

In order to push for the establishment of the "new web city," the Taipei City Government has earmarked NT$4.6 billion for the purpose, he went on, adding that of the sum, NT$1.3 billion will be used to upgrade the computer equipment in primary and junior high schools.
Meanwhile, the city government also plans to set up 800 public computers at public sites by the end of 2002 to allow Taipei citizens to go on-line at any time.

According to the mayor, some manufacturers are willing to provide free e-mail to every Taipei citizen, and he reiterated a promise he made while seeking office last year to give each Taipei citizen three hours of free on-line service.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL SIGNS PROCUREMENT AGREEMENT WITH AIRBUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) on Thursday signed an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
The procurement agreement accounted for 32 percent of the orders placed by CAL over the last two days as part of its efforts to renew its aging fleet.

Meanwhile, CAL Chairman Chiang Hung-yi broke his silence on his company's decision to switch part of its order for passenger jets from the Boeing Co. to Airbus, explaining that the change was made to speed up the company's fleet renewal.

Hung said that although Boeing's B777 series planes and Airbus' A330s and A340s all meet CAL's operational needs, the B777s, Boeing's modern long-range jetliners, are twin-engine aircraft. This means that if the company wants to use the planes for its long-haul routes, it must wait at least one year for flight permission under civil aviation laws.

CAL originally signed a letter of intent with Boeing to purchase 12 B777s in 1995, but dropped out of the deal because of the urgency of the need to replace old airplanes to improve business competitiveness, Hung said.
He added that the company decided to buy the four-engine A340s because the one-year wait for approval is not required for these planes.
Hung said the A340-300 jets will be used on inter-continental flights, while the A330s, which are also twin-engine jets, will ply Asian and middle-distance routes.

CAL on Wednesday signed an agreement with Boeing to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion. It also announced that it will purchase five B737-800 passenger planes with an option on four more B747-400 cargo aircraft and two more B747-400 passenger jets, at a total cost at US$1.3 billion.
The total procurement, worth US$5.6 billion, is regarded as the largest ever in Taiwan's aviation history.

DOC.HEADLINE: US GIRL SEEKS BIRTH PARENTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 20-year-old American girl looking for her birth parents in Taiwan held a press conference on Thursday to publicize her search.

Legislator Chin Huei-chu of the ruling Kuomintang, who accompanied Desiree Leary to the press conference, said the girl was born on approximately July 8, 1979, and is said to be the sixth child in her family. Her parents, who could not afford to raise another child, left her in a Taipei City clinic after her birth.
At two months of age, Desiree was adopted from a local orphanage by an American widow who took her to America, she went on.

Chin also provided the numbers of two telephone hot lines -- 02-2358818 and 0938373730, in the hope that someone among the general public will be able to shed some light on the whereabouts of Leary's biological parents.

Desiree, who now lives and studies in Pennsylvania, said that she came to Taiwan in mid-June to participate in an event held by the China Youth Corps, and took the opportunity while here to seek her parents. So far, she said, she has been unsuccessful, and is scheduled to leave Taiwan on Aug. 18.

The girl said that although her adoptive mother treats her well, she still has the feeling that she does not belong in America. Since arriving in Taiwan, she went on, she feels at home, and now most of all would like to find her birth parents and the rest of her family.
However, she also stressed that she does not want to disrupt the lives of her birth parents, and really just wants to discover her roots.

Her search has been thwarted by the fact that the clinic where she was abandoned has closed, and Dr. Huang, the clinic's owner, has forgotten the details of her case. In addition, the records relating to her birth cannot be found.

According to a local woman who was involved in Leary's adoption, the child contracted serious jaundice as a newborn, and had a green birthmark on her back. As she is a tall young woman today, it is thought that her parents might also be tall.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN COUNTY MAGISTRATE DIES OF CIRRHOSIS

TEXT.P: Su Wen-hsiung, the Kuomintang magistrate of Yunlin County in central Taiwan, died at the National Taiwan University Hospital on Thursday after a long fight with liver disease.
Su, 56, was sent to a hospital in rural Taipao Township in Chiayi County on June 20 because of gastric bleeding, and was transferred to Taiwan University Hospital five days later.
Su, who suffered from chronic cirrhosis and hepatitis B, sank into disorientation earlier this week and died of liver failure on Thursday afternoon, said a hospital official.

Entering politics as a secretary in Huwei Township, Yunlin County, Su served as the Secretary-General of Huwei Farmers Association, and was a two-term member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly before being elected Yunlin Country Magistrate in 1997.
His four-year term still has two years and three months to run, which will be served by a successor elected within three months in a by-election, said officials from the Central Election Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES KOREAN OLYMPIC C'TTEE CHAIRMAN KIM UN YONG

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui received Korean Olympic Committee Chairman Kim Un Yong on Thursday to exchange views on sports exchanges and cooperation programs between the Republic of China and the Republic of Korea.
The ROC head of state told his visitor that the Republic of China could learn many things from Korea in the area of sports, especially in coaching, training and skills.

President Lee stressed that the promotion of physical education should be aimed at promoting sporting activities for everyone. The goal should be to cultivate outstanding athletes and to select those sports suitable for peoples' abilities, he said.

The president went on to say that in the past, the ROC implemented a vocational training program in which the ROC government cultivated the development of technical skills, and then used people with these skills to train even more technicians, which helped the nation in its industrial development. "These measures could apply to physical education development," Lee said.
Lee pointed out that physical education can be achieved only by the joint efforts of the government and civilian agencies.
President Lee also spoke highly of achievements of Korea in the field of sports.
In return, Kim praised the ROC's progress in the field in recent years.
He said he hoped that the ROC and the ROK will further strengthen sports exchanges and cooperation programs.

Kim called on President Lee in the company of his ROC counterpart Hwang Ta-chou, chairman Nancy Chao of the Council for Physical Fitness and Sports and ROC International Olympic Committee member Wu Ching-kuo.
Ding Mou-shih, senior adviser to the president, and Lin Bih-jaw, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, were also present at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-VIETNAM ECONOMIC MEETING TO BE HELD NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The Sixth ROC-Vietnam Economic and Industrial Joint Meeting will be held in Vietnam from Aug. 17-20.
The Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) and the Vietnamese Federation of Trade and Commerce will jointly hold the meeting in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City.

In addition to Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang and ROC Representative to Vietnam Hu Chia-chi, Huang Shih-hui, head of the CNAIC's Vietnamese affairs committee and also chairman of the Chingfong Group, will lead a CNAIC delegation to the meeting and tour a Taiwan-funded industrial zone in Hanoi.
The meeting has been held alternately in the Republic of China and Vietnam each year since 1992, when the two countries clinched a trade and commerce cooperation accord.

Ranking officials and delegates of the two countries will discuss and exchange opinions on a variety of topics related to business and investment opportunities in Vietnam, according to CNAIC officials who expressed optimism about Vietnam's economic prospects.

Since the second half of 1997, when the Asian financial crisis broke out in Southeast Asia, the Vietnamese government has been seeking to attract foreign investment by offering handsome incentives and lease reductions on land rentals.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AGENCY WEBSITE RE-HACKED

TEXT.P: The website of the National Assembly was hacked Thursday for the second time in a week, causing the paralysis of a mainframe computer.

It is believed that the National Assembly's website was hacked by a mainland Chinese computer specialist following a previous intrusion Tuesday, in which some files were replaced. Thursday's attack was more serious, however, as viruses introduced into the system by the hacker damaged computer equipment.
Fortunately, a firewall -- a device that protects data from outside intruders -- kept most of the information safe, said National Assembly Secretary-General Chen Chaun.

After attempts to restart the computer failed, National Assembly officials went to the police and the National Security Bureau to report the crime. They also sought technical help from the machine's vendor.

Amid concerns that mainland China will launch an attack on Taiwan under a similar Internet warfare model, various organizations have been instructed to look into the origin of recent intrusions and come up with protective measures.

The Ninth Investigation Corps of the Criminal Investigation Bureau believes an attack against the Control Yuan's website on Aug. 9 and recent attacks against the National Assembly's website were committed by different people, as the attack against the National Assembly site crippled it, whereas the one against the Control Yuan merely resulted in a pro-mainland Chinese message appearing on the site's homepage.
Police officers do not exclude the possibility that the attacks were retaliation for President Lee Teng-hui's recent "special state-to-state relationship" declaration.

In light of the series of attacks, Director Cheng Nien-hsing of a Taiwan computer center for emergency measures admitted that the center failed to detect the intrusion into the National Assembly's website.

Cheng said there is no system that is completely free from flaws, and he suggested that the best way to keep hackers from further intruding is to reduce the system's external connections. He also suggested that extra access points into systems be disconnected.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPANY SELLING AUSTRALIAN SHOPPING CENTER

TEXT.P: The Hong Yang Group based in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung is selling a shopping center in Australia's Brisbane, Queensland for close to A$80 million (US$53 million), the Australian Financial Review reported on Thursday.
The daily reported that Shin Yen, a subsidiary of Hong Yang, had decided to sell the center because of financial strains in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS NOTE: REPEAT WITH MINOR CORRECTIONS IN THE FOURTH, FIFTH AND

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER GOVERNOR LEADING FOUR-MAN PRESIDENTIAL RACE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong is keeping his lead in the four-man race for the presidency of the Republic of China, according to the results of a survey released on Thursday.

Independent Soong was the favorite candidate of 33.3 percent of those surveyed, while Vice President Lien Chan, the Kuomintang's candidate, had the support of 21 percent of the survey respondents, followed by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian, with 19.2 percent, and former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, with 0.2 percent.

If the election were to be held the day after the survey instead of in March 2000, 34.4 percent of the respondents said they would vote for Soong, 21.7 percent said they would support Lien, 20.6 percent for Chen and 0.2 percent for Hsu.

However, 47.8 percent of the respondents said they believe Lien commands the best chance of winning the election, 19.3 percent believe Soong will win, and 6.6 percent believe Chen will be the victor. Hsu did not even get a mention.

Soong was considered by the majority of 47.6 percent as the candidate most aware of public dissatisfaction. Chen ranked second, with 20.6 percent, Lien came in third with 5.8 percent, and Hsu was last again, with 1.1 percent. The remaining 13.2 percent of the respondents said they did not know the answer to the question.

As to which one of the four have the most ambition and capability to carry out reforms, Chen led the others with a vote of 43.4 percent of those polled. Soong got 22.3 percent, Lien got 10.6 percent, and Hsu trailed behind with 1.1 percent.

However, Lien might take comfort in the fact that he was considered by most of the respondents as the one most capable of maintaining the island's stability and protecting the national interest in the face of Beijing's military threat, followed in descending order by Soong, Chen and Hsu.

The survey, conducted by the Focus Survey Research Corp., conducted the telephone interview among 1,130 adults around the island between Aug. 5 and 6. It had a margin of error of 2.98 percentage points, said the authors.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO LINKS BETWEEN PLANE PURCHASES AND CROSS-STRAIT AIR TRAFFIC: CAA

TEXT.P: No links exist between the recent purchase by China Airlines (CAL) of cargo and passenger jets and the anticipated opening of direct air links across the Taiwan Strait, an official with the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said on Thursday.
Denying the rumors, CAA Deputy Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng stressed that CAL's procurement of new planes is aimed purely at replacing its aging fleet.

Chang made the remarks while attending the 1999 Taipei Aerospace Technology Exhibition in the face of speculation over CAL's purchase of a total of 36 passenger and cargo planes from the France-headquartered Airbus Industrie and the US-based Boeing Co. at a cost of US$5.6 billion, a record in Taiwan's aviation history.
It had been rumored that the move is in preparation for the opening of direct air traffic links with mainland China.

Pointing out that no fixed schedule for the establishment of cross-strait direct air links has been set, Chang claimed that no aviation company would be prepared to lose money by investing for that purpose so soon.

Even if such links were effectively set up, Chang said he believed the relevant mainland authorities would in any case reserve the lucrative Taipei-Beijing or Taipei-Shanghai routes for mainland-based airlines only.

As any airplane procurement plan requires a great deal of advance preparation, Chang asserted that CAL's recent placement of orders for Airbus and Boeing airplanes is part of the company's long-term development program.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BETTER THAN SINGAPORE, HK FOR FOREIGN INVESTMENT: REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Thursday that Taiwan has become more attractive than Singapore and Hong Kong for foreign investors.

A CEPD report indicates that Taiwan's labor costs in the manufacturing sector is lower than Singapore's, while its rents for industrial areas and offices are also lower that those of Singapore and Hong Kong.

The report shows that the monthly labor cost for Taiwan's manufacturing sector stood at US$1,100 in June of this year. The figure in Singapore was 20 percent higher, while Hong Kong's was 20 percent lower.
The monthly pay for an engineer in Taiwan averaged US$1,600 in the same month, while Singapore's was a whopping 140 percent higher, and Hong Kong's was 10 percent lower.
The monthly pay for a middle manager in Taiwan was US$2,600, again far outstripped by the 120 percent higher rate for Singapore.
Meanwhile, monthly rent for industrial zones was US$18 per ping (six square feet) in Taipei, and four times this figure in Singapore and Hong Kong.
The monthly rent for offices was US$57 per ping in Taipei 50 percent higher in Singapore, and 150 percent higher in Hong Kong.

CEPD Deputy Chairman Schive Chi told the media the figures show that if foreign investors want to invest in Asia, Taiwan remains the best choice, although he admitted that investment in Taiwan has disadvantages such as the unstable relationship between mainland China and Taiwan, and the lack of Taipei's internationalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA PUSHES FOR JOINT VENTURE BETWEEN BOEING AND TAIWAN CARRIERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is wooing US-based Boeing Co. into a joint venture with four local air carriers to remodel aged passenger planes for use as cargo planes, a MOEA official said on Thursday.

One day after Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) signed an order for 13 Boeing-747s, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chi-ming said that his ministry is trying to lobby Boeing to join CAL, EVA Airways, Aerospace Industrial Development Corp., and Air Asia Co. in the venture.
Thus far, all of the local carriers except CAL have agreed to join the venture.
Yin said that even if CAL is not interested in the project, his ministry will press on with promoting the venture with the participation of the other three carriers and Boeing.
The remodeling business, which transforms aging passenger planes into cargo jets, is a lucrative market estimated at about US$100 billion worldwide.

Although remodeling an existing plane is far less expensive than buying a new cargo plane, US$40 million to US$50 million startup capital must still be put up before a potential investor can be certified as an accredited operator, a regulation which has scared away many would-be operators.

Yin said CAL's newly signed contract with Boeing, as well as the MOEA's pushing for the new venture, should dispel the allegations that the Taipei authorities tried to persuade CAL to switch its order from Boeing to its European rival, Airbus Industrie, to vent its anger over Washington's tilt toward Beijing in Taipei's dispute over the island's statehood.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAINS OF CO-PILOT OF CRASHED MILITARY CHOPPER FOUND
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Central Taiwan, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The rescue team searching for a military helicopter which crashed recently into a central Taiwan reservoir on Thursday recovered the remains of co-pilot Capt. Shih Po-shou.
Shih's body was immediately rushed to Taichung Armed Forces Hospital for a post mortem examination.
The super Cobra AH-IW of the Army's Airborne Second Attack Squadron crashed into Taichung County's Techi Reservoir on July 17.

The fuselage of the stricken craft was not salvaged until Aug. 9 due to the extreme depth of the water into which it crashed, and the remains of pilot Feng Cheng-chieh and Shih were not found in the cockpit when it was finally raised to the surface.

The rescue team, composed of civilian and military personnel, continued to search for the bodies of the two pilots in around 100 meters of water using sophisticated sonar instrument, and discovered Shih's body, identifiable by the name tag on his uniform, in 75 meters of muddy water.
The search continues for Feng's body. According to military sources, the heavy-duty combat uniforms worn by the chopper's crew were the main cause of the deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S TAX ADMINISTRATION WEBSITE HACKED

TEXT.P: A local computer hacker broke into the website of mainland China's State Administration of Taxation (SAT) on Wednesday night in apparent retaliation for a mainland intrusion into the website of Taiwan's National Assembly earlier in the day.

Signing himself "A Killer," the Taiwan hacker broke into the SAT website and posted the national flag of the Republic of China on the web's home page as well as writing "Taiwan, sovereignty by the people."

The hacker urged Beijing to stop playing with fire, saying that if mainland China dares to attack Taiwan by force, "we dare to announce independence." "Liberating the mainland ..." was also displayed.
Earlier, the Taiwan National Assembly website was infiltrated by a mainland Chinese hacker, crashing the organization's computer system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO GO AHEAD WITH HIGH SPEED RAIL PROJECT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui has played a vital role in saving Taiwan's long-awaited high speed railway project from being aborted at the last minute.

Taiwan High Speed Rail Corporation (THSRC) Chairwoman Yin Chi and Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-chen, after a four-hour meeting on Thursday evening, reached a consensus that THSRC will go ahead with the project.
THSRC, comprised of several local business groups, won the bid in July last year to build Taiwan's first high speed rail at a cost of over US$16.5 billion on a BOT (build-operate-transfer) basis.

However, troubled by financial strains resulting from the reluctance of a local banking consortium to provide sufficient funding, and what it claimed is the government's failure to honor promises to provide other support, THSRC had threatened to scrap the agreement for the 345-kilometer high speed rail project.
Lee met Yin on Tuesday for what were believed to be discussions on the issue, although neither the Presidential office nor THSRC would reveal any details of the meeting.

Officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, THSRC and the banking consortium are scheduled to sign a tri-party agreement on Friday afternoon under which the banks will promise to offer the loans needed by THSRC.
Yin expressed her gratitude to Lin for helping THSRC secure the loans. "We will not talk about abandoning the project any more," she said after Thursday's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
12 ROC allies propose a bill calling for Taiwan's equal representation in the United Nations.
The China Times:
Contractor, government and banks reach a final agreement on financing for the island's high-speed railway project.
The United Daily News:
Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. to go ahead with the new rail system construction project and a loan agreement for the BOT project will be sign today.
The Liberty Times:
The high-speed railway crisis is over.
The Commons Daily: @The China Post:
'ROC on Taiwan' casts new bid for UN membership.
The Taiwan News:
Taiwan stresses equality in latest UN entry bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWAN STUDENTS KILLED IN EAST IDAHO ROLLOVER

TEXT.P: Four Taiwan students were killed and six others injured Thursday morning (US time) when their van rolled over in eastern Idaho while en route to Yellowstone National Park, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported on Friday.

Frank Liu, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Seattle, has left for St. Anthony, a town near the scene of the rollover, to help the accident victims, all of them Taiwan students studying in New York, according to Liu Chih-kung, director of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs.
Some of the students are studying at City College of the City University of New York and some are students at Pace University, New York.
Kuo Wei-chieh was in critical condition after an operation, while five others are recovering in three different hospitals in an area stretching some 300 kilometers.
As of press time, the parents of two of the students were on their way to the United States, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SAYS DALAI LAMA'S VISIT NOT POLITICAL

TEXT.P: Tibet's Dalai Lama is currently visiting the United States "in his capacity as a religious and spiritual leader," not as a head of state, said James Rubin, spokesman for the Department of State, Thursday.

Contrary to press reports, Rubin said, the US government is not involved in scheduling the Dalai Lama's itinerary or travel plans. But Special Coordinator for Tibetan Affairs Julia Taft is expected to meet with the Dalai Lama when the Tibetan religious leader is in New York City Friday, he added.

The spokesman said at a regular briefing at the State Department that since 1942, the United States has "regarded Tibet as part of China," stressing, "We do not recognize the Tibetan government-in-exile as a sovereign entity, but we do believe that restoration of a dialogue between China and the Dalai Lama is an important element of a peaceful solution to diffuse tensions."
The United States, Rubin also noted, supports the unique spiritual, cultural and linguistic heritage of Tibet.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SAYS US WILL NOT LOSE ACCESS TO PANAMA CANAL

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration said Thursday the United States is satisfied that Beijing will not try and does not have the capability to command the Panama Canal despite Republican fears over a Hong Kong company's control of ports at both ends of the strategic waterway.

Responding to Republican worries about mainland China's growing influence over the Panama Canal, David Leavy, spokesman for the White House National Security Council, said, "The United States is satisfied our interests will be protected after the canal is turned over this December."

"We have seen no capability on the part of the PRC, which is a heavy user of the canal, to disrupt this operation. So I would caution people not to get too alarmist over this issue," added Leavy. American ships are guaranteed access to the canal under a law that governs the contract of the Hong Kong shipping firm Hutchinson-Whampoa, he stressed.

At the Pentagon, Defense Department spokesman Ken Bacon noted that Hutchinson-Whampoa will have port facilities designed to load and unload containers from ships that are too big to go into the canal.

"The company does not have any ability to stop or impede traffic through the canal," Bacon said. "In fact, the treaty that has been signed by the US and Panama calling for the transfer of the canal at the end of this year provides a guarantee for security of the canal, and it also says that the canal will be operated in a neutral way ... open to ships from all countries," he pointed out.

Bacon went on to say that the Panama Canal treaty includes a provision saying that if the canal is closed or its operations are interfered with, the United States and Panama each has an independent right to take any steps necessary, including the use of military force, to reopen it.

"So the United States has a unilateral right to maintain the neutrality of the canal and to reopen it if there should be any military threat," said the Pentagon spokesman, adding that the United States did not see the Hong Kong firm's owning of the ports as a military or a national security threat.

But Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott, a Mississippi Republican, sent an angry letter to Defense Secretary William Cohen on Aug. 1, accusing the Clinton administration of "allowing a scenario to develop where US national security interests could not be protected without confronting the Chinese communists in the Americas."

"US naval ships will be at the mercy of Chinese-controlled pilots and could even be denied passage through the Panama Canal by Hutchinson, an arm of the People's Liberation Army," wrote Lott in the letter that his office released Thursday.

"In addition, the Chinese Communist Party will gain an intelligence information advantage by controlling this strategic chokepoint," the senator added. "It appears that we have given away the farm without a shot being fired."
Panama in 1997 awarded a 25- to 50-year contract to Hutchinson-Whampoa, permitting it to operate at the two ends of the Panama Canal, which connects the Atlantic and the Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNBALANCED TAIWAN POLICY DOES AUSTRALIA NO FAVORS: COLUMNIST

TEXT.P: Kowtowing to mainland China and ganging up with Beijing against Taiwan with no good reason will not benefit Australia and is an overreaching step by Canberra, a well-respected columnist warned on Friday.

In an article published in The Australian on Friday, Greg Sheridan, foreign editor of the mass circulation daily, said: "Despite Washington's weird and unpredictable wobbles, there is a strong case that Canberra is taking the process of sucking up to Beijing needlessly far."
He pointed out Australia's relations with Taiwan have been pointlessly scaled back with fewer senior Taiwanese being allowed to visit, and fewer Australian ministerial visits to Taiwan.
"Nations which kowtow have almost never done any better with China than those that pursue sensible, non-provocative but also non-kowtowing policies," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN UNEMPLOYMENT RATE HITS 9-YEAR LOW IN JULY

TEXT.P: Australia's unemployment rate, buoyed by rising employment and a strong economic performance, fell to 7 percent in July, the lowest level in almost nine years, and economists have said the figure could further drop to 6.5 percent in the next 12 months.

The jobless rate fell by 0.2 percentage points to 7 percent in July from June while total employment reached a record high as the number of people seeking work fell to the lowest level since October 1990, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Thursday.

The news sent the All Ordinaries Index higher, closing 9.1 points up to 2,944 on Thursday. The Australian currency was also boosted to 65.10 US cents on Thursday, up 0.35 US cents from Wednesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIANS GIVEN RIGHT TO VOTE FOR REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: The House of Representatives and Senate in Canberra have passed a resolution aimed at allowing Australians for the first time ever the right to remove the queen as head of state and vote for Australia's becoming a republic in a referendum slated for Nov. 6.

The resolution, passed Thursday night after a heated debate on the model and wording of the referendum, will enable Australians the choice to form a republic by replacing the queen and the governor-general with a president appointed by two-thirds of the Parliament.

"For the first time since the Federal (in 1901), under this government and under this prime minister, the Australian people will be given an opportunity to decide whether or not this country should become a republic," John Howard told the Parliament.
"I think the course of the debate over the next few weeks will be a matter of great fascination, great intensity and great interest," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF BRIEFS FOREIGN REPRESENTATIVES ON 'STATE-TO-STATE'

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi on Friday briefed 41 foreign representatives stationed in Taipei on major points of the Republic of China's "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
The briefing at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs followed a similar presentation by Su on Tuesday to resident ambassadors of 13 of the ROC's diplomatic allies.

Resident representatives of 41 countries which do not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC attended Friday's briefing. Many of them posed questions about the "special state-to-state" theory after hearing Su's 40-minute briefing.
Australian Representative Sam Gerovich told CNA that Su's briefing has helped all foreign envoys come to a better understanding of ROC President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" concept.

In an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station on July 9, President Lee defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship," drawing furious reaction from communist China which has consistently regarded Taiwan as its "renegade province."
Su pointed out that the gist of the "special state-to-state" concept is to emphasize equality and parity between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"The definition is mainly a political declaration aimed at affirming the reality," Su said, adding that the "special state-to-state" theory does not mark any shift in the ROC's policy toward mainland China.
"Our policy of promoting cross-strait civilian exchanges, trade and investment has remained unchanged," the scholar-turned-official stressed.

Su reiterated that the ROC sincerely welcomes top mainland negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan to visit the island this autumn to see for himself democratic development here. "We welcome cross-strait dialogue on any topic that can help boost mutual understanding and trust."

In response to an inquiry whether increased sorties in the skies over the Taiwan Strait recently will affect cross-strait relations, Su said the so-called military escalation in the strait is largely an exaggeration by Hong Kong news media.
"To our knowledge, the situation is not as serious as reported," Su said.

Asked how to define "democratization" when President Lee said the two sides of the strait can be unified only after mainland China democratizes, Su said it's not easy to define "democratization." Nevertheless, Su said a democratically elected parliament can serve as a major indicator of democratization.

One foreign envoy said Beijing leaders have decided at their annual Beidaihe meeting to cancel top mainland negotiator Wang Daohan's planned Taiwan visit. In reply, Su said there is so far no official statement from Beijing to verify such a report. "For our part, we still sincerely welcome Wang's visit," he added.

The top mainland policy planner went on to say that the timing for unveiling the "special state-to-state" concept is not important. "The announcement is mainly aimed at affirming the reality of cross-strait parity," Su said, adding that if the declaration were to be made until October this year, its impact on the ROC's presidential election next year may even greater.

In reply to an inquiry why mainland China's jet fighters crossed over the center line of the Taiwan Strait, Su only said the ROC will not take any provocative action to add up to cross-strait tension.

Su said he believes that mainland China has a learned a lesson from the 1996 cross-strait crisis that saber-rattling would only increase Taiwan people's aversion to communist China and thus hinder eventual unification.

A foreign representative asked what role the United States will play should a military conflict erupts in the Taiwan Strait. In reply, Su said the United States upholds its own version of the "one China" policy under which the United States encourages cross-strait dialogue and resolve their disputes through peaceful negotiations.
"Promoting cross-strait dialogue and seeking peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes are also our basic policies toward the mainland," Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BULLET TRAIN PROJECT REVIVED UPON SIGNING OF TRI-PARTY ACCORD

TEXT.P: A tri-party agreement was struck on Friday, reviving Taiwan's first bullet train project which was nearly aborted two weeks ago, according to sources from the Executive Yuan.

Under the agreement between the government, the builder of the rail system, and a banking consortium which is providing funding for the project, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) promised to offer guarantees securing the banking consortium's creditors rights.

At the same time, the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corporation (THSRC) agreed to go ahead with the project, and to repay an agreement deposit of NT$15 billion (US$463 million) if it cannot raise some NT$280 billion (US$8.7 billion) in syndicated loans by next March.

Premier Vincent Siew expressed delight with the development, saying that the planned 345-km railway, Taiwan's first BOT (build-operate-transfer) project, is now expected to be completed in 2005, fulfilling the expectations of the Taiwan government and people.

Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng, who met with THSRC Chairman Nita Ing on Thursday for a six-hour discussion, said the three parties reached consensus late on Thursday night after two major thorny issues were resolved.

Lin said that although the MOTC is not liable for any of the project's financing problems, it nevertheless agreed to offer the guarantees in the hope of reviving the long-awaited major infrastructure project.

If everything goes smoothly, he said, THSRC should be capable of completing the bullet train by 2005, two years later than the originally scheduled date. According to a THSRC analysis, the builder will sustain a loss of NT$100 million (US$3.1 million) for each day the project falls behind schedule.

Trains traveling on the new railway will operate at a maximum speed of 300 kilometers per hour and will shuttle passengers from Taipei City in the north of the island to Kaohsiung City in the south in just 90 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 13, or the third day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1888: John Logie Baird, the Scottish electrical engineer who invented television, is born.
1896: Sir John Everett Millais, British painter and president of the Royal Academy, dies at the age of 67. He founded the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood in 1848 and became the first artist to receive a baronetcy in 1885.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish-American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho," and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Fidel Castro, the Cuban revolutionary who became the country's socialist president in 1959, is born.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Tse-tung names Beijing as communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut HQ of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seekers freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Chinese communist Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria to Seoul, Korea on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of them plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1991: The Dangerous Dogs Act comes into force in Britain. Under the new act, fighting dogs such as the American pit bull terrier and Japanese tosa must be muzzled and leashed in public.
1993: A hotel collapses in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Truth is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S SOVEREIGNTY IS INDISPUTABLE FACT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is an independent sovereign state since its founding in 1912 and this is an indisputable fact, a senior mainland affairs official said on Friday.
Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), was commenting on Beijing's claim that "one China" is an indisputable fact.
