The press departments of the Taiwan Work Office of the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee and the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council jointly issued an article on Thursday, saying Taiwan is part of China's territory, and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait belong to one country, not two. "This is an indisputable fact," the article asserted.
Sheu said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, will carefully study the two mainland Taiwan affairs offices' article.

Nevertheless, Sheu said he hopes mainland authorities will also pragmatically, calmly and seriously read the MAC's Aug. 1 written explanation of ROC President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" theory.

Sheu reiterated the ROC's welcome to top mainland negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan's planned visit to the island this autumn. Sheu said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resolve their disputes or differences through dialogue and consultations.

Wang, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), is scheduled to visit Taiwan either in mid-September or mid-October. His visit, however, has become uncertain since President Lee defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station on July 9. Lee's declaration has drawn Beijing's furious reaction.

Sheu said the MAC's Aug. 1 written explanation was designed to highlight key points of Lee's definition, including laying a basis of parity for cross-strait engagements and upgrading the level of cross-strait dialogue.

The MAC-issued position paper stressed what the ROC opposes is Beijing's "one China" principle which downgrades the ROC to a local-level government and denies its rights to take part in international activities and organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOFU TO BE CENTERPIECE OF 1999 TAIPEI FOOD FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Tofu is to be the theme of the 1999 Taipei Chinese Food Festival scheduled to be held Aug. 20-24, sources from the Tourism Bureau said on Friday.

Top-notch chefs from 18 leading tourist-oriented restaurants and hotels around Taiwan are expected to show off their culinary skills and creativity with cuisine featuring tofu during the five-day festival, according to event organizers.
Tofu, lauded by the festival's organizers as "white jade" and an essential element of traditional Chinese cuisine, "can be old yet new," depending on its preparation, the organizers said.
Tofu, or soybean curd, has been a major item on Chinese dinner tables since the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-219 A.D.).
A natural substance rich in vegetable protein, tofu has been nicknamed by Chinese as "the poor man's meat" because of its pleasant taste, nutritional value and low price.
Tofu can be made into hundreds of dishes, from a gourmet delicacy in a five-star restaurant to a ready-to-serve fast food conveniently available on supermarket shelves.

Besides the tofu theme, a classic Chin-ping-mei feast will be presented at the festival, along with traditional northern Chinese steamed bread and dishes considered to be aphrodisiacs, said the organizers.

Chin-ping-mei is the title of a Ming Dynasty (1386-1644 A.D.) novel by an anonymous author, and is commonly regarded as obscene, although the book, which mainly depicts luxurious lifestyles in wealthy homes during the Ming Dynasty, is also lauded as a masterpiece.
Meanwhile, Hakka cuisine, another facet of Chinese cooking, will also be on display for the first time at this year's exhibition, the organizers said.

To mark the festival, the tenth of its kind, the Directorate General of Posts will issue a series of stamps depicting the essence of the eight major schools of Chinese cooking. The cuisine stamp series, the first of its kind in the world, will have a print run of 2.5 million sets, with each set including eight pieces, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CELL PHONES GAINING POPULARITY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said on Friday that he predicts that half of Taiwan's population will own a cellular phone by 2001.

Mao was speaking at the opening ceremony of the 1999 Taipei Telecommunications and Network Exhibition held at the Taipei World Trade Center, where he jointly cut the ribbon to open the show with Chien Jen-te, director-general of the Directorate General of Telecommunications under the MOTC.
Mao noted that the government partly liberalized the telecommunications market for mobile and satellite telecommunications in 1996, and said the next step is to further open the fixed-network market.

He went on to say that before the telecommunications market-opening, only 7 percent of local residents used mobile phones. However, during the past one-and-a-half years, the figure has reached 37 percent, he continued.
In addition, national and foreign investments relating to telecommunications have amounted to NT$50 billion and US$30 million, respectively, producing thousands of employment opportunities.

As an overall liberalization policy will be implemented in 2001, new investment is expected to hit NT$400 billion (US$12.3 billion), resulting in related industries worth more than NT$10 billion, he added.

He also stressed that the current priority is to open the fixed-network market. The end of this year is the deadline for bids relating to the fixed-network business, and the service should be available to the public before the end of next year, by which time the entire island is expected to have entered a 3C integrated wide-frequency era.
An exhibition center spokesman said 137 companies have rented 614 booths at the show, the largest number of booths used in a single exhibition in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND CONFIRMS US CARRIER GROUP EXERCISES IN SOUTH CHINA SEA

TEXT.P: A Ministry of National Defense (MND) official confirmed Friday recent reports of two US aircraft carrier groups exercising in the South China Sea, but stressed that the drills are part of the US Navy's annual routine event.

Vice Defense Minister Sun Tao-yu made the remarks during Friday morning's breakfast meeting and at the invitation of New Party Caucus Convener Lee Ching-hua and Legislative Vice Convener Feng Hu-hsiang. The meeting was called to examine how the ministry is operating amid continued tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

When asked by Feng about foreign wire service reports on exercises by two US aircraft carriers last week near Singapore, Sun confirmed that the United States did send two carrier groups, the USS Kitty Hawk and Constellation, to the South China Sea, but stressed that it was probably part of an annual routine exercise.

After the war in the Persian Gulf, Sun said, North and South Korea have become the United States' major strategic concerns; thus this was probably just part of a normal exercise of the US South Pacific fleet, he said.
Whether the battle group exercise was related to tensions in the Taiwan Strait, the MND has no way of knowing, the vice minister said.
Sun also stressed that the situation across the Taiwan Strait mostly depends on the Republic of China's ability to clearly monitor mainland Chinese military activities.
As for the fact that mainland Chinese jet fighters crossed the center line of the Taiwan Strait twice in late July, Sun said that the ROC Air Force had closely monitored both incidents.

The center line of the strait is not a statutory boundary, but a tacit understanding between the two sides, he said, and the mainland Chinese Air Force has always shown considerable self-restraint in the past.
As long as its activities do not interfere with Taiwan's international and domestic flights and are not provocative, no conflicts are likely to erupt, he said.

Since the outlying Matsu and Kinmen islands both lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan, the ROC Air Force would have to cross over the center line as well when providing air supplies, he pointed out.

Sun dismissed foreign wire reports of two ROC Mirage jet fighters being locked onto by mainland Chinese Su-27s. If the Su-27s had targeted ROC jet fighters with their narrow radar beams and not fired, their positions would have been exposed, he pointed out.

He continued that unless mainland China was prepared to wage war, the ROC Air Force would actually welcome more mainland jet fighters locking onto Taiwan warplanes so that Taiwan can easily obtain information on mainland Chinese fighters.
The vice minister also dismissed reports that 500,000 reservists had been amassing in Fujian province and that they could "easily take over Taiwan in four to five days."

As mainland China lacks military mobility, Sun said that military experts from both England and the United States have said that the mainland does not have the ability to conquer Taiwan at present, and that Beijing's claims are part of its psychological warfare campaign against the ROC.

Sun pointed out that the MND is well prepared for further "information warfare" against Taiwan, and added that it is not likely that Beijing would launch an economic blockade against the island since such a move would affect the economic benefits of other Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAINS CAUSE NT$578 MILLION IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: Heavy rains have caused agricultural damage totaling NT$578 million (US$17.7 million) since the beginning of this month, with soil conservation losses alone totaling about NT$300 million, according to the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

Kaohsiung County has suffered the largest losses in terms of both crops and farmland. In addition, Nantou, Yunlin and Tainan counties have also suffered, the council said, adding that there have been agricultural losses of NT$225 million in these areas, which have 4,830 hectares of farmland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTICIPATED KOALA FEVER PROMPTS TRAFFIC CONTROLS AROUND ZOO

TEXT.P: Koala fever is set to hit Taipei on Saturday, when the city zoo's newest acquisitions -- two koalas from Australia -- will meet the public for the first time.

The furry beasts are expected to be such a powerful attraction that the Taipei City Bureau of Transportation (BOT) on Friday decided to implement strict traffic controls in front of the zoo until the end of the month.

A BOT spokesman said that starting from Saturday until Aug. 31, Hsingkuang Rd. Sec. 2 in front of the zoo will be sealed off to private cars and motorcycles from 6 a.m.- 3 p.m. on weekends and national holidays to prevent traffic congestion.
During this period, only buses, tour buses, taxis and drivers with disability passes will be allowed to enter the restricted area, he said.

The Taipei Mass Rapid Transit Corporation on Friday also decided to increase the frequency of trains to one every two minutes during the day, which is almost the full passenger capacity of the Mucha line, on weekends and national holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTRONICS FIRMS SIGN GPS JOINT VENTURE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan electronics companies on Friday signed a joint venture agreement to share their technology to make Global Positioning System (GPS) products in the United States under the name of OmniTrack International Co.

The agreement between United Microelectronics Group (UMG) and Computer Association (CA), was signed by UMG Chairman Robert Tsao and CA Chairman Wang Chia-lien, and it was announced that OmniTrack will have paid-in capital of US$2 million.

Speaking at the ceremony, Wang said that "the application of GPS products is very limited at present, but we hope that our cooperation will lead to the development of better GPS products, and increased sales."

Tsao for his part said that UMG will provide OmniTrack with the advanced technologies needed to design the smaller wafers required for GPS products which enable such products to be more convenient and portable.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES SURGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices surged 4 percent on Friday to reclaim the psychologically important 7,600-point level after Morgan Stanley Capital International announced that it was raising the weighting of Taipei stocks on its indices.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index soared 295.81 points to close at 7,626.05.
A total of 3.49 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$172.53 billion (US$5.37 billion), up from the previous session's NT$128.28 billion.

Among the eight major stock categories, all sectors reported rises for the day, with financial shares posting the largest gains at 5.5 percent, followed by plastic and chemical stocks, which rose 4 percent.
Construction issues went up 3.9 percent, electronics stocks climbed 3.8 percent, and textile issues registered a 3.4-percent increase.
The cement sector advanced 3.3 percent, paper and pulp shares jumped 1.9 percent, and foodstuff stocks closed 1.8 percent higher.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market rose 2.84 points to close at 165.15, with a turnover of NT$5.38 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August soared 369 points to finish at 7,685, with 3,592 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September jumped 349 points, closing at 7,679, while those for December gained 300 points to close at 7,630. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 1,273 and 25, respectively.
Futures for next March surged 310 points, ending the day at 7,630, with three contract transactions. Next June's futures increased 280 points to close at 7,600, with one contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,316 points for August, 7,330 points for September and December, and 7,320 points for next March and next June.
August electronics futures (TE) climbed 13.7 points to finish at 348.6, with 1,171 contract transactions; September TE futures advanced 13.2 points to close at 348, with 220 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months' TE futures.
August TF futures surged 71.0 points, closing at 1,104, with 176 contract transactions; September TF futures rose 72.4 points to close at 1,110.4, with 28 contract transactions.
There were no transactions recorded for TF futures for the other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY SPEAKS ON POLICY TOWARD BEIJING ON US TV
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China hopes to push for mainland China's peaceful evolution through civilian exchanges, trade and investment so that all Chinese people can enjoy full freedom and democracy, the ROC envoy to the United States said on Thursday.

ROC Representative Stephen Chen made the remarks in a C-SPAN live program. In addition to introducing the ROC's stance on its relations with mainland China, the de facto ROC ambassador to the United States also answered many call-in questions on ROC-mainland China and ROC-US relations in the program.

Chen said the ROC on Taiwan will be a friend of the United States forever. On relations across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said Taiwan looks forward to negotiating with mainland China various kinds of issues, including democratic unification, on an equal footing or a basis of parity.
Chen categorically denied reports that Taiwan is pursuing independence and wants the United States to assist it in fighting with communist China.

The seasoned career diplomat pointed out that ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview on July 9 mainly because a reporter from Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station had asked whether he agreed with Beijing's claim that "Taiwan is a renegade province of the PRC."
Noting that Lee's remarks contain nothing new, Chen said the "special state-to-state" definition mainly reflects historical facts and legal reality.
Chen also denied that ROC-US relations have worsened because of recent cross-strait tension over the "special state-to-state" theory.
He stressed that ROC-US relations have proceeded smoothly under the Taiwan Relations Act, the US law governing exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
In fact, Chen said, American authorities have recently assured Taipei that the US executive branch and Congress remain firm on security commitment to Taiwan.

Chen also clarified reports that Taiwan's flagship China Airlines (CAL) had abandoned its purchase order for Seattle-based Boeing Co. under political consideration. The reports were not true, Chen said, adding that the carrier has ordered roughly equal amount of aircraft from both Boeing and Europe's Airbus Industrie. "CAL has adopted a balanced purchasing principle," Chen said, adding that the ROC's aircraft purchases from Boeing in recent years are the largest in the world.

Chen further explained that the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States is the ROC's de facto embassy in Washington, D.C. With a 200-member staff, the ROC representative office is one of the largest foreign institutions in the US capital. The ROC has posted additional 450 officials in other major US cities.

During the half-hour program, Chen also introduced the ROC's history, foreign trade, major industries, government system, cross-strait relations and its cooperative programs with the United States in commercial, cultural, technological, academic and security fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR SURGES 4.4 CENTS

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.044 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market (TFEM) on Friday, to close at 32.087.
The local currency opened at 32.121 and was traded between 32.087 and 32.121.
Interbank US dollar trading reached to US$411.5 million.
According to TFEM dealers, the greenback was dragged down by Nastique which declined 15.49 points following an overnight rally on Wall Street.

In addition, foreign investment reportedly worth more than US$100 million which has recently poured into the market, can also explain the swell. The local currency is expected to continue its rise, dealers added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWIAN TRANSPORTATION MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Minister of the Malawian Transportation and Engineering Ministry (TEM) Peter Chupa, along with two government officials, is slated to arrive in Taiwan on Aug. 16 for an eight-day visit.

The three-member delegation, which includes Dauphin E. Makako, chief executive of the Highway Repair and Maintenance Administration under the TEM; and Maxwell Kachiwala, division chief of the Highway Administration, also under the TEM, will pay an official call on ROC Premier Vincent Siew and other government officials as well.

Liu Chen-kun, deputy director of the African Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said on Friday that Chupa took over the post early this year and that he is in charge of affairs relating to civil aviation and highways. He was one of the few ministers to remain in the country's Cabinet after a reshuffle this year.

Liu also added that Chupa has expressed his admiration for the ROC's development in the areas of transportation and highways. The three Malawian government officials are scheduled to visit the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the MOTC and various transportation and public constructions.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 100 NATIONAL ASSEMBLY MEMBERS RECOMMEND LIEN-WU TICKET

TEXT.P: A letter recommending presidential advisor Wu Poh-hsiung as Vice President Lien Chan's running mate in the 2000 presidential election, signed by 110 members of the Republic of China's National Assembly, was submitted on Friday to the Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
National Assembly member Chang Ming-chih said that having Wu run for the vice presidency would enhance Lien's presidential bid.
He also urged the KMT to attach importance to the opinion of the party grassroots to avoid the possibility of an unfavorable backlash in the coming election.
Chang made the remarks during a news conference at Yangmingshan, in suburban Taipei, where the National Assembly is convening to discuss constitutional amendments.

Chang and his colleagues stressed that Wu has ranked high in various public opinion surveys, and that a Lien-Wu ticket could not only offset the adverse impact of former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong's presidential bid, but may also lead to an election victory for the KMT.
On the other hand, Chang went on, if the KMT leaders ignore Wu and fail to put him on the ticket, it could result in antipathy toward the party which could in turn lead to lost votes.
The recommendation letter was submitted to John Chang, secretary-general of the KMT Central Committee, who will forward it to KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui and party Vice Chairman Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TAIWAN STUDENTS STUDYING OVERSEAS DECLINING

TEXT.P: The total number of Taiwan students studying in eight major foreign countries fell to 26,200 in 1998, down more than 1,427 from the 1997 level, according to statistics released on Thursday by the Ministry of Education.

America leads other countries, absorbing 13,109 students from Taiwan last year, down 933 from 1997. Britain and Australia took the second and third spots, receiving 6,173 and 1,921, down 241 and 205, respectively, from a year ago, the tallies show. Some 1,649 local students chose to study in Japan, a decrease of 51 on a year-to-year basis.

Canada was the only country to register an increase last year, welcoming 2,359 students from the island, up 79 from the 1997 level, according to the same statistics. Other European countries such as France, Germany, Spain and Switzerland also took from 137 to 342 students from Taiwan.

C.C. Lee, director of the Education Ministry's Bureau of International Cultural and Education Relations, attributed the following factors -- the large number of overseas students returning to Taiwan, the increased opening of domestic graduate schools, the high education costs of studying abroad, and the increasingly popular short-term courses abroad -- to the falling number of Taiwan students going abroad for advanced studies.

However, he also pointed out that the government's efforts to encourage students to study in countries other than just the United States has paid off, as a greater number of local students are now choosing to pursue their studies in Europe and other parts of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TO SQUARE OFF AGAINST US IN WORLD BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei and the United States will meet in the championship game of the 18th International Baseball Association Junior World Championship in Kaohsiung Country on Saturday.
On Friday Chinese Taipei, group A's runner-up, defeated the winner of Group B, Panama, 1-0, on Friday to secure a berth in Saturday's final.
Meanwhile the United States, the runner-up of Group B, upset Cuba, the winner of group A and pre-tournament favorite, 3-2, to earn the right to compete with Chinese Taipei in the championship.
Cuba and Panama will vie for the third place on Saturday.

Tournament organizers due to heavy rain had to quickly format the two games between the first-place winners and the second-place finishers of the two groups to replace the initial play-off between the first four teams in each group.
In Thursday's game against Panama, Chinese Taipei won by scoring a run during its last at-bat.

In the US-Cuba game, the US went ahead first with two runs in the top of the sixth inning. Cuba answered with one run in the bottom of the sixth inning and tied with the game with another run in the seventh inning.
However, the US won the game with a solo home run in their ninth inning, then held Cuba scoreless during their last at-bat.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAP BETWEEN SOONG, LIEN NARROWING: POLL

TEXT.P: Margins are narrowing among the three main candidates in the 2000 presidential election in the terms of their public support, according to polls conducted by the Taipei-based Shih Hsin University.
Since the beginning of July, the private academic institution has conducted six surveys on Taiwan citizens' choice of candidate in the four-man race for the Republic of China's presidency.

In the most recent Shih Hsin poll, which was conducted from August 6-10 among residents of southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung, Pintung, and Penghu counties, former Taiwan Governor James Soong, who is running as an independent candidate, would receive 28 percent of the respondents' votes if the election were to be held the day after the survey.

Vice President Lien Chan, the ruling Kuomintang's candidate, had the support of 24 percent of those polled, while former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, the candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), also gained 24 percent of the survey votes.

The fourth candidate, former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, also running as an independent, gained the support of less than 1 percent of the respondents, according to the poll results which were released on Friday.
There was a total of 2,538 valid responses to the survey, with a margin of error of 3.9 percentage points, Shih Hsin said.
During a Friday press conference, Hsu Chen-jung, a scholar from National Chung Cheng University who was invited to comment on the poll, said Lien's popularity appears to be growing.

Although Soong has been the most popular candidate in all six Shih Hsin surveys, his margin of popularity has gradually declined. He received the support of 44.5 percent of those surveyed in the first poll, conducted from July 5-7 around the island, while Lien had only 14.3 percent support.
Chen's support rate has remained in the 20.8 percent-24.7 percent range, while Hsu's popularity has consistently been negligible.

DOC.HEADLINE: NINE FARMERS JAILED FOR ORGANIZING DEMONSTRATIONS IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Nine mainland Chinese farmers in the southern province of Hunan were sentenced to jail terms ranging from two to six years this week on charges of "organizing people to oppose government offices," a human right group said here Friday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Right and Democratic Movement in China said they were among the 50 farmers arrested on Jan. 8 when some 10,000 people in two villages in Ningxiang county staged demonstrations against heavy taxes.
About 500 soldiers and 1,000 police tried to disperse the demonstrators with tear gas and clubs, killing one person and injuring 100 others, the center said.
Mainland Chinese farmers have staged numerous demonstrations against heavy tax and government corruption in recent years, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MSCI INDEX CHANGE CONFIRMS ROC'S MONETARY STRENGTH: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA): The Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) announcement that it is raising the weighting of Taiwan stocks on its indices exchange immediately gave boost to the Taiwan stock market as the local bourse rallied 295.81 points on Friday.

A senior official of the Finance Ministry's Securities and Exchange Commission said that MSCI's action was the result of the government's liberalization of foreign capital investment and a well-administrated foreign capital policy.

The Switzerland-based Morgan Stanley Capital International announced that it would count Taiwan at 100 percent of its market capitalization in three major indices effective next February. Taiwan is currently indexed at 50 percent.
The MSCI's move will raise the weighting of Taiwan shares from 17.3 percent prices to 27.3 percent on the indices, indicating a 58 percent increase.

Chu Chao-chuan, deputy chairman of the commission, pointed out that Taiwan has emerged as the top investment destination for the Emerging Market Country Free and the All Country Far East Free Ex-Japan mutual funds, accounting for 19.3 percent of the Emerging Free Market and 27.3 percent of the All Country Far East Free Ex-Japan, respectively.

He said that all the said indices belonged to the foreign capital section, especially those American-owed capital companies. They will compete to purchase more Taiwan stocks, which was reflected Friday in the Taiwan Stock Exchange Market. The indices rallied 295.81 points, or 4 percent, to 7,626.05 with a strong turnover of NT$172.53 billion (US$5.37 billion). Foreign dollars buying into the local totaled NT$12.7 billion, eight times more than the NT$1.5 billion on Thursday invested from abroad. By Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND LACKS VISION: COMMENTARY

TEXT.P: A military takeover of Taiwan and the expected loss of innocent lives will create lasting ill-feeling and bitterness and pose as a real stumbling block to communist China's aspired national revival, according to a commentary article in The Straits Times today.

With the title "China lacks vision over Taiwan", the article pointed out that the Taiwan issue can turn explosive in the next century. The communist China's leadership would need exceptional statesmanship and far-sighted strategic vision if it wants to extricate Beijing from such a situation.
Unfortunately, these attributes seem to be lacking at the moment.
Only two options are open currently: reunification under Beijing's terms or the use of force.
It would be extremely naive of Beijing if it were to assume that Taipei could accept the "one country, two systems" model.
Taipei would never enter into negotiations which would relegate the island to a subservient position, it said.

Few people doubt mainland's ability or determination to regain Taiwan by force, or question its legitimacy in doing so. But doing so will surely create a phantom that will haunt the Chinese race for the next 100 years, it stressed.
The June 4th Incident has haunted the Communist Party for the past 10 years.
A military takeover of Taiwan and the expected loss of lives will create lasting ill-feeling and bitterness and pose as a real stumbling block to communist China's aspired national revival.
Unfortunately, under Beijing's terms war and peace are the only alternatives. This lack of strategic vision is really a tragedy, it said.
Beijing should be able to see that once the country resumes its previous position as a strong nation with irresistible cultural charm, the reunification problem would be resolved naturally, it noted.
In it's 3,000-year history, China had been the preeminent country in the world for 70 per cent of the time, when countries far apart felt honored to be associated with it.
The setback suffered in the last 150 years is but a minor and temporary hiccup.

Therefore, in order to solve a problem that has straddled three centuries, Communist China should take a long-term view, focusing first on regaining its former position: the leadership that was among the strongest in the world.
Unfortunately, the present leadership is too much bogged down by petty politics and temporal concerns, it pointed out.
Politicians argue that since Taiwan is physically much smaller than the mainland, there is no reason to accord it a position equal to that of Beijing.
The military argues that since Taipei's Kuomintang government was defeated by its troops, in 1949, there is no reason to accord it equal rights at the negotiating table.
As long as the leadership in Beijing is stuck in this mind-set, there is no chance of solving this three-century-old problem, the commentary ended. SHERMAN WU

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUPS AND LEGISLATORS MEET TO ENACT ASYLUM LAW

TEXT.P: Three private groups and several legislators met on Friday to call for the enactment of an asylum law to solve the issue of more than 100 Tibetans currently in Taiwan.
The proposed new law will also extend political asylum to foreigners who are politically persecuted in their home countries.

The Chinese Association for Human Rights, the Taiwan Chapter of Amnesty International, the Chinese International Law Society and Legislators Chen Hsueh-sheng and Lee Ching-an held a seminar at the Legislative Yuan to push for the enactment of the law.
Chai Sung-lin, president of CAHR, said any country that values human rights should constitute an asylum law to give shelter to foreign refugees.

He said at present, the Republic of China lacks related laws governing the protection for foreign refugees, forcing those refugees applying for political asylum in the ROC to be repatriated back to their countries.

At present, more than 100 Tibetans reside in Taiwan with Indian or Nepalese passports. Because the governments of India and Nepal do not wish these Tibetans to return, they face the possibility of being repatriated to unknown destinations once their passports expire.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY RETURNS TO TAIPEI FROM TOKYO

TEXT.P: Tseng Wen-fui, wife of President Lee Teng-hui returned to Taipei from Tokyo Friday night.
The nation's first lady had been in Japan since last Sunday attending the christening of a freighter built for a Taiwan company at a shipyard in Shikoku.
She was greeted at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon her arrival by Legislator Wang Ling-lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: BODY OF FATAL CHOPPER PILOT FOUND

TEXT.P: The body of a missing pilot whose military helicopter crashed into a reservoir in central Taiwan last month has been found on Friday by rescuers.

The body of Captain Feng Chun-chieh, 28, pilot of the Army's AH-IW Cobra combat helicopter, was recovered by the rescue team in the evening within the 70-meter-deep Techi Reservoir in Taichung County, while the remains of co-pilot Captain Shih Po-shou, 29, was found one day earlier.
Feng's body was sent to Taichung Armed Forces Hospital for a post mortem examination.

The No. 562 super Cobra AH-IW of the Army's Airborne Second Attack Squadron crashed into the reservoir on July 17 while carrying out a routine training mission. Wreckage of the crashed craft was salvaged on Aug. 9.

Relevant authorities will continue investigation to find out the cause of the accident, although it is said that the heavy-duty combat uniforms worn by the pilots might have been the main cause of the deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD ESTIMATES ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE AT 5.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development of the Executive Yuan (CEPD) estimated Friday that the nation's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent this year.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the Economic Research Department, said that due to the economic recovery in East Asia, the boom in exports and the breakthrough of the stalemate in two important build-operate-transfer (BOT) construction projects -- the Taiwan High Speed Railway and Taipei International Financing Center -- the CEPD has optimistically estimated the economic growth rate at 5.5 percent.
Hu said that six big investment projects, amounting to more than NT$100 billion (US$3.13 billion), will greatly stimulate the domestic economy.

According to the statistics made available by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics under the Executive Yuan, as a result of the government's domestic investment incentives, investment grew 6.4 percent during the first seven months of this year.

Hu noted that the implementation of all the BOT projects -- the syndicated commercial and industrial centers, the private-run power plants and industrial parks as well as the privatization of the telecommunications industry -- will stimulate domestic economic development and investor interest.

Hu added that although the housing construction is still in a recession and may affect to some degree the investment willingness of private investors, the solid performance of the semi-conductor and the liquefied crystal display sectors will help the nation achieve a 5.5 percent growth rate by the end of this year. By Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO DISCIPLINE NA PARTY MEMBERS WHO FAILED TO TOE PARTY LINE

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Friday that it will discipline party representatives at the National Assemblymen (NA) who deviate from the party's line by supporting National Assembly power-expansion and the extension of their terms.

Reiterating the party's opposition to the two proposals, DPP General Secretary Yu Hsi-kun said that any DPP assemblyman who supports the bills will be referred to the party's Central Advisory Committee for possible discipline.

Outraged by the outcome of Friday's first reading of the constitutional reform proposals, Yu said the party's Central Standing Committee was displeased with the explanation offered by the NA party whip, Chen Chin-teh, who voted in favor of the bills.
The Central Standing Committee decided on Friday that all National Assembly members, including Chen, who failed to follow the DPP's party line should be disciplined, said Yu.
Those who walked out of the conference during the ballot, will also be referred to the Central Advisory Committee to receive a reprimand.

In order to ensure that all DPP members toe the party's line during the second reading of the two bills on Aug. 31, Yu said party leaders will be present at the conference to ensure the members follow the party's directives.
The ruling Kuomintang party's National Assembly leader offered to resign after the two bills cruised through the floor.
However, the KMT party spokesman Huang Hui-chen said that KMT leaders were fully aware of Chen's effort to block the two bills and will not blame him for the outcome.
Huang said the KMT does not plan to sanction its members who supported the two bills in defiance of the party chairman Lee Teng-hui's public call on Wednesday to drop them.

He said the KMT is confident the two bills and any others which are not approved by the party authorities will be killed during the second reading when a three-fourths majority is needed to keep any bill alive for the second and the third reading.
One of the two controversial bills is designed to give the National Assembly the power to work out its own structure and approve its own budget without the interference of the Legislative Yuan.
The other bill would extend members terms in office by two years to 2002, thus aligning the election of National Assembly members and legislators.

Both bills have met strong public opposition. Public opinion shows a majority would rather downsize or abolish the relic of the Constitution drafted five decades ago that includes representation of all of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DASSAULT CEO CALLS ON ECONOMICS MINISTER WANG

TEXT.P: The chief executive officer of French aircraft manufacturer Dassault called on Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Friday seeking trade opportunities for his company's commercial aircraft in Taiwan.
Serge Dassault is reportedly highly interested in whether the ROC has a new procurement plan for purchasing commercial planes from his company.
During their talks, Wang expressed his hope that Dassault Co., the manufacturer of Mirage-2000 fighters, would continue its high-tech exchanges with ROC aircraft manufacturers.
Dassault has paid much attention to the recent China Airlines' purchase of passenger jets and cargo planes from French Airbus Industrie and the US Boeing Co.

He asked Wang whether other ROC airlines such as EVA Airways or Far East Air Transport Corp. have any intention to enlarge their aircraft fleet. If so, Dassault expressed his company is interested in supplying them.
Wang told Dassault that he was willing to tell ROC airlines that Dassault would like to be considered as an aircraft supplier.

Wang said the Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) under the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs is now undergoing privatization and is currently negotiating with overseas strategic investors. He welcomed Dassault Co. to attend the process.
Dassault said his company is willing to proceed with technological cooperative exchanges with AIDC after AIDC's privatization is completed.

Wang indicated that ROC-French economic and trade ties are moving closer. He welcomed French high ranking officials to visit the ROC and hoped Dassault would exercise its influence to promote bilateral exchanges and reciprocal visits.

Dassault welcomed the ROC's selecting aviation academy students for advanced study at the French Aviation Academy. He said his company will send representatives to the ROC for further talks on the program. Wang agreed to the student exchange program and said he will help ensure the program is implicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHI HWEI-YOW PESSIMISTIC ABOUT WANG'S VISIT

TEXT.P: Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow said on Friday that after reviewing the current cross-Strait situation, he is pessimistic Wang Dao-han, chairman of mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will visit Taiwan this fall as scheduled.
Shi, however, hoped that Wang, the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan, would visit the island sometime in the future.

In an interview with the TVBS cable television network, Shi said that scholars from both sides of the Taiwan Strait as well as from the United States have described the prospects for Wang's visit as slim.
Shi said that the SEF has not received any information from ARATS that Wang has canceled his fall visit.
A trip to Taiwan by Wang would be historic and would perceived as a major boost in the interchange between Taiwan and the mainland.
SEF and ARATS are two semi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing respectively to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contact.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Vice President Lien Chan proposes amendment of election laws to bar gangland figures from becoming candidates.
The China Times:
Power-expansion and term-extension proposals passed in first reading at National Assembly, disturbing both ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The United Daily News:
KMT party whip said he will resign over the first-reading passage of National Assembly power-expansion and term-extension proposals.
The Liberty Times:
Both party whips of Kuomintang and DPP resign and order discipline over first-reading passage of National Assembly power-expansion and term-extension proposals.
The Commons Daily:
Mainland China yet incapable of attacking Taiwan, says Defense Ministry.
The China Post:
Morgan Stanley sets fire under Taiwan stocks.
The Taiwan News:
Chinese officials tell US military action considered; America would retaliate if Taiwan is attacked, Clinton team warns.

DOC.HEADLINE: US RECEIVES NO THREATS FROM MAINLAND CHINA OVER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration said on Friday that it has not received any threats or ultimatums from mainland China on the possible use of force against Taiwan.
However, US officials once again urged both sides of the Taiwan Straits to exercise restraint and seek a peaceful resolution to their differences through dialogue.

White House National Security Council spokesman David Leavy said that President Bill Clinton can be expected to discuss Taiwan and other issues in bilateral relations when he meets mainland China's President Jiang Zemin next month on the sidelines of the APEC summit in New Zealand.

Responding to American newspaper reports that mainland Chinese officials have told US experts and policy analysts that Beijing may use force against Taiwan to curb what it sees as independence moves by Taipei authorities, Leavy pointed out that there have been no mainland Chinese threats or ultimatums conveyed through official channels.
While refusing to comment on what Chinese officials may have told private US experts, Leavy said the PRC has traditionally not ruled out the use of force with regard to the Taiwan issue.

Leavy admitted that US officials are concerned about an increase in military flights by both sides of the Taiwan Strait that could trigger accidental conflict. But he stressed that US intelligence has not detected any unusual mainland Chinese military buildup in the area, as some Hong Kong newspapers have reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 14, or the fourth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy, march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1901: An aircraft powered by an engine and designed by the Wright brothers (Orville and Wilbur) makes its maiden flight of 900 meters at an altitude of 12 meters.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The ROC Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow" press, dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1956: Bertolt Brecht, the Marxist German playwright and poet, dies at the age of 58. His works include the play "Galileo" and the libretto for Kurt Weill's "The Threepenny Opera."
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three communist MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States maintains embargo on US trade with communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1974: Greece pulls out of NATO after a breakdown of Geneva peace talks and new fighting on Cyprus.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at the Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1979: The classic Fastnet Race ends in tragedy when a Force 10 gale and mountainous seas claim the lives of 17 sailors from competing yachts.
1980: Polish workers take over a shipyard at Gdansk in Poland.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities involved in the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal: 15 financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits, or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in Burundi in east- central Africa, killing more than 24,000.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTS AGAINST JIANG ZEMIN EXPECTED IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Mainland China's President Jiang Zemin is expected to be dogged by protesters -- from Tibetans, Chinese pro-democracy activists, and supporters of the Falun Gong sect -- during his visit to Australia beginning Sept. 7.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday quoted Rinzin Zatul, president of the Tibet Independence Movement of Australia as saying that Jiang heads a nation that "abuses human rights and has illegally occupied our country. We find it a pity that the Australian government will receive the head of such a state." "We will voice our protest very strongly," he added.

The Alliance for a Democratic China-Chinese Liberal Democratic Party in Australia, and members of the Falun Gong sect, said they will also organize groups to protest Beijing's arrests of Chinese dissidents and sect leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE OFFICIALS IN TOWN FOR AIR TALKS

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Assistant Secretary for Legal Affairs of the Philippines Franklin Ebdalin flew into Taipei on Saturday to meet Republic of China officials for discussions on alleged breaches of an air agreement between the two countries.

Speaking to local reporters upon his arrival at the airport, Ebdalin, a member of the Philippine Civil Aeronautics Board, said there should be no big problems preventing the two sides from continuing their aviation agreement, so long as several amendments can be made.
Ebdalin was accompanied by Eva Estrada Kalaw, board chairwoman of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) in Taipei.
Manila in early August threatened to scrap the air accord with Taipei, and to stop allowing Taiwan carriers to ply Philippine routes from Sept. 30 if no new agreement is negotiated by then.

Ebdalin said besides meeting with ROC officials for talks on the pact, he will also meet with Philippine officials stationed in Taiwan to brief them on Manila's latest position on the air agreement and other issues.

Kalaw, who is familiar with Taiwan affairs and Manila-Taipei relations, stressed that Taiwan and the Philippines have maintained close and cordial ties over the past years, and added that the last thing she would like to see is the two friendly countries at loggerheads over "trivial" issues.

Kalaw was referring to several events, including a brawl between local and Philippine players during the Jones Cup Basketball Tournament held recently in Taipei. The Philippine team stormed out of the competition the day after the fight, and refused to apologize to the Taiwan players for instigating the fracas.

Meanwhile, officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said they would like to meet with Ebdalin and Kalaw for talks over the next few days, but they stressed that Taipei will ask for an explanation from Ebdalin about "improper remarks" which he made recently.

According to reports from Manila, Ebdalin said during an aviation discussion with Taipei representatives last month that since Taiwan maintains no official relations with the Philippines, the aviation agreement signed in 1996 between Manila and Taipei was only a "technical agreement between two civil groups" which could be nullified with a domestic order from the Philippine side alone.

Unconfirmed sources said MOFA officials will ask Ebdalin to clarify the remarks before proceeding with any negotiations concerning the air pact, to find out whether his remarks represent just his own opinion or that of his government. They added that the remarks have shaken the foundation for cooperation between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN SMOKERS ALLOWED TO SUE TOBACCO FIRMS

TEXT.P: An Australian federal judge has made a landmark resolution clearing the way for up to 40,000 Australian smokers to sue tobacco firms for causing their smoking-related diseases contracted over the last two decades.

Justice Murray Wilcox on Friday rejected an application by the tobacco firms to dismiss the class action in which six people with lung cancer allege negligence by the companies under the Trade Practices Act between Oct. 1, 1974 and April 16, 1996.

The judge said the action will proceed, possibly as early as March 2000. So far, 2,500 Australians have joined the class action. Tobacco firms are expected to contest the ruling, and legal experts believe it will be a long battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACEH BECOMING INDONESIA'S HEADACHE AS REBELS WAGE MEDIA WAR

TEXT.P: Aceh is becoming a headache for the Indonesian government because rebels in the northwestern tip of Sumatra have started a media war in addition to their guerrilla war in the jungles against Indonesian troops.

In a dispatch from Aceh, the Australian Financial Review on Saturday reported that the rebels have quickly adjusted to the media war with sit-ins and mass movements of refugees, keeping their cause on the world's TV screens.
For nearly 10 years, former president Suharto's army fought the rebels in Aceh in a shadowy conflict which rarely made world headlines.

The fiercely independent and strongly Muslim inhabitants of Aceh have been at war with their overlords -- first the Dutch, then the Japanese, and now the Indonesians -- for all but 16 of the past 125 years.
Human rights groups say at least 4,000 people have been killed or gone missing in Aceh in the present rebellion which started in 1989, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AERONAUTICS INDUSTRY KEY TO NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is poised to expand Taiwan's aeronautics industry, as development in this sector is one of the benchmarks of an advanced country, Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday.

As the nation prepares to enter the 21st century, Siew said, the aeronautics industry is high on the government's national development agenda, as advances in the high value-added industry will help create job opportunities and upgrade the national image.
After a long period of effort and promotion, the premier continued, there are currently 239 firms in Taiwan's aeronautics sector, with total investments of at least US$730 million.

He made the remarks while addressing the inauguration of the two-day "1999 Aeronautics Exhibition" sponsored jointly by the Economic Affairs Ministry, the National Defense Ministry and the Taoyuan County Government at the Taoyuan Air Force Base in northern Taiwan.
Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang, Vice National Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, and Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu were also present at the opening ceremony.

Thanking the relevant authorities for their efforts in organizing the event, Siew said the exhibition, in addition to marking the 62nd anniversary of the "814 Air Force Victory," is also aimed at allowing the people of Taiwan to gain a fuller understanding of the air force's combat strength.

Apart from an aerobatics flight by locally built Indigenous Defense Fighters, the air force also mounted a ground exhibition of the island's French-made Mirage-5s and US-made F-16 jet fighters, OH58D reconnaissance helicopters, Cobra AW-IW combat helicopters and TH67 training helicopters, as well as S708M and MD500 helicopters belonging to the navy.

DOC.HEADLINE: `SPECIAL RELATIONSHIP' THEORY WINS WIDESPREAD SUPPORT: POLL

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relationship" theory has won widespread support from the heads of Taiwan's 319 counties and cities, according to the results of the latest poll.

According to the survey results revealed by Kuomintang Legislator Chen Horng-chi at a news conference on Saturday, 86 percent of the respondents agree with the view that Lee's airing of the term was aimed at increasing Taiwan's bargaining power with mainland China at the negotiating table and expanding the island's niche in the international community.

Some 46 percent of those polled said they highly support Lee's redefinition of Taiwan's ties with mainland China, while 59 percent said they agree in principle, but feel that the issue could have been downplayed, the poll indicated. Another 58 percent opined that the public should have been informed before Lee spelled out the issue.

Despite the fact that 60 percent of the respondents agreed that Lee's statement has escalated tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, some 77 percent still said they believe his statement will help lay a solid foundation for long-term cross-strait exchanges.

In terms of Taiwan's relations with the United States, around 66 percent said they do not think Lee's words have had a negative impact, well ahead of 22 percent who said they think the relationship has been adversely affected.

At the same time, some 53 percent said they believe that Lee's "two-state relationship" theory will influence the results of Taiwan's next presidential election slated for March 2000, according to the survey.

More than 62 percent said they think that the ruling KMT's presidential candidate, Vice President Lien Chan, will be most benefited by Lee's remarks, while 26 percent said it will be Chen Shui-bian, the contender fielded by the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Only 11 percent pointed to former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong.
The public opinion survey was conducted from Aug. 6-1. About 83 percent of the respondents are KMT members, while 11 percent are DPP members. The remaining six percent have no party affiliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CANNOT AFFORD TO KEEP APPEASING CHINA: US CONGRESSMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: The United States cannot afford to keep appeasing China, otherwise in a few years the United States will discover that its world leadership has been overtaken by China with disastrous consequences following, US Congressman Bob Barr (R-Ga.) said Friday.
The Republican congressman from Georgia pointed out in a statement issued by his office that the biggest mistake free countries have made in the 20th century is appeasing tyrants.
Before World War II broke out, democratic European countries including England and France believed that as long as they agreed to Hitler's demands, he would leave them alone, he said.

However, Barr continued, that appeasement policy directly led to the massacres of World War II. He challenged that the Clinton administration obviously has not learned from this historical lesson the consequences of appeasing tyranny.

In the past few years, the White House under President Bill Clinton's leadership has not been able to prevent mainland China, which is gradually leaning towards expansionism, from threatening Japan, Taiwan and the Philippines, he said.
What is more deplorable is that mainland China's record of oppression is not restricted to its foreign diplomatic policy, the congressman went on.
During this period, Beijing has kept up a cruel suppression of its own people, oppressing democracy activists and arresting others for their religious belief, he said.
Worst of all, he added, mainland China continues the practice of forced abortion under its Stalinist family planning policy.

Moreover, he said, Beijing has directly destroyed the United States' election system and conducted espionage activities by stealing US nuclear secrets. Recently, mainland China has further advocated attacks against the US embassy, and even issued threats against the US parliament.

In response, he said, Clinton merely used the US Department of Commerce to encourage American companies to export its newest technologies to mainland China, including instrument planes, super computers and communication equipment that will reinforce mainland Chinese military strength.

Barr said that the Justice Department under the Clinton administration has also effectively prevented any prosecutions against those participating in mainland Chinese espionage activities or illegal campaign fund contributions.

Last month, Barr said, Clinton accorded mainland China most favored nation treatment, worth billions of dollars. The right-wing conservative continued that at the end of this year, the Clinton Administration will give up control of the sea ports on both sides of the Panama Canal.
And finally, he said, despite Beijing's unceasing threats toward Taiwan, the Clinton administration has failed to declare continued US support for Taiwan's safety.

"The United States cannot afford to keep appeasing China," Barr said, otherwise in a few short years the United States might discover that it is facing a serious displacement role, and "might suffer disastrous consequences."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAPABLE OF DETERRING PRC CRUISE MISSILE ATTACK: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's military is capable of deterring an attack by the mainland Chinese cruise missiles which Beijing authorities claimed have been successfully developed and deployed in major bases targeting Taiwan, a military strategist said on Saturday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chung-ping, who is a Beijing military development expert, said Taiwan cannot afford to underestimate mainland China's military research and development capabilities.

Taiwan should watch closely not only the People's Liberation Army's ballistic missile attacks, but also the overall "acupuncture point poking" warfare capability that the PLA may launch at any moment, Lin warned.
Acupuncture point warfare refers to the application of information or other technologies to paralyze an enemy's military command and control centers.

Lin said cruise missiles are comparatively more threatening to Taiwan than ballistic missiles, as cruise missiles are self-contained bombs that can cruise and change course according to geographic changes. Moreover, cruise missiles cannot be detected and are not easily destroyed.

The top brass at the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology, at a recent ceremony marking the institute's 30th founding anniversary, told President Lee Teng-hui that Chungshan has successfully researched and developed a vehicle-mounted anti-air weapon radar system which could be effective in deterring PLA cruise missile attacks, according to Lin.
The newest generation of the radar system will be mass-produced in the near future and then deployed as the backbone of Taiwan's defense against low-flying weapons, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 AVIATION EXHIBITION HELD AT TAOYUAN AIR BASE

TEXT.P: The two-day 1999 Aviation Exhibition opened on Saturday at the Taoyuan air base, sponsored jointly by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of National Defense, and the Taoyuan County government.
Speaking at the opening ceremony, Premier Vincent Siew said that the development of the aviation and space industries, a government priority for 2000, will help promote Taiwan's international image.

In addition to Siew, Vice Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-pang, Taoyuan County Magistrate Annettee Lu, and Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min also attended the event.

As part of the event, the Taoyuan and Hualien air bases were opened to the public, and various types of fighters and other air force hardware were put on display. A highlight was an aerial performance by the Indigenous Defense Fighter wing.
In related news, Air Force Headquarters held a celebration the previous day to commemorate the 62nd anniversary of the air force's "814 victory."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MOURNS YUNLIN COUNTY MAGISTRATE'S DEATH

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-huei on Saturday morning mourned with the family of Yunlin County Magistrate Su Wen-hsiung's death and pledged to assist Su's dying wish of establishing a branch school of the National Taiwan University (NTU) in Yunlin.
Su, 56, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) magistrate, died of liver failure at the National Taiwan University Hospital on Thursday after a long fight with liver disease.

Lee, accompanied by Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Huang Kun-huei as well as other government officials, arrived at Su's residence in Central Taiwan and had a brief talk with Su' family after the acts of condolence.
Su Kuo-hua pointed out that his father strove to establish a Yunlin branch of NTU during his tenure.

In addition, Secretary-General of the Kuomintang Central Commission John Chang, president hopefuls Chen Shui-bian and Hsu Hsin-liang as well as other government officials and legislators also mourned Su's passing.

In regard to the election to fill Su's post as the Yunlin County magistrate, Chang said that currently many people within the KMT have shown interest in being a candidate and that the party will follow regulations in nominating a candidate as soon as possible.
Yunlin County councilman Chen Kuo-sung expressed his hope to Chang that the KMT would nominate a candidate for the race rather than adopt an open-election policy within the party.
Chang said he would consult local politicians for their input next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT MARSHALL ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee is scheduled to leave for the Marshall Islands Monday for a four-day official visit, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Saturday.
Lee, at the head of a 140-member Taiwan delegation, will meet with Marshall Islands' President Imata Kabua, Foreign Minister Phillip Muller and other ranking government officials during his stay.

Lee will accompany members of a Republic of China agricultural technology mission, the first of its kind ever to be stationed in the Central Pacific country. Lee will also preside over the opening of a new ROC-aid farming ranch.

Other prominent members of Lee's entourage include Senior Presidential Adviser Huang Hsin-chieh, Vice Education Minister Yang Kuo-tsu, as well as several legislators and city councilmen from Taichung, according to MOFA officials.

Also in Lee's delegation will be representatives from the Republic of China Boat Fishing Association and the Taipei Travel Agency Association, who will estimate the tourism resources and potential of the Pacific Ocean island-country.
The Republic of China established formal diplomatic relations with the Marshall Islands in November of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VICTIM OF IDAHO CAR ACCIDENT IN CRITICAL CONDITION
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan student involved in a car accident that killed four other local students Thursday, remains in a coma after emergency head and chest surgery.
Kuo Wei-chieh was listed in "critical" condition Friday, according to Frank Liu, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Seattle.
Kuo's has a serious head wound, and although doctors have treated most of his blood clots, his face is still badly swollen and the pressure on his brain maintains at a dangerous high level, Liu said.

Four of the 10 Taiwan students on their way to Yellowstone Park were killed when their rented van rolled over in eastern Idaho near the national park. The accident occurred when the driver, Hsue Ya-wen, lost control while trying to avoid hitting a squirrel.
Hsue and four other passengers suffered injuries, with Kuo being the most serious. The injured are now at three different city hospitals receiving treatment.
The students are all attending either Pace University in New York or Baruch College of the City University of New York.
Idaho police speculated that the serious injuries resulted because few of the passengers had buckled their seat-belts.
The police investigation will not be complete until next week, according a police spokesman.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan college and university student union in New York on Friday launched a relief campaign on the Baruch College campus, hoping to raise funds to refer the medical costs of the victims.
Some of the injured may not have medical insurance, likely straining their financial situation, the convener of the student union, Liu Yuan-ping, said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SCHOLAR: 'STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY HISTORICALLY CORRECT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun and Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's "special state to state relations" theory merely states an historical fact, a mainland Chinese professor residing in the United States said Thursday.

Xin Haonian, a visiting professor of East Asian studies at Columbia University, made the remarks in his speech on Lee's "special state to state relations" theory at a Chinese reunification conference in New York City.
Xin stressed in his speech that the ROC, founded by Dr. Sun Yatsen, did not disappear when the Chinese communists took over the mainland in 1949.
The ROC on Taiwan possesses land, people and a administrative government, he pointed out, adding that its historical and factual legitimacy is indisputable.
The professor said that Lee did not propose the establishment of a "Republic of Taiwan," thus Beijing's attacks on him were "groundless."
He also said that the day mainland China attacks Taiwan is the day Beijing authorities fall from power.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE SUPPORT STATE-TO-STATE THEORY: OCAC MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Huang Wen-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Most overseas Chinese appear to support President Lee Teng-hui's call for mainland China to deal with Taiwan on a state-to-state basis, the minister of Taiwan's cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) said on Friday.
Chiao Jen-ho said Lee has concretely defined the vague cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship," declaring that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are equal.
Chiao is visiting Los Angeles inspecting the services OCAC providing to overseas Chinese in the LA vicinity who support the Republic of China on Taiwan.

Chiao said at a CNA interview that he has found most overseas Chinese assert that Taiwan and mainland China should continue boosting mutual relations through peaceful methods. However, his surveys have found most overseas Chinese believe Taiwan should not sacrifice its equality for harmony, he said.
The ROC insists that when the two sides conduct political dialogue they must treat each other as equal and sovereign political bodies, Chiao stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMEN ON VISIT

TEXT.P: Three members of the Armed Forces Committee of the US House of Representative flew into Taipei Saturday for a two-day visit.

"We are here to learn about the military situation in Taiwan and find out if the United States can do anything to meet Taiwan's military needs," said Lindsey Graham, a Republican representative from South Carolina.
Graham, who is on his first-ever visit to Taiwan, told the media at the airport that he personally will fully support Taiwan getting what it requires to fulfill its economic and military needs.
Graham, Solomon Ortiz (R-Tx) and Jerry Weller (R-Il) will meet with President Lee Teng-hui and top ROC military brass to discuss Taiwan's military needs and other issues.
The three congressmen were accompanied by Jim Walker, a military officer, as well as business and trade representatives from the three states they represent.

The visitors were met at the airport by officials from the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S UN BID ATTRACTING INTERNATIONAL ATTENTION

TEXT.P: Twelve countries friendly to the Republic of China have requested that the United Nations discuss their proposal on Taiwan rejoining the UN during its 54th session which opens in the middle of September.
This is the seventh consecutive year that the ROC has taken action to rejoin the world body through the help of friendly countries.

Some political observers say that this year's bid is expected to draw more international attention because ROC President Lee Teng-hui's recent redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Accompanied with the proposal is an explanatory memorandum indicating that each side of the Taiwan Strait has been ruled by a distinct and separate government since 1949 as well as a draft resolution demanding the UN establish a working group on the issue.

This year, the proposal was signed by Burkina Faso, Gambia, Swaziland, Liberia, Senegal, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Honduras.
The number of signing countries is larger than 1998's 11 countries and 1997's nine countries, but less than 1966's 16 countries.

Panama, Guatemala and Costa Rica have not signed the proposal for three consecutive years. Macedonia, which forged diplomatic relations with the ROC in January of this year and is the recipient of a large Taiwan aid package, is also not one of the signatory countries.
The ROC's basic stance for striving to rejoin the UN has not changed, and its policy of continuing to promote the bid until it meets ultimate success remains unchanged.

However, there is a difference in tactics compared with previous years' attempts. ROC Vice Foreign Minister David Lee has stated that this year the ROC will take a "rational, moderate and goodwill" approach in pursuing the country's basic rights, while demonstrating the "equality concept" as displayed in President Lee's "special state-to-state theory."
According to Lee, UN membership is one part of the island's overall diplomatic strategy and is a long-term goal of the government. He admitted that immediate results are not expected.

The spokesman for mainland China's UN Mission, Chen Zanfeng, on Aug. 12 described Taiwan's bid as "a revelation that the Taiwan authorities' are pursuing splittism." He said the 12-country proposal this year is certain to fail, the same as the past six attempts.

No matter what the consequence will be, this issue, however, is expected to focus more international attention on the unreasonable exclusion of Taiwan from the UN. (By David Wang & Victor Lai) EDITERM

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING COULD CRACK DOWN ON A SISTER SECT OF FALUN GONG

TEXT.P: Xiang Gong, a variant of qigong being practiced by some 30 million people in mainland China, could become a new target of government crackdown, a human rights group said here Saturday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that Xiang Gong, which is similar to Falun Gong, has rapidly developed into a powerful spiritual movement worrying Beijing leaders. Many senior members of the Chinese communist party are followers of the Xiang Gong sect.
Founded in 1988 by its leader Tian Ruisheng, the sect has now 1,200 practice centers in mainland China and has followers in more than 40 other countries in the world, the center said.

Like Falun Gong, Xiang Gong combines traditional Chinese breathing and meditation exercises with religious teachings. In Chinese, Xiang means "fragrance." It is said that after a long period of practicing, the body of Xiang Gong practitioners may become strong and have pleasant smell.

Unlike Falun Gong founder Li Hongzhi, who is a legal US resident in New York, Tian, 73, lives in Loyang city, Henan province, in northern China. His three children, who have promoted Xiang Gong in various parts of the country, are also living in mainland China.
The mainland Chinese government banned Falun Gong as an illegal organization and issued a warrant to arrest Li last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: USA WINS IBA BIG LEAGUE BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The United States defeated Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association (IBA) Big League Championship in Kaohsiung on Saturday.
In the heated match before some 20,000 fans, each team used four pitchers trying to block their rivals. But Chinese-Taipei still managed to blast 11 safeties, while the US team recorded 13 hits.
Phil Clark, chief coach of the US team, was excited over the victory, and cited a good rotation of pitchers keeping them in their best conditions as an indispensable factor for winning the final.
Chinese-Taipei's coach, Tsai Chi-sheng, blamed poor defense of his team for losing the deciding game to the US team.
Earlier, Cuba beat Panama 8-0 to rank third place. Panama was fourth.

The rankings of other teams were Japan and South Korea, sharing fifth place; Venezuela, seventh place; Australia, eighth place; the Czech Republic and South Africa, sharing ninth place; Guam and the Netherlands, sharing 11th place.
The 10-day event opened at the Kaohsiung County Baseball Stadium on Aug. 5. Next year, the IBA championship will be held in Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN, SOONG WOO SUPPORT IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan and former Taiwan Governor James Soong held respective rallies in Taipei County on Saturday night to seek support for their presidential bids.
Both contenders for next March's presidential election took advantage of the opportunities to spell out some outlines of their domestic and foreign policies.

Lien told the rally in Hsinchuang City that the government will not agree to establishment of direct trade, transportation and communication links with mainland China, unless the island's security has obtained full protection.

He stressed the need for Taiwan to participate in international affairs with dignity and with a pragmatic attitude, and said that Taiwan deserves its right to join the US-proposed theater missile defense system.
The vice president will be formally named as the ruling Kuomintang's candidate for the presidential race later this month.

Meanwhile, Soong told his supporters at a rally in Yungho City that if he becomes the president, he will form a government with elites from all parties, and the priority of the government will be given to the people's welfare.
He said the Taiwan people will never accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, but added that Taiwan should avoid making a showdown with mainland China.

Regarding President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship," Soong said that it still requires a review over the timing and process of presenting such redefinition.
Many prominent political figures and legislators attended the rallies for Lien and Soong to show their respective support for the two rivaling presidential hopefuls.

Former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, whom both the Lien and Soong camps are trying to woo, remained neutral at this moment, saying that like other voters he has only one vote, and he will cast his vote to the best candidate.

Wu Poh-hsiung, senior adviser to the president, has not given up his hope of becoming the running mate of the KMT presidential candidate. He told the media in Taichung that what Lien and Soong should do is "competition," not "struggle."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 15, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. Legend of his rise to power and reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1856: James Keir Hardie, Scottish politician and founder of the British Labour Party, is born.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1908: German women are permitted to enter the University of Prussia.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of digging.
1945: The ROC Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with General Chen Cheng as governor.
