1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules ground-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan ruled that, according to Article 77 of the Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner sank after hitting an iceberg during her maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying 3,657 meters deep under the Atlantic Ocean.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen-kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists of the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-some years had won international recognition and was an indispensable strength against communist expansion in the Asian-Pacific area.
1987: Corporal punishment is banned in Britain except in private schools.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel prize winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was expelled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missiles exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Taipei County voters rally in solidarity with Lien Chan.
The China Times:
Presidential hopefuls Lien Chan and James Soong hold campaign rallies simultaneously in Taipei County.
The United Daily News:
Both Lien and Soong campaign in Taipei County.
The Liberty Times:
Lien Chan lashes out at James Soong at a campaign rally for the first time.
The Commons Daily:
Clinton warns mainland China against taking Taiwan by force.
The China Post:
Taipei County hosts Lien, Soong rallies.
The Taiwan News:
Taipei, Manila agree to a truce in their air dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS SUPPORTERS OF LIEN CHAN TO GATHER IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Leaders of Vice President Lien Chan's overseas supporters will gather in Taipei on Aug. 26 in a show of solidarity with Lien in his bid for president in 2000, said the secretary-general of the headquarters of the Association of Lien's Overseas Friends, Winston Lih-yeu Yang, on Friday.

The Chinese-American professor at Seton Hall University, located in South Orange, New Jersey, said that some 550 leaders from various chapters of the Association of Lien's Overseas Friends will take part in the rally in Taipei.

They will sign a declaration in support of Lien's presidential bid at the rally in front of Lien and leaders of Lien's domestic supporters. Premier Vincent Siew, President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, Speaker of the National Assembly Su Nan-cheng and Kuomingtang Secretary-General John Chang will be among those present, said Yang.
President Lee Teng-hui, who is the political mentor of Lien, is expected to meet with Lien's supporters on that afternoon, said Yang.
Noting that there are 128 chapters of the Association of Lien's Overseas Friends around the world, Yang said Lien has the most supporters abroad of the four presidential hopefuls.
Lien's arch-rival, James Soong, has about 20 such groups, and Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian has about 30.

ROC nationals living outside Taiwan can vote in presidental elections, provided they have registered with their local ROC representative office. Even those who are ineligible to vote can help out by drumming up support for Lien among relatives and friends at home, Yang said.
Some of the supporters will come to Taiwan to campaign for Lien personally, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US POLICE WILL NOT TAKE LEGAL ACTION AGAINST TAIWAN VAN DRIVER
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Police in Idaho's Fremont County said Saturday they do not plan to take any legal action against the Taiwan driver of a van that rolled over, killing four Taiwan students and injuring six others early Thursday morning.
The students were injured when the van, driven by Hsueh Ya-wen, rolled over near Fremont County, eastern Idaho, while en route to Yellowstone National Park from New York, where they were studying.

A high-ranking officer from the Fremont County police department told CNA that Hsueh was both physically and mentally injured by the accident. He said both the local prosecutors and police believe that even if Hsueh was negligent, taking legal action against her is unnecessary and meaningless.
An investigation of the accident is underway, said the police officer, adding that it will likely be completed by Monday.
According to a Taiwan student who suffered a minor injury in the accident, the van rolled over after Hsueh swerved to avoid hitting a squirrel that suddenly appeared on the road.
But a police officer from Fremont County noted that the skid marks left by the van's tires did not suggest the brakes were hit suddenly, and he said he was skeptical about Hsueh's story.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW POLL GIVES CABINET 53 PERCENT APPROVAL RATING

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew's Cabinet has an approval rating of 53 percent, while the job performance of Siew himself is approved by 68 percent of the public, according to a opinion poll released on Sunday.
The figures were included in a survey, conducted by the non-profit Association for Public Opinion Research.

The survey also shows that nearly 70 percent of the surveyed knew of Siew's trip to Macedonia between Aug. 3 and 9, and 71 percent said they believe overseas trips by government leaders will boost the country's international profile and deepen understandings between the country and its allies.

In the poll, 60 percent of those interviewed said they are satisfied with the government's handling of the islandwide power failure on July 29 that inflicted serious damage to the island's wafer foundry industry and caused snarled traffic around the island.

Meanwhile, 56 percent of the people polled said they agreed with the steps taken by the government to cope with the Asian financial crisis that wrought havoc on regional economies between 1997 and 1998.
As to the top concerns of those interviewed, social peace and order, traffic infrastructure and economic development were the ones most often mentioned.
The poll was carried out between Aug. 10 and 12 among 1,141 adults around the island via telephone. It had a margin of error of 5 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: OBSTACLES IN ROC-PHILIPPINE AVIATION TALKS REMOVED: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press release late Saturday that through negotiations with Philippine officials, obstacles to talks on Republic of China-Philippine aviation rights have been eliminated.

MOFA officials met with Eva Estrada-Kalaw, chairman of the Philippines' Manila Economic and Cultural Office, and Franklin Ebdalin, director of the Department of Treaty and Legal Affairs under the Philippine Foreign Ministry, on the restoration of bilateral aviation talks.

Shih Ting, director of the Department of Asia-Pacific Affairs under MOFA, reiterated at Saturday's talks that the wording and measures adopted by the Philippine side in July to revoke the 1996 ROC-Philippine aviation accord has severely undermined mutual trust and friendship and has damaged the foundation for various agreements and cooperative relations between the two countries.

He said he hopes that the Philippine government, in consideration of bilateral interests, will deal with the dispute rationally to rebuild a foundation for mutual trust and cooperation in hopes of restoring the 1996 bilateral aviation agreement.

The Philippine side reiterated that the Philippines values the friendship between the two countries and various cooperative relations. The Philippine side also expressed their intention to clarify misunderstandings on crucial issues related to the ROC-Philippine aviation accord to address ROC concerns.
The Philippines maintains that the 1996 ROC-Philippine aviation pact has not been revoked.
MOFA said the ROC hopes both sides will negotiate the issue rationally and reach an arrangement that can be accepted by both sides.

The Philippines unilaterally suspended the 1996 ROC-Philippine aviation accord in July on the grounds that the ROC's China Airlines was using large passenger jets on its Taipei-Manila service, a violation of the bilateral aviation pact.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTER TO VISIT MARSHALL ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee is scheduled to head for the Marshall Islands on Aug. 16 with some 140 representatives and delegates for a three-day official visit.

Senior adviser to the President Huang Hsin-chien, Vice Education Minister Yang Kuo-tsu, legislators, delegates from business circles and the tourism industry and members of Taiwan's agricultural technical mission to the country will be among the delegates.
During the visit, the delegates are expected to meet with Marshall Island's President Imata Kabua, Foreign Minister Philip Muller and other government officials.

The delegation will attend an inauguration ceremony for "Farm Laura," an experimental farm to be used by Taiwan's agricultural technical mission. They will also take part in panel discussion on issues of mutual cooperation.
Apart from official activities, the delegates from Taiwan's tourism industry will explore local sightseeing spots for Taiwan travelers' reference.
The delegation is slated to return to Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO US SPEAKS ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT TENSION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Stephen Chen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, said in an interview carried by the Nihon Keizai Shimbun daily on Sunday that if the military tension in the Taiwan Strait escalates, the United States will support Taiwan.

In the interview conducted in Washington, D.C., Chen indicated that Taiwan has recently obtained assurances from the Clinton administration and the Congress that the United States' commitment to honoring the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) remains unchanged.
According to the TRA, a threat to Taiwan's security will be considered a vital concern to the United States, Chen told the Japanese daily.
So the United States would come to Taiwan's aid if the situation in the strait worsened, he said.
Nevertheless, Chen stressed that Taiwan will continue its efforts to engage in a peaceful dialogue with mainland China.
He said that Taiwan still welcomes Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to visit Taipei this fall.

Exchanges between ARATS and Taipei's Strait Exchange Foundation have come to a standstill since ROC President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" in early July.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC CHAIRMAN VISITS SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Huang Wen-tsung and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), on Thursday donated US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
The gifts are part of the ROC government's support for the federation and is aimed at promoting Chinese-language education in the United States, he told leaders of the area's Chinese community.

Chiao also revealed that the OCAC has already spent about NT$100 million to establish a worldwide network for Chinese-language teaching, and will spend an additional NT$240 million in the next year on software.
On Thursday, the OCAC chief also attended an annual sports meet of the Chinese community in the San Francisco Bay area, which attracted about 6,000 participants.
Messages from ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew were read at the event's opening ceremony.
Among the participating teams were visiting teams formed by alumni of Chiao Tung University residing in Taiwan, Shanghai and Xian.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN'S TAKE ON 'STATE-TO-STATE' GAINS MOST PUBLIC SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan's assertion that Beijing's leaders should recognize the Republic of China's existence is the most heavily supported statement on the matter among Taiwan's four presidential hopefuls, according to polls conducted by Kaohsiung's National Sun Yat-sen University.

In a public survey on presidential candidates' views toward President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-state relationship" remark, Lien received support from 79.6 percent of respondents, topping all other candidates.
Lien asserted that Beijing's leaders should recognize the Republic of China's existence and that both sides of Taiwan Strait should resolve the dispute peacefully and sincerely.

Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong's position on the matter was supported by 42.1 percent of those interviewed. He said that because the United States does not understand the ROC's assertion, it should not label Taiwan a "troublemaker."

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian received support from 58.2 percent of respondents for saying President Lee Teng-hui should establish a group to engage in nationwide consultations to reach a consensus on the theory, since the security of the Taiwan Strait will affect the security of the Asia-Pacific region.
Hsu Hsin-lian, a former DPP chairman who is running as an independent, won support from 42.7 percent of respondents for his position.

The same survey also showed that Lien topped the four hopefuls in terms of their ability to stabilize Taiwan's political and security situation. Some 33.2 percent of respondents called Lien the most able of the four candidates to do so, while 27.2 percent said Soong was best able to provide stability.
The polls were conducted from Aug. 5 to Aug. 9 and included 1,092 responses. There was a margin error of 2.79 percentage points in the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN URGED TO MONITOR HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATION IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Fifty-six mainland Chinese dissidents living overseas in exile have jointly sent a letter to UN Secretary General Kofi Annan, saying that the United Nations should closely monitor the worsening human rights condition in mainland China.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that among them are such prominent dissidents as Wang Xize, Yan Jiaqi, Wang Dan, Wang Juntao, and Wang Bingzhang.

The letter said the human rights condition in mainland China is worsening, as can be seen from the recent government crackdown on dissent. Since NATO bombing of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgrade in early May, at least 14 dissidents have been sentenced to long prison terms. Twenty more could be convicted soon for their political beliefs, it added.
If the mainland Chinese government is allowed by the UN to violate human rights relentlessly, the situations in mainland China will get even worse, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
George Bush Jr. says if he is elected next US president, he will uphold commitment to helping defend Taiwan.
The China Times:
Credit departments of 160 local farmers associations around the island are poorly managed and need restructuring.
The United Daily News:
Two Republican presidential hopefuls -- George Bush Jr. and Elizabeth Dole -- say they would use US forces if necessary to defend Taiwan from communist Chinese invasion.
The Liberty Times:
George Bush Jr. says he might use force to defend Taiwan against aggression from communist China if he were elected next US president.
The Commons Daily:
Both George Bush Jr. and Elizabeth Dole say if they were elected, they would not rule out the possibility of using US forces to help protect Taiwan from communist attack.
The China Post:
Presidential hopefuls vie for Hakka votes.
The Taiwan News:
Bush backs Taiwan, blasts Clinton policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 16, or the sixth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1886: Ramakrishna, the Indian Hindu saint and religious educator, dies. He taught the essential unity and truth of all religions.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine at Anshan in Liaoning province in Manchuria, where Japan had extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant at Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli statesman and prime minister of Israel from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt against Japanese rule of Taiwan in Tahu, Hsinchu County, in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli statesman and prime minister of Israel from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council meeting decides that the National government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China armed forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the major league home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21) and again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly consisting of eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies from heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing at his mansion in Memphis, Tennessee.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. As Progressive Conservative Party prime minister, he lost the 1963 election because of opposition to proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns US President George Bush that thousands of the troops he sent to the Gulf would return home in coffins.
1993: The 14th National Congress of the Kuomintang opens.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; critically to inquire into it; carefully to ponder over it; clearly to sift it; and earnestly to carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SAID TO HAVE IMPORTED GERMAN NAZI SCIENTISTS

TEXT.P: Australia competed with Russia and other nations in importing at least 127 German Nazi scientists and technicians, who were recruited between 1946 and 1951 to do security clearances for weapons development and rocket research at Woomera in South Australia, The Sydney Morning Herald reported on Monday.

In addition to the 31 Nazi Party members, a further 12 belonged to other Nazi groups, and others were key figures in the German military during the war. Six were in the Schutzstaffel, or SS, or had been storm-troopers with the Sturn Abteilung (SA) brownshirts, the daily reported.

The daily reported Nazi scientists brought to Australia after World War II were used in secret government defense projects, including weapons and rocket propulsion research. Some were employed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALANDERS COULD VOTE FOR REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: New Zealanders are ready to follow their Australian brothers and sisters and put the issue of republicanism to a vote as Canberra has set Nov. 6 as the date for the referendum to decide the future of the country.

The New Zealand Press Associates (NZPA) on Sunday reported that Dr. Alan Webster and Paul Perry, compilers of the long-running New Zealand Study of Values, said while 63 percent of those polled a decade ago were against becoming a republic, by last year, only 40 percent were against.
The NZPA quoted Prime Minister Jenny Shipley as saying that she did not believe any change was imminent. "It is rarely raised with me," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BADLY NEEDS US MISSILE DEFENSE SYSTEM: MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China badly needs US-developed missile defense system to upgrade its capability to cope with mainland China's low-altitude cruise missiles, ROC Defense Minister Tang Fei said in an interview with the Defense News weekly.

The American weekly said in its latest issue that mainland China's purchase of 60 Russian-made Su-30 advanced fighter jets has prompted the ROC government to adjust its air-defense strategy, including beefing up air-defense facilities and air combat capabilities in eastern Taiwan.

In another Taipei-datelined report appearing in the same issue of the weekly, Minister Tang said if communist China uses missiles or other conventional military forces to attack Taiwan, the ROC economy would be seriously affected. Therefore, he said, Taiwan must make proper investment in the military field to offset pressure from mainland China's military build-up, particularly its ballistic missiles, cruise missiles and satellite technology.

Tang told the Defense News that the ROC is studying how to enhance its defense capabilities against low-altitude missiles. In addition to developing its own missile defense system, Tang said Taiwan is very interested in purchasing US-made Patriot III modified missile defense system and Aegis radar system
Tang said acquiring Aegis radar system is critical to upgrade Taiwan's ability to intercept low-altitude cruise missiles from mainland China.

During the 1999 ROC-US military meeting held in Washington, D.C. in April, the United States tentatively agreed to provide Taiwan with early warning radar system. Nevertheless, the Clinton administration is still mulling some details concerning the deal.

The Defense News said the Clinton administration has also agreed to sell six additional sets of Patriot missile defense system to Taiwan to help fortify air-defense facilities in major areas outside Taipei. However, the weekly said, the quantity and quality Taiwan demands are far higher than what the United States has agreed to offer.

Quoting a congressional report unveiled in February on the military build-up on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the weekly said Taiwan's biggest disadvantage lies in its limited ability to fight against mainland China's ever-growing ballistic missiles.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: MILOSEVIC ASKED TO RELEASE AUSTRALIANS CONVICTED FOR SYPING

TEXT.P: The pregnant wife of Steve Pratt, an Australian relief worker being jailed in Belgrade on charges of spying for NATO, has sent a video-taped appeal directly to President Slobodan Milosevic after a series of attempts by Pope John Paul II and other leaders failed to secure their release.

Samira Pratt is due to give birth on Aug. 30 and is desperate to have her husband released. To secure her husband's release, she has recorded a two-minute video message to Milosevic, asking for clemency.
Also jailed are Peter Wallace and Yugoslav colleague Branko Jelen. The three were convicted and sentenced for spying for NATO during the recent US-led bombing on Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ESTABLISH TIES WITH THE STATE OF VERMONT
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan province will establish sister-hood ties with the US state of Vermont in September, the Taiwan Provincial Council said Monday.
The signing ceremony Sept. 15 at the Grand Hotel in Taipei will conclude with Vermont becoming the 40th American state to establish sister-hood ties with Taiwan.
While Vermont's population is only 580,000, its per capita income ranks 31st among the 50 states. Vermont is known as the Green Mountain State.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.085 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 31.999.
The local currency opened at 32.074, the day's lowest level, and was traded between 32.074 and 31.974.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$1.051 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS RECLAIM 8,000-POINT LEVEL AFTER MSCI DECISION

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices soared 5.1 percent on Monday to reclaim the 8,000-point on strong institutional buying following last week's decision by Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) to raise the weighting of Taiwan shares.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price index rallied 392.42 points to close at 8,018.47 with share prices up across the board.
Local and foreign institutional investors are rushing to buy new shares as the MSCI effect continues to prevail, resulting in multi-faceted gains across the eight major stock categories.
Dealers said that the surge is simply reflecting the market's fundamentals since there are no signs that the cross-strait relationship will further deteriorate.
Monday's turnover totaled NT$168.26 billion (US$5.24 billion), slightly lower than the previous session's 172.53 billion.
The financial sector and electronics shares enjoyed the largest gains among the eight major stock categories, ending the day with gains of 6.48 percent and 5.2 percent.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 436 to 56, with 30 stocks unchanged.
The over-the-counter market posted a 5.47-point gain to close at 170.62 points on a turnover of NT$5.79 billion.
Meanwhile, TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) all reported gains, boosted by the bullish performance in the stock market.

TAIEX Index Futures for August rose 510 points to close at 8,195 points, with 2,938 contract transactions, those for September climbed 537 points to finish at 8,126 points, with 2,414 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December jumped 534 points to close at 8,166 points, with 20 contract transactions and those for next March and next June both climbed 510 points to close at 8,140 points. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAO ANNOUNCES NEW POLICY ON OVERSEAS CHINESE AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Minister Chiao Jen-ho said on Sunday that the OCAC will set up a worldwide business network, as well as a Chinese TV channel, in an attempt to spread the motherland's latest information and integrate the business resources of worldwide Chinese through the Internet.

Speaking at the closing ceremony of an annual meeting of Chinese schools across America and a seminar of Chinese teachers in the Greater New York region, Chiao expressed his admiration and respect for the some 250 Chinese teachers in attendance. He also thanked them for their devotion to promoting Chinese education, which he believes will play a pivotal role in promoting world culture.

Having just arrived in New York early Sunday, Chiao said that currently there are some 3,000 overseas Chinese schools all over the world. In light of the importance of overseas Chinese education, the Executive Yuan passed a NT$500-million special bill last week allowing the creation of the "Worldwide Mandarin TV Channel," which will begin airing next May.

Through five satellites, the TV channel is expected to broadcast news and programs in mandarin around the clock. The programming will center on the views of overseas Chinese, and with its mix of lively and practical programs, it is hoped that it will make overseas Chinese more interested in learning their mother tongue.

In addition, the government is making efforts to set up the "Worldwide Chinese Businessmen Information Network" in hopes of integrating the resources of Chinese businessmen, Chiao said, noting that there are some 30,000 overseas Chinese businessmen in the world with investments totaling US$100 billion.
He went on to say that the network will provide services for Chinese businessmen who want to put ads on the network's website or make deals on-line.

He also pointed out that according to statistics, the global business volume of the Internet has reached US$25 billion and it is expected to rise to US$1.5 trillion by 2003. Thus Chinese businessmen throughout the world are expected to display their business strength through the OCAC network.

Chiao earlier on his US trip visited New York's Taiwanese community, where he contributed 12 computers, two printers and two lion costumes for use in special festivals and celebrations. His gifts were greeted with gratitude by overseas Taiwanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS GOLD COAST CITY DELEGATION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met a Gold Coast City delegation on Monday and thanked them for their donation of two koalas, Harley and Patrick, to Taipei City.

Gold Coast City chief executive officer Paul Stevens, Councilman Peter Armstrong and other four representatives came to the Taipei City Government building Monday to visit with Ma. They said they were surprised by the large crowds of people waiting to see the koalas.
The two koalas are from Australia's Gold Coast. When the pair met the public on Aug. 14, the delegation visited them and observed their accommodations.

During the meeting Stevens handed Ma a letter from the Gold Coast mayor. Ma said that he can understand the mayor's absence and that the relationships between Taipei City and Gold Coast City are the closest among all Taipei's sister cities.
Taipei City will host a high-tech exhibition next June, and Ma said he hoped Gold Coast City and other sister cities would send groups to Taipei for the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHIEF INVITED TO ATTEND CEO SUMMIT UNDER APEC FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top economic policy planner on Monday denied a newspaper report that he has been banned from delivering a speech at a business summit meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said the report was totally groundless as he has not applied for delivering a keynote speech at APEC's 1999 CEO summit.

A local newspaper said on Monday that Chiang, who will represent President Lee Teng-hui at this year's APEC leadership meeting, would be unable to speak at the CEO summit because of the recent controversy over the "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
Commenting on the report, Chiang said he will check the source of such a groundless, speculative report.

The CEO summit refers to a breakfast meeting between chief executive officers of large conglomerates and top leaders from all APEC member economies. The CEO summit, part of the annual APEC activities, is traditionally organized by the leading business association of the host country of the annual APEC ministerial-level and leadership meetings.

Noting that the keynote speaker at the annual CEO summit is usually arranged by the host country, Chiang said New Zealand's CEO Summit Ltd., which organizes the 1999 CEO summit, has invited US President Bill Clinton to deliver a keynote speech at the coming CEO summit.
The 1999 APEC ministerial and leadership meetings will be held in New Zealand in September. The theme of the coming CEO summit will be "Sharing Economic Leadership."

Chiang has been invited to attend the CEO summit. Several local business heavyweights, including Jeffrey Koo, chairman of Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Chang An-ping, chairman of Chia Hsin Cement Co. and I-Mei Foods Co. Vice Chairman Kao Chih-shang.
The 21-member APEC is a regional economic cooperation forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment. Both Taiwan and mainland China are APEC members.
Because of Beijing's opposition, President Lee has been barred from attending the annual APEC leadership meeting. Lee instead has to name a surrogate to attend the summit meeting on his behalf.

Since President Lee clearly defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station on July 9, Beijing has stepped up saber-rattling and launched new diplomatic offensive against Taiwan as it regards the definition as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

Local press reports said New Zealand authorities have on many occasions expressed their hope that the ROC delegation to this year's APEC ministerial-level and leadership meetings will not touch on any issues related to the "special state-to-state" theory.

Senior ROC officials were also quoted as saying that they hope New Zealand will simultaneously demand mainland China not to mention its so-called "one China" principle, which downgrades the ROC as a local-level government, during the coming APEC conferences.

"We hope the host country will treat the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on an equal footing and fully respect the ROC's rights and interests as a full APEC member," said a senior official, who demanded anonymity.

One noteworthy development is that whether mainland President Jiang Zemin and US President Clinton will issue any key statements concerning regional security and topics related to cross-strait ties following their planned meeting during the annual APEC extravaganza, political observers said.

In the past, the top ROC delegate to the APEC leadership meeting usually managed to hold bilateral talks with top leaders from other APEC countries. It remains unclear whether the controversy over the "special state-to-state theory" will hinder arrangement of such high-level talks this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA NOT TO COMMENT ON US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES'S STATEMENT

TEXT.P: In response to US presidential front-runner George W. Bush's statement on Sunday that he would use force to defend Taiwan against mainland Chinese aggression if he is elected, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday said that it would not comment on statements made by any US presidential candidates.

MOFA spokesman Chen Ming-chen was responding to media questions about the statement by Bush, the son and namesake of the former US president. However, Chen did confirm that Taiwan has been in contact with all of the US presidential hopefuls.

Bush, currently Governor of Texas state, said in a CNN interview on Aug.14 that "We need to be very resolute about our position when it comes to Taiwan." He added that US President Bill Clinton should make it clear that the United States would "adhere to the spirit of, and the law, of the Taiwan Relations Act."

Chen noted that while Taiwan welcomes the efforts of US congressmen and civilian organizations to urge the US government to honor the Taiwan Relations Act and its commitment to Taiwan's security, MOFA would not comment on any specific candidate's statements. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS CASES AMONG THE YOUNG RISING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health under the Executive Yuan on Monday warned young people that according to its latest statistics, the largest proportion of AIDS carriers on the island is unmarried and between 18-35 years of age segment.
The research conducted by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the department showed that the average age of domestic male and female AIDS carriers is 34 and 36, respectively.

However, 64 percent of all AIDS victims in Taiwan are between 18-35 years of age. Of those infected, some 83 percent are unmarried with 85 percent claiming to have contracted the disease through sexual intercourse.
In addition, the CDC also pointed out that there are currently 2,379 domestic AIDS carriers. The proportion of male to female carriers is 12.5 to 1.
Among all carriers, there are 2,139 local carriers and 240 foreigners. So far in 1999, 767 local and 16 foreign residents have developed the symptoms of AIDS.

With Chinese Valentine's Day approaching, the CDC explained that having single sexual companion would greatly reduce the chances of contracting AIDS, while adding that practicing safe sex is the most important guideline to remain AIDS free.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN COUNTY MAGISTRATESHIP BY-ELECTION SLATED FOR OCT. 16
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The by-election for the Yunlin County magistrateship is slated for Oct. 16, the Taiwan Election Committee confirmed on Monday.
Yunlin County Magistrate Su Wen-hsiung died of liver disease on Aug. 12. Because Su's remaining tenure exceeds two years, a by-election has to be held within three months.
The Taiwan Election Committee is scheduled to publish an election gazette on Aug. 20 and receive registrations from prospective candidates between Sept.13-17.
Candidates will be allowed to campaign from Oct. 6 until Oct. 15. Voting and ballot counting are slated for Oct. 16, according to the Taiwan Election Committee's plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG'S WORKING OFFICE CALLS FOR VOTERS' SPONSORSHIP

TEXT.P: The working office of former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, an independent candidate for the presidential election in March 2000, is calling for voters' to support Soong candidacy through a sign-up sponsorship campaign.

Although the 2000 presidential campaign has not formally started, Soong as an independent presidential candidate, without any political party support, should amass at least 224,000 signatures supporting his candidacy. Soong's team is now exerting much effort into meeting the threshold.
Posters released by Soong's working office have a theme of "The People's Opinion Dictates Our Direction."

The Soong posters stress that the former governor is the most reliable and trustworthy presidential candidate, and that he will fully enact political reform measures. The posters urge voters to show the people's power by signing their support.

In view of the fact that Soong has consistently placed at the top of various public opinion surveys, passing the 224,000-signature threshold of sponsorship should not be a problem, according to Soong's working staffs.

The Soong team is now seeking voter support through its affiliates in northern, southern and central Taiwan, with no set goal for the number of signatures. A staff member was quoted as saying, "the more, the better."

During a mass rally held in Taipei County Saturday evening, copies of the sponsorship sheets were disseminated to an estimated 50,000 potential voters. The crowd was also given the donation bank account number into which they could deposit funds to be used by Soong's election campaign.

According to ROC presidential election statutes, the sponsorship of any voter is limited to only one presidential ticket. A sponsor is considered invalid if his/her signature is on more than one presidential ticket sponsorships.
To stop voting irregularities, all sponsor's signatures and their personal seal must be attached with a photostatic copy of their ID card.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STRESSES EQUAL FOOTING ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Monday received a group of US congressmen at the Presidential Office and reaffirmed his "special state-state relationship" regarding ties between Taiwan and mainland China.

Speaking to the delegation of the House Military Affairs Subcommittee jointly led by Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and Solomon P. Ortiz (D-Texas), Lee stressed the importance of clarifying that the relationship between Taiwan and the mainland should be on an equal footing so as to ensure the rights and interests of the ROC and its people.
He went on to say that the ROC's mainland policy remains unchanged.

The president pointed out that the Beijing regime has been stressing it's so-called "one country, two systems" formula which treats the ROC as a local government. Beijing's assertion not only contravenes the facts, it also fully exposes the mainland's hegemonic attitude, he said.
Lee told his guests that President Bill Clinton's China policy -- peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, and dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China -- has gained the support of the ROC.
He said that the government and people of the ROC are grateful for the help and assistance of the United States, especially that provided by the US Congress.

Speaking on the country's economic development, Lee told his visitors that many people believe that the mainland has a tremendous population representing a vast market. However, they neglect one point -- purchasing power. Citing as an example the fact that Taiwan imports 1.5 times the amount of American-produced products as mainland China, he said this indicate the ROC's economic and trade power and potential.
Graham and Ortiz both said they comprehend and support Lee's explanation.
Graham stressed that liberty and democracy cannot be compatible with the communist system, and that Beijing's "one country, two systems" proposal is doomed to failure.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI NEWSPAPER URGES BEIJING TO SHOW RESTRAINT

TEXT.P: Beijing should ease its rhetoric and move to assure its neighbors that it does not plan to risk a military attack on Taiwan, a Bangkok-based English-language daily said on Monday.
"Like our neighbors and like both China and Taiwan, Thailand has much to lose and absolutely nothing to gain by a war between the two parts of China," said an editorial in the Bangkok Post.

The newspaper said in its editorial: "China should know that its neighbors will never accept a military attack on Taiwan, although China has said during its entire 50-year-communist history that it reserves the right to use military force against Taiwan.
"While once understandable in theory, this outdated policy is unacceptable in fact," the newspaper stressed.
"Taiwan has built itself from a tiny and corrupt province into a formidable economic force," the editorial said.
Commenting on the reunification of China, it said that Taiwan has seen little reason for the past 50 years to rejoin the mainland under the dominant political system.
"The island's citizens have prospered and developed politically far more than their communist brothers," it said.
It went on that if Beijing wants the respect of the world, it should act a little more respectably, and show some respect for the opinions, thoughts and cultures of the rest of world.
"If China wants to attract Taiwan to its offer of a merger, it should make itself look like a little more attractive," the editorial concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, GE, CFMI SIGN NT$800 MILLION ENGINE CONTRACT

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL), General Electric Co., (GE) and CFMI on Monday signed a purchase contract under which CAL will purchase used airplane engines in a deal worth US$800 million.

A CAL spokesman said the agreement is part of the company's US$5.6 billion purchase project, following agreements signed last week with Boeing Co. and Airbus Industrie for 17 Boeing 744-400 cargo planes, five Boeing 737-800, and eight Airbus A340-300s.

After the evaluation of operations and technical issues, CAL has decided to purchase the CF6-80C2 high-capacity engine produced by GE for Boeing 747-400 use, and the CFM56 high-capacity engine manufactured by CFMI, a joint venture between GE and France's Snecma.

Chairman of CAL's board of directors Chiang Hung-yi, General Manager of GE's CF6 Project Department Roger Seager, and CFMI executive deputy president Williams Clapper signed the agreement on behalf of the respective parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: EL SALVADOR REPLACES ENVOY TO ROC OVER SCANDAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed on Monday that El Salvador has decided to replace its ambassador to the Republic of China because of its incumbent envoy's alleged involvement in a scandal.

MOFA acting spokesman Henry Chen said incumbent Salvadoran Ambassador David Ernesto Panama is scheduled to leave Taipei on Aug. 22 and that his successor, Francisco Ricardo Santana, will assume the post the following day.

Panama was accused of having illegally sold diplomatic automobile license plates to local people, and Chen said his departure will mark an end to controversy over the alleged illegal license plate deals. Noting that the replacement of its envoy is basically El Salvador's internal affair, Chen said the ROC government fully respects the Salvadoran government's decision.
Panama was first accused of having sold diplomatic plates to a noted local business tycoon in 1996, but was never brought to trial because he enjoyed diplomatic immunity.

Earlier this year, Panama allegedly sold another diplomatic plate, this time to a man with 14 previous criminal convictions, who had repeatedly been accused of violating traffic rules in the central Taiwan township of Tsaotun.
The Salvadoran embassy in Taipei refused to comment on its imminent change of guard.

According to Chen, new Salvadoran Ambassador Santana, 45, previously served as Salvadoran ambassador to the ROC from 1985 through 1991. His wife is an ethnic Chinese. Santana studied mandarin Chinese at National Taiwan Normal University from 1982 to 1984. He also studied at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Business Administration, and can speak fluent Chinese.

Meanwhile, Chen said the ministry will retrieve all single- and double-digit "Shih-designation" car license plates issued to resident foreign ambassadors here once a new head of the diplomatic corps is determined in the near future.
Chen said the ministry will then issue new license plates to resident ambassadors based on their seniority.
Of the 28 ROC diplomatic allies, 15 countries have set up embassies in Taipei.

At present, the No. 1 diplomatic license plate belongs to Haiti Ambassador Sonny Seraphin, who concurrently serves as head of the diplomatic corps. However, Seraphin left Taipei for home about a month ago amid reports about his alleged "frivolous" lifestyle, leaving the post of diplomatic corps chief vacant.
The No. 2 license plate is presently owned by Panama, who will soon leave his post, while the No. 3 plate is held by Burkina Faso Ambassador Jacques Y. Sawadogo.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTRY SETS UP INFORMATION WARFARE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Monday said it had established a committee to deal with information warfare.

A MND official disclosed the information at a public hearing on the protection of Taiwan's computer systems from mainland Chinese intrusion. He noted that "we are able to defend ourselves in an information war, but we will not initiate an offensive."
According to the official, in 1985 Beijing had already developed its plans for information warfare, and actual implication of the plan started in 1995.
He claimed that in 1997 Beijing conducted exercises in Nanjing and Beijing using computer viruses to interrupt broadcasting systems and military communication systems.
Those at the public hearing were also told that mainland China has introduced advanced technology from Britain and France for use in simulated wars.

To counter the mainland moves, the official said the MND has set up an advisory committee on information warfare strategy, and in the future will invite experts and party representatives to study its comprehensive strategy to combat information warfare.
Regarding the safety of the island's military data, the official said the MND computer system can be separated from outside connections.

He went on to say the ability to separate was why the MND computer system was not affected during the July 29 islandwide power blackout nor by recent incidents of website invasion by computer hackers.
The public hearing, held at the Legislative Yuan, was presided over by two Democratic Progressive Party legislators, Lee Wen-chung and Tsai Ming-hsien.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER APPROVES RESIGNATION OF MINISTER WITHOUT PORTFOLIO

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Sunday approved the resignation of Minister Without Portfolio Wu Jung-ming, according to a report on Monday by Director-General Chen Chien-jen of the Government Information Office.
Chen said Wu's successor has yet to be decided, but according to unconfirmed reports, former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yi is tipped to succeed him.
Wu tendered his resignation orally to Siew before the premier set off on a visit to Macedonia on Aug. 3, saying that he wants to return to his college teaching profession.

However, it is believed that Wu, who was vice Taiwan governor before assuming his Cabinet position, will be a key campaign assistant for former Taiwan Governor James Soong, who has announced his candidacy as an independent in the 2000 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN OFFICIAL TRYING TO LURE ROC INVESTMENT, TOURISM

TEXT.P: Jakarta Deputy Mayor Fauzi Alvi Yasin held a press conference in Taipei on Monday to introduce the current political and economic situation of Indonesia and to lure ROC investment to Indonesia.

Yasin, accompanied by a group of municipal officials, will preside over a seminar on investment opportunities in Indonesia on Tuesday, in line with Jakarta's hopes of upgrading the level of interchanges of tourism, investment, enterprises and culture with Taiwan.

He stressed that the smooth proceedings of Indonesia's elections last June have led to political and economic stability in Indonesia, providing investors and tourists with a secure and comfortable environment which is being enforced by a 20,000-strong police task force charged with protecting tourists.
He claimed that security in Jakarta is "better than that of mainland China, Japan and Australia," while transportation conditions in Jakarta have improved greatly this year.
He also pointed out that Taiwan possesses the brightest future of any country in Asia.
As well as the investment seminar, the cultural mission accompanying Yasin will also give exhibitions of Indonesian dancing and food during its stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEBSITE HACKERS TRADE WAR ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan hackers have so far hacked 19 websites in mainland China, while hackers from the mainland on Monday infiltrated the website of the Investigation Bureau of the Justice Ministry, indicating that the "computer war" across the Taiwan Strait is continuing.
A communist Chinese flag on the homepage of the Investigation Bureau was the latest twist in the cross-strait Internet war.
Meanwhile, a Taiwan hacker announced recently that he will launch a series of assaults on mainland Chinese websites on Oct. 1, mainland China's National Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ROC WARSHIPS DECOMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: Two Republic of China warships were decommissioned on Monday after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.

The ceremony for the decommissioning of the Hui Yang and the Han Yang was held at southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung Port, and was presided over by Rear Admiral Chang Wu-tai, commander of the 168 Warship Fleet. More than 400 officers and seamen, including former commanders of each of the two warships, also participated.
No. 906 Hui Yang began service in the ROC Navy in 1971, carried out more than 400 missions, and received many distinguished merits during her 28 years of service.
No. 915 Han Yang started its military career in 1974. She also carried out numerous distinguished exploits during her 25 years of service.
In the last two years, the navy has commissioned a series of modern, advanced warships into its battle fleet, while accelerating its weeding out of older vessels.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESS REPORT OF TAIWANESE `RECRUITED' BY PRC DENIED

TEXT.P: The Investigation Bureau under the Justice Ministry of the Republic of China on Monday denied a newspaper report that over 30,000 Republic of China nationals have been "recruited" by the mainland Chinese authorities.
The newspaper further claimed that the information came from the Investigation Bureau itself.

Dismissing the report, the bureau pointed out that the data used by the newspaper was from mainland China's People's Daily newspaper of Sept. 16, 1992, which carried a Xinhua News Agency dispatch. Xinhua is one of Beijing's official mouthpieces.

The bureau, which has kept the mainland data, pointed out that the information indicated only the number of people from Taiwan who attended the provincial-level meetings for the 8th National People's Congress, and had nothing to do with so-called "recruitment" by the mainland authorities.
Investigation Bureau officials said that some Taiwan businessmen residing in mainland China have to attend such meetings in order to maintain good relations with authorities there.

The officials added that Taiwan businessmen who attend such meetings and who have "suspicious backgrounds" become the target of investigation by the Investigation Bureau, but stressed that the number of such investigations is limited.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPUTER GIANT TO INVEST IN INTERNET UNITS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Acer Group, whose subsidiary, Acer Computer International (ACI), last week announced a sharp surge in profits, expects well over US$1 billion to be pumped into two new Internet-focused business groups over the next three to five years.

In an interview with Singapore's Business Times on Friday, Acer chairman Stan Shih said he also sees an expanded role for his company's Singapore operation as the computer conglomerate makes its long-awaited leap onto the Net.

Acer announced in Taiwan last week plans to invest US$200 million in a digital service group and another US$200 million in a venture capital group that will finance intellectual property (IP), primarily software, companies.
According to Shih, however, total investment in the two key projects is likely to be far higher.
Referring to the venture capital group, which he dubbed Acer SoftCapital, Shih clarified: "Acer will commit to about US$200 million, but we are expecting to raise US$1 billion.
"We will invite financial institutions to invest with us, maybe through a number of funds which combined together should reach US$1 billion."
Shih said management teams will be set up to direct fund operations in the US, Greater China and Southeast Asia from de facto operational headquarters.
Furthermore, the funds themselves will be registered in different locations, and again, Singapore is a possible choice.
The Acer chairman also confirmed plans to raise US$200 million by the end of 2000 for Acer's digital services venture.
This group, a unit of which will be sited in Singapore, will consolidate internal development efforts involving a wide range of Internet-related products and services.
This initiative will initially be funded privately, he said, adding: "We are committing US$50 million immediately."

And he noted: "Operationally, because there will be many joint venture partners, the overall investment may be US$400 million or more. All of this is actively under development right now. It will be very clear by the end of this year."

Singapore will be the site of a "Competence Center" responsible for Acer's thrust in Net-based educational services, Shih revealed. The center, an arm of the newly announced Acer Digital Services Group, will develop the necessary technology and tie up with business partners within the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEMENS VICE PRESIDENT CALLS ON ROC PRESIDENT, PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew on Monday received a call from Guenter Wilhelm, vice president of Germany's Siemens Co., to exchange views on his company's investment plan for Taiwan.

Last year, the electronics giant purchased US$400 million-worth of products from Taiwan, with information industry-related products accounting for the largest portion. In the first nine months of this year, its Taiwan purchases have already reached US$700 million.
Wilhelm told the local media after his meeting that Taiwan will in the future become Siemens' global center for the procurement of information industry-related products.

He added that his company will continue transferring the most advanced semiconductor technology to its Taiwan partners, and that its investment and procurement in Taiwan will not be affected by non-economic factors.

During his talks with Lee and Siew, Wilhelm indicated Siemens' strong desire to become the supplier of the NT$300 billion (US$9.12 billion) mechanical-electrical system for the Taiwan High-Speed Railway build-operate-transfer project.
He said his company is confident of winning the bid to provide the system because it has outstanding power supply systems, and has good technology and experience in the field of railway signals.
Since 1994, Siemens has invested US$725 million in Taiwan, with its work force in the country soaring to over 1,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUAN DEVALUATION CALLED JUST A MATTER OF TIME

TEXT.P: Fears that mainland China may be forced to devalue the yuan in order to offset mounting pressures on its economic growth are becoming pervasive with some analysts arguing that it is now a matter of time when such a move will be made, according to a report in The Business Times.
Economists at the World Bank acknowledge that mainland China may be hard pressed to avoid a devaluation if current adverse trends persist, it said.

Quoting the World Bank official line, the chief economist for Asia and Pacific Masahiro Kawa says that "the disadvantages of a renminbi devaluation outweigh the potential advantages and that the currency should not be devalued". Privately, however, some World Bank officials qualify such statements by adding "not this year at least".

One fear is that a yuan devaluation would send an "adverse signal to the rest of Asia. " Indonesia and Thailand in particular could be adversely impacted by price-competitive Chinese exports. What World Bank officials term the V-shape or U-shape recovery in regional economies might turn into W-shaped or double-bottomed recessions, especially if US import demand should slow.

It is not only the need to improve export competitiveness in international markets that could force mainland to abandon its long-standing pledge not to devalue its currency. Foreign direct investment is "down due to weaker economic activity and also because of fears that the yuan will be devalued", noted a World Bank official.

"China is struggling," acknowledges Kawa. "It has deflation and an economic growth rate that is decelerating each quarter . The growth rate will be 7 percent this year but if China undertakes the promised reform of its state-owned enterprises, it will need a stronger growth rate. Seven percent is not sufficient to enable China to absorb unemployment and to contain social problems."

Mainland's export performance is deteriorating, thereby "putting pressure on the exchange rate" of the yuan. But World Bank economists are confident that the overall current account will remain in surplus. The fact that mainland China still has a trade account surplus and rising foreign exchange reserves makes it difficult for Beijing to justify any yuan devaluation at this time, they suggested.

Mainland needs to maintain a high level of foreign exchange reserves to back its foreign currency debt. Mainland's external debt in 1998 was US$145.6 billion, according to World Bank figures, and in 1999 it is estimated to rise to US$153.5 billion.

A devaluation of the yuan is one factor that could upset what World Bank officials see as a relatively promising scenario for economic recovery in the rest of Asia. "The worst is now over and economies are picking up in terms of gross domestic product," said Mr. Kawa, "In the first half of this year GDP growth rates were positive in the formerly crisis-affected Asian countries." SHERMAN WU

DOC.HEADLINE: US-TAIWAN BUSINESS COUNCIL ANNOUNCES NEW CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council announced Monday that Frank Carlucci, former US National Security Adviser and Secretary of Defense under President Ronald Reagan, will succeed William Clark as its chairman.
Clark has been chairman of the Council for the customary two-year term. Carlucci will assume the chairmanship effective September 1, 1999.

In a press statement, Clark said, "I am proud to have been chairman of this fine organization and to have worked for the continued development and improvement of relations between the United States and the Republic of China on Taiwan."

He said, "I am delighted that my good friend and former colleague in government will succeed me. Frank is a great American with a distinguished record in both government and in business, and I'm sure he will do a great job."
Carlucci is chairman and a partner in the Carlyle Group, a Washington, D.C.-based merchant bank founded in 1987 as a private global investment firm.
Before joining the Carlyle Group in 1989, Carlucci was President Reagan's National Security Adviser in 1987 and Secretary of Defense later that year until President George Bush was sworn in.
Carlucci will be the third former Reagan Administration cabinet member to chair the council, after Caspar Weinberger, a former Secretary of Defense and William Clark.

The US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council changed its name from the USA-ROC Economic Council in 1997 and moved to Arlington, Virginia earlier this year. The council works closely with its counterpart on Taiwan, the ROC-USA Business Council, to promote business relations between Taiwan and the United States. Herman Pan

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE GORGES DAM RISKS ENGULFING 30 M. PEOPLE

TEXT.P: A growing chorus within China is urging the Three Gorges Dam to be scaled down from the current size as fears rise that 30 million people in Chongqing could be engulfed if the dam bursts, according to a local news report.
Outspoken opponents, including journalist Dai Ging, and hydro-engineer Huang Wanli, have repeatedly asked Beijing authorities to scale down the dam, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIMORESE LEADER WARNS PRO-INDONESIA MILITIAS TO DISARM OR DIE

TEXT.P: Less than two weeks before the August 30 UN-sponsored ballot, a detained East Timorese leader has warned that his forces will track down and kill Indonesian soldiers caught supplying weapons to rival pro-Jakarta militias, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Tuesday.

Xanana Gusmao on Monday accused Indonesia's military or TNI of planning to provoke a new wave of violence if the ballot favors independence. So far 450,000 Timorese have registered for the August 30 ballot, which will give them a choice for the first time between autonomy and independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ANGERED BY MORGAN STANLEY REWEIGHTING

TEXT.P: United States investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has touched raw nerves of communist China again after its index services provider announced last week it would increase Taiwan's weighting, sending the island's dollar and stock prices soaring.

According to a report appearing in the South China Morning post today, Chinese officials were said to be "angry" over Thursday's announcement by Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI), which came as Beijing was waging psychological warfare on Taiwan.
"We don't understand it at all. We are particularly puzzled by the timing of the announcement," one source was quoted as saying.
"Why should they increase Taiwan's weighting when cross-strait relationships are at their worst," the source was further quoted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS 1 IN 4 NEW ZEALANDERS HAVE LOST FAITH IN DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: One in four New Zealanders refuses to support their democratic political system. They would rather see the nation run by a board of directors.

In a dispatch from Auckland, the Australian on Tuesday reported that an astonishing 39 percent of the 1,200 New Zealanders surveyed favored a team of experts -- not a government -- making decisions "according to what they think is best for the country."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO RETRACT 'SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday he sees no need for the Republic of China government to retract the "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
Siew was responding to mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's remarks that the "special state-to-state" theory is purely ROC President Lee Teng-hui's own views.

Qian, a former mainland foreign minister, was quoted as saying during a meeting with a pro-unification delegation from Taiwan on Monday that Beijing is still waiting for Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, to retract the "special state-to-state" theory so as to pave the way for opening cross-strait political negotiations.

Qian was referring to President Lee's defining relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" during an interview with Germany's Deutsche Welle radio station on July 9. The definition has drawn furious reaction from Beijing which regards it as a move to promote Taiwan independence.
Commenting on Qian's remarks, Premier Siew said the "special state-to-state" theory simply describes facts and clarifies special features of cross-strait relationship.

"President Lee's definition mainly affirms reality and underscores parity between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Siew explained, adding that the definition does not mark a shift in Taiwan's policy toward the mainland.

The premier went on to say that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's mainland policy, has issued a position paper detailing the meaning and purposes of the "special state-to-state" theory.
"We have also reiterated on many occasions that our policy of promoting cross-strait exchanges and dialogue as well as seeking an eventual democratic unification remains unchanged," Siew said.
Stressing that the ROC's sovereign status is an indisputable fact, Siew said he does not think that the ROC government has to retract President Lee's "special state-to-state" remarks.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing Koo Chen-fu reiterated the ROC's sincere welcome to his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan this autumn.

Koo, a veteran business tycoon and senior adviser to President Lee, said despite the recent controversy over the "special state-to-state" theory, the ROC government still looks forward to hosting Wang's visit.

Koo, who made an ice-breaking visit to the mainland last October, made no immediate comments on Qian's Monday call for him to retract the "special state-to-state" theory. "I can't respond to Qian's remarks until I obtain a full text or full information about his talks," he added.

In related news, MAC Chairman Su Chi said in an interview with Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper that so long as Beijing accepts the "special state-to-state" definition, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can start negotiations on highly sensitive political issues, including the opening of direct cross-strait trade, transport and postal links.
The ROC's top mainland policy planner told the largest Japanese daily that the definition is mainly aimed at setting the fundamental principle for substantive talks with communist China.
"Only under this principle can Taiwan starts political negotiations with the mainland," Su explained.

The scholar-turned-policy planner pointed out that Beijing's so-called "one China" principle is detrimental to Taiwan in any political negotiations because it downgrades the ROC to a local-level government.

Su stressed that in the 21st century, cross-strait ties should not be a "father-son" relationship as Beijing claims. "We hope cross-strait ties will move toward a 'brotherly' or 'neighbor-like' relationship," he noted, adding that this is what the "special state-to-state" theory means.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 17, or the seventh day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: During the Hundred Years' War, the English defeat the Scots and French at the Battle of Verneuil.
1743: Jack Broughton, champion bare-knuckle English fighter, publishes a set of rules to control boxing. He also introduces 10-oz (300 g) gloves, called mufflers, to protect the hands and face from bruising during training.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a US representative from Tennessee and joint the Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico and died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West: American comedy actress known for her sulty stage persona and an international sex symbol during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage plays and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold find at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England by a car traveling at just 6.4 kph.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon holds its premiere in Paris.
1943: American forces under Gen. George S. Patton relieve Messina, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After Japanese occupation during World War II, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist "Yenan General Headquarters" issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch full-scale war against the government.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator, a device that speeds up the movement of tiny bits of matter, is formally inaugurated in Genava, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao Island in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the US and communist China. The ministry also asks the US to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the past 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when the camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane in which he was traveling crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, one hour and 20 minutes faster than the old record.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy in the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his 42-year KMT membership.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learn a thing you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS WITH LIBERIAN SENATE PRESIDENT PRO TEMPORE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday said Taiwan is willing to help Liberia to develop, as he received Liberian Senate President Pro Tempore Keikura Bayoh Kpoto, Madame Kpoto and other members of a visiting delegation.
Lee welcomed the guests and exchanged views with them on issues of mutual cooperation.

During the meeting, Lee said he hoped Kpoto would make use of his opportunity to see Taiwan's current development, and he asked Kpoto to give his regards to Liberian President Charles Taylor when he goes home.

In response, Kpoto expressed his appreciation to Lee and said that Taiwan was the first country to give Liberia a hand in rebuilding after the country's civil war -- hence Liberia considers Taiwan a real friend.
Kpoto reiterated that Liberia will continue to support Taiwan's involvement in the international community.

An agricultural technical mission from Taiwan has spared no efforts to help the Liberian people cultivate rice, and the mission has also helped people to produce higher-quality rice, Kpoto said. He added that he wished Lee, an expert on agriculture, would visit the country to provide personal experience on agricultural development.
Lee said in response that he would like to visit Taiwan's African allies one day to see their development in agriculture and to offer his expertise.

Members of the delegation included Sen. Thomas Nah Nimely and House Foreign Committee Chairman Francis R. Garbo were received by President Lee. Senior adviser to the President Ding Mou-shih, Deputy presidential Secretary-General Lin Bih-jaw and Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan were also present at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE CALLS FOR FEWER FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: The number of foreign laborers employed in Taiwan should be decreased gradually because the island's domestic unemployment problem is becoming increasingly serious, said the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Tuesday.
The number of unemployed in Taiwan has hit its highest level in more than a decade, and the problem is noteworthy and worrisome, said the opposition DPP's presidential candidate, Chen Shui-bian.

Chen is now touring the island to drum up support for his candidacy. During a stop in Tsochen, a town in the southern county of Tainan, Chen gained a firsthand understanding of efforts to repair an electrical transmission tower that collapsed July 30 after a landslide. As a result of the collapse, most of western Taiwan suffered a power outage.

Later Chen turned to Jen-teh, a town in Tainan County, to address a general assembly of the local Federation of Industries. During his speech, the DPP presidential candidate brought up the island's unemployment problem.

In view of the fact that the island's unemployment in May and June hit a record high, the problem is indeed critical, Chen remarked. Lots of young workers who have failed to find jobs in cities are increasingly going back home and being fed by their parents, he added.
There is a relationship between Taiwan's unemployment and the government's foreign labor policy, Chen indicated.
The official number of unemployed in Taiwan ranges from 270,000 to 300,000, which is about equal to the number of foreign laborers employed in Taiwan, Chen pointed out.

The best way to resolve the unemployment problem is not to freeze the quantity of foreign laborers, he said. Instead Taiwan should consider what has been done in Hong Kong and Singapore -- a gradual reduction in the number of foreign laborers over a long period of time.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS ASKED FOR HELP IN SECURING RELEASE OF DETAINED ROC FREIGHTER

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) faxed a letter recently to mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to ask for its help in securing the release of the detained Keelung-based freighter Shin Hwa and its 15-member crew.

Shin Hwa was taken over by mainland China's security force in Taiwan's territorial waters near Lienchiang County, Fujian province, on July 31 while on a routine mission. The military-commissioned vessel was to deliver 900 metric tons of commodities to the islands of Matsu and Wuchiu when it was ordered to the mainland. The vessel is now anchored at Mawei Port in Fujian province.
Lienchiang County Magistrate Liu Li-chun, who was worried about the safety of the freighter's 15-member crew, sent a letter dated Aug. 11 to SEF asking for its help in resolving the issue.

In a reply SEF said it faxed ARATS, its mainland Chinese counterpart, on Aug. 13 to ask for coordination among the various mainland Chinese agencies concerned so that the freighter and its 15 crew members would be released.

The letter said that the detained crewmen still have not been permitted to contact their families since the incident occurred two weeks ago. Their families are worried greatly about the crew's safety, and the detention of the vessel, used to deliver commodities to Matsu and Wuchiu, has affected the supply of commodities to the two ROC-controlled islands which are just several miles away from mainland's coast.

"In addition, according to family of crewman Wang Chih-tzu, Wang has hypertension requiring continual medical care. The family is worried about his health and asked ARATS to coordinate with the mainland Chinese agencies concerned to take care of him," SEF said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AERIAL DISPLAY ON SEPT. 1 NOT A MILITARY EXERCISE: MND

TEXT.P: An aerial display will be held in Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan on Sept. 1 to mark the 70th anniversary of the Air Force Academy, Kung Fan-ting, spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND), said Monday.

Speaking at a regular press conference, the spokesman said the aerial display is not a military exercise. He denied an earlier news report by a foreign wire service that the aerial display was deliberately arranged for a show of force.

He said the aerial display will provide a good opportunity for the general public to see the performance of Taiwan's "second generation" military aircraft. But he did not say what kind of warplanes will take part in the display.
President Lee Teng-hui will inspect the aircraft and their performance during the celebration.

The spokesman said it is important to help the general public understand the performance of the armed forces at a time when mainland China is waging psychological warfare against Taiwan through news media in Hong Kong.
Rehearsals of the aerial display will be held in the mornings of Aug. 18, Aug. 22, Aug. 27, and Sept. 1, he added.
Taiwan's lawmakers and representatives of local and foreign news media will be invited to observe the aerial display, he said.

Meanwhile, the spokesman also said Monday at the regular news briefing that the "South China Sea Fleet" of mainland China has been conducting live ammunition shooting drills since Aug. 10 on the seas east of Leizhou Peninsular in the southern tip of southeastern Guangdong province, posing no threat to the safety of Taiwan.
