He also said that certain mainland Chinese troops and air force units are also conducting regular training exercises.

The spokesman began on Aug. 10 to give regular briefing on the activities of mainland Chinese armed forces after Beijing had repeatedly released news of military exercises through news media to intimidate Taiwan people and wreak a havoc on Taiwan's stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS GAIN 0.8 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose 0.8 percent on Tuesday, following a possible alleviation of cross-strait tensions, as well as a decision by Morgan Stanley Capital International last week to raise the weighting of Taiwan shares.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index posted a 64.96-point increase to close the day at 8,083.43, with a total of 3.29 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of NT$164.11 billion (US$5.1 billion).

Among the eight major stock categories, construction shares enjoyed the largest gain, rising 3.3 percent. They were followed by financial issues and textile stocks, which rose 2.3 percent and 1.7 percent, respectively.
Plastic and chemical issues and pulp and paper stocks were the only losers, registering a 0.9-percent and a 0.6-percent drop, respectively.
Gainers led losers 281 to 196, while 48 stocks remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market opened at 170.1 and closed at 170.58 points, posting a 0.04-point drop, with a turnover of NT$5.94 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for August went down 65 points to finish at 8,130, with 1,503 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September dipped 26 points to end at 8,190, while those for December moved up 34 points, closing at 8,200. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 3,262 and 21, respectively.
Next March's futures declined 86 points to finish at 8,054, with four contract transactions, while there were no contract transactions recorded for next June's futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 8,195 for August, 8,216 for September, 8,166 for December, 8,140 for next March and 8,110 for next June.

August electronics futures (TE) fell 2.8 points to end at 370.1, with 392 contract transactions recorded; September TE futures gained 0.05 points to close at 372.4, with 637 contract transactions registered; and December TE futures went down 2 points, ending at 375, with five contract transactions.
There were no contract transactions recorded for other months' TE futures.

August financial futures (TF) went down 11.2 points to close at 1,170, with 149 contract transactions, and September TF futures climbed three points to finish at 1,191, with 222 contract transactions, while no contract transactions were recorded for other months' TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR REACHES 20-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose 3 cents, ending the day at 31.969 against the US dollar on Tuesday, a 20-month-high.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 31.992 and rose as high as 31.938 in the day's trading.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$767 million.

According to analysis by dealers in Taipei's foreign exchange market, Morgan Stanley Capital International's latest move to raise the weighting of Taiwan shares resulted in a large amount of foreign investment pouring into the market, which explains the currency's rise.

As the Foreign Exchange Department under the Central Bank of China has continually moderated the NT dollar's rise, it is unlikely the currency will hit the 31.5-level against the greenback, dealers added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA: JAPAN'S NEW VISA SYSTEM TO BENEFIT ROC-JAPAN EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Japan's new visa system will help facilitate exchanges of people between the Republic of China and Japan, Henry Chen, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said Tuesday.

Japan, which announced in June that it would affix a seal allowing 72-hour visa-free entry to the passports of ROC citizens, announced Monday that it was further easing visa regulations for ROC citizens.
Currently Japan offers a multiple-entry visa that permits 15-day visits over a three-year period. Starting next month, multiple-entry visas will permit 90-day visits over a five-year period.
In response to journalists' questions, Chen said that more than 1.5 million people in Taiwan and Japan visit the other side each year.

The ROC government began offering 120-hour visa-free entry to citizens of 12 countries, including Japan, on Jan. 1, 1994. On Jan. 1 1995, the government extended the period to 14 days for citizens of 18 countries.
Japan's relaxation of visa regulations will greatly benefit exchanges and cooperation between the two countries, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL VOWS TO FORM SUPRA-PARTY CABINET

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday that he might announce part of his Cabinet prior to the presidential election, to show his desire to form a supra-party government.

Potential candidates for the Cabinet he will form if he achieves victory in the March 2000 election will come from all parties, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the minor opposition New Party, as well as independents, Chen noted.

He said he is still seeking an appropriate candidate to be his running mate in the election, but added that he has been talking to several potential vice presidential candidates, including KMT members and close allies to independent presidential front-runner James Soong, the former governor of Taiwan.
The most essential qualification for the vice president, Chen said, is competence, adding that he will be chosen before the end of the year.
Speaking of the DPP's chances of election victory, Chen said that DPP can win if the whole party devotes itself to the campaign.

He noted that it is too early to predict the impact on the election of President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relationship" statement, but went on to say that the theory comes down to a battle between Taiwan independence or reunification with mainland China, which is so crucial that it will have to be discussed sooner or later.
The election will still be a battle between the island's two main parties -- the KMT and the DPP -- which means there is little space left for those running as independents, Chen claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSILE CRISIS WILL NOT BE REPEATED: SEMINAR

TEXT.P: Mainland China may conduct scattered "military harassment" action against Taiwan, but the missile crisis which occurred in 1996 across the Taiwan Strait is unlikely to take place again, according to experts who attended a Tuesday seminar.

At the symposium sponsored by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on mainland China's current policy toward Taiwan, DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said there have been widespread rumors that the mainland might use military force against Taiwan since President Lee Teng-hui redefined Taiwan's ties with the mainland as a "special state-to-state relationship" on July 9.

Some of these rumors have been fabricated by mainland authorities with the aim of menacing Taiwan, while some of them are products of the ignorance of the Taiwan people, Lin added, claiming that it is useless to predict or analyze Beijing's reaction as this will only lead to the loss of faith and the bargaining power to deal with the situation.

Lee Kuo-hsiung, vice director of the Institute of International Relations under National Chengchi University, pointed out that it is easy to see that the string of moves adopted by Beijing following Lee's "special state-to-state" theory have been no more than "knee jerk" reactions from a totalitarian regime.

However, Lee said, it is hard to forecast Beijing's next moves as the Chinese communist regime is now caught in a trap of its own devising -- having to win the hearts of the Taiwan people while at the same time recovering its lost face.

The most feasible development will be that Beijing will continue to intimidate Taiwan, in addition to conducting small-scale military maneuvers in the runup to Taiwan's next presidential elections slated for March 2000, he said.

W.Y. Chang, director of the Mainland China Affairs Institute at Tamkang University, said Beijing will use the promised autumn visit by top mainland negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan as its prime bargaining chip to keep pressure on Taiwan, coupled with verbal attacks, military intimidation and psychological war.

Wang is chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), which handles the mainland's unofficial exchanges with the island in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.

In view of the current situation across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan cannot afford to allow the mainland to have any excuse to use force against it, Chang asserted, saying that the two sides should further boost communication and understanding to mend their differences.
"Suspending bilateral dialogue is not the way to clarify the facts if something happens," he noted.

Pan Shih-tang, a mainland China affairs professor at Tamkang University, said he believes that the mainland will continue its military pressure on Taiwan until the March election, but will refrain from instigating another missile crisis in the Taiwan Strait.
Keeping open the invitation to Wang is the best countermeasure to curb mainland China's verbal attacks and saber rattling, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'HEALTH 99' WEBSITE LAUNCHES

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) under the Executive Yuan launched a new website, "Health 99," on Chinese Valentine's Day to highlight the fact that the public can now use the Internet to download the latest health information.

DOH Deputy Director-General Yang Chi-liang said his department had been working on the "Health 99" website for the past two years. The website was established to provide better health information to the public, especially teenagers. Yang noted that the public can now obtain the latest health information from his department simply by using a computer.

The website offers a variety of material, including information on healthy mobile phones and on popular and current issues, as well as medical advice. The site will also include health news and a health poll.
Yang said the website is user-friendly and provides visitors with a complete introduction after they log-in.

The DOH expressed their hope that all citizens will have a Chinese Valentine's day that is healthier and more informative as a result of the website. In the future the site will allow the public to subscribe through e-mail to pamphlets or films on health issues.

"The website 'Health 99', will benefit all ages, no matter what their health needs are," Yang said, adding that "our education system needs 'Health 99' so students can receive sufficient physical health information." (Michelle Tseng)

DOC.HEADLINE: JMIB DENIES SPY REPORTS

TEXT.P: The Justice Ministry's Investigation Bureau (JMIB) on Tuesday denied local media reports that over 30,000 Taiwan people have been recruited by mainland China to work as spies in Taiwan for the communist regime.

Brushing aside the reports, the JMIB clarified in a press release that the figure actually represents the number of Taiwan people residing in mainland China, not the number of Taiwan people serving as spies for mainland China.

According to the JMIB, the figure reported by the local media was taken from a general report issued in June this year on mainland China's commercial organizations dealing with Taiwan, which was taken in turn from a Sept. 6, 1992 People's Daily news reports on the mainland's seventh National Congress. The JMIB stressed that the number was cited by the congress in reference only to the number of Taiwan people living in the mainland.
It is rare for the Investigation Bureau to issue a press release to refute media reports, but an official said on this occasion that the action "was necessary to clarify the matter."

DOC.HEADLINE: FUNERAL HELD FOR TAIWAN STUDENTS KILLED IN IDAHO CRASH
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The funeral of three of the four Taiwan students killed in a traffic accident last Thursday was held on Monday in Rexburg, Idaho.

The four students, Chen Hsueh-chou, Weng Hui-ya, Lu Chih-jen and Chao Chih-ying, were killed on Aug. 12 when a van in which they were traveling, driven by Hsueh Ya-wen, rolled over near Fremont County, eastern Idaho, while en route to Yellowstone National Park from New York, where they were studying.
Hsueh and five other Taiwan students were injured in the accident. Among them, Kuo Wei-chieh was seriously wounded and still in intensive care as of press time.
Meanwhile, the Fremont County police department published a formal investigation report on the accident.

According to the report, speeding was the main cause of the accident. Experts who examined the wreckage determined that the van was traveling at 78-82 miles per hour, far in excess of the 55 miles per hour limit.

According to one of the injured students, the van rolled over after Hsueh swerved to avoid hitting a squirrel that suddenly appeared on the road, but a police officer cast doubt on the story, noting that the skid marks left by the van's tires did not suggest that the brakes were hit suddenly.

The police officer told CNA that Hsueh was both physically and mentally injured by the accident, and added that both the local prosecutors and police believe that even if Hsueh was negligent, taking legal action against her would be "unnecessary and meaningless."

DOC.HEADLINE: ESCAPED CONVICT SHOT DEAD BY POLICE

TEXT.P: Police and escaped convict Wu Shih-chuan exchanged a fierce one-hour shootout on Tuesday which ended in Wu's death, according to police.
Police said that Wu had escaped from an eastern Taiwan jail after being sentenced to life, but, amazingly, then went home to his apartment, where police found him after being tipped off.

After an exchange of fire, Wu escaped, but police managed to capture his girlfriend. Reinforcements were then called in to help in the search for Wu, and another gun battle ensued at a nearby house. Police took the house by force and found Wu's body inside.
One police officer was wounded during the shootout and rushed to a hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-TO-STATE TIES COULD BE A TOPIC OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The special state-to-state ties between Taiwan and mainland China could be an issue on the agenda of dialogue between Taipei and Beijing rather than a barrier to such talks, a mainland China affairs official said on Tuesday.

Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that Taipei would not respond to Beijing's assertions that it is still waiting for Taiwan to withdraw its claims that cross-Taiwan Strait ties are "a special state-to-state relationship."

Emerging from a meeting on mainland China affairs with Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) leaders, Wu told waiting reporters that Taipei has made its approach to Beijing very clear and there is no need for further explanation.

Wu was referring to reports that Beijing's Vice Premier Qian Qichen told a pro-reunification Taiwan group in Beijing on Monday that Beijing is waiting for Taipei to back down before going ahead with the planned Taiwan visit by Beijing's top negotiator Wang Daohan this autumn.

Although he said he could not comment without seeing the text of Qian's statement, Wu expressed the hope that Wang will visit as scheduled. Such a visit, he said, "would deepen his understanding of Taiwan, and he would even be able to challenge the state-to-state theory during his dialogue with his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu."
"Face-to-face talks are better than rhetoric and a war of words in terms of sorting out mutual differences," Wu went on.
Beijing which considers Taiwan a part of China, was enraged by Taipei's claims in July that Taipei-Beijing ties should be put on a state-to-state basis.
It demanded an explanation from Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu, only to return the written explanation unopened on July 30 as "unacceptable."

In his meeting with the leaders of the pro-independence DPP, Wu warned that political dialogue with Beijing is inevitable, and that local political parties should brace for the encounter by working out a united front.

Noting that Beijing is adhering to its policy of "peaceful reunification with Taiwan" and its "one Country, two systems" formula, Wu said it is obviously that Beijing will refrain from using force against Taiwan, provided the island does not outright declare independence.

To counter Beijing's attempts to annex Taiwan via political pressure, military intimidation, diplomatic isolation and economic integration, Wu said Taipei is pressing on with its economic development, improvement of democracy, consolidation of internal solidarity and strengthening of defense capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA CONSERVATIVE ON JOINING WTO BY YEAREND

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials have become more conservative on whether the ROC will be allowed to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) by the end of this year.
Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu admitted on Tuesday that various elements still need to be overcome, but stressed that WTO entry by the yearend is still the goal the government is striving for.
He said that a working committee will be held in late September or October in Geneva to complete the documentary legalization procedures.

Lin was speaking as chair of an ad hoc committee on ROC entry into world economic and trade organizations at the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT). More than 70 officials from various government agencies attended the meeting.

Speaking on the outlook for the ROC's WTO entry, Lin told the participants that some countries are in favor of mainland China being granted entry earlier than Taiwan, although not the United States, Canada or the European Union, judging from the results of the extraordinary working committee meeting in Geneva on July 30.
Due to WTO member nations' failure to reach consensus on mainland China's WTO membership, it is difficult to say whether Taiwan will be admitted by the end of this year, Lin said.

Commenting on whether the United States and mainland China will be able to complete their negotiations for WTO entry during the September summit meeting of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, Lin said that the opportunities are slim.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALIAN CLERGYMAN-DOCTOR WON ESTEEM WITH DEDICATED SERVICES (I)

TEXT.P: Italian clergyman-doctor Bro. Davide Luigi Giordan, who devoted more than 50 years of his life to the sick on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, has died of heart failure in Penghu off Taiwan's southwestern coast.
The 75-year-old director of St. Camillus Hospital in Penghu was found dead in his office by one of his colleagues on Sunday evening.
"I found Bro. Giordan `sleeping' on a chair when I went to his office to invite him to dinner at around 6 p.m.," Bro. Paul Han Kuo-chien recalled.
When Giordan failed to respond to Han's attempts to wake him, Han alerted hospital medical staff to administer emergency treatment, but they were unable to revive the respected doctor.
Giordan's sudden death shocked and saddened all the hospital staff, who still remembered vividly their boss' broad smile after a ceremonial mass earlier that day.

Cheng Ming-man, a nurse who had worked with Giordan for 35 years, said Giordan died quietly and peacefully. "His face shone with glimpses of light. We believe that was an honor bestowed on him by God in recognition of his devotion to his Chinese patients," an emotional Cheng said.

Many Penghu residents who went to the hospital's outpatient department on Monday broke into tears when they learned of Giordan's passing. The bearded Italian was admired throughout the community for his professionalism, devoted service, kindness and good humor.

"Despite his failing health in recent years, Giordan had never hesitated to donate his blood whenever any patient at the hospital needed type B blood. Throughout his life here, he donated more than 37,500 c.c. of his blood to local patients," Cheng said.

One 70-year-old female Penghu resident said Giordan had often led a group of young doctors around the rural communities of the offshore Penghu County to offer free medical services in the 1950-1980s. "He was the most diligent doctor here," she said, adding that nearly all Penghu residents aged over 40 have received his medical services at one time or another.

Giordan became determined to help the needy at a very early age, and joined the Catholic Camillians Society at the tender age of 12. In addition to abiding by the Camillians' stringent discipline, Giordan privately swore himself to serving patients, particularly those suffering from dangerous contagious diseases.
Ten years after joining the Camillians, the Catholic church sent him to care for leprosy patients in the remote southwestern Chinese province of Yunnan in 1946.

Giordan felt heartsick when he saw Chinese leprosy patients banished into isolation in the barren mountain region. To offer better treatment for those patients, he and his Catholic colleagues built two sanitariums and a hospital with funds raised in Italy.
For his efforts, Giordan was accused of spying by communist Chinese authorities and expelled from the Chinese mainland in the late 1940s.

Although saddened by his expulsion from the mainland, his love for the Chinese people remained unshaken after returning to his Italian hometown. He continued his medical studies in Italy, after which he came to Taiwan. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALIAN CLERGYMAN-DOCTOR (II)

TEXT.P: Giordan's first post in Taiwan was at St. Mary's Hospital in Loutung, in northeastern Taiwan's Ilan County. During his service there, Giordan often rode his bicycle to make free housecalls to residents in remote townships such as Sanhsing and Tatung.
Later, undeterred by Penghu's inhospitable geographic nature in the 1950s, Giordan moved to the offshore island county in 1957, where he cared ceaselessly for his patients until his death.
Giordan continued to make strenuous efforts to raise funds for building St. Camillus Hospital to offer better medical services for the residents of Penghu.

On his mother's advice, who once told Giordan that the best way to protect the clergy's image was to project an image of a "loving elder," he began to cultivate a beard at a young age, and indeed his hirsute growth impressed many of his patients.

Giordan built up a good rapport with ordinary folk, and spoke fluent Chinese and even Taiwanese. He took great interest in conversing freely with his patients. His good humor and kindness soon won him the hearts and minds of many Penghu residents, and St. Camillus Hospital quickly emerged as the largest hospital in the fishing county.

Giordan was on call 24 hours a day and always took the initiative to work overtime. "No matter when patients visited him for emergency treatment, he never looked tired, even at midnight," one nurse at the hospital said.

A self-effacing person, Giordan led a simple, frugal life, often wearing clothes cast off by other priests. Over the past years, he had received many honors for his devoted services to the residents of Penghu, including honorary citizenship of Penghu, and awards for outstanding and devoted medical professionals. Former Italian President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro also presented the honor of Ordine Al Merito to Giordan in May 1997, the third-highest honor offered by the Italian government.
However, he seldom worn his medals as he disliked publicity and was unimpressed by such laurels. What he cared about above all else was accomplishing his wishes to serve his patients.

In recent years, Giordan often traveled to Yunnan to see leprosy patients there, and in fact managed just a couple of years ago to raise enough funds in Taiwan to build a modern sanitarium for mainland Chinese leprosy patients.

On the eve of his death, he was still writing a book introducing the plight of mainland leprosy patients. The book was originally scheduled for publication at Christmas this year, and Giordan had been hoping to use the proceeds from the book sales to build a second leprosy hospital in Yunnan.

Hu Li-chun, Giordan's personal secretary, said Giordan felt great pain when he was forced to part company with his leprosy patients in Yunnan after being expelled by communist Chinese authorities on charges of spying more than 40 years ago.

"Therefore, he treasured every opportunity to work in any remote barren land," Hu said, adding that she earnestly hopes there will be people willing to carry on Giordan's legacy and continue caring for Yunnan's leprosy patients.
Giordan's body was sent to Loutung, Ilan County on Monday afternoon, and he will be buried in the cemetery of St. Mary's Hospital there after a funeral mass on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE GAP WITH JAPAN KEEPS SHRINKING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan has shrunk by 8 percent in the first seven months of this year, in tune with a trend since July of 1998, an economics official said on Tuesday.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu told a committee for narrowing the trade gap with Japan that Taiwan's exports to Japan started to grow in January, and accumulated a combined gain of 21.4 percent in the January-July period, including a single-month growth of 36.4 percent in July alone.

Estimating that the trade gap with Japan will be US$16 billion in 1999, compared to an all-time high of US$17.7 billion in 1998, Lin said that the makeup of Taiwan's exports to Japan has shifted away from traditional agricultural and livestock products to electronic, electrical and machinery goods, which bodes well for the prospects of reversing the long-standing trade imbalance.

Presiding over the meeting, Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang attributed the increasing exports to Tokyo's economic recovery, which in turn has driven up imports, in addition to Taiwan's efforts to pry open the Japanese market.

Citing statistics compiled by the Japanese Ministry of Finance, Wang said imports from Taiwan increased by 15.29 percent in the first half of this year, the highest among Japan's top-13 trade partners, and making Taiwan its fourth-largest trade partner with a market share of 4.23 percent, compared to 3.69 percent in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST SPECIAL HORTICULTURE DEMONSTRATION ZONE TO BE SET UP IN 2003

TEXT.P: The government will set up Taiwan's first special horticulture demonstration zone (SHDZ) in central Taiwan in 2003, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced on Tuesday.

COA officials said the SHDZ will be developed in three stages, and estimated that after completion in 2003, it will generate an annual turnover of more than NT$700 million for Taiwan's horticulture industry.
The zone will be located at Houli farm, Taichung County, and will occupy nearly 100 hectares.
The COA has invited Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) to share in the NT$1 billion investment required to develop the project.
The first stage of construction is slated for completion in 2000, and it is expected that harvesting will have begun by the end of that year.
The SHDZ will produce mainly tropical flowers for export to Japan, the Netherlands, the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PROMISES AID TO FAMILY OF TAIWAN STUDENT SLAIN IN PARIS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) of the Republic of China promised on Tuesday to do its best to help the family of a Taiwan student who was murdered in Paris on Saturday.
Ministry spokesman Henry Chen said MOFA will provide whatever aid is needed by the family of Lee Chi-cheng to reclaim his body from Paris police.

Although Taiwan's representative in Paris has expressed concern over Lee's death, French police have been reticent about details of the case while the murder investigation is still under way, said Chen.

Lee, a 30-year-old Taiwan student, was found dead with his hands tied in his Paris apartment when firefighters broke in to extinguish a blaze which gutted his apartment. It took police two days to make a positive identification of the body.
Since there was also evidence that Lee's apartment had been ransacked and that Lee had been killed before the fire broke out, police suspect foul play.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMODELED TANKS DISPLAY FIREPOWER IN CENTRAL TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Fifty remodeled M41D tanks displayed their firepower and improved capabilities at a base in Nantou County's Chichi on Monday and Tuesday before an audience of some 1,000 local residents, lawmakers and reporters.
A public anti-tank live-fire exhibition was also held at the base with the purpose of promoting the public's understanding of the strength of the Republic of China Armed Forces.

The ROC Army first introduced the American-made M41 tanks in 1958. They have since become obsolete and have been replaced by the domestically produced M48H tank and used American-made M60A3 tank as the mainstay of the army's tank battalions.

Because Taiwan is unable to procure the most advanced tanks from the United States and other industrialized countries, the army decided in 1996 to improve the capabilities of 50 M41s with a cost of NT$1.3 billion.

The remodeling project proved successful, and the tanks have now been converted to run on diesel and equipped with night vision battle devices. Their maximum range has also been extended from 160 kilometers to 470 kilometers.

According to army officials, the 50 remodeled tanks will be used on the offshore islands, while the M48H and M60A3 tanks will continue to form the backbone of the army's mechanized units for the foreseeable future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ROC closely monitoring communist China's military training drills and deployment.
The China Times:
Premier Siew says he sees no need to retract the 'special state-to-state' theory.
The United Daily News:
Violations of traffic rules to be subject to heavy penalties, with the maximum fine reaching NT$500,000.
The Liberty Times:
Strong quake claims 1,200 lives in Turkey.
The Commons Daily:
The ruling Kuomintang and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party will jointly block any proposal to extend the term of office of National Assembly deputies.
The China Post:
ROC, PRC conduct military maneuvers.
The Taiwan News:
The ROC government is firm on 'state-to-state' theory.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 CRASHES, PILOT ESCAPES
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The pilot of an F-16 fighter jet ejected from the aircraft before it crashed near an airbase in Chiayi Wednesday morning because of mechanical malfunctions, according to the General Headquarters of the Republic of China Air Force.

Maj. Lin Keng-sheng parachuted to safety at 8:58 a.m. after his second attempt to land failed. Lin, returning from a routine training mission, discovered an absence of propellant power from his single-seater jet's engine. He ejected after efforts to correct the malfunction proved ineffective, Air Force officials said.
Lin, 36, was hospitalized with bone fractures in both his legs.
The Air Force General Headquarters announced on Wednesday an overall grounding of all F-16 fighters for comprehensive safety checks after the crash.

The fighter jet crashed in an area some 6,000 feet (about 1,829 meters) south of the runway of Chiayi Airbase, part of which is opened to civilian air traffic. Civilian air traffic at the airbase, however, has been suspended as a result of the crash.
The ROC Air Force has organized an exclusive task force to investigate the accident.

Premier Vincent Siew instructed both the Ministry of National Defense and the Air Force General Headquarters to do their utmost to look into the accident and make necessary measures to improve the training of pilots and the maintenance of all F-16s in service in Taiwan.
The crash was the fourth incident involving an F-16 since the first F-16 squadron was formed in Taiwan in October 1997.

On March 20, 1998, a twin-seater F-16 B disappeared over the sea near Penghu County, a group of small islands off the western coast of Taiwan. The wreckage of the aircraft has not been found, and its two pilots are presumed dead.

On Jan. 25 this year, another twin-seater F-16 B crashed in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County, and its two pilots remain unaccounted for. The jet fighter, one of 30 twin-seater F-16 B's to have been delivered by the United States since 1997, smashed into a tea plantation, destroying a nearby building that was burned as a result of fuel spilling from the crashed plane. No fatalities on the ground were reported.

On June 1 this year, a single-seater F-16 A, piloted by Maj. Hsu Chung-wei, dropped into the sea about 35 kilometers southwest of Green Island off the coast of southeastern Taiwan. Both the pilot and the aircraft remain missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 18, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, conqueror of a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Admiral Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, now in Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War I, is born.
1900: Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Indian politician and diplomat, is born. She served as ambassador to Moscow, Washington and Mexico and was president of the UN General Assembly in 1953.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung.
1974: ROC baseball teams win for the first time all three world titles of Little League, Senior League and Big League.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its racist politics.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action to launch a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the ROC leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua, and Honduras, and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy at San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: Earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE POSTPONES INTRODUCTION OF F-16'S INTO ACTIVE SERVICE

TEXT.P: Prompted by another crash of a US-made F-16 jet fighter on Wednesday, the Republic of China Air Force announced the postponement of plans to introduce the fighters, which are still being evaluated, into active service, while pilot training will be extended from six months to eight, according to sources from the Ministry of National Defense (MND).
The introduction of the fighters into the ROC's combat forces will definitely be delayed, MND officials noted.

National Defense Minister Tang Fei, who was formerly commander-in-chief of the ROC Air Force, instructed the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) to review plans to introduce the fighters into service, as well as pilot training, after Wednesday's crash.

Major Lin Keng-sheng parachuted to safety on Wednesday morning after his second attempt to land his single-seater F-16 A failed. Returning from a routine training mission, Lin discovered he was unable to obtain thrust from his plane's engine, and ejected after efforts to correct the malfunction proved ineffective.
The fighter, one of the 44 F-16s stationed at the Chiayi airbase, crashed some 1.8 kilometers south of the air base runway.
Tang also asked the AFGH to determine whether there are any similarities among the four accidents in the past 17 months involving twin-seater F-16 B's and single-seater F-16 A's.
Mechanical and design problems could be behind the tragic incidents, Tang said, though he stressed that attempts to introduce them into service too quickly may also have played a role.

Tang expressed particular concern over pilot training. He said it is questionable whether ROC Air Force pilots, despite their commendable physical and mental ability, can be adequately trained to pilot the fighters in only six months. Noting that six months is the required training period for US pilots, Tang said a variety of factors, including language problems and training environments, could make a longer training period necessary.
Tang assured the government and the public that even if the introduction of the F-16's into active service is delayed, it will not affect the ROC Air Force's defensive capabilities.

With the delivery and commissioning of 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters, and the introduction of 130 locally developed Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDFs) into service, there are absolutely no gaps in the ROC's air defenses, Tang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGE CRACKDOWN ON INTERNET CRIME

TEXT.P: Amid a recent spate of incidents involving websites being hacked into on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the government has been urged to enact laws to crack down on such crimes.

Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of the ruling Kuomintang and Legislator Lai Shih-pao of the tiny opposition New Party jointly held a public hearing on Wednesday, calling on the government to work out a special law effective against this type of crime. They also suggested a rating classification system be adopted to protect children from being negatively influenced by pornographic websites.

Statistics compiled by the National Police Administration show that police have managed to crack only 73 website crimes during the period from the beginning of 1997 to July this year, while Taiwan's online population has topped 3 million.
Of the 73 crimes committed, most of them were cases involving CD rom piracy and operating pornographic websites, according to the tallies.

However, N.P. Hsiu, director of the National Information Infrastructure task force under the Executive Yuan, voiced opposition to government interference in the form of special laws, claiming that there are already relevant regulations governing Internet crime.

Echoing Hsiu's view, a ranking analyst at the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, said the less government interference with the Internet the better, opining that the Internet should not be controlled by governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONCERNED ABOUT CLINTON-JIANG TALKS DURING APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is concerned about a probable meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in New Zealand in September, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.

Hu was responding to an announcement on Tuesday by the US Department of State that Clinton will attend the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in New Zealand from Sept. 12-13.
As usual, Clinton is expected to take advantage of the annual event to hold bilateral talks with top leaders from other APEC countries, including mainland China.
As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are currently at odds over the "special state-to-state relationship" theory, Taiwan is concerned about the agenda of the upcoming Clinton-Jiang meeting.

Hu said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has ordered the ROC representative office in the United States to keep abreast of the developments before and after the Clinton-Jiang meeting, as well as any conclusions reached at the meeting.

Hu said it remains unclear whether the coming Clinton-Jiang talks will focus on Taiwan-related issues, and added that he is also not sure at the moment whether Clinton and Jiang will meet outside the APEC framework.

Beijing has intensified its saber-rattling against Taiwan since ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station on July 9.

Both Taiwan and mainland China are APEC members, but because of Beijing's opposition, Lee has been barred from the annual APEC leadership meeting. Instead, he has to appoint an envoy to attend the summit on his behalf. P.K. Chiang, the ROC's top economic policy planner, will attend the 1999 APEC leadership meeting on the president's behalf.
APEC, which groups 21 economies, is a regional economic cooperation forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAIWAN PEOPLE REPORTED DEAD OR INJURED IN TURKISH QUAKE
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Early reports from earthquake-shattered areas of Turkey say that no Taiwan people are among those reported dead or seriously injured as a result of Tuesday's devastation which has left at least 2,100 people dead and more than 13,000 injured.

According to a crisis center established by the Turkish prime minister's office, there is still no way to identify whether there are "foreigners," particularly those with Oriental names, among the victims, because the number of casualties is so big.

After a day of frantic checking, the CNA reporter was told by an overseas Chinese leader in Istanbul surnamed Sun that none of the 20-odd Taiwan expatriates and students registered as living in Istanbul, Turkey's largest city, have been reported dead, while only a few of them have suffered shock and minor injuries.
Similar telephone calls to relevant people in Turkey's capital, Ankara, also found that none of the approximately 20 Taiwan expatriates or students there have been killed or injured.
Meanwhile on Tuesday, a children's folk arts troupe from the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung left Turkey for home, escaping the killer earthquake.

A 12-member tour group sponsored by Taipei's Singi Travel Agency is leaving Turkey for home on Wednesday after concluding a 10-day tour of the country. All members of the group are safe and sound, according to the travel agency owner.
Tuesday's quake measured 7.4 on the Richter scale and was centered on the northwestern industrial city of Izmit, some 90 kilometers east of Istanbul.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MAGAZINE SAYS MAINLAND MAY ACT SOONER RATHER THAN LATER

TEXT.P: An August attack on Taiwan by mainland China cannot be dismissed out of hand, and that means the United States must take steps now to deter it. But it is not too late for the Clinton administration to act with the necessary resolve, according to the latest issue of a conservative American magazine.

The Weekly Standard wrote in an editorial titled "The Present Danger" that many China experts inside and outside the Clinton administration who said mainland China would not escalate the conflict across the Taiwan Strait are now saying they will not do so until after Beijing celebrates the 50th anniversary of the Communist Party's victory on Oct. 1.

But the conservative political magazine said, "We're not so sure. If the Chinese are going to carry out some form of aggression against Taiwan, it makes a lot of sense to do it in the next few weeks. First of all, the United States is now unprepared to respond quickly. From what we gather, the Clinton administration has gone out of its way to avoid 'provoking' the Chinese by stepping up our military presence in the region."

Meanwhile, the editorial noted, everyone knows the US government goes on vacation in August. And Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait, which also took everyone by surprise, occurred in August. If mainland China acts quickly, they can present the United States with a "fait accompli," it said.

The weekly doubted that the United States, under the current administration, will respond militarily to evict mainland Chinese forces or in some other way. In fact, it said, the Clinton administration might just choose the opposite course.

Why should the mainland Chinese, or anyone else, assume that an attack on one of Taiwan's offshore islands, or even an attack on a couple of Taiwanese airfields, would necessarily derail either President Bill Clinton's scheduled meeting with Jiang Zemin in mid-September or the giant party Beijing is holding for over 300 American CEOs in Shanghai later in September? the magazine asked.

If an attack is carried out, China experts and administration officials will argue that what is most needed is intensive diplomacy to diffuse the crisis. "Our guess is that after an attack, President Clinton would declare it more essential than ever to meet with Jiang," and do not bet on the Clinton administration canceling talks on mainland China's entry into the World Trade Organization, wrote the magazine.

In the end, the editorial said, the mainland Chinese might wind up demonstrating to Taiwan, and to the rest of East Asia, that the United States cares more about doing business with Beijing than about defending some small Taiwanese islands from attack. And that would really give mainland Chinese leaders something to celebrate on Oct. 1. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: US MAGAZINE SAYS MAINLAND MAY ACT SOONER RATHER THAN LATER (CONT'D)

TEXT.P: Some leaders in Congress -- notably Senate majority leader Trent Lott, Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Jesse Helms, Sen. Robert Torricelli and House International Relations Committee Chairman Benjamin Gilman -- have been strong in their support for Taiwan.

Friday morning, Sen. John McCain issued a statement criticizing the Clinton administration's "failed policy of pressuring Taiwan" and declaring, correctly, that "strategic ambiguity will not serve United States interests or values in this current crisis," according to the magazine.

The editorial continued that McCain called on the administration to be "very clear with Beijing that the United States will do what it must to help defend freedom and stability in Asia." Gary Bauer has also been a strong supporter of defending democratic Taiwan.

The Weekly Standard concluded, "Now it's time we hear from the other presidential candidates. If you aren't prepared to explain what we should do to defend Taiwan in the current crisis, why should anyone think you are prepared to be president?"

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SUPPORTS DEPORTATION OF ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS IN CANADA

TEXT.P: While public sentiment in Canada seems to support the decision to deport most of the mainland Chinese migrants who illegally arrived off British Columbia's coast last week, a dog that made the trip is receiving a rousing, warm welcome.

Dozens of Canadians have offered refuge to "Breeze," the golden-Lab cross, pregnant with puppies, who came across with the illegal immigrants, said the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Tuesday.
Her warm welcome stands in contrast to the attitude expressed toward the people who made the two-month voyage in a rusty ship.

"Go Home!" blared the front page of one West Coast newspaper over the weekend. Another, The Victoria Times-Colonist, reported that 97 percent of respondents to its poll said the migrants -- and another 123 who arrived last month -- should be sent home.

Immigration Canada appears to be listening. The department said 77 of last week's arrivals have been ordered out because they came to Canada to make money. Only 10 of the 131 plan to seek refugee status because many did not feel it was necessary for them to stay in Canada.

Department spokeswoman Janis Harper said for the most part, the migrants do not express fear at the prospect of returning to mainland China. People usually have 30 days to leave Canada after failing to file for refugee status, Harper said.
All 123 mainland Chinese nationals from the first ship, found July 20, claimed refugee status. Most of them are now free, awaiting refugee hearings in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: POVERTY, OPPRESSION DRIVE FUJIANESE TO ESCAPE, SAYS REFUGEE

TEXT.P: A costly, clandestine journey arranged by human smugglers is the only route out of poverty and oppression in mainland China for the desperate people of Fujian province, The Canadian Press (CP) reported Tuesday.

The CP quoted a recent Fujianese arrival to Canada as saying whether by boat -- like the two groups that arrived off the West Coast in the last month -- or more commonly by air, Fujianese know the journey has risks.
But the alternative is a hopeless existence under a corrupt government in an increasingly crowded piece of mainland China, the man told The Canadian Press.
The man, whose refugee claim was approved last fall, did not want to be identified because he is trying to bring his wife and two teen-age children to Canada, the CP noted in a report from Vancouver.
The refugee, who is a 43-year-old technician with a power company, said through an interpreter that he began having trouble at work because he is a Christian.
Fujian has been fertile ground for Western missionaries, but he said Communist Party membership, the key to job security and advancement, is denied to adherents of any religion.

Fujian is located on mainland China's eastern coast across from the island of Taiwan. Hemmed in by mountains, Fujian is known even in mainland China for its lack of elbow room. More than 30 million people live there.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DEFENSE DEPARTMENT SEES NOTHING UNUSUAL FROM MAINLAND FORCES

TEXT.P: The United States Department of Defense said Tuesday that it is not aware of any extraordinary activity by mainland Chinese Marines.

Meanwhile, when asked whether the United States has gradually reduced the quantity and quality of arms sales to Taiwan in accordance with the Aug. 17 communique signed with Beijing in 1982, State Department spokesman James Rubin said, "We believe we have lived up to all the communiques (signed by Beijing and Washington) as well as the Taiwan Relations Act."
The Xinhua News Agency reported Tuesday that mainland Chinese Marines were training for an amphibious landing somewhere in the South China Sea.

When asked if the Pentagon is concerned about a possible mainland Chinese amphibious assault on Taiwan, Defense Department spokesman Kenneth Bacon said, "China has about 5,000 marines -- an extremely small force. It has a very small fleet of amphibious vehicles, amphibious craft."

"The marines are based, generally, down in the south in a place called Zhanjiang. And they have standard training, and we're not aware that there is anything extraordinary going on with the marines, aside from their normal training," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOA SAYS MAINLAND CHINA PONDERING MOVES AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Voice of America (VOA) reported Tuesday that mainland China continues to denounce Taiwan and threaten military action against it more than a month after Taiwan insisted upon being treated as an equal state in its dealings with the mainland.
But apart from threats, scare tactics and inflammatory rhetoric, it said, "Beijing has apparently not yet made up its mind how to deal with what it considers Taiwan's slap in the face."

The US government-funded radio network reported from Beijing that battle tanks, self-propelled artillery pieces and missiles on flatbed trucks rumbled through the streets of the mainland capital Monday night in a rehearsal for the giant military parade to mark mainland China's 50th anniversary Oct. 1. But the display of military might also had another purpose: It projected an image of strength and resolve in the midst of what Beijing sees as a threat from Taiwan to move toward independence.

The VOA noted that mainland Chinese news media -- all of them controlled by the government -- have been unceasing in their vituperation against what they have called the separatist intentions of Taiwanese President Lee Teng-hui. Not only have they continued to insinuate that mainland China will use force against Taiwan, they are now reporting on military exercises and troop preparations in areas facing Taiwan.

Despite the rhetoric, the radio pointed out, Western and Asian diplomats in Beijing wonder just what Beijing will do to hit back at the Taiwanese leader. They said a real debate is going on within the Beijing regime, with hard-liners demanding some kind of military action and moderates advising a more cautious approach.

The options advocated by hard-liners include capturing small outlying islands and firing missiles to disrupt shipping in the Taiwan Strait. The moderates would rather put a freeze on contacts with Taiwan until after the island's presidential elections in March, said the report.

The VOA went on to say that most diplomats agree that what action mainland China may take depends in large part on the signals it gets from the United States. Washington has said any attack on Taiwan would be a matter of grave concern, "but it has remained purposefully ambiguous about what it would do."

Last week, the state-owned China Business Times acknowledged that the crucial issue is whether the United States would come to Taiwan's rescue. That, it said, "is a very big question mark," according to the VOA.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEEN AS URGING MAINLAND CHINA TO RESOLVE TAIWAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard is expected to urge mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully when the mainland Chinese leader makes his first visit to Canberra in early September, a veteran writer predicted.

Paul Kelly, international editor of The Australian, on Wednesday said Howard's "message over Taiwan will be that although Australia has a firm one-China policy, the entire region wants this issue resolved peacefully -- and that's a message to Taiwan as well."

Kelly said the Australian government would ideally like to see four results from the face to face talks with Jiang, who will become the highest-ranking mainland Chinese leader to visit Australia since Canberra recognized Beijing in late 1972.

They four results are: a showpiece economic announcement; a deepening of the two countries' political and economic partnership; progress on efforts to release imprisoned Australian citizen James Peng, who was kidnapped in the early 1990s, convicted of embezzlement and sentenced to 16 years in jail; and an ongoing neutralization of the Taiwan issue through bilateral relations.
In addition, Australia wants to sell liquefied natural gas to mainland China and wants another license for one of its insurance firms to operate in the mainland, Kelly said.

"The China relationship is where Australia benefits from its medium-power status. While the US knows China is its potential rival next century, Australia has no such hang-up. The Australia-China relationship is shaped by economic complementary and strategic asymmetry," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA WARNED OF COMPUTER CHAOS IF IT SABOTAGES E. TIMOR BALLOT

TEXT.P: An East Timorese independence leader has warned Indonesia that the country would be brought to a standstill by a global network of computer hackers if Jakarta sabotaged the UN-sponsored ballot on Aug. 30 to decide the future of the former Portuguese colony.

Nobel laureate Jose Ramos Horta warned of a "desperate and ferocious" international campaign against Indonesia that included developing a dozen special viruses to infect the country's electronic communications systems, including aviation.

He told The Sydney Morning Herald that more than 100 computer wizards, mostly teenagers in Europe and the United States, had been preparing a plan that would bring the world's fourth-most populous nation to a standstill for weeks.
Banks, the stock exchange and government computer systems would be targeted in particular, Horta said.
Horta, who represents the East Timor independence movement in Sydney and outside Indonesia, said he had been contacted by some of the people planning the attack and shown what they could do.
"They definitely have the ability to do this," he told the daily in an interview.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS DECLINE 1.1 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taipei share prices closed 1.1 percent lower on Wednesday despite serious buying which breached the 8,000-point level at one point during the day's trading.
The benchmark Taiwan Exchange Weighted Price Index dropped 89.72 points to close at 7,993.71 points, with a total of 3.33 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of NT$148.28 billion.

Among the eight major stock categories, construction issues reported the largest gains, ending the day up 2.6 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.9 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, cement issues at 0.6 percent and paper and pulp shares at 0.1 percent.

Electronics stocks, financial issues and plastic and chemical shares all posted losses, with electronics stocks suffering the largest decline of 2 percent. Plastic and chemical shares were down 1.2 percent, and financial issues dropped 0.8 percent.
The over-the-counter market declined 1.79 points to end the day at 168.79 points, on a turnover of NT$5.93 billion.
Meanwhile, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, expect for next June's futures, for which no contract transactions were registered.
TAIEX Index Futures for August dropped 130 points to the finish at 8,000, with 695 contract transactions; those for September closed 130 points lower at 8,060, with 3,571 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December were down 100 points to end at 8,080, with 25 contract transactions; those for next March fell 24 points, ending the day at 8,051, with four contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures on Wednesday were 8,130 points for August, 8,190 points for September, 8,180 points for December, 8,075 points for next March and 8,045 for next June.

August electronics futures (TE) plunged 7.65 points to close at 362.45, with 164 contract transactions; those for September shed 10.4 points to finish at 362, with 761 contract transactions. December TE moved down 8.1 points ending the day at 166.1, with four contract transactions. There were no transactions recorded for TE for the other months.

August financial futures (TF) were up 10.2 points, ending the day at 1,180.2, with three contract transactions; those for September declined 22 points to close at 1,169, with 229 contract transactions.
There were no transactions registered for next March and next June TF.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO SELL ITS DEFENSE BUSINESS TO PRIVATE VENTURE

TEXT.P: The Australian government plans to sell its defense business -- ADI Limited -- to a private joint venture of Australian and French companies.

Defense Minister John Moore and Finance Minister John Fahey jointly announced that Australian company Transfied Holdings and the French aerospace company Thomson-CSF would be the government's preferred buyers.
But the opposition Labor Party's Spokesman Stephen Martin attacked the plan as risking future access to American know-how.

"I am seeking an assurance from the minister that the acquisition of ADI by a foreign national will in no way compromise Australia's ability to access defense technology, particularly from the United States," he told reporters.

Thomson CSF is partly owned by the French government, raising the possibility that Australia may have difficulties in the event of future policy disagreements between the two governments, which are at present on good terms.
ADI is Australia's largest defense contractor and employs 3,000 people. It is among the state enterprises to be privatized by the federal government.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 INTERNATIONAL YOUTH CULTURAL AND STUDY TOUR OPENS

TEXT.P: The 1999 International Youth Culture and Study Tour to Taiwan, ROC, jointly sponsored by the Education Ministry and the Foreign Affairs Ministry, opened Wednesday at the Chientan Overseas Youth Activity Center.
The annual international activity attracted 161 students from 51 countries, including 26 diplomatic allies of the Republic of China around the world.

The activity is expected to end on Aug. 28. The 161 students will visit official institutions and some famous sightseeing spots in southwestern Taiwan. They will also be treated to local folk art performances.

The event's sponsor said that the 161 students will visit the Education Ministry and the Taipei City Government on Aug. 19. They will also meet Premier Vincent Siew that same day. On Aug. 24, they will leave for Kaohsiung, where they will visit the Kaohsiung City Government. In addition, they will tour Kenting National Park, the Shitou Forest Recreation Area and the Formosan Culture Village.
The 1999 International Youth Culture and Study Tour to Taiwan, ROC activity will conclude with a farewell dinner party and closing ceremony on Aug. 27, said the sponsor.

DOC.HEADLINE: DHL TO POUR US$30 MILLION INTO TAIWAN MARKET

TEXT.P: World-renowned DHL Worldwide Express, which has been in the Taiwan market for 26 years, has decided to invest US$30 million in Taiwan to reinforce its fleet of aircraft and equipment to provide customers better service, the manager of DHL's Taiwan branch, Lu Li-hsing, announced on Wednesday.

According to Lu, DHL's headquarters has announced an investment plan worth US$1.5 billion, which includes the purchase of aircraft and information and technology equipment, as well as the establishment of additional ground service facilities.

Of the total investment, US$1.3 billion will be used to procure aircraft. In addition there will be a US$234 million investment in Taiwan, Japan, Singapore and Germany to strengthen ground service facilities in those areas.
The new aircraft DHL plans to purchase are expected to join the European and African air transportation network by 2001, and they will replace its current fleet of B727 aircraft.
The enhancement of hardware facilities in Asian and European airports is another important component of the investment plan.
DHL, which entered the Taiwan market in 1973, was the first of the four international express companies now operating in Taiwan. Its range of services covers 227 countries and areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRITER RECRUITED BY NEW PARTY TO RUN IN PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: Much to the surprise of pundits around Taiwan, the tiny opposition New Party announced on Wednesday that it has recruited Lee Ao, a famous local writer, to run in the island's March 2000 presidential election.
Lawmaker Lee Ching-hua, a New Party stalwart and head of the party's National Campaign and Development Committee, announced the party's decision at a news conference.

The New Party decided to field Lee Ao as its presidential hopeful because of his strong opposition to Taiwan independence and money politics, and because of his overwhelming support for less-privileged groups and the pursuit of peaceful co-existence across the Taiwan Strait, the lawmaker said, adding that the party shares these same aspirations.
According to Lee Ching-hua, Lee Ao accepted the invitation to run last Friday, and his candidacy will be approved in the near future at the New Party's national congress meeting.
Lee Ao, 64, is a savvy historian famous in Taiwan for his fierce criticism of aspects of society with which he disagrees, and has written a number of books.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SET FOR KMT PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATION

TEXT.P: The Central Standing Committee of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang on Wednesday named Lien Chan as the party's presidential candidate to be voted for in party primaries scheduled to be held on Aug. 21.
The nomination will be formally announced by the committee on Thursday.

Lien has obtained the support of 2,119 out of the total 2,182 delegates to the party primaries, or 97.2 percent, far surpassing the minimum 10 percent support rate required by a hopeful candidate under KMT election rules.
The election will be simultaneously held in Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Hualien and Taitung counties on Saturday.

The election result will be submitted to the Central Standing Committee for reference on Aug. 25, the same date on which the presidential candidate should submit his choice of running-mate (candidate for the vice presidency) for party approval.
The party's nomination will be approved by the second plenary session of the 15th Party Congress on Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR RISES

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.019 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 31.950.
The local currency opened at 31.960, and was traded between 31.960 and 31.934.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$418.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HOUSEHOLD AVERAGE INCOME RISES 1.27 TIMES IN 10 YEARS

TEXT.P: The average monthly regular income of families in Taipei City have increased 1.27 times over the last 10 years, according to statistics released on Wednesday by the Taipei City Government.

The results, based on a survey of income and expenditure of Taipei City citizens, show that as the economy has developed over the period, the household revenue and savings of Taipei City residents have also increased.

According to the statistics, monthly household regular incomes increased from NT$46,412 in 1988 to NT$105,231 in 1998, and jumped again in the first half of 1999 to NT$113,836. During the same 10-year period, disposable income went up 1.29 times, while savings increased 1.92 times.

However, the percentage of average household consumption compared to household earnings has dropped, posting a downward trend from 80.81 percent in 1988 to 75.53 percent in 1998, and a further drop to 72.58 percent during the January-June period of 1999.

Meanwhile, the Engel Coefficient, which gauges living standards by comparing a family's eating expenses as a percentage of total family expenditure, posted a decrease from 29.88 percent in 1988 to 21.6 percent in 1998, while the coefficient for the first half of 1999 was 21.56 percent. The lower the Engel Coefficient, the higher the standard of living.

Taipei's Engel Coefficient for 1998 was far lower than the 25.28 percent recorded for the island as a whole, showing that the city possesses the characteristics of a highly urbanized city -- high income, high consumption, and high living standards.
The average monthly household expenditure used in dining out was NT$1,571 in 1988, a figure which had risen to NT$3,899 by 1998, and NT$3,886 in the first half of 1999, respectively.

In addition, transportation, education and recreation, and health care expenses jumped from 7.92 percent, 12.36 percent and 4.19 percent, respectively, in 1988 to 8.27 percent, 15.16 percent, and 8.57 percent, respectively, in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AMERICAN TOP LEADERS TO MEET IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will host a leadership meeting in Taipei on Sept. 7 with the participation of senior leaders from Central American countries, Foreign Minister Jason Hu announced on Wednesday.
This will be the first time that the ROC has hosted a summit meeting with its Central American allies.
The ROC's diplomatic allies in Central America, including El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Guatemala and Honduras, will send their top leaders to attend the first-ever Taipei summit, Hu said.
According to Hu, heads of state from some Central American countries will arrive in Taipei as early as Sept. 3 for the extravaganza.
As Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez made a state visit to the ROC last September, Costa Rica will send its first vice president to attend the Taipei summit meeting.

Hu said participants to a recent Central American foreign ministers meeting had discussed the agenda and other technical details concerning the upcoming leadership meeting. "The theme and meeting schedule will be finalized by the end of this month," he added.

The minister went on to say that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will also arrange for heads of state of two ROC allies in the Caribbean -- the Dominican Republic and Belize -- to visit Taipei later this year.
Central America and the Caribbean are the ROC's diplomatic stronghold where many of its diplomatic allies are located.

Responding to press reports that mainland China has stepped up efforts to court some ROC diplomatic allies to switch diplomatic allegiance amid the recent controversy over the "special state-to-state relationship" theory, Hu said Beijing has never ceased its efforts to isolate the ROC in the international community.

Hu said he knows that Beijing is lobbying several ROC allies to switch diplomatic recognition. However, Hu declined to identify those countries. He instead said the MOFA will make every possible effort to cement ties with all ROC allies.
Hu recently attended separate Central American and Caribbean foreign ministers meetings. Hu said many allies have expressed concern about the current Taiwan Strait situation.

"I have told them that President Lee Teng-hui's definition of cross-strait ties as a 'special state-to-state relationship' is aimed at stressing parity in Taipei-Beijing relations and does not mark a change in its policy toward mainland China," Hu said, adding that if Beijing could understand the ROC's true intention, cross-strait ties will make positive progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1999 IMPORTS EXPECTED TO SCORE POSITIVE GROWTH: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's annual imports are expected to register positive annual growth this year, according to government assessments based on figures accumulated from Jan 1 to Aug. 31, 1999.

Import-export statistics released every two weeks by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) showed on Wednesday that the value of Taiwan's exports from Aug. 1-14 totaled US$4.6 billion, a growth rate of 8.2 percent compared to the same period of last year, while imports totaled US$4.11 billion, an increase of 11 percent. The figures represent a trade surplus of US$490 million for the two-week period.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the Department of Statistics under the MOF, pointed out that the island's exports for the whole of August are likely to exceed US$10 billion, while imports should also enjoy double-digit growth as a result of a surge in private investment and increasing demand for imported capital goods.

According to MOF statistics, telecommunication products formed the bulk of the island's exports in the first half of August, while agricultural and industrial raw materials, as well as capital goods, formed the bulk of imports.

Taiwan's export value from Jan. 1 to Aug. 14 totaled US$72 billion, or year-on-year growth of 6.5 percent, while import value totaled US$64.8 billion, a slight decline of 0.04 percent, according to the statistics.
The island's export value started to grow from April this year, and the scale of the decline of import value has narrowed since May, and in fact has almost come to a halt, said Hsu.

In view of the facts that Taiwan's export performance has been robust since spring and that economic prospects are looking increasingly bright, private investment has gradually increased, which in turn has led to a growth in demand for imports, noted the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN STEPS UP EFFORTS TO WOO YOUNG TAIWAN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Japan has stepped up efforts to attract tourists from Taiwan, particularly young fans of Japanese pop culture and music.

A tourist marketing manual compiled by Japan's Ministry of Transportation suggested that Japanese tourist service operators focus their efforts on courting repeat Taiwan visitors and design tour packages catering to the taste of young Republic of China nationals.

The Marketing Manual said travel agencies can include sightseeing spots that once appeared in popular Japanese soap operas or movies. It also suggested that tour guides arrange for young Taiwan tourists to visit shops that sell products featuring popular cartoon figures.

According to tallies by the Taiwan Visitors Association, ROC nationals made 840,000 visits to Japan last year, surpassing for the first time the number of Japanese visitors to Taiwan, which stood at 830,000.
Japanese tourist sources said more than 60 percent of Taiwan visitors to Japan are tourists and that their purchasing power is very impressive.
Taiwan replaced South Korea as Japan's largest source of tourists last year as South Korea was hit by a financial crisis and economic recession.

As part of its efforts to woo Taiwan tourists, Japan has decided to further ease visa restrictions for Taiwan visitors. Starting Sept. 1, multiple-entry visa holders from Taiwan will be allowed 90-day visits over a five-year period, compared to the current 15-day visits over a three-year period.

DOC.HEADLINE: DENG'S CREDO ENCOURAGES WIDESPREAD CORRUPTION IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The famous credo of mainland China's late Deng Xiaoping -- "to get rich is glorious" -- has helped encourage widespread corruption despite stringent efforts by Premier Zhu Rongji to eradicate the problem, which is expected to remain for many years to come.
In a dispatch from Beijing, The Australian on Wednesday reported Chinese Communist Party cadres throughout mainland China have set about amassing often obscene wealth by pilfering the public purse.

In the first half of 1999, the endemic corruption had already cost the mainland Chinese government about US$13 billion, and much of it was pilfered by provincial government officials, the daily reported.

Money allocated for specific projects such as water conservancy and flood control and interest earned on pension funds and government department budgets had been siphoned off and deposited in the private bank accounts of officials, the daily reported, quoting the country's auditor general.

Officials have employed a range of tricks to cheat the government, such as forged tax rebate invoices, under-reporting of duties collected on imports and exports, failure to allocate money to designated projects and diversion of funds to other uses, such as the building of luxury offices and apartment blocks, the daily reported.
The daily reported increasingly frequent protests by farmers and workers often focus on such corrupt practices as the collection of illegal taxes by Communist Party officials.

Misuse of government funds has also been blamed for various tragedies such as the collapse of buildings and bridges that have resulted in deaths. In addition, corruption and smuggling have been eating away at the fabric of mainland Chinese society since the late Deng launched policies in 1978 to reform the economy, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO TACKLE ECONOMIC PROBLEMS: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing's leadership has decided to focus attention on solving domestic problems and to refrain from escalating reactions against Taiwan unless Taipei takes concrete moves forward in regard to Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's call for "special state-to-state" ties with the mainland, The Hong Kong Standard reported Wednesday.

The leadership reached an agreement during their meeting in the northern sea resort of Beidaihe early this month that the focus of their work for the latter half of this year should be concentrated on "bottleneck" problems in the economy, the report quoted a Beijing source as saying.
The country's leaders view domestic affairs, especially "bottleneck" problems complicating economic reform, as more urgent and serious than the Taiwan issue, the same source said.
Such bottleneck problems include stagnation in restructuring the state sector, the continuation of deflation and the further shrinkage of the domestic market.

As for reform in the state sector, the leaders in their meetings endorsed principles set forth by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in several of his "key" speeches, made during inspection trips in recent months.

They also agreed to present the principles to the fourth plenary session of the Communist Party' s policy-making Central Committee, to be convened next month, for formal endorsement as government policy, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TMD SYSTEM MEETS TAIWAN'S NEED: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui who is also the chairman of the Kuomintang party on Wednesday asked KMT party members serving in his Cabinet to conduct a study on the installation of the Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system.
Lee described the TMD system as not only being able to meet Taiwan's current security needs but also providing long-term protection.

After being briefed by Minister of National Defense Tang Fei on the need for the TMD at the weekly meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, Lee then asked party members in the Cabinet to study Tang's suggestions on converting the island's armed forces into a lean and mean military force as well as ways to protect the public from a Beijing missile attack.
Tang, during his 30-minute briefing, analyzed the political, economic, defensive and psychological aspects of installing the TMD.
While the text of Tang's brief was classified -- copies were collected after the meeting -- portions were released to the media by KMT spokesman Huang Hui-chen later in the day.

Huang quoted Tang as saying that the anti-missile system is vital to Taiwan's security, especially the low altitude defense system which, combined with other air-defense measures, can effectively protect the island from airborne attacks.
Given the fact that missile attacks inflict more psychological impact than physical damage, Tang urged a campaign be conducted to lessen public fear of a missile attack.
