Tang said that although the TMD system can ease the immediate threats posed by Beijing's missiles, Taiwan's security will be further challenged in the next decade, making a transformation of the armed forces essential.
Tang's brief, stated amid increasing Beijing-Taipei tension, won praise from several members of the KMT Central Standing Committee during the meeting, said Huang.

Huang added that during the meeting, both former Minister of National Defense Chiang Chung-ling, and former Secretary General of the National Security Council Ding Mou-shih emphasized the importance of national security and called for increasing the national defense budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER CAR ACCIDENT IN US KILLS 4 TAIWAN TRAVELERS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Huang Kwei-mei & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A car accident in the United States claimed the lives of four Taiwan travelers and seriously injured three others Wednesday near Las Vegas, Nevada, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
The Taiwan visitors were traveling from Yosemite National Park in California toward Las Vegas when the accident occurred.

It was the second fatal traffic accident involving Taiwan visitors in the United States in less than one week. On Aug. 12, a van carrying ten Taiwanese students studying in New York, rolled over near Fremont County, eastern Idaho, killing four and injuring six others.
The victims of Wednesday's accident were all members of a 18-person group from National Chung Cheng University in Chia Yi County, central Taiwan.
Headed by Associated Professor Chen Ming-chang, the group arrived in San Francisco Aug. 12, and was scheduled to tour various scenic spots until Aug. 30.
The injured were rushed to hospitals near Las Vegas for treatment.

The Foreign Ministry has asked its representative offices in the United States to find the cause of the tragedy and offer necessary assistance as soon as possible. (By Bear Lee) EDITEM ZCZC CEP031 08-18-99 JAPANESE NEWSPAPER SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S 'STATE-TO-STATE' CLAIMS
Tokyo, Aug. 18 (CNA) The mass-circulated newspaper Sankei Shimbun urged the Japanese government on Wednesday to support President Lee Tung-hui's redefinition of the Taiwan-Beijing relationship.
In its evening edition, the newspaper said in its "Tide Watch" column that Japan should break free from the fictitious "one China" policy, and back Taiwan's democratic development.

The column, signed with the pseudonym "Multiple Eyes Dragon", called President Lee's characterization of Taipei-Beijing ties as a "special state-to-state" relationship, "a move that exposes the underlying fact by clearing ideological prejudice."
The column cited polls showing that 73 percent of the Taiwan people favor Lee's new definition while only 17 percent oppose it.

The influential paper said Taiwan, after a decade of democratic and economic reforms, sharply contrasts with the communist-totalitarian regime on mainland China, and it would be impossible to incorporate the two systems into a "one China".
As is the fact now, a "one China" can not be realized without resorting to force -- something that is unacceptable to the international community, the column said.

Therefore, the paper said, President Lee is right in pointing out that "one China" is not an existing fact, rather, it is a goal to be carried out in the future when mainland China has fully democratized.
In other words, the only peaceful way to achieve a "one China" is for mainland China to follow Taiwan's footsteps on the path toward democracy, said the daily.
Instead of fooling itself with the false "one China" policy, the author called on Tokyo to review its policy toward mainland China and Taiwan.

The column urged the Japanese government to expand exchanges with Taiwan in the fields of politics, economics and culture. It also said Taiwan's bid for World Trade Organization membership should be supported by the Japanese government as well as President Lee's attendance at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum summit next month in Auckland, New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED REACTIONS TO WRITER'S NEW PARTY CANDIDACY

TEXT.P: The decision of the opposition New Party to nominate the well-known writer Lee Ao as its presidential candidate in 2000 presidential race has received mixed reactions on Wednesday.

Hsieh Chung-yu, a member of National Assembly from the New Party, called Lee's nomination an "explosive story" since he had not previously been informed of the event. Hsieh, however, spoke highly of Lee as a well-known critic of social affairs. Hsieh predicted the nomination would be a good selling point for the party.
Hsieh doubted whether Lee would affect the number of votes former Taiwan Governor James Soong would receive in next spring's election.
Mei Tzai-hsing, a New Party Kaohsiung City Council member, said that he supports Lee's nomination.

Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the leading opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), welcomed Lee as a candidate. Chen said he hoped that the upcoming election would be fairly contested by all participants.
Former DPP chairman Hsu Hsin-liang who is running as an independent, also welcomed the New Party's candidate and said that the participation of Lee will improve the atmosphere of election.

Chiu Yi-jen, executive secretary general for Chen Shui-bian's campaign headquarters, said that the participation of Lee further complicates the election. Chiu described Lee as an "explosive" candidate. Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION DISQUALIFIED AS POLITICAL PARTY

TEXT.P: An Australian court in Queensland on Wednesday annulled One Nation's standing as a political party on grounds that it frauded its registration in 1997.

One Nation President Pauline Hanson, who was once a household name in Australia as well as overseas due to controversial comments advocating policies that were anti-Asian immigration, anti-multiculturalism and anti-Aboriginal people, refused to make any comment after hearing the decision on Wednesday morning.

She said she would consult her lawyer before making any move to appeal the court's decision against her party, which stunned the world by winning 11 seats in a June 1998 election in the state of Queensland. But the party's fortune has since declined, with support now down to only 2 percent from its height of 13 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANSON CHAN SEEN AS HONG KONG'S FUTURE LEADER

TEXT.P: Hong Kong Chief Secretary for Administration Anson Chan, formerly seen as too pro-British, is now acceptable to mainland China as a future chief executive of the special administrative region, according to the August 26 issue of the Far Eastern Economic Review.

Quoting official sources in Beijing, the magazine reveals in an advance copy that while mainland Chinese leaders trust Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa and are generally happy with his performance, there is a feeling that he lacks political strength.

The article cites Chan's recent performance in Washington, where she strongly defended Hong Kong against charges that the territory is a transshipment point through which mainland China receives banned hi-tech products. (By Stanley Cheung) EDITERM ZCZC CEP035 08-18-99 EXPERT WARNS OF FOREIGN CAPITAL OUTFLOW IF SHARE INDEX BREAKS 10,000

Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) An expert on financial management warned the government on Wednesday that foreign stock market investors will take their profits and run once the local bourse reaches the 10,000-point mark.
Dr. Cheng F. Lee from the US State University of New Jersey, Rutgers, made the remarks during a speech delivered at Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Lee, a renowned financial professor and an economics consultant to Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, pointed out that Taiwan is the only Asian country to have remained relatively unscathed by the Asian financial crisis, so it is not surprising that foreign capital rushed into Taiwan to make easy profits.
However, Lee continued, one should never expect foreign capital to stay forever.

The excessive inflow of foreign capital from the beginning of the year has already resulted in an overheated stock market and a "bubble rally," but fortunately, the share prices gradually cooled down in the wake of selling panic sparked by the president's "special state-to-state relationships" remark in early July, Lee noted.
He added that he considers it unnecessary for government-linked funds to enter the market for stability as long as the stock index maintains the 7,500-point level.
He also urged the Central Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance to take measures to slow down the appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KAOHSIUNG MAYOR ANNOUNCES SUPPORT FOR VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Dun-yi, who has not previously endorsed Vice President Lien Chan as the ruling Kuomintang's presidential candidate, on Wednesday announced his support for Lien.
Attending his first KMT Central Standing Committee meeting in two months, Wu was treated to the kind of media treatment usually reserved for pop stars as he stepped into the conference room.

In an attempt to clarify speculation that he supported former Taiwan Governor James Soong rather than Lien, Wu for the first time made public his endorsement of Lien, stressing that as a KMT member, it is natural for him to back the candidate nominated by the party.

Meanwhile, he remained tight-lipped regarding whether or not he will accept the position of minister without portfolio made vacant by Wu Rong-ming, who reportedly quit the job in order to assist Soong in his presidential campaign.

Other sources have revealed that the Executive Yaun is planning to assign Wu as head of a new coastal patrol administration to be set up next year, a position equivalent to that of Cabinet minister in terms of ranking.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG LEADING PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL: DPP POLL

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong is leading three other presidential hopefuls in a survey released by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday.

Soong, who will run as an independent and has been at the top of most polls conducted by various groups, was favored by 31.3 of the 1,097 eligible voters in the DPP telephone survey conducted between Aug. 11-13 in 23 counties and cities around Taiwan.
The survey has a margin of error of 3 percent.
Immediately trailing Soong was former Taipei mayor and DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian, with a support rate of 21 percent.
Vice President Lien Chan, who is sure to be the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang, was in third place with 17.7 percent of the support.
Former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, who earlier this year quit the party he co-founded in 1986 to run in the 2000 presidential election as an independent, had a support rate of only 0.7 percent.
The DPP said that "it released the results of the survey to refute untrue reports" that Chen's support had fallen to a point below Lien.

Analyzing the results of the four surveys the DPP conducted between July and mid-August, the party said that Chen's support rate had stabilized at between 20 percent and 22 percent; while Lien's support had increased by 4 percentage points -- from 13 percent to 17 percent; Soong's support had dropped 5 percentage points -- from 36 percent to 31 percent.
When asked whether the rotation of different ruling parties would be dangerous for the island, 56.8 percent of those surveyed said "no", while 26.3 percent said "yes."

On the controversial issue regarding Taiwan's future status, 44 percent of the surveyed said they favor an independent Taiwan, 25 percent supported Taiwan's unification with the mainland China, while 9 percent preferred to keep the status quo.

The presidential race, scheduled to be held next March, was further complicated earlier in the day when the tiny opposition New Party announced that it had recruited the well-known author Lee Ao to run on its ticket. Bear Lee

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS WITH VISITING US CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui met with visiting US congressman John Cooksey on Wednesday.
Lee explained his "special state-to-state relations" theory to the Louisiana Republican representative, stressing ROC's sovereignty in terms of history and law.
Lee, who was an agro-economist before entering into politics, also exchanged views on agriculture development with Cooksey who is also interested in the field.
Cooksey praised the development of Taiwan's intensive farming and said he was impressed by the island's automated irrigation system.
The US representative was surprised when President Lee told him that hard-working Taiwan farmers manage to harvest grain four times a year from the island's limited arable fields.

Lee attributed the island's agricultural achievement to the government's land reform program implemented between 1949-1953. That program distributed land to peasants, boosting their willingness to work in agriculture.
Lee told Cooksey that land reform has led to farmers working 280 days a year with agricultural production increasing annually.
Earlier in the day, Cooksey called on the Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian.
He told Chen it is unlikely that US President Bill Clinton will change his policy toward Taiwan as only one and a half years remain in his term.

The US Congressman also reaffirmed his support for Taiwan's participation in the US-led Theater Missile Defense program and ensured Chen that Washington would not bow to pressure from Beijing and back down on its commitment to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUNDS F-16S

TEXT.P: The Air Force grounded all of its US-made F-16 jet fighters following a crash in Chiayi Wednesday that caused Premier Vincent Siew to order a thorough probe into its cause.

It was the fourth crash involving a F-16 since they were commissioned into the Taiwan Air Force. The grounding occurs only two weeks after the fighters were released from a previous 90-day grounding following the disappearance of a fighter into the sea on June 1.
Taiwan has purchased 150 F-16s from the United States, although only a portion of them have already been delivered.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40 FORMER JAPAN'S TAIWAN SOLDIERS PROTEST IN DIETMEN HALL

TEXT.P: Forty-seven former Taiwanese soldiers who fought for Japan in World War II protested on Wednesday in front of the Dietmen's Hall in downtown Tokyo against what they called insufficient compensation by the Japanese government to them.
The Asahi Shinbum in its evening edition reported that the protesters were recruited by the Japanese government during the Second World War to construct the airport in Southeast Asia.

The newspaper quoted Chen Ching-tsu, a 72-year-old former soldier from Kaohsiung as saying that in October 1943, some 1,000 young men from Taiwan were recruited to go to Indonesia to build a military airport. The wage was 108 yen per month. He and his fellow soldiers only received the first three months of their promised 18-month payment. Chen claimed the remainder has yet to be paid.
In 1995, the Japanese government unilaterally announced that it would offer a compensation 120 times that of the original amount of the unpaid salary.

Chen pointed out that this figure was too small. Taking himself as an example, he worked for 18 months, therefore he would only receive 230,000 Japanese yen in compensation if he accepted the Japanese government offer.
Chen said the workers risked their lives during the World War II ,and he described the Japanese move as "inhumane."

According to Japan's Health and Welfare Ministry, only 38,272 out of a total of 84,000 former soldiers from South East Asia recruited by the Imperial Japanese Armed Forces had accepted the compensation offer as of July 31, this year. (By Huang Kuei-Mei & Edward Che)n

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC SAYS NO NEED TO RETRACT 'SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Wednesday again turned down a request by mainland China that it retract the "special state-to-state relations" theory in regard to cross-strait relations.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi said that the theory spelled out by President Lee Teng-hui early last month simply seeks to clarify the reality across the Taiwan Strait, and there is no need for the Republic of China government to retract it.

Premier Vincent Siew made the same comment Tuesday in response to mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's remarks that the "special state-to-state' theory is purely Lee's own view and that Beijing is waiting for Taipei to retract the theory so as to pave the way for the opening of cross-strait political negotiations.

Su was responding to reports that Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office has openly asked Taipei to abandon the theory, saying that by doing so and returning to the "one China" principle, the mainland will be able to resume dialogues with Taiwan on political, economic as well as a wide range of other issues.
Su asked Beijing not to set any preconditions or barriers to the improvement of cross-strait exchanges.
He said that judging from the results of various surveys, President Lee's redefinition of cross-strait relations has won the support of most people in Taiwan.
"The theory is the voice of a majority of people, and the next ROC president, whoever he will be, will not deviate from it," Su said.

Su reiterated that Taiwan welcomes the scheduled fall visit to the island by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS). "We have been very sincere in continuing constructive dialogue with the mainland," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIP REMAINS DRIVING FORCE BEHIND TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) remained the driving force behind the country's economic growth in the first half of this year as both its business turnover and exports continued to expand, the government said on Thursday.

With flying-color growth of 33.6 percent in its overall business turnover and 31 percent in exports, the HSIP is expected to continue to lead Taiwan's economic growth, estimated to top 5.3 percent for the year 1999, said officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
HSIP manufacturers and companies generated NT$284 billion (US$8.8 billion) worth of business turnover in the first six months of this year, up 33.6 percent over the year-earlier level.

Of the total, companies of integrated circuits (ICs) contributed NT$149.3 billion (US$4.65 billion); followed by computer and peripheral makers with NT$97 billion (US$3.02 billion); and optical-electronics and telecommunications firms with NT$35 billion (US$1.09 billion), DGBAS officials quoted tallies provided by the industrial park as indicating.
In the Jan.-June period, HSIP companies exported NT$166.7 billion (US$5.2 billion) worth of products, comprising about 10 percent of Taiwan's entire exports in the six-month period.
Of the total, the exports of computers and peripherals amounted to NT$84 billion (US$2.6 billion), up 36 percent as compared with those posted in the same period a year ago.

The exports of ICs totaled NT$54 billion (US$1.68 billion), up 13.4 percent, optical-electronics' exports totaled NT$10.9 billion (US$339.56 million), up 27.7 percent, and telecommunications, totaled 6.8 billion (US$211.8 million), an increase of 15.8 percent.
The United States remained HSIP's largest export outlet by absorbing NT$42 billion (US$1.3 billion) worth of products from the park in the first half year.

Japan was the second-largest export market, receiving NT$30.6 billion (US$0.95 billion) worth of HSIP-originating products, followed by Hong Kong, NT$20.4 billion (US$635.5 million), and the Philippines, with NT$14.2 billion (US$442.37 million).
The NT$14.2 billion worth of exports to the Philippines was a substantial increase of 242.5 percent over the same period a year ago, according to DGBAS officials.
As of the end of July this year, there were 284 manufacturers and companies operating in the HSIP, 24 more than a year ago. Of the total, 116 firms were IC makers, 10 more than in July 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 PILOT PERFORMANCE 'COMMENDABLE': AIR FORCE
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Major Lin Keng-sheng's daring escape from an F-16 jet fighter which crashed due to mechanical failure on Wednesday was a commendable performance, officers from the Chiayi Airbase said on Thursday.
Lin parachuted to safety on Wednesday morning after his second attempt to land the F-16 single-seater failed.

Returning from a routine training mission, Lin discovered he was unable to obtain enough thrust from the fighter. He was forced to eject after repeated efforts to correct the malfunction proved ineffective.

The fighter, one of the 44 F-16s stationed at the Chiayi airbase, crashed some 1.8 kilometers south of the base runway, while Lin ejected to safety. He is currently hospitalized with bone fractures in both legs.

Nothing was improper in Lin's handling of the emergency and his "abandonment" of the jet fighter was virtually inevitable under the circumstances, said Col. Yueh Hsiu-chi, chief general staff officer at the Chiayi Airbase.

Lin, 36, a flight instructor assigned to the F-16 wing, narrowly escaped death as he repeatedly tried to save the aircraft and did not parachute to safety until the fighter was less than 300 feet (about 91 meters) from the ground, Yueh said.
Yueh described the ejection as "daring" because Air Force fighter pilots are trained to escape from an aircraft at no less than 2,000 feet (610 meters) from the ground.
As an experienced pilot who has accumulated 2,380 hours in military aircraft, including 220 hours exclusively in F-16s, Lin's handling of the situation was proper and commendable, said Yueh.

Yueh made the analysis to a group of Control Yuan members, including Chao Chang-ping, who flew to the southern Taiwan airbase to gain further understanding of Wednesday's crash, the fourth such incident involving an F-16 since a portion of the US-made jet fighters were commissioned into the Taiwan Air Force in 1997.
Taiwan has purchased 150 F-16s from the United States in 1992, although only some 100 have been delivered to date.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MERCHANDISE EXPORTS TO TAIWAN, CHINA UP

TEXT.P: Australia's primary products continue to dominate its exports while its manufactured exports are rising in importance, according to Trade Minister Mark Vaile on Thursday.

In a statement faxed to CNA on Thursday, Vaile said: "Primary products still account for 58 percent of merchandise exports, but manufactures have moved up from 22 percent to 28 percent over the past decade."
"Wine exports have grown by 35 percent in 1998, and have gone on to break through the A$1 billion (US$666 million) mark in the first half of 1999," he said.
He said although exports to the Asia Pacific region fell, APEC member countries, including Taiwan, China and Hong Kong, accounted for 70 percent of Australia's merchandise exports in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA CONTINUES TO THREATEN TAIWAN WITH FORCE: CBC

TEXT.P: Mainland China leveled more threats at Taiwan Wednesday over the island's political future, Canada's national broadcaster said.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. said Beijing is warning Taiwan not to pursue any move toward more independence.
Taiwan said it wants to be treated as an equal partner in future economic and diplomatic relations with China, the CBC noted in a report from Beijing

DOC.HEADLINE: 'KID BOAT PEOPLE' FROM CHINA SEEN AS 'UNUSUAL' PHENOMENON

TEXT.P: It is unusual in Chinese culture for parents to send their children away from their homes unaccompanied, a Canadian expert said Wednesday of the scores of migrant children among the 131 boat people that landed in western Canada last week.

David Lai, a University of Victoria professor who specializes in China issues, said, "Based on Chinese tradition, you don't send a child of 11 years old out of your country without guarantees of care from a relative."
"It's unusual for a parent to do that unless the parents are crazy," Lai told The Canadian Press in Victoria, BC.
Many of the Chinese migrant children who spent 60 days aboard a cargo ship sailing from Fujian will go to British Columbia group homes until their refugee status is decided.

The estimated 53 Chinese children ranging in age from 11 to 18 years old made the lengthy voyage to BC's coast on a cramped human smuggling ship without their parents or relatives, investigators found.
Immigration Canada officials are still trying to determine why the children would make such a long journey to a strange land alone.
"Most of the children have said they were put on the boat by families and relatives and told to come to Canada," said Jim Redmond, an Immigration Canada spokesman in Victoria.

Since the children appear to be without family members or relatives, the B.C. government must legally assume their guardianship. The provincial Family Relations Act appoints the province as the legal guardian if the child "has no guardian or if the guardian appointed is dead, refuses or is incompetent at law to act."

The estimated cost of providing group home care for each migrant youth is about C$8,200 (NT$172,000) per month. That includes about C$1,200 each month for interpreters and English language courses, but does not include medical costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DONATES A$1 M. TO TURKEY FOR QUAKE RELIEF

TEXT.P: Australia has initially pledged A$1 million (US$666,666) to help victims of the earthquake in Turkey.

The Australian money will be divided between the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent societies so that the Turkish Relief operations can use it to provide needed water, food and medical supplies, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S CENTRAL BANK CONCERNED ABOUT VALUE-ADDED TAX

TEXT.P: As Australia is set to introduce for the first time a 10 percent goods and service tax the Reserve Bank is expressing concern about its possible inflationary impact.
In its quarterly report, the central bank says: "The main economic event now in the horizon in Australia is the introduction of the tax reform package in July 2000."

The government estimates that the GST will add a little more than 2 percent to the Consumer Price Index in the long run but the central bank warns that the initial impact in the third quarter of 2000 could be higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM THREATENING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A tropical storm near the Philippines is continuing to gain strength and is likely to turn into a typhoon which directly threatens Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported on Thursday.
The tropical pressure, which will be named Sam if it develops into a typhoon, was situated some 750 kilometers southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun as of 2:00 p.m. Thursday.

Moving in a north-westerly direction toward Taiwan at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour, the low pressure mass is very likely to affect Taiwan in the following two days as its power continues to strengthen, CWB weathermen warned.
The weather bureau will issue a sea warning later Thursday if the low pressure mass does not change its course or reduces its speed, the weathermen said.

By Saturday, the whole island of Taiwan is expected to be under the low pressure's influence with the accompanying torrential rainfall, they said, adding that the rainfall will continue until next Monday.
Sam will be the second typhoon to directly influence Taiwan this year after Rachel, which caused torrential rainfall in central and southern Taiwan during the first week of August.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGLISH-CHINESE INTERNET INFO TO BE INTRODUCED TO AUSSIE BOURSE

TEXT.P: A Melbourne company will soon introduce a new real-time internet share trading system which can enable Asian traders to trade on the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) in both English and Chinese.

The Australian Financial Review on Thursday reported a pilot system developed by Timemac -- a Melbourne internet service company plans to launch its Dragonstock share-trading service for the ASX on November 1, an executive of the Timemac said.
"This will open up the ASX to the Chinese-speaking world and especially China, which has 18 million people with a personal net worth of more than US$10 million," he told the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 19, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
14 A.D.: Augustus, originally Octavian, the first Roman emperor and the grand-nephew of Julius Caesar, dies at the age of 77. He defeated Mark Anthony and Cleopatra in 31 A.D. and subsequently gained control over the empire.
1560: James Crichton, the Scottish scholar who propounded many scientific theories, is born.
1587: Pope Sixtus V proclaims Catholic Crusade for invasion of England.
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under US tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1905: A revolution forces Czar Nicholas II to establish a Russian parliament.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980, and from 1982 until he was elected president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years' detention.
1966: Earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1977: Julius Marx, the American comedian better known as "Groucho," dies of pneumonia in Hollywood at the age of 87.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a US withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- glasnost and perestroika -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the old Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The ROC Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the UN Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stressed that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but when you once try to figure out a thing you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA OVERRATED: BRITISH SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Communist China, home to a fifth of humankind, is overrated as a market and a world power that in reality is, at best, a second-rank middle power, said a United Kingdom expert in Asian affairs.

Gerald Segal, director of studies at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, wrote in the latest issue of "Foreign Affairs," that Beijing clearly is a serious menace to Taiwan, but even Taiwanese defense planners do not believe Communist China can successfully launch an invasion.

The mainland Chinese missile threat to Taiwan is much exaggerated, especially considering the very limited success of the far more massive and modern NATO missile strikes on Serbia. "If the Taiwanese have as much will to resist as did the Serbs, China will not be able to easily cow Taiwan," said Segal.

The expert pointed out that before strategic paranoia sets in, the West should note that the Chinese challenge is nothing like the Soviet one. "China is less like the Soviet Union in the 1950s than like Iraq in the 1990s: a regional threat to Western interests, not a global ideological rival. Such regional threats can be constrained."

Since the Middle Kingdom is merely a middle power, Segal wrote in the article titled "Does China Matter?" that it is not that Communist China does not matter at all, but that it matters far less than most of the West think. "China matters about as much as Brazil for the global economy. It is a medium-rank military power, and it exerts no political pull at all."

"China matters most for the West because it can make mischief, either by threatening its neighbors or assisting anti-Western forces further afield. Although these are problems, they will be more manageable if the West retains some sense of proportion about China's importance," he stressed.

A strategy of "containment" would lead to a new and very different Western approach to mainland China, Segal wrote, saying "One would expect robust deterrence of threats to Taiwan, but not pusillanimous efforts to ease Chinese concerns about Theater Missile Defense.

One would expect a tough negotiating stand on the terms of China's WTO entry, but not Western concessions merely because China made limited progress toward international transparency standards or make us feel guilty about bombing its embassy in Belgrade."

He continued that with such an approach to Communist China, one would expect Western leaders to tell Beijing leaders that their authoritarianism puts them on the wrong side of history, but one would not expect Western countries to stop trying in the United Nations to censure human rights abuses or to fall over themselves to compete for the right to lose money in the mainland China market.

Nevertheless, Segal concluded, until Communist China is cut down to size in Western imaginations and treated more like a Brazil or an India, the West stands little chance of sustaining a coherent and long-term policy toward it. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS DOWN, FUTURES RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan price shares closed 0.4 percent lower Thursday as a result of an overnight plunge on Wall Street as well as the government's financial policy.
The benchmark Taiwan Exchange Price Index fell 29.04 points to close at 7,964.67 points, with 2.33 billion shares changing hands on turnover of 101.94 billion.
Among the eight categories, electronics shares and plastic and chemical stocks posted gains, ending the day up 0.8 percent and 0.2 percent, respectively.

Construction issues declined 4.1 percent, the largest loss of the day, followed by the textile sector at 2.6 percent. Cement issues dropped 1.9 percent and financial shares reported a 1.8-percent loss. Foodstuff and paper making stocks suffered a 1.3-percent decline.
The over-the-counter market fell 1.03 pointS to the end at 167.76 points, on a turnover of 4.35 billion.
Meanwhile, the TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) Thursday posted a gain, rising 14 points to close at 8,074 points, with 2,673 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for October fell 1 point to close at 8,059 points, with 15 contract transactions; those for December were the same -- 8,080 points -- as Wednesday. Next March's TAIEX Index Futures rose 1 point to end at 8,052, with 4 contract transactions. There were no TAIEX Index Futures registered for next June.

Reference levels provided by Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures on Thursday were 8,060 points for September, 8,060 points for October, 8,080 points for December, 8,051 points for next March and 8,050 points for next June.

September electronic futures (TE) advanced 5.1 points to close at 367.1 points, with 895 contract transactions; those for October dropped 1.4 points to end at 364 points, with 5 contract transactions. TE for December ended the day up 2.75 points at 369.3 points, with one contract transaction. There were no TE future transactions recorded for next March and June.
September financial futures (TF) climbed 1 point to the finish at 1,170 points, with 133 contract transactions. There were no transactions registered for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID PRESSURING US TO SUSPEND ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin has written a letter to US President Bill Clinton demanding him to cease arms sales to Taiwan amid the controversy over the "special state-to-state relationship" theory.

According to reliable sources, Jiang sent the letter to Clinton between late July and early August. Jiang demanded in the letter that the United States cut arms sales to Taiwan and force Taipei to back off its "state-to-state" theory and start negotiations with Beijing under the so-called "one China" principle.

Informed sources told CNA that mainland China began to divulge this episode to Washington-based China affairs experts this week, indicating that Beijing authorities were disappointed by the Clinton administration's failure to give any positive response to Jiang's requests.

Douglas Paal, director of the Asia-Pacific Policy Research Center, a Washington-based think tank, said Jiang's demands reflected Beijing's concept or sentiment that the United States should be held responsible for Taipei's insistence on its statehood.
Paal, a former White House National Security Council official, said Beijing apparently still does not understand the US domestic political situation.

The noted China hand said it is hard for Clinton to accept Beijing's demands because he faces congressional pressure and has to take into consideration their possible impact on next year's US presidential election.

Paal said he is worrying that Beijing may tie the Clinton administration's response to Jiang's demands to the resumption of its bilateral negotiations with Washington on terms for its entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO). Such a link-up could make resumption of WTO talks even more difficult, he noted.

Beijing-Washington talks on WTO accession terms have been suspended since the US-led NATO mistakenly bombed the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgrade in May. The Clinton administration originally hoped that the upcoming informal leadership meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum will help score a breakthrough to Beijing's WTO accession. Both Clinton and Jiang will attend the annual APEC summit meeting.

The White House neither confirmed nor denied the report that the mainland president has written to Clinton during the past month. It only said the two presidents can talk to each other whenever they want.
Clinton and Jiang once discussed the Taiwan Strait situation by telephone on July 18 amid escalation of cross-strait tension over the "special state-to-state" theory.

ROC President Lee Teng-hui said in an interview with a German radio station on July 9 that cross-strait ties are a "special state-to-state relationship," drawing furious reaction from Beijing which regards the definition as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: A STRONG YEN HELPFUL TO APPRECIATION OF OTHER ASIAN CURRENCIES: CBC

TEXT.P: The appreciation of the Japanese yen will help other Asian currencies maintain a strong performance, a ranking official of the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Thursday.
The remarks, made by an official in the CBC's Economic Research Department, were in reference to the yen's recent rally against the US dollar and the euro.

The yen has surged to a six-month high against the US dollar and to its highest level ever against the euro. The surge is a result of a combination of a consistently strong Japanese economic performance over the past several weeks and an apparent shift in Japan's yen policy over the past few days, according to reports.

The dollar has been trading at around 110 yen recently, its weakest performance since early February. The CBC official indicated that the yen's current strong performance is likely to lead to a general appreciation in other Asian currencies.

The way that a strong yen affects the value of the currencies of other Asian countries is similar to the depreciation of the Thai baht in the latter half of 1997, which resulted in the general depreciation of other Asian currencies, noted the CBC official.
Whether the yen will rise still further against the dollar hinges on the attitude of the Central Bank of Japan, the official said.

If the yen rises too quickly, it could have an adverse impact on the recovery of Japan's economy, said the official, adding that it remains to be seen how the Japanese will adjust to the new situation.

Meanwhile, foreign exchange traders in Taipei said that the appreciation of the Japanese yen and other Asian currencies is mainly the result of a weaker US dollar and the economic resurgence of the Asian region as a whole.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MANIA, DEPRESSION SUFFERERS IN TAIWAN REACHES 220,000

TEXT.P: As people living in Taiwan face more pressure, the number of people on the island suffering from mania and depression has reached 220,000, psychiatric doctors at Taipei Medical College Hospital (TMCH) said on Thursday.

In a bid to efficiently treat those suffering from mania and depression, the hospital's psychiatry department set up the first mania and depression therepy center in Taiwan in 1998 and has successfully healed many and helped them return to society.

According to psychiatrist Chen Yi-chun from TMCH, those who suffer from mania and depression are unable to properly handle their emotions. For those who suffer from the disease but do not develop symptoms, they may go undiagnosed because the disorder does not visibly damage one's brain, Chen said.

Symptoms of mania include incessant talking, hyperactivity, staying up all night, an overactive libido and an excessive interest in shopping, Chen said, adding that those suffering from depression display opposite forms of behavior.

Chen noted that two-thirds of those who came to the therapy center are people who have several academic degrees or who come from high society. In most cases, symptoms did not appear until after they were subjected to various kinds of pressure, he said.
Symptoms showed up when they were serving the military, studying abroad, or experiencing work- or marriage-related problems, Chen said.
Chen advised those who have tendencies indicative of mania and depression to go for therapy as early as possible to prevent the further development of the disorder.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The White House reaffirms commitment to helping defend Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act if Beijing attacks the island.
The China Times:
US President Bill Clinton rejects Beijing's demand to stop arms sales to Taiwan.
The United Daily News:
Mainland President Jiang Zemin wrote to Clinton demanding suspension of arms sales to Taiwan.

The Commons Daily:
Clinton has not responded to Beijing's three demands against Taiwan.
The China Post:
Cabinet calls for establishment of defense system.
The Taiwan News:
Cabinet steps up plans to build missile defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REFUTES BEIJING ENVOY'S ACCUSATION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui is by no means a "troublemaker," but is rather the instigator of many positive movements that have resulted in closer exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, a Presidential Office spokesman said on Friday.

Lin Pi-chao, deputy secretary-general to the president, was rebutting an accusation leveled on Thursday by Beijing's ambassador to Washington Li Chaoxing that Lee has muddied US-mainland Chinese ties with his recent statehood assertions regarding cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Li described Lee as "the biggest obstacle" to Beijing-Taipei relations and the "biggest troublemaker" for US-mainland Chinese ties.

He suggested that Lee's "state-to-state" comments were a deliberate attempt to drive a wedge between mainland China and the United States. "This is a very serious and dangerous matter," he said, and cautioned the United States against interfering in what mainland China views as an internal matter.
He also said that Beijing "cannot rule out the force option. We want to prepare ourselves to stop any Taiwan independence or foreign intervention."

Lin refuted Li's accusation, describing it as untrue and ridiculous. Instead, he said, Lee has been largely instrumental in expanding private exchanges across the strait which were zero more than 10 years ago, increasing business and trade interflow, and increasing the number of meetings between quasi-official intermediary bodies of the two sides.

Lin reiterated that President Lee's "special state-to-state" remarks referring to cross-strait relations were simply a redefinition of existing facts and the current jurisdiction situation in the Taiwan Strait.

By spelling out these facts, Lin went on, Lee also meant to pave the way for further development of cross-strait relations prior to a scheduled visit to Taiwan this autumn by Beijing's point-man in negotiation with Taiwan, Wang Daohan.

Lin stressed that many recent public opinion polls conducted in Taiwan have indicated that most of Taiwan's residents support the idea that Taiwan and mainland China should be two separate political entities and that negotiations should be held on an "equal and parallel" basis, so that Lee's remarks echoed the opinion of the majority.

Lin also said that Taipei still looks forward to Wang's visit later this year, despite the rumors which say that the visit by the chairman of Beijing's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait may be canceled once and for all due to Lee's assertions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 20, or the 10th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Alaska is discovered by Danish explorer Vitus Bering on a mission sponsored by Russia.
1794: Gen. Napoleon Bonaparte is freed from the jail where he was being held on suspicion of Robespierrism.
1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.
1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.
1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in Shantung province overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid of Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time by the British during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.
1944: China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Ghandi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting Mao to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.
1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilman Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin invading Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a US team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the US government had not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC would open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A UN-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."
