DOC.HEADLINE: HK URGED TO MAINTAIN ENVIRONMENT FOR FREEDOM OF SPEECH

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday urged Hong Kong to continue to maintain the open environment for freedom of speech which the former British colony enjoyed prior to the 1997 handover to Beijing rule.
MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng made the appeal after mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen warned Hong Kong's media against helping promote any calls for Taiwan's statehood or independence.

During a meeting in Beijing with Hong Kong visitors on Thursday, Qian said open support for Taiwan's "special state-to-state relationship" theory is a violation of guidelines on Hong Kong-Taiwan relations.

Qian's remarks were seen as an indirect criticism of ROC Representative to Hong Kong Cheng An-kuo's recent explanation of the "special state-to-state" theory on a Hong Kong government-funded radio station.

Commenting on Qian's statements, Sheu said that in an open democratic society, any person can freely express his or her opinion about any topic. "We hope the Hong Kong authorities will uphold their stance on protecting freedom of speech," Sheu added.
Meanwhile, some Hong Kong political observers have expressed concern as to whether the Hong Kong government will renew Cheng's work permit after his current visa expires at the end of November.

A Hong Kong daily said Beijing's wrath at ROC President Lee Teng-hui's declaration in an interview with a German radio station in July that relations across the Taiwan Strait should be on a "special state-to-state" basis may hinder Cheng's acquisition of a renewed work permit.

Cheng assumed his current post in November 1995 and his work permit has to be renewed every year. According to the Hong Kong paper, the Hong Kong government usually links its decision on whether to extend Cheng's work permit to both his performance and the state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
The Hong Kong paper said Cheng's predecessor, John Ni, was forced to leave the former British colony after Hong Kong authorities declined to extend his visa due to his "high-profile working style."

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC MEETINGS SHOULD NOT BE POLITICIZED: MOFA

TEXT.P: Political issues should not be discussed at upcoming meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, an official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

K.Y. Tung, deputy director of MOFA's International Organizations Department, said that APEC is clearly and exclusively a regional group for promoting economic cooperation, and should therefore not touch on political issues in any of its gatherings. He further said he believes that political questions will not be raised in the forthcoming series of APEC meetings scheduled to begin on Sept. 9 in Auckland, New Zealand.

Tung was referring to recent reports from foreign sources that sponsors of this year's APEC meetings do not wish to see any references made during the meetings to the "special state-to-state relations" remarks that Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui made in July to redefine cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Lee's statehood assertions have incurred Beijing's wrath with Taiwan, and are also said to have had an adverse impact on Beijing-Washington ties.

Tung stressed that Taipei agrees that the "special state-to-state" assertions should not be discussed in the upcoming APEC gatherings, and expressed the hope that the APEC member economies will respect and understand the basic goals and principles behind the establishment of APEC.

At this year's APEC ministerial-level meeting scheduled to be held from Sept. 9-10, Taiwan will be represented by Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang and Finance Minister Paul Chiu, while Andrew Hsia, director of MOFA's International Organizations Department, will lead a Taiwan mission to an informal meeting of APEC senior officials prior to the ministers' meeting.
P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will represent Taiwan at the APEC informal leaders' summit slated for Sept. 12-13, according to Tung.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE COUNCIL DETERMINED TO CRACK DOWN ON SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is determined to crack down on smuggling involving Taiwan smugglers and mainland Chinese fishery and agricultural produce, despite strong protests leveled by fishermen from Hsinchu, COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei said on Friday.

Responding to the fishermen's protests, Peng vowed to squarely carry out the second wave of the "Ching Hai" (to calm the sea) Project exclusively in coastal areas off Hsinchu and Miaoli counties in northern Taiwan and Taichung County in central Taiwan.
Dozens of Hsinchu-based fishing boats converged on the Hsinchu Fishing Port Thursday to protest against the "Ching Hai" Project, which they said is making it harder for them to earn a living.
Peng stressed that the COA will try its utmost to protect the fishermen's well-being, but will not condone smuggling or any illicit activities on the seas.

COA sources said they suspect that some of the Hsinchu-based fishing boats have engaged in the smuggling of agricultural, fishery and livestock products from the mainland. Some of the fishing boats indeed were found to have carried packed livestock products, such as frozen pig offal, and hauls of fish too large for the type of fishing gear the boats had.

To carry out the "Ching Hai" Project, Peng said, an active task force has been organized with personnel from the National Police Administration, the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau, the Coastal Guard Command and the Directorate General of Customs.

The task force will launch their surveillance missions randomly while local government authorities in Hsinchu, Miaoli and Taichung will conduct routine inspections on inbound and outbound fishing boats and their crew members, Peng noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNG CHENG UNIVERSITY STUDENTS RETURN HOME FOLLOWING FATAL ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Faculty members and students from National Chung Cheng University returned to Taiwan from the United States on Friday after a tragic road accident killed four and injured three others in their travel group.
Those who returned included Lee Yi-tsung, an associate professor of the university in the southern Taiwan county of Chiayi and five students from the university.

Lee broke down when he recounted the accident which took place when one of two vans in which the group was traveling swerved off the road and crashed on the way to Las Vegas from Yosemite National Park on Tuesday.
Lee said that he was in the lead van, and was in close radio contact with the second one when he saw the huge flurry of sand thrown up when the fatal accident took place.

Lee stressed that excessive speed was not a factor in the accident, pointing out that the lead van was traveling no faster than 60 miles per hour. He said he could not figure out how the accident had occurred.
He implored the media not to interview the students, saying that they were still traumatized after witnessing the tragedy.

Headed by professors Lee Yi-tsung and Chen Ming-chang, a 16-member group composed of Chung Cheng University students and their relatives left for the United States on Aug. 12 to attend a three-day seminar on business administration in San Francisco followed by a few days of travel, before their scheduled return to Taiwan on Aug. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN WANTS INDONESIAN ARMY SABOTEURS REMOVED FROM EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: The United Nations has called for the removal of Indonesian army personnel involved in deadly pro-Jakarta militia violence in East Timor so that the Aug. 30 ballot can proceed smoothly.

In a dispatch from Dili, Australia's Sydney Morning Herald on Friday reported that the entire staff of a major UN provincial office was evacuated on Wednesday after armed militiamen took over the streets of a southwestern town in an embarrassing protest that coincided with a visit by Ian Martin, the head of the UN mission in East Timor.
The latest violence had already left two people dead, the daily reported, and quoted Martin as saying that the UN now expects to see strong action from Indonesia.
Martin gave a list of names of serving military personnel linked to militia violence to Indonesian authorities because they seek to sabotage a free poll in East Timor.
Meanwhile, the Indonesian government has attacked the East Timorese independence activist and Nobel laureate Jose Ramos Horta, who revealed plans to sabotage Indonesia's computer network.

A senior Foreign Ministry official said Indonesia regards the threat as "extremely serious" and has referred it to the Ministry for Political and Security Affairs for "preventive action," the daily reported.

At the same time, the daily also reported that Indonesia's parliament launched an inquiry on Thursday into a bank corruption scandal that some experts predict could threaten the country's shaky economic recovery and President B.J. Habibie's chances of retaining power.

The scandal surfaced after an audit into Bank Bali found that its directors had used government bailout money to pay a US$80 million fee to PT Era Giat Prima, a little-known finance and debt-collecting company controlled by a senior official of Habibie's Golkar Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOPS AMONG ASIA'S FOUR DRAGONS IN US EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan-made products accounted for 3.48 percent of all US imports during the first half of this year, an 8-percent decline over the same period last year.
But the figure still put Taiwan ahead of the Asia's three other "Little Dragon" economies, according to the US Department of Commerce (DOC).

Canada, Japan and Mexico remain the largest sources of US imports, with Canada accounting for nearly 20 percent of US imports. Meanwhile, 7.5 percent of US imports were from mainland China, making it the fourth-largest source of US imports, reported the commerce department.

Taiwan exports to the United States reached US$16.67 billion in the first half of 1999, an increase of 5.6 percent from 1998. Taiwan's export level put it seventh among countries exporting goods to the United States.
The United States' trade deficit with Taiwan was up 19 percent during the first half of this year from the same period last year, totaling US$7.88 billion.

More US imports were from Taiwan than from any of Asia's other Little Dragons. Products from South Korea accounted for 2.91 percent of US imports; from Singapore, 1.81 percent; and from Hong Kong, 0.96 percent.

The top 10 trading partners of the United States were Canada, Mexico, Japan, mainland China, Germany, England, Taiwan, South Korea, France and Singapore. Together the partners accounted for 69.6 percent of US imports, according to the commerce department.

Meanwhile, the US trade deficit totaled US$118.1 billion for the first half of 1999, its highest level in several decades, said the DOC. The United States' deficits with Japan and mainland China rose to US$33.6 billion and US$29.3 billion, respectively, representing respective increases of 8.8 percent and 16 percent over the same 1998 period.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S 2ND QUARTER BALANCE OF PAYMENTS SURPLUS AT 12-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, a single -quarter high in 12 years, the Central Bank of China (CBC) announced on Friday.
According to statistics from the CBC, the current account surplus reached US$1.67 billion in the second quarter, compared to US$779 million surplus recorded for the same quarter of last year.
Capital account, however, suffered a deficit of US$39 million in the quarter and monetary account net inflows totaled US$2.96 billion.

Taiwan's current account surplus for the first half of the year amounted to US$3.78 billion, while its capital account deficit totaled US$71 million. During the same period monetary account inflows totaled US$4.95 billion, while Taiwan's balance of payments totaled US$10.35 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN EXPECTED TO GET STRONG SUPPORT AS KMT'S PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: A ranking official of the ruling Kuomintang said on Friday that he is confident that Vice President Lien Chan will receive strong support as the party's presidential nominee.
John Chang, KMT secretary-general, made the remarks as deputies of the ruling party prepared to nominate its presidential candidate on Saturday.

Some 2,180 KMT party deputies representing six constituencies -- Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan, Kaohsiung, and Hualien and Taitung -- will vote on the party's candidate from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Saturday.

Chang said that he was confident about a high support rate for Lien, noting that Lien has collected the signatures of 2,119 deputies, or 97.2 percent of the total number, who support him as the party's presidential candidate.
According to the KMT's rules on the nomination of presidential and vice presidential candidates, a person must win the votes of more than half of the party's deputies to be nominated.

If Lien gets more than half of the votes, he will name his preferred running mate at next Wednesday's meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee. Lien's nomination as the party's candidate and his choice to be running mate must win final approval from an Aug. 29 party congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 40 US WARSHIPS HELP DEFEND TAIWAN DURING 1996 CRISIS

TEXT.P: The United States sent nearly 40 warships to help defend Taiwan in early 1996 when Beijing lobbed missiles into the Taiwan Strait in the run-up to the island's first-ever direct presidential election, a Kuomintang official said on Friday.
Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Research Department, made the revelation in a speech on cross-strait relations and Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.
Chang said the fire-power carried by the American warships far exceeded mainland China's three naval fleets.

Chang mentioned this episode in an attempt to convince mainland China to end its current rounds of saber-rattling against Taiwan simply because ROC President Lee Teng-hui declared in an interview with a German radio station on July 9 that relations across the Taiwan Strait should be on a "special state-to-state" basis.
Chang said Lee's statement mainly affirms reality and does not mark a shift in Taiwan's mainland policy.

Quoting the results of many public opinion polls conducted after Lee's "special state-to-state" declaration, Chang said most local people support the definition and that less than 20 percent oppose such a declaration.
Moreover, Chang said, all major political parties here unanimously insist that cross-strait relations should be on a basis of parity and equality.
If Beijing disagrees with the "special state-to-state" theory, Chang went on, it should negotiate with Taiwan for working out a mutually acceptable solution.
"Therefore, we sincerely hope that mainland China's top negotiator Wang Daohan will visit Taiwan as scheduled," Chang said, adding that Wang's visit can help forge goodwill and mutual understanding.
Chang said he does not think that the basis for cross-strait talks no longer exist in the wake of Lee's "special state-to-state" definition.
Chang said the 1992 "one China" principle, which allowed each side to have its own definition of "one China," still can serve as the basis for cross-strait dialogue.
"Even though the two sides remain divided over the definition of 'one China,' they can talk to work out a solution," Chang stressed.

He said mainland China need not think that Wang's visit to Taiwan would mark an endorsement to the "special state-to-state" theory. "While we disagree with Beijing's 'one China' principle, we still sent our top negotiator Koo Chen-fu to the mainland last year in an effort to forge rapprochement and pave the way for resumption of regular cross-strait dialogue," Chang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES BOTH UP

TEXT.P: Strong buying of electronics and construction stocks prompted the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) to rally on Friday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, reclaiming the psychological 8,000-point level.
The benchmark index surged 152.75 points to close at 8,117.42, with 2.88 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of NT$139.39 billion.

All eight major stock categories closed higher with construction stocks registering the largest gain, rising 4.2 percent. They were followed by electronics stocks, which rose 2.4 percent; textile shares, 2.2 percent; plastic and chemical shares, 2 percent; pulp and paper-making issues, 1.6 percent; cement issues, 1.3 percent; foodstuff issues, 1.1 percent; and financial issues, 1.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market rose 3.64 points to finish at 171.4 on a turnover of NT$4.84 billion.
The TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) also performed pretty well on Friday.

TAIEX Index Futures for September were up 145 points to close at 8,219 with 3,446 contract transactions; October futures were up 146 points to close at 8,205 with 37 contract transactions; and those for December were up 200 points to close at 8,280 with 9 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March soared 238 points to 8,298 with 1 contract transaction. There were no transaction records for next June's futures.

Reference levels provided by Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures on Friday were 8,074 points for September, 8,057 points for October, 8,080 points for December, 8,060 points for next March and 8,064 points for next June.

September electronic futures (TE) advanced 10.4 points to close at 377.5 points, with 865 contract transactions; those for October ended up 12 points to 378, with 2 contract transactions. TE futures for December ended the day up 8.35 points at 380, with 3 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for TE futures for next March and June.
September financial (TF) futures climbed five points to 1,175, with 130 contract transactions. There were no transactions registered for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX PEOPLE COMMIT SUICIDE EVERY DAY

TEXT.P: Suicide has become a danger to the lives of the Taiwan people as an average of six people kill themselves every day in Taiwan, according to a Min Sheng Daily report.

Citing statistics released by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), the report said women are more likely to attempt suicide than men, while the 15-24 age group posts the highest level of suicide attempts.

Analyzing Taiwan's suicide levels over the past three years, the DOH said it has not found any evidence showing that there is a "peak month" for suicide attempts, but it added that it is worth noting that the number of people committing suicide has been on the rise in the past three years.

In 1996, 10.24 people out of every 100,000 committed suicide, while the figure rose to 11.43 in 1998, DOH tallies indicated. In addition, suicide has been one of the top 10 causes of death among the people of Taiwan since 1997.

The DOH further found that suicide was the ninth-leading cause of death among Taiwan's male population in 1998, the report said, adding that 1.69 times as many men as women succeed in killing themselves when attempting suicide.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISA CARDHOLDERS REACH 12 MILLION

TEXT.P: VISA International Service Association (VISA), Taiwan's biggest credit card company, announced Friday that it had issued more than 12 million cards to people on the island as of the end of June, it said Friday.
VISA is holding a series of programs to benefit cardholders in celebration of its achievement. Among the programs is a cash lottery with a NT$1 million grand prize.
With each VISA charge before the end of this month, cardholders receive one chance to win the lottery, while people with VISA gold cards will receive two chances for each charge made this month.
The last lottery drawing will be held Sept. 15.
Taiwan VISA cardholders passed the 10-million mark in April, while MasterCard International has issued nearly 6 million cards in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE CALLS FOR PEACEFUL SOLUTION TO CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui renewed his call on Friday for peaceful solution to disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lee made the appeal during a meeting with Japanese lawmaker, Masateru Nakayama, who is currently on a visit here.
Lee said the Republic of China government cannot accept Beijing's "one China" principle which downgrades the ROC to a local-level government.

Stressing that cross-strait relations can make positive headway only under the condition that the two sides regard each other as equals, Lee said his definition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" only affirms historical facts and political reality and does not mark any shift in the ROC's policy toward mainland China.

In an interview with a German radio station on July 9, Lee said cross-strait ties should be on a "special state-to-state" basis, drawing furious reaction from communist China, which views Lee's statement as a move to promote Taiwan independence.
Lee told the Japanese lawmaker that the definition only reflects facts and is also aimed at clarifying "parity" and "equality" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lee said the clarification is necessary in preparation for serious talks with mainland China on sensitive political issues, including eventual democratic unification of the two sides.

The president went on to say that he has consistently advocated cross-strait dialogue and exchanges. "This policy has remained unchanged," Lee reiterated, adding that he hopes Taipei and Beijing can continue strengthening exchanges and dialogue and resolving their disputes strictly by peaceful means.

For his part, Nakayama said he fully supports Lee's "special state-to-state" definition as it is an indisputable fact that the ROC is an independent sovereign state. The 10-term member of the lower house of the Japanese Diet further said the Japanese government should make greater efforts to promote its relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNSTABLE RELATIONSHIPS RESULT IN REDUCED TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: There were 157 fewer investments in mainland China by Taiwan companies from January to June of this year than the same period last year, according to statistics released by the Investment Commission (IC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Friday.
In terms of investment value, Taiwan investment in the mainland during the seventh-month period was off 36 percent from the same period last year.
Some 256 Taiwan investments in the mainland with a total value of US$592.34 million were approved from January to July. This represents a drop of 157 cases or US$336.31 million from year-ago levels.

An IC official attributed the reduction to new economic policies from the mainland, including a reinforcement on foreign exchange controls, a crackdown on smuggling, overwhelming tax investigations into Taiwan-run companies and stricter restrictions on export tax rebates.
The official added, however, that expectations by Taiwanese businessmen of a devaluation of the renminbi and unstable cross-strait relations were also factors.
Meanwhile, inbound investment by overseas Chinese and foreigners increased by US$100.38 million or 5.26 percent from the same period of last year.
The growth indicates that overseas Chinese and foreign investors are optimistic about Taiwan's business outlook and are looking forward to continued economic recovery in the second half of this year.

In regard to the domestic business firms' foreign investments, 44 investment projects worth US$464 million were approved in July. While foreign investments from domestic businesses from January to July were up US$103.83 million in terms of volume compared with the same period last year, there were 87 fewer investments this year.

The IC official said the reason there are fewer investment cases but a larger investment value is because many Taiwan companies are simply increasing the level of previous investments, and these increases are not counted as new investment cases.
Approved foreign and overseas investments by domestic firms in the seven months amounted to 430 cases, with a total volume of US$2.09 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TRADE INCREASES BY 8.4 PERCENT IN JULY

TEXT.P: Singapore's total trade increased by 8.4 percent in July, the third consecutive month of expansion.

The growth reflected the continued strength of the global electronics demand and further improvement in economic conditions of the crisis-hit Asian economies, according to Trade Development Board of Singapore.
In particular, non-oil domestic exports (NODX) expanded by 11.5 percent, marginally better than the 10.3-percent growth registered in June 1999.

The positive trend for NODX, which started in April 1999, continued into its fourth consecutive month in July 1999. Non-oil re-exports (NORX) fell by 3.5 percent, the third consecutive monthly decline. The decline was milder, however, than the double-digit contractions in the preceding months.
Non-oil imports excluding aircraft and ships, expanded by 13.4 percent, following a healthy growth of 11 percent in June 1999.

Despite the overall improvement in trade performance, there were isolated export segments and markets that remained depressed. Domestic exports of printers remained in the negative territory, contracting by 4 percent in July 1999 after a 9.1-percent contraction in June 1999.

While domestic exports of disk drives increased for the first time in four months, it is uncertain whether the growth would be sustainable as price competition among the major disk drive manufacturers continues.
NODX to Hong Kong continued its downward trend, contracting by 15.6 percent in July 1999.
The improvement in NODX mirrored the continued recovery of electronic exports and the healthy growth in non-electronic exports.

Domestic exports of electronic products increased for the third consecutive month, by 8.6 percent in July 1999, after a 5.4-percent expansion in June 1999. With the exception of printers, domestic exports of the other four top electronic exports registered positive growth rates.

Domestic exports of non-electronic products expanded for the fifth consecutive month, growing by 17.7 percent. The increase continued to come from strong growth in domestic exports of pharmaceuticals and intermediate compounds to the European Union and disc media products to Japan.

Domestic exports of oil grew by 6.2 percent in July 1999, moderating marginally from the 6.9 percent recorded for June 1999. An increase in oil prices continued to contribute to the growth of oil exports in July 1999.
Non-oil re-exports (NORX) fell by 3.5 percent in July 1999, the third consecutive month of more moderate declines as compared to the double-digit declines in the preceding months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PM URGED TO AVOID GIVING BEIJING CONCESSIONS OVER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard should avoid making political concessions over Taiwan during his September meeting in Canberra with mainland China's President Jiang Zemin, according to the Australian newspaper.
Greg Sheridan, the paper's foreign editor, wrote on Friday that Canberra "wants and needs good relations with China. But this should not be at any price."

"Howard should avoid (US President Bill) Clinton's mistakes. He should warmly affirm China's right to join the World Trade Organization but should not make any new political concessions over Taiwan. He should reaffirm Australia's one-China policy but not get into Clinton's ridiculous `three noes' formula (no Taiwan independence, no `two Chinas' or `one China, one Taiwan,' and no Taiwan membership of international organizations based on statehood), which the Japanese sensibly refused to do," Sheridan said.
He also urged Howard to raise directly with Jiang the continued imprisonment of Australian businessman James Peng.

"The Howard government claims (with great fatuousness) that relations with China are at an all-time high. This can't mean very much if Peng is still in jail. Australian indifference to China's treatment of its own citizens' human rights is one thing, but the rights of an Australian citizen in China are another thing altogether," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US POLITICIANS DRAWN INTO TAIPEI-BEIJING WAR OF WORDS

TEXT.P: Canada's national broadcaster reported on Thursday that the ongoing war of words between Taiwan and mainland China has escalated into an exchange of threats involving politicians of the United States.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) quoted Beijing's ambassador to Washington, Li Zhaoxing, as telling American politicians that Taiwan's ultimate future is none of their business.
"We cannot rule out the force option ... Taiwan is not Florida or Hawaii. The issue of Taiwan is entirely China's internal matter brooking no foreign intervention," the CBC quoted Li as saying.

Li was responding to remarks in Iowa last weekend when Republican candidates for the US presidency Elizabeth Dole and George Bush Jr. said they would send in American troops if mainland China used force against Taiwan, the CBC said.

Tensions between Taiwan and the mainland increased last month, when Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-Taiwan Strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship," the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS REVISES UPWARD ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE TO 5.74 % THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) of the Executive Yuan on Friday revised upward the nation's economic growth rate this year to 5.74 percent.
The DGBAS also lowered the consumer price index (CPI) growth to 0.5 percent.

Wei Duan, director general of the DGBAS, said that the adjusted economic growth will put the Republic of China fifth among world economies, following Ireland, Vietnam, mainland China and the Ivory Coast.
The economic growth rate for next year is projected at 5.96 percent, a little lower than 6.05 percent previously projected. Meanwhile, next year's CPI growth has been put at 2.04 percent.

The DGBAS estimated the year's gross national product (GNP) at NT$9.16 trillion (US$283.1 billion), with per capita GNP at US$12,874. Household disposable spending averaged NT$72,765, while the ratio of the highest and lowest income levels is 5.5 to 1, a little lower than last year's 5.4 to 1 ratio.
Wei Duan said that due to the economic recovery in the second quarter, growth in the second half of this year will total 6.1 percent.
Economic growth for this year's four quarters has been set at 4.26 percent, 6.54 percent, 5.95 percent and 6.16 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON JIANG'S LETTER TO CLINTON: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday refused to comment on reports that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in a latter to US President Bill Clinton demanded that arms sales to Taipei be stopped.

Sheu Ke-sheng, the spokesman for MAC -- Taipei's chief policy-making body for the issues involving mainland China -- refused to comment on the matter except to remark that MAC officials are now in the process of trying to understand the matter.

According to reports, after the hot-line conversation between Jiang and Clinton over the Taiwan Strait situation following ROC President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" cross-strait relationship statement on July 9, Jiang then sent a letter to Clinton in late July or early August.

Jiang's letter, according to reports, demanded that the US cut arms sales to Taiwan, force Taipei to scrap its "special state-to-state relationship" theory and continue to hold talks with Beijing under the premise of the "one China" principle.
Informed sources in the United States claim that although Jiang made three demands in regard to Lee's remarks, there has been no response from Clinton as of date.

Clinton is unlikely to give Jiang an answer before their private meeting at September's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leadership forum in New Zealand, said local observers. Clinton is not expected to provide Jiang with a satisfactory response, they added.

Henry M.C. Chen, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said at a news conference Friday that Taipei is not surprised that Beijing is taking a high-handed policy toward Taiwan. Nor is Taipei surprised at Washington's stance regarding Taiwan's security, Chen noted.
Chen pointed out that both the executive branch of the US government as well as the Congress have recently urged a reaffirmation of Washington's commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act.

Regarding the comment's the this week from Li Zhaoxing, the mainland Chinese Ambassador to the US, who labeled President Lee a "trouble maker" as well as the chief obstacle to improving cross-strait relations, Chen stressed that "having both sides sit, talk and resolve the issues peacefully" has always been Taipei's basic stance.

The Taipei side has repeatedly said that it welcomes a visit to Taiwan by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, the MOFA spokesman said. However, Beijing has continued to make trouble, thus straining regional and Taiwan security, Chen added.
Chen's remarks were echoed by the MAC spokesman Sheu as he noted that Lee's statement did not carry the intention of causing trouble, rather, it aimed at making peace.

Sheu told the press that Taipei's position on the "special state-to-state relationship" with regard to relations between Taiwan and mainland China was made very clear in an official explanation released by MAC on Aug.1.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIFFERENT SURVEYS HAVE DIFFERENT CANDIDATES LEADING THE 2000 RACE

TEXT.P: Two newly-released polls, place Vice President Lien Chan and former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong in the lead respectively in the race for the 2000 presidency.

In a survey conducted by Taipei's Shih Hsin University, Soong kept his lead over two other candidates with 29.3 percent of the support of those interviewed, Lien followed closely behind with 24.2 percent. Chen Shui-bian, the candidate nominated by the Democratic Progressive Party won the support of 22.8 percent.
The survey didn't disclose the share of support for independent presidential candidate Hsu Hsing-liang, and was conducted before the New Party candidate Lee Ao entered the race earlier in the week.

Although Lien trailed Soong in terms of support, he was considered by most -- 42.7 percent -- as the likely winner of next spring's election. Soong followed Lien with 26.7 percent, while 6.2 percent thought Chen would be the next occupant of the Presidential Office.
The author of the survey said that although Soong is still the front runner, his lead over Lien is narrowing, an ill omen for Soong.
The survey was conducted between Aug. 12-16, among 1,818 residents of Taipei City, Taipei County and Keelung County. The margin of error was five percentage points.
Meanwhile a survey among 622 owners of small- and medium-sized business found Lien as the preferred presidential candidate.

When asked who would they vote for if the election were to be held tomorrow, 43 percent answered Lien, 22 percent said Soong, while Chen Shui-bian got 17 percent and Hsu Hsin-liang, two percent. The remaining respondents either refused to answer or said they didn't know.

Lee Cheng-chia, the honorary chairman of the ROC Association of Samll- and Medium-sized Business that conducted the poll and boasts of having 4,417 members, pitched for Lien's candidacy at the press conference called to release the survey.
Lee praised Lien's performance throughout his political career and touted the vice president as the most forward-looking candidate as well as the one with the best international vision.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DENIES REPORTS ON SIEW'S MEETING WITH CLINTON IN PANAMA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday denied news reports that he will meet with US President Bill Clinton at the inauguration of Panama President Mireya Moscoso.
Premier Siew is slated to leave Taipei Aug. 30 for Los Angeles en route to Panama for Mireya Moscoso's inauguration on Sept. 1 in his capacity as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-huei.

Several local mass media reported that Siew will seek to explain Taipei's "special state-to-state relationship" theory to US officials during his stopover on US soil and later during his meeting with Clinton in Panama.

Meanwhile, Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), said the reports were a complete fabrication by the local mass media, adding "I have never heard of such a matter."
Chen said that Clinton has yet to confirm whether he would attend Moscoso's inaugural celebration, therefore how could the premier meet Clinton in Panama?
Foreign Ministry Spokesman Henry Chen made the same denial, saying the false reports have created troubles for the ministry.
He added that Siew will make a simple transit in the United States and would not undertake any official activities.

Meanwhile, it was announced Friday that Ohio State University in the United States will confer an honorary doctorate degree of public service on Siew for his outstanding leadership and contributions to Taiwan.

The conferring ceremony will be held at the International Convention Hall of National Taiwan University on Aug. 23. Dr. Bobby Moser, deputy director of Ohio State University, will confer the degree on Siew on behalf of the university.

Koo Chen-fu, senior adviser to President Lee; Education Minister Yang Chao-hsiang, Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee, Rector of National Chengkung University Chen Wei-chao, Director of National Policy Study Institute Tien Hong-mao, as well as the family and friends of the premier will witness the ceremony.
Ohio State University is one of the most renowned universities in the United States. Among its enrollment of 55,000 students this fall, are 500 students from Taiwan. By Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S ONE NATION PARTY IN CRISIS

TEXT.P: Australia's One Nation party has been officially deregistered as a political party in Queensland following Supreme Court ruling, and the party is now fighting for its survival.

David Ettridge, national director of One Nation, on Thursday rushed to Brisbane to assure One Nation's five state MPs of the survival of the party, which is often described as racist because of its anti-Asian immigration and anti-Aboriginal policies.

One Nation is also facing pressure to reveal what it has done with A$500,000 (US$333,333) in electoral funding, with Queensland Premier Peter Beattie claiming former leader Pauline Hanson and her two senior advisers -- Ettridge and David Oldfield -- used the money like a "lotto prize."

Ettridge told reporters that One Nation will appeal against the Supreme Court ruling and will soon move to re-register the party. But the party was dealt a second legal blow on Thursday after its bid to extend a stay on the court ruling was rejected, meaning it lost the chance to be re-registered.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DETAINS AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities have detained an Australian researcher in a sensitive area near Tibet, while allowing an officially invited Australian human rights delegation to visit the area, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Friday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily reported that Gabriel Lafitte, 50, was detained on Aug. 15 while he was studying a controversial World Bank project to resettle 58,000 ethnic Chinese in Dulan, an area of western Qinghai Province traditionally regarded as part of Tibet.
An American Tibet language expert working with Lafitte -- Daja Meston -- was also detained at the same time, the daily reported.
The Australian embassy in Beijing has raised the matter with mainland China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and is seeking further details of his detention, the daily reported.

Beijing had already invited an Australian human rights delegation to visit Qinghai to study the project that has drawn fire from local Tibetans, foreign governments, pro-Tibet groups and environmentalists.

The delegation had conducted three rounds of human rights dialogue with mainland China in Beijing before heading to Qinghai. Australia believes the annual talks can help improve the human rights situation in the mainland, but critics, including Amnesty International and other human rights organizations, have described the dialogue as useless and inefficient.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING-MOSCOW MIL. ALLIANCE FORMING: RUSSIAN DEFECTOR

TEXT.P: Mainland China and Russia are moving closer to forming a political and military alliance to challenge the United States and the West, a Russian defector to the United States said on Thursday.

The West should be alarmed by such an alliance, which will likely be realized in the next few months and have dramatic consequences for world civilization that cannot be overestimated, claimed Col. Stanislav Lunev, the highest ranking Russian military officer ever to defect to the United States.

He wrote in an analysis on the internet that one of the military ramifications of intelligence cooperation between Russia and Red China may have been mainland China's provocation against Taiwan in 1996 when it fired missiles across the Taiwan Straits precisely at a time when the U.S. Navy had no ships nearby. Reports are that Communist Chinese intelligence did not have its own information on global U.S. ship deployments but had received this information from Moscow.

Similarly, Lunev said, Communist Chinese development of the warhead known as the W-88, reportedly stolen from the United States by Chinese operatives, may actually have been given to Beijing by the Russians, who had acquired this technology some years ago.

He wrote in an analysis on the Internet Thursday that fearing an aggressive NATO in the wake of the Yugoslavia campaign right on Russia's doorstep, the Russian Federation seeks new military allies as a counterbalance to NATO and the Russian elites are now turning to Red China as the foremost among their new partners.

Communist China also fears NATO, Lunev noted, saying that Beijing leaders believe that NATO, especially after bombing the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, is not genuinely a defensive organization. Also, President Bill Clinton's justification for the Kosovo war, the human rights issue, has been worrisome for Communist China, so they will try to stop the Western countries from attacking mainland China for human rights abuses in Tibet and other areas with large ethnic minorities.

The former GRU agent, who defected in 1992, said the so-called "democratic" Russia and totalitarian Red China are proving to be natural allies. Both have buried the hatchet on the ideological differences that imbued hatred between the two for almost three decades. And mainland China continues to present the world the prospect of "real socialism -- Chinese style" under the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party. And this, no doubt, has impressed Kremlin leaders, who never really wanted democracy except for the riches that come from it.

Internationally, Lunev noted, both countries are standing together, and this became apparent during the Kosovo crisis when mainland China and the Russian Federation officially condemned NATO and supported Yugoslavia's ruling regime. The military ties between Beijing and Moscow began to develop in 1992. These were, and still are, characterized by active military sharing on the highest levels, with ongoing cooperation in the development and production of the most modern weapons systems.

Lunev is convinced that President Boris Yeltsin, who has favored an alliance with Communist China to counter Washington, clearly looks with favor on these developments. And the military relationship is moving at great speed. Both nations have already introduced compatible weapons systems. By integrating the weapons systems of the Russian armed forces and the Communist Chinese People's Liberation Army, the two countries are rapidly becoming a superpower, he said.

Moreover, Lunev continued, cooperation between Russia and mainland China is expanding in the area of intelligence, which is laying the foundation for a climate of mutual trust in the Russian-PRC relations, including guarantees of each other's security. Thus, all the necessary preconditions for the strategic alliance between the two sides are in place, and this alliance could threaten the United States and the West much sooner than anyone thinks. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON SAM UNLIKELY TO HIT TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said on Friday that it is unlikely that Typhoon Sam will directly hit Taiwan during the next two days as was originally forecast.
Sam was situated some 400 kilometers south of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun as of 2:00 p.m. Friday, according to the CWB report.

The wind speed near the center of the typhoon had increased to 23 meters per second from 20 meters per second, an equivalent of wind of the ninth grade. Sam occasionally had gusts of wind of up to 30 meters per second, an equivalent of wind of the 11th grade.

The CWB originally forecast that Typhoon Sam would directly threaten Taiwan after it struck the Philippines and turned in a northerly direction. However, the typhoon has not followed the direction that was forecasted by the CWB earlier in the week.

CWB weathermen urged ships sailing and fishing in the Bashi Channel, the Taiwan Strait, waters off Pratas Island, and waters off the southeastern coast of Taiwan to be aware of Sam suddenly changing direction.

Over the weekend the CWB officials forecast that there will be heavy rains in southern and southeastern Taiwan. While northern Taiwan, influenced by the atmospheric current surrounding Sam, will be hit with strong wind that includes occasional gusts of the 9th-10th grade.
The CWB urged the public to use caution over the next two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIRTH PARENTS OF TAIWAN-BORN US GIRL FOUND

TEXT.P: Birth parents of Desiree Leary, a 20-year-old Taiwan-born girl from the United States, have been found on Friday after DNA tests proved their relationship earlier the same day.
Mother Liu, who was proved to be Desiree's biological mother by the DNA results, said she was so happy because her dream of finding her little daughter has finally come true.
Mother Liu, who personally went to the hospital to receive the DNA match results, said she had already contact Desiree and Legislator Chin Hui-chu after learning of the development.

Chin was the major figure involved in assisting Desiree to search for her biological parents on this island. Mother Liu and her husband came to meet Desiree after the girl, helped by Chin, showed up on television last week appealing for the public to help her find her parents.

Desiree was said to be born on July 8, 1979 in Taipei, and was adopted by an American woman, Grace Leary, from the US one week later with the help of a Taiwanese woman named Hsueh Mei. According to Mother Liu, she gave birth to her sixth child 20 years ago at a Taipei hospital, but was forced to drop the baby alone there because her disabled husband could not afford to raise her.
Desiree, who concluded her two-month long search in Taiwan, left here for the US on Wednesday as her college semester is due to begin.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHING BOAT CAPTAIN, OFFICERS CHARGED WITH KILLING 3 CREWMEN

TEXT.P: A capitan of a Kaohsiung-based fishing boat and two other officiers were prosecuted Friday on charges of beating to death three mainland crewmen earlier this year aboard their boat.
The vessel, Hsiang Man Chun No. 17, of the Yu Hsiang Sea Product Enterprises Ltd. in Kaohsiung, headed to waters off the coast of Argentina last Nov. 15 to fish for squid.

While off the coast of Argentina, Captain Chen Kun-lin, chief officer Hsu Hsun-ai and second officer Cheng Chen-liang, unsatisfied with the attitude and performance of mainland Chinese crewmembers Chen Tsai-fu, 21, Chang Lin-yuan, 23, and Lee Cheng, 21, hit them with steel bars, pipes and hammers on at least three occasions in April, May and June.
Captain Chen told police during the interrogation that the crewmen were bound and starved to death. They died at different times, Chen added.
Captain Chen told police that two of the victims' bodies were put in the ship's refrigerated hold while that of the third victim was thrown into the sea.
Chen then made a false navigation report that the three had died accidentally from negligent work on board the ship. Chen forced all his crewmembers to falsely sign his version of how the men died.

Police in Koahsiung have been suspicious of the happenings on the vessel before the boat's return to its base. They created a panel to probe into the accusation by crew member Lee Chen-chung that he was beaten by the captain on March 20, 1999 in waters off of Argentina.
The Hsiang Man Chun No. 17 returned to Kaohsiung port Wednesday and police immediately interrogated the crew members, leading to the unveiling of the killings. By Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: US WILL NOT RULE OUT INCLUSION OF TAIWAN IN TMD SHIELD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: State Department Spokesman James Rubin Washington on Thursday deliberately kept the door open for Taiwan to join the US anti-missile program.

Rubin during a press briefing said: "We would view with grave concern any use of force against Taiwan, and we don't preclude the possible sale of theater missile defenses (TMD) to Taiwan in the future."
The United States would help Taiwan defend itself according to the provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act, and the 1982 communique between Washington and Beijing, said Rubin.

Rubin made the remarks amid increasing tension between Taipei and Beijing over Taiwan's bid for state status when dealing with mainland China and reports that Beijing is lobbying Washington to stop all arms sales to the island.

Dismissing Beijing's alleged demand that Washington cut off all arms supplies to Taiwan as a long-standing position of the mainland, Rubin said the United States would honor the Taiwan Relations Act and supply Taiwan with weapons necessary for its defense.
Although Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui has declared the island's willingness to take part in the TMD program, Rubin cautioned that weaponry alone would not guarantee the island's security.
Instead, the spokesman touted the importance of dialogue as the method to resolve peacefully any disputes between Taipei and Beijing.
Citing the US experience as proof, Rubin said tensions in the Asian Pacific region have lulled whenever an amicable climate prevailed between Washington and Beijing.

Rubin noted that Taipei has acquired a US-made modified air defense system -- a modified version of the Patriot anti-missile system. This purchase, Rubin said, shows Taiwan is assessing its capability to shelter itself from missile attacks.
He shrugged off questions about whether Beijing President Jiang Zemin in a personal letter had asked President Bill Clinton to stop arms sales to Taiwan.

The spokesman said that the leaders of the two countries have exchanged letters several times recently, and that Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has spoken with Beijing Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan many times.

Throughout recent Washington-Beijing dialogue, the Taiwan issue has hardly been raised without Beijing vocally opposing US arms sales to Taiwan and without Washington reiterating its obligation to provide Taiwan with arms under the Taiwan Relations Act, said Rubin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IMPORTS FAR MORE US AGRO PRODUCTS THAN MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan imported US$970 million worth of agricultural products from the United States in the first half of 1999, about 3.5 times as much as the US$280 million-worth purchased by mainland China.

According to the latest report from the US Department of Agriculture (DOA), US farmers suffered the heaviest decline in exports in a decade in the first six months of this year as a result of a greater-than-expected output at home and the Asian economic crisis, which diminished demand for and imports of American agricultural products.
Except for sales to Taiwan, exports of US agricultural products to all its top nine export outlets declined in the six-month period, DOA officials said.
Exports to Taiwan, worth US$970 million in the period, posted an increase of 13 percent over the year-earlier level, they noted.
This is the third year the United States has suffered a decline in agricultural exports, and the declines are the largest seen in a decade.

DOA tallies showed that the exports of US agricultural products amounted to US$23.09 billion in the January-June period, down US$3.3 billion, or 12.4 percent, from those posted in the same period of the previous year.

In the first half of this year, Taiwan was the fifth-largest export market for US agricultural products, behind Japan, Canada, Mexico and South Korea, and it was the only market that posted growth in purchases among all major importers of US agricultural products.
By comparison, similar exports during the same period to mainland China fell 60.9 percent to US$280 million, the largest decline seen among all major import countries.

Similar exports to Japan, meanwhile, dropped 6.3 percent, while exports to the European Union plummeted 21.2 percent; to South Korea, down 24.2 percent; and to the Middle East, down 22.8 percent, according to the DOA report.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAP BETWEEN RICH AND POOR IN TAIWAN WIDENED IN 1998

TEXT.P: The gap between high income and low income families in Taiwan widened to a ratio of 5.51-to-1 in 1998 from 5.41-to-1 in 1997, according to statistics from the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Saturday.
In terms of a household's individual disposable income, the ratio between the low and high ends of the scale was 2.46-to-1, up from 2.44-to-1 in 1997.

DGBAS Director General Wei Duan said that the widening of the gap between the rich and the poor is the result of increased unemployment among families' chief bread earners, the booming development of Taiwan's high-tech industry and the increased level of wage hikes.

But Wei said that because the government has pushed actively for all kinds of social welfare programs, the gap is narrower than it would have been otherwise. Without the programs, Wei said, the ratio could have been substantially higher.
Taiwan's 5.51-1 ratio was higher than the 4.7-1 ratio between high- and low-income earning families in Japan last year and the 5.3-1 ratio in South Korea.
But the figure was lower than the 8.6-1 ratio in mainland China, the 9.5-1 ratio in the United States, the 8.5-1 ratio in Singapore or the 9-1 ratio in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON SAM MOVING AWAY FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Sam is moving northwestward after passing through waters off southern Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau reported on Saturday, adding that the typhoon is not expected to hit Taiwan.
The bureau canceled a warning to ships in waters off southeastern Taiwan and is expected to lift a comprehensive sea warning by Saturday night or Sunday.
Although the typhoon is turning away from the island, UNI Airlines suspended its Kaohsiung-Taitung and Kaohsiung-Chimei flights on Saturday as a precaution.
All railway transportation is operating normally.

A weather forecaster from the bureau said Typhoon Sam is currently located 370 kilometers west-southwest of Hengchun and is moving in a northwesterly direction toward Hong Kong and Santou, mainland China, at 17 kilometer per hour.
It is unlikely that the typhoon will hit Taiwan, the forecaster said.
But Sam's outer rim is bringing heavy rains to eastern Taiwan, including Hualien and Taitung, the forecaster said, adding that the downpour would not weaken until Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 21, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal-gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1765: William IV, the English monarch known as "the sailor king," for his service in the British Navy, is born. He joined the Royal Navy at 13 and was a close friend of British admiral Nelson. The king was renowned for his affairs and had 10 illegitimate children by actress Dorothea Jordan.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States, meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1976: Mary Langdon, 25, joins the East Sussex fire brigade to become Britain's first female firefighter.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: ROC Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: Massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1988: Earthquake rocks India's border with Nepal, killing at least 300 people and injuring over 1,500 others.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes at Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir, and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of an attempt by hardliners to depose him.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."
