The local currency opened at 32.915 and was traded between 32.886 and 31.915. Interbank US dollar reached US$218 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WATCHES CLOSELY TMD-RELATED DEVELOPMENTS: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Continuing to provide Taiwan with defensive arms is the consistent policy of the United States, and Taiwan will keep a close watch on developments relating to its proposed inclusion in a US missile defense shield, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said on Saturday.

US State Department spokesman James Rubin on Friday hinted that the United States may keep the door open for Taiwan to join a US anti-missile program, saying that "we would view with grave concern any use of force against Taiwan, and we don't preclude the possible sale of theater missile defenses (TMD) to Taiwan in the future."
The United States would help Taiwan defend itself according to the provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act and the three communiques signed between Washington and Beijing, said Rubin.

Dismissing Beijing's alleged demand that Washington cut off all arms supplies to Taiwan, Rubin said at a press conference on Friday that the United States would honor the TRA and supply Taiwan with weapons necessary for its defense.
Rubin said that although Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui has declared the island's willingness to join the TMD program, weaponry alone would not guarantee the island's security.
Instead, the State Department spokesman touted the importance of dialogue in resolving peacefully any disputes between Taipei and Beijing.

Chen said Taiwan welcomes Rubin's statement amid increased tension in the Taiwan Strait in light of President Lee Teng-hui's statehood assertion and reports that Beijing is elbowing Washington to stop all arms sales to Taiwan.

Rubin's remarks are also encouraging in that they come just one day after President Lee voiced his backing for Taiwan's inclusion in the US-initiated TMD system and the Ministry of National Defense's (MND) announcement that Taiwan will establish a comprehensive missile defense system step-by-step in accordance with its financial strength, Chen noted.

Chen said the MND is studying the feasibility of joining the TMD program. The MND now places top priority on building up an early-warning system to cope with mounting mainland Chinese missile threats and Taiwan's future air-defense needs. An early-warning system will allow the military to quickly detect aerial activities by enemy warplanes and thus secure more time for preparing counterattacks, he added.

Although mainland Chinese Ambassador Li Zhaoxing on Thursday launched a vitriolic attack on President Lee's "special state-to-state" assertion on cross-strait relations, Chen said international opinion leaders have now shifted their attention from Lee's remarks to Beijing-Taipei tensions and possible changes in the situation in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME FOR TAIWAN TO HAVE 'PLAINER SPEAKING': REPORT

TEXT.P: It is no bad thing that President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China on Taiwan has decided the time for "plainer speaking" on cross-strait relations has come, said an article appearing in Friday's issue of The Guardian.

Written by Martin Woollacott, the article said that in East Asia ambiguity has often been deemed a virtue, and a careful lack of clarity has helped limit conflict between mainland China and Taiwan in the past. But it has also fed Beijing's illusions and ambitions, and, he added, it is no bad thing that President Lee has decided that the time has come for some plainer speaking.

On July 9, President Lee said in a radio interview that future relations between the island and mainland China should be conducted on a "special state-to-state basis." President Lee's remark has so enraged Beijing that it has repeatedly threatened a military assault on Taiwan.

But in Woollacott's opinion, President Lee's rephrasing of the issue in itself is not a great shift from previous Taiwanese formulations. The "gnashing of the teeth" on the part of Beijing only serves to show that Lee's remark "could mark the moment when China has to accept that Taiwan cannot be annexed by any combination of guile, intimidation and appeal to patriotism."

The problem, Woollacott said, is that "the only reliable road to unification is through convergence, a convergence in which the People's Republic would have to adapt far more to the democratic values represented by Taiwan than Taiwan would to mainland principles and interests." But one can tell that convergence is still a very long way off, in view of Beijing's dubious record on human rights and its lack of respect for democracy.

The use of the phrase "state to state" is to establish equality between the two sides, rather than to stake a claim to permanent independence, Woollacott continued. If there is equality, then unification will come about only when the Taiwanese government and people fully agree, and they will fully agree with unification only if it is unification with a fully democratic China, he said.

Woollacott also pointed to the fallacy of Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula devised for Hong Kong in expectation of acceptance by Taiwan. For one thing, even while wanting to make Hong Kong a showcase for the two systems formula, Beijing has a very imperfect idea of what autonomy is, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO HELP HIGH-TECH MANUFACTURERS TAP JAPANESE MARKET

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will hold a series of presentations next week to help Taiwan manufacturers tap potential markets in Eastern Europe and Japan, CETRA officials said on Saturday.
The officials said the first of the five presentations will be held in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park on Monday.
They said that many high-tech manufacturers in the park have expressed an interest in the presentation and are especially interested in making inroads into the Japanese market.

CETRA estimates that 106 Taiwan manufacturers have set up branches in Japan so far. Among them, more than 50 used CETRA's center in Osaka as a base before setting up footholds in Japan after becoming more familiar with the market.

CETRA officials said that according to the economic indexes released by the Japanese government, its economy has bottomed out and begun to rebound. Five major semiconductor manufacturers have begun to expand production capacity and demand for personal computer display devices is strong, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA EXPERT CALLS ON CLINTON TO MAKE CLEAR US POSITION

TEXT.P: Given the high stake of stability in East Asia, Washington should make it crystal clear that a military move against Taiwan would be resisted by the United States, said an American expert.

Ross Terrill, a research associate at Harvard's Fairbank Center and author of a book titled "China in Our Time" and biographies of Mao Zedong and Madame Mao, wrote in the latest issue of The Weekly Standard that President Bill Clinton should pick up the phone and say to President Jiang Zemin, in the words of President Ronald Reagan, that any attack by Beijing on Taiwan would damage US-mainland Chinese relations "beyond repair."
In a world without the Soviet Union, he said, "we do not lack the power to hold China in balance -- and keep the peace in the Taiwan Straits." The only problem is, "do we have the will?"

Terrill noted that the United States has locked into a Beijing-flavored "one China" policy based on a fiction. Once, in his opinion, it may have been a useful fiction, but it has become a dangerous one.

DOC.HEADLINE: US BOOSTS CANADIAN BORDER PATROLS TO WARD OFF CHINESE

TEXT.P: The United States is adding more government agents along the Canadian border to try to reduce the number of foreigners sneaking into the United States, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) reported Friday.
The CBC said 22 agents are to join the 300 now patrolling the US side of the 49th parallel, mainly to keep illegal mainland Chinese immigrants from entering the United States.

Two boatloads of mainland Chinese stowaways have landed in Canada in the past month, bringing in a total of 254 Fujianese migrants. A majority of the 123 in the first ship have been released pending refugee board hearings.
The CBC quoted American officials as saying the flow across the Canadian border is small but sophisticated. This is particularly true of smuggling operations involving mainland Chinese migrants.
Ed Duda, who patrols the Canada-US border along the St. Lawrence River sector, calls the Chinese rings "well-oiled machines."

"If you stop a load of aliens at 11 a.m., it isn't 11:30 or 11:45 a.m. and we're already getting calls from attorneys in New York City asking what the bonds are on these people that we arrested," he told CBC News. "The attorneys know before the sector staff does."
Last December, police and immigration officials on both sides of the border cracked a smuggling ring in the St. Lawrence area, arresting dozens of people.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S GAMBLING INDUSTRY EXPECTED TO GROW

TEXT.P: Gambling in Australia is showing no signs of ebbing, according to an official report.
The Australian Productivity Commission recently reported that the social cost of gambling was rising due to the increase of poker machines, casinos and other types of gambling.
It reported that at least 333,000 people have become problem gamblers.
About 82 percent of Australia's adult population of 14 million have gambled in some form, the commission reported.
Commission officials said the number of gambling devices is showing no signs of declining and is instead increasing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ROC-LED MEDICAL PROJECTS APPROVED BY APEC

TEXT.P: Two medical projects led by the Republic of China have been approved by the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, Department of Health Director-General Chan Chi-shean said over the weekend.

One of the two projects, related to the study and research of children's enterovirus and approved during APEC's 17th technology meeting in Seattle on Friday, has gained widespread support from APEC member countries, including Australia, Indonesia, Canada, mainland China, the Philippines, South Korea, the United States and Vietnam, said Chan.

Since 1997, a string of enterovirus epidemics in Malaysia, Taiwan and Hong Kong have claimed the lives of dozens children in those countries and areas, according to Chan, who added that the project will focus on the establishment of a enterovirus prevention network to reduce the number of deaths caused by the epidemic among children.

Another project approved by APEC centers on the setting up of a cross-recognition network that will determine the side effects of new medicines on different races, Chan said, claiming that the two study programs will allow Taiwan to make a greater contribution to the international community in the field of medical cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6 KMT CENTRAL STANDING COMMITTEE MEMBERS TENDER RESIGNATIONS

TEXT.P: A senior ruling Kuomintang official confirmed on Saturday that six incumbent members of the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) have tendered their resignations.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang said all the six CSC members have offered to resign mainly because of changes in their official duties.

Among them was former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan who reportedly may throw his support behind former Taiwan Governor James Soong instead of Vice President Lien Chan in the coming presidential election.
Lien will be the KMT's candidate for the 2000 presidential election while Soong, a former KMT powerhouse, has announced his determination to run for the presidency even without the party's blessing.

Other CSC members who tenered resignations included former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yi, former Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chen Tien-mao, former Taipei City Council Speaker Chen Chien-chih and former Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling.
Chang didn't identify the sixth CSC member who has offered to resign.

The KMT will reshuffle its Central Standing Committee on Aug. 29. According to KMT rules, the party's 230 Central Committee members will elect from among themselves 17 members to the standing committee while 16 other CSC members will be appointed by party chairman mainly in terms of their functions.
Chang said President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman, is expected to present a list of appointed CSC members next week.
The KMT is also scheduled to hold the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress on Aug. 29 to formally endorse the party's presidential/vice presidential ticket.
Vice President Lien, also a KMT vice chairman, won the support of 96.33 percent of 2,180 party congress delegates in Saturday's primary election to qualify him for the KMT's presidential candidacy.
Lien is expected to announce his running mate on Aug. 25 after his candidacy is endorsed by the KMT's Central Standing Committee. Lien was still tight-lipped on his choice Saturday.

Former KMT Secretary-General Wu Poh-hsiung. a charismatic Hakka politician who has made no secret his intention to seek the KMT nomination for the vice presidency, said on Saturday after casting his ballot in the party primary for the presidential candidacy that he is confident in his vice presidential bid.
Nevertheless, Wu was quick to add that Lien should be given more "time and room" to make an ultimate decision on his running mate.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LACKS THE MEANS TO GRAB TAIWAN: REPORT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China on Taiwan has exposed the myth of Chinese power in a challenge that has reduced Beijing to frustrated saber rattling and hysterical propaganda, The Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday.
In a dispatch titled: "China can only rattle the sabers" from Beijing, the newspaper quoted experts as saying that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) lacks the means it would need to invade Taiwan.
This inadequacy would be even more pronounced if the US military helped counter a landing, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES MOTORBIKES TO SWAZILAND'S AGRICULTURE MINISTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-hsiung & Shammy Chao)

TEXT.P: Ambassador of the Republic of China (ROC) to the Kingdom of Swaziland Chang Chin-kou on Friday contributed eight motorbikes and safety helmets to the country's Ministry of Agriculture on behalf of the ROC government, in hopes of providing local agricultural promoters with better equipment.

Speaking at the dedication ceremony, Chang said that the ROC and Swaziland have long been friendly allies. Thus the ROC government has made efforts to help the country's agricultural development by sending ROC agricultural missions to the African country. These missions are expected to assist in the development of the country's agriculture industry and to promote agricultural production.
He went on to say that with the motorbikes, agricultural promoters who help local people to plant maize and sweet potatoes will be able to work more efficiently.

Meanwhile, Swaziland's Minister of Agriculture, Roy Fanourakis, received the gifts on behalf of his government and expressed his gratitude to the ROC government, which has provided assistance aimed at helping his country improve its economic condition, particularly in terms of agricultural production.
Fanourakis added that the motorbikes are expected to accelerate agricultural development in some remote areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY COULD NOT BE MY EX-WIFE, SAYS WRITER-CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Acid-tongued writer Li Ao, who may be nominated by the Kuomintang-breakaway New Party (NP) as its presidential candidate, said on Saturday that the NP could not be the second "Hu Ying-meng" -- his ex-wife -- because the "NP is more merciful than Hu."

Hu, a renowned actress in Taiwan during the 70s and now a self-made sophist and writer, this year published a book on her brief marriage to Li in which she discussed the wide differences of opinion and ways of thinking between them -- the main cause of their divorce.
To retaliate against Hu's "untrue" accusations, Li has launched vitriolic attacks on Hu on his television talk show, and more than 40 such attacks had been made by Saturday.
The party's nominee will not be decided until Aug. 29, when New Party's National Election and Development Committee makes its final decision.
Despite the likelihood of his being nominated, Li insisted that he will not join the New Party. He said he declined New Party membership due to "selfish, private reasons."

If he is not nominated as its candidate simply because he is not a party member, Li said he will appeal for an explanation from the Grand Justice on whether such a prohibition violates people's constitutional rights.

Li, meanwhile, apologized to the New Party for calling the mini opposition party "a rotten melon" compared with the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which he described as a "big watermelon."

A nonconformist critic who has never hidden his contempt for politicians, comparing them to prostitutes who make a living by pandering to customers, Li said he is not like most politicians, who turn to the side that seems to have larger political resources and support. That, he said, is why he chose to affiliate himself with the New Party rather than the ruling Kuomintang or the opposition DPP.

Li said he never meant to offend the New Party by calling it a "rotten melon." "I simply used the language of X-generation people to highlight the comparison," he said, adding that New Party members should learn "new languages" and avoid being "too conservative."

Although describing the New Party's nomination of him as tantamount to "leading a wolf into the house," Li still looks forward to the Aug. 29 vote, saying that at least he will succeed in injecting "new thought into the rigid party."

When asked whether his controversial advocacy of the abolition of the National Assembly and the "one country, two system" formula concerning Taiwan's jurisdiction may backfire or undermine the New Party's chances of winning even minimal support, Li said that the New Party, which has already been labeled as a party that will sell out Taiwan, stands to lose nothing. "A dead pig scares no boiling water," he said.

Noted for his biting humor and free-wheeling criticism of politicians, regardless of their party affiliation, Li was imprisoned during Taiwan's period of martial law and later became the host of his own TV talk show, which he has used as a forum for criticism.

Speaking about the most recent public opinion poll, which puts Li's approval rating at about 1 percent -- a score equal to that of DPP breakaway Hsu Hsin-liang, Li said there are three kinds of lies -- lies, goddam lies and the polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTS CONTINUE TO GROW IN LATTER HALF OF 1999

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production is expected to grow continually in the latter half of 1999, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Saturday.

The MOEA made public domestic industrial production figures for July, which showed an increase of 7.12 percent compared with the same month last year, while January-to-July production was up 7.61 percent from the same period last year.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the Statistics Department under the MOEA, said that due to the robust export performance of telecommunications products, the sixth naphthalene cracker plant's starting production and the resurgence of the international steel market, Taiwan's manufacturing output has grown since the beginning of 1999.

The manufacturing sector in July scored 8.82-percent year-on-year growth. Within the sector, the telecommunications industry's 19.58-percent growth ranked highest, while the chemical industry and metal machinery industry registered growth of 10.36 percent and 3.23 percent, respectively.

Regarding prospects for the lower half of this year, Chang pointed out that as the third and fourth quarters are seen as the most prosperous seasons for telecommunications products, especially for semiconductor products, growth is highly likely.

In view of the fact that the price of crude oil has soared recently, together with the effects of the strategic alliance of global petroleum plants becoming evident, as well as an increase in both the demand for and the price of raw materials, a bright future is expected for the petro-chemical industry, the steel industry and the paper manufacturing industry, Chang said.
Chang said rising economic prospects for the United States and Southeast Asia bode well for Taiwan's exporters, which is in turn good for the island's makers of industrial products.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WORKS OUT STRATEGY AGAINST POSSIBLE BEIJING BOYCOTT AT APEC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has worked out strategies to cope with Beijing's possible offensive against Taiwan during the upcoming meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a senior official said on Saturday.

"We have finalized preparations and drawn up a comprehensive package of measures to address mainland China's possible hostile or detrimental moves against our country during the annual APEC gatherings," said the official with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), who preferred anonymity.

The official said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, will send a staff member of "proper level" to take part in the 1999 APEC activities scheduled to start on Sept. 9 in New Zealand.
In the past, the MAC used to send a section chief-level official in charge of economic affairs to join the ROC delegation to the annual APEC ministerial-level and informal leadership meetings.

This year, the MAC is expected to send a higher-level official to join the APEC delegation as communist China is likely to take actions against Taiwan during the APEC event to vent its wrath at President Lee Teng-hui's declaration of relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Beijing has launched saber-rattling against Taiwan since President Lee said in an interview with a German radio station on July 9 that cross-strait ties should be on a "special state-to-state" basis. Beijing claims Lee's declaration as a dangerous move to promote Taiwan independence.
The MAC already issued a position paper explaining the ROC's basic stance on its relations with mainland China and the true meaning of Lee's "special state-to-state" theory.

In view of Beijing's furious reaction to the "special state-to-state" concept, the MAC official said the ROC delegation to the coming APEC meetings will do its best to explain to the world the gist of Lee's definition if Beijing takes the initiative to bring up the issue.

The 1999 APEC ministerial-level meeting will be held from Sept. 9-10 in Auckland, New Zealand. Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Finance Minister Paul Chiu will head the ROC delegation to the meeting.

Meanwhile, top leaders from all of the 21 APEC member economies will meet in Auckland from Sept. 12-13. P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will represent President Lee at the informal leadership meeting.
During the APEC informal leadership meeting, US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin are expected to hold bilateral talks on matters of mutual concern.

The MAC official said the ROC government will keep a close watch on the developments concerning the Clinton-Jiang meeting. "It is our consistent stance that US-mainland China engagements should not undermine the ROC's national interests."

Reports from Washington, D.C. said Jiang wrote a letter to Clinton early this month demanding the United States to stop arms sales to Taiwan and force Taipei to retract its "special state-to-state" theory and to start talks with Beijing under the so-called "one China" principle.
Clinton is expected to respond to Jiang's demands when they meet during the APEC event in Auckland. Some observers said they don't think that Clinton will give Beijing a satisfactory response.
The MAC official said it is unrealistic for Beijing to ask the ROC to repudiate the "special state-to-state" theory because the definition just reflects historical facts and political reality.

In fact, the official said, the "special state-to-state" definition is only aimed at affirming parity between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in preparation for upgrading the level of cross-strait dialogue and laying a framework for peaceful bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATERIAL NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR F-16 WIRING PROBLEM: AIR FORCE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Air Force General Headquarters on Saturday blamed last Wednesday's crash of an F-16 fighter jet on defective wiring, saying the problem was due to an assembly error, not the material used to make the wires.

Officials from the headquarters made the statement in response to an accusation from Legislator Chen Pao-chin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party that the Ministry of National Defense discovered a problem with the aircraft's wiring material before purchasing 150 of the fighters from the United States in 1992 in a deal worth US$5.8 billion.

Chen, who made the accusation at a press conference on Saturday, said he suspected the ROC Air Force was trying to free itself of responsibility for the crash and for three similar crashes, which have resulted in the deaths of five pilots since March 1998.

During the press conference, Chen faulted the Air Force for investigating only the most recent F-16 crash, saying it is apparently ignoring a government demand for a thorough and detailed check on all F-16s serving in the Air Force.

Air Force officials responded to Chen's accusation by saying that after an F-16 crashed last March, there was a short circuit in another of the planes. That problem was found to be the result of an overly long Capton cable.

The Air Force brought the problem to the attention of the F-16's manufacturer, Lockheed Martin, which soon took measures to correct the defect, the officials said. They added that the US manufacturer also performed a check of all similar fighters in the United States and found that the problem was the result of improper wiring system assembly at a plant in Mexico.
No material defaults were found to have been responsible for the short circuit, which can cause a fatal explosion, the officials said.

At Saturday's press conference, Yang Ying-chieh, a professor of electrical engineering from National Taiwan University, revealed evidence pinpointing serious defects in the Capton wires. Yang has served for the US Department of Defense.

Citing reports released by a US Navy research center, Yang said the Capton wires are made from polyimide, an insulator that is not resistant to high temperature and humidity. It is not suitable for use on aircraft that fly over areas surrounded by seas, such as Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN URGED NOT TO TRY RU-486 ABORTION DRUG

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) under the Executive Yuan on Saturday urged the island's women not to use the abortion drug RU-486, noting that preliminary clinical tests put its failure rate at 44 percent.
An official with the DOH told the media that four local medical institutions have been authorized to conduct clinical trials of the French-made medicine.
In one of the tests, 14 of 32 pregnant women who took the drug did not experience full abortions, with 13 experiencing partial abortions and one woman remaining pregnant.

Difference in the physical conditions of Taiwan and foreign women and an insufficient amount of a second drug that must be taken along with RU-486 have been cited as probable reasons for the drug's high failure rate, which is normally around 7.5 percent abroad.

DOH Director-General Chan Chi-hsien said his department hopes to approve the commercial sale of RU-486 as early as possible, but urged the island's women not to try it until studies show how much of the medicine that complements RU-486 should be taken for the drug to be effective.

DOC.HEADLINE: 96 PERCENT OF KMT DELEGATES SUPPORT LIEN AS PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates on Saturday voted to support Vice President Lien Chan as the ruling party's candidate in next spring's presidential election.
The selection of Lien was a foregone conclusion as he was the sole candidate.

Of the 2,180 votes cast in Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Huangtung, 2,071 were valid. Lien collected 1,995 of those votes, or 96.33 percent of the total cast. He fared better than current President Lee Teng-hui, who in 1995 garnered 91.27 percent of the votes cast by party delegates.
After the results were announced, Lien said that he would do his utmost to achieve victory in the 2000 presidential race. He expressed a hearty thanks for the support of party delegates.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang told the media that the strong support for Lien indicated that the party remained unified, and he said he believes Lien would win next March's election.

According to KMT rules, the Central Standing Committee will approve Lien as the party's presidential candidate at next Wednesday's regular meeting. Lien will also announce his running mate at that time.
At the present stage, the favored contenders for the vice presidential spot are Premier Vincent Siew and Senior Presidential Adviser Wu Poh-hsiung.
The KMT National Congress will formally name Lien and his running mate as the party's presidential and vice presidential candidates at the second plenary session of the congress on Aug. 29.
In addition to the KMT, the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party has named former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian as its presidential candidate.
Other presidential hopefuls include former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang and writer-critic Li Ao, who is expected to represent the New Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,000-PLUS GANGSTERS ARRESTED IN NEW ISLANDWIDE ANTI-CRIME DRIVE

TEXT.P: A total of 1,090 gangsters and wanted criminal suspects have been arrested in a new islandwide anti-crime campaign, police authorities said on Saturday.
The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) launched a "Rapid Thunder" anti-organized crime operation Friday. The drive ended Saturday morning.

It was the six time that the CIB has launched an islandwide anti-crime campaign so far this year. CIB officials said similar operations will be staged in coming months as part of the government's efforts to improve public order and reduce domestic crime rate.

Among those nabbed in the latest anti-crime sweep were three key figures of the Tien Lai Hui, a division of the Bamboo Union crime syndicate. The three Tien Lai Hui masterminds -- Hsiao Ting-yi, Tsai Chung-hsin and Hsiao Hsiu-ta -- were accused of having recruited some 500 junior high school students into their criminal ring.

Also arrested were Chan Sheng-hsiung, who was accused of having extorted money from local hospitals and clinics; Chuang Chun-hsiung, an alleged "engineering gangster" who was accused of involvement in manipulating bidding for a number of construction projects; and Chou Cheng-yi, Chen Yao-tung and Chou Yu-li, who allegedly had instigated many violent clashes between ordinary residents and law enforcement officers on the excuse of environmental protection.

Chou Cheng-yi was also accused of having poached gravel in the Kao-Ping River for windfall profits. Chou allegedly had collaborated with other criminal ring members in the Kaohsiung-Pingtung region to set up illegal gravel cleaning and processing plant along the bank of the Kao-Ping River. Chou's gang was allegedly the largest gravel poaching operation ever seized in Taiwan.
Under the continued CIB-led anti-crime operations, local crime rate has declined steadily over the past year, according to official tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS RISE 0.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.4 percent higher on Saturday, boosted by the government's latest upward revision of its economic growth forecast, while technology stocks remained weak due to the government's attempt to withdraw capital from the electronics sector.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index went up 36.15 points to close at 8,153.57 on a turnover of NT$164.38 billion (US$5.15 billion).

Among the eight major stock categories, electronics shares were the only loser, closing down 1.4 percent. The paper and pulp sector posted the largest gains, rising 3.8 percent; they were followed by cement shares and construction issues, which rose 3.7 percent and 3 percent, respectively.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 393 to 97, while 35 stocks remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market climbed 1.76 points, ending the day at 173.16, with a turnover of NT$6.2 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September gained 42 points to end at 8,261, with 3,329 contract transactions, while those for October advanced 73 points, closing at 8,280, with 56 contract transactions recorded.
December futures moved up 70 points to finish at 8,350, with 14 contract transactions registered, while next March's futures went up 45 points to end at 8,343, with 8 contract transactions.
There were no contract transactions recorded for next June's futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 8,219 points for September, 8,207 points for October, 8,280 points for December, 8,298 points for next March and 8,209 points for next June.

September electronics (TE) futures declined 5.5 points to finish at 372 points, with 1,202 contract transactions; October TE futures fell 0.55 points to end at 375 points, with 13 contract transactions. No contract transactions were recorded for other months' TE futures.
September financial (TF) futures rose 39 points to close at 1,214, with 265 contract transactions, while there were no transaction records for other months' TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS INCREASE 5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers amounted to US$ 10.9 billion in July, its highest level since October 1997, and export orders are expected to increase 4 percent to 5 percent for all of this year, according to Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Chang Tseng-yiao, director-general of MOEA's Statistics Department, said that export orders of electronics and information and telecommunication products rose 22.8 percent and 16.72 percent, respectively, compared with the same 1998 period. The textile industry also reported gains resulting from money spent by Taiwan textile producers to expand their presence in foreign markets.
The value of Taiwan export orders from January to July totaled US$ 71.33 billion, up 4 percent from the same 1998 period.
Stable export growth is expected for the second half of 1999, and it is hoped that electronics and information products will be especially popular, Chang said.
The value of export orders from the United States in July increased 8.62 percent to US$3.73 billion, of which US$100 million was for textiles and US$70 million for electronics.
Meanwhile, the value of export orders with Hong Kong totaled US$1.94 billion, up 18.92 percent from the same 1998 period, while orders with Japan totaled US$1.13 billion, up 14.82 percent.
In addition, the balance of export orders with European countries decreased 0.44 percent in July 1999 from the same period last year to US$ 1.79 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 22, or the 12th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1868: Ten thousand Chinese plunder the China Inland Mission as the Taiping Rebellion gathered momentum.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement to obey the National government, to join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprising China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Tanks belonging to a five-nation Warsaw Pact force enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush with military might the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named US secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1978: Jomo Kenyatta, the first president of Kenya, dies at the age of 87.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang-kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the nomination but to run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, you will use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds by ten efforts, you will use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Lien Chan endorsed by 96.3 percent of all KMT delegates to be the party's candidate in the KMT primary.
The China Times:
An official delegation from the US will visit Taiwan to try and ease Taipei-Beijing tensions.
The United Daily News:
Lien Chan's candidacy endorsed by 96.3 percent of all KMT delegates.
The Liberty Times:
Lien Chan seeking running mate after securing KMT nomination.
The Commons Daily:
Lien Chan chosen as presidential candidate in KMT primary.
The China Post:
Lien claims expected win in KMT primary.
The Taiwan News: Taroko Gorge landslide occurs after heavy rain.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON SAM MOVES AWAY

TEXT.P: Typhoon Sam moved away from Taiwan Saturday night restoring the island's weather to a clear and hot pattern.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) lifted its comprehensive sea warning against typhoon Sam late Saturday night.
After passing through waters off southern Taiwan, Sam headed in a northwestward direction toward Hong Kong, CWB weathermen said.
Although Sam did not land on Taiwan, it brought plenty of rainfall to eastern and southern Taiwan from early Friday through late Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU-CHI ASS'N BUYS BLANKETS TO HELP TURKEY QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association on Sunday agreed to purchase 3,000 woolen blankets and mattresses to help victims of the earthquake in Turkey.
On Aug. 17 Turkey suffered an earthquake measuring 6.8 on the Richter Scale that has left 11,000 dead.

The association said that a mission previously sent to Kosovo arrived in Turkey on Aug. 19 through the aid of the ROC Embassy in Macedonian and the Taiwan Trade Center in Istanbul in Turkey and met with local relief organizations to asses what materials were required by victims.
A spokesman for Tzu Chi said that the quake victims badly need tents, woolen blankets, medical drugs and a mobile medical care station. By Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: KOALAS ATTRACT THRONG OF VISITORS TO TAIPEI ZOO

TEXT.P: The two koalas borrowed from the Gold Coast of Australia by the zoological garden of Taipei City continued to attract a throng of visitors, with more than 20,000 people pouring into the Mucha complex to see them on Sunday morning.
Although the two koalas, Harley and Patrick, have been on display for a week with more than 350,000 visitors, local people's enthusiasm is none the lesser.
The garden's parking lot was almost full at 9:00 a.m. when the garden opened Sunday morning. Soon after, traffic jams began to appear on roads heading into the zoo.

In order to maintain order, the garden put its entire staff on duty. Some staff were posted in front of the koalas' cage to prevent visitors from taking photos using flashes which could scare the two animals.

Meanwhile, the Director of the Zoological Garden, Yang Sheng-hsiung, took a group of journalists to Tamshui, Taipei County to show them a forest of eucalyptus trees to dispel allegations that the Australian owner of the two Koalas was mulling whether to take them back because of the lack of eucalyptus tress in Taiwan. Eucalyptus leaves are the only food koalas will eat.

A story in the United Daily News on Saturday said that all the eucalyptus leaves used to feed the two koalas thus far have been shipped in from Australia. As a result of the shipping and the time-consuming quarantine procedure after they arrive, the Australian leaves are often whitered and unsuitable for feed. As a result, the koalas' owner reportedly was weighing whether to take them back because Taiwan lacked eucalyptus.

Yang told journalists that 4,000 eucalyptus trees were planted on the hectare of land in 1997 in preparation for the arrival of the koalas. An additional 2,000 eucalyptus trees were planted inside the Mucha Zoological Garden complex.
Yang said each of the two koalas consumes about five kilograms of eucalyptus leaves per day. The zoo is importing from Australia 20 kilograms per week, with the rest collected locally.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES US TO SEND OFFICIAL DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Sunday denied reports that the United States will send an official delegation to visit Taiwan.

The mass-circulation China Times reported on Sunday that US President Bill Clinton has decided to send a three- or four-member group, including Kurt Campbell, deputy assistant Defense Secretary for Asian and Pacific Affairs, as well as unidentified National Security Council and State Department officials to Taipei to meet with high-ranking officials.

The report said that as tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not eased since President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship," in July, Clinton decided to send the delegation to Taipei to further discuss the cross-strait as well as the Taipei-Beijing-Washington triangular relationship.
Beijing has accused Lee of pursuing separatism. The US previously sent special envoy Richard Bush to Taipei and Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth to Beijing to try to ease the tensions.
Taipei assured Bush during his visit that its mainland policy had not changed and that Lee's redefinition is simply a reflection of the political reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE IN US TO RETURN FOR 10-DAY HOME VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to the United States left Washington for Taipei on Saturday for a 10-day home visit.
Stephen Chen is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Monday and return to Washington on Aug. 31.
Before returning to Taipei, Chen will call on National Chung Cheng University students injured in a road accident when traveling to Las Vegas from Yosemite National Park last Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO BE CAUTIOUS OF US COMPROMISING WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A local scholar urged the government to guard against the United States compromising Taiwan's interests in dealing with mainland China during a summit meeting next month.
Tamkang University Professor Pan Hsi-tang made the remarks on Sunday in a cross-strait relations seminar sponsored by the Chinese Learned Society.

US President Bill Clinton is scheduled to go to New Zealand to attend the summit meeting of the Asia and Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC) September 12-13. While there, Clinton will meet with mainland Chinese Presdient Jiang Zemin. Taiwan's redefinition of the cross-strait relationship is expected to be at the top of the two leaders' agendas.

Pan noted that Beijing's current strategy toward President Lee's redefinition is to monitor the situation while continuing the pressure on Taiwan politically and militarily, and to formulate a timetable for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The scholar also said that Beijing will step up its combat readiness against Taiwan and prepare a series of military exercises, as well as redefine its relationship with the US as "strategic competitive ties."
Pan said that the US is under pressure to promote cross-strait dialogue to avoid a repeat of the 1996 missile crisis.

In 1996, Beijing lobbed missiles into Taiwan waters to intimidate Taiwan people in the run up to its first popular presidential election. The US responded by sending two aircraft carriers into waters near Taiwan.

As the US can not force Taiwan to abandon its redefinition of cross-strait ties, Pan said the US may reluctantly accept Taiwan's stance that both sides of Taiwan Strait are entitled to its own definition of "one China."

Under the circumstances, Pan said that Taipei's continued welcoming of mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, to visit Taiwan is the best strategy to counter Beijing's verbal attack and military intimidation.

Chuang Sheng-jung, National Assembly deputy from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, also said that with increased cross-Strait tension, a delayed cross-strait dialogue will not in the interests of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chuang suggested that the United States help both sides start dialogues on a parity basis without touching on sovereignty issues so as to create a "win-win-win" situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIT TOPS LIST OF BEST US UNIVERSITIES AND COLLEGES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The California Institute of Technology (CIT) tops the list of "1999 best US universities and colleges," according to the latest issue of US News and World Report.
Harvard University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Princeton University and Yale University are ranked second, third, fourth and fifth, respectively, the news weekly revealed.
The weekly indicated that CIT, founded in 1891, has been on the top 10 US universities and colleges list during the past 10 years. Its previous highest ranking was in 1989 when it ranked third.
CIT was rated the best university in the US based on percentage of freshmen whose high school grades were in the top 10 percent (100 percent), financial resources and faculty to student ratio (1:3).
According to US News and World Report, Stanford University, Duke University, Johns Hopkins University, Pennsylvania University and Columbia University are 6th through 10th on its list.
Cornell University is ranked 11th, followed by Dartmouth College, Chicago University, Brown University and Northwest University.

The weekly also indicated that the University of California-Berkeley, is the best public university in the United States, followed by Virginia University, University of California- Los Angeles, University of Michigan, North Carolina University, College of William and Mary, University of California-San Diego, Illinois University, Wisconsin University and the Georgia Institute of Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENT PARTY CANDIDATE ADVOCATES NUCLEAR WEAPONS

TEXT.P: Cheng Pang-cheng, chairman of the Independence Party, announced his entry into the presidential race on Sunday.

Cheng called for the development of nuclear weapons as a counter measure against Beijing, and lambasted Lee Ao, the New party's presidnetial candidate, as a "foreigner" for advocating reunification with mainland China.
In a ceremony to announce his candidacy, Cheng vowed to declare an end to the Republic of China and replace it with the Republic of Taiwan.
In order to safeguard Taiwan's security, Cheng advocated the development of a nuclear weapons program to counter military threats from Beijing.
Once elected, Cheng promised to create a just and fair society, a government system of three separate branches, and to educate Taiwan people on the island's identity.

Cheng said his party will try to raise NT$50 million-NT$100 million (US$1.51 million to US$3 million) to fund his campaign and will seek the signatures of 240,000 sponsors to meet the threshold to become an official presidential candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL CHINESE BUSINESSMEN INFORMATION NETWORK SET UP

TEXT.P: An information network of ethnic-Chinese businessmen around the world has been set up by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission as part of the government's National Information Infrastructure program, according to the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission on Sunday.

The information network will organize ethnic Chinese from around the world, allowing them to advertise, book hotel rooms and conduct business more easily, said Chiao Jen-ho, minister of the commission.

Noting that Taiwan businessmen have invested about US$75 billion worldwide, and have an annul trade volume of more than US$300 billion, Chiao said the business power of Taiwanese businessmen would be strengthened if they are linked through an information network.

DOC.HEADLINE: US COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN REMAINS UNCHANGED, SAYS ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top representative to the United States, Stephen Chen, said in San Francisco on Saturday that the US commitment to Taiwan as stipulated in the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) remains unchanged.
Chen was making a stopover in San Francisco on his way back to Taipei.

Following Taipei's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" in early July, the development of cross-strait relations and Sino-American relations has become a great concern of Washington.

When asked to comment on this issue, Chen told CNA that the US commitment to Taiwan in accordance with the TRA remains unchanged, and that the Taipei-Washington communication channel remains very smooth.

He said he will report the latest developments in Taipei-Washington relations to President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew and Foreign Minister Jason Hu during his home stay in Taipei.

Chen will arrive in Taipei aboard a China Airlines flight Monday morning. He will return to the US Aug. 29 so that he can greet Premier Siew in Los Angeles Aug. 30 during the premier's US transfer on his way to Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE NAB DRUG TRAFFICKER IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Police on Sunday arrested a fugitive on charges of drug trafficking, forging identity card and other offenses.
After being tipped off, police traced Ho Lung-hsing, 35, for more than one month, and apprehended him in his hideout at the residence of his girl friend in Kaohsiung city.

Police also uncovered four pistols, and more than 170 rounds of ammunition, as well as 2.5 kg of heroin and 19 kg of amphetamine. Ho has been wanted for drug offenses and taking part in mafia activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPERT: PRC'S RENMINBI STILL FACES DEVALUATION PRESSURE

TEXT.P: Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the Kuomintang's Business Management Committee, indicated on Sunday that mainland China's renminbi still faces devaluation pressure because the inflow of foreign capital has decreasing sharply.
Owing to the economic problems, Liu disclosed that mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji was criticized by some "hawkish" opponents last month and was on the brink of losing his post.

Although Zhu and his reform plans have tided over the worst of the financial crisis, Liu noted, Beijing's internal political scene may ultimately play a role on whether and when the renminbi is devalued.

In addition to the political factor, the expert said, mainland China still has some financial problems. The sharp decrease in foreign investment is threatening the foundation that supports the renminbi from being devalued.
Once the renminbi is devalued by 15 percent, he said, the debts incurred by the mainland's state-operated enterprises will soar to hundreds of billion U.S. dollars.
But thanks to a continued trade surplus, Liu said, the mainland's currency remains stable, eliminating the need for an immediate devaluation.
Liu also predicted that if the renminbi is devalued by less than 10 percent, the economies of Southeast Asian countries will not be greatly affected.

Regarding the value of Taiwan's currency, Liu said, it will depend on the values of the greenback and the Japanese yen, adding that one US dollar to 31.5-32.5 Taiwan dollars will best reflect the island's economic fundamentals.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SET UP OVERSEAS SATELLITE TELEVISION CHANNEL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will be able to counter mainland China's propaganda blitz against the Republic of China after the inauguration of its overseas satellite television channel, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) said on Sunday.

OCAC officials said that in order to counter Beijing's stepped up efforts to woo overseas Chinese community and its campaign to isolate Taiwan internationally, the commission had planned to set up the channel targeting overseas Chinese two years ago.
They noted that the channel will enable the government to set up a direct and effective communication channel with the world, and participate in international affairs by expressing its views.
Through the satellite, the government also hopes to enhance the world's understanding of the ROC's politics, economy, culture, and its other aspects, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL AIRLINER CRASH LANDING IN HK. AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane with 315 on board deviated from the runway and caught fire after an emergency landing during a typhoon at the Hong Kong airport, rescuers said.
Rescuers said that most of the aircraft's passengers, arriving from Bangkok, were evacuated from the plane. There were no early reports of any injuries or fatalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG WINS HIGHEST SUPPORT RATE IN YUNLIN COUNTY

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong on Sunday won nearly 25 percent support in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan, in a survey of the candidates running in the 2000 presidential election.

The survey, entrusted by the Global TV and the Journalist weekly's poll center and conducted by Shan Sui Public Opinion Co., showed that 24.8 percent of all those polled expressed their support for Soong, versus 21.8 percent for Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, while incumbent Vice President Lien Chan picked up 17.4 of the support.

Writer Li Ao, who is to be nominated by the opposition New Party as its presidential candidate, won 0.5 percent support rate, the same as former chairman of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Yu Ying-lung, a professor at Soochow University, pointed out that the outcomes of several public opinion polls conducted in southern Taiwan have shown a see-saw game between the support for Soong and Chen, while Lien is consistently third.
The same survey also showed that 55.2 percent of the polled said the next Yunlin County magistrate should be of a member of an opposition party.

Fifty-two percent said that the Mafia and black money are over-involved in Yunlin County's local self-government. Forty-five percent thought environmental protection is superior to industrial development.
Former Yunlin County Magistrate Su Wen-hsiung died of liver disease on Aug. 12. A by-election is scheduled to be held Oct. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IMMIGRANTS SET UP CALF. COMPUTER ASSOC.

TEXT.P: In a speech, Daniel Hou, the newly-elected president of the Southern California Chinese Computer Association (SCCCA) said on Sunday that "Computer hardware is the backbone of next century."
SCCCA is the largest non-profit organization in Southern California, operated exclusively by overseas Chinese merchants in the US. "Our members are all from Taiwan," said Hou.
The formation of SCCCA was based on the necessity to unite the local Chinese merchants, to protect the members' interests, and mostly, to establish solid ground work for the future.

Market surveys performed indicated that there are between 8,000 to 12,000 business that are either operated or owned by Chinese. The range of products and the sizes of these establishments vary but the Republic of China on Taiwan was identified as the source of most of the commodities.

SCCCA operates with simple idea "Preparing for the future." The Association is seeking to recruit more members to strengthen its ability to unite similar organizations throughout the US. "As an organization, one of our goals is to elevate ourselves to an equal and competent level among competitors and to have equal opportunity to grow in the computer industry," Hou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER OFFICIAL URGES CLINTON TO STAND UP FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The danger of a shooting war across the Taiwan Strait through mischance or miscalculation is great. To reduce the threat of war, the Clinton administration should make clear to Beijing that it will not tolerate any military action against Taiwan and any aggression will be resisted by US forces in the region, said a former US State Department official Saturday.

Harvey J. Feldman, senior fellow in the Asian Studies Center at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, wrote in an analysis that such a Washington response followed Communist China's threatening military exercises in the Taiwan Straits on the eve of Taiwan's presidential election in March 1996.

The US Navy deployed two aircraft carriers and 36 ships and submarines to the region to diffuse that situation, disclosed the former official in charge of Republic of China affairs at the State Department when President Jimmy Carter switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.

For the longer term, Feldman pointed out, the Clinton administration must distance itself from public or veiled support of Beijing's views regarding Taiwan. "It is not up to the United States to determine Taiwan's future status. This right belongs to the people of Taiwan alone, not to a government in distant Washington," he said.

The former US ambassador to Papua New Guinea stressed, "Although the United States no longer recognizes the Republic of China diplomatically, the Taiwan Relations Act establishes that, for all purposes of US law, Taiwan is to be treated as a state separate and distinct from the PRC."

The Clinton administration claims that promoting democracy is one of its goals. Yet its failure to clarify America's commitment to support the right of Taiwan's 22 million people to determine their own future -- free from coercion or military threat -- would be an unpardonable betrayal of American ideals and could lead to an armed conflict with disastrous results," said Feldman.

He noted that President Lee Teng-hui's remarks that the relationship between Taipei and Beijing was on a "state-to-state or special state-to-state basis" would be understood by a German audience to explain why Taiwan would never negotiate with Beijing as a province with a central government. But the Clinton administration's reaction to President Lee's observation was almost as intemperate as that of Jiang Zemin's government in Beijing.

Agreeing to the PRC's "Three Noes" toward Taiwan stripped away much of the necessary ambiguity in the formal "one China" policy that had guided US-PRC and US-Taiwan relations for two decades. Faced with this change in US policy, "it is no wonder that President Lee was compelled to clarify Taiwan's position. It also is no wonder that Beijing demanded that the Clinton administration pressure Taiwan to acquiesce," explained Feldman. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: WRITER'S ENTRY HAS NO EFFECT ON PRESIDENTIAL RACE: POLL

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong continued his lead in the 2000 presidential race after New Party recruited outspoken writer and former political prisoner Li Ao to serve as the tiny opposition party's presidential candiate, a poll showed on Sunday.

Soong was followed by Vice President Lien Chan of the ruling Kuomintang and Chen Shui-bian of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party, indicating that Li's entry has not affected the presidential race, the poll showed.

The poll was conducted by the Republic of China's Public Policy Society at the commission of Tsai Chih-hung, National Assembly deputy of the Kuomintang. The society called voters islandwide between Saturday night and Sunday morning. It collected 1,128 effective samples with a margin of error of 2.91 percent.

A majority 48.4 percent said they didn't know which candidate would benefit the most from Li's entry, 18.8 percent said Soong would benefit the most from Li's entry, while 7.7 percent said Lien would benefit.
Soong was leading with a 29.9 percent support rate, followed by 23.4 percent for Lien, and 15.4 percent for Chen. Some 28.5 percent of the polled said that they have not yet decided whom to support.
But Lien was voted the most likely to be elected the ROC's next president with 43.3 percent, followed by Soong, 21.2 percent, and Chen with 5.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 INJURED IN CAL AIRLINER CRASH LANDING IN HK AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: About 10 were injured and rushed to
hospitals for treatment after the China Airline McDonnell-Douglas 11 passenger plane they were aboard crash landed during typhoon at Hong Kong airport late Sunday afternoon, rescuers said.
The plane, on a flight from Bangkok to Hong Kong, deviated from the runway due to strong wind, and caught fire while landing at 6:45 p.m.
Most of the 315 passengers and crew were evacuated safely.
The leading Taiwan airlines was tainted with its poor safety record after several accidents in recent years.
On April 26, 1994, a CAL Airbus A300-600 crash landed at Japan's Nagoya airport, killing 264.

On February 16, 1998, a CAL Airbus A300-600R aircraft crashed after hitting a row of houses near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, killing 196 passengers and crew members as well as six other people on the ground.
The Hong Kong airport, which remained open during the typhoon, was closed after the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1 KILLED, 188 INJURED IN CAL AIRLINER CRASH LANDING IN HK
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane with 315 on board crash landed at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during typhoon late Sunday afternoon, killing 1 and injuring at least 188, rescuers said.
The injured were rushed to several hospitals for treatment. A medical task force was established by Hong Kong authorities to take care of the injured.

The CAL Mcdonnell-Douglas-11, on a flight from Bangkok to Hong Kong, deviated from the runway after one of its main wings touched the ground at landing at 6: 15 due to strong side wind promoted by typhoon Sam. The aircraft was to return to Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at 8 p.m. after a short stop in the former British colony.

A press release by the Hong Kong Special Administration Region government said that one passenger, whose name could not be identified, died at a nearby hospital. While, among the 188 injured were five of the 15 crew.
But in Taipei, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng said at a press conference that none of the passengers and crew was killed.
The leading Taiwan airlines was tainted with its poor safety record after several accidents in recent years.
On April 26, 1994, a CAL Airbus A300-600 crash landed at Japan's Nagoya airport, killing 264.

On February 16, 1998, a CAL Airbus A300-600R aircraft crashed after hitting a row of houses near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, killing 196 passengers and crew members as well as six other people on the ground.
The Hong Kong airport, which remained open during the typhoon, was closed after the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 KILLED, 211 INJURED IN CAL AIRLINER CRASH LANDING IN HK
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane with 315 on board crash landed at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during typhoon late Sunday afternoon, killing 2 and injuring 211, according to a press released by the Hong Kong Special Region Administration govenrment.
The injured were rushed to several hospitals for treatment. A medical task force was established by Hong Kong authorities to take care of the injured.
The CAL Mcdonnell-Douglas-11, on a flight from Bangkok to Hong Kong, deviated from the runway after main wings hit the ground at landing at 6:15 p.m. due to strong side wind brought by typhoon Sam.
The aircraft was to return to Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at 8 p.m. after a short stop in the former British colony.

As a result, the aircraft flipped over with its two main wings destroyed, said Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director-general of Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), at a Taipei press conference.
Five of the 15-member crew were among those injured.
But in Taipei, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng said at a press conference that none of the passengers and crew was killed.
Lin said that a three-man team led by Chang will fly to Hong Kong Monday morning to deal with the aftermath of the latest accident.

Upon informed of the accident, Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan ordered rlevant government agencies to do their best to take care of those injured and other passengers and to find out its cause as soon as possible.
The leading Taiwan airlines was tainted by its poor safety record after several accidents in recent years.
On April 26, 1994, a CAL Airbus A300-600 crash landed at Japan's Nagoya airport, killing 264.

On February 16, 1998, a CAL Airbus A300-600R aircraft crashed after hitting a row of houses near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, killing 196 passengers and crew members as well as six other people on the ground.
The Hong Kong airport, which remained open during the typhoon, was closed after the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEADERS EXPRESS CONCERN OVER CAL JET ACCIDENT IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan Sunday night expressed their deep concern about the crash-landing of a China Airlines passenger jet in Hong Kong.
The jetliner from Bangkok with 315 people aboard caught fire and crash-landed at Chek Lap Kok Airport amid a windy storm caused by Typhoon Sam. Two persons were killed, and 206 others were injured.
Lee and Lien instructed related authorities to do their utmost to help the victims, and to find out the cause of the accident.
Premier Vincent Siew asked the ROC's representative to Hong Kong, Cheng An-kuo, to dispatch personnel to help handle rescue and rehabilitation operations.
Siew also expressed his sympathy to the victims and their families, and asked the Transportation and Communications Ministry to send relevant officials to Hong Kong to help the rehabilitation work.
Information from Hong Kong said that Cheng's secretary Lee Hua-chiang rushed to the Hong Kong airport Sunday night to provide necessary assistance for the victims and other passengers.

Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng ordered the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) to set up an emergency task force to handle the matters related to the accident. The task force was headed by CAA Deputy Director Chang Kuo-cheng.
