DOC.HEADLINE: 5,000 CONSCRIPTS TO BEGIN ALTERNATIVE MILITARY SERVICE NEXT JULY

TEXT.P: The first 5,000 conscripts to perform an alternative to traditional military service will begin their service next July, the Executive Yuan said.

The Executive Yuan said the 5,000 will be drawn from 70,000 college students expected to graduate next June. They will then be dispatched to perform alternative services according to their specialties.

The alternative military service is largely divided into two categories: one that deals with social order, such as security guards, neighborhood security watchers, assistant traffic police, school guards, correctional officers and emergency rescue workers; and one that deals with social work, such as social welfare workers and environmental protection workers.

The Executive Yuan has decided that every year, 10,000 conscripts will go into the alternative military service, meaning that they will serve in non-military units in lieu of the traditional two years of compulsory military service. As the system will be put into practice in the latter half of next year, the quota for next year will be only 5,000.

Alternative military service is one of several measures considered by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to alleviate the oversupply of conscripts in the military, which has resulted in some conscripts waiting for long periods of time before being called up to serve.
The MND has also considered shortening the period of military service to allow earlier discharges of conscripts from the military.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TO US RETURNS FOR HOME CONSULTATIONS

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen returned to Taipei on Monday for a 10-day home consultation tour.
The de facto Republic of China ambassador to Washington, D.C. returned at a time when relations across the Taiwan Strait have been strained over the "special state-to-state relationship" theory.

ROC President Lee Teng-hui told a German radio interviewer in July that Taiwan-mainland China relations should be on a "special state-to-state" basis, sparking furious reaction from Beijing which regards Lee's definition as a dangerous move to promote Taiwan independence.
In the past few weeks, many US congressmen and academics have come to Taipei to seek a better understanding of the "special state-to-state" theory and the ROC's stance on cross-strait ties.

Chen, the ROC's top representative in the United States, is expected to brief senior government officials on the Clinton administration's views and opinions about the "special state-to-state" theory and all other related issues during his home consultation tour.
Chen, a seasoned career diplomat, would not elaborate on the purpose of his home visit. He only said he has returned for routine home consultations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR REMAIN IN CRITICAL CONDITION AFTER SUNDAY'S CAL CRASH LANDING

TEXT.P: Four people, including two China Airlines (CAL) crew members injured in a crash landing of a CAL passenger jetliner in Hong Kong Sunday evening, remain in critical condition, CAL sources reported on Monday.

CAL's Flight CI-642, a McDonnell-Douglas 11 en route from Bangkok to Hong Kong, crash-landed in a driving rain as Typhoon Sam was sweeping through Hong Kong. The plane, landing at an abnormal 15-degree tilt, cracked a wing, which caused a fire, and flipped onto its back after landing on the southern runway of Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok Airport.
Two passengers, including a 30-year-old Taiwanese man named Lin Keng-hui, were killed and 211 of the 315 passengers and crew aboard were injured, according to CAL officials.
As of Monday noon, 61 passengers and crew members remained hospitalized, with four in critical condition, 10 in serious condition and 47 in stable condition.
The hospitals could not identify the nationalities of those hospitalized, although most of the passengers aboard the ill-fated liner were Portuguese and Hong Kongers.
A CAL emergency cell along with Lin's relatives, were expected to try again around Monday noon to fly to Hong Kong for relevant post-accident work.

The Taiwan group, headed by CAL Vice President Chou Kuo-hsing, boarded a CAL passenger jetliner bound for Hong Kong at 7:30 a.m., but the plane returned to Taiwan without landing at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok Airport because the airport was closed Monday morning as a result of continued stormy weather and torrential rainfall.

Two other CAL passenger planes, carrying passengers who had been stuck in Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport since Sunday due to flight cancellations, suffered the same fate Monday morning.
Meanwhile, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng said he was puzzled as to why the jetliner's pilots decided to land in Hong Kong during the height of the typhoon Sunday evening.
Lin, however, said the crew's handling of the emergency was still laudable as there were only two fatalities in a situation that had the potential for a massive loss of life.

Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), said that after having detailed discussions with relevant CAL officials, it was decided that investigations on the accident may focus on four major points -- the pilot's deciding to land as a result of overconfidence in his flight skills; mechanical failure; a sudden wind gust that caused the plane to tilt as it was landing; and a technical flaw stemming from a height readjustment as the plane was attempting to land.
CAL Board Chairman H.I. Chiang apologized to Taiwan's public, saying that CAL was greatly disturbed as the accident has again tarnished Taiwan's international image.
Chiang would not speculate on the cause of the accident, saying only that CAL would respect the investigation results of Hong Kong's civil air authorities.

Meanwhile, the Executive Yuan's Aviation Safety Council, which is also dispatching specialists to Hong Kong to help probe the accident, suggested that the Hong Kong civil air authorities allow the flight recorder, or "black box," of Flight CI-642 be transported to Taiwan for further investigation.

Council members said there are only two countries in Asia, Japan and Taiwan, that have the know-how and devices to decode or analyze black box records, while only Taiwan is capable of decoding or analyzing black box recordings that contain information in mandarin.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO PREPARE FOR MAINLAND CHINA'S SQUEEZING OF TAIWAN THROUGH APEC

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Monday the government will prepare for attempts by mainland China at a summit meeting next month to further squeeze Taiwan.

Hu was referring to an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting to be held in New Zealand next month. The meeting comes amid renewed tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship."
Many of the participants, including the host country of New Zealand, have said that they do not wish to discuss the issue in the summit meeting.

Hu said that the main topic of the APEC meeting will be economic cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region, and the ROC government does not wish to see the summit meeting turn into a forum for debate on the issue of a "state-to-state" cross-strait relationship or other political issues.

In analyzing the possible strategy Beijing may adopt to squeeze Taiwan, Hu said that Beijing will try to woo more support for its "one China" rhetoric. Beijing will also try to create an impression that the United States is tilting toward mainland China, he added.
Beijing will also use the occasion to further isolate Taiwan, Hu continued.
"We don't want the APEC meeting to be used by anyone to serve as the forum to discuss cross-strait issues," Hu said.

But noting that Beijing would certainly use the occasion to further squeeze Taiwan, Hu said that he will meet with P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planing and Development, and other officials to discuss ways to deal with the situation.
Chiang will head the ROC delegation attending the APEC informal leadership meeting scheduled for Sept. 12-13.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 23, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
93AD: Julius Gnaeus Agricola, Roman general renowned for his conquests in Britain, dies in Rome at the age of 53.
410: Alaric, king of Visigoths, orders his men to storm Rome after the refusal of the Roman emperor of the West, Honorius, to agree to his terms.
1305: Sir William Wallace, Scottish patriot who demanded independence for his country, is hung, drawn, and quartered in London.
1754: Louis XVI, French monarch responsible for the Revolution and the last king of France, is born.
1818: The first steamship service opens on the Great Lakes in North America.
1821: Mexico is declared independent of Spain.
1912: Gene Kelly, American dancer, choreographer, singer, actor and director, is born. He starred in Hollywood musicals, including "Anchors Aweigh," "Singin' in the Rain," and his "Invitation to Dance."
1914: Japan declares war on Germany.
1926: Screen actor Rudoph Valentino, the idol of millions, dies of peritonitis in New York's Polyclinic Hospital. He was 31. The Italian-born American actor was known for his romantic leading roles in silent films such as "The Sheik," and "Blood and Sand."
1927: In one of the most controversial cases in American legal history, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti are sent to the electric chair. In July 1921, a jury found the two Italian political anarchists and immigrants guilty of the murder of a factory paymaster and a guard during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts.
1928: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung and Chu Teh, and their troops flee to Chingkangshan in Kiangsi Province after being outflanked and besieged by government forces from both Hunan and Kiangsi Provinces.
1933: Ghandi is released from Poona jail after his hunger strike almost kills him.
1939: The USSR and Germany sign the Molotov-Ribbentropp non-aggression pact, a terrible shock to the Western European leaders.
1940: German bombers begin night raids on London.
1944: Marshal Ion Antonescu, the pro-Nazi dictator of Romania, is overthrown.
1945: Soviet troops occupy Manchuria.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a third invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting Mao to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14 and again on Aug. 20.
1958: The Battle of the Taiwan Strait begins with the Chinese communists firing 57,000 rounds on the Kinmen Islands in 2 hours. Many defenders are killed, including Gen. Chi Sing-wen, deputy commander of the Kinmen Garrison Command.
1963: Ambassador to the United States Tsiang Ting-fu signs the nuclear test ban treaty on behalf of the Republic of China.
1981: One hundred and ten persons die in the crash of a Far Eastern Air Transport plane, becoming Taiwan's worst air disaster.
1990: East and West Germany choose October 3 as the date for reunification.
1990: Amenia declares its independence from Moscow.
1992: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with South Korea.
1998: Boris Yeltsin, president of Russia, sacks his government and names former premier Viktor Chernomyrdin as acting prime minister.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The Emperor Shun might perhaps be considered in the highest sense of the word a pious man. In moral qualities he was a saint.In dignity of office he was the ruler of the empire. In wealth all that the wide world contained belonged to him."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN LEADER URGED NOT TO APPEASE MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard should clearly tell President Jiang Zemin during talks in early September that Australian-mainland Chinese relations are based on mutual interests and not on a cringing desire by Canberra to appease Beijing at any price, a senior writer said on Monday.
Writing in The Australian Financial Review, Geoffrey Barker, a veteran writer of the daily, offered a three-point suggestion for Howard on how to deal with Jiang.

First, Barker noted the need to explain to mainland China the security link between Australia and the United States. If mainland Chinese bellicosity prompts the United States to sail carrier battle groups again into the Taiwan Strait, Australia will support the United States. Beijing should ensure that its saber-rattling remains carefully calibrated and controlled.

Second, Howard should tell Beijing that Australia will not seek improved trade ties no matter what the cost. Taiwan is Australia's seventh-largest trading partner and fifth-largest market for merchandise exports. A "one China" policy does not mean the abandonment of Taiwan.
Third, Howard should make clear Australia's commitment to human rights. Mainland China's international relations will continue to be fraught while it criminalizes and terrorizes peaceful citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8-23 KINMEN BOMBARDMENT MARKED

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Tang Fei on Monday presided over a ceremony on the offshore island of Kinmen to mark the 41st anniversary of the 8-23 Kinmen Bombardment.

The 700 participants of the solemn ceremony included Vice Chief of the General Staff Wang Han-ning, Kinsmen Defense Commander Chu Kai-sheng, Legislator Han Kuo-yu, family members of those killed in the bombardment, Kinmen dignitaries as well as troops currently stationed at the outpost.
Tang and others burned incense, placed flower wreaths and recited eulogies to pay their respects to the victims.
Tang said he hoped the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would never again engage in shelling and hoped that future cross-Strait differences would be resolved with patience and wisdom.
During the battle of the Taiwan Strait, Chinese Communists fired 57,000 shells on the Kinmen Islands over a two-hour period on Aug. 23, 1958.

Tang later greeted one by one, the nearly 300 family members of those killed during the shelling. Many of the relatives became emotional and cried during the ceremony held in the Martyr's Shrine at the Tawu Mountain Cemetery in Kinmen.

The MND made all the necessary travel arrangements so that family members could attend Monday's ceremony. Tsao Chin-huan said that he like many others flown to the ceremony had previously been unable to visit the cemetery to pay homage because Kinmen was considered a combat zone before Taiwan annulled its martial law in 1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was quoted at 31.883 against the greenback in Taipei on Monday, gaining 1.6 cent.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 31.896, and had a high of 31.872. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$415.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE PARTY CAUCUSES VOICE CONCERN OVER CAL TRAGEDY

TEXT.P: The caucuses of both the ruling and opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan showed deep concern over the China Airlines (CAL) crash Sunday which killed two passengers and injured 212 others.

Tseng Yung-chuan, director-general of the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said that if the accident was due to human error, CAL high ranking officials should not be free from blame. In the upcoming September legislative session, the KMT will enhance the supervision of flight safety, Tseng added.

The CAL MD-11 jet, was carrying 300 passengers and 15 crew on flight CI-642 from Bangkok, Thailand. It flipped over and caught fire while landing at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok International Airport during Tropical Storm Sam.

Since the CAL has been plagued by a poor safety record, the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) demanded on Monday that a legislative Transportation and Communication Committee ad hoc meeting be held and suggested the disbanding of the CAL foundation.

The DPP legislative caucus strongly demanded an investigation into the administrative responsibilities of the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC), and the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the MOTC.

Lee Yin-yuan, convener of the DPP's legislative caucus, said the immediate priority is for CAL to take responsibility for the dead and injured and their bereaved families. In the mean time, CAL should make a public apology to the country, he added.

Tsai Huang-lang, convener of the Transportation and Communication Committee of the Legislative Yuan, pointed out that "disharmony" has reportedly long existed between CAL foreign and local pilots, which could be a factor in CAL's flight safety problems.
Lai Hse-bao, lawmaker of the New Party, also indicated that CAL internal management problems, which are long over-due for reform, should share the blame for the Hong Kong tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAINS OF STUDENT KILLED IN US RETURNED

TEXT.P: The remains of one of four Taiwan students killed in a car accident last week in the United States were brought back to Taiwan on Monday.

With the help of the ROC representative office in the United States and the US branch of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the parents of Hung Ten-yao brought their son's remains home aboard an EVA Airways plane early on Monday morning.

Meanwhile, the bodies of Shen Juo-han, Fu Hung, and Cheng Ya-ping are scheduled to be transported back to Taiwan within two weeks after relevant legal procedures have been completed in the United States.

The four students were members of a 16-person National Chung Cheng University delegation which went to the United States on Aug. 12 to attend a three-day seminar on business administration in San Francisco followed by a few days of sightseeing before returning to Taiwan on Aug. 26.
But a van in which some of the students were traveling swerved off the road while they were on their way from Yosemite National Park to Las Vegas on Aug. 19, killing four and injuring three.
The surviving members of the delegation, including Associate Professor Lee Yi-tsung, who was leading the group, and five other students and faculty members, returned to Taiwan last Friday.

On Sunday, a Buddhist funeral ceremony was held in Las Vegas for the four dead students, marking an end to the last journey of the young lives. Officials with the ROC representative office, volunteer workers with the Tzu Chi Foundation, and representatives of local Chinese communities were also present at the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TMD REFERS TO TAIWAN MISSILE DEFENSE: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Monday the Republic of China will establish its own missile defense shield which can be referred to as the "Taiwan Missile Defense (TMD)."
Tang said in an exclusive interview with CNA that TMD is usually known as the US-initiated theater missile defense system.
"Nevertheless, TMD can also refer to Taiwan Missile Defense to be developed by our own armed forces," the minister said.
Tang's remarks were seen as an effort to clarify speculation on Taiwan's intention to join the US-initiated theater missile defense project.

In fact, Tang said when he pointed out in a report to the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee last week that installing an anti-missile system is vital to Taiwan's security, he was referring to the need to establish a "Taiwan Missile Defense" system.

Under Taiwan's own missile defense program, Tang said the top priority in the initial stage is to build up a low-altitude safety dragnet capable of intercepting middle-range guided missiles, cruise missiles and traditional airborne attacks from mainland China.
Noting that the US-initiated TMD is basically a high-altitude missile defense system, Tang said it's too early for Taiwan to decide whether to join such a program.

For one thing, Tang said, the United States has not invited Taiwan to take part in its TMD project. Furthermore, he said, the highly sophisticated US-proposed system is still in the development stage. "We'll evaluate whether to join the project based on future developments," he noted.

Tang went on to say even if the United States invites the ROC to join its TMD system, the military will still study whether Taiwan needs to do so and whether the majority of local people support such a move before making a final decision.

For building up a low-altitude missile defense system, Tang said, Taiwan will purchase foreign-developed equipment in addition to developing needed systems on its own. The military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology is in charge of research and development of new weaponry systems and defense technology.
As part of the low-altitude missile defense development program, Tang said the ROC will install an early warning radar system and purchase the US-built Patriot III anti-missile system.

Tang said the Ministry of National Defense plans to complete establishment of a comprehensive low-altitude missile defense system in 10 years at a cost ranging between NT$250 billion and NT$300 million, adding that the ministry will set aside NT$30 billion in its annual budget for the critical project.

Stressing Taiwan's urgent needs for missile defense infrastructure and a low-altitude missile defense system, Tang said such facilities can not only help defend Taiwan against middle-range guided missiles and traditional airborne attacks but also against cruise missiles.

In the past, Tang said, Taiwan people most worry about threats from mainland China's tactical missiles and ballistic missiles. "In fact, it is more worrisome that mainland China is focusing on developing cruise missiles," Tang said, adding that cruise missiles pose even greater threats to Taiwan's security.

Nevertheless, Tang said mainland China's cruise missiles still fall below world standards in terms of speed and accuracy. In the face of the situation, Tang said the ROC military has also stepped up efforts to work out countermeasures to cope with mainland China's cruise missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS CONDITION MONITORING INDICATOR TO SHOW GREEN LIGHT

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Monday that the business condition monitoring indicator for July showed a green light for the second time since the regional financial turmoil hit Taiwan.
A green light indicates that business conditions are favorable for expansion.
The business condition report, to be officially released Friday, will show the CEPD saw a thriving July following a prosperous June due to a bullish export market and an abundant export orders.
Meanwhile, the composite index of leading indicators as well as the index of coincidence indicators for June both rebounded and created new 14-month and 18-month records, respectively.
The business condition monitoring indicator for June flashed a green light for the first time in 15 months, suggesting Taiwan has officially started a revival of its business environment.

If tensions are not raised further between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the US economy avoids a recession and mainland China maintains a stable currency, this year's economic growth rate could easily reach the CEPD's projected target of 5.5 percent.
The employment number for the non-agricultural sector in July was 8.64 million, marking a slight 0.14-percent increase.
The one negative factor was that will be that the annual growth rate of industrial production for July was 7.12 percent, down from June's 11.1 percent. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER GRANTED HONORARY DOCTORATE BY OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew was awarded a honorary doctorate in public service by Ohio State University on Monday in Taipei.

In a ceremony held at National Taiwan University in Taipei, Bobby Moser, deputy director of Ohio State U., presented the honorary diploma to Siew in honor of his distinguished leadership and contribution to the nation.

Moser said the decision to honor Siew was made about six months ago, and added that although the premier was too busy to receive the honor in the United States, he is expected to deliver a speech at the university at Columbus, Ohio some other day.
Noting that this is his first honorary degree, Siew said he considers it not only an affirmation of his performance in public office but also an acknowledgment of the ROC's democratic development.
He said he will share the honor with all the people of the island, because all have played a role in the nation's development.
He thanked Ohio State University for turning out some excellent Taiwanese alumni who have played vital roles on the island, and vowed to do his best to promote ties between Taipei and Washington.
There are about 2,000 Ohio State University alumni working in Taiwan, in addition to 500 local students presently studying at its Columbus campus.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON SAM AFFECTS FLIGHTS TO MACAU AND HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Scheduled flights from Taiwan to Hong Kong and Macau on Monday morning continued to be disrupted by the lingering weather conditions in the vicinity of Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok caused by typhoon Sam.

All four of Monday morning's China Airlines' (CAL) Taiwan-Hong Kong flights were interrupted and sent back to the Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport, and no indication was given by the airline authorities as to when normal services would be resumed.
Thai Airways suspended both its Taipei-Hong Kong flights, while Cathay Pacific Airways canceled all its morning flights, although four flights left for Hong Kong in the afternoon.

The one scheduled Eva Airways' flight landed successfully in Hong Kong, while Air Canada and Ansett Australia, whose flights were not originally scheduled to land in Taipei but were forced to reroute because of the weather, were to resume services to Hong Kong on Monday afternoon.
However, all Monday flights to Macau had to return to CKS, as the Portuguese enclave's airport services were suspended until the typhoon passes.

Meanwhile, about 2,000 passengers were stranded in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung International Airport on Sunday evening when Chek Lap Kok was closed following the crash of CAL flight 642. (Shammy Chao)

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT IN JULY HIT 3.11 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment in July reached 3.11 percent in July, with 302,000 job seekers being not able to find work, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
July's figure was the highest level for that month since 1985.
The DGBAS said the figure was the result of a large number of new graduates looking for work, adding that unemployment will fall below 3 percent as the economy recovers.
Unemployment in July was mainly due to seasonal factors. In fact, the seasonally adjusted jobless rate was only 2.88 percent in July, up slightly from 2.83 percent in June, the DGBAS said.
Taiwan's unemployment rate in July was lower than South Korea's 6.4 percent, Hong Kong's 6 percent, Japan's 4.9 percent or Singapore's 3.3 percent, said the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JULY EMPLOYMENT REACHES NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's number of employed persons totaled 9.41 million in July, a sharp increase for the 4th consecutive month and a record high, according to official statistics released Monday.
The increase in the number of employed persons indicates that Taiwan's economic situation is steadily improving and that the labor force is gradually flowing back into the employment market.

The unemployed people on the island due to factory closedowns and business shrinkage stood at 85,000 in July, a decrease of 5,000 from June, statistics of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed.

Thanks to an injection of graduates and summer part-time student-workers into the employment market, Taiwan's July employment population reached 9.41 million, an increase of 28,000 over June and up a significant 142,000 from the same month last year, DGBAS statistics showed.

Compared with June, Taiwan's July industrial sector labor population increased by 11,000, while service sector labor expanded by 22,000. However, agricultural sector labor decreased by 4,000, according to DGBAS statistics.
Taiwan's July labor force population totaled 9.71 million, an increase of 48,000 from the previous month and up a sharp 164,000 from the same month last year.

The island's labor participation rate in July expanded to 58.18 percent, an increase of 0.19 percentage points from the previous month, and an increase of 0.18 percentage points from July of last year.
The labor participation rate for the first seven months of this year was 57.87 percent, a decrease of 0.15 percentage points from the same period last year.

Taiwan's population not in the labor force by reason for nonparticipation, such as housewives and those too young or too old to work, stood at 6.98 million, a decrease of 21,000 compared with the previous month, DGBAS statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, DECLINE 0.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan price shares closed 0.4 percent lower Monday under rising profit-taking pressure and the influence of the China Airline's tragedy.
The benchmark Taiwan Exchange Weighted Price Index dropped 33.59 points to close at 8,119.98 points on a turnover of 97.37 billion.
The over-the-counter market rose 2.19 points to end at 175.35 points, on a turnover of 5.84 billion.

The glass and porcelain sector posted the largest gain ending the day up 2.02 percent, followed by department store issues, up 1.46 percent. Transport stocks and construction shares declined 1.5 percent and 1.09 percent, respectively.

Meanwhile, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) reported gains, except for December futures which fell 15 points to end at 8,280 points, with 8 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September closed up 4 points at 8,265 points, with 2,065 contract transactions; those for October climbed 6 points to finish at 8,286, with 35 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March advanced 4 points to close at 8,347 points, with 1 contract transaction; those for next June rose 4 points to end at 8,225 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: US NOT TO BACK OFF COMMITMENT TO ROC: ENVOY

TEXT.P: The United States will not back off its commitments to the Republic of China under the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), ROC Representative to Washington, D.C. Stephen Chen said here on Monday.
Chen, who returned to Taipei earlier in the day for home consultations, made the statement while meeting with the local press in the evening.

Chen said the timing of his current home consultation tour has nothing to with the reported arrival of a US official delegation for discussing the recent escalation of tension in the Taiwan Strait over the "special state-to-state" theory.

The de facto ROC ambassador to the United States stressed that he knew nothing about what local press reports claimed that a US official delegation will come to Taipei in the near future to meet with senior ROC officials on current cross-strait tension and the Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular relations.
Chen further said the timing for his present home consultation tour has long been set. He last made a home consultation visit in august 1998.

According to Chen, the United States attaches great importance to Taiwan-mainland China relations and hopes to see continued cross-strait dialogue and stable bilateral exchanges. "The Clinton administration does not like to see an escalation of cross-strait tension," he noted.

Cross-Taiwan Strait relations have been soured after ROC President Lee Teng-hui declared in an interview with a German radio station in July that cross-strait ties should be on a "special state-to-state relationship" basis. As Beijing regards the definition as a dangerous move toward Taiwan independence, it has launched war of words and saber-rattling against Taiwan.

Chen said despite the recent cross-strait controversy over the "special state-to-state" theory, the US executive branch and Congress have reaffirmed their commitments to Taiwan under the TRA, the US law regulating relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
According to the TRA, the United States is obligated to provide Taiwan with adequate defensive arms and will view any military action against Taiwan by mainland China as a matter of grave concern.
Chen further said communication channels between Taipei and Washington have operated smoothly.

The seasoned career diplomat also dismissed as "incorrect" press reports that Kurt Campbell, US deputy assistant secretary of defense, will be among members of an American delegation to visit Taiwan to discuss the "special state-to-state" controversy.
Meanwhile, other senior ROC officials, including Premier Vincent Siew, Foreign Minister Jason Hu and Deputy Secretary-General to the President Lin Pi-chao, also unanimously denied such reports.
"There is no such thing. The local press need not speculate on that," Premier Siew said.

According to press reports, the Clinton administration will send a delegation of officials from the White House National Security Council, the Department of State and the Department of Defense to Taipei to exchange views with senior ROC officials on the current Taiwan Strait situation and the Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations amid the "special state-to-state" controversy. (BY Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF CAL CRASH FATALITIES TO BE COMPENSATED WITH US$91,000

TEXT.P: The families of the two people killed in a China Airlines (CAL) MD-11 which crash-landed in Hong Kong on Sunday will each receive compensation of at least NT$3 million (US$91,200), according to an announcement on Monday by Taiwan's Ministry of Finance (MOF).

Each of the 211 injured passengers will have all medical treatment paid for, an MOF insurance official added. Flight number CI-642, which flipped and caught fire while landing at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok airport on Sunday during typhoon Sam, was carrying 315 passengers and crew.

The official noted that the family of Taiwanese passenger Lin Keng-hui, one of the two dead, is expected to receive at least NT$8.85 million (US$277,600), as Lin had taken out several different life, travel and accident insurance policies.
The other fatality was a Portuguese woman who was yet to be identified, while four of the injured, including two CAL crew members, were in critical condition as of press time.
Under Taiwan's civil aeronautics laws, the official explained, air carriers must pay out NT$3 million for each victim, and more if the airline is found to have been responsible for the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60 VICTIMS OF CAL CRASH STILL HOSPITALIZED IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Belle Chou & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A total of 60 victims of Sunday night's China Airlines (CAL) crash at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok airport were still hospitalized late on Monday, with two of them in serious condition, according to police.

The other 152 passengers injured in the accident have already been released from hospital, the police said. The CAL MD-11 plane was carrying 315 passengers and crew when it flipped and caught fire while trying to land at the height of typhoon Sam which battered Hong Kong over the past two days.
The wreckage of the plane was still piled on the runway on Monday, awaiting a full inspection by aviation experts. The crash also claimed the lives of two of the passengers.

A Hong Kong government official said that an investigation panel was being set up to look into the accident, but added that the black box of the crashed plane will have to be sent to Britain for decoding because Hong Kong lacks the equipment to conduct the analysis.
Air traffic at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok remained seriously disrupted as of Monday, with many scheduled flights canceled.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO EVALUATE PUBLIC STRAY DOG SHELTERS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Monday it has formed a special task force to evaluate all the 62 public stray dog shelters around the island as part of its efforts to improve treatment of stray animals.

The special task force is composed of scholars, experts and veterinarians, COA officials said, adding that members of the team will visit all public stray dog shelters to evaluate their facilities and treatment of animals kept there. They will also offer counseling services to help public stray dog shelters improve their services.
Meanwhile, the council has commissioned National Taiwan University to conduct a national survey of the island's total canine population.
This is the first time that the council has launched such a survey to compile basic data concerning the number of pet dogs and unwanted or abandoned dogs here.
COA officials said the dog population census is scheduled to be completed by the end of October.
In addition to conducting telephone surveys, National Taiwan University will also refer to calculating formulas set by the World Health Organization to assess the number of wandering dogs here.
According to COA tallies, local people adopted a total of 5,353 abandoned dogs from public stray animal shelters around the island in 1998.

COA officials further said public stray animal shelters which fail to offer humanitarian or civilized treatment of unwanted animals under their protection will be penalized, adding that the COA has offered subsidies to all local stray animal shelters to hire veterinarians and improve their facilities.
The COA has in recent years come under heavy pressure from animal rights groups at home and abroad to improve treatment of the island's stray animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL DISTRIBUTOR PUNISHED FOR CAR MALFUNCTION

TEXT.P: Taipei District Court ruled on Monday that auto distributor Cannon Taiwan Ltd. must pay NT$1.07 million compensation to a Taipei citizen who hurt his head two years ago as a result of alleged sudden acceleration (ASA).
ASA refers to a malfunction which causes a vehicle to suddenly accelerate in a violent and uncontrollable manner.
The ruling marks the first time in Taiwan that such a case has been decided by a court, and is expected to set a precedent for dealing with similar cases in the future.

The Taipei citizen, surnamed Tsai, filed a lawsuit according to the Consumers Protection Law against Cannon on July 21, 1997 after the car -- a Volvo 960 -- in which he was a passenger, accelerated without warning when the driver started the engine and stepped on the brake in order to engage the drive gear. The sudden movement caused Tsai to hit his head on the windshield before he had a chance to fasten his seat belt.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SOLICITS SUPPORT FOR KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Monday solicited support among overseas delegates to the ruling Kuomintang's party congress for Vice President Lien Chan to run for the presidency on the party ticket in March 2000.
"The forthcoming presidential election will be key to the consolidation of the nation's democracy, and to the creation of a new era for the Kuomintang," he told over 190 KMT delegates from abroad.
Lee urged the delegates to do their utmost to mobilize support for Lien in next March's election.
The vice president's election bid obtained 96 percent support from some 2,100 KMT party congress delegates in last Saturday's party primaries.
The KMT Central Standing Committee will approve Lien's nomination and his running mate on Aug. 27, with the party congress giving its final stamp of approval on Aug. 29.

Lee also explained to the party delegates the basic policies of the nation's development, stressing that in order to ensure the ROC's survival and development, the government must pursue a balanced development in domestic affairs, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and foreign affairs.

He defended his recent redefinition of Taiwan-mainland ties as a "special state-to-state relationship," saying that his statement was intended to let the international community know the facts with regard to the existence of the ROC.

Despite furious criticism from Beijing over his statement, he said Taipei will continue to push forward the idea of consultations with Beijing to peacefully narrow bilateral differences with goodwill.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO COMPUTER FAILURES DISRUPT SERVICE ISLAND WIDE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) entire computer system shut down on Monday, leaving MOEA officials with no clues as to why the failure occurred.
The MOEA's mainframe computer crashed suddenly and unexpectedly on Monday morning, hampering the customer services provided by MOEA's Commerce Department.

Although the computer malfunction was corrected by noon, it was not until that evening that specialists at the MOEA Computer Center were able to determine that the crash was the result of a hacker who infiltrated the system via the ministry's website.
Also on Monday, 1,000 automatic teller machines (ATM) in post offices islandwide were paralyzed, preventing customers from withdrawing money.
Postal authorities blamed the shut down on the improper installation of a new-generation ATM system which is replacing the existing one.

Postal authorities reacted to the failure by instructing an immediate resumption of the old ATM system. The authorities said the existing system will remain in operation until the new ATM system is proven to be reliable.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TOLD TO PRESENT STEPS TOWARD FLIGHT SAFETY IMPROVEMENT

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Republic of China Ministry of Transportation and Communications on Monday ordered China Airlines (CAL) to present concrete steps on flight safety improvements within one week.

The order was issued in the wake of a crash involving a CAL passenger jet which crash-landed and overturned at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok airport on Sunday night, killing two passengers and leaving 212 passengers and crew injured.

CAA Director-General Chang Yu-heng told a press conference that his administration has told CAL to step up its crew training program, and to suspend the crewmen involved in the latest of a string of accidents.

If an investigation into the crash finds that CAL crew members were responsible for the accident, he said, CAL's rights to a share of flight routes and an increase of flight numbers will be suspended for one year.
Regarding CAL's plans to procure new aircraft, Chang said he is glad to see the plans being realized, so long as they can also boost flight safety.
The CAA chief admitted that the accident rate of Taiwan's aircraft is too high, averaging 3.0 per 1 million flying hours, compared with the world average of 0.818 per 1 million hours.

He said the CAA will hold monthly meetings to review flight safety measures for domestic airlines, with the hope of bringing down the island's aircraft accident rate to below the world average within five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS SAID SEEKING ASYLUM IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Tourism relations between Australia and mainland China got off to an embarrassing start when two of a group of 42 tourists from the mainland were reported missing and seeking political asylum.
The two Chinese tourists were among the second group to visit Australia since Beijing designated Australia as one of six countries for "pleasure trips" for its citizens.
The two went missing in Sydney and did not rejoin the group to return to mainland China at the end of its tour last week.
Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock on Sunday slammed the door on any mainland Chinese tourists who try to seek asylum, saying their applications will never be approved under any circumstances.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETAINED AUSTRALIAN RESEARCHER DEPORTED FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: An Australian researcher has returned to Melbourne and was reunited with his family after being deported by mainland Chinese authorities following a week-long detention over allegations of spying near Tibet.

Gabriel Lafitte of the Melbourne University on Sunday told the Age newspaper about his experience, saying he was continually interrogated by mainland Chinese security agents, deprived of sleep and forced to sign "hundreds" of confessions after he, an American linguist and a Tibetan interpreter were accused of conducting "an illegal visit and doing illegal interviews" and having driven past a "forbidden" prison farm near Tibet.
He said what started as a trip to independently observe a controversial World Bank project in the remote north-west of China turned into an ugly diplomatic incident.

He said he had received written assurances from the mainland Chinese government and the World Bank before he left Australia two weeks earlier that he was free to inspect the project and speak to local Tibetan and Mongolian nomads about it.

The World Bank has agreed to a A$63 (US$42) million loan to fund irrigation and resettlement of 58,000 Chinese in Dulan County, traditionally seen as a part of Tibet. Pro-Tibet campaigners say the move will dilute the native population with Han Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA URGED TO REPEAL INTERNET CENSORSHIP LAW

TEXT.P: Australia's Internet censorship laws are draconian and repressive and should be repealed, according to the president of the US Civil Liberties Union.

The Australian Associated Press (AAP) on Monday quoted Professor Nadine Strossen of the union as criticizing the new Australian laws as vague and susceptible to being infused with the values of those enforcing them.

She urged the Australian government to repeal the laws, which will become effective on January 1. The laws require that Internet service providers in Australia block "anything that offends against the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adults."

Strossen, currently on a visit to Melbourne, said Australia was now looking like the global village idiot. She said the Internet should not be censored because it was "potentially the most empowering, the most enlightening, the most liberating tool for individual self-realization."

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC OKAYS BLOOD TESTS FOR SYDNEY OLYMPIC GAMES

TEXT.P: Competing athletes from more than 100 countries in the Sydney's 2000 Olympic Games will face blood tests after the International Olympic Committee gave a go-ahead signal for organizers to do so.

The Sydney Morning Herald reported the IOC, which had previously wavered over the tests due to uncertainties about the legality of positive results, will now allow organizers to conduct blood tests on any athlete competing in the Olympic Games.

"It is a very positive message that will have a huge deterrent value because cheating athletes will now be confused about what can be detected and how far back the blood tests go," Nicki Vance, anti-doping manager of the Sydney Organizing Committee for Olympic Games, said.

Blood testing can detect the latest drugs used by athletes, perfluorocarbons, or artificial oxygen carriers, which enable the body's cells to utilize up to 60 percent more oxygen from the blood, which causes stunning improvement in stamina, the daily reported.
Australian Olympic organizers hope to make Sydney the cleanest games ever in the Olympic games history.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui said Vice President Lien Chan is qualified for the top leadership post.

The Taiwan News:
Transport minister blasts CAL; chairman apologizes for crash.
