DOC.HEADLINE: POPE APPOINTS NEW CHARGE D'AFFAIRES TO ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Michelle Tseng)

TEXT.P: Pope John Paul II announced Thursday that Adolofo Tito Yllana has been appointed Holy See's Charge d'affaires a.i. to the Republic of China.
Rev. Monsignor Joseph Chennoth, the outgoing Holy See Charge d'affaires to the ROC has been named Ambassador to the Central African Republic and Chad.
Holy See Deputy Secretary Giovanni Battista informed the ROC Ambassador to the Holy See, Raymond Tai of Yllana' appointment.
The appointment of Yllana by the Pope was not unexpected as Yllana had been sent to Taiwan by the Vatican in July to perform the duties as the counselor to the Embassy of the Holy See.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN CONTAINER SHIP COLLIDES WITH CRUISE LINER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp. said on Tuesday that one of its container ships was involved in a collision with a cruise liner off Britain's southeast coast.
An Evergreen spokesman said all 17 crew members of the container ship, the 50,000-ton Ever Decent, were safe and unharmed. Evergreen is currently checking the details of the incident.
Wire services reported that the Bahamas-registered Norwegian Dream cruise ship had three passengers evacuated with slight injuries.
The crew of the Ever Decent was said to be battling a fire on the deck when the collision occurred in the English Channel about 20 miles northwest of Margate on Tuesday.
The Ever Decent was on a round-the-world eastbound route carrying a wide range of exports from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA ISSUES DEPORTATION ORDERS FOR 57 CHINESE MIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Canada on Monday issued 57 deportation orders for mainland Chinese migrants who came ashore on British Columbia on Aug. 11. The other 74 of the 131 Chinese stowaways on board the same ship have made refugee claims.
Immigration authorities transferred 76 Chinese migrants -- 44 minors and 32 adult females -- from a military base near Victoria to Vancouver on Monday.
The women will be taken to an undisclosed detention facility, while 39 of the 44 minors will be put into the care of the BC Children and Family Ministry.
It was the second illegal immigrant ship to arrive off the BC coast this summer.

All those aboard the first ship have applied for refugee status in Canada. All but 37 have been released pending the outcome of their refugee applications. Some are being held on suspicion of involvement in the smuggling operation. SC CHANG

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIR PLANE CRASH-LANDED AT HUALIEN AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Twenty-five passengers were injured when a UNI Air plane from Taipei crash-landed at Hualien Airport in flames Tuesday afternoon.
Fifteen of the injured passengers were rushed to an army hospital in the eastern Taiwan city of Hualien, while three others were sent to Tzu Chi Buddhist General Hospital for emergency treatment.
A news release issued by UNI Air said the MD-90 airliner, with 90 passengers on board, took off from Taipei's Sungshan Airport at 12:16 and landed at Hualien Airport at 12:40.

When the plane was approaching the runway, the front part of the fuselage was in flames, causing the plane to veer off the runway. According to the carrier's press release, the flame erupted from the stowage compartments near the 10th-12th rows of seats in the cabin. The fire was put off quickly.

Following the mishap, the Hualien Airport was closed. Upon learning of the incident, Premier Vincent Siew immediately ordered Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng and Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsieh Shen-shan to fly to Hualien via a helicopter to look into the incident and handle aftermath.
The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, CLOSE BELOW 8,000-POINT LEVEL

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1.7 percent lower Tuesday, falling below the 8,000-point level, amid a decline in investor confidence.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 135.59 points to close at 7,984.39 points with a turnover of NT$104.79 billion.
The over-the-counter market dropped 2.05 points to end at 173.3 points, on a turnover of NT$5.95 billion.

Paper-making issues posted the largest losses among the eight major categories, ending the day down 4.18 percent. Electronics shares suffered a 3.79-percent decline and cement stocks closed 3.28 percent lower.
Meanwhile, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) reported losses.

TAIEX Index Futures for September were down 264 points to close at 8,001 points, with 3,708 contract transactions; those for October plunged 256 points to finish at 8,030 points, with 86 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December slid 230 points to end at 8,050 points, with 21 contract transactions; those for next March dropped 277 points to finish at 8,070 points, with 5 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next June were at 8,150 points, with 1 contract transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL CARRYING BACK STUCK PASSENGERS IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) is expected to carry all the Taiwan passengers stranded in Hong Kong back to Taiwan by Tuesday night, a spokesman for the aviation company said on Tuesday.

From Monday night until Tuesday noon, CAL had transported about 1,500 local passengers back to Taiwan on six additional flights after operations at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok Airport returned to normal, according to CAL spokesman Shih Ping-huang. During the same time, CAL also took 1,100 passengers to Hong Kong.

Due to bad weather conditions brought by Typhoon Sam and a CAL passenger jet crash-landing on Sunday night in Hong Kong, a large number of passengers traveling between Taiwan and Hong Kong were stuck on both sides.

It is reported that more than 10,000 Taiwan passengers were stranded in the Hong Kong airport, while over 50 flights at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport near Taipei were delayed until Monday night. Some angry passengers quarreled with aviation companies for not having informed them of the cancellations of flights and the failure of airlines to arrange hotel accommodations for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 24, or the 14th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
79AD: Mount Vesuvius erupts and destroys Pompeii, Herculaneum, Stabiae, and a number of smaller settlements in Italy.
1690: Job Charnock establishes a trading post on behalf of the English East India Company in Kalikata, West Bengal.
1770: British poet Thomas Chatterton becomes depressed and fatally poisons himself with arsenic in London at age 18. He duped scholars by ascribing his poetry to a 15th-century monk, Thomas Rowley.
1814: The small but very bitter war currently being fought by Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek, leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the UN Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Getulio Vargas, President of Brazil, shoots himself to avoid scandal and demands that he should relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the US West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon last December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Chinese communist pilot Lieutenant Colonel Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter on Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Chinese communist pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year jail term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the US city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UNLIKELY TO HIT 31-LEVEL AGAINST US DOLLAR THIS YEAR: CEPD

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Tuesday forecast that the NT dollar, which was quoted Monday at a 20-month high of 31.883 against the greenback, would not reach the 31:1 level this year, though there is room for further rises.
CEPD said that the 31:1 exchange rate for the NT dollar is reasonable, though the exact exchange rate must be determined by the market.
CEPD Secretary-General Ye Ming-fung said there are three reasons the NT dollar would likely appreciate further.

First, the Central Bank of China (CBC) and the CEPD's Effective Exchange Rate Index is located at a level of about 85 points, which is considered too low. Second, strong exports this year have resulted in an export growth rate for the first half of 1999 of 5.5 percent and a trade surplus of US$6.2 billion.

Finally, the continuous recovery of Taiwan's economy, the allure of Taiwan stocks to foreign investors and the recent decision by Morgan Stanley Capital International to raise the weighting of Taiwan shares -- resulting in an influx of foreign investment -- could all contribute to a further rise as well.
In response to predictions that the NT dollar might reach a 30-level mark against the greenback, Ye said it would be impossible "in the short term," meaning by the end of this year.

Explaining the reasons for the impossibility of the NT dollar's reaching the 30-level, Ye said that the CBC may stabilize the foreign exchange market by all means, as it worries that a sudden fluctuation of the NT dollar may have a great impact on imports and exports.
In addition, Taiwan's economy is still recovering and has not reached its peak. Thus, the NT dollar cannot ascend to such a high level.
In regard to whether the NT dollar will reach a 30-level against the US dollar next year, Ye said that it depends on the undulations of the renminbi, the greenback and other international currencies.

Ye said he doubted predictions by foreign agents that the renminbi would be devalued within 45 days, saying that as the yen has appreciated to 110 against the US dollar, the currencies of Southeast Asian countries have rallied. In addition, mainland Chinese exports in July have resulted in positive growth of 7.5 percent, which has also eased pressure on the currency to devalue.
If the export competitiveness of the mainland cannot be bolstered by export taxes rebates, the renminbi will likely be devalued, Ye added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 28 INJURED IN UNI AIR FLIGHT MISHAP

TEXT.P: Twenty-eight passengers were injured when a domestic jetliner landed in flames at Hualien Airport, some 180 kilometers southeast of Taipei, on Tuesday.
The UNI Airlines jetliner, with 90 passengers and six crew members on board, was crippled by a cabin fire but managed to land and evacuate its passengers before being consumed by blaze.
"All passengers safely escaped down emergency rescue chutes, though 28 are being treated for injuries, chiefly burns," said a UNI executive.
Seventeen of the injured have been rushed an army hospital and 11 others were sent to Tzuchi Buddhist General Hospital. Three of the injured are in critical conditions.
The airline has formed an emergency relief team which already traveled from Taipei to Hualien under the leadership of UNI Vice Chairman Su Chung-ching to handle all related affairs.

At Premier Vincent Siew's instruction, Transportation and Communication Minister Lin Feng-cheng and Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsieh Shen-shan also flew to Hualien on Taiwan's Pacific shore to look into the incident.

Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, said the UNI plane, a McDonnell Douglas MD-90, was set ablaze after explosion-like sounds were reportedly heard from baggage compartments above the seventh-ninth row of seats in the main passenger cabin. The plane skidded off the runway and black smoke belching from the plane's fuselage.
The plane had made a scheduled flight from Taipei to the eastern resort city of Hualien. It took off from Taipei's Sungshan Airport at 12:16 and landed at Hualien Airport at around 12:40.

The Hualien Airport was closed after the mishap and will not reopen after evidence concerning the incident has been collected and the plane is towed away. Chang said further investigations are needed before the true causes of the mishap can be determined.
UNI Airlines is a wholly-own subsidiary of Taiwan's Evergreen Group, which operates the world's largest container fleet.
The incident came two days after a China Airlines (CAL) MD-11 crash-landed in Hong Kong during a typhoon. Two people were killed and more than 200 injured in the CAL plane crash.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO PROVIDE FULL INFORMATION FOR GLOBAL INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Scholars in a seminar suggested on Tuesday that the government provide more comprehensive information to help Taiwan businessmen invest globally.
The scholars made the comments in a weekly seminar on China policy sponsored by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). The seminar was presided over by DPP Secretary-General You Hsi-kun.

Professor Lin Juo-yu of Tamkang University said that though there is advocacy of Taiwan businessmen investing westward or southward, Taiwan businessmen should make their own judgments on where to invest.

She noted that Taiwan businessmen have invested more than US$40 billion in mainland China over the past two decades. Though Taiwan now ranks as one of the top three sources of foreign capital in mainland China, it still cannot be considered as playing a crucial role in the mainland's capital market.

Other scholars voiced concern about the mainland currency, the renminbi, saying that mainland China's economy has been seriously damaged by financial storms that have been sweeping through the region since mid-1997.

Professor Wei Ai of National Chengchi University said that since mainland China launched economic reforms in 1978, economic development in the mainland has been moving rapidly. Economic reforms have brought about an increase in income for its people, the booming development of its rural regions and an expansion in foreign trade, which has contributed greatly to its increased economic might.
But Wei said that on the other hand, its economic reforms have also highlighted the poor efficiency of its state-owned enterprises, its unbalanced regional development and problems with inflation.

Fan Ching-ming of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research noted that investors withdrew nearly US$100 billion from Southeast Asia between 1997 and 1998, which dealt a serious blow to the economic development of the region. At the same time, he said, mainland China did not devalue its currency.

Fan said that the mainland Chinese leadership misjudged the seriousness of the crisis, believing it be only a short-term one. Its insistence on not devaluing its currency has resulted in a large decline in its exports to Southeast Asia, which traditionally accounts for about 40 percent of mainland China's exports.
Whether Beijing can continue to prop up the renminbi remains to be seen, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND TROOPS SLOWING DOWN ACTIVITIES: MND

TEXT.P: Affected by Typhoon Sam, military troops in mainland China have slowed down training activities over the past week, Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding said on Tuesday.

Due to the influence of Typhoon Sam, Kung said in a regular news briefing, mainland China's troops have taken special anti-typhoon measures, but the measures pose no threat to Taiwan's national security.

During the period from Aug. 17-24, exercises conducted by mainland Chinese ground troops and its Navy were limited to routine training, while the mainland Chinese Air Force has not demonstrated any unusual activities, and it is evident that fewer missions are being flown by mainland fighters.

Stressing that the ROC armed forces will maintain their combat readiness and remain on high alert to safeguard Taiwan, Kung called on the public to stay calm and assured it that ROC troops are ready to counter any situation across the Taiwan Strait.

The MND will continue monitoring movements by mainland Chinese troops and will explain the latest cross-strait situation to the public at appropriate times as part of its efforts to stem the spread of groundless rumors, Kung pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR AT 21-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar continued its upward momentum on Tuesday, closing NT$0.001 higher against the US dollar at NT$31.882, a 21-month high.
The local currency opened at 31.881, the day's high and had a low of 31.923.
Interbank transactions totaled US$374 million.

The NT dollar was relatively weak against the greenback at one point in Tuesday's trading session due to the weakness of the Taiwan bourse. The currency regained its strength near closing after "hands-on" buying by the Central Bank of China, which was apparently trying to maintain the NT dollar's momentum.
Tuesday's closing marked the ninth consecutive daily rise by the NT dollar against the US dollar, and over the past nine days the NT dollar has risen NT$0.249 against the greenback.

Foreign exchange dealers speculated that there is still room for the NT dollar to appreciate further against the greenback in the near future, given that Taiwan's financial strength is basically healthy and that the US dollar may turn flat again.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS DEMANDS PREMIER STEP DOWN OVER CAL CRASH

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday called for the resignations of the premier and the transportation minister in the wake of a China Airlines (CAL) jet crash Sunday.

Flight CI-642, a CAL MD-11 jet, was carrying 300 passengers and 15 crew from Bangkok to Hong Kong Sunday night when it crash-landed at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok International Airport during Tropical Storm Sam. As it was landing, the plane flipped over and caught fire, killing two passengers and injuring 212 others.

Following Monday's censure of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) for dereliction of its supervisory duty, the DPP legislative caucus on Tuesday held a news conference in which it called on Premier Vincent Siew and Transportation Minister Lin Fong-cheng to step down.

Chen Chi-mai, head of the DPP caucus, told the press that in view of the fact that MOTC and CAL officials did not act properly in the aftermath of the accident, which in turn damaged the image of Taiwan, it is necessary for those at a higher level to take responsibility for the incident.

Lin, who pledged to address the flight safety issue when he took office, has not done anything concrete to improve CAL's flight safety, Chen said. In addition, the CAL foundation remains in limbo, being neither a private nor a state-owned operation, Chen said.

Chen's remarks were echoed by DPP lawmaker Wang Tuo, who pointed out that the MOTC's Lin had vowed to resign if he could not improve the flight safety of the island's airlines. Therefore, the DPP's demand is merely that Lin keep the promise he has made.

Chen Chao-nan, deputy convener of the DPP's legislative caucus, disclosed that Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the MOTC, told the caucus Monday that the CAA reported to the Executive Yuan long, long ago that its flight safety team was seriously understaffed; however, the issue has never been regarded as important.

The CAA official's comments highlight the fact that the premier and the transportation minister have ignored completely the flight safety issue. Therefore, they are not free from blame and must step down, stressed the DPP's deputy convener.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SCHOOLCHILDREN DONATE STATIONERY TO AFRICAN KIDS

TEXT.P: Schoolchildren from around Taiwan have donated 320 cases of stationery as gifts to their counterparts in five African countries.
The stationery were presented to Liberian and Chad ambassadors to the Republic of China in a ceremony presided over by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The recipient countries will also include Sao Tome and Principe, Malawi and Botswana. Except for Botswana, the four other recipient countries all maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.
The stationery donation program was initiated by the privately owned Guinness World of Records Museum in Taichung, central Taiwan.

The museum originally collected stationery donated by local schoolchildren as gifts for children of the two-toed tribe in Botswana, southern Africa. As local schoolchildren have responded enthusiastically to the drive, the museum decided to present excess stationery to the ROC's four African allies.
Vice Foreign Minister Lee said at the presentation ceremony that the program signifies the private sector's zeal to help promote pragmatic diplomacy and win more friendship from around the world.

Nine cases of stationery will be brought to Botswana in September by a pair of two-toed sisters from that country. The two sisters -- Nkhuhlani Matukola and Mokhuhlane Georginah -- have been on a six-month visit to Taiwan since March at the invitation of the Guinness World of Records Museum in Taichung.
The remaining stationery will also be sent to Malawi, Chad, Sao Tome and Principe, and Liberia to help upgrade elementary educational quality in those countries.
The stationery include pencils, erasers, crayons, schoolbags, notebooks, pencil cases and other related articles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME SPENT IN MILITARY SCHOOL CAN COUNT TOWARD MILITARY SERVICE TERM

TEXT.P: For the sake of fairness and the protection of the interests of those who perform voluntary military service, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday that part of the time spent in military schools can be counted toward a person's military service term.

The policy ruling went into effect Aug. 3, and those who retired from the army after June 5, 1998, can apply for a certificate recognizing time spent in military schools. Some 100,000 people are expected to benefit from this policy.

During a routine MND press conference, MND spokesman Major Gen. Kong Fan-ding pointed out that the Council of Grand Justices had ruled in 1998 that voluntary military service can be counted as part of officers' total service terms.
This ruling can directly affect the amount of one's pension and the age at which a person may retire.

To further protect the interests of career army officers who have performed voluntary service, the MND has ruled that part of the time spent in military schools can be counted toward a person's total service term as well, which may enable some soldiers to retire earlier, Kong said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOEMAKERS ACCUSE DUMPING OF CHEAP MAINLAND IMPORTS

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan shoemakers on Tuesday blasted the government for its alleged lax attitude toward cracking down on dumping and smuggling of cheap footwear from mainland China.
The shoemakers voiced their strong protests at a public hearing hosted by Legislator Chen Hung-chi (KMT-Taipei) on illegal entry of mainland Chinese footwear.

Local shoemakers said although the government still bans imports of mainland Chinese footwear, a large quantity of cheap mainland-made shoes have made inroads into Taiwan through smuggling or indirect imports via Hong Kong, Macau and the Philippines with false certificates of origin.

Statistics compiled by local shoemakers associations show that footwear imports from Hong Kong, Macau and the Philippines have increased by an annual rate of 30 percent. A large portion of footwear imports from these areas are believed to have originated in mainland China.

In 1998, shoe imports from Hong Kong, Macau and the Philippines exceeded 7 million pairs, and the number reached more than 4.5 million pairs in the first half of this year. The total import value, however, declined from the same period of last year, indicating that mainland footwear has been sold under fair market value here.
Local shoemakers claimed that the influx of cheap mainland footwear has seized 60 percent of Taiwan's shoe market and forced many legally operated local companies to go bankrupt or cease operations.

Worse yet, shoemakers said a large number of cheap mainland footwear have also been sumggled into Taiwan via the offshore frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, which lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.

Shoemakers said local government authorities have never taken effective measures to curb smuggling or dumping of mainland footwear. "We hope this phenomenon can be imporved immediately and effectively. Otherwise, we'll stage further demonstrations to pressure the govenrment to respond to our demand," said Chao Chien-ho, president of the Taipei County Footwear Industry Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND MUM ON REPORTED PASSAGE OF KITTY HAWK AIRCRAFT CARRIER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Tuesday declined to comment on a press report that the US aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk will sail through the Taiwan Strait in the next few days.
"We have no knowledge about the report and cannot make any comment on such a report," said military spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding.

Nevertheless, Kung said any foreign country whose warships or military aircraft plan to pass the Republic of China's territorial waters or airspace must obtain the ROC government's approval in advance.

Kung told CNA that 84 US warplanes flew past the ROC's flight information zone last year. "And the number US military planes that flew over our flight information zone so far this year was 28," Kung said, adding that the United States had consistently applied for the ROC's approval.
In consideration of long-term friendship between the two countries, Kung said, the ROC had approved all those applications after inspecting their flight paths and time schedules.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AVIATION EXPERTS JOIN INVESTIGATION INTO CAL CRASH

TEXT.P: Five members of Taiwan's aeronautic safety commission and several China Airlines (CAL) representatives arrived in Hong Kong on Tuesday to join a task force formed by Hong Kong's civil aeronautics authorities to investigate Sunday's CAL crash.
The Hong Kong government has also invited local aviation experts, as well as experts from the United States and Britain, to participate in the investigation.

Two people were killed when a CAL MD-11 passenger plane en route from Bangkok to Hong Kong crash-landed and overturned at Chek Lap Kok airport on Sunday. Over 200 of the 315 passengers and crew aboard were injured, with six victims remaining in serious condition.
The task force on Tuesday was recovering the aircraft's black box from the aircraft wreckage in order to send the device to Britain for analysis.

Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Deputy Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said in Taipei that according to a report from Liu Cheng-hsi, the co-pilot of the stricken plane, he had given the pilot, Gerardo Lettich of Italy, faulty information about wind speed during preparations for landing.

Strong wind shear caused the jetliner to flip upside down and burst into flames after its right wing clipped the runway upon landing at the height of a typhoon which swept the former British colony over the weekend.

Liu's report said he had told Lettich that the wind was blowing at 42 kilometers per hour, when in fact it was blowing at 48 kilometers per hour, although Chang said the final analysis will not be possible until the black box has been decoded.

Meanwhile, Taipei's representative to Hong Kong Chen An-kuo visited the crash victims who were still in hospital on Tuesday to extend grave condolences on behalf of Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LIMITS LEGAL SERVICE TO FALUN GONG DEFENDANTS

TEXT.P: The Justice Bureau of the Beijing Municipal People's Government has issued a circular telling lawyers to get official permission before they take up the responsibility to provide legal service to Falun Gong defendants, a human rights group said here Tuesday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said the circular also tells lawyers in Beijing to observe central government positions when they provide legal advice to Falun Gong defendants.

The mainland Chinese government has issued a circular saying that core members of the Falun Gong spiritual movement "must be punished in accordance with the law," the Xinhua News Agency of Beijing reported Tuesday. But it did not say how many of them will be prosecuted.
The government outlawed the Falun Gong organization on July 22, accusing it of spreading superstition, disturbing public order, and pursuing an alleged political agenda.

The information center also said that the mainland Chinese government has told law courts throughout the country not to make legal decisions on cases involving Falun Gong members before receiving instructions from the central government.

The government has detained thousands of Falun Gong members since more than 10,000 members of the organization staged an enormous demonstration around the Zhongnanhai leadership compound in central Beijing on April 25. Some 50 leaders of the organization are still kept in detention, the information center said, adding that some of them may be prosecuted soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FACING RISING UNEMPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has entered an era of high unemployment as a result of an imbalance between supply and demand in the job market, according to the domestic human resources sector.

The "104 human resources databank," a well-known executive search website, said the failure to transform the low-skilled workforce and the delinkage between the education sector and the job market were the prime factors behind the phenomenon.
Statistics compiled by the site show that there were an average of 20,851 job opportunities in July, up 3.2 percent from the June level.

The sectors which provided higher numbers of job opportunities last month included computer peripherals, electronic components, foreign trade, semiconductors, computer software, the Internet, and chemical and plastics industries, according to the statistics.

At the same time, the electronic components, chemical and plastics, foreign trade, food and beverage, computer systems, nursing, tourism, insurance, and semiconductor industries were among the leading 10 sectors which posted the largest increase in new jobs in July, the same tallies show.

Meanwhile, plastic injection technicians, computer hardware and software developers, IC engineers, product designers, and editors of technical manuals were among the most sought-after professional talent in the July job market, while flight attendants, singers, factory outworkers, bakers, radio hosts, teachers and actors faced the greatest competition for jobs.

However, the numbers of job seekers registered in the previous two months have declined in August, an indication that some job seekers have joined the workforce this month, according to the head-hunting resource.

Statistics recently released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that Taiwan's July jobless rate hit a 14-year high of 3.11 percent, representing 302,000 unemployed persons.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES NICARAGUAN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday received Nicaraguan Minister of Education, Culture and Physical Education Jose Antonio Alvarado Correa at the Presidential Office.
Lee expressed the hope that Alvarado's visit will help the promotion of educational and cultural exchanges between the two countries.

During the meeting, Alvarado indicated his support for Lee's recent redefinition of Taiwan-mainland China relations as a "special state-to-state relationship," praising the statement as "forward-looking."

Lee told his visitor that as head of state, he must point out that Taiwan's relationship with mainland China is not a relationship between a central government and a local government, nor an internal issue, but a "special state-to-state relationship."

He said that rational cross-Taiwan Strait interactions have been stalled because of Beijing's "hegemonic posture," and added: "If we fail to present our position clearly, we can be easily driven into a corner."
Lee said his statement was intended to gain an equal footing with Beijing for future negotiations, and did not signal any change of Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN CONTAINER VESSEL HIT BY PASSENGER SHIP IN ENGLISH CHANNEL

TEXT.P: A Panamanian-flagged container ship owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp. was hit by a cruise ship on Tuesday in the English Channel, resulting in injuries to three people aboard the cruise ship, an Evergreen spokesman said.
The collision occurred at 8:50 a.m. local time, as the vessel, the Ever Decent, was making for the Belgian port of Zeebrugge from Britain.
The three injured people aboard the Bahamas-registered passenger ship which struck the Ever Decent a glancing blow on its port side were transported by helicopter for medical treatment.

None of the 16-member crew aboard the Ever Decent were hurt, but two containers were damaged, the spokesman said, adding that the vessel's oil tank was not damaged, and that no pollution will be spilled into the sea.
The 55,604 deadweight ton Ever Decent has been plying Evergreen's round-the-world westbound route since its launch in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPLOSIVE DEVICE BLAMED AS CAUSE OF UNI FIRE

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-chang on Tuesday confirmed suspicions that a fire which broke out aboard a domestic UNI Air passenger jet as it was landing at Hualien airport in eastern Taiwan was caused by an explosive device.
The incident, which occurred at around 12:40 p.m. on Tuesday, resulted in 28 passengers being injured, with most of the casualties sustaining burns.
Officials from the Cabinet-level Aviation Safety Council (ASC) had earlier ruled out mechanical failure or pilot error as factors behind the accident.

Judging from a large hole on the fuselage of the MD-90 plane, and the way in which the steel skin of the fuselage around the hole had burst outward, an explosive was deemed to be to have been the most likely cause of the damage, said ASC officials.

According to passengers who witnessed the accident, the sound of an explosion was heard before an overhead baggage compartment near the seventh or eighth line of seats was engulfed in flames, with small pieces of debris flying all over the inside of the plane.
Passengers sitting near the source of the blast had their hair set on fire while the airplane was still taxiing to a halt on the runway, according to the witnesses.
The crew of the stricken jet managed to help all 90 passengers escape from four emergency exits in just a few minutes.

As of Tuesday evening, 20 of the injured remained hospitalized. Of them, five were in intensive care with massive burns. According to hospital authorities, two passengers who suffered burns over more than 60 percent of their bodies were in critical condition.
Lin, who rushed to the scene around 2 p.m., said at a press conference in the evening that it was still not known what type of explosive was used or how it was brought aboard.
The accident came just two days after the crash landing of a China Airlines MD-11 at the height of typhoon Sam in Hong Kong on Sunday that killed two passengers and injured 211.
Lin said he will make a decision within the next few days on whether to step down as a way to take political responsibility for the spate of air accidents among Taiwan carriers .

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ESPOUSES `YOUNG TAIWAN, VIGOROUS GOVERNMENT' AS CAMPAIGN THEME

TEXT.P: "Young Taiwan, Vigorous Government" has been named as the main campaign theme of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for the 2000 presidential election, a DPP stalwart said on Tuesday.

Chiou Yi-jen, who is the top aide responsible for assisting DPP presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian in his run for the presidency, stressed that the reconstruction of national systems through constitutional amendment will be high on his party's agenda over the next 10 to 20 years.
In order to strengthen the confidence of the party's existing supporters, the DPP will hold a series of campaign rallies from Saturday to tour the campaign theme.
Chiou interpreted the term "vigorous government" from three aspects -- the spirit of the government, the structure of the government and the action of the government.

Referring to the spirit of the government, he noted that many government officials appear unaware that their function is to serve the public. A vigorous government is one that possesses the spirit of being willing to take the initiate to provide the public with the best possible service, he said.

Explaining the structure of the government, he slammed the swollen current central government structure and reiterated the DPP's consistent intention to condense the five branches of the central government to three, along with promoting parliamentary reforms, judicial independence and the redemarcation of administrative areas.

With regard to the action of the government, Chiou hit out at the ruling Kuomintang for its abuse of administrative resources, and the serious involvement of gangsterism and "black money" in politics.
As for "young Taiwan," he noted that this goal will be achieved once Taiwan's new vitality is formed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TRYING TO ARRANGE MEETING BETWEEN US PRESIDENT, ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Taipei is trying to arrange a meeting between US President Bill Clinton and Republic of China Presidential Envoy P.K. Chiang, according to sources from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Such a meeting would take place during the upcoming informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Auckland, New Zealand, on Aug. 12-13, the sources said.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is trying to arrange the private talks between Clinton and CEPD Chairman Chiang, President Lee Teng-hui's special envoy who will represent Taiwan at the APEC leaders summit.

MOFA is attaching great importance to the hoped-for meeting, as it would be the first high-level exchange of opinion between US and Taiwan officials since Lee redefined cross Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state" relationship in July, the CEPD officials said.
Lee's statehood assertions have incurred Beijing's wrath, and have caused jitters in Washington.

Meanwhile, Lin Chung-ping, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan's highest government agency responsible for charting the country's mainland China policies, said a summit meeting between Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin could serve as a crucial sounding board for Beijing's latest attitude toward Taipei in light of Lee's statehood assertions.

Lin stressed that Taipei is still enthusiastically preparing to welcome Wang Daohan, Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan, who is scheduled to visit the island this autumn. He noted, however, that Taipei is also prepared for the possibility that Wang's proposed visit might be canceled by Beijing once and for all.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER GOVERNOR DISPUTES POSSIBILITY OF RUNNING ON KMT TICKET

TEXT.P: Accusing the ruling Kuomintang of contradicting itself, independent presidential hopeful James Soong pointedly denied newspaper reports on Tuesday that the KMT is still trying to recruit him as the party's candidate for vice president in the 2000 presidential election.
In a hastily called press briefing, Soong dismissed as "a political gambit" alleged KMT efforts to persuade him to run on the KMT ticket as the party's vice presidential candidate.

The United Daily News ran a story on its front page on Tuesday that KMT is still trying to woo Soong to run as Lien's running mate, and that Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and former Kaohsiung City Mayor Wu Den-yi were the mediators spearheading the eleventh hour efforts.

Ma was reticent on Tuesday about his role in attempting to broker the Lien-Soong partnership which is considered to be a sure-win ticket in the 2000 presidential election, saying that he would spare no effort to consolidate KMT solidarity.
Wu could not be reached for comment.

The former Taiwan provincial governor and KMT secretary-general stressed that his entry into the presidential race is in order to seek a chance to fully realize a "democracy for all the people" rather than to seek personal gains, and that he will not stop his campaign for anything less than that, much less an offer to award him a slot on the KMT ticket.

He admitted that KMT Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met with him on Monday in order to urge him to meet with Vice President Lien Chan, the KMT presidential candidate, in an apparent effort to broker a partnership between Lien and Soong.

However, Soong said that he would rather not see Lien before the KMT approves Lien's choice of running mate, an event which is expected to take place at an extraordinary KMT meeting on Friday, to avoid the perception that he is trying to seek the chance to be Lien's running mate.

As for former KMT Kaohsiung City Mayor Wu Den-yi, who has reportedly met with Soong more than twenty times, also in a bid to recruit him as Lien's running mate, Soong said they only met about twice and the question was never raised.
Soong said the KMT leadership have already ruined any chance of a Lien-Soong partnership in the presidential race by their mudslinging campaign against him.

Quoting an unnamed KMT leader who chided him as "a selfish politician oblivious to loyalty and gratuity," Soong asked, tongue in cheek: "Why would they name such a mean guy to stand up for them in the presidential race?"

Noting Lien's exhibition at a recent campaign rally when he applauded enthusiastically after a well-known entertainer derided Soong as a "traitor" for helping President Lee Teng-hui oust legislators and national assemblymen elected before the ROC relocated to Taiwan, Soong said Lien owes him an explanation for the display of name-calling before talking about any partnership.
Soong boasted of the mass support he enjoys among the grassroots, and reiterated his statement of July 16, when he announced his candidacy, that he will never back down on his presidential bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SALVADORAN AMBASSADOR TO ROC PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: New Salvadoran Ambassador to the Republic of China Francisco Ricardo Santana presented his credentials to Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Tuesday.

Hu extended his cordial welcome to Santana's second visit to the ROC. He also lauded Santana for his outstanding contributions to the promotion of ROC-El Salvador relations during an earlier tenure in the same post.
Santana served as Salvadoran ambassador to the ROC from 1985 until 1991.

Born in 1954, Santana studied Chinese at the Chinese language and literary center at National Taiwan Normal University from 1982 through 1984 and also studied at the research institute of industrial and commercial administration of the same university from 1983 through 1984.
Santana, who is married to a Chinese woman, has a good command of mandarin Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL SEES NO US PRESSURE OVER CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin on Tuesday refused to confirm whether the US government has dispatched a delegation to Taiwan.
But he said that if such a delegation were to visit Taipei, it would not be for the purpose of putting pressure on Taiwan over the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
It is understood that a US official delegation has arrived in Taipei to discuss security issues, but its level is though to be not as high as reported by some local newspapers.

Since President Lee Teng-hui redefined Taiwan-mainland China ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" on July 9, Beijing has been pressing Lee to retract his statement, and the international community has been following the situation closely.

According to Lin, the reactions to Lee's statement from the international community have now become more favorable than before, and the US government has reiterated its policy of seeking a resolution of cross-strait issues through peaceful means.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERAL LEGISLATORS PLEDGE SUPPORT FOR FORMER GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: A dozen legislators are set to declare their support for former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong's bid for the presidency of the Republic of China.

The group of legislators from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the small opposition Democratic Alliance, led by Kuomintang legislators Liu Wen-hsiung, Chou Hsi-wei, Hsieh Chang-chih and Chen Chao-jung, blamed KMT and the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party for having been obsessed with partisan bickering, and praised Soong as a reformer who really puts the people's interest ahead of anything else.
In a draft statement, the group of legislators said they support Soong's presidential bid because they share Soong's political vision for the country.

Asserting that they are not seeking any personal gains in return of their support, the signatories said they will promise to reject any offer of public office or personal gain from Soong if he is elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENT VISITS AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Wei Jingsheng, dubbed the "father of the Chinese dissident movement," on Tuesday arrived in Australia for the first time since he was allowed to go to the United States in late 1997.

In an exclusive interview with CNA on Tuesday night, Wei said he will take the opportunity to make friends with Australian government officials and politicians and academics so that they will better understand the goal of the Federation for a Democratic China (FFDC) movement.

"We hope that the Australian government and MPs can help all the Chinese people and not the Chinese communist government, so that China can one day become a democratic country like Australia," he said.
At the invitation of the prestigious Sydney Institute, Wei will give a speech titled "Human Rights and Democratization in China" on Wednesday, and will also meet scholars and China experts.
He will also meet with Chinese immigrants from Taiwan, mainland China and other countries on August 26, also in Sydney.
The FFDC was founded in Paris about nine years ago and has a number of branches in Australia and other Western countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADERS CHALLENGE APEC LEADERS TO SPEED UP

TEXT.P: In a frank and challenging report, business leaders from Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum countries say individual member economies are not moving fast enough to achieve their deadlines for free and open trade and investment.

The APEC Business Advisory Council (ABAC) report to the APEC Chair, New Zealand's Prime Minister Jenny Shipley, which was made public on Tuesday, sets down the directions the Asia-Pacific business community believes APEC must follow, and includes a series of specific recommendations.
ABAC Chair, New Zealand's Philip Burdon said in the report that APEC has achieved a great deal in the past ten years.

"APEC has become a major force for economic reform and growth, having put in place far-reaching programs for trade liberalization, economic and technical cooperation between members, and the removal of red tape and unnecessary costs to business," Burdon said.
"But like all processes which move by consensus and which are subject to the pressures of domestic politics, APEC has at times lost sight of its own goals," he continued.

The report challenges APEC leaders to work more vigorously to achieve their agreed free trade and investment goals by 2010 for developed economies and 2020 for developing economies. It also calls on APEC leaders to work together in the World Trade Organization to achieve comprehensive multilateral trade liberalization.

The report also says that APEC members need to reduce tariffs further, but emphasizes that non-tariff measures -- such as streamlining customs procedures -- are an equally significant impediment to trade which needs to be addressed.

The report offers a number of proposals for economic and financial restructuring in order to equip economies for more open markets, and to assist with recovery and renewed growth in the wake of the Asian regional crisis.
ABAC members from around the region will be meeting with APEC leaders in Auckland, New Zealand, next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Vice President Lien Chan invited former Taiwan Governor James Soong for meeting on Kuomintang intra-party unity.
The China Times:
Explosion cited in UNI Air jet fire on Hualien Airport runway.
The United Daily News:
Twenty-eight passengers injured in UNI Air jet fire at Hualien Airport.
The Liberty Times:
A UNI Air MD-90 jet caught fire as it was landing at Hualien Airport, leaving 28 passengers injured.
The Commons Daily:
Former Taiwan Governor James Soong rejected Vice President Lien's invitation for discussion on KMT unity.
The China Post:
UNI Airways flight explodes in flames; twenty-eight injured.
The Taiwan News:
UNI Air jet fire injures 28 aboard.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN CONTAINER SHIP FIRE UNDER CONTROL, UK RESCUE CREW STANDS BY
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The fire that broke out on an Evergreen Marine Corp. container ship, Ever Decent, after a collision with the Bahamas-registered cruise liner Norwegian Dream in the English Channel on Tuesday has been put under control, according to an Evergreen spokesman.

Earlier worries that the fire might cause the explosion of containers on board Ever Decent carrying hazardous chemicals -- thus unleashing a biological disaster on the surrounding area -- were dispelled as it was determined that the 46 containers carrying such chemicals were not located near the fire, which has already been extinguished, said the spokesman.
Crew members of Ever Decent decided not to evacuate the ship, saying that they would stay to help out with fire control and other tasks.

British Coast Guard authorities said their rescue operations are underway, with helicopters hovering above the container ship. The rescue force will remain on standby in case there are further emergencies on the ship, which was still taking on water, they added.

The 55,604-deadweight-ton Ever Decent, with 3,092 containers on board, was making for the Belgian port of Zeebrugge from Britain's Thamesport when it collided with the 50,764-gross-ton Norwegian Dream, which was carrying about 2,400 passengers.

Describing the collision as only a glancing blow, the Evergreen spokesman declined to comment on how the collision occurred. He said further details would be released once British authorities compiled an accident report.

The three people aboard the Norwegian Dream injured in the collision were earlier transported by helicopter to England for medical treatment. The cruise liner limped into the English port of Dover about six hours after the collision, which spilled several Evergreen containers onto the liner's deck.
British Coast Guard officials gave no clues to the cause of the accident, saying winds were light and visibility good.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING NOT TO TOUCH ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES DURING APEC

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait have agreed not to touch on their bilateral fracas during the upcoming meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a noted local economist said on Wednesday.

Wu Jung-yi, head of the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research, said the Republic of China has reached a consensus with mainland China through mediation of New Zealand, the host country of the 1999 APEC events, on avoiding mentioning cross-strait issues under the APEC framework.

Wu, an adviser to the APEC Business Advisory Council (ABAC), has been invited to attend the 1999 ABAC summit meeting, which refers to an annual rendezvous between senior business executives and top leaders from all APEC member economies.

The annual APEC extravaganza will kick off in New Zealand's largest city of Auckland on Sept. 9, with a senior officials meeting and a ministerial-level conference. An informal leadership meeting will also be held from Sept. 12-13.

Both Taiwan and mainland China are APEC members. They have been at loggerheads since ROC President Lee Teng-hui told a German radio interviewer on July 9 that cross-Taiwan Strait ties should be defined as a "special state-to-state relationship." Lee's declaration just affirms political reality. Beijing, however, regards it as a dangerous move to promote Taiwan independence.

In an effort to ensure smooth proceeding of annual APEC gatherings in an amicable atmosphere, Wu said the New Zealand government has taken the initiative to mediate an agreement between Taipei and Beijing to avoid raising their bilateral issues during the upcoming APEC meetings.

Nevertheless, Wu said if international news media raised questions about the "special state-to-state relationship" theory or other cross-strait disputes during a press conference to be held after the APEC ministerial-level meeting, ROC officials are still likely to answer those inquiries.

The ROC delegation to the APEC ministerial-level conference will be led by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Finance Minister Paul Chiu. And P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, will attend the APEC leadership meeting on behalf of President Lee. The ROC head of state has been barred from the annual APEC summit meeting because of Beijing's opposition. Lee instead has to name a surrogate to attend the summit meeting on his behalf.
APEC is a 21-member regional economic cooperation forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMIC GROWTH LIKELY TO BE ADJUSTED UPWARD AGAIN: THINK-TANK

TEXT.P: Positive indicators have led to the conclusion that Taiwan's economy is expected to improve even more in the second half of this year than it did in the first half, the head of a private economic think-tank said on Wednesday.

The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) will have to make a further upward adjustment to its forecast for the island's economic prospects for the second half of the year if the overall economic upswing continues, said Wu Rong-I, TIER president.

In July, TIER adjusted its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth for 1999 from 5.28 percent to 5.34 percent after all economic indicators, including domestic investment, export business and the stock market, showed positive growth.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics also revised this year's annual growth upward this month to 5.74 percent, showing much higher confidence in Taiwan's economic prospects than does TIER, Wu noted.
If the upswing continues and cross-Taiwan Strait relations do not sour further in the remaining months of the year, Wu said, TIER is likely to adjust its forecast again in November.

According to TIER tallies, the July index of leading indicators, which is designed to forecast economic prospects three to six months in advance, rose to 106.71 points, the highest level in 22 months.

A monthly TIER survey of domestic manufacturers conducted in early August found that industry executives have become more optimistic about their business prospects in the months ahead, even though they admitted that President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" assertions on cross-strait relations have temporarily shattered their confidence in Taiwan's overall prospects.
Thirty-seven percent of those surveyed forecast that the economy will improve in the next six months, compared with 34.1 percent in the July survey.

Forty-seven percent of the survey respondents believe the economy will remain unchanged, compared with 48.1 percent in the July poll. Only 15.9 percent said the economy will worsen over the next six months, compared with 17.8 percent in the July survey.

Meanwhile, Wu said Taiwan is unlikely to raise interest rates simply because the US Federal Reserve on Tuesday lifted the federal funds rate for overnight loans and discount rate by a quarter-percentage point each.

He said that although Taiwan's currency is facing pressure to further appreciate against the US dollar due to continuously expanding exports and growing inflow of foreign capital, the Central Bank of China will not sit idly by and allow the NT dollar to surge, but will make sure it protects the island's export business.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA FLIGHTS CANCELED DUE TO ENGINE PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Two TransAsia Airways domestic flights were canceled on Wednesday after the planes developed engine problems.
TransAsia canceled flight No. B22805 from southern Chiayi City to Taipei slated to take off at 9 a.m. after the ATR passenger plane was found to have developed engine problems.
A total of 72 travelers were transferred to a UNI Airlines flight at 9:30 a.m. to allow TransAsia to conduct a thorough overhaul of its aircraft.
A ranking TransAsia official said the cancellations were made because flight safety and customer service are the most important issues to the aviation company.
He also asked other passengers for forgiveness and understanding, as flights for the rest of the day were affected because of the incident.

Earlier the same day, another TransAsia flight from eastern Hualien bound for Taipei was also canceled after a similar problem was found by maintenance personnel during a routine pre-flight inspection.
Twenty passengers with seats on flight No. B22715 later traveled on a UNI Airlines flight.

The problem aircraft was grounded for repairs at the Hualien airport, which only reopened at 7 a.m. that day following a 20-hour closure because of an explosion on a UNI Airways passenger plane on Tuesday. Twenty-eight passengers were injured in the blast and ensuing fire.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC SAID TO BE LOSING SIGHT OF ITS GOALS

TEXT.P: The business arm of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum has delivered a withering assessment of the forum's record in lowering regional trade and investment barriers less than three weeks before an annual leaders summit in Auckland, The Australian Financial Review reported on Wednesday.
The daily reported that the criticism was detailed in a report from the 62-member Business Advisory Council. The report was delivered to New Zealand Prime Minister Jenny Shipley.

The council, which includes the chairman of General Motors, Jack Smith of the United States, and Commonwealth Bank Executive Director David Murray of Australia, told the APEC leaders that APEC had "lost sight of its goals" and needed to make "more serious and substantial commitments" to opening markets.

Reflecting growing business frustration with the regional economic forum, the council warned that APEC's self-paced approach to liberalization was not delivering results and lacked transparency, specificity and comprehensiveness.
The APEC leaders summit in Bogor, Indonesia, in 1995 has set a liberalization timetable of 2010 for industrialized economies and 2020 for developing economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: BISHOP BELO CALLS FOR INTERNATIONAL INTERVENTION IN EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: Only international intervention can prevent East Timor from descending into a blood bath after the Aug. 30 vote that will decide the future of the territory, prominent Bishop Carlos Belo has warned.

In an article he wrote for The New York Times on Tuesday and which was published by The Australian on Wednesday, the Nobel laureate called on the United States to withhold military assistance and financial aid from Indonesia until the military stops the violence in the former Portuguese colony.
Belo said a fair ballot would result in a majority vote for independence.
"If not, there would be no need to wage a campaign of violence and coercion to prevent free elections from taking place," he said.

He blamed the deaths of hundreds of East Timorese and the violence in the lead-up to Monday's vote on the Indonesian military, which has helped pro-Jakarta militias intimidate Timorese, particularly supporters of the pro-independence movement.

The Australian also reported that rising militia violence has prevented the independence lobby from putting forward its case in many regions in East Timor, while the autonomy campaign is accelerating its efforts with daily rallies in major centers.

In another report, The Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday reported Australia has now more than 5,000 combat-ready troops to draw on if the United Nations decides to set up an armed peacekeeping force in East Timor.
The report also indicated Foreign Minister Alexander Downer will meet US Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and the Pacific Stanley Roth on Wednesday to discuss the security situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER GROUP ESTABLISHES STRATEGIC TIES WITH CISCO CORP.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Acer Group and the Cisco Corp., the world's largest network manufacturer, jointly announced on Wednesday that they have established a strategic alliance.
Under the terms of the alliance, Acer will build internal computer communication networks using Cisco peripheral equipment, and will help Cisco expand its presence in the Taiwan market.

"Personal computers (PCs) have made Taiwan a household name in the information industry; however, to win a larger share of the PC market, we should combine the functions of PC with those of the Internet. This will enable us to produce better PCs to compete with those of other companies," said Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih.

Cisco will provide Acer with network technology allowing the Taiwan company to produce DVVI (Data, Voice, Video Integration) systems, and help Acer create a no-obstacle Internet environment, said Richard Freemantle, Cisco's regional vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIANS LOVE MOVIES; ATTENDANCE UP FOR SIXTH STRAIGHT YEAR

TEXT.P: Forget about videotapes and TV, Canadians just love to go to the cinemas, and movie attendance hit a 17-year high in 1997-98, according to Statistics Canada.
The federal agency reported Tuesday that attendance at theaters and drive-ins increased by 8 percent to almost 100 million, the sixth straight annual increase in the number of moviegoers.
The rise of the giant mega-theater has helped boost attendance. Statscan said recent openings of very large theaters contributed significantly to the rise in attendance.

But these giants may have hurt their smaller competitors, the report said. Bigger theaters reported a 6-percent jump in patrons, while small theaters -- ranked by revenue -- saw business drop 10 percent and medium-sized theaters were off 23 percent.

The movie house industry earned C$85.8 million (US$58.5 million) in 1997-98, up 31 percent from the previous year. Full-time employment slipped about 2 percent to 1,376 jobs, while part-time employment rose 11 percent, to 9,895.
There were 617 theaters operating during the year in Canada, with 2,186 screens. There were 71 drive-ins with 115 screens.

The drive-in seems to have lost its allure, however. While the number of screens actually increased, admissions fell 5 percent to 2.2 million. It was the third year in a row that attendance has fallen.
Cinemas, on the other hand, recorded 97.7 million admissions, with box office receipts totaling C$490 million and total revenues amounting to C$699.9 million.

The average Canadian went to the movies 3.3 times during the year, although Newfoundlanders tended to go only half that often. People from Alberta were the most avid moviegoers, averaging 4.6 cinema visits per year

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENT RAISES TAIWAN, TIBET AT MEETING WITH AUSTRALIAN FM

TEXT.P: Chinese dissident leader Wei Jingsheng on Wednesday raised the issues of Taiwan, Tibet and human rights when he met Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer in Canberra.

At a press conference at Parliament House, Wei said he hoped the Australian government could play a bigger role in maintaining stability and peace in the Taiwan Strait following the recent tension between Taipei and Beijing because of President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of ties between the two sides as a "special state-to-state relationship."

"If we don't have enough concern over the current tension and conflict in the Taiwan Strait, if war broke out, Australia would be more directly affected than America because Australia is closer to the region," Wei said.
He said Australia would have good opportunity to express that when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin makes his first visit to Australia on Sept. 6.
He said Downer agreed that both Taiwan and mainland China should restrain themselves and seek reconciliation so that the current tensions can be eased.
"Whether Taiwan becomes independent or not is up to the people of Taiwan. I personally do not agree, but I do respect the decision of the people of Taiwan," Wei said.
He said the same of the people of Tibet.

Wei also said he had discussed the Taiwan issue with politicians of the country's ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, and had come to the conclusion "that the issue of Taiwan independence is not important."
"The democratization of China is more important than Taiwan independence. The issue of a democratic China should come before the Taiwan independence issue," he said.
Wei, dubbed the "father of the Chinese dissident movement," is currently making his first visit to Australia to try and drum up support from Australian government officials and politicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO PUMP BILLIONS INTO ARMS: HK NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese leadership has decided to pump billions of yuan into supporting its declining arms industry in a policy change to deal with economic and political problems, the Hong Kong Standard reported on Wednesday.
The report in the English-language daily quoted a China watcher as saying that the decision is a major compromise between the reformist civilian government and the hawkish military.
It is also a major industrial policy adjustment following a decade-old effort to restructure the industry into a civilian-run operation.

In recent high-level meetings, the party and government leadership reached consensus to earmark more funds for arms research and manufacture while increasing the military budget to allow the People's Liberation Army to purchase more hardware, the report revealed.
In an apparent gesture to the armed forces, President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji have in recent months paid visits to several arms manufacturers in Liaoning and Sichuan provinces.

Increasing calls have been made by the military and arms manufacturers for the central government to upgrade military hardware following the US-led NATO attack on Yugoslavia and Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's assertion of the island's statehood, the report quoted mainland sources as saying.

Jiang and Zhu have recently been under political pressure from the party's conservative wing and hawkish military for their enthusiastic efforts to mend ties with the United States and be soft with Taiwan, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPLOSIVE MATERIALS BLAMED FOR UNI AIR JET BLAST

TEXT.P: Taiwan's UNI Airlines vice chairman asserted on Wednesday that Tuesday's explosion and fire aboard one of the company's MD-90 planes which injured 28 people was caused by explosive material brought aboard by a passenger.

Si Chung-ching made the remarks at a Taipei press conference, where he also angrily brushed off an "analysis" by a local professor who claimed, seemingly without any evidence, that the blaze was caused by faulty materials used in the plane's construction.

Although the investigation into the incident has yet to be completed, Si said, it has already been established that no materials capable of producing such a blast were used in the part of the plane where the explosion occurred, and that the source of the explosion must have originated "externally."
He stressed no human or machine error was behind the incident.

Meanwhile, Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Commissioner Chen Ching-sung cited preliminary investigation results as saying that the blaze was caused by an explosion, but he declined to comment on what could have caused the blast.
Chen said that no evidence has been found to suggest an explosive device was responsible, although CIB experts are conducting in-depth examinations of debris collected from the airplane wreckage.

The UNI Air jet with 90 passengers and six crew aboard, landed in flames on Tuesday at the Hualien airport, around 180 kilometers southeast of Taipei, just two days after Sunday's crash landing of a China Airlines MD-11 at the height of typhoon Sam in Hong Kong.
Most of the 28 victims suffered slight or severe burns. As of Wednesday, six of them remained hospitalized in the Hualien-based Tzuchi Buddhist General Hospital, with three in serious condition.

Meanwhile, experts from the Cabinet-level Aviation Safety Council (ASC) began to decode the plane's two flight data recorders, the first time that such work has been attempted in Taiwan rather than at a specialist laboratory overseas.

The ASC opened Asia's first "black box" decoding laboratory on Aug. 10, at a cost of NT$10 million (US$314,000), allowing black box analysis results to be available much more quickly. However, an ASC spokesman refused to say when the UNI results would be released.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI URGED TO DEAL WITH NEW MONGOLIAN SITUATION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mongolian & Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC) has been urged to deal with possible changes in the situation between Taiwan and Mongolia, as Mongolia has set up a new organization to take charge of exchanges with Taiwan.

The "Mongolia-Taiwan Cultural and Trade Association," with influential figures from both the government and private sectors forming the bulk of its members, has recently become operational, according to an MTAC report.

Mongolian Prime Minister personally presided over the organization's opening in the capital, Ulan Bator, the MTAC said, noting that the head of the Mongolian government' endorsement of the body shows that he supports further trade and economic exchanges with Taiwan.

The MTAC report called for greater heed to be paid and active measures to be taken to deal with the issue, as the setting up of the association is set to have a heavy impact on the future of existing two-way exchanges.

Although the political situation in Mongolia is not expected to stabilize until after a general election is held in June 2000, the MTAC report proposed that a systematic mechanism for two-way exchanges be set up quickly to ensure continued exchanges no matter which party takes power in Mongolia in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER CALLS FOR ANNULMENT OF MAC

TEXT.P: A legislator of Taiwan's main opposition party said on Wednesday that the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) should be abolished and replaced by a mainland China department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Tong-jung said the move should be made in light of the new situation in which Taiwan finds itself after President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship."
Tsai, who was promoting his idea at a press conference, said he first raised the issue on July 13, but decided to mention it again "to remind the government of Lee's political advocacy."

The ruling Kuomintang's attitude to Lee's statement has evolved into "selective forgetfulness" from its earlier unanimous support, causing the relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to return to normal as if nothing has happened, Tsai claimed.

According to Tsai, the most pragmatic way to settle the relationship between the two sides would be to adjust the organizations and structures under the Executive Yuan, which is why he suggested dismantling the MAC and forming instead a new "mainland China department" under MOFA. Tsai said he would bring up his proposal at the next legislative session scheduled to open in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1.8 percent higher on Wednesday, rebounding to break the psychological 8,000-point level on strong buying in the technology and plastic and chemical sectors.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price rose 142.70 points to close at 8,127.09, following a 1.7-percent decline in the previous session.
A total of 2.72 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$125.36 billion (US$3.91 billion).

Dealers said the buying in the electronics sector mainly reflected the rosy prospects of the semiconductor industry and the price increases for DRAM (dynamic random access memory) chips which pushed up shares of DRAM makers.

The electronics sector again posted the highest gains among the eight major stock categories, ending the day with a 2.6-percent gain, followed by plastic and chemical issues and the financial shares, which posted gains of 2.5 percent and 0.9 percent, respectively.
Construction shares suffered losses of 0.9 percent despite hot trading during the session. Foodstuff issues as well as cement issues also reported losses of 0.2 percent each.
The over-the-counter market posted a 2.18-point gain, ending the day at 175.48 points.
Meanwhile, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains, except for next June futures, for which no contract transactions were registered.
TAIEX Index Futures for September jumped 229 points to close at 8,230, with 3,643 contract transactions, while those for October rose 217 points to end at 8,247, with 92 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December rose 170 points to close at 8,220, with five contract transactions, and those for next March climbed 180 points to finish at 8,250, with six contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading for Wednesday were 8,001 points for September, 8,030 points for October, 8,050 points for December, 8,070 points for next March and 8,150 points for next June.
Electronics and financial futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported gains.
September TE futures rose 12.4 points to 376, with 1,044 contract transactions; October TE futures climbed 10 points to 375, with six contract transactions.
There were no transactions recorded for TE futures for other months.
September TF futures moved up 46.8 points to 1,173, with 217 contract transactions; December TF futures dropped 42.6 points to 1,082, with one contract transaction.
There were no transactions recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FOREIGN-POLICY EXPERTS CALL FOR DEFENSE OF TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States should declare unambiguously that it will come to Taiwan's defense in the event of an attack or a blockade against the island, said a joint statement released by two American think tanks on Tuesday.

The statement, co-authored by the Heritage Foundation and the Project for the New American Century, was issued amid recent escalation of tension across the Taiwan Strait over the "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
Twenty-three leading US conservatives and foreign-policy experts, including heads of the two Washington-based think tanks, Edwin J. Feulner Jr. and William Kristol, signed the statement.
Other signatories included former US Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger, former Assistant Secretary of State Paul Wolfowitz, and former Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard L. Armitage.
The statement said communist China has continued to threaten military action against the democratically-elected government of Taiwan over the "special state-to-state" fracas.

"It has therefore become essential that the United States make every effort to deter any form of (mainland) Chinese intimidation of the Republic of China on Taiwan and declare unambiguously that it will come to Taiwan's defense in the event of an attack or a blockade against Taiwan, including against the offshore islands of Matsu and Kinmen," the statement said.

It continued that the United States should also make clear that while it is prepared to accept any resolution regarding Taiwan's future status to which both sides voluntarily agree, the future of Taiwan must reflect the will of the people of Taiwan as expressed through their duly elected government.

"If the people of Taiwan do not want to be united with the mainland until China becomes a democracy, the United States has a moral obligation and strategic imperative to honor that determination," the document said.

It warned that efforts by the Clinton administration to pressure Taiwan to cede its sovereignty and to adopt Beijing's understanding of "one China" are dangerous and directly at odds with US strategic interests, past US policy and American democratic ideals.

"Failure to stand by Taiwan and live up to the spirit and letter of the Taiwan Relations Act in the present crisis can only exacerbate tensions and may well lead to serious miscalculation by Beijing," the statement noted.

It further said the time for strategic and moral "ambiguity" with regard to Taiwan has passed. "We urge the administration and leaders in Congress to make a clear statement of America's commitment to the people of Taiwan," the statement said, adding that such a commitment is consonant with US national interests and ideals, and will help ensure peace in East Asia.
