A Heritage Foundation news release issued on the same day also stressed that the Clinton administration and Congress should dispel the uncertainty that has clouded the US position in the weeks since ROC President Lee Teng-hui declared in an interview with a German radio station in July that mainland China and Taiwan should interact on a "state-to-state" basis.
Other former US officials who signed the statement included former Central Intelligence Agency Director R. James Woolsey and former Ambassador to the United Nations Jeane J. Kirkpatrick.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA ADOPTS APPROPRIATE POLICY TOWARD ROC AND MAINLAND: PANAMA FM
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai and Shammy Chao)

TEXT.P: Panamanian Foreign Affairs Minister Jorge Eduardo Ritter said in an interview that the present policy of President Perez Ballabares in dealing with cross-strait ties meets his country's interests: maintaining diplomatic relations with the Republic of China (ROC), and establishing economic and trade cooperation with the People's Republic of China (PRC).

In the interview with a Panamanian TV station, Ritter further pointed out that in view of his country's geographical location and the ROC's efforts to strengthen its diplomatic relations with allies neighboring Panama, a "special relationship" between the two countries is developing.

Ritter visited Taiwan about a month ago and during his meeting with ROC officials, he gained a better understanding of the current cross-strait situation. He hoped Panama's new government will maintain the current China policy.
According to official statistics, exports from Panama to Taiwan in 1998 totaled a record high of US$3.4 million. Panama's major exports to Taiwan include beef, shrimp, leather, fish and handicrafts.
Panama is the only country in Central and South America permitted to export meat to Taiwan, which also imports meat from Australia, New Zealand and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE EXPORTS TO REACH US$20 BILLION BY 2002

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF) on Wednesday announced three goals for the local textile industry in the 21th century -- reaching US$20 billion export volume by 2002, making Taiwan Asia's textile design and manufacturing hub, and maintaining competitiveness.

The goals were announced by TTF Market Promotion Dept. Director Dr. Eric Ying at the "ROC-India Textile Seminar" jointly sponsored by the TTF, the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC), the India-Taipei Association, and the Cotton Textiles Export Promotion Council of India (TEXPROCIL).
Also at the seminar, T. Kannan, Deputy Chairman of TEXPROCIL, pointed out that India's textile and cloth export volume has reached US$10.54 billion, accounting for 3.2 percent of the world total.

India's textile-related output is sent mainly to Asian countries, which account for 37 percent of India's total textile exports, followed by European countries, which account for 31 percent, he said, adding his hope that India and Taiwan can enhance bilateral economic and trade cooperation.

Meanwhile, a CNAIC official noted that in line with the Indian government's policy of encouraging national industrial development, the South Asian country is in urgent need of technical assistance from foreign countries. According to a market survey, India's most promising products include plastics, rubber, textiles, mechanical products, petrochemicals, and processed foods.
In addition, he said, India is making efforts to develop itself into a software research and development hub for the world's leading computer companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN GROUP INCREASES INVESTMENTS IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai and Shammy Chao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based Evergreen Group has expanded its business range in Panama, as it has recently invested US$100 million in the establishment of a Panamanian harbor along with a Hong Kong company and a Panamanian-US joint venture, said sources from Panama's the Interoceanic Region Authority.

In addition to the harbor construction project, an Evergreen housing project is nearly completed and is now being promoted on the market. Meanwhile, preparations are finished for the group's entry into Panama's restaurant industry, with decisions on the interior of its first restaurant to be made soon, according to a commercial.
Moreover, Evergreen plans to bring to Panama several Taiwanese chefs, which is expected to create a new image for Panama's Chinese food restaurants, said the commercial.
It is also said that Evergreen has already bought a large tract of land in the city center of Panama City for the construction of a five-star hotel.

According to data provided by Panama's authority, Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa Group has invested US$170 million in the harbor construction project, while US-venture Manzanillo International Terminal has invested US$220 million in the same project.
In terms of industrial investments, the administration said that the ROC-Panamanian joint-venture Sino-Panameno Co. takes the No. 1 spot, with an investment of US$50 million.

The Panamanian government has also called for foreign businesses to increase their investments in the hospitality industry, adding that Korea's UETG is the front-runner, having invested US$300 million on establishing tourist hotels and exploring sightseeing spots.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 25, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1530: Ivan IV, known as "Ivan the Terrible," the Russian Tsar who executed more than 3,000 people, including the royal heir, is born.
1819: James Watt, English engineer and inventor of the steam engine, dies at the age of 83.
1819: Allan Pinkerton, Scottish-born founder of the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the United States, which specialized in railroad theft, is born.
1270: Louis IX, known as "Saint Louis," the king of France who led the Seventh Crusade against Egypt in 1248, dies in a subsequent crusade to Tunisia at the age of 56.
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-km stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1919: The first scheduled international air service begins between Paris and London.
1921: Germany and the United States sign a peace treaty ending the state of war between them.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year long ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1961: The second phase of the Yangmingshan Forum opens to study the ROC's educational and cultural issues.
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life He fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall He cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION CAUCUSES DEMAND TRANSPORTATION MINISTER'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of two of Taiwan's opposition parties on Wednesday urged that the transportation minister should resign to take responsibility for a series of air traffic incidents within just a couple of days.

The call came in response to an incident in which a UNI Air MD-90 jet caught fire as it was landing at Hualien Airport on Tuesday, just two days after a China Airlines plane crashed at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok International Airport.
A total of 28 people were injured when Flight B7-973 burst into flames as it was taxiing to a stop at the eastern Taiwan airport, according to UNI Air.

Lee Ying-yuan, chief convener of the legislative caucus of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said he doubted the competence of the Aviation Safety Council (ASC) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), and that Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Fong-cheng should take responsibility.

DPP lawmaker Wang Tuo said he was also disappointed with Lin's performance. He pointed out that Lin pledged to address the flight safety issue when he took office. However, Wang claimed, he has not done anything concrete to boost flight safety.
Furthermore, the transportation minister had vowed to resign if he could not improve the flight safety of the island's airlines, Wang pointed out, adding that he hoped Lin will keep his promise.

In addition, Wang said, the ASC should be placed directly under the Executive Yuan, rather than remaining under the control of the MOTC, so that it can operate independently and be free from administrative intervention.

Meanwhile, Lai Hse-bao, a lawmaker from the tiny opposition New Party, said at a news conference that the flight safety team of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) is seriously understaffed, with just 38 personnel made up of either retired air force officers or workers receiving a period of flight safety supervisory training. He pointed out that none of them have any form of internationally recognized flight safety supervisory license.
Lai said that the head of the MOTC should not be free from blame and should step down, along with the director-general of the CAA.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL BARRED FROM TAKING PART IN FLIGHT ALLOCATIONS FOR ONE YEAR

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) will not be considered for the next one year when the Civil Aviation Administration (CAA) distributes flight allocations, CAL Director-General Chang Yu-hern said on Wednesday.

The decision was made in the wake of CAL's latest air accident when one of its MD-11 jetliners crashed in flames and flipped upside down in Hong Kong on Sunday, miraculously leaving just two dead and 211 injured.
Chang said that CAL had asked to be allowed to increase the number of its flights on the Taipei-Bangkok-Amsterdam route, but that the request was rejected by the CAA.
Analysts said that if costs are calculated based on four flights by B747-400 jetliners every week, the decision will cost CAL NT$2 billion (US$62.11 million) a year.

CAL, the country's leading airline and former flag-carrier, has been tainted by its poor safety record in recent years. Its last fatal crash occurred on Feb. 16, 1998, when another of its planes crashed near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, killing 196 passengers and crew members as well as six other people on the ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC POLICY ADVISER TO DISCUSS CROSS-STRAIT TIES WITH US OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A national policy adviser to Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will attend a closed-door seminar on relations across the Taiwan Strait with US officials in New York later this week.

Tien Hung-mao, director of the Institute for National Policy Research, a Taipei-based private think tank, told CNA after his arrival in San Francisco that he has been invited by the US Foreign Policy Association to attend the seminar.

Officials from the US Department of State and Department of Defense as well as academics from mainland China will also attend the symposium whose theme is expected to focus on the "special state-to-state relationship" theory declared by President Lee in July.

Tien, a US-trained international affairs scholar, will deliver a speech on the development of cross-strait relations from Taiwan perspective during the seminar. Tien is expected to analyze the Taiwan Strait situation in the past six months in his speech.
In addition to talks during the seminar, Tien said he does not rule out the possibility of holding further talks with American officials in private.
Stressing that he is not an official delegate, Tien said he will only present his personal observations and views during his talks with American officials.

President Lee's declaration on July 9 in an interview with a German radio station that Taiwan-mainland China exchanges should be on a "special state-to-state" basis has drawn furious reaction from Beijing which regards Lee's statement as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

Tien said one major factor prompting Lee to make the declaration was that he felt that the Clinton administration is leaning toward Beijing's so-called "one China" principle which downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under its jurisdiction.
In addition, Tien said, ROC officials have felt pressure from some US officials for opening sensitive political dialogue with mainland China.

Against this background, Tien said President Lee must clarify the status of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "Taiwan cannot start political talks with mainland China under Beijing's 'one China' principle," he noted.

Tien said Beijing need not overreact to the "special state-to-state" theory because it just reflects reality and does not mark a shift in Taiwan's policy and stance toward the mainland. "Moreover, the ROC government has not taken any action to amend its constitution or relevant laws in line with the theory," he added.
Through Taiwan's extensive explanations, Tien said US authorities have come to a better understanding of the ROC's stance and has not pressured it to retract the "special state-to-state" theory.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SOUTH KOREA JOINT VENTURE OPENS IN SEOUL
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Asia Development Corporation, a joint venture of South Korean and Taiwanese businessmen opened in Seoul on Wednesday with a reception.
The opening of the firm, was presided over by Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the ruling Kuomintang party's Business Management Committee.

Liu said the KMT's Yu-tai Industrial Corp. and South Korea's CDIB & MBS each have invested US$1 million in the new company. A Japanese firm and a Hong Kong-based corporation invested an additional US$500,000 each.
Liu also confirmed at the reception that he is exploring the possibility of investing in the cash-strapped Daewood Group, probably by taking over one or more units of the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY & PARAGUAYAN PROVINCE SIGN SISTERHOOD AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung County Government and the Central Province of Paraguay on Wednesday signed a memorandum establishing sisterly county relations.
The memorandum, subject to approval by the Kaohsiung County Council, is meant to strengthen personal and cultural interchanges between the two counties.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien and Martin Federico Sannemann inked the memorandum on behalf of their respective parties. Paraguayan Ambassador to the Republic of China Ceferino Adrian Valdez and representatives from Kaohsiung agricultural, industrial and commercial sectors witnessed the ceremony.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien said that the Central Province of Paraguay will be the seventh sisterhood agreement established with Kaohsiung and is also the first sisterhood agreement with Kaohsiung from the South American region.

Yu said that Kaohsiung County Government was planning to organize a goodwill mission comprised of representatives from the County Industrial Association, County Chamber of Commerce and County Agricultural Association to visit Argentina en route to the Central Province next March.

Sannemann, in return, said that the Central Province will give a warm welcome to the Kaohsiung goodwill mission and hoped that Kaohsiung will purchase the high-quality and less expensive soybean products produced in his province.
In answer to a question raised by an entrepreneur, Sannemann said that the Paraguayan government welcomes ROC investors by providing a seven-year tax exemption as an investment incentive.

Sannemann and his party called on President of the Kaohsiung County Council Hsu Fu-sen. Hsu told his visitors that the memorandum is expected to be approved by the council at an extraordinary session in September.
The Central Province, located in western Paraguay, is an industrial county. The province has a population of 860,000 people. By Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ATHLETE DENIES INVOLVEMENT IN JET BLAST

TEXT.P: A former national decathlete of the Republic of China on Wednesday protested his innocence of any intent to cause harm after being named as the man responsible for Tuesday's explosion and fire on a UNI Airlines jet.
Local reports claimed that Ku Chin-shui had given his nephew a bag containing explosive goods before the latter boarded the MD-90 jet from Taipei to the eastern Taiwan city of Hualien.

Ku's mother, brother, two nephews, and several other relatives were all passengers on the flight, and an investigation showed that the family were sitting near the luggage rack where the explosion occurred.
According to the investigation report, the blast was caused by two bottles of household bleach.

Ku said he was originally scheduled to take the same flight, but canceled the trip for business reasons and assigned his nephew to carry certain items that his mother had ordered him to buy in Taipei.
All the members of the family who made the trip were injured, with Ku's brother, Ku Ching-chi, listed in serious condition with extensive burns.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG ASKS AUSTRALIA TO PRESS CHINA ON HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Chinese dissident leader Wei Jingsheng on Wednesday urged Australia and other Western countries to press China to improve its human rights and speed up democratization.

Speaking at a gathering of 150 academics and business leaders in Sydney, Wei said Western countries should exert strong pressure on China and urge Beijing to respect human rights and take concrete steps towards democratic system.
"We need to constantly voice our strong concerns over human rights situation and the democratic process in China," he said at the Sydney Institute, a prestigious organization in Australia.

Wei said the prospects of improving human rights situation and democratic system in China are gaining momentum. "But we need to unite all the promoters of democracy among those who live overseas and in China so that they would become a powerful force," he said.

In his meeting with members of Parliament from the Liberal, National, Labor Parties and Independent on Wednesday afternoon in Canberra, Wei discussed the human rights issues with Australian politicians.

He reminded that the current annual bilateral dialogues between Australia and mainland China on human rights and the Tibet issue have produced little in pressing China to improve the human rights records in the mainland.
"That kind of dialogue is ineffective to press China to improve its human rights records," he told the Australian MPs, who agreed with Wei's views.
The MPs said they would press their government to do more and ask China to improve its human rights situation in future dialogues.
Wei, who arrived in Australia on Tuesday for the first time, is expected to see points of interest in Sydney on Thursday before giving another speech to overseas Chinese on August 28. PETER CHEN

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS AGAINST NT DOLLAR

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Market on Wednesday, declining NT$0.015 to end at NT$31.867.
A total of US$314.5 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$31.870 and was traded between NT$31.872 and NT$31.856.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRADE IN AGRICULTURAL GOODS DOWN 5.6% IN FIRST HALF YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports of agricultural products totaled US$5.35 billion in the first half of this year, down 5.6 percent from the same period of last year, according to the Council of Agriculture (COA) on Wednesday.
The Cabinet-level COA listed Taiwan's imports in the January-June period at US$3.81 billion, down 6.4 percent, and exports at US$1.54 billion, down 3.5 percent.
The United States was the top supplier of agricultural imports, accounting for 28.8 percent of all imports, while Australia and Japan, accounting for 6.5 percent and 4.8 percent respectively.

The largest export destination for Taiwan's agricultural products was Japan, accounting for 26.6 percent of the total value, followed by Hong Kong and the US, accounting for 23.3 percent and 10.2 percent respectively.
Exports of Taiwan agricultural products to all countries witnessed a decrease, with the exception of a 14.4 percent and 10.6 percent increase in exports to Vietnam and South Korea respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL NOMINATE PRESIDENTIAL TICKET ON AUG. 29

TEXT.P: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approved on Wednesday the draft programs of the second plenary session of the party's 15th Congress on Aug. 29, including the nomination of presidential and vice presidential candidates.
In addition to nominating the KMT ticket for the 2000 campaign, the KMT will hold its third Central Committee meeting to select new Standing Committee members.
These programs will also be submitted to the preparation meeting of the second plenary session of the party's 15th Congress for reapproval.
According to the programs approved by the party's Central Standing Committee, delegates to the 15th Congress will register on the morning of Aug. 27 and hold a welcoming tea party in the afternoon.
On Aug. 28, an opening ceremony will be held and the congress preparative meeting and the presidium will meet following the opening ceremony on the morning.

In the afternoon, the presidium of the Central Advisory Committee, and representatives of the delegate to the 15Th congress will pay homage to the nation's founding father, Dr. Sun Yat-sen, at the Sun Yet-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei and to late President Chiang Kai-shek at Tzufu and President Chiang Ching-kuo at Toulao, both in Taoyuan county.

On Aug. 29, the KMT congress will formally approve the nomination of the presidential and vice presidential candidates. Vice President Lien Chan gained the support of 96.6 percent of the 2,180 delegates to the congress last Saturday.
President Lee Teng-hui in his capacity as chairman of KMT will present Vice President Lien Chan a party flag symbolizing the formal launching of the 2000 presidential election campaign.
The KMT congress will also be approved during the meeting of the new members of the Central Advisory Committee and of the presidium of the Central Advisory Committee as recommended by Chairman Lee.

The third Central Committee meeting will be held that afternoon with the aim of electing new members to the Central Standing Committee. The Central Standing Committee is comprised of 33 members. By Edward Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: LIN YUAN GROUP TOP OF TAIWAN BUSINESS GROUP: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The Lin Yuan Group topped Taiwan business groups last year with an annual turnover of NT$343.3 billion (US$10.66 billion), according to a survey released by monthly magazine Commonwealth on Wednesday.
The Formosa Plastics Group, which topped the list in 1997, saw its turnover decline by three percent last year, in falling to second place.

Shin Kong, Acer, and the Yulon Group took the third, fourth and fifth place. They were followed by the Koo's, Evergreen, United Microelectronics, Far Eastern, and Philips Electronics Industries (Taiwan).
The magazine said that last year's performance of the 50 business groups was lackluster, with combined net profits shrinking to NT$138.2 billion (US$4.29 billion), down 36 percent from 1997.
Profitability also went down to four percent in 1998, from 6.7 percent in 1997. Even so, the semiconductor sector led other sectors in turning a profit.

In 1997, the profitability of both the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. and United Microelectronics was more than 30 percent, making them the first and second most profitable business groups. While the semiconductor industry as a whole was sluggish last year, the profitability of the two groups still registered profits of 20.75 and 16.99 percent, respectively.

The survey also showed that the proportion of turnover of business groups in the domestic economy increased, noting that turnover among the top 50 business groups accounted for 41.7 percent of gross national product in 1997. The turnover of the top 50 groups last year climbed to NT$4,342.2 billion (US$134.85 billion), accounting for half of the GNP.
On the other hand, the 50 top business groups currently employ a total of 740,000 laborers, meaning that one out of every 12 employed persons in Taiwan is working for one of the top 50 groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MA TO VISIT OSAKA ON SEPT. 2-3

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to visit Osaka, Japan to participate in the Taipei-Osaka 21st Century City Consultative Confab Sept. 2-3.
Mayor Ma will also observe the city installations of Osaka during his two-day stay.
Due to a tight schedule, Ma will not visit Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ichihara.
This will be the second time the Taipei-Osaka 21st Century City Consultative Conference has been held in Osaka.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will deliver a keynote speech at the conference's closing ceremony Sept. 3. Ma will then visit Osaka's Big-egg Stadium before returning to Taipei on the afternoon of September 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 40 PERSENT OF TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS MULL SETTING UP FOOTHOLDS IN EUROPE

TEXT.P: Following the Euro's launch this year, nearly 40 percent of domestic manufacturers are considering setting up an European foothold or warehouse, according to a survey conducted by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).

CETRA officials on Wednesday said that as the wage for western European laborers is high and the rent for office space and warehouse expansive, they are suggesting that Taiwan manufacturers setting up footholds in Spain and Portugal in southern Europe, or Poland, the Czech Republic, and Hungary when the three countries join the European Union in 2001.
The officials said that in May they surveyed the effect of the single European currency on the marketing strategies of Taiwan businesses, targeting the top 3,000 Taiwan exporters to Europe last year.

The survey showed that after the launch of the Euro in 1999, most Taiwan manufacturers still quoted product prices in US dollars. However, 70.3 percent of the surveyed also said that it is necessary to open Euro-deposit accounts.

Some 19.7 percent of Taiwan manufactures said they plan to go to Europe to set up footholds or warehouse within three years; 16.6 percent said they are assessing the possibility, while 63.7 percent said they would not set up a European foothold.

The officials said that Taiwan businessmen are more willing than before to set up footholds in Europe because competition in Europe is steeper in recent years and customers are asking for an earlier delivery of goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAST SQUADRON OF MIRAGE FIGHTERS TO BE DEPLOYED BY NEXT MARCH
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: All 60 Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters ordered by the Republic of China Air Force have arrived in Taiwan, with the last squadron to be deployed by next March, according to an air force general on Wednesday.

Gen. Chin Nai-chieh, who is in charge of the Mirage fighter wings at the Hsinchu Air Force Base, told the media that 40 Mirages have already joined the combat-readiness deployment unit, while the last squadron is undergoing intensive training.

He said the air force originally planned to complete deployment of the Mirage fleet by the end of this year, but the schedule has now been extended to next March as the training for the last squadron will be extended from six to eight months.
To demonstrate the Mirage fighter's performance capability, Major Liu Hui-chien, who has 650 flying hours in the French-made fighter, made a performance flight for the media at the Hsinchu base.
Meeting with reporters later, Liu said the Mirage is flawless in flight training and combat training, adding that the only requirement is to step up the training of personnel.
Meanwhile, Colonel Shen Yi-ming of the Mirage tactical combat wing said that mainland China's SU-27 jet fighters are the presumed rivals of Taiwan's Mirage fighters.

He noted that both Mirage and SU-27 fighters are high-altitude high-speed interceptors, but because Mirage 2000-5s have better weapon systems, the ROC Air Force is able to maintain an air supremacy over the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT RULES OUT LIEN-SOONG PRESIDENTIAL TICKET

TEXT.P: One day after former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said that he has crossed the Rubicon in his presidential bid, ruling Kuomintang Secretary General James Chang ruled out on Wednesday any possibility that Soong could be recruited as the running mate of KMT presidential candidate Lien Chan.

After a group of retired Kuomintang party officials lodged an appeal to the KMT Central Standing Committee on Wednesday strongly urging the Lien-Soong political partnership, Chang said that the KMT's exhaustive efforts to broke a compromise between the two politicians came to no avail due to Soong's insistence on running as an independent.

In light of Soong's snub of the KMT heavyweights' outreach on Tuesday and the Friday deadline for the KMT to name Lien's running mate, Chang said there is no possibility to have the Soong and Lien on the same ticket.

Chang confirmed a report in Wednesday's United Daily News that Lien, positive that he will represent the party in the 2000 presidential race, wrote a personal letter to Soong exploring the possibility of cooperation in the presidential election on Monday, only to see the letter returned within two hours.
Denouncing Soong's rejection as "rude, irrational" behavior, Chang said the former KMT secretary general has "disappointed everyone who cares about the party."
He called on party members to give up any hope of a Lien-Soong partnership and unconditionally ruled out a meeting between Soong and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui.
Meanwhile, a Soong spokesman on Wednesday urged KMT supporters to stop collecting signatures for an appeal to Soong to serve as Lien's running mate.

"Justice delayed is justice denied," Ching Chin-shen said in appealing to voters to stop the signature collection. He said that any call, however well-intentioned, for Soong to give up his presidential bid will only cause trouble for Soong.

Ching thanked the supporters' for their concern but insisted that the KMT leaders' outreach to Soong was insincere and a political gambit aimed at shifting the blame for the party's division onto Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Vice President Lien Chan making extensive consultations on running mate issues.
The China Times:
Vice President Lien met Premier Vincent Siew Wednesday night on the teaming-up issue.
The United Daily News:
Bank of Taiwan is expected to merge large domestic banks together.
The Liberty Times:
Explosive substance suspected in UNI Air plane fire.
The Commons Daily:
23 leading US conservatives and foreign-policy experts issued a joint statement calling for defense of Taiwan.
The China Post:
Bombing ruled out in UNI plane accident.
The Taiwan News:
Three flights canceled because of plane woes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 26, or the 16th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1346: An English army under Edward III wins an overwhelming and unexpected victory by defeating Philip VI's larger French force in the battle of Crecy.
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."

DOC.HEADLINE: US MUST MAKE POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN CLEAR: EDITORIAL

TEXT.P: It is a lesson and warning from the Ronald Reagan years that Washington needs to make it clear to Beijing that any violence against Taiwan would be met not with diplomatic indulgence, but military force, a leading American newspaper said editorially Wednesday.
"When it comes to preserving peace, grave concern is no substitute for the Seventh Fleet," said the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette in its editorial titled "Chinese Puzzle: What would Ronald Reagan do?"

It said that uncertain about what to do about the two Chinas except to keep insisting on the fiction that there is only one, the United States' diplomatic establishment is in its usual dither. That is, it's following Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's wobbly lead, and she is giving off conflicting signals like a traffic light stuck on red, yellow and green.

Not since Dean Acheson put South Korea outside the American "defensive perimeter" has the State Department given a potential aggressor so clear an invitation. And the Pentagon has done its part by calling off a military mission to Taiwan. It, too, seems resolved to be irresolute. Various other American officials, civil and military, have joined the confused chorus, attacking Taiwan's leaders on and off the record as if they were the ones fomenting war. No wonder the Communists on the mainland talk openly of using military force against "the last redoubt of Chinese freedom," noted the newspaper.

The editorial said that Washington's policy is to have no policy, hoping that the generous amounts of verbal fog will keep the peace. Here is today's equivocation: The United States would clearly view an attack on Taiwan as a matter of "grave concern," while Washington just as clearly disapproves of Taiwan's acting like a free country or, far worse, talking like one. Which is what Taiwan's president has been doing, and the Clinton administration is not about to forgive him for it.

Trade replaced freedom as the lodestar of American foreign policy in Asia sometime during the Bush administration. But not until now has an American administration begun to "treat any talk of freedom and independence from the other China, our old ally, as grounds for abandonment," the newspaper pointed out.

The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette continued that it's not so much that Washington's policy invites war, rather its lack of a policy does. No one is quite sure what Washington would do if China fired a few missiles over Taiwan as it has done before, or blockaded the island's ports, or just occupied a smaller island or Quemoy and Matsu. Once upon a time in the 1950s, such overt acts of aggression would have been recognized for what they were. Now they might merit only a polite protest. Which may be why Beijing is tempted to bite off what it can.

Back in 1980, the newspaper said, it wasn't the president of Taiwan who was asking that his island nation be treated as a state of its own, but an American presidential candidate with a way of putting things plain. Ronald Reagan's statements may have deterred the aggressor, but they disturbed the kind of politicians who make a career of ambiguity. So it was only natural for Mr. Reagan to mention in his offhand way that, in his administration, Taiwan would have an official relationship with the United States.

Immediately, his running mate, the experienced and sophisticated George Bush, stepped in to explain that of course Mr. Reagan hadn't meant what he'd said. "But of course he had, and Beijing got the message. Or at least it behaved itself once Ronald Reagan became the next president of the United States," according to the editorial.

The newspaper said that there is much to be said for giving aggressors clear notice that they will be treated as aggressors, rather than poor, misunderstood nations who only want to take over their immediate neighbors. "Calling aggression by its right name may prevent it. Going wobbly may only encourage it," stressed the editorial.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA RECORDS TRADE SURPLUS

TEXT.P: South Africa recorded a trade surplus for the first seven months to July this year, according to statistics released by the South African Revenue Service Wednesday.
The country's exports totaled 92.9 billion rand (about 15.25 billion US dollars) during the seven months, compared to imports of 81 billion rand.
Europe remained the country's biggest trading partner with imports from that continent exceeding 38.85 billion rand, and exports to the continent totaling nearly 30.2 billion rand.
Asia was South African second biggest destination for goods, totaling 18 billion rand, while imports from the Asian continent totaled 23.1 billion rand.
During the seven-month period, imports from America amounted to roughly 14.7 billion rand while South African exports to America totaled 8.7 billion rand.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURGLARY, DANGEROUS DRIVING MOST FEARED IN AUSTRALIA: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Australians are more worried about their house being burgled and dangerous and driving than being murdered, assaulted or raped, according to the National Crime and Safety Survey on Thursday.

The survey shows most people fear break-ins, which account for 44 percent of all respondents; followed by dangerous and noisy driving 34 percent; and vandalism and graffiti and car theft, which account for 24 and 28 percent respectively.
Trailing behind are youth gangs, louts, drunkenness, illegal drugs, problems with neighbors, prowlers and loiterers. Sexual assault only accounts for 5 percent.

"Maybe people have become a bit more realistic about it," said an official of the Bureau of Crime Statistics in New South Wales. He said the survey found people were increasingly concerned about crimes closer to home instead of more serious offenses they were less likely to experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUITION KEEPS RISING IN CANADA

TEXT.P: University tuition in Canada is set for another jump this year, with undergraduate arts students facing a rise of 7.1 percent over the last academic year, a federal agency said Wednesday.
The average annual rise over the last five years has been about nine percent as universities struggled to offset government funding cuts.
Statistics Canada said the average undergrad will pay C$3,379 in tuition this year compared with C$3,156 in 1998-99. Graduate students face an 8.3-percent increase, to an average of C$3,681.

Fees rose this year in every province except British Columbia and Quebec. The former has frozen tuition fees for the last five years and Quebec is maintaining a freeze for residents, who pay C$1,668. Non-residents, however, are looking at a 10-percent hike this year.
Would-be doctors and dentists are hit hardest by fee increase, Statscan noted. Medical schools will charge an average of C$5,699, a 15.6-percent increase from 1998-99.
These are all the fees for Canadian citizens or landed immigrants. Visa students from abroad usually are charged three times what locals pay.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES LOWER

TEXT.P: Despite an overnight rally on Wall Street and aggressive foreign buying, the Taipei stock market on Thursday closed 0.4 percent lower as heavy selling pressure near the end session eroded early gains.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index shed 29.52 points to close at 8,097.57 points, following a 1.8-percent rise in the previous session.
A total of 3.44 billion share changed hands on a turnover of NT$149.88 billion (US$ 4.7 billion), compared to NT$125.36 billion on Wednesday.

Encouraged by a record high on Wall Street, the bourse opened 44.19 points higher and at one point had soared 113.08 points to 8,240.17 points. But late profit-taking took the index to negative territory.

As market confidence remains fragile, investors rushed to lock in profits when the index surged, dealers said, adding that the stock market is trapped in a consolidation phase and sharp gains in the near term are unlikely.
The construction sector and the plastic and chemical sector enjoyed the only gains among the eight major stock categories, as both finished 0.4 percent higher.
Foodstuff issues reported the largest losses, falling 1.5 percent; they were followed by paper-making issues, which lost 1 percent, and textile shares, which lost 0.9 percent.
The over-the-counter market closed 1.22 points higher at 176.70 points on a turnover of NT$6.33 billion.
Meanwhile, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, except for those for next March and next June, for which no contract transactions were registered.

TAIEX Index Futures for September dropped 96 points to close at 8,134 points, with 3,108 contract transactions; those for October shed 97 points to finish at 8,150 points, with 66 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 138 points to end at 8,150 points, with 20 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 8,230 points for September, 8,247 points for October, 8,288 points for December, 8,299 points for next March and 8,379 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported losses.
September TE futures dropped 3.8 points to end at 372.2 points, with 961 contract transactions; October TE futures shed 5.8 points to close at 372 points, with 10 contract transactions.
No transaction records for TE futures for other months were registered.
September TF futures declined 3 points to close at 1,170 points, with 234 contract transactions while there were no transaction records for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA STALLING LNG SALES TO TAIWAN: REPORT

TEXT.P: Australia is stalling the sale of its liquefied natural gas worth A$50 (over US$33) billion over the next 10 years because it fears offending mainland China, the Australian Financial Review reported in its front page lead news on Thursday.

In the article headlined: "China row threatens A$50 billion deal," the daily, the largest business newspaper in Australia, reported Taiwan's offer to buy the LNG this week following reports that China might sign its own A$15 (US$10) billion agreement when President Jiang Zemin makes his first official visit to Canberra in early September. Sales to China are expected to start by 2004 with an annual amount of 3 million tons.
The daily quoted a spokesman for the Department of Foreign Affairs on Wednesday night as denying suggestions that the Howard government was stalling on the Taiwan offer.
Taiwan currently imports about 3.5 million tons of LNG from Indonesia and Malaysia. Taipei has told Canberra it is anxious to diversify its sources of supply, the daily reported.

The daily reported Taipei's irritation has been intensified by reports in the Review that Chinese ambassador to Australia has spoken about the possibility of the LNG sale because China appreciated Australia's view on Taiwan.
Australia moved openly to discourage Papua New Guinea's recent plan to establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan in return for cheap loans, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSTIGATORS OF FOREIGN LABORER MELEE MAY FACE REPATRIATION: POLICE

TEXT.P: The instigators of a melee involving some 300 Indonesian and Philippine laborers Wednesday night may face repatriation if the two laborers who were injured in the fight file lawsuits, the Yunlin police said on Thursday.

The two workers were reportedly injured in the brawl between Indonesian and Filipino workers, all employees of Formosa Plastics' naphtha cracking plant in Mailiao, Yunlin. The two groups engaged in a melee late Wednesday night using wooden clubs, bricks and iron sticks as weapons.
According to officials from the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), the scuffle was due to a personal vendetta between Indonesian workers and their Filipino manager.

Two Indonesian workers were about to be dismissed by Formosa Plastics because of a "poor work performance." The two Indonesians suspected their Filipino foreman had lodged a false management report. The Indonesians met the Filipinos for a "talk" Tuesday night. That "talk" occurred without any violence.
However, Wednesday night, Filipino workers physically attacked Indonesian laborers, instigating a mass brawl. Reports say up to 300 laborers, all working for Formosa Plastics, took part.
Mailiao police were called in immediately to calm the melee and found that at least two were injured.
To prevent further conflicts from occurring, Formosa Plastic management ordered some 500 Indonesian workers to move to another dormitory building in the plant complex.
Fist fights and exchanges of dirty words occurred again Thursday morning while the Indonesian workers were moving, according to the police.
If the two injured laborers file a lawsuit against those instigators of the violence, the accused might face repatriation, police said.

Wednesday's scuffle was the second brawl involving Formosa Plastic foreign workers since the Mailiao plant became operational in 1993. In June 1997, Philippine and Thai laborers engaged in a bloody conflict after several bicycles were stolen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRACKDOWN ON DISSENT SEEN HAMPERING CLINGON-JIANG TALKS

TEXT.P: Mainland China's latest crackdown on the fledging China Democratic Party (CDP) and religious Falun Gong sect will serve as a barrier to a successful summit between Presidents Bill Clinton and Jiang Zemin on September 14-15 in Christchurch, New Zealand, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Thursday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily's correspondent David Lague quoted some foreign diplomats in the city as predicting that China's tough repression could be a barrier to a successful summit at a time when harmony with the US could be vital in averting a crisis over Taiwan.

They said when the two leaders met in China last year, Clinton hailed the Chinese leadership for easing their repression on dissidents and described Chinese move to improve its image as a "Beijing spring." But the latest crackdown on CDP and Falun Gong has brought the euphoria of last year to an end, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN OFFICIALS OPPOSE UN COUNT OF EAST TIMOR VOTE

TEXT.P: Indonesian officials in East Timor said they would reject the outcome of the UN-sponsored August 30 ballot on the former Portuguese colony because the UN count on the votes could be unfair.

In a dispatch from Dili, the Sydney Morning Herald on Thursday quoted Francisco Lopez da Cruz, Jakarta's ambassador at large, as saying that the UN plans to centralize vote-counting in the capital of East Timor were neither democratic nor transparent.
"If you try to bring the ballot boxes to Dili, by road or helicopter, anything could happen to them on the way," he said.
U.N. officials, diplomats and independent analysts have predicted a victory for the pro-independence supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS HOLDING ON TO LOCAL SECURITIES

TEXT.P: Foreign investors bought from Jan. 1 to Aug. 23 of this year NT$634.72 billion (US$19.94 billion) worth of Taiwan securities and sold NT$424.21 billion worth, according to statistics released Thursday by the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC).

The NT$210.51 billion (US$6.62 billion) difference between the amount of Taiwan securities bought and sold rose to NT$217.32 billion (US$6.83 billion) on Wednesday as more investments were made, the SFC said.
The tallies also show that the SFC under the Ministry of Finance approved 28 applications in July from foreign investors to purchase US$1.87 billion-worth of local securities.

As of the end of July, 321 foreign trust and investment institutes had purchased Taiwan securities this year, and 93.3 percent of those purchases were of stock. The market value of shares bought by foreign investors over the year-to-July period was NT$531.9 billion (US$16.73 billion), the SFC statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR DENIES CANCELLATION OF 'TWO CITIES FORUM'

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Thursday denied that the city government has canceled plans to host a Forum of Two Cities between Taipei and Hong Kong.

Rebutting rumors that the forum will be canceled as a result of an adverse impact from President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" assertion on cross-strait relations, Ma said the forum will be held in Taipei with representatives from both Taipei and Hong Kong taking part.
Ma said the schedule of the forum is expected to be finalized soon after the Hong Kong sponsors notify Taipei City of a proposed date. That notification is expected within a week.
The Forum of Two Cities, a brainchild of Ma, was first proposed by the mayor when he last visited Hong Kong in March. Several private Hong Kong groups will jointly sponsor the gathering.
Ma made the remarks Thursday when he met with Liu Huei-ching, convenor of The Frontier, a Hong Kong-based political group, and a member of Hong Kong's Legislative Council.

Liu and a group of representatives of several Hong Kong private organizations are currently on a fact-finding tour of Taipei, mainly to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's medical services and the national health insurance program that has been in effect in Taiwan for more than five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMY UNVEILS SKY BOW MISSILE BASE IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Army unveiled its Sky Bow surface-to-air missile base in Linyuan in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung County on Thursday amid escalation of tension in the Taiwan Strait.

This was the first time that the ROC military has opened its Sky Bow air-defense missile base for media coverage. Observers said the move is part of the military's efforts to allay local people's jitters about possible mainland Chinese attacks over the "special state-to-state relationship" controversy.

The Army General Headquarters said all Sky-Bow missile units in Taiwan and on offshore islands have completed combat deployment with the assistance of the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) and the Combined Service Force.

The CIST-developed Sky Bow surface-to-air missiles have been deployed at six army bases, with five in Taiwan and one in Tungyin, a small islet of the Matsu island group which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.

The five Sky Bow missile bases in Taiwan are located in Sanchih, a northern Taiwan coastal township; Penghu, an offshore island county off southwestern Taiwan coast; Taichung in central Taiwan; and two bases in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung.
All of the six Sky Bow missile bases are equipped with highly advanced phased array radar systems.

In addition, the CIST, the military's research and development arm, has completed combat testing on the second-generation Sky Bow missiles. Military sources said Sky Bow II missiles are more sophisticated and more powerful than Sky Bow I missiles. Mass production and deployment of Sky Bow II missiles have also got underway, CIST officials said.

Beijing has launched new rounds of saber-rattling against Taiwan since ROC President Lee Teng-hui said in an interview with a German radio station on July 9 that Taiwan-mainland China relations should be on a "special state-to-state relationship" basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: RARE STOAT SPECIES FOUND ENDEMIC ONLY TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The latest collaborative research between specialists from Taiwan and Japan has confirmed that the two mini stoats discovered in mountains in central Taiwan are a virtual "relic species" and endemic only to Taiwan, according to an Asahi Shimbun report.

Associate Professor Lin Liang-kung from Taiwan's Tunghai University who found the two stoats, and Masanori Harada, an associate professor of the City University of Osaka, recently announced that the Taiwan mountain stoat, believed to be an Arctic species that survived the last ice age, is unique and endemic only to Taiwan, the Asahi Shimbun report said.

Lin and Harada made public their findings after conducting a series of laborious DNA comparisons between cell samples of the two Formosan stoats and those of distant relatives originating from Japan, Russia and the Korean Peninsula.
It was the first time that the rare Formosan stoats have been discovered since World War II, according to the Asahi Shimbun report.

According to Lin, who discovered the first Formosan stoat on Mt. Hohuan in June 1997 and the second in July this year, the mammal is known as a "relic species" and is considered as important a species in biological terms as Taiwan's other relic species, the Formosan landlocked salmon.
"Relic species" refers to a species that has survived from a previous age, such as before the last ice age, when many other species died out.
The rare stoats that Lin found on 3,000-meter Mt. Hohuan are both adult mammals weighing some 20 grams each and are around 16 centimeters and 20 centimeters long.
With brown fur all over its body except for its belly, which has white fur, the Formosan stoat looks like the snow stoat that has been found in the high mountains of Japan, Lin said.

Lin speculated that the Formosan stoat is descended from stoats originating in mainland China 10,000 to 60,000 years ago and has evolved as a unique species in isolated highland areas in Taiwan, which is believed to be the creature's only habitat.

It is biologically significant that an essentially Arctic species like the Formosan stoat can be found in subtropical Taiwan, Lin noted. It suggests that more previously unknown or rare species of animals and plants may remain to be discovered in remote and mountainous areas of Taiwan, he said.

According to Taiwan's biological records, the two Formosan stoats that Lin found are the third and fourth stoat of their kind to have been found in Taiwan in recent years. A similar specimen was found dead in 1996 and is now stored at the National Taichung Museum of Natural Sciences. A second one was captured five years ago, also by Lin, near central Taiwan's Jade Mountain, but he released the animal, mistaking it for a more common weasel.

Lin and his researchers have established observation posts in areas above 3,000 meters in national parks in the hope that more specimens will be found and thus contribute to research into the species.

Lin's only worry is that the Formosan stoat's population is under threat, as it is believed to share its habitat with weasels, which are far more abundant and will compete with the stoats for limited food resources. Both species are ferocious carnivores that prey mainly on mice, shrews and voles.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR SURGES THREE CENTS

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.3 against the US greenback on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Market (TFEM) on Thursday, to close at NT$31.854.
The local currency opened at NT$31.864 and was traded between NT$31.856 and NT$31.867.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$285.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN-SIEW TICKET NOT A PLUS FOR KMT, SAYS DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: A Lien-Siew ticket is not a plus for the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in the 2000 presidential election, said the secretary-general of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday.
Yu Hsi-kun made the remark as the KMT prepares to announce its ticket, which is expected to match presidential candidate and current Vice President Lien Chan with Premier Vincent Siew.

He said the KMT's singling out of the head of a "disastrous cabinet" to be its vice presidential candidate is not a plus for the party. Instead such a ticket would make the DPP feel that it is "more and more close to victory in the election," he said.

Yu Ying-lung, spokesman for the headquarters of DPP presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian, said a Lien-Siew ticket is the party's third choice. The KMT would rather see Lien paired with former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong or Senior Adviser to the President Wu Poh-hsiung.
When Siew assumed his post, he promised that his cabinet would be one of action, but the facts have shown otherwise, Yu Ying-lung said.

He noted, however, that although Siew has the image of a yes-man, he still possesses plenty of administrative resources as a civil servant. In addition, Siew is a native of southern Taiwan and may help the KMT to grab votes in that region.

Yu Hsi-kun said the men close to Lien, including Siew, are mostly outdated in their thinking. He slammed Siew for what he called the string of disasters that have occurred during Siew's tenure, and he said Siew is not good at dealing with crises.
Yu Hsi-kun called Siew's cabinet a "disastrous cabinet" and said the Lien-Siew ticket is nothing new and not a plus for the KMT.
Yu Ying-lung noted that for the KMT, a Lien-Soong ticket would be the best choice, but such a ticket will not be formed, as Soong has declared his intention to run for president as an independent.

Although a Lien-Wu ticket is the second best choice, it seems that the combination is also impossible because Wu loudly and publicly voiced in early August his intention to be Lien's running mate, an act that breaks a taboo of the ruling party.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN CALLS FOR KMT SOLIDARITY DURING PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: As the presidential election approaches, the ruling Kuomintang's quasi-presidential candidate Lien Chan on Thursday urged all KMT party member to unite closely to fight against those who bear "daydreams" of bringing to an end the KMT or the Republic of China.

Over 500 supporters from the overseas "Friends of Lien Chan Club" on Thursday morning gathered outside the headquarters of the KMT's Central Committee to drum up support for Lien. Loud chants of "Lien Chan, elected" echoed through the building.

While delivering a thank-you speech, Lien noted that it is the aspiration of all Taiwan people that Taiwan become a completely modernized country -- characterized by dignity, peace, job opportunities and justice -- in the 21st century. This, he added, is his main political goal.
He noted, however, that many different views, some of which would be contrary to those of the KMT and are mainly fierce attacks to KMT ruling, would be raised during the election campaign.

Some will campaign for the termination of the ROC, while some are keen on knocking down the KMT. Hence, all KMT supporters have to work together to ensure the victory of the KMT in the upcoming presidential election so as to create a modern ROC, Lien said.
At the gathering, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jyng-ping, Vice Chairman Rau Yin-chi and KMT Secretary-General John Chang were also present to cheer on supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO MAKE PUBLIC FLIGHT SAFETY ASSESSMENTS

TEXT.P: Many local scholars and experts, concerned over the poor safety record of China Airlines (CAL), on Thursday called for the government to make public airlines' flight information and their flight safety assessments.

The scholars and experts voiced their opinions at a seminar sponsored by the Consumers Foundation in the wake of a CAL jet crash landing Sunday that killed two passengers and injured 212 others, the third serious accident for CAL this decade.
The flight accident rate of the island's civilian airlines is 3.7 times that of the worldwide average, according to an investigation.

Su Ching-hsia, secretary-general of the Consumers Foundation, said that domestic consumers have all been in the dark in terms of their knowledge about the flight safety records of various airlines in Taiwan.

Su called for the government to implement a flight safety assessment project thoroughly. The government should make public the number of flight hours of all the pilots of Taiwan's airlines, as well as maintenance records and an explanation of how the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) supervises the airlines, Su said.

During the seminar, Lai Hse-bao, a lawmaker from the opposition New Party, said that not only is the CAA's flight safety team seriously understaffed, no team members have internationally recognized flight-safety supervisory licenses. The government cannot shirk its responsibility in addressing the issue, he added.
Lee Ying-yuan, chief convener of the legislative caucus of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, also censured CAL for being reckless.

Wu Jung-kuei, head of the Navigation and Aviation Department under the Ministry of Transportation of Communications, indicated that a government-designed flight safety measurement based on information from airlines' flight records will be released to the public within two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY IS DEFENSIVE POLICY: SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" theory is basically a defensive policy to cope with changes in the status quo and rules of game in Taipei-Washington-Beijing ties, a scholar said here Wednesday.

Tien Hung-mao, director of the Institute for National Policy Research, a Taipei-based private think tank, said President Lee was forced to redefine relations across the Taiwan Strait because the rules of game in the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations have been changed by the United States and mainland China.

Tien, a national policy adviser to Lee, said US President Bill Clinton's 1998 "three noes" statement and Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth's recent "interim agreement" proposal have made President Lee feel that the US stance on cross-strait ties have been leaning toward Beijing.
Worse yet, Tien said, Beijing has unilaterally backed off a 1992 cross-strait consensus that each side is allowed to have its own definition of "one China."
Against this background, Tien said, President Lee passively declared in an interview with a German radio station on July 9 that cross-strait relations should be on a "special state-to-state" basis.

"Lee's declaration is basically a passive, defensive and preventive move to ward off imbalance in cross-strait ties and triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations," Tien said, adding that the "special state-to-state" definition just affirms reality in order to ensure Taiwan's survival and safety.

Tien, a US-trained political scientist who maintains close ties with the Republic of China's policy-making system, said even though communist China has repeatedly pressured the United States to force Taiwan to retract the "special state-to-state" theory, the Clinton administration has so far not asked Taiwan to do so.
The US government has only expressed hopes that Taiwan will continue exchanges, dialogue and negotiations with mainland China so as to work out a peaceful solution to their disputes, Tien said.

As to Beijing's reaction, Tien said mainland China has so far not conducted abnormal military activities and that its air force has maintained normal operations. "There are also no signs showing that mainland China has moved troops from inland provinces to coastal areas opposite Taiwan."

Tien further predicted that mainland China will not take any military action against Taiwan before the island's next direct presidential election scheduled for March 2000. "Mainland leaders will wait until after the election to decide whether to take any military action against Taiwan," he forecast.
Tien made the above remarks in a speech to a seminar sponsored by the North California Taiwan Chamber of commerce.
The main purpose of Tien's current US trip is to attend a closed-door seminar to be held in New York on cross-strait relations and the US policy toward Taiwan and mainland China.

Tien said two US officials in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs --Kurt Campbell, deputy assistant secretary of defense, Susan Shirk, deputy assistant secretary of state, will also attend the roundtable meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL TO LAUNCH WARM-UP CAMPAIGN RALLY

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate fielded by the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), is scheduled to kick off a pre-election warm-up campaign rally in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan on Saturday.

DPP officials said the party will mobilize more than 100,000 supporters from across Taiwan, especially from the seven counties and cities in the southern part of the island ruled by DPP magistrates and mayors, to attend the rally on Saturday night, the first of a series of five similar events.

DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, Tainan City Mayor Chang Tsan-hung, and Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan will also take part in the rally, designed to demonstrate and drum up public support for Chen's bid for the presidency.
Sept. 28 marks the 13th anniversary of the DPP's funding, and Chen plans to have completed an islandwide tour of 309 townships by that time.

Vice President Lien Chan, the ruling Kuomintang's candidate for Taiwan's next presidential election slated for March 2000, and former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who has announced his candidacy as an independent contender in the race, already held similar pre-campaign rallies of their own in mid-August.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL YOUTH CULTURE AND STUDY TOUR VISITS MOFA BUILDING

TEXT.P: The 1999 International Youth Culture and Study Tour to Taiwan, ROC, sponsored by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the Education Ministry and the China Youth Corps, visited the MOFA Thursday.

MOFA's Chief Secretary Timothy Yang delivered a speech to the 104 young delegates from 51 countries. Yang said that the Republic of China is now regarded as a developed country, yet is not treated as a developed county. Yang added that he hoped the delegates would be able to bring justice to the ROC's bid to rejoin the world community.
"Taiwan has become a highly developed country. Many nations want to learn from the Taiwan experience and we are willing to share our experience with others," Yang said.

Yang asked the delegates to keep an open mind concerning Taiwan's status in the world community. "Sometimes we feel lonely and that it is unfair that we are not treated as equals by other countries. This situation is due to the efforts of Beijing. The 104 delegates gathered here can testify to the existence and vitality of Taiwan," Yang said.
He added, "We hope we can be recognized by all counties and can devote ourselves to world peace."

The 1999 International Youth Culture and Study Tour to Taiwan, ROC, activity will conclude with a closing ceremony on Friday. The 104 delegates will return to their various homes after the ten-day visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIANT STAR TO BE ASSIGNED TO COASTAL PATROL ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Customs Office of the National Tax Administration will assign the patrol ship Giant Star to Taiwan's coastal patrol administration.
The well-equipped Giant Star comes rigged with four patrol cutters, each of which can reach speeds of 35 knots. Patrolmen may use the boats to capture smugglers.

The ship's crew has caught more than 30 smugglers and several ships, including the mainland Chinese fishing boats Lungfeng, Hsengli, Minchinung 42018 and Yaman 101, which tried to smuggle tobacco, agricultural goods and guns into Taiwan, the National Tax Administration of Kaohsiung City said.
The 1,951-ton Giant Star was built by China Shipbuilding Corp. and is 82 meters long and 11.5 meters wide. The ship, which has a 13,000-horsepower engine, can carry up to 76 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES LLI EXECUTIVES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday received executives of the Life Lines International (LLI) and expressed his heartfelt admiration and gratitude to all its members and volunteers for their long-term endeavor to help people while promoting social harmony in Taiwan.

Addressing the guests, Lee said that the LLI is an international consulting organization. Through consultation and guidance, the LLI has helped numerous despondent callers through dilemmas. Lee credited the group with helping callers establish active life attitudes.

The LLI was introduced in Taiwan in 1969. It currently has some 5,300 members and 2,500 volunteers, and serves more than 110,000 citizens per year. Its contribution to the society is seen as an example of a successful private group, Lee added.
Lee went on to say that in recent years, some people have been unable to ease their mental stress and adjust to the rapidly-changing society caused by fast economic development.
As a result, many problems have emerged in conjunction with the social change. Thus, the LLI plays an important role to shoulder more responsibility and exert more influence on society.
Lee encouraged the attendants to continue helping people with pyschological problems.
In addition, Lee hoped that more and more social groups will devote themselves to social service in order to establish a more harmonious and happier society.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAKING EFFORTS TO POPULARIZE ITS EUROPE WEBSITE FRENCH SECTION
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Shammy Chao)

TEXT.P: The Information Division Bureau of Taipei's representative office in France, organizer of the French-language section on the bureau's Europe Internet website, is making endeavors to promote the popularity of its site in Europe.
Bureau Director Wang Chen-tai said the site is unfamiliar to many European people, receiving just 18,000 hits in the last year.

The site is visited mainly by French speakers living in European and African countries, as well as by Taiwan's students of French and is divided into six major categories relating to the Republic of China, such as current events and politics, using information from periodicals published by the ROC Government Information Office and news items provided by CNA.
Wang added that plans are afoot to add more categories to the section, such as Taiwanese religion, festivals and celebrations and ROC Tourist Information.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-TO-STATE THEORY TO BE DISCUSSED IN SCHOLARS MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Romulo Huang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's recent redefinition of the "state-to-state" theory will be a key issue at a discussion of experts scheduled to open on Sunday in New York.

Kao Ying-mao, a professor at Brown University in the United States, said on Thursday that he will take part in the three-day round table meeting of more than 20 scholars and experts from the United States, Taiwan and mainland China sponsored by the US National Foreign Relations Policy Council. In an interview with the CNA, Kao said the meeting will center on an exchange of views without fixed issues.

However, he said he believed that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory, the escalating tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and US policy toward the cross-strait issue will be the key points of the discussion.
The meeting, regarded as a controversial diplomatic "track two " of negotiation among the United States, mainland China and Taiwan, was first held in the summer of 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: COCKROACHES RAMPANT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Nearly 5,000 cockroaches were caught overnight at a bakery in Taipei, indicating that the insect is extremely rampant in the city, a National Taiwan University professor said on Thursday.

Prof. Hsu Er-lieh, who has been commissioned by the Taipei City Government to conduct a cockroach ecological survey aimed at helping curb rapid growth of the insect in the city, said he was not surprised by the large catch of cockroaches at the Taipei bakery.

Field surveys conducted by Hsu's research team found that more than 80 percent Taipei households have been haunted by cockroaches. "The number of cockroaches found in a single household ranges from tens to hundreds," Hsu said, adding that most cockroaches found here are German species.

Noting that German cockroaches are highly reproductive, Hsu said a German cockroach can lay an average of 30 eggs a day and that it takes only a very short period of time for an egg to grow into a mature cockroach.

"Given German cockroach's high reproduction capability, I'm not surprised by the catch of more than 4,800 cockroaches overnight at a 20-ping Taipei bakery," Hsu said. (One ping equals 36 square feet.)
Hsu said German cockroaches have topped American and Australian species as well as brown-banded cockroaches and small brown cockroaches to become the largest cockroach species in Taiwan.

Hsu further said cockroaches have not only haunted local families but also hospitals and clinics. "Cockroaches are the main vehicle to spread a variety of viruses and bacteria at local hospitals," he noted.

Many insect scholars and pharmaceutical makers have been endeavoring to study ways to extinguish cockroaches. Novartis Co., for instance, plans to market a drug that can halt cockroaches' reproduction capabilities. (BY sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA CHIEF CRITICIZED FOR FAILURE TO IMPROVE AVIATION SAFETY

TEXT.P: The director-general of the Republic of China's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) faced severe criticism from lawmakers on Thursday for the recent series of aviation incidents among Taiwan carriers.
Scolded for his failure to improve aviation safety, Chang Yu-hern dissolved into tears at one point, although he defended himself by saying that he has put all his strength into his work.

Chang, who holds a doctoral degree in transportation management and a license as an aeronautic engineering technician, was a professor at the Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University before taking his current post eight months ago.

A non-partisan legislative group invited Chang and CAA officials to a lunch meeting to discuss aviation safety in the wake of two recent incidents involving local airliners which have claimed two lives and injured more than 200 people.

A China Airlines MD-11 passenger jet crash landed at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong on Sunday at the height of typhoon Sam, killing two people and injuring 213. Two days later, a domestic UNI Airliners MD-90 was engulfed in flames after it skidded off the runway at Hualien Airport in eastern Taiwan, resulting in 28 injuries.

Legislator Chen Chau-jung of the ruling Kuomintang noted that no high-ranking officials have been seen to have taken responsibility for the incidents, pointing out that Premier Vincent Siew was too busy celebrating Vice President Lien Chan's birthday to respond to news of the crash.

Meanwhile, he went on, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng has been spending all his time delivering messages from Lien to James Soong, an independent presidential hopeful, in an attempt to recruit Soong as Lien's presidential running mate.
