KMT Legislator Hou Huei-hsien said the CAA has had eight heads since 1990, none of whom have performed well.

In other related news, the Cabinet-level Aviation Safety Council (ASC) revealed that experts have completed the decoding of the cockpit voice recorder, one of two flight data recorders on the UNI Air jet involved in the Hualien incident, and have detected no abnormalities.

ASC Director of Administration Jung Kai said the council needs more time to decode the other recorder that contains digital flight navigation data, and added that a 10-strong panel formed by the US civil aeronautics authorities and the plane's maker, McDonnell Douglas Corp., will arrive in Hualien on Saturday to help investigate the accident.
Members of the task force will include an expert in explosions, he said, noting that existing evidence, including eye-witness accounts, have suggested that an explosion was the cause of the fire.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS OF A SECRET ARMY ARRESTED IN CHINA: REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities arrested on Aug. 4 eight leaders of a small secret army in the Chongqing area in southwestern Sichuan province on charges of "subverting state power," according to a recent report by the Yang Cheng Evening News of Guangzhou city in southeastern Guangdong province.

The report said that the anti-Communist army is composed of only several dozens of farmers from 13 villages and townships in the area in eastern Sichuan, and that the army was established in June, 1998.

Authorities found many anti-government slogans and short poems in more than 20 villages and townships in the area in June, the report said. But it did not reveal the contents of those slogans and poems.
The report said that 10 leaders of the secret army were wanted by authorities, and that two of them are still at large.

One of the leaders is Yang Jiahua, 52, of Zhijiang County in eastern Sichuan. He was previously wanted by public safety authorities for participating in an anti-Communist organization in 1997. He sneaked back to Chongqing in February, 1998, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SWEDEN PARLIAMENTARIANS ASSOCIATION SET UP

TEXT.P: A group of local legislators on Thursday set up the Taiwan-Sweden Parliamentarians Association, the first time an association of this kind has been set up without using the name the Republic of China.

Huang Ming-ho (KMT, Changhua) and Lee Hsien-jen (KMT, Taipei County), both backed President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of ties between Taiwan and mainland China as "a special state-to-state relationship," saying they believe that a proper distinction between Taiwan and China will help Taiwan's position in the international community, which is why they organized the Taiwan-Sweden Parliamentarians Association, they said.

More than 20 dignitaries, including Legislative Yuan President Wang Ching-ping, legislators Hsu Shao-ping (KMT, Keelung), Wang Hsueh-feng (Democratic Progressive Party, Taipei City), Hsu Jong-su (DPP legislator-at-large) Ying Chih-hung (New Party, overseas Chinese), and five Swedish parliamentarians witnessed the ceremony.

Wang Ching-ping said that parliamentary diplomacy will help fill in the shortcomings of traditional diplomatic activities, and that the ROC will continue to promote parliamentary diplomacy, especially among European countries.

Huang said he has visited Sweden several times, and has found that Taiwan can learn a great deal from the Scandinavian country's social welfare system. In addition, Sweden's high-tech development can provide cooperation opportunities for Taiwan companies.

Sten Tolgfors, chairman of the foreign relations committee of the Swedish parliament, said in return that Sweden and Taiwan should strengthen their cooperation and exchanges in the fields of small- and medium-sized enterprises, culture and education.
Tolgfors also extended an invitation to Wang Ching-ping to visit Sweden next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA RELEASES STUDY ON SOUTHEAST ASIAN ECONOMIES

TEXT.P: The economies of Southeast Asian countries, hard-hit by the 1997-98 financial turmoil, are on the way to recovery, but their steady growth may be affected by some "changeable elements."

The results of a study released on Thursday by the Republic of China Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) cited the changeable elements as huge foreign debts, heavy dependence on the US and Japanese economies, high shares of the electronics industry, lack of self-reliance in technology, unstable political and social situations, and the effects of mainland China's economy.
Regarding the effect of a possible devaluation of mainland China's currency, the renminbi, the report said the timing and scale of such a devaluation poses a threat to Southeast Asian countries.

Although there are no signs that a devaluation of the renminbi is likely in the immediate future, the report noted, the threat remains as the mainland's balance of international payments and its exports have not been as good as expected.

The report also said that mainland China and Southeast Asian countries are using abundant and inexpensive labor forces to support their competitiveness, and are attempting to woo as much foreign capital as possible to expand their economies.
Therefore, it said, the most important question for mainland China and Southeast Asia is how to avoid unnecessary, harmful competition in these aspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF STILL PREPARING FOR TAIWAN VISIT BY MAINLAND CHINA ENVOY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is still preparing for an autumn visit by mainland China's top envoy to the island, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow said on Thursday.

Unless the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) officially informs the SEF that ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan has canceled his Taiwan visit, the SEF will continue making arrangements for Wang's trip, an optimistic Shi said.

As to the question of whether Beijing may change its policy toward Taiwan, or cancel Wang's visit to Taiwan, after mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin meets US President Bill Clinton in a coming meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, Shi told reporters that Taipei will closely watch subsequent developments. Any meeting between the two must not hurt Taiwan's interests, he stressed.

Although it has been rumored that Beijing intends to cancel Wang's visit to Taiwan in the wake of President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of Taiwan's ties with mainland China as a "special state-to-state relationship," Shi said he thinks Wang's visit will go ahead as scheduled according to the consensus reached between the two sides when SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu paid a historic visit to Wang in Shanghai last October.

Brushing aside the widespread rhetoric that Beijing is gravely concerned that Wang's Taiwan trip may reflect Beijing's endorsement of Lee's "special relationship" theory, the SEF secretary-general pointed out that while Koo met Wang and Jiang last year, that did not represent Taiwan endorsement of the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" formula for China's unification.
Taipei is opposed to Beijing's "one country, two systems" scheme, but has never threatened to suspend dialogue and exchanges with the mainland unless Beijing renounces it, Shi noted.

The existence of the SEF and ARATS is to serve the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, not to serve politics, he pointed out, stressing that the two sides should first address issues of major concern and interest arising from bilateral exchanges of the people of both sides.

Given the fact that Taiwan and the mainland remain sharply divided over the definition of the disputed "one China" principle, Shi proposed that Wang should not scrap his Taiwan trip and that Taiwan and the mainland should continue to maintain two-way exchanges under the framework that each side can express its own interpretation of so-called "one China."
The SEF and ARATS are semiofficial organizations representing Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to conduct cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PGA TOURNAMENT RAINED OUT

TEXT.P: Heavy rain stopped the first day of play in the 1999 Republic of China PGA championship on Thursday afternoon, with six groups of players unable to complete their rounds.
A total of 114 professional golfers from the United States, South Africa, Paraguay, Brazil, Japan, Thailand, Sweden and the ROC are participating for NT$10 million in prize money.

South African Andre Cruse, and Mike Tschetter of the United States, each shot a four-under-par 68 to share the leader's spot in the tourney being held at the North Bay Golf and Country Club in Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS ON THE RUN IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Critics of Canada's immigration system were furious on Thursday with the disappearance of seven mainland Chinese illegal immigrants allowed to stay in Canada after they arrived in July.
The seven had their refugee applications processed and were then released into the community.
They were supposed to report this week for a routine hearing, but failed to show up on Wednesday. Canada-wide arrest warrants have been issued.
More than half of the Chinese nationals who file refugee claims in Canada abandon them to live here illegally or sneak into the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY TUITION RISING IN CANADA

TEXT.P: University tuition in Canada is set for another jump this year, with undergraduate arts students facing a rise of 7.1 percent over the last academic year, a federal agency said on Wednesday.
The average annual rise over the last five years has been about 9 percent as universities have struggled to offset government funding cuts.
Statistics Canada said the average undergrad will pay C$3,379 in tuition this year compared with C$3,156 in 1998-99. Graduate students face an 8.3-percent increase, to an average of C$3,681.

Fees rose this year in every province except British Columbia and Quebec. The former has frozen tuition fees for the last five years and Quebec is maintaining a freeze for residents, who pay C$1,668. Non-residents, however, are looking at a 10-percent hike this year.
Nova Scotia has the highest average fees, at C$4,113 and Ontario is next, with tuition averaging C$3,872.

Would-be doctors and dentists are hardest-hit by fee increases, the agency noted. Average tuition in dental schools will hit C$7,377 this year, up a third from last year. Medical schools will charge an average of C$5,699, a 15.6-percent increase from 1998-99.
Visa students from abroad are usually charged three times what locals pay.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT EXPRESSES REGRET TO ABORIGINES

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard on Thursday formally expressed deep regret for the first time ever to Aboriginal people, saying past wrongs and injustice hurt and caused trauma to the country's earliest settlers.

Speaking at the House of Representatives, Howard said the government recognizes the importance of understanding the shared history of indigenous and non-indigenous Australians and the need to acknowledge openly the wrongs and injustices of Australia's past.
The government also "acknowledges that the mistreatment of many indigenous Australians over a significant period represents the most blemished chapter in our international history," he said.
He also reaffirmed the "wholehearted commitment to the cause of reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians as an important national priority for Australians."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER'S CANDIDACY FOR VICE PRESIDENT CAUSING CONCERN

TEXT.P: Allegations that Vice President Lien Chan, the ruling Kuomintang's candidate for the 2000 presidential election, has chosen Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate caused concern at the Legislative Yuan on Thursday.

Doubting that Siew can juggle the demanding job of premier with the responsibilities of joining the election campaign, many legislators from various parties have voiced their opposition to Siew's candidacy.
Legislators of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and New Party said that if he accepts Lien's offer, Siew should resign as premier and concentrate on the election.
As the head of the government, they said, a premier should stay beyond the election fray and refrain from influencing its outcome by aiding any party in the race.
Even some legislators of the ruling Kuomintang would not support the partnership between Lien and Siew.
KMT Legislator Chin Hui-chu predicted that the choice of Siew will draw fire from KMT legislators who support Wu Poh-hsiung, another vice-president-aspirant.

A former KMT secretary-general, Wu is the only KMT heavyweight to repeatedly express his desire to represent the party in the race for vice president, and a campaign to seek support for Wu's bid is under way among KMT legislators, led by Legislator Wu Ke-ching.

Independent Legislator Hsu Cheng-kun said that Siew has already used his office to aid Lien's campaign over the past six months, and is expected to do this even more blatantly if he is named as Lien's running mate.
In order to keep the election just and fair, Hsu said he will force Siew to choose between the premiership and candidacy, or face a boycott at the legislature.

Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen refused on Thursday to answer questions about how Siew will defuse the critics' blame because his candidacy is still pending KMT approval. He said, however, that the premier will act according to the law.
A government official who asked not to be named said that the law does not prohibit government officials from running for public office.

Citing former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong and former Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian as examples, the official said there are many prominent cases of government officials running for office without giving up their government jobs.

As to the legislative opposition, the senior official said with confidence that it will be defused by Lien and Siew. Given the KMT's overwhelming majority at the Legislative Yuan, and the fact that some DPP legislators favor Siew's candidacy, the official said any boycott by Siew's opponents will be totally ineffective.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES 5 DRAFT ACTS GOVERNING COAST GUARD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Executive Yuan on Thursday approved five draft acts governing the coast guard as part of moves to form a Cabinet-level general administration for coast guard on Jan. 1, 2000.

The five draft acts are: coast guard law; organic law of coast guard administration; organic statute of offshore guard administration under general administration for coast guard; organic statute of coast guard administration under general administration for coast guard; and general rules on the organization of district coast guard bureaus under coast guard administration.
The five draft acts will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for screening to complete the legislative process.

At present, the Coast Guard Command under the Ministry of National Defense is responsible for coordinating and supervising military personnel, armed forces policemen, policemen, and customs personnel to carry Taiwan's coast guard duties.

The decision to implement a Cabinet-level coast guard administration was made on March 18 to overcome the problems caused by the lack of a single, unified organization exclusively responsible for the island's coast guard affairs, and to improve the effectiveness of smuggling crackdowns.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT PICKS PREMIER AS RUNNING MATE IN 2000 ELECTION

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan, who will represent the ruling Kuomintang in the 2000 presidential election, will formally name Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate on Friday.

The Lien-Siew ticket is expected to be approved by the KMT Central Standing Committee at an extraordinary meeting later that day, with the Party National Congress giving its final stamp of approval on Aug. 29.

On Thursday, Lien met with the chiefs of the Executive Yuan, the Examination Yuan and the Legislative Yuan, as well the secretaries-general of the National Security Council, the Presidential Office and the KMT Central Committee, telling them of his decision to select Siew as his running mate.
According to Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng, Lien praised Siew as a qualified choice to team up with, because of his rich experience in the administrative branch and as a legislator.

Lien said he had also conferred with Senior Presidential Adviser Wu Poh-hsiung, who had tried hard to be chosen as Lien's running mate, and had obtained his promise to support the party's nominees in the presidential election.
Lien's choice has caused some opposition within the ruling party, especially among anti-Siew legislators.
In this regard, Senior Presidential Adviser Hsu Li-teh said that Siew and Lien have been trying to defuse the opposition through various channels.
He said he expects the "Lien-Siew Election Campaign Headquarters" to be established in September, adding that the Lien-Siew ticket "is absolutely able to win the 2000 election."

So far, the prospective candidates for the presidential race include former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian (representing the Democratic Progressive Party), former Taiwan Governor James Soong, former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, Cheng Pang-chen (representing the Taiwan Independence Party), and writer-critic Li Ao (who is expected to represent the New Party).

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGHEST ESCALATORS IN TAIWAN TO BE INAUGURATED BY END OF YEAR

TEXT.P: Four of the highest escalators in Taiwan are expected to be inaugurated at an interchange mass transit station in eastern Taipei by the end of the year, the Department of Rapid Transit Systems said on Friday.

Department officials said that it will take people in the Chunghsiao Fuhsing Station one minute and 15 seconds to ride the escalators stretching from three floors below ground to the station's third floor.

In anticipation of the opening of part of the Nankang Line by the end of the year, the officials said that Chunghsiao Fuhsing Station will be the interchange for the Nankang Line and the Mucha Line, which connects Taipei City Zoo and Chung Shan Middle School.

A temporary Chunghsiao Fuhsing station now serves passengers traveling along the Mucha line. Construction of a permanent station building has been completed, and the installation of the four escalators is underway.
They said that the escalators, imported from Germany, measure 19.72 meters high and 49 meters long. They will be the highest escalators in Taiwan.

The Nankang line will run from the headquarters of Academia Sinica in Nankang to Panchiao, but only the 7.7-kilometer section between Taipei City Hall and Lungshan Temple will be open by the end of the year. A trip between those two points will take about 13 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE TAIWAN GROUP DONATES RELIEF GOODS TO TURKISH QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A private group from Taiwan on Friday donated packs of relief goods to Turkey to help the tens of thousands of people who were victimized by a deadly earthquake in the early morning of Aug. 17.

The donation, comprising 2,475 camping tents, 2,168 sleeping bags, 433 bed pads and 258 blankets, was received by Turkish Representative in Taiwan Teoman Surenkok in a ceremony presided over by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco Ou.

The relief goods, weighing a total of 14,200 kilograms, will be transported to Turkey separately by China Airlines and Turkish Airlines, according to Yang Chin-chu, chairman of the Meditation Association of the Republic of China, which offered the donation.

Speaking at the ceremony, Ou said the Turkish people have the deepest degree of sympathy and compassion from the government and people of the Republic of China in light of the devastating earthquake, which left more than 10,000 people dead and over 40,000 injured.

Ou lauded the Meditation Association of the ROC and other charity organizations in Taiwan for the love and compassion shown to needy and less-privileged people around the world. He said their efforts have won Taiwan more respect and friendship from the international community.
Surenkok expressed the Turkish people's gratitude toward Taiwan.

The Aug. 17 earthquake, measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale and centering on Turkey's northwestern industrial city of Izmit, killed some 15,000 people and injured or left missing 45,000 people. About 200,000 were left homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN HAPPY WITH HIS DECISION TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng, who resigned earlier this week, said on Friday that he is happy to have decided to leave the post so that he can start a new era in his life.
Sheu, however, refused to disclose future career plans, calling his affairs "personal."
He also denied media reports that his resignation was related to a "question of chemistry and understanding" between him and MAC Chairman Su Chi.
Su, through his aides, said Friday that he envies Sheu and his wife for deciding to retire simultaneously, and he denied that there is any difference of opinion between him and Sheu.
Sheu said his resignation is expected to go into effect Oct. 1, and all his superiors have agreed.

Sheu, 66, a graduate of National Taiwan University, has a master's degree from the University of Hawaii. He served as an economics liaison official at Republic of China representative offices in Britain and the United States before becoming director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade.
Before becoming MAC vice chairman, Sheu was vice economic affairs minister.

Commenting on remarks made by Macau's chief executive-designate Edmund Ho that the official name of Taiwan's liaison office in Macau should be changed after the Portuguese colony was returned to mainland Chinese rule on Dec. 20, Sheu, as MAC spokesman, said it is yet the time now to discuss the name change. MAC will pay close attention to this issue, he said.

On Beijing's suppression of Falun Gong followers on the Chinese mainland, Sheu said communist Chinese authorities should not focus all their efforts on economic reforms. Rather, he said, the policy makers there should do more to protect human rights and religious freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHOREOGRAPHER HONORED BY MAGSAYSAY AWARDS FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Lin Hwai-min, founder and choreographer of Taiwan's Cloud Gate Dance Theater Company, together with four other prominent Asians will be honored at the Ramon Magsaysay Awards presentation ceremony in Manila on Aug. 31.
Lin is a co-winner in the journalism, literature and creative communication arts category.

Lin left for Manila Friday morning. Manila's media and cultural circles are expecting to know the dedicated artist and successful theater manager better through speeches and interviews before the ceremony.

Lin's creative talent and his dedication to embracing Chinese culture and giving it a global and contemporary interpretation are well-recognized internationally. The Cloud Gate Dance Theater Company just returned from Berlin, where the company gave three performances of Lin's 1998 production "Moon Water" at the "Deutsche Oper." The performances were the highlight of this year's international ballet festival in Berlin.
The Ramon Magsaysay Awards, established in 1957 in memory of the late Philippine President Ramon Magsaysay, who died in a plane crash, has been described as Asia's Nobel Prizes.

Four awards will be presented this year. Lin and Filipino publisher Raul Locsin will share the award for journalism, literature and creative communication arts. Women's movement leader Angela Goes from Bangladesh will be awarded the prize for community leadership. The government service award winner is Tasneem Ahmed Sddigui, head of Pakistan's Sindh Katchi Abadi Authority, and the public service award winner is Rosa Rasal of the Philippine National Red Cross.

Lin is the second Republic of China national to be honored by the Ramon Magsaysay Awards Foundation. Publisher Diana Yin received the award for journalism, literature and creative communication arts years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 27, or the 17th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Cheng Cheng-kung, a Ming dynasty general better known to Westerners as Koxinga, is born in Japan. He sailed his troops to Taiwan in 1661 with the hope of fighting his way back to mainland China after the fall of the mainland to invading Manchu troops. Although he never realized his dream, he succeeded in opening up Taiwan for Chinese settlement.
1770: George Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, the German philosopher who proposed that truth is reached by a continuing dialectic, is born.
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800 meter Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 km away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1891: Russia and France sign an entente cordiale.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam, and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: A pilot's ejector seat prototype is successfully demonstrated at Wright Airport in the United States.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks in 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and properties caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIFT BETWEEN TAIWAN AND CHINA WIDENING: REPORT

TEXT.P: It is difficult to imagine Taiwan and mainland China reunifying unless the latter changes, said an American national newspaper Thursday.

USA Today reported from Taipei that, since President Lee Teng-hui declared on July 9 that mainland China and Taiwan should deal with each other as separate states and Beijing responded with threats to invade if Taiwan declares formal independence, Taiwanese nationalism has been rising.

The report said that the nationalism is hardly surprising, as "50 years of separation have pushed mainland China and Taiwan so far apart politically, socially and culturally that it is difficult to imagine them ever being part of the same whole -- unless China changes."

It seems that more and more people in Taiwan regard mainland China as a foreign land. In one of the latest national opinion polls in Taiwan, taken after President Lee's statement, 46 percent of Republic of China nationals identified themselves as strictly Taiwanese, up from 37 percent in April. Those identifying themselves as both Taiwanese and Chinese fell to 42 from 45 percent, and those identifying themselves as only Chinese edged down to 11.4 from 12.7 percent.

The American newspaper said, "Changing sentiments, unless curtailed, will make it tougher for mainland China and Taiwan to peacefully reunite," which both have agreed to do in the future and which the United States says is the preferred outcome.

The current tense situation across the Taiwan Strait is far from what the people of Taiwan want, according to the report. Before President Lee's statement, the majority of Taiwan's 22 million people were content to promise reunification and go about their lives, opinion polls showed.

But USA Today pointed out that despite reunification dreams, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are worlds apart: Taiwan is a vibrant democracy, while mainland China is a one-party state ruled by the Communist Party; Taiwan is one of the richest places in Asia, while mainland China is one of the poorest; the streets of Taipei are crowded with cars and motorcycles, while bicycles are the only mode of transportation many mainland Chinese can afford.

"There is little interest" for the people of Taiwan in news from mainland China, a news executive at a television station in Taipei was quoted as saying. Young people in Taiwan "don't think anything from mainland China is worth copying," said a Taipei business executive and mother of two teenagers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRIADS LINKED TO HACKING AT CANADIAN MISSION IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: A published report said Thursday that mainland Chinese nationals linked to organized crime broke into computers at the Canadian High Commission in Hong Kong in 1992 to hide their links with "triads," or the Chinese mafia.

The National Post and the Vancouver Province carried an identical report saying the Canadian government has for seven years covered up the security breach, in which commission staff were allegedly bribed to delete computer files.
A related concern is that some 2,000 stolen visa forms have been used for people, including criminals, to enter Canada illegally, the report said.
It quoted secret documents as saying at least 788 files from the Computer-Assisted Immigration Processing System (CAIPS) were deleted, and up to 2,000 blank visa forms have disappeared.

For seven years, the RCMP, Immigration Canada and the Department of Foreign Affairs are alleged to have kept a lid on the case, unwilling to reveal the extent of what several sources call a "breach of national security," the dailies said.
In 1992, Ottawa sent two officials to investigate, but they just carried out a cursory investigation, the Province quoted reliable sources as saying.

Despite evidence indicating security breaches by locally employed staff and the discovery of fake Immigration Canada stamps in one of their desks, neither of the two officials sent to Hong Kong recommended further investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD CAL CRASH VICTIM DIES
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Chou Chia-hung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong man surnamed Chou who suffered massive burns during a crash landing of a China Airlines (CAL) passenger liner last Sunday died on Friday, increasing to three the number of people who died from the crash.
According to hospital sources, Chou suffered burns to more than 55 percent of his body.
As of Friday 31 passengers and crew members injured in the crash remained hospitalized, with one in critical condition, the hospital sources said.

A CAL MD-11 jetliner crash-landed in flames and flipped upside down onto a runaway at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok Airport during the height of Typhoon Sam. Miraculously, the crash, the worst accident so far at Hong Kong's new airport, left only two dead and 211 injured before Chou's death on Friday.

Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Airport Administration reported that the removal of the wreckage of the ill-fated CAL MD-11 from the airport area hit another snag Friday as the debris was too big and too heavy to be towed by existing crane facilities.

Administration officials said the wreckage removal work has become even more difficult after days of torrential rainfall that helped to sink the wreckage into the earth. In addition, the weight of the debris has been increased as a result of residue from the material used to extinguish the flames.
An administration spokesman said it has been decided that the wreckage will be sawed into three parts before workers make any further moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN CONSORTIUM SAID HOPING TO SUPPLY LNG TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A major consortium in Australia will take part in a bid to supply liquefied natural gas to Taiwan , according to The Australian Financial Review.
In a dispatch from Hong Kong, it reported that Australia LNG (ALNG) will bid to take part in supplying about 1.8 million tons of LNG per year to Taiwan.

On Thursday, the daily reported that the Australian government was stalling the sales of LNG to Taiwan for fear of offending mainland China, which is expected to buy A$15 billion (US$10 billion) worth of Australian LNG starting from 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN-SIEW TICKET APPROVED IN KMT CENTRAL STANDING COMMITTEE MEETING

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomingtang on Friday approved Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew as party's ticket in the 2000 presidential election.

At the KMT's provisional Central Standing Committee meeting, the participants first heard reports by the party's Department of Organization Affairs, which reported that Lien garnered support from 96.33 percent of the 2,180 party delegates who voted last Saturday on the selection of the party's candidate.
The proposal was passed by means of resounding applause. Lien then recommended Premier Siew as his running mate, which was also passed in the same manner.
The Party National Congress will give the final stamp of approval on Aug. 29.
President Lee said the 2000 presidential election is crucial to the future development of the nation, and that the party must unify to ensure Lien and Siew win the election.
He stressed that he, in his capacity as party chairman, will work with all party members to fight tooth and nail for the party's victory.

Three Central Standing Committee members -- Koo Chen-fu, Wang You-cheng and Wang Jin-pyng -- spoke in the meeting. They lauded the Lien-Siew ticket as a correct and appropriate team, and they said they are confident of the pair's victory in the election.

Koo and Wang also said that there is no problem in regard to Siew's running, even though he is currently premier. Some legislators have questioned the premier's ability to balance the demands of his position with those of a strenuous campaign and have requested that Siew resign as premier if he accepts the nomination as Lien's running mate.
Both said that it would be perfectly plausible for a public official to run in a race without resigning his position, adding that there are many examples of officials who have done this.
Central Standing Committee member Wu Poh-hsiung, who sought to be Lien's running mate, and former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan did not attend Friday's meeting.
After the 30-minute meeting, Lien spoke to his supporters, who had thronged to the party's Headquarters.
Lien lauded the 60-year-old Siew as one who has served in various major government posts, adding that he has rich experience in both the administrative and legislative branches of government.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN SECRETARY-GENERAL CONDEMNS VIOLENCE IN E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan has condemned the escalating violence in East Timor and demanded that the Indonesian government ensure that an Aug. 30 ballot on the former Portuguese colony's future be held peacefully.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on Friday reported that Annan wants to see a peaceful ballot in East Timor and has asked Indonesia to ensure a successful vote in East Timor. The United Nations earlier delayed the vote from Aug. 22 to 30.
The United Nations in May brokered an arrangement between Indonesia and Portugal for a fair and peaceful ballot.

DOC.HEADLINE: PNG STUNNED BY REPORTS OF 30 BOYS RAPING CLASSMATES

TEXT.P: The animal-like rapings by 30 teenage boys of their female classmates en masse have stunned Papua New Guinea, The Sydney Morning Herald reported on Friday.
The daily reported that the 30 boys had gone on an "animal-like rampage" and raped 30 of their female classmates in a school outside Mount Hagen, causing a deep disturbance.
The daily quoted Malcolm Culligan, education director of the Highlands Province, as saying that he had "just no answers as to how such a deeply disturbing event could have occurred."

On Monday night at Togaba High School, about 10 kilometers west of Mt. Hagen, there was a disturbance at the school during which a classroom was burned to the ground. The school of 600 has 450 boarders who come down from the villages in the hills to live during the week, and after the fire the children returned to their dormitories, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN TROOPS READY TO EVACUATE AUSSIES FROM E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: Australian troops have been put on full alert and are preparing for the evacuation of some 200 Australians from East Timor as signs of violence are accelerating on the eve of the Aug. 30 ballot to decide the future of the former Portuguese colony.

Australian leaders, including Prime Minister John Howard and Defense Minister John Moore, have contacted their Indonesian counterparts and asked them to maintain peaceful balloting by providing law and order in East Timor.

Seven Timorese have been killed in the latest street violence as a result of a series of armed clashes between pro-independence and pro-Indonesian groups in Dili, capital of East Timor, and cities and towns this week.
The Australian Financial Review on Friday reported that if widespread violence erupts after the ballot, Australian troops may set for possible immediate deployment to East Timor.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-LANGUAGE `DREAMER' WEBSITE OPENS NEW YORK SITE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu and Huang Kuan-chun)

TEXT.P: The Chinese-language Internet website, "Dreamer's Media," presented by controversial Taiwan politician Sisy Chen, will open a separate site in New York on Sept. 1, providing local content to Chinese communities in North America.

Chen, the site's initiator, has previously served as head of the information department of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party and of the private non-profit Rising People Foundation. She enjoys fame as one of Taiwan's foremost feminists.
Lee Hung-chih, a board-member of the Dreamer's Media Corp., said on Thursday that since the website's founding last August, the number of visitors from around the world has increased enormously.

Each day, Lee said, www.dreamer.com receives more than 200,000 hits, and he noted that the website ranks as one of the most popular Chinese websites according to local search engines such as Yam and Kimo.

In addition to an efficient search engine, the Dreamer also contains the world's first data page -- named "iRose" -- designed especially for Chinese-speaking females. This page features feminist-oriented gender issues, said Lee.
Taipei-based Dreamer's Media has also developed a separate site operating from Shanghai to serve surfers in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.006 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at 31.858.
The local currency opened at 31.860 and was traded between 31.846 and 31.870.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$299 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAPID TRANSIT PASSENGERS MUST GET USED TO PINYIN TRANSLATIONS

TEXT.P: Passengers on Taipei's mass rapid transit (MRT) system will have to learn to read the pinyin romanization system for Chinese place names following a decision by the Taipei City Government.

Under the new spelling system, Yuanshan will be the only MRT station to retain its original English spelling. Other stations, for example Chunghsiao-Fuhsing, will be respelled as Zhongxiao-Fuxing. The English spelling changes will cost the city government an estimated NT$100 million.

However, since many stations are named after nearby institutions or landmarks, some controversy remains among the authorities in charge of the operation as to whether across-the-board changes should be made.

Replacing station names such as the Technology Building with the pinyin version -- Kejidalou -- for example, will make little sense to the foreign visitors for whom the translations are being provided.
The Bureau of Civil Affairs will study these special cases, including the station serving the City Government, and are expected to allow some exceptions to be made.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AIT TAIPEI DIRECTOR EXPECTED TO ASSUME POST WITHIN DAYS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), said on Friday that US policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged despite a minor personnel change.

Speaking at a press conference held exclusively for the Taiwan media, Burghardt, who is expected to assume his Taipei post at the end of August, said Taiwan has seen dramatic changes over the past two decades and has maintained close and cordial relations with the United States. "My job in Taipei is to further strengthen those relations," he said.

Burghardt stressed that US policy toward Taiwan, which is regulated by the Taiwan Relations Act, and the cross-Taiwan Strait relations that were stipulated in the three communiques signed between Washington and Beijing, remain unchanged.

Burghardt, who was scheduled to leave for his new post on Friday and formally assume the directorship of the AIT Taipei office on Tuesday, is the eighth local AIT chief since the institute was established in 1980.
He succeeds Darryl Johnson, who returned to the United States in July after his three-year tenure expired.

At the press conference, Burghardt said he feels honored to be appointed to the post at such a "good and exciting moment." He said he has met with relevant officials in the Clinton Administration over the last week to gain a deeper understanding of US interests in Taiwan.

He said that although he has not visited Taiwan since he left the island in 1977 after studying Mandarin Chinese for one year, he has constantly kept abreast of Taiwan affairs, and knows clearly that Taiwan has experienced dramatic changes over the last 20 years, with political democratization and a rapidly expanding free market-based economy.

Burghardt, the US consul general in Shanghai before being appointed the AIT Taipei director, is also an old acquaintance of Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, with whom he used to meet at least once a month.

He was appointed the American consul general in Shanghai in 1997, which gave him the status of minister-counselor in the United States Foreign Service. He had previously served as Deputy Chief of Mission at the US embassy in Manila from 1993 to 1996, and in Seoul from 1990 to 1993.

Burghardt's previous positions also included a stint with the National Security Council Staff as a special assistant to former President Ronald Reagan, and as senior director of Latin American affairs. His earlier Latin American experience included service at the US embassies in Honduras and Guatemala.

Burghardt was a political counselor in Beijing from 1987 to 1989. He has also worked as a political officer in Hong Kong and Saigon, and as deputy director of the State Department's Office of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia Affairs.

He was born in New York City in 1945 and grew up in the New York metropolitan area. He received a B.A. from Columbia College in 1967 and did graduate work at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs. He served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Colombia and elsewhere in South America before joining the foreign service in 1969.
Burghardt is married to the former Susan Day. They have two daughters. He speaks Mandarin, which he studied in Taichung, as well as Spanish, Vietnamese and French.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW NATIONAL PRESS COUNCIL CHAIRMAN ELECTED

TEXT.P: Board Chairman Yeh Ming-hsun of Shih Hsin University was elected as new chairman of the National Press Council (NPC) of the Republic of China on Thursday.
Yeh takes the vacancy left by the death of former NPC Chairman Pan Huan-kun, who died in May aged 83.

Meanwhile, Lu Yu-nu, associate professor and head of the Department of Mass Communications at Ming Chuan University, was elected as new secretary-general of NPC, replacing Lai Kuo-chou, who recently resigned from the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DEADLINE FOR TAIPEI-MANILA AVIATION TALKS

TEXT.P: The Philippines has declared that the aviation accord between Taipei and Manila launched in 1996 has not been suspended, an official of Taiwan's Minister of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

Answering a reporter's question Liu Yi-ming, deputy director of MOFA's East Asian and Pacific affairs department, said at a routine press conference that negotiations over the aviation right dispute between Taiwan and the Philippines will continue even if the two sides fail to reach consensus before Sept. 30.

Manila in early August threatened to scrap the air accord and stop allowing Taiwan carriers to ply Philippine routes from Sept. 30 if no new agreement was negotiated by then. It claimed that China Airlines and EVA Airways had violated the Taipei-Manila pact by carrying more passengers than allowed under the terms of the agreement.

A Philippine mission led by Foreign Assistant Secretary Franklin Ebdalin held talks with Taiwan officials on Aug. 14 in Taipei, in an attempt to smooth Taipei's ruffled feathers and its subsequent threat of economic sanctions.
Taiwan authorities were enraged by Manila's move, protesting that Manila violated international precedents that require a minimum of 12 months notice to terminate aviation pacts.

Liu said the two sides completed minutes of the meeting, with the Philippine side reiterating its respect for the existing Taipei-Manila bilateral aviation accord, and affirming that the agreement has not been revoked and is still valid.
In a further gesture of goodwill, the Philippine side also noted that Sept. 30 is not a deadline for the aviation negotiations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN CALLS FOR SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Amid the recent tension between Taiwan and mainland China, US Congressman Vito Fossella (R-NY) has issued a statement calling for support for Taiwan from the administration of US President Bill Clinton.

Fossella also condemned Beijing for rejecting an application by Pope John Paul II to visit Hong Kong last month, stressing that the United States should further help Taiwan maintain its democracy and prosperity at a time when Beijing is still seeking to deprive its people of basic religious freedom.

Clinton's spelling out of his "three noes" policy toward Taiwan last year during a visit to Shanghai has misled the Beijing leadership into believing that the United States will agree to its attempt to control Taiwan, Fossella pointed out.

Although Washington's "one China" policy acknowledges that there is only one China, which includes Taiwan, that does not represent formal recognition that Taiwan is part of communist China, he explained.

Pointing out that it was the sending of unclear messages to invaders which caused the First and Second World Wars and the Korean War, Fossella asserted that history should tell America that firmly supporting Taiwan will help prevent greater conflict in the Taiwan Strait in the future.
Fossella issued the statement after receiving information from ethnic Chinese US citizens relating to Beijing's repression of religious freedom in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING, WASHINGTON MAY INK ACCORD IN OCT. ON WTO BID

TEXT.P: Mainland China and the United States may ink an accord in October on Beijing's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), Administrative Vice Minister of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Lin Yi-fu said on Friday.

Lin's remarks were referring to concerns over whether US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin will meet at the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum leaders' summit to talk about Beijing's entry into the world trade regulatory body. The APEC forum will be held in Auckland, New Zealand, in mid September.
The MOEA official was responding to reporters' questions as he attended a seminar on the development of malls and the retailing industry in 1999.

Since Taiwan's WTO entry bid is tangled up with that of mainland China, whether Beijing is ready to resume talks with Washington, or even sign an agreement on its entry into the WTO, is being closely scrutinized by outsiders.

Although there has been no official information suggesting that Washington and Beijing will discuss mainland China's WTO bid during the APEC forum gathering, Lin said Clinton and Jiang are widely expected to use the opportunity to discuss the issue.
If events proceed smoothly, Beijing and Washington are likely to ink a WTO accord in October, Lin noted.

However, there are still more than 20 WTO member countries to date which have yet to reach bilateral agreements with Beijing on terms for entry, so that even if Beijing manages to clinch a deal with Washington over its membership, time is running short for the mainland to gain entry by the end of 1999, Lin pointed out.

It is deemed a tall order for Beijing and Washington to complete bilateral talks on market opening and tariff concessions in just a few months. However, if Beijing fails to win accession this year, it will have to wait for many more years to make a successful bid, as the price of entry is increasing all the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU CONSUMER PRICE INDEX FALLS 3.2 PC

TEXT.P: Macau's composite consumer price index fell 3.2 percent in the first seven months this year compared with the same period last year, the Macau Statistics and Census Department announced today.

According to Lusa News, the index dipped 0.3 percent between June and July. When compared with the same month last year, the index decreased 3.7 percent in July. The index fell 2.5 percent in the 12-month period ending in July from the same period.
Macau's inflation rate amounted to 0.2 percent last year and 3.5 percent in 1997, according to the Portuguese news agency. (Belle Chou)

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURERS CONFIDENT OF ECONOMIC RECOVERY: CEPD

TEXT.P: Nearly 24 percent of Taiwan's manufacturers took an optimistic view of the island's economic recovery, while 17 percent had the opposite opinion and 59 percent saw no change, according to the results of a July poll released on Friday.

The result of the survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) was the seventh consecutive month in which the optimists outnumbered the pessimists, although July manufacturing profits remained at 4.7 percent, the same figure as that recorded for June.
July manufacturing sales declined 3.7 percent compared to June, a 3.1 percent decrease from the same period of 1998, while new orders received fell 1.6 percent, according to the CEPD tallies.

Regarding non-economic factors that could negatively affect the business situation, such as an easing of tension between Taiwan and Mainland China, the CEPD said such moves would allow the manufacturing sector to become more confident of economic recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, INDEX DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.5 percent lower Friday, dragged down partly by an overnight decline on Wall Street and by heavy selling pressure at the 8,000-point level.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index dropped 43.6 points to close at 8,051.79 points, with a total of 2.51 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of NT$101.4 billion.
Cement issues enjoyed the only gains among the eight major categories, closing 0.5 percent higher.

Financial stocks reported the largest losses, ending the day down 1.3 percent; they were followed by textile shares, which were down 1 percent. The paper-making sector also finished 1 percent lower, while foodstuff stocks, electronics issues and construction shares all dropped 0.2 percent. Plastic and chemical stocks closed 0.1 percent lower.
The over-the-counter market shed 0.49 points to close at 176.21 points on a turnover of NT$6.78 billion.
Meanwhile, TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains Friday except for those for December, next March and next June.

TAIEX Index Futures for September rose 11 points to close at 8,145 points, with 2,626 contract transactions; those for October climbed 3 points to finish at 8,135 points, with 35 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December were down 21 points to end at 8,139 points, with 1 contract transaction; those for next March dropped 13 points to close at 8,190 points, with 2 contract transactions. There were no contract transactions registered for next June.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 8,134 points for September, 8,150 points for October, 8,160 points for December, 8,203 points for next March and 8,280 points for next June.

Electronics futures (TE) for September advanced 0.6 points to close at 372.8 points, with 594 contract transactions; those for October declined 2 points to finish at 370 points, with 4 contract transactions.
No transaction records for TE futures for other months were registered.
September financial futures (TF) fell 10 points to end at 1,160 points, with 104 contract transactions, while there were no transaction records for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY RECOVERING SLOWLY, BUT STILL UNSTABLE: CEPD

TEXT.P: An economic report judging Taiwan's business condition released on Friday by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) shows that while the economy is currently making an upturn, it remains unstable.

The business outlook report for July shows that the index of leading indicators, which gauges economic prospects for the next three to six months, climbed 0.1 percent from last month to 102.5 points, marking a new high since May 1998 and also posting a consecutive five-month increase, while the index of coincident indicators, which reflects present economic activity, declined 1.3 percent from June to 102.5 points.

The CEPD pointed out that while the indexes of the two indicators reflect inconsistencies, the business condition monitoring indicator for July flashed a green light representing steady growth, and the percentage of firms which anticipate bright prospects for the next three months rose to 24.
Taken overall, these factors signify that Taiwan's economy is well on the way to recovery, but is not yet steady enough.

Meanwhile, according to the latest statistics provided by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan's economy for the first half of 1999 grew 5.4 percent compared with the 4.7 percent in 1998.
In the second quarter alone, it reached 6.5 percent, due mainly to strong goods and services exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH SEMICONDUCTOR BUSINESSMEN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A French delegation comprised of representatives from semiconductor and electronic businesses is scheduled to visit Taiwan on Sept. 13 at the invitation of the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), CETRA officials said on Friday.
The officials said the delegation will attend meetings with local semiconductor businessmen to discuss strategic cooperation.
Several local companies have expressed interest in forging cooperation with European high-tech firms, they said.

Members of the French delegation will be ranking executives of well-known semiconductor manufacturing companies such as Phillips, Motorola, and Infineon Technology, an affiliate of the Siemens Group, according to the CETRA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: JULY BAD CHECKS REDUCED TO 7-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Dishonored checks and bills in Taiwan in July fell to 0.46 percent of the total number issued, statistics released on Friday by the Central Bank of China (CBC) shows.
The tallies mark a seven-year low and a drop of 0.02 percentage points from the previous month.

According to the statistics compiled by the Economic Research Department (ERD) of the CBC, 15.89 million checks and bills changed hands in July, posting a four-month high, 73,155 of which were dishonored, also a four-month high.
In terms of value, NT$3,624.8 billion-worth of checks and bills changed hands in July, again a four-month high, NT$16.5 billion-worth of which were dishonored, a two-month high.

Analyzing the main reasons why July's dishonored checks and bills fell to a seven-year low, an ERD executive cited an upturn in Taiwan's economy and a steady growth of exports, as well as a large decrease of checks and bills issued by local enterprises, which resulted in an significant enhancement of private credit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVINCE, US CONNECTICUT STATE TO FORGE SISTERLY TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, central Taiwan, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Province will sign an agreement here on Sept. 2 with the US state of Connecticut to forge sisterly ties.

Led by Chinese-American Dr. Henry Lee, a delegation from Connecticut, including the adviser to the state governor, the attorney general of Connecticut, as well as several state senators and representatives, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on Aug. 31 for the ceremony.

Another US delegation from the state of Iowa, led by Governor Tom Vilsack, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan in September to call on Taiwan Provincial Governor Chao Shou-po to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the establishment of sisterly ties between Taiwan Province and the state of Iowa.
The Taiwan Provincial Government will entertain the delegation from Iowa at a luncheon on Sept. 22 at the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG SAID TO BE CONSIDERING WU POH-HSIUNG FOR VP

TEXT.P: Proving the idiom -- politics makes strange bedfellows -- independent presidential aspirant James Soong is said to be eyeing former political rival and the current Senior Adviser to President Lee, Wu Poh-hsiung as his running mate in the 2000 presidential election.
Local mass media was awash with reports Friday that Soong's aides had contacted Wu's staff to explore the possibility of forming a team comprised of the two former KMT secretary generals.
The Lien-Siew ticket was approved by the KMT Central Standing Committee on Friday morning.
Wu denied on Friday that Soong had ever contacted him but stopped short of shutting the door completely on a possible pairing with the former governor.
In a press conference Friday afternoon Wu denounced as "insulting" speculation that he has agreed to support the Lien-Siew ticket in return for a high position in a Lien administration.
Meanwhile Soong kept a tight lid on his desired running mate. Stalling over questions whether he would choose Wu, Soong simply said, "we certainly could support each other."
Wu, who in 1993 aspired to be the KMT standard bearer in the first-ever Taiwan Provincial governor election, saw his hope dashed by Soong who won the KMT nomination and the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA PROTESTS AUSSIE FM MEETING WITH WEI JINGSHEN

TEXT.P: China has strongly protested Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer for meeting with Chinese dissident leader Wei Jingsheng in his Canberra office this week.
The protest was lodged by the Chinese embassy in Canberra, an informed source said on Friday.

A spokesman for the Chinese embassy said Wei was imprisoned in China on charges of subversion and that he has been participating in anti-China movements and activities since he was allowed to go abroad in late 1997. His activities have caused a great damage to the interests of Chinese people in the mainland, the spokesman said.

The spokesman said the Chinese government was strongly dissatisfied with Downer's meeting with Wei because Beijing has made efforts to improve its human rights records while achieving great success in the political, economic and cultural fields.

But political experts here said the spokesman was distorting the truth. Chinese authorities are alleged to have returned to their previous policy of arresting dissidents and leaders of the Falun Gong sect in the mainland. PETER CHEN

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ROC MINISTERS TO ATTEND APEC MEETING IN AUCKLAND

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Finance Minister Paul Chiu will attend the annual ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Auckland, New Zealand Sept. 9-10.
The ROC's APEC mission, to be headed by the two ministers, will consist of some 50 officials from various ministries of the Cabinet.

An official with the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that major topics at this year's meeting include the expansion of the region's business opportunities, consolidating markets and broadening public support for APEC.
The 2000 round of negotiations of the World Trade Organization (WTO) will also be discussed at the ministerial meeting, the official added.
Following the ministerial meeting, an informal leadership conference will be held.
ROC President Lee Teng-hui, who will not take part in the conference because of opposition from Beijing, will be represented by Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang.
As in the past, Chiang is expected to take advantage of the opportunity to hold talks with the leaders of several friendly APEC member countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE HIJACKER TO BE REPATRIATED

TEXT.P: A pilot of mainland China's Air China, who hijacked an passenger plane to Taiwan in 1998, was sent to a detention center in Hsinchu County on Friday pending repatriation to mainland China after serving out his 10-month imprisonment in Taiwan.
Yuan Bin, 31, diverted an Rangoon-bound Air China plane to Taiwan, on Oct. 28, 1998. His wife, Xu Mei, was on board.
He was sentenced to 10 months in prison which ended on Friday.
He and his wife will be repatriated to mainland China as is the standard under Taiwan legal procedures.
Xu has been detained in Hsinchu detention center for four months. She was found guilty of conspiring with Yuan to carry out the hijacking.
After being deported to mainland China, Yuan will stand trial again and face an maximum punishment of 15 additional years in prison because Beijing doesn't recognize Taiwan's judicial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 2ND-LARGEST SOURCE OF TOURIST ARRIVALS FOR HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Belle Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: More than 900,000 foreign tourists visited Hong Kong in July 1999, with 19 percent of them coming from Taiwan, the second-highest level among all foreign arrivals, tallies released on Friday by the Hong Kong Tourist Association showed.

A total of 913,734 foreign tourists traveled to the former British colony last month, bringing to 5.95 million the aggregate number of the total foreign arrivals for the period from January to July, up 11.1 percent from the same period of 1998, according to the same statistics.

Tourists from mainland China were Hong Kong's largest source of foreign arrivals during the first seven months of this year, accounting for 30 percent of the total, while Japanese travelers ranked third by making up 9 percent, the tallies found.

In July alone, the number of mainland Chinese tourists visiting Hong Kong posted a 10.9 percent increase on a year-to-year basis, while the number of travelers from Japan fell by 10 percent, the association said.

It attributed the rise in mainland Chinese visitors to the success of large-scale promotional activities held across the mainland before the summer, and pointed out that higher airfares on the Japan-Hong Kong route and lingering economic uncertainties in Japan were the major factors behind the drop of tourist arrivals from that country.
