DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY ORDERS 11 US-MADE ANTI-SUBMARINE HELICOPTERS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy has ordered 11 S-70C anti-submarine helicopters from the United States which be will used to form a second anti-submarine aviation group when they are delivered next year, a navy officer said on Friday.
According to the officer, the navy has established an aviation command to step up its anti-submarine capability.

In addition to the S-2T anti-submarine aircraft transferred from the air force, the naval aviation command already possesses nine S-70C anti-submarine helicopters, being deployed aboard the French-made La Fayette frigates and the domestically-made Cheng-kung frigates.
The naval aviation command plans to form a second anti-submarine group when the S-70C helicopters are delivered, said the officer.
The all-weather S-70C helicopter has a patrol speed of 100 knots per hour. They are able to fly for up to four and a half hours when additional fuel tanks are attached.

In the wake of ROC President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of Taiwan-mainland relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" early last month, cross-Taiwan Strait tension escalated as jet fighters from both sides increased their patrol sorties over the strait.

But the naval officer said there have no signs that mainland Chinese submarines were operating in the Taiwan Strait during the past year, adding that no unusual mainland naval movements were detected following Lee's state-to-state statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PHILIPPINE ECON. CO-OP CONFERENCE TO BE HELD ON SEPT. 1-3

TEXT.P: The Republic of China-Philippine economic cooperative conference is slated to be held in Taipei Sept. 1-3 with seven major subjects on the agenda.
The conference will be jointly presided over by ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Philippine Trade and Industry Minister Jose Pardo.

The seven major subjects are the promotion of investments, economics and trade, agriculture and fishery, labor hiring, developing the Subic Bay, avoiding double taxation and a customs bond entry agreement.

In order to promote bilateral investments, the Philippine side hopes that Taiwan businessmen will strengthen their investments in the Cagayan Special Economic Zone, Bataan and in northern Luzon Island.

As to economic and trade issues, the Philippine side will urge Taiwan to stop the quarantining of Philippine bananas and mangoes exported to Taiwan. They also want Taiwan to strengthen its bilateral cooperation on sugar manufacturing.
With regard to agricultural and fishery issues, the Philippine side hopes Taiwan will help develop the gardening, florist and mushroom industries in their country.
On the issue of Filipino labor in Taiwan, the Philippine side hopes Taiwan managers will directly sign a memorandum on hiring.
ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said the ROC side will place an importance on the signing of an agreement on the avoidance of double taxation and a bond entry agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 28, or the 18th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues and national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration committed to furthering the civil rights cause.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during their exhibition to a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt: sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee passed the Lien-Siew ticket for the 2000 presidential election at an extraordinary meeting on Friday.
The China Times:
Prosecutor demanded a 12-year jail term for Lo Chih-hao, a former official with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, on charges of leaking national secrets.
The United Daily News:
The 15th KMT National Congress opened on Saturday to endorse the party's presidential ticket; popular Hakka politician Wu Poh-hsiung was absent from the meeting after losing his vice presidential bid.
The Liberty Times:
President Lee Teng-hui, also KMT chairman, said he is fully confident with the Lien-Siew ticket.
The Commons Daily:
The anti-Premier Vincent Siew forces within the ruling party have faded into obscurity.
The China Post:
Lien-Siew ticket announced; premier's candidacy continues party line of conservatism.
The Taiwan News:
Lien, Siew joins together; KMT committee backs choice of premier for vice presidential spot on party's ticket.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PREDICTS 5.7 PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew predicted on Saturday that Taiwan's economic growth this year will be 5.7 percent, topping the four Asian dragons -- Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea.
Siew made the optimistic remark on the island's economic prospects during an address at the opening in Taipei of the 15th Kuomintang National Congress.
Speaking on the theme of "entering the new era in stability, justice, prosperity and creativity," Siew said that continued economic growth is the key to whether the nation can continue to develop.

He said that over the past year, the world economy has remained sluggish in the wake of the regional financial storm which started in mid-1997, but noted that Taiwan has managed to maintain a growth rate of 4.7 percent, representing moderate growth when compared to the stagnant or even negative growth suffered by many other nations.

He said that since the beginning of the year, the development of the world economy gives cause for cautious optimism, and Taiwan's domestic consumption and investment have continued, leading him to his 5.7 percent growth prediction for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE DO NOT WANT TO BE CENTENARIANS: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 70 percent of the people of Taiwan do not want to live to be 100 years old, according to the results of a recent survey released on Saturday.

Some 34.2 percent of the people surveyed said they worry most about becoming ill or disabled in their old age, ahead of 28 percent who said they are not particularly worried, while around 40 percent expressed a lack of confidence with Taiwan's medical care.

At the same time, nearly 30 percent of the respondents said they feel anxious and uncertain about becoming old, while 53.6 percent of those polled aged below 65 think they will have a comfortable life in old age. Meanwhile, 74.2 percent of the respondents currently aged over 65 said they feel happy in their day-to-day lives.

Most of those surveyed said they expect to continue living with their spouses or on their own when they are old, while quite a few of them (more men than women), also expressed willingness to live with their children in their dotage, the survey found.

Although 30 percent of the respondents said they had never given much thought about how long will they live, most said they hope to be able to live to at least 70 years, according to the survey. More than 62 percent cited health as the most significant issue in old age, while a stable income and a positive attitude toward life were also cited as important factors in a happy retirement.

As to the question of the biggest potential threat to their lives in old age, Taiwan's relations with mainland China, environmental pollution, social violence and public security were cited as the four leading grave concerns.
More than half of the respondents said they believe that taking exercise, eating healthily and maintaining an upbeat mood are essential to good health, according to the poll.

The islandwide public opinion poll conducted by a local monthly magazine also pointed out that despite the fact that Taiwan is already a graying society, only about 20 percent of the island's residents will make provisions for their evening years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO ATTEND PANAMA'S PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew, traveling at the head of a 16-member delegation, is scheduled to arrive here on Tuesday to attend Wednesday's inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso.

During its four-day visit, the delegation will visit Panamanian business leaders, call at the Colon Free Trade Zone and the Taiwan-funded Fort David Export Processing Zone, and hold seminars with Panamanian and Taiwan businessmen.

As the United States will cede the jurisdiction of the Panama Canal to the Panamanian government by the end of this year, Panama Canal authorities will also brief the delegation as part of efforts to court Taiwan investment in the Canal Zone.

As the Panama Canal provides a junction point between the Pacific and Atlantic oceans, the export processing, transshipment and tourism industries of this central American country are especially suitable for Taiwan investment, trade officials with the ROC Embassy here said.
Upon leaving Panama, the delegation will proceed to El Salvador, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, all of which are ROC diplomatic allies in the region, to seek further trade and investment opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPENS 15TH NATIONAL CONGRESS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Saturday convened the second meeting of its 15th National Congress, to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's ticket for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Lien and Siew are, respectively, the country's incumbent vice president and premier.

Addressing the opening ceremony, KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who serves concurrently as ROC president, called on party members to devote all their efforts to help Lien and Siew win an overwhelming victory in the election slated for March next year.

During his address, Lee described the upcoming national election for the ROC's 10th head of state as the most influential vote concerning the country's future development, and said victory should be listed as the KMT's most important political mission, noting that winning the campaign will further intensify the KMT's power base.
He stated his conviction that the Lien-Siew team is the party's optimum ticket in the 2000 presidential election, and claimed that they are also the candidates most favored by the people of Taiwan.

Participants in the two-day National Congress will review key political administration and crucial party affairs, and will decide upon members of the Central Advisory Council nominated by the party chairman, as well as approving the nomination of the presidential candidates on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFECT OF HIGHER CRUDE PRICES ON DOMESTIC PRICES YET TO EMERGE: MOEA

TEXT.P: The effect of a hike in the price of crude oil on domestic prices will gradually emerge over time, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Saturday.

MOEA officials said that since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) reached agreement to cut production, global petroleum prices have begun to surge, citing as an example the fact that Western Texas crude oil sold for US$11.29 per barrel in December, but was selling recently for more than US$20 per barrel.

The officials noted that although the effect on the domestic economy of fluctuations in crude prices has been less than during past energy crises, as the production value of Taiwan's petroleum and chemical industry accounts for one-third of gross domestic product, the full effect will gradually emerge.

However, they pointed out that fortunately, due to a 6.43-percent drop in labor costs in the manufacturing industry in the first five months of the year, coupled with a labor productivity increase of 8.34 percent, it is estimated that domestic prices, although facing upward pressure, will still be able to maintain stable levels.

The officials said that the rebound in world crude prices will help stabilize the economies of newly developed countries, and will help prevent the world from plunging into another economic recession.
They said that a crude price increase will help the refinery and petroleum and chemical industries, as well as ease the pressure of economic recession.

But the MOEA experts also warned that if the price hike is too big, it will have a detrimental effect on the international balance of payments, economic development, and domestic prices of such nations as Japan and Taiwan, which rely heavily on crude imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: 33% OF LOCAL WOMEN WORRIED ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT WAR: POLL

TEXT.P: Thirty-three percent of local women responding to a recent public opinion poll said they are worrying about military confrontation across the Taiwan Strait over the "special state-to-state relationship" controversy.
The telephone survey was conducted by the Awakening Foundation from Aug. 12-14, with 1,053 valid replies collected.
Survey results showed that 74 percent of those interviewed said they knew President Lee Teng-hui's declaration of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship."
A further analysis found that the number of male respondents who have heard of the "special state-to-state" theory exceeded the number of their female counterparts by 7 percent.
Career women also far outnumbered homemakers in terms of their knowledge of the "special state-to-state" theory, 81 percent to 64 percent.

Asked whether they worry about an eruption of military conflict between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait due to President Lee's "special state-to-state" definition, 60 percent of female respondents and 70 percent of male respondents said they don't worry about that.

In contrast, 33 percent of women interviewed said they worry about the possibility of a cross-strait war sparked the "special state-to-state" fracas, while only 22 percent of male respondents said they have such a worry.

Survey results also showed that 35 percent of those who have relatives serving in the military are worrying about their relatives' safety amid the current cross-strait fracas over the "special state-to-state" theory.

According to the survey, women who said they worry about their relatives' safety outnumbered male respondents by 13 percent. Moreover, as high as 53 percent of homemakers interviewed said they worry about their relatives' safety.

Meanwhile, 53 percent of all respondents said they will encourage their families or relatives to join the military to defend their homeland if a cross-strait war erupts, while 30 percent said they have never thought about such an issue.

On this issue, male respondents are more willing than their female counterparts to encourage their relatives to serve in the military to help defend Taiwan. Career women also outnumbered homemakers in this regard.

Asked how to resolve the cross-strait dispute over the "special state-to-state" theory, the majority of respondents, regardless of their gender, support for peaceful resolution through consultations and exchanges. Only 2.4 percent opt for the use of force to settle the fracas.
Analyzing the survey results, Awakening Foundation Chairman Wang Ju-hsuan said women are more peace-loving, more disgusted with war and more treasure lives than their male counterparts.

Chiu Chao-lin, an Academia Sinica researcher, said 99 percent of wars in human history were determined by men and that women's views on military confrontation have seldom received serious attention. "I think policymakers should be due attention to women's opinions in the future," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-OWNED ENTERPRISE WORKERS DEMAND A SLOW DOWN OF PRIVATIZATION

TEXT.P: Thousands of employees from state-owned enterprises gathered in downtown Taipei on Saturday to demand the privatization of state-owned enterprises be slowed down.

The protesters rallied at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall and walked toward Taipei World Trade Center, near Taipei International Convention Center, where the ruling party Kuomintang was holding its 15th national congress to give the final stamp of approval on Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew to run on the party's ticket in the 2000 presidential election.
The protesters shouted slogans along the way demanding that Lien and Siew pay attention to the rights of laborers and review the privatization policy of state-owned enterprises.

They said that if the Lien-Siew ticket turns a deaf ear to their demands, they risked losing the support of 300,000 state-owned enterprise employees and their dependents in the presidential election next year.
The protesters had come from petroleum, telecommunication, as well as banking industry associations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE OPENS PINGTUNG AIR BASE FOR PUBLIC VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force on Saturday opened its Pingtung air base in southern Taiwan for public visit.
A number of warplanes, including E2T airborne early warning planes, C-130 transports, S2T anti-submarine planes, AT-3 trainers and F-5E fighter jets, were parked on the apron for public view.

The Pingtung air base also invited the noted Shen Lung (Miracle Dragon) squadron to perform free-style parachuting and other sensational airborne acrobatic feats, winning critical acclaim from audience.
More than 10,000 residents in the southern Taiwan county visited the air base.

The event was part of the air force's celebrations of the 62nd anniversary of the "Aug. 14" victory, which refers to the defeat of Japanese attack on the ROC's air base in Chienchiao in southeastern China during World War II. The public display of warplanes was originally scheduled to take place in July, but was postponed to Saturday because of poor weather conditions in the Pingtung area over the past weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW REPORTS ADMINISTRATION RESULTS TO KMT NATIONAL CONGRESS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew delivered a report on the achievements of his administration at the ruling Kuomintang party's second meeting of the 15th National Congress (NC) Saturday in his capacity as a party member.
In the report titled "Approaching a New Century with Stability, Justice, Prosperity and Innovation," Siew pledged that his cabinet will continue its devotion to modernizing the country.

Siew reported that over the past two years his team has completed such varied missions as the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government in order to pursue efficiency, overcoming the tough economic challenges that followed the Asian economic meltdown and carrying out social reconstruction and educational reforms to upgrade the people's quality of living.

Siew added his executive departments have aggressively pursued maintaining the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait region, as well as promoting pragmatic diplomatic relationships between Taiwan and foreign countries.

Siew then revealed the four goals of his future administration: bringing more justice and stability to society, pursuing a more mature economy while maintaining the current prosperity, putting into practice a creative and multifarious cultural educational system and enhancing national security.
Siew assumed his current post in September 1997, vowing to strengthen national defense while seeking "peaceful and dignified" relations with mainland China.
In his Saturday report, the premier stressed that his mainland policy of seeking constructive dialogue and exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will not change.

In addition, Siew praised President Lee Teng-hui's description of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in a German radio interview on July 9 as a significant move that clearly defines the sovereign status of Taiwan.

Although the statement has caused an irrational response from Beijing, it has won the overwhelming support of the Taiwan people, Siew said in reiterating the government will continue to try and gain support from the international community for a redefinition of the Taiwan-Beijing relationship.
The NC meeting will last two days with the participants on Sunday giving their final stamp of approval to the 2000 presidential ticket of Vice President Lien Chan and Siew.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON `COMMITTED' TO TAIWAN'S DEFENSE: WEINBERGER

TEXT.P: One thing should be made eminently clear to mainland China: "The United States is absolutely committed to the defense of Taiwan and will not permit it to be overrun," stressed a former US defense secretary.

In the September issue of Forbes magazine, Casper Weinberger said the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) strongly implies this, but passage of the proposed Taiwan Security Enhancement Act would send the message unmistakably.

Weinberger said that because the Clinton administration has wavered too often regarding Taiwan, "there is now a genuine fear that China might believe it could, with impunity, attack Taiwan, while we sit by helplessly, seeking a UN vote of disapproval, but doing little else."

Were this to happen, the former US defense chief warned, "it would be the crowning error of all this administration's foreign policy mistakes, and a legacy of catastrophic proportions for Mr. (Bill) Clinton."

Weinberger noted that after Britain and France sold out Czechoslovakia to secure the infamous Munich Pact with Hitler and Mussolini in 1938, some Czech leaders were incautious enough to protest their loss of freedom and the dismemberment of their country. In reporting those objections to Neville Chamberlain, British foreign office officials referred to the protesters as "these blasted Czechs."

He was reminded of that when Secretary of State Madeleine Albright all but ground her teeth in public annoyance at Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui and sent envoys to Taipei to remind him of the error of his ways, said Weinberger.

Lee's offense? Weinberger pointed out that he had restated an obvious truth -- that Taiwan's relationship with the mainland is one of "state to state." Lee's very able negotiator in the cross-strait talks with Beijing, Koo Chen-fu, said exactly the same thing. Koo reiterated that while both sides seek reunification, Taiwan will only consider it after the mainland moves toward democracy, freedom and rights for the individual.

Weinberger added that the US response has been to blame Taiwan -- as Czechoslovakia was blamed in 1938 -- and demand Lee retract his statements. "Our position seems designed to continue the appeasement of China that President Clinton began on his ill-fated trip there in 1998 ... and we are encouraging the PRC in an extremely dangerous way."

He continued that Taiwan has been making increasingly urgent requests for defensive arms, particularly an early warning radar system, but the Clinton administration has consistently answered the requests with excuses and delays. Against this backdrop, Senators Jesse Helms (R-NC) and Robert Torricelli (D-NJ) have introduced The Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, which would lift restrictions on the sales of defensive arms to Taiwan and authorize sales of key weapons systems, including theater missile defenses.

The former defense secretary said the TRA, enacted after President Jimmy Carter abandoned Taiwan, was carefully crafted to leave the US room to be able to come to Taiwan's aid. Unfortunately, many people mistakenly believe the Aug. 17, 1982 Communique with Beijing overrides and reverses the major provisions of the TRA because the Communique states that the US eventually will end arms sales to Taiwan.

Weinberger said he is convinced that the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act would clear up any misconceptions. Hearings on the bill have amply shown the need for such legislation. There has been surprising support for the principles of the bill from the Democratic side, but in view of the lack of time before Congress adjourns for the holidays, it is doubtful the measure can be enacted this year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST TIMOR LEADER APPEALS FOR PRESSURE ON INDONESIA

TEXT.P: A leading independence campaigner in East Timor has appealed to the United States and Australia to take tougher action against Indonesia after Jakarta vetoed a foreign peacekeeping force for the violence-wrecked territory.

The appeal was made by Nobel peace prize winner Jose Ramos Horta, who said the international community will have to bear responsibility for the loss of life due to the escalating violence in Dili and other cities and towns in the former Portuguese colony.

Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas on Friday said Indonesia would allow an additional 430 international police and military liaison officers into East Timor after the Aug. 30 ballot to determine the future of East Timor, but he flatly ruled out a foreign armed peacekeeping force being allowed in.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA-AUSTRALIA TO SIGN ADOPTION ACCORD

TEXT.P: Australian couples will be allowed to adopt Chinese babies, mainly girls, when Beijing and Canberra formally sign an agreement giving access to up to one million orphaned children.
Officials from both Australia and mainland China are now putting the finishing touches to the adoption agreement.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday quoted a spokesman for the Federal Attorney-General's department as saying that the agreement will hopefully be signed at a meeting in Beijing in early September.
Mainland China has become a leading source for adoption because many parents there do not want to raise daughters as a result of Beijing's one-child policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND'S ECONOMY SEEN PERFORMING BETTER

TEXT.P: New Zealand's economy is expected to grow between 3.7 percent and 4.3 percent next year thanks to rising exports of manufactured products and tourism, the Australian Financial Review reported on Saturday.
In a dispatch from Wellington, the daily reported that the forecasts were made by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand and the National Bank.

Government officials attributed the stronger performance to economic rebounds by New Zealand's trading partners, who are expected to increase their imports of primary products and manufactured goods from New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA REPLACES COMMANDERS IN EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: Indonesia, facing international condemnation, has suddenly replaced senior military commanders in riot-torn East Timor as thousands of Timorese rush to escape disputed areas.

In a dispatch from Dili, the capital of the former Portuguese colony, the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday quoted Western diplomats as saying that intense international pressure is behind the recalls ahead of the Aug. 30 ballot to decide the future of East Timor.
UN Secretary General Kofi Annan on Friday made a scathing attack on Indonesia and demanded that it take steps to restore law and order and ensure a peaceful vote on Monday.
He described the renewed violence by pro-Indonesia militias in Dili as "appalling."

DOC.HEADLINE: CRASH HELMETS HELP CUT TRAFFIC ACCIDENT DEATH TOLL

TEXT.P: The death toll of motorcycle-related traffic accidents has declined significantly since the law requiring all motorcyclists to wear crash helmets took effect on June 1, 1997, the ROC External Injury Prevention Association said on Saturday.

Chiu Wen-ta, president of the association, said accident-caused injury was No. 3 cause of deaths in Taiwan between 1991 and 1997. "It declined to the No. 4 place for the first time in 1998 thanks to the legislation of the crash helmets law," he reported.

Noting that the implementation of the law has helped cut the accident-related death toll by more than 2,000 over the past three years, Chiu said the crash helmet law has set the most stunning achievement in the domestic public health history.
Quoting official tallies, Chiu said the death toll of motorcycle-related accidents exceeded 7,000 persons annually between 1988 and 1997.

Nevertheless, Chiu said, the death toll dropped to slightly more than 58,000 in 1998, realizing the goal of the safety helmets legislation which is aimed at cutting the motorcycle-related death toll by at least 1,000 a year.

In addition, Chiu said, the ratio of head injuries caused by motorcycle-related accidents has also decreased by 33 percent during the same period. Moreover, the head injuries-related surgeries involving motorcyclists have fallen 42 percent.
In all, Chiu said the implementation of the compulsory wearing of crash helmets has helped the Central Health Insurance Bureau save about NT$100 million (US$3.13 million) in medical bills per month.

Pai Lu, an associate professor with National Defense Medical College, said the accident-related mortality rate has been very high and that traffic accident has topped all other accidents in terms of death toll.
Official tallies show that the annual traffic accident mortality rate reached 40 persons per 100,000 between 1994 and 1997.
Pai said even though accidents fell to the No. 4 cause of deaths in Taiwan last year, the number of people killed in accidents still reached 10,973, or one death per 48 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CULTURAL FESTIVAL TO BE HELD IN TORRANCE, CA.

TEXT.P: The first annual Taiwan Cultural Festival will take place September 12th at the Torrance Cultural Center, at Torrance, California.
Visitors to the festival will be able to sample authentic Taiwanese cuisine at the many food stalls that will be hosted by local Taiwanese restaurants.
A replica of an original Taiwanese Night Market will provide visitors a chance to browse and purchase wares that are made in Taiwan.
Entertainment will be an event with music, dance, puppet shows, and performances from various Taiwanese groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPENS 15TH NATIONAL CONGRESS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Saturday convened the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress, to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's ticket for the 2000 presidential election.
Lien and Siew are, respectively, the country's incumbent vice president and premier.
KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui called on party members to spare no effort in helping the Lien-Siew ticket win an overwhelming victory in the election slated for March of next year.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Lee described the upcoming national election for the ROC's 10th head of state as the most important vote concerning the country's future development. He said victory should be listed as the KMT's most important political mission, noting that winning the campaign will further intensify the KMT's power base.
Lee stated his conviction that the Lien-Siew team is the party's optimum ticket for the 2000 presidential election, adding that they are also the candidates most favored by the people of Taiwan.
Lee, who serves concurrently as ROC president, arrived at the venue at 8:30 a.m., and received a warm welcome from dozens of young people serving in the party's youth affairs division.

Presenting a traditional heavy lamp representing good luck to the audience, Lee encouraged more young people to enter the KMT, saying the party is the vehicle that will allow them to fulfill their creative dreams.

During his address, Chairman Lee endorsed the KMT's pragmatic and aggressive policies as well as its efforts for a unified organization. Lee cited party unity as the reason why the KMT was successful in elections held last year.
The election victories proved the KMT is supported by most people in Taiwan, Lee said.

He went on to say that the KMT has successfully helped the country promote political democracy and stabilize the economy, expand the ROC's role in the international community and enhance national security.

In dealing with mainland China, Lee said, the party has also gradually opened a new era of exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in a pragmatic manner. He added that in the future the party will promote goodwill and equal status during cross-strait dialogues in the hope of narrowing differences between the two sides.

As the party that built the Republic of China in 1911, Lee said, the KMT is responsible for the country's existence and prosperity. The KMT is obliged to give the people of Taiwan a more just and democratic society, Lee concluded.

Participants in the two-day National Congress will review key political administration measures and crucial inter-party affairs. They will then confirm or deny membership into the Central Advisory Council on the nominees whom were selected by Lee before approving of the Lien-Siew presidential ticket on Sunday.
The first plenary session of the 15th KMT National Congress was convened in August, 1997. At that time, Lee was re-elected chairman of the party with 93 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW DEPARTS FOR PANAMA FOR INAUGURATION OF NEW PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew will depart for Panama on Monday for the Sept. 1 inauguration of newly elected President Mireya Moscoso.
Siew, whose candidacy for vice president was approved by the ruling Kuomintang on Sunday, will attend the inauguration as President Lee Teng-hui's special envoy.

Besides meeting with Moscoso, outgoing President Ernesto Perez Balladarez and other Panamanian leaders, Siew is expected to meet with Nicaragua's president Arnoldo Aleman Lacayo, head of another ally of the Republic of China in Latin America, on the fringes of the inauguration, before returning to Taipei on Sept. 6.
He will stop briefly in Los Angels and Houston on his way to and from Panama.

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Lee tells KMT congress: Ensure Line-Siew's overwhelming victory in Taiwan's presidential election.

KMT opens congress with an absence of heavyweights; Lee strongly endorses Lien-Siew ticket.
The United Daily News:
Lee plugs Lien-Siew ticket before KMT congress, which is also expected to pass a resolution on state-to-state ties with Beijing.
The Liberty Times:
KMT congress to approve Lien-Siew ticket.
The Commons Daily:
Chen Shui-bian stages his first election rally, drawing 100,000 supporters.
The China Post:
Factional strife simmers as KMT kicks off congress.
The Taiwan News:
At mass rally, Chen promises vigor, stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN GERMANY PREPARING TO MOVE TO BERLIN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Kuo Wu-hueng and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in Germany is actively preparing to move to Berlin, the new capital of unified Germany.
The future site of the ROC's representative office is located in Markgrafenstr, eastern Berlin, across from a luxurious opera house and two grand churches.
Because Germany's federal Parliament and government have moved to Berlin, many countries' embassies have also been actively constructing new embassies in Berlin.

Although the ROC has no diplomatic relations with Germany, economic, trade and cultural exchanges between the two countries have been more and more frequent. Therefore, the setting up of a new office in Berlin is a matter of significance.

It is expected that under the supervision of Representative Charles King, the staff of the ROC's representative office will formally begin their operations at the new office in Berlin in early October.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE HEAD VOWS TO PROMOTE PARLIAMENTARY DIPLOMACY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will actively promote cooperative relations with its counterparts in Europe, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said on Sunday.

Wang expressed his hope that a push for parliamentarian cooperation between Taiwan's legislature and European parliaments would help bring about substantial relations with them, noting that Beijing has tried every means to squeeze Taiwan diplomatically.
Wang said that promoting parliamentarian cooperation with European countries would be the focus of the next stage of his work.
Wang cited as an example of such cooperation recent exchange visits by parliamentary delegations from the Republic of China and Macedonia.
He said that both sides agreed that each should visit the other side every three months to establish closer relations.
Sources said that Wang has sought to break new ground in parliamentary cooperation. He has set up a foreign relation desk since he assumed his post.
Wang led a delegation to Macedonia in early July and signed an agreement on exchanges.
Macedonian Assembly President Savo Klimovski led a delegation to the ROC in March, during which he signed a joint declaration of parliamentary cooperation with Wang.
The declaration calls for regular meetings, as well as the exchange of visits between lawmakers of both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMAND DEPOSIT TOTAL FALLS NT$170 BILLION IN JULY

TEXT.P: Apparently affected by President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties, current demand deposits in all banking institutions in the Taiwan area totaled NT$3.56 trillion in July, down NT$170 billion from the previous month.
Due to foreign capital pouring into Taiwan, deposits in Taiwan's banking institutions reached NT$3.72 trillion as of the end of June.
Because of the escalation in tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in July, the annual rise in current deposits has fallen from 14.67 percent to 12.84 percent.
Time deposits in the banking institutions amounted to a record high of NT$9.57 trillion in July, up NT$45.2 billion from the previous month.
Total deposits in July amounted to NT$17.48 trillion, a drop of NT$3.8 billion from June.
Meanwhile, loans and capital investments totaled NT$15.53 trillion in July, down NT$133.3 billion from June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 29, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1475: The Truce of Picquigny is signed, under which King Edward IV of England agrees to withdraw his invading troops from France in return for gold and a yearly pension.
1782: Royal George, a first-rate ship of the British fleet, sinks while undergoing repairs at Spithead, killing more than 900 people.
1831: Michael Faraday, British physicist and chemist, successfully demonstrates the first electrical transformer in London. He also proposed the field theory later developed by Maxwell and Einstein.
1842: The Treaty of Nanking is signed by Britain and the Ching court, ending the Opium War. Among the treaty's stipulations were the opening of five ports to British trade and the ceding of Hong Kong to England.
1835: John Batman and associates buy land from Australian Aborigines and officially establish Melbourne.
1877: Brigham Young, Mormon leader and founder of Salt Lake City, dies at the age of 76.
1885: The first motorcycle is patented in Germany by Gottlieb Daimler, German engineer and pioneer automobile manufacturer who produced the first high-speed internal-combustion engine.
1910: Japan takes complete control of Korea and governs Korea as a colony to benefit its own interests.
1926: Nepal abolishes slavery, freeing some 55,000 slaves.
1929: The giant airship Graf Zeppelin returns to Lakehurst, New Jersey, after completing a 21-day trip around the world.
1932: India's nationalist leader Mohandas Gandhi arrives in London to attend the second Round Table Conference at St. James' Palace.
1932: A Chinese volunteer army in northeast China launch a surprise attack at Shenyang (Mukden), capital of Liaoning province, during the night, burning the airport and destroying 27 Japanese military aircraft.
1945: Allied forces land in Japan following Japan's surrender.
1945: The National government appoints Chen Yi as governor of Taiwan following its retrocession to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, receives Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung to discuss such issues as national unity and reconstruction.
1948: Thailand expels some 5,000 ethnic Chinese.
1949: The Soviet Union tests its first atomic bomb.
1958: Michael Jackson, American pop mega-star, is born; his hit albums such as "Thriller" and "Bad" are backed by equally successful videos.
1962: A sword belonging to Lee Siu-cheng, one of the leaders who launched the Taiping Rebellion against the Ching court 97 years ago, is returned to mainland authorities by a Briton.
1966: The Beatles end their controversial tour of the United States with a concert for thousands of screaming fans at Candlestick Park in San Francisco.
1969: Chiang Cheng-Tao, a mainland Chinese musician who defected to France, arrives in Taipei.
1975: A nova in the Cygnus constellation is discovered by the Taipei Observatory.
1982: Ingrid Bergman, Swedish star of stage and screen who won Oscars for both "Gaslight" and "Anastassia," dies on her 67th birthday at her London home.
1987: The ROC Little League baseball team wins the world title by beating the US West team, 21-1.
1996: A Tupolev 154 chartered by a Russian mining company crashes on the Arctic island of Spitzbergen, killing all 141 aboard.
1998: A Tupolev of Cubana de Aviacion crashes after taking off from Ecuador's international airport in Quito, killing 81 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The intelligence which comes from the direct apprehension of truth is intuition. The apprehension of truth which comes from the exercise of intelligence is the result of education."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY NOMINATES WRITER-CRITIC LI AO AS PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: The New Party (NP) formally recruited writer-critic Li Ao as the party's candidate for the 2000 presidential election in a meeting of party officials on Sunday.
Li, supported by 53 of 66 officials present at the meeting, later attended a press conference during which champagne bottles were popped open to celebrate his nomination.
New Party heavyweight Lee Ching-hua lauded Li for his knowledge, eloquence, humor and competitive ability.
Lee said that Li's entry in the presidential race will bring mirth and new thinking to the election campaign, adding that it will not be a live-or-die battle but a carnival.

He also said that Li will tell everyone that the 6-year-old New Party, which is a splinter party of the ruling Kuomintang, will be the true opposition party and that the NP is the only party that opposes the moving of the Legislative Yuan to a new, spacious and luxurious facility and the extension of terms for National Assembly deputies.

Taking off his trademark red jacket to show his yellow shirt -- the color of the New Party -- Li expressed his appreciation that the New Party has given him the chance to run, and he vowed to promote the party.

Li also said that in the seven months remaining until the presidential election, he will not give the other presidential candidates an easy time, but will instead draw attention to explosive issues involving them.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONGRESS APPROVES LIEN-SIEW TICKET

TEXT.P: The second plenary session of the Kuomintang's 15th National Congress formally nominated Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate for president and Premier Vincent Siew as its candidate for vice president in the 2000 presidential election.

As the highlight of the two-day congress, party delegates, of whom 96.3 percent supported Lien's candidacy in a party primary earlier this month, approved Lien and his choice for his running mate, Siew.

When former Vice President Lee Yuan-zu, who presided over the congress Sunday morning, announced the approval of a Lien-Siew ticket, there was vociferous applause at the conference site. All party delegates, led by an emcee, chanted "Lien Chan, elected" and brandished flags with Lien's name.
At the same time, images of Lien and Siew appeared on a big screen at the conference site, accompanying by sayings supporting their candidacies.
Then the attendants sang the campaign song of President Lee Teng-hui and Lien Chan, who ran for office four years ago.
President Lee, who is also the party's chairman, presented to the two nominees ribbons with their names and handed over a flag to them as a token of the party's mandate.

Saying the nomination represented the party's firm intention to win next year's presidential race and to solemnly meet the anxious expectations of the Taiwan people, Lee touted the pair's achievements and urged all party members to rally behind the candidacy of Lien and Siew.
"Now that the nomination has been made," the chairman said, "it is time for the whole party to campaign for the party's candidates."

He urged party members to overlook no constituencies in their efforts to solicit votes for Lien and Siew, and to get across the message to all the people that support for the KMT candidates ensures the Republic of China's survival and protects their own security and livelihoods.
Lien gave a 20-minute nomination acceptance speech, in which he thanked the delegates for their support and vowed to devote all his energies to fulfilling the party's mandate by winning the election.

Promising that the KMT will form a governing team with reform-minded people and an administration that fully satisfies the peoples' desires, Lien outlined four campaign principles: concern for Taiwan's well-being above all else; safety first; respect for public opinion; and the predominance of justice.
Pledging to do whatever is needed to win the election, Lien said he would fight to win not only votes in the 2000 election but also the people's respect for the KMT.
The nomination ended with a climax when Lien, Siew and their supporters within the party sang in chorus "You are my brothers" to signify the party's unity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE BODY URGES US TO GIVE AMNESTY TO ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By David Wang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A US national Chinese mutual aid organization on Friday urged private groups to ask Congress to pass an act granting amnesty to more than 5 million illegal immigrants in the United States.

Ma Wen-wu, chairman of the organization, said here in a press conference that his organization has mailed copies of a report on the amnesty of illegal immigrants to 100 senators and 455 representatives, urging them pass the amnesty act to improve illegal immigrants' quality of living, their physical and mental health, and work and educational opportunities for their children.

Ma indicated that most of the illegal immigrants work in the United States and some of them pay taxes. The amnesty could result in increased tax revenues for the US government and a decrease in the exploitation by underground factories of illegal immigrants, he said, adding that the amnesty is in line with the United States' principles of democracy and the promotion of human rights.
The Chinese mutual aid organization will present petitions to the governors of all 50 US states and will seek the signatures of leaders of various countries in support of the act.
Precedents in US history regarding the granting of amnesty to illegal immigrants are as follows:
-- 4 million illegal immigrants were granted permanent residency rights in January 1981;
-- Some 40,000 illegal agricultural workers were granted legal immigrant status in 1986;
-- The so-called "June 4 green card" enabled many students from mainland China to permanently stay in the United States in the early 1990s; and
-- President Ronald Reagan signed an amnesty act benefiting some 4,000 Catholics during his tenure.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIFFICULT TO DRAW SUPPORT FOR LIEN-SIEW TICKET: KMT LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Several legislators from the ruling Kuomintang said on Sunday that it will be tough to draw support from grassroots voters for the just-approved Lien Chan-Vincent Siew ticket in next March's presidential election.
The KMT approved the nomination on the second day of a two-day party congress despite strong opposition from party members.

Legislators Chu Fong-chi (Taoyuan), Wang Tien-ging (Kaohsiung), Yang Chung-ying (Taichung) and Ho Chi-hui (Miaoli) said outside the conference room that it would be very hard to drum up support for the two candidates, since natural disasters and man-made mistakes happened during Siew's tenure have made a greater impression on people than his political achievement.
They urged the party's core members to take substantial measures to fight against money politics to win back the people's hearts.

In response to some KMT legislators' opposition, the KMT's legislative caucus said everybody should support the party's nominated candidates, even though they may not share common ground with the candidates and even though they may have endorsed different candidates in the past.

Siew should not be held solely responsible for the problems during his tenure, said KMT legislative caucus Whip Tseng Yung-chuan, adding that in light of Siew's complete political career and his integrity, it is expected that Lien and Siew will gradually win back the people's support.

Meanwhile, Senior Adviser to the President Wu Po-hsiung, who aggressively sought to be Lien's running mate, said as he took part in a Buddhist gathering in Taoyuan that he would let his supporters decide how to make the next move.

In response to media questions, Wu said he had engaged in talks with former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong two months ago, but said he would make a decision on his next move only after thoroughly evaluating his supporters' views.

Soong, who is running for president as an independent and who has led in most public opinion polls, arrived at the Buddhist gathering later and stressed that he would combine power from supra-party talents to strive for victory.

Soong went on to say that about two years ago he discovered that there was serious discrepancy between the views of grassroots people and the party's high-ranking officials, adding that the situation has not improved at all since then.
He also said there is no split within the KMT; otherwise Vice President Lien Chan would not have received an overwhelming 96 percent support rating in the party's primary, held earlier this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: DHL PLANS TO CAST NT$1 BILLION TO MODERNIZE SERVICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: World-renowned express service DHL will invest NT$1 billion to modernize and expand its services in Taiwan, Lu Li-hsing, general manager of DHL Taiwan Corp., said on Sunday.

Lu said that with the investment, DHL will build eight service centers in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung during a three-year-period. Each center will occupy 1,200 ping (3,900 square meters) and will begin service starting next year.

Lu said that the investment will be centered on automating merchandise delivery and modernizing the system's telecommunications and computer systems. After the completion of the planned service centers, processing time will be reduced by more than 50 percent.
DHL was the first world-class express company to enter Taiwan. It now cooperates with 2,044 7-Eleven stores and has 23 service posts scattered around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO PROMOTE NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN NEW CENTURY: LEE

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has full confidence and ability to improve the living standard of the people and promote national development in the new century, President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China said here Sunday.

Speaking at the closing ceremony of the Second Plenary Session of the 15th KMT National Congress, Lee, who is chairman of the ruling party, said the party "has sacred responsibility for the future and development of the Republic of China, and for the safety and welfare of the 22 million citizens." He urged members of the party to unite and work together, so as to lead the nation into a bright future in the new century.

In the two-day party congress, the KMT approved the nomination of Vice President Lien Chan as its candidate for the up-coming presidential elections and the nomination of Premier Vincent Siew as Lien's vice-presidential running mate.
Lee stressed that Lien and Siew are the most suitable candidates for the elections, which will be held in March, 2000.
The KMT will be able to build the Republic of China into a more stable, righteous, innovative, and prosperous country, he added.

The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:

The Taiwan News:
'State-to-state' adopted as official KMT policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES TAX TO BE HIKED TO FINANCE NATIONAL ANNUITY PROGRAM: MOF

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is planning to hike the level of Taiwan's sales tax as a means to help finance the proposed national annuity program, Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Monday.
Although the sales tax will not be raised this year, Chiu said an increase of 10 percent could be expected beginning next year, hiking the sales tax from the current 5 percent to 5.5 percent.
The MOF will not discuss the tax hike until after Friday when the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) makes public formal plans for the national annuity program, Chiu noted.

The national annuity program is expected to be launched in 2000, with estimated per capita monthly contributions of NT$870 to be paid by eligible ROC nationals between the ages of 25 and 64. People aged 65 and over may receive a monthly pension of NT$2,000 for the rest of their lives, according to preliminary CEPD plans.
In addition to the increase in sales tax, according CEPD plans, a public lottery will also be used as a supplementary source of funds for the pension program.
