DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SALVADORIAN AMBASSADOR PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: New Salvadorian Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presented his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui on Monday.

Ambassador Santana, accompanied by John Feng, director-general of the Department of Protocol under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, presented his credentials to the president. Witnessing the ceremony were Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-hui and Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu.
President Lee extended a sincere welcome to Ambassador Santana on his return to Taiwan. The 56-year-old diplomat first served as ambassador to the Republic of China between 1985 and 1991.

Lee also asked the ambassador to convey his greetings to Salvadorian President Francisco Flores, who is scheduled to arrive here Friday to attend a summit meeting between Central America nations and the Republic of China.
Stressing the long-standing friendship between the ROC and El Salvador, President Lee said that the ROC is happy to help the Central American nation develop its economy.
Ambassador Santana said he felt honored to serve as the country's ambassador to the ROC once again, and he vowed to dedicate himself to the promotion of friendly bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 30, or the 20th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of France after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1860: The first trains in Britain begin running.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troop at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1881: Germany's Clement Ader patents the first stereo system.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her accomplice -- her sister Dora -- in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of German air force, directed the German wartime economy and was named Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Fart to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a 1906 Nobel Prize for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1941: The Germans surround Leningrad.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with his opposite in Moscow, becomes operational.
1967: The US Senate approves the appointment of Thurgood Marshall as associate justice of the US Supreme Court. He becomes the first Afro-American to serve the position.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of the Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Muhammad Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese national classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE MAINLAND SPOUSES TO BE ALLOWED TO SETTLE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced on Monday that the annual quota for local people's mainland Chinese spouses to settle in Taiwan will be raised to 3,600 starting this year.
MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng made the announcement after a meeting of all MAC commissioners.
Sheu said the meeting focused discussion on the annual quota for mainland spouses to settle in Taiwan and all other related regulations.

Based on humanitarian considerations, Sheu said, all MAC commissioners unanimously agreed to largely increase the number of mainland spouses to be allowed to settle in Taiwan to 3,600 people from the current 1,800.
Sheu said the new quota will take effect after the Legislative Yuan approves the proposal at its new session scheduled to open next month.

Under current regulations, mainland people who have married Republic of China nationals for two full years and have children can apply to settle in Taiwan. Nevertheless, the ROC government has imposed an annual quota on such applicants.
Although the government has many times raised the annual quota, it still fails to meet the rapidly rising demand. The quota was last adjusted to 1,800 in 1997.

Sheu said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has also decided to ease restrictions on mainland Chinese spouses' rights to work and national health insurance coverage after they are allowed to settle here. "Once mainland spouses obtain legal residence here, our government will give them good care based on humanitarianism," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA MAPPING OUT PLANS TO COPE WITH APEC FISHING-CUTTING PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan has continued to reduce the number of aged fishing boats in operation in an effort to increase the cost efficiency of its fishing industry, as well as to prevent ocean fishing fleet from further expanding, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Monday.

The Republic of China government allocated a total of US$90 million between 1991 and 1995 to buy some 2,300 aged fishing boats totaling 140,000 deadweight tons, according to Hsieh Dah-wen, deputy director of COA's Fisheries Department.
Of the boats, 136 were ocean-going tuna fishing boats, which together represent about 16 percent of Taiwan's entire ocean-going tuna fishing boat tonnage, said Hsieh.
It is hoped that Taiwan's efforts to reduce the number of aged fishing boats in operation will be counted as a measure to cut back the size of the island's fishing fleet, Hsieh added.

Hsieh made the remarks in response to a recent proposal, submitted by Japan, asking all fishing parties around the world to cut their fishing fleets by 20 percent in an effort to protect dwindling stocks of fish.

Through the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, the Japanese government said it will take the initiative in reducing the number of Japan's fishing boats by 20 percent and hopes that other APEC fishing nations around the world will follow suit.

According to a recent survey conducted by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, 60 percent to 70 percent of fish resources around the globe have been explored, with some fish species facing the threat of extinction because of over-fishing.
The Japanese proposal, however, met with opposition from major fishing nations, including New Zealand, Canada and South Korea, according to Hsieh.
Although the Japanese proposal was temporarily set back, Hsieh said, the UN effort to stop the global depletion of fish stocks is expected to continue.
It is hoped that Taiwan's efforts to reduce the number of aged fishing boats will be counted by APEC member countries as an attempt to reduce the size of its fishing fleet, Hsieh reiterated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA KEY ISSUES IN REVIEW OF ANZUS ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan, mainland China and the role of the United States in the Asia-Pacific region appear clearly to be the major issues in an extensive review of the ANZUS alliance between the United States and Australia at meeting in Sydney, The Australian reported on Monday.

The daily reported that the ANZUS alliance meeting was being attended by representatives from the US and Australian private sector. Among those attending are US ambassadors, former presidential adviser Robert Blackwell and Professor Paul Dibb of Australian National University.
Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer welcomed the review, but warned that it should not become "too sinophobic."

The daily reported that the issues to be canvassed include the United States' role in the Asia-Pacific region, the rise of mainland China, the Taiwan issue, instability in North Korea, the new Indonesia, the nuclearization of the India-Pakistan conflict, the prevention of the proliferation of nuclear and conventional weapons, an open world trading system, terrorism and refugee flows.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN EXPORTERS WARY, DESPITE ASIAN PICKUP

TEXT.P: Australian iron ore and coal exporters are still wary despite some encouraging signs of rising steel production in Taiwan, South Korea and Japan, The Australian Financial Review reported on Monday.
The daily quoted a Merrill Lynch report as saying that Japan's steel production outlook was improving at least in terms of volume.

The report quoted analysts as saying that other Asian countries such as Taiwan and Korea are also increasing steel production as countries across the region recover from the worst of the recent economic crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: E. TIMORESE GO TO POLLS

TEXT.P: About 450,000 East Timorese on Monday will go to the polls to decide their future for the first time in 24 years, while Australian troops are standing by for a full evacuation of Australians and other foreigners from the former Portuguese colony.

In Dili, Bishop Carlos Belo, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, on Sunday issued a statement encouraging all Timorese to defy intimidation by pro-Jakarta militia groups. "Don't be afraid, be brave and choose the future of East Timor," he said.
Australian troops have been put on fully alert and are ready to evacuate hundreds of Australian citizens and other foreigners from East Timor in case civil war erupts following the voting.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CRITICIZED FOR QINGHAI RESETTLEMENT PROJECT

TEXT.P: The recent detention of one Australian and one American researchers involved in the World Bank-funded resettlement project in Qinghai has cast a harsh light yet again on mainland Chinese treatment of Tibetans, an Australian newspaper said editorially Monday.

In an editorial titled "China's Tibet," The Sydney Morning Herald said the incident "has raised questions over China's claim to World Bank assistance for projects which can be criticized as part of a systematic attempt to dilute the Tibetan population in traditionally Tibetan lands."
The Qinghai resettlement program will put further pressure on the local population, including ethnic Tibetans, the editorial noted.

Both Australian and American researchers on the World Bank project were released after being detained for some time due to their research on the project, but the fate of their detained Tibetan interpreter remains unknown, and this will put pressure on the World Bank to withdraw support for the resettlement project, the editorial said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRAY DOGS NUMBER ABOUT 600,000: COA

TEXT.P: There are currently about 600,000 stray dogs in Taiwan, far less than the 1.3-1.4 million posted four years ago, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Monday.

At the same time, some 2 million dogs are house kept as pets, compared with the 300,000 to 400,000 reported in 1995, officials from COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (APHIQ) said.

Quoting the latest survey conducted by Prof. Fei Chang-yung from National Taiwan University's Veterinary Medicine Department under a COA contract, APHIQ officials said the number of stray dogs has declined by about 50 percent in Taiwan while the number of house-kept dogs increased by 50 percent over the past four years due to strenuous government efforts.
Beginning on Sept. 1, according to APHIQ officials, the entire canine population in Taiwan will be implanted with IC chips for easy identification.
It is expected that by the end of October when the IC chip implantation is completed, an even more precise count of the canine population will be obtained, the officials noted.

The IC chip implantation is the latest government effort to improve Taiwan's stray dog population amid rising international concern about the country's excessive number of stray dogs and the methods the authorities used to deal with the homeless animals, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO AMEND CONSTITUTION IN LINE WITH 'STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY: LIEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Monday said that the Republic of China does not need to amend the constitution in line with President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of the "special state-to-state relationship" between Taipei and Beijing.
Lien made the remarks during a press conference held one day after he and Premier Vincent Siew were confirmed by the KMT National Congress as the party's ticket for 2000 presidential election.
Lien also said that if he is elected, it would be natural for him to continue to consult with President Lee, who serves concurrently as the ruling party's chairman.
Lien also defended his choice of Premier Siew as his running mate in the 2000 presidential election.

Lien lauded Siew as a rare example of someone having executive as well as legislative experience. Lien said that Siew started his career at the grassroots level and worked his way up to premier, serving in various important political and economic posts along the way.

Lien said that he has worked with Siew, whom he called "sincere and modest," for many years. When Lien concurrently served as premier, he asked Siew to be responsible for implementing the Asia-Pacific operations hub project, as well as an economic stimulus plan -- projects Lien described as having proved their benefit to the nation.
Siew has also been in charge of cross-strait relations, Lien added. He called the KMT's ticket very complimentary.

Asked about the latest survey, which puts support for the Lien-Siew ticket at 16 percent, Lien implored the media to give a higher score to the government, saying that Taiwan's economic growth was the second highest in Asia last year and that this year it is expected to reach 5 percent.
Lien also touched on cross-strait relations, saying that five decades of rivalry between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is enough.

Lien expressed the hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be more pragmatic and that they will work out their differences on the principles of "peace, rationality and equality" in order to reach a mutual benefit.
Lien said Taiwan's transition from authoritarian to democratic rule and from poverty to affluence could be a lesson for mainland China.

He reaffirmed that President Lee's "special state-to-state relationship" redefinition of cross-strait ties sets the record straight by pointing out that the Republic of China is an independent sovereign state, and not a renegade province, as mainland China claims it to be.
Lien said that the ROC wants to deal with mainland China on an equal basis and does not want the mainland to treat it as a provincial government.
Siew, speaking on the same occasion, was asked if he would serve concurrently as premier if he were elected vice president.
Siew said that he would observe the spirit of the constitution and he personally would not agree to concurrently serve as premier and vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE ARE VISA INTERNATIONAL'S TOP ASIAN CLIENTS

TEXT.P: The 12,398,471 Visa International card holders in Taiwan set a one-month record in July by using the card for purchases of NT$38,354,637,592 (approximately US$1.21 billion) according to Visa International's Taiwan branch office on Monday.

As of the end of July, Visa International has issued 12,398,471 cards to the some 21.5 million residents of Taiwan. Keen on traveling, shopping and dining out make Taiwan residents the ideal holders of Visa International cards. The company has 16 million contract business establishments world over and nearly 200,000 in Taiwan.

Visa clients in Taiwan demonstrated their impressive consuming power in the first seven months of this year, by taking on a total of NT$245.46 billion in credit, an increase of 26.6 percent over the same period last year. In 1998 when most Asian economies were badly stricken by the Asian financial crisis, Taiwan's power of comsumption was still strong in terms of plastic currency transactions.

In 1998, Taiwan residents became Visa's best Asian client group by taking on NT$362.7 billion in credit. Competition in the credit card market has become increasingly severe. However, Visa International was able to issue a total of 9.4 million new cards in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taipei share prices closed 0.2 percent higher on Monday due to bargain hunting by investors.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 17 points to close at 8,071.36 points. A total of 3.09 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$131 billion.

The paper making sector posted the largest gain among the eight major categories, ending the day, up 2.2 percent, followed by plastic and chemical shares, up 1.6 percent. Textile issues and electronic shares rose 0.7 and 0.4 percent, respectively.
Foodstuff stocks fell 1 percent. Construction issues and financial shares both suffered a 0.4-percent loss, while cement stocks reported a 0.1 percent decline.
The over-the-counter market was up 2.16 percent to the close at 178.37 points, on a turnover of NT$6.34 billion.
Meanwhile, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) reported gains, except for next March and next June futures, for which no contract transactions were registered.

TAIEX Index Futures for September rose 45 points to finish at 8,190 points, with 2,748 contract transactions; those for October climbed 34 points to close at 8,187 points, with 78 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved up 52 points to end at 8,193 points, with 4 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 8,145 points for September, 8,153 points for October, 8,141 points for December, 8,141 points for next march and 8,294 points for next June.
The electronic futures (TE) for September advanced 0.7 point to close at 373 points, with 520 contract transactions.
Financial futures for September dropped 0.4 point to finish at 1,160 points, with 109 contract transactions.
There were no transactions recorded for TE and TF futures for the other months. (by Michelle Tseng)

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR REACHES 21-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan was quoted at 31.85 against the greenback on the Taipei market on Monday, the highest level in 21 months.
The local unit opened at the day's low of 31.85 and experienced a high of 31.832 during Monday's session. It gained 0.8 cents in value against the US dollar.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$457 million.
The NT dollar has climbed 13 consecutive business days since Aug. 12, gaining 28.1 cents against the US dollar.

Local dealers expect the NT dollar will further appreciate since the Taiwan economy remains stable. However, whether or not the currency will surge to break through the 31.5 resistant level depends on the central bank's attitude, dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US, MAINLAND CHINA HOLD ROUNDTABLE IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Officials and academics from the Republic of China on Taiwan, mainland China and the United States are meeting in New York amid escalation of tension in the Taiwan Strait over the "special state-to-state relationship" controversy.

The closed-door roundtable meeting, also known as "Track II" Taipei-Washington-Beijing dialogue, is being sponsored by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP). This is the fifth time that the private US think tank has organized this kind of three-way unofficial conference since mid-1997.

Such roundtable discussions, mainly aimed at reviewing the general situation and policy developments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and seeking solution to cross-strait issues or disputes, usually do not have a fixed agenda and the meeting results have never been published.
The current session will formally kick off on Monday and ROC President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" declaration is expected to be the main focus of discussion at the two-day conference.

Beijing has reacted furiously against President Lee's declaration in an interview with a German radio station in July that Taiwan-mainland China relations should be on a "special state-to-state" basis. It may have been further angered by the ROC ruling Kuomintang's adoption of the theory as one of its future policy guidelines on Sunday.

While mainland delegates managed to refrain from touching on the issue during a Sunday dinner hosted by the NCAFP in honor of all participants, observers said they believe mainland delegates will certainly blasted President Lee for deliberately advocating the "special state-to-state" theory to spoil cross-strait ties.

The ROC delegation is composed of Tien Hung-mao, a senior adviser to President Lee and director of the Institute for National Policy Research, a Taipei-based private think tank; professor Kao Ying-mao of US Brown University; Soochow University professor Kuo Cheng-liang; National Chiao Tung University professor Wei Yung; and Wu Hsin-hsing, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation.

Members of the mainland delegation include Xu Shihquan, director of the Taiwan Research Institute under the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences; Guo Changlin, a mainland Foreign Ministry official who will attend the meeting in his capacity as a research fellow with the Beijing-based Contemporary International Relations Research Center; and Su Ge, an assistant to the director of the Institute of Diplomacy.
The American delegates include Winston Lord, a former assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs; and noted China hands Ralph Clough and Gerrit W. Gong.

Susan Shirk, deputy assistant secretary of state, Kurt Campbell, deputy assistant secretary of defense, and all senior executives of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy will also attend the closed-door discussion.

Taiwan delegate Kao Ying-mao said the main function of the roundtable meeting is not necessarily to seek definite agreements or conclusions. "The main purpose is to exchange ideas and opinions so as to boost mutual understanding," he added.

Kao said he believes that mainland China will intensify diplomatic squeeze against Taiwan after the island's ruling party adopted the "special state-to-state" theory as one of its major policy guidelines at its just-concluded national congress.
Nevertheless, Kao said he doesn't think that the United States will easily make concessions to any mainland demand concerning the Taiwan issue.

Some sources said major topics to be discussed at the Aug. 30-31 roundtable will include whether mainland President Jiang Zemin will push US President Bill Clinton to explicitly promise "no US support" for the "special state-to-state" theory when they meet in New Zealand in September; as well as the possibility of cross-strait military confrontation; possible US reaction in the event of a mainland attack on Taiwan; US arms sales to Taiwan; and the feasibility of Taiwan's participation in the US-initiated theater missile defense (TMD) system.

DOC.HEADLINE: WU POH-HSIUNG SPECULATED TO BE JAMES SOONG'S RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: Presidential adviser Wu Poh-hsiung is likely to be the running mate of independent presidential candidate James Soong, according to a relative of Soong on Monday.

Richard Wu, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association, whose relationship with Soong is uncle and nephew, made the remarks to reporters after he attending a seminar on laws protecting the investments of Taiwan businessmen.
Wu said Wu Poh-hsiung and Soong share many things, including friends and supporters. Therefore, cooperation between the two can not be ruled out, said Soong's relative.

He cited Soong, the former Taiwan provincial governor, as saying that public opinion will dictate Soong's direction and action; hence, as long as it complies with the people's will, cooperation with Wu Poh-hsiung is highly likely.
However, since Soong is still weighing his options for a running mate, his final decision will not be made until November, Wu stressed.

Wu Poh-hsiung, who has been trying to position himself for a vice presidential nomination, was apparently disappointed when Vice President Lien Chan decided, last week, to chose Premier Vincent Siew as his KMT running mate in next year's presidential election.

In the wake of the Lien-Siew ticket approval at the second plenary session of the ruling Kuomintang's 15th National Congress last Saturday, whether Wu will be tapped as Soong's running mate has been the focus of scrutiny by outsiders.
Wu and Soong met by chance Monday morning at the Yi Ming Temple (a temple in honor of people with a deep sense of justice) in Hsinchu County.
Soong and Wu said hello to each other, shook hands and then parted. Nevertheless, supporters of both Wu and Soong at the scene repeatedly called for a Soong-Wu ticket.
Soong's working team said later that the meeting at the temple was a sheer coincidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS TO VISIT US IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Several Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators will visit the United States in mid-September to express their support for the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) currently being screened by the US Congress, said a DPP legislator Monday.

Trong Chai said he and Tsai Ming-hsien, Lee Ying-yuan, Chung Chin-chiang and Chang Hsiu-chen will visit the United States Sept. 13-15 to call on Democratic and Republic Party leaders in the US Senate, Chairman Richard Bush of the American Institute in Taiwan, as well as several think tanks such as the American Enterprise Institute.

Chai said the main purpose of the visit is to express the DPP's concern over the TSEA. The TSEA stipulates that any final decision on Taiwan's future must be approved by the people of Taiwan and that the US government must help strengthen Taiwan's defensive ability.

Tsai Ming-hsien said the group will also inform the US Congress and the American news media that President Lee's redefinition of ties across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" has won the support from the majority of people in Taiwan.
Because Beijing will probably threaten the island's security during the 2000 presidential election, they will also urge the United States to attach much importance to the TSEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA DISSATISFIED WITH CAL'S FLIGHT SAFETY IMPROVEMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) on Monday rejected a China Airlines (CAL) report on its recent flight mishap and various flight safety improvement measures, saying the report lacks substance.
"CAL didn't show full sincerity and determination to learn a lesson from the recent tragic incident," CAA Director-General Chang Yo-heng said after reading the CAL report.

Chang demanded CAL, Taiwan's flagship carrier, to present a more detailed report on the possible drawbacks or negligence in its internal control system and concrete steps for improving its safety measures within 10 days.

CAL's Flight CI-642, with 315 passengers and crew members on board from Bangkok, crash-landed in Hong Kong on Aug. 22 in a driving rain as Typhoon Sam was sweeping through the former British colony. The McDonnell-Douglas 11, landing at an abnormal 15-degree tilt, cracked a wing, which caused a fire, and flipped onto its back after landing at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok Airport. Three passengers already died from the incident and 206 others were injured.

Responding to CAA's rejection of the carrier's flight safety improvement plan, CAL President Liu Ke-ai said the airline will make a further review and come up with a more comprehensive and concrete package of measures to meet the CAA's requirement.
Meanwhile, Liu denied a Hong Kong press report that the Italian pilot of the ill-fated CAL plane, Gerardo Lettich, had gone missing.
"The report was incorrect," Liu said, adding that Lettich returned to his home country after Hong Kong law enforcement authorities completed questioning on him.
Liu said Lettich returned to Italy on Aug. 26, while co-pilot Liu Cheng-hsi came back to Taipei on Aug. 25.

As part of the government's efforts to further improve flight safety, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng will meet with senior executives of eight Taiwan-owned airline companies to discuss effective measures on Tuesday afternoon to prevent recurrence of flight mishaps.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO FORM SPECIAL COURT FOR TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: In an attempt to safeguard the rights and interests of Taiwan businessmen who invest in mainland China and run afoul of mainland laws, a local business association on Monday called on Beijing to set up a special court with such cases.

Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) Chairman Wu Si-chung made the call at a press conference to propose the establishment of such a court and discuss regulations governing the protection of Taiwan investment in mainland China in light of the recent arrest of six Taiwan businessmen in the southeastern mainland city of Donguan on allegations of smuggling and exchange infractions.
Wu said he hoped the trial of the businessmen will be undertaken by judges who are familiar with Taiwan's customs in doing business and with mainland regulations governing investment from Taiwan.

Hsu Sheng-hsiung, head of the mainland trade department under TEEMA who visited Beijing's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation (MOFTEC) to personally put forward the proposal a few days ago, said in the press conference that MOFTEC promised to transfer the petition to the Supreme People's Court and the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council to determine whether the proposal is feasible and justified.

Hsu noted that MOFTEC is aware of the situation that many mainland Chinese local governments have promised excessive preferential measures in order to attract investment from Taiwan, which often results in contravention's to central government regulations.
TEEMA's proposal is expected to narrow the discrepancies between local and central government regulations and accordingly strengthen the protection to Taiwan businessmen, Hsu added.

Chang Keng-ming, an ROC national who holds a Ph.D. from the mainland's Politics and Law University, and works as an arbiter on the Beijing arbitration committee, urged local businessmen investing in the mainland to seek help from local arbitration committees instead of settling arbitrarily with local government officials in disputes.

Wu pointed out that the mainland is to formally implement the regulations governing the protection of investment and businessmen from Taiwan in October, and that relevant mainland authorities will promote a fair trade system, covering such areas as tax collection, for Taiwan businessmen as part of Beijing's equal treatment policy.
The policy will also allow Taiwan businessmen to report any local administrative torts and will allow whistle-blowers to remain confidential and free from retaliation, Wu added.
Currently, there are over 3,000 TEEMA member manufacturers with investments in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW LEAVES FOR PANAMA TO ATTEND NEW PRESIDENT'S INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew left Taipei for Los Angeles on Monday night en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.

Siew was accompanied by his wife and a group of officials, including Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho, Government Information Office Director-General Chen Chien-jen and Vice Foreign Minister Francisco Ou.

During his stay in Panama, Siew will call on outgoing Panamanian President Ernesto Perez Balladares, President Mireya Moscoso, First Vice President Arturo Valarino and Second Vice President Dominidor Bazan. The Premier will also take the opportunities to call on Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman.
The inaugural ceremony will be held at the newly-built National Stadium at 11:00 a.m. on Wednesday.

The Moscoso-Vallarino-Bazan ticket on behalf of "the Union for Panama" won the general election held May 2. The Union for Panama was composed of the Arulfist Party, the Democratic Change Party, the National Republic Liberal Party and the National Renovation Party.
Siew and his entourage will return to Taiwan on Sept. 6.

In a related story, Premier Siew called on President Lee Teng-hui Monday morning to report on his Panamanian trip. President Lee asked Siew to convey his best regards to the outgoing Panamanian President Ernest Perez Balladares as well as President-elect Moscoso.
The trip will be the first for Siew to Panama since he assumed the premiership of the Republic of China two years ago.

President Lee visited Panama in September, 1997. In addition to attending the World Congress of the Panama Canal, President Lee and his Panamanian counterpart Perez Balladares signed a series of bilateral economic and technology cooperation accords.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT INCLUSION OF `STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY IN RESOLUTION SAID `NATURAL'

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said on Monday that it is only "natural" for the ruling Kuomintang to include the "special state-to-state relationship" theory in the resolution passed by its National Congress.

Su noted that since it was President Lee Teng-hui who redefined cross-Taiwan Strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship" on July 9, and as Lee is also the KMT chairman, it is only natural that the theory was included in the party's resolution.
He also pointed out that Lee's statement only reflects existing facts and is not a new policy but a political declaration in anticipation of upcoming cross-strait political dialogue.
He said that there is no need to amend the constitution in line with the "special state-to-state" statement, and no question that the theory violates the constitution.

Su made the remarks in an address to legislators who expressed concern as to whether the constitution will be amended in line with the theory following the KMT's adoption of it as the basic tone of its mainland policy.

The second plenary session of the KMT's 15th National Congress on Sunday endorsed "stability, justice, prosperity, and creativity" as the basis of the party's efforts to enter the new millennium, with "special state-to-state relationship" clearly defined as the basis for cross-strait ties in anticipation of the new era of cross-strait exchanges.

The party stressed that in line with the National Unification Guidelines, and its established policy, it will continue to push for "normal and long-term" relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait toward a unified China under democracy.

The party also said that it wants to promote cross-strait constructive dialogue under the principles of parity, as well as cross-strait exchanges, so as to create an environment conducive to a win-win situation for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN EASES VISA SYSTEM TO BENEFIT ROC VISITORS

TEXT.P: Visitors to Japan from the Republic of China will benefit from the new Japanese visa system effective Sept. 1, a local tourism official said on Monday.

The new system extends the current three-year multiple entry visa with visits limited to 15 days to a five-year multiple entry visa with a 90-day visit limit. Visa fees remain unchanged at NT$1,700, while ROC visitors will be allowed to enter Okinawa without a visa fee if traveling as part of a group.

Officials of the Taipei office of the Interchange Association of Japan, a semi-official organization representing Japan's interests in the absence of diplomatic ties with Taiwan, met recently with local tourism industry representatives to announce the decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TO PUT TWO RUSSIAN-BUILT DESTROYERS TO COMBAT DUTY

TEXT.P: The national radio station of Russia reported in a Mandarin broadcast last weekend that two Russian-built destroyers equipped with supersonic anti-ship cruise missiles will be put on combat duty in the mainland Chinese Navy next year.

The broadcast monitored here said the supersonic anti-ship cruise missile is the most advanced anti-ship weapon in the world today. It may be the "Moskit Guided Missile" mentioned in a study released in October 1997 by the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, an expert here said Monday.

The two destroyers are built by Russia's Northern Shipyard, which built 17 destroyers of this kind between 1981 and 1993. The two destroyers are also equipped with anti-submarine systems and other modern weapons, the broadcast added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR DIFFERENCE IN KMT, DPP POLICIES TOWARD BEIJING: CHEN

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian said on Monday that he sees no major differences between his party and the ruling Kuomintang in policies toward mainland China.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of Japanese academics and political commentators.

Chen said President Lee Teng-hui's defining relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" indicates that the KMT's basic stance on cross-strait ties is similar to the DPP's.

Beijing has reacted furiously against Lee's "special state-to-state" declaration as it regards the declaration as a move to promote Taiwan independence. However, Chen reminded Beijing to take note of the word "special" in Lee's definition.

Noting that there is still no mutually acceptable and beneficial formula for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to normalize their relations, Chen said he hopes that both sides can work out a solution through peaceful negotiations.
Chen exchanged views with his Japanese guests on Asia-Pacific security and Taiwan's next presidential election scheduled for March 2000.
Concerning Taiwan's coming presidential election, Chen said he believes that domestic affairs, not cross-strait ties, will be the main focus of campaign debate among all presidential hopefuls.

For his part, Takashi Hirabayashi, head of the Japanese delegation, told Chen that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin once pushed Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi to declare "three noes" policy toward Taiwan.
"Obuchi declined Jiang's demand, indicating that Obuchi is friendly toward Taiwan," Hirabayashi said.
Chen said he appreciates Obuchi's support for Taiwan, adding that a democratic, stable and prosperous Taiwan will contribute much to security and stability in the Asia-Pacific area.
MOreover, Chen further said he is convinced that close cooperation among Taiwan, Japan and the United States will benefit one another, adding that they share common interests and responsibilities.

Chen said as a candidate for next year's presidential election, he is obligated to defend Taiwan's interest, safety and national sovereignty. He also pledged that if he manages to win the presidency, he will do his best to promote cultural, economic and other exchanges with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ENACT INTERNET SECURITY-RELATED REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien said on Monday that in light of the recent spate of Internet crimes, the government will enact regulations and assist information offices to enhance their ability to maintain Internet security.

Yang was speaking at a seminar held by the Institute for Information Industry (III) on Internet security protection. Nearly 200 experts in various related fields took part in the seminar, while some 10 Internet security service providers put their products on display.

Yang said that as Taiwan's Internet users have reached more than four million people, and as electronic commerce has strong potential, Internet security protection is becoming more and more important.

He went on to say that the III has set up a Network Security Protection Service Team under the National Information Infrastructure (NII) project. The team will publicize the importance of Internet security and promote the enactment of related regulations.
In addition, it will assist information units to train related personnel in order to allow these units to promote their information and Internet security defensive capability.

III President Kuo Yun said that the team is divided into four sections, comprising "firewall" specialists, virus specialists, telecommunications security specialists, and legal consultation specialists.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-BEIJING EXCHANGES LIMITED SINCE JULY

TEXT.P: Middle-ranking officials from Beijing have stopped visiting Taiwan ever since July 9, when Taipei claimed statehood in dealing with mainland China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said on Monday.
However, other exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not been affected, said Su in an exchange of views with a group of legislators on ties with Beijing.

Although, he said he would rather not speculate on whether Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan -- Wang Daohan -- will visit Taiwan this autumn as scheduled, he stressed that he is "not pessimistic about it."
He pointed out that Beijing has not decided to close channels of contact with Taiwan, and that the mainland authorities know "it is better to have Wang come than not" and that "life must go on."
Citing the current tensions prevailing between Taipei and Beijing, he also rejected as "inappropriate" one legislator's suggestion that the MAC should set up a branch office in Beijing,

He defended the approach taken by the MAC and the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) after a Taiwan-registered freighter was seized by mainland public security officials last month, saying the case is under judicial investigation and that Taipei has refrained from involving itself out of respect for Beijing's judiciary.
Critics had slammed this policy as "offhand."

The ship, the Hsinhua, was chartered by the National Defense Ministry to ship non-military supplies to Taiwan's frontline island of Matsu when it was reportedly caught smuggling and arrested by Fujian Province public security officials on July 31.
Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, who visited the detained crew of the Hsinhua in Mawei, Fujian, early this month complained to Su that the MAC and SEF have done nothing to help them.

DOC.HEADLINE: 200 TAIWAN STUDENTS SWINDLED BY BOGUS UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: A legislator revealed on Monday that a local swindler has managed to cheat more than 200 naive and gullible people by enrolling them in a non-existent US university.
Legislator Lee Ching-an of the ruling Kuomintang made his announcement at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan which he called to warn others not fall for the ruse.

Tzeng Hsun-ming, who claimed to be the holder of three doctoral degrees and be the president of the American Pushington University Group, established the Pichang and Pichichang companies and took out advertisements in local newspapers to enroll students for the "ghost" American university for fees of tens of thousands of dollars.

Unbelievably, the students dutifully attended "classes," even when they were held in places such as McDonald's restaurants, although some of them admitted that they felt the class venues to be "a little strange."
It was not until Tzeng finally conferred diplomas bearing three different names for the university that the victims began to smell a rat.

One student, who was doubtful of Tzeng's setup, went to the United States to find out if the university exists, and found that the address of the so-called university was actually a residential apartment building.

Ouyang Yien-heng, the director of the Bureau of International Culture and Education Relations under the Education Ministry, said that Pushington University is not recognized by either the Republic of China or the US governments, and asked students who are suspicious of foreign schools to check their credentials with the Education Ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE DELEGATION TO ARRIVE FOR ROC-PHILIPPINE ECONOMIC CONFAB
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A 23-member Philippine delegation is expected to arrive in Taipei on Tuesday to attend the eighth ministerial-level Republic of China-Philippine Economic Cooperation Conference to be held from Sept. 1-3.
The Philippine delegation will be led by Trade and Industry Minister Jose Pardo, who will jointly preside over the conference with ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang.
Topics on the agenda will include the promotion of Taiwan investment in Philippine special economic zones, the avoidance of double taxation, and other major issues.

Meanwhile, a 104-member delegation led by Tung Shang-chen, chairman of the Association for Philippine-ROC Economy, is expected to arrive in Taipei on Wednesday to attend the 14th joint conference of the Association for ROC-Philippine Economy and the Association for Philippine-ROC Economy.
Up for discussion at the conference will be the strengthening of bilateral trade and investment, the seeking of trade opportunities, and other major issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOSE OF HAPPINESS PRESCRIBED FOR YOUNG CANCER SUFFERERS

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's Asia Travel Service on Monday announced that his agency has invited 10 children suffering from cancer to visit Tokyo from Sept. 1-4 for the trip of a lifetime, saying "love is the best medicine against cancer."
Lin Jui-ping said the young patients will visit the Tokyo-based Disneyland and the Hello Kitty amusement park during their dream trip.

The father of one of the children in the tour group extended his heartfelt thanks to Lin and his travel agency for sponsoring the trip, saying that his daughter, who is a big Hello Kitty fan, has long wished to visit the Tokyo amusement park dedicated to the cartoon cat.

He said that he too feels strongly that happiness is the only good medicine for a young cancer sufferer, and added hopefully that maybe the Japan trip can help reawaken the will to live in the young victims.
Lin said the group of 10 cancer sufferers aged between six and 16 will leave for Tokyo on Wednesday accompanied by an oncologist and a senior nurse from the Kaohsiung Medical College.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES BUDGETING NT$10 BILLION FOR PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang on Monday denied reports in various local newspapers that it is planning to spend NT$10 billion in next year's presidential election.
Huang Hui-chen, director general of the Cultural Affairs Department and concurrently spokesman for the KMT, brushed off the reports, but said they have hurt the KMT's image.
He stressed, however, that in the process of democratization, the cost of financing a presidential election campaign has shot up for all participants.

Huang said that the majority of KMT election funding will come chiefly from party-run enterprises, which he claimed are now run in a transparent manner, so that it will be possible to monitor where election funds come from.

He also urged the country's voters not to allow prejudice to color their judgment of the party, and noted that "someone has already spent a lot of money sponsoring mass political rallies in Tainan and in Yungho," a thinly veiled allusion to other presidential contenders.

Meanwhile, Liu Tai-ying, the chairman of the Business Management Committee for the KMT, also denied on Monday the reports of the party's election budget, saying that KMT-run enterprises plan to spend a total of just NT$500 million to help the party's candidates in the presidential election, while additional funding will come from donations from people in all walks of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC VICE CHAIRMAN CALLS ON HONDURAN VICE PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Vice Minister Chu Chien-yi of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) under the Executive Yuan of the Republic of China called on Honduran Vice President A. Arevalo on Monday.

Chu, who arrived in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa on Aug. 25 to attend the annual meeting of Chinese associations and overseas Chinese confederations in the Central American region, exchanged views with his host on the promotion of exchanges of visits between the people of the two countries.
During the meeting, Chu had high praise for the overseas Chinese in the Central American region for their contributions and achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BID FOR US SUPPORT FOR WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's vice economics minister on Monday pledged to pursue Washington's support for Taiwan's bid for World Trade Organization (WTO) membership at September's meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Lin Yi-fu made the remarks while answering reporters' questions following a meeting with Nick Bridge, New Zealand's representative to Taipei, who extended his country's formal invitation to Taiwan to attend the 1999 unofficial APEC leadership summit and ministerial meeting, both of which are slated to open in New Zealand in September.

Lin said that Taiwan has arranged to conduct bilateral talks on Taiwan's WTO bid, APEC issues and mutual trade and economic issues with representatives from 11 countries, including the United States, during the upcoming meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE'S POPULARITY INCREASES: POLL

TEXT.P: The popularity of Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has soared to 28 percent, according to the latest public opinion survey.

The results of the survey conducted by a local cable TV station and released on Monday, showed Chen to be three hundred points behind the front runner, former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, while the ruling Kuomintang candidate Lien Chan was in third place with a 16 percent popularity rating.
The survey was conducted among 1,085 people islandwide on Aug. 29 with a margin of error of 3 percent.
According to the survey, Soong's popularity has declined a little to 31 percent.
If the poll is to be believed, the KMT National Congress which on Sunday approved a ticket of Lien with Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate, had apparently failed to bolster Lien's popularity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROVERSIAL CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM PROPOSALS SCRAPPED

TEXT.P: A controversial Constitutional reform proposal to extend by two years the term of current National Assemblymen was scrapped on Monday during a National Assembly session.

Apparently bowing to the overwhelming pressure of public opinion, none of the 254 delegates present at the session raised their hand to support the proposal which would have allowed them to retain their seats for an additional two years.
Even National Assembly Speaker Su Nan-cheng, who supported the idea as recently as Aug. 9, did an abrupt about-face while presiding over Monday's debate.

The proposal, which was aimed at having the National Assembly elected at the same time as the Legislative Yuan, caused uproar among the public, with the mass media dubbing it a "self-profiting clause."
Monday's decision, the last part of the first reading, meant that the proposal would not receive a second reading on Tuesday.

Also scuttled in the session were five other proposals out of a total of 21 which were approved on Sept. 13, including one initiated by the Democratic Progressive Party to lower the voting age from 20 to 18, and another which would have allowed prosecutors and police to detain suspects for a total of 48 hours without charge.
Under the current Constitution, suspects should be sent to court for a hearing within 24 hours of arrest.

However, several other controversial proposals, which would allow the National Assembly to decide its own organization law, approve its own budget, and oblige heads of the Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan and Control Yuan to brief the National Assembly on their work -- the so-called "power-expanding clause" -- passed their first readings.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI ADVANCES TO SECOND ROUND OF ASIAN BASKETBALL TOURNEY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei on Monday beat Bahrain 68-59 to enter the second round of the 20th Asian Men's Basketball Championships currently under way in Fukuoka, Japan.
Chinese Taipei had three victories in the first round of the contest.
The top two teams from four preliminary first round groups advanced to the two-group second round, and the top pair from those two groups will advance to the knock-out semifinals.
Chinese Taipei will take on South Korea on Tuesday, followed by Syria on Wednesday and Japan on Thursday.
The overall winner will also win a place at the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY DENIES PROBLEMS WITH LAFAYETTE FRIGATES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy on Monday denied that its French-made Lafayette-class missile frigates are plagued by problems.

A statement issued by the navy said the six Lafayette frigates, known locally as Kangting-class warships, have been operating normally ever since they were commissioned in 1996, and have performed well on various missions.

Contradicting a local newspaper report, the statement stressed that the computer systems used on the frigates are fully Y2K-compliant following readjustments by the French builders of the radar-evading "stealth" warships.

The statement also denied that retrofitted electronic warfare equipment spoils the ships' radar invisibility, saying the electronic equipment is totally consistent with the original systems installed by the builders.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 31, or the 21st day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1688: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer, dies at the age of 60. He was famed for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of the journey by Christians from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1916: The price of a Model T touring car produced by the Ford Motor Company, drops to US$250, compared with the original price of $825 in 1908, putting the automobile within reach of the average family.
1925: Snake-skin dresses become a new fashion item in London.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American newsmen that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago becomes an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1963: Georges Braque, French painter, dies in Paris at the age of 81. He was a leading exponent and theorist of the cubist movement.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1969: Rocky Marciano, former undefeated heavyweight champion of the world, dies in an air crash near Newton, Iowa, just hours before his 46 birthday.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: East and West Germany sign a historic treaty to harmonize their legal and political systems after merging on Oct. 3.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems" while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed, an ethnic Egyptian, are killed in a Paris car crash.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SHOULD HELP US IN CASE OF WAR WITH PRC: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Australia has a role in preventing Beijing from using military force against Taiwan and Canberra must stand ready to give military support to Washington if the US goes to war with China, according to a top adviser to US presidential candidate George W. Bush.

In an exclusive interview with the Australian Financial Review in Sydney, Richard Armitage, who is one of the US delegates to hold talks with his Australian counterparts on a private sector, said there was a danger that the ongoing crisis in the Taiwan Strait could lead to war between the United States and China and that Washington would expect Australia to contribute to "the dirty, hard and dangerous work."

He called on Prime Minister John Howard to help prevent war: "We do not want to go to war with China, and that is why now is the time for preventive work. Australia has a role now. John Howard is ideally positioned because he is meeting the president of China next week."

"I would hope that the prime minister would make the point that China needs to resolve the situation peacefully," he added. He said: "If Australia does not rally round the defense of Taiwan, it would be the greatest breach of the relationship since World War II," he said.

Armitage said Australia should also urge Taiwan to work towards a peaceful resolution. But he said Australians did not fully grasp that there had been a big change across the Taiwan Strait: "Taiwan is now a democracy. That is a fundamental change."
Jiang is scheduled to arrive in Australia on September 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERWHELMING TURNOUT IN EAST TIMOR VOTE

TEXT.P: East Timorese voters turned out in huge numbers Monday so that they could decide their future, bringing a stunning failure to pro-integration militias and Australia called on more UN personnel so that they could help maintain the territory peacefully after the ballot.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on Tuesday reported 99 percent of the strong 430,000 Timorese cast their votes in disregard of threats and intimidation by pro-Indonesian militia groups on Monday when the vote took place in Dili and other cities and towns in the former Portuguese colony.

DOC.HEADLINE: US OFFICIAL URGES TAIPEI, BEIJING TO RESUME DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By J. J. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: US Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Susan Shirk on Monday urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume exchanges and dialogue as soon as possible to help ease tension in the area.
Shirk made the appeal at the opening session of a "Track II" unofficial Taipei-Washington-Beijing roundtable conference organized by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy.

The off-the-records, closed-door forum has drawn much attention as it is being held at a time when Taipei and Beijing are at loggerheads over Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
In her speech to the meeting, Shirk reaffirmed the US commitment to the so-called "one China" policy, saying the US stance on the policy remains unchanged.

Commenting on President Lee's declaration in an interview with a German radio station on July 9 that cross-strait ties should be defined as a "special state-to-state relationship," Shirk said frankly that the US government was surprised by Lee's remarks.
Shirk also reiterated US opposition to the "special state-to-state" theory.

This is the fifth time that the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a private US think tank, has sponsored this kind of three-way roundtable since mid-1997 aimed at helping boost cross-strait mutual understanding.
According to those present at the Monday meeting, scholars from Taiwan, mainland China and the United States debated hotly on the "special state-to-state" theory.
Some participants said argument among academics from the three sides was far fiercer than before and that Taiwan and mainland scholars were far divided over the theory.
Most noteworthy was that some American scholars also said on the occasion that they feel the timing and content of Lee's "special state-to-state" remarks were not opportune.
The Monday session reportedly didn't touch on issues as to what measures the US government can take to cope with the current cross-strait tension over the "special state-to-state" theory.

On Tuesday, a senior US military officer at the US Embassy in Beijing will give a briefing on the general military situation in the Taiwan Strait area. This will be the first time that a senior American military officer on active duty has attended the "Tract II" three-way roundtable.

The Taiwan and mainland Chinese delegations to the current session are mainly composed of scholars and policy researchers. While several incumbent Clinton administration officials, including Kurt Campbell, deputy assistant secretary of defense, will deliver speeches during the two-day forum, which will end on Tuesday. Former Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord is also taking part in the meeting.

Observers said the main purposes of the present roundtable discussion are to dissuade communist China to make miscalculation of the current situation as well as to push the Clinton administration not to make any wrong decision on cross-strait issues amid the escalation of tension over the "special state-to-state" theory.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER TANG TALKS ABOUT THREAT FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said in an interview that there would be no immediate major threat from mainland China to Taiwan, but "small incidents of a provocative nature from the People's Liberation Army (PLA) will be predictable in the future."

In the interview published in the latest issue of Defense News weekly, the former ROC chief of the General Staff pointed out that "My concern is that if China chooses to take military action (against Taiwan), they will do it step-by-step. But we also believe that using force would be a last resort, because they are concerned about international pressure and economic growth."

Tang indicated that there are many options for Beijing, such as seizure of the offshore islands followed by missile attacks to paralyze transportation systems, as a warning to try to force Taiwan to the negotiating table.

Even if the PRC were to conduct an economic blockade of Taiwan, it would not be beneficial to Beijing since trade between Taiwan and mainland China is very interrelated, he said, adding that it would also bring down foreign investment in mainland China.

Nuclear weapons aside, Tang is confident that the PLA is not able to conduct an all-out invasion of Taiwan. Over the long run, he noted, if mainland China's economy continues to grow, which sustains Beijing's force buildup, they will add increasing military pressure on Taiwan. But in the next few years, the military gap between the two sides will persist "unless our economic situation worsens," stressed the defense chief.

Tang conceded that ballistic missile defense is Taiwan's highest priority now, although the Ministry of National Defense is still coordinating different opinions within the ROC government. "Establishment of a low-tier defense system is feasible (now), and we still have time to evaluate systems for upper-tier defense," he said.

Since Taiwan is a heavily industrialized island, if the PRC used missiles or other conventional forces to attack it will result in severe damage to Taiwan's economy. "Therefore we have to make necessary investments to offset pressures from PLA missiles, cruise missiles and satellite technology," explained the defense minister.

Tang went on to say that Taiwan is pursuing Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC) and Aegis radar systems for lower-tier missile defense. But he added that it is too early to say whether Taiwan will adopt DDG-51 Aegis-class destroyers as well as the anti-missile system.
He told Defense News that the US government has made a commitment to study which type of advanced early warning radar system will be provided to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNTEX DENIES PLAN TO MOVE 7TH NAPHTHA CRACKER PLANT TO WEST AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Tuesday that the Tuntex Group has not given up on its plan to build a naphtha cracker complex in southern Taiwan in favor of investment in west Australia.
Vice Economics Minister Ying Chi-ming was responding to newspaper reports that some of the ruling Kuomintang's businesses will join with Tuntex to mine liquefied natural gas (LNG) in west Australia.

The reports quoted Liu Tai-ying, chairman of China Development and Industrial Bank, as saying that Tuntex and several KMT businesses -- China Industrial and Development Bank, Central Investment Holding, and state-owned enterprises Taiwan Power Co. and Chinese Petroleum Corp. -- will jointly invest a total of NT$200 billion (US$6.21 billion) to prospect for LN0 and establish related facilities in Australia.

Reports said that in view of steep opposition from domestic environmentalists over the building of the proposed naphtha cracker plant -- the 7th in Taiwan, Tuntex might choose to build the plant in west Australia.

The seventh naphtha cracker complex, which was originally to be located in Pinnan Industrial Park in Tainan, southern Taiwan, is now undergoing environmental assessment, Ying said. Construction of the plant has not yet begun, although construction has begun on related facilities within the complex site.
He said that the MOEA has checked with Tuntex and learned that it has not given up on its project in Tainan and that its investment in Australia is mainly in liquefied natural gas and equipment.
Ying said that the seventh naphtha cracker project has encountered opposition from local people in Tainan, mainly because they are concerned about pollution problem.
But Ying said that the petrochemical industry has actually made a lot of improvements in pollution prevention, and the public should not have a stereotypical view of the industry.

Ying cited as examples Singapore and Australia, saying that the two countries have continued to develop their petrochemical industries, and that the industry will help the development of such high-tech industries as semiconductors and information technology.
Meanwhile, local reports indicated that a NT$600 billion (US$18.63 billion) eighth naphtha cracker plan will be located in the state-owned Taiwan Salt Works salt field in Butai, Chiayi County.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar climbed 0.7 cent to 31.843 against the US dollar on the Taiwan market on Tuesday.
The local unit opened at 31.845 and was traded between 31.838 and 31.85. Interbank US dollar reached US$310.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES HIGHER

TEXT.P: After days of consolidation, the Taipei stock market closed 1.1 percent higher on Tuesday, with buying interest focused mainly on the technology and traditional manufacturing sectors.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index gained 86.37 points to close at 8,157.73 points.
A total of 3.28 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$156.47 billion (US$4.91 billion).
Shares in material providers and those in the manufacturing sector, including paper, textiles and cement, were favored by investors, and all turned in gains ranging from 4.8 percent to 0.9 percent.

Paper-making issues enjoyed the largest gains among the eight major stock categories, posting a 4.8-percent climb, while plastic and chemical shares and construction stocks reported the only losses, both falling 0.1 percent.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 295 to 171, with 56 stocks unchanged.
The over-the-counter market posted a 3.25-point rise, ending the day at 181.62 points on a turnover of NT$8.8 billion.
Meanwhile, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains, except for futures for next June, for which no contract transactions were registered.

TAIEX Index Futures for September rose 58 points to close at 8,248 points, with 2,852 contract transactions; those for October gained 98 points to finish at 8,285 points, with 82 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December climbed 117 points to end at 8,310 points, with 9 contract transactions; those for next March hiked 142 points to close at 8,320 points, with 4 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 8,190 points for September, 8,187 points for October, 8,193 points for December, 8,186 points for next March and 8,339 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported gains.
September TE futures rose 6 points to 379.5 points, with 687 contract transactions; October TE futures climbed 8.3 points to finish at 381 points, with 4 contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for TE futures for December, next March and next June.
September TF futures rose 5 points to 1,165 points, with 107 contract transactions, while there were no transaction records for other month's futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURING OUTPUT AND BUSINESS TURNOVER ROBUST IN 2ND, 3RD QUARTER

TEXT.P: An estimate of Taiwan's manufacturing output in August shows an increase of 10.24 percent over the same period last year, according to government figures released Tuesday.

The Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) made public its assessment of domestic manufacturing output in August. The month's figure represents a 0.54-percent increase over July, while accumulative manufacturing output from January to August 1999 is expected to come in 7.94 percent higher than the same 1998 period.

Electrical and electronic products, and chemical material products are the top two sectors, scoring respective growth of 22.39 percent and 15.83 percent in August over the same month last year, said the government report.
In addition, the business turnover in June totaled NT$655.2 billion, the highest level seen since January 1998, and 10.38 percent higher than the August 1998 figure, the MOEA statistics showed.
The figures highlight the fact that domestic consumption has been warming up steadily, said MOEA officials.

The accumulative business turnover in the upper half of 1999 totaled NT$3.83 trillion, a year-on-year increase of 7.85 percent. The food and beverages sector ranked at the top by registering an increase of 9.38 percent, while the retail sector scored 8.62-percent growth and the trade sector came in third with a growth rate of 8.15 percent.

The turnover in the wholesale sector in June totaled NT$150.7 billion, an increase of 5.64 percent on year-on-year basis. Meanwhile, turnover in the retail sector rose 13.68 percent to NT$250.6 billion, turnover in the trade sector rose 9.44 percent to NT$234.2 billion and turnover in the food and beverages sector rose 19.42 percent to NT$19.7 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW ARRIVES IN L.A.

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew arrived in Los Angeles on Monday en route to Panama to take part in the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Mireya Moscoso in his capacity as the special envoy of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui.
Siew and his entourage were greeted by Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, and Stephen Chen, the ROC representative to the United States, upon arrival at the airport.
Siew is not scheduled to engage in any interviews or official activities while in Los Angeles.

Siew was accompanied by his wife and several officials, including Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho, Government Information Office Director-General Chen Chien-jen and Vice Foreign Minister Francisco Ou.
Siew and the delegation will leave for Panama on Tuesday. They will stay one week in Panama and are expected to return to Taiwan on Sept. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED NOT TO ABUSE MANDATORY SOCIAL SERVICE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A group of opposition lawmakers on Tuesday urged the government not to abuse a proposed professional social service system for the country's conscripts.

The legislators were responding to a Cabinet proposal to allow only male college graduates to draw lots to decide whether they can embark on selected social services as an alternative way to fulfill their mandatory military service.

According to the Cabinet plan, the period for both mandatory military service and professional social service will be two years, but the opposition lawmakers said the proposed plan seriously violates the principles of fairness and professionalism.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chien Hsi-kun told a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan that a total of 23 European countries have implemented a professional social service system for draftees.
In all those countries, Chien said, the service period for social service is between 30 percent to 100 percent longer than that for mandatory military service.
"If the Cabinet insists on the two-year service period, it should cut the term for military service in line with the principle of fairness," Chien said.

Speaking on the same occasion, New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao said if conscripts for selected social service are determined solely on the basis of a lottery, it would violate professionalism and undermine the value of the social service system.
He added that social service qualification should instead be skills-based, with draftees selected according to the various types of skills required at any given period.
Moreover, Lai said the original purpose of the Cabinet plan to introduce a social service system for conscripts was to encourage qualified draftees to opt to serve in professional social services.
"If the option is determined by lot drawing, the practice would certainly discourage qualified conscripts from making their special services available," Lai warned.
He urged the government to deal with the issue more prudently in order to live up to public expectations of the much-anticipated social service system.
